title: SWEDISH COUPLE WIN '70 MYSTERY EDGAR
description: A husbandandwife writing team from Sweden were recipi ents last night of the Mystery, Writers of America's Edgar for the best mystery novel of 1970. They are Maj Sjowall and Per Wahloo, authors of The Laugh ing Policeman, published by Pantheon. They were among eight writers to be awarded Edgars, small busts of Edgar Allan Poe, at the group's an nual dinner at the Essex House. About 400 persons attended the event.

title: TRIPLEJUMP MARK SET BY M'BRYDE
description: Ken McBryde of Mount Vernon High School shattered the triple jump meet record yesterday as the sixth annual New York Relays opened a twoday stand at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: New Graffiti on the Old IRT
description: In the days of my preadolescence, stations from Dyckman to 66th Streets on the IRT Broadway line offered a showandtell of cheerful obscenity. There, on the billboards, my friends and I found All We Wanted To Know About Sex (and were afraid to ask). Each station had its own characteristic theme: as though it were one room of many in a highly specialized brothel. At 91st Street we could copy down a little black book or two of randy tele phone numbers. Homosexual idiosyn crasies were featured at 103d Street. The interrelationships of an odd mnage  trois (or quatre? or cinq?) appeared serially like some perverse As The World Turns at 145th Street. There were clinical diagrams, often sketched in three colors, at 116th Street and 137th Street. It was a use ful education.

title: TIMOTHY LYNCH, METAL EXPERT, 68
description: Timothy A. Lynch, a widely known metals expert, died yes terday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N. J., at the age of 68. He had suffered a heart attack in his home at Mon mouth Beach earlier in the day.

title: LAMMONS ACCEPTS JETS' PACT FOR '71
description: Only one loose end remains for the New York Jets foot ball team after yesterday's an nouncement that Pete Lam mons, their 6foot3inch, 230 pound tight end, had come to terms with Weeb Ewbank, coach and general manager, on his 1971 contract.

title: Legislators Hear Public's Ideas On NonpublicSchool Aid Here
description: The deputy minority leader of the State Assembly, Albert H. Blumenthal, joined by other Assemblymen and State Sena tors, conducted an allday pub lic hearing yesterday in the State Office Building, at 270 Broadway, on state aid to pa rochial and other private schools.

title: Amerada Hess Earnings Soar by 85.3% in Quarter
description: The Amerada Hess Corpora tion increased earnings in the first quarter by 85.3 per cent to $45,896,891, or $1.29 a share, from $24,771,035, or 70 cents a share, in the 1970 quarter, according to the report issued yesterday.

title: MISSISSIPPI UPHOLDS OLD LAW ON PRIMARY
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 30 The State Election Commission decided yesterday against ap pealing a Federal court suspen sion of the state's new open primary law and declared that this year's elections would be held under the old party pri mary system.

title: C.B.S. AGAIN DENIES DATA TO HOUSE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem refused again today to comply with a House Commerce subcommittee subpoena that it turn over all the material it collected for its program The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: U.S. Sets Up Drive On Wild Marijuana In 10 Farm Areas
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Agriculture Department officially announced today that a pilot program for eradicating wildgrowing marijuana would be started this summer on farm land in 10 states.

title: FUND BACKS MOVE SEEKING G.M. DATA
description: The College Retirement Equi ties Fund announced yesterday that its trustees had voted 8 to 7 to support a proposal by the Project on Corporate Responsi bility to compel the General Motors Corporation to make additional disclosures on its progress in minority hiring, air pollution control and auto safety.

title: MRS. PERRY O. HALL
description: JERSEY CITY, April 30 Mrs. Elizabeth Barbour Hall, wife of Dr. Perry O. Hall, an obstetrician, died today at her home, 88 Fairview Avenue, at the age of 75.

title: Stokes Is Planning A Mississippi Trip To Aid Evers Race
description: Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleveland said last night that he would go to Mississippi to help Charles Evers in his cam paign for Governor.

title: MidHudson Folk Festival Will Be Celebrated May 9
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., April 30  The music of hard times will be the theme of the third annual MidHudson Folk Festi val to be held at Orange County Community College on Sunday, May 9.

title: DERBY FANS FAVOR UNCONSCIOUS (31) IN EARLY BETTING
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 With 20 colts ready to go, the Kentucky Derby will have its 97th running on the Churchill Downs track tomorrow.

title: Russians Said to Have Let 1,300 Jews Leave in April
description: MOSCOW, April 30Soviet authorities have permitted more than 1,300 Jews to emigrate to Israel this month, reliable Western diplomatic sources said today. This is believed to be the largest number of Jews allowed to depart in one month since Israel was founded in 1948.

title: Austrian Castle Is a Stop On SovietIsrael Route
description: VIENNA, April 30Schiinau Castle, 20 miles south of Vien na, once housed a branch of the Hapsburg family. Privacy was insured by vast wooded grounds, and even today the castle is hidden from the near est roads.

title: PRESIDENT GREETS COMBAT MARINES
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., April 30President Nixon wel comed home from Vietnam to clay the vanguard of the First Marine Division with a pledge to end the war in a way worthy of your service.

title: Coast Rightist on Probation
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30 (Reuters)Robert Sherman, a 51yearold rightist extremist accused of plotting to assas sinate the Superior Court judge who ordered an end to racial segregation in Los Angeles schools, was placed on proba tion today for five years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. SAMUEL J. BARON
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 30 Mrs. Lena Tannenbaum Baron, the mother of Jerry Wurf, pres ident of the American Federa tion of State, County and Mu nicipal Employes, died here last night after a long illness. She was a native of Austria and had lived in Brooklyn before moving here.

title: MITCHELL ASSAILS VERACITY OF MEDIA
description: DALLAS, April 30 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mit chell, joining the Nixon Ad ministration's attack on the news media, criticized some of the press today for what he termed shocking contempt for truth and cheap surrender to instinct.

title: 2 COURTS UPHOLD AMTRAK SYSTEM; SERVICE IS BEGUN
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, May 1The National Railroad Passenger Corporation, known as Amtrak, officially went into business at 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Sculptors Turn Their Hand to Jewelry
description: Shop Talk

title: VARIED WORKS GIVEN BY AMERICAN BALLET
description: Dipping into repertory Thurs day evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company drew out three varied ballets; one of which, At Midnight, pre dated the formation of the com pany by a year. At Midnight was the second and last work Mr. Feld choreographed for American Ballet Theater before minting his own company, and is the precursor of a number of expressionist ballets he has done since then.

title: Mothers' Day Protest Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)The National Organiza tion for Women announced to day a Mothers' Day demonstra tion at the White House to demand universally available child care throughout the country. The group said mem bers, their husbands and chil dren will march in front of the White House on the after noon of May 9.

title: Vietnam Medal of Honor Winner Killed in Detroit Store Holdup
description: DETROIT, April 30 (AP)  A Michigan man who won the Medal of Honor for bravery in Vietnam was shot and killed today by a store owner who said the soldier had tried to rob him.

title: Taylor and Neuwirth Join Eric Andersen For Songs at Cafe
description: Eric Andersen, a folk singer with a lot of friends, was joined by a few of them during his engagement this week at the Gaslight, 1.52 Bleecker Street.

title: Chinese Barefoot Doctor a Farmer, Too
description: PEKING, April 30Miss Chang Yujung, a barefoot doctor on a collective farm in the China  Korea Friendship Commune on the outskirts of Peking, does not wait for the sick to come to her but seeks them out and treats them in their homes.

title: Problems Are Depicted
description: DALLAS, April 30  They don't wine and dine em like they used to, drawled a Ling TemcoVought Inc., shareholder at the company's annual stock holders meeting here today. No, and it's just as well? snapped another.

title: GILES, PEARCE GAIN NORTHSOUTH FINAL
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 30 (AP)Vinny Giles and Eddie Pearce scored 2andI victories today to gain th final of the North and South amateur golf tournament tomorrow.

title: Possibility of Outvoting of Egypt In New Federation Is Eliminated
description: CAIRO, April 30  Any possibility that Syria and Libya could outvote Egypt in their planned federation has been eliminated. A crucial amend ment in the statutes requires unanimity of the three presi ents for federal executive de cisions and the selection of a federal president.

title: SQUIBBLANVIN TIE VOTED BY HOLDERS
description: Squibb BeechNut, Inc., the result of a 1968 merger be tween a pharmaceutical house and a candychewing gum com pany, yesterday added a major cosmetics producer to its fold.

title: Amex Adopts Rule For Flexible Fees By Vote of 269266
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its membership had adopted rules changes to imple ment negotiated sales com missions on certain large trans actions by only three votes, 269266.

title: Municipal Stations Win Delay On Processing of 55 Dismissals
description: The city's radio and television station received an uncertain reprieve yesterday afternoon as the city's Department of Per sonnel reported that it could not complete the processing of the 55 dismissals originally scheduled for last night.

title: INTERFAITH TO SHOW ART BY FIVE YOUTHS
description: Monday might will be a big one in the lives of five teen age boys who attend painting classes Tuesday nights at Inter faith Neighbors, the youth and family counseling organization at 331 East 70th Street.

title: Antiques: Pictures of Idealized Style Mark Flea Market Steins
description: Steins ar one of the items reserved for the big spenders at the Flea Market that op erates Sundays at Avenue of the Americas and 25th St.

title: Missing U.P.I. Correspondent Freed by Enemy in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, May 1 (UPI)Catherine M. Webb, United Press Inter national bureau manager in Pnompenh, who has been miss ing since April 7, was freed today by her captors.

title: German Magazine Gets Awards as It Is Closed
description: BONN, April 30This week, at the same time the illus trated Twen magazine won three graphic awards at the annual art directors club competition in New York, its West German publishers or dered the monthly to close.

title: 25 News Teleprinter Lines Are Cut in A.P. Building
description: At least 25 news teleprinter circuits and numerous tele phone lines were disabled yes terday when wires were cut in a locked communications room of The Associated Press Building at 50 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: G.I. Patrol Attacked In the Ashau V alley; 5 Killed and 10 Hurt
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 1 (AP)North Viet namese troops ambushed reconnaissance patrol of Amer ican paratroopers in Ashau Valley, killing five and wound ing 10, the United States com mand reported today.

title: PROXMIRE WEIGHS NOMINATION RACE
description: BOSTON, April 30 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire said today that he was considering campaigning for the Democrat ic Presidential nomination and would make two trips to New Hampshire in May to appraise his chances in its Presidential primary, the country's first.

title: Donald M. Kammert, 62, Dies; Allegheny Power System Head
description: Donald M. Kammert, presi dent of Allegheny Power Sys tem, Inc., died Thursday at his home in Fairmont, W. Va., after a short illness. He was 62 years old and also lived at 420 East 51st Street.

title: India Gets Japan Credit
description: TOKYO, April 30Japan ex tended to India today a credit equivalent to $15.4million for use in connection with a deep sea oilexploration project, the Foreign Ministry said. It will be used to finance purchases of oildrilling platforms and supply boats from Japan.

title: NEW ISSUES POST STRONG ADVANCE
description: The newissue market, where shares of companies that have never previously had public owners are traded, made a strong advance in active trad ing this week.

title: Order in the Court
description: The court reform rules announced this week by Chief Judge Stanley Fuld of the State Court of Appeals are drastic, but by no means too drastic for the deteriorating condition they are meant to correct. They provide that if, through no fault of a defendant, the state fails to try him within six months of his arrest, it must give him his freedom; even after three months it must release him on parole or reasonable bail, except in cases of homicide.

title: Air Force Halts All F111's After Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Air Force temporarily grounded today its 257 opera tional F111 aircraft after it had investigated the 18th crash involving the supersonic, swing wing jet.

title: TIMES AND COWLES COMPLETE ACCORD
description: Merger News

title: LAWYER ASSAILS ATTACK ON C.P.A.'S
description: A lawyer for a major ac counting firm charged yester day that securities law forces unreasonable risks of liability on the profession and that as a result accountants are becom ing gun shy in conducting their business.

title: Lower Car Output Scheduled
description: DETROIT, April 30 (AP) The nation's auto makers planned to produce fewer cars this week than last week, but the output will still be sub stantially higher than during the yearearlier week, accord ing to Automotive News.

title: In South Korea, Urban Affluence and Rural Poverty
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 29  Kwan Su Tae Is a skilled worker in a motorcycle factory outside Seoul and Kim Sang Ho is a rice farmer in an isola ted mountain village in a re mote corner of southwestern Korea. The lives of both men have changed in the last ten years during South Korea's re markable economic growth.

title: Nominee for Top Amtrak Post Roger Lewis
description: Man in the News

title: Permanent Mall Planned On Madison by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday to turn part of Madison Avenue into a permanent pedestrian mall with a widened street, large trees, many benches and special lanes for small buses and trucks.

title: NORMAN MAILER VS. WOMEN'S LIB
description: For a while last night it seemed like Norman Mailer against the worldin A Di alogue on Women's Liberation at Town Hall.

title: PRICES RECEIVED BY FARMERS DROP
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)Prices received by farm ers for raw products dropped one per cent in April, the first downward trend since last De cember, the Agriculture De partment announced today.

title: Transcript Errors Cited in Plea To Dismiss a Police Graft Trial
description: The lawyer for a police lieu tenant who told a grand jury that he had received $200 a month to protect gamblers asked yesterday that Police De partment charges against him be dismissed on the ground that the transcript of the officer's grand jury testimony was in accurate.

title: Move to Block Perot's Bid For F. I. duPont Is Dropped
description: HARTFORD, April 30 (UPI) A Connecticut couple has with drawn a request for an injunc tion to block the takeover of A brokerage firm by H. Ross Perot, the Texas financier.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended April 27, 1971:

title: Silent Beauty Beats Grafitti In $64,750 Kentucky Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 (AP)Silent Beauty turned the tables on Grafitti today and won the $64,750 Kentucky Oaks after a seesaw stretch bathe at Churchill Downs.

title: Barber and Green, at 137, Gain Golf Lead by Stroke
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 30 Miller Barber and Hubert Green, a rookie, set the 36hole pace at 137 today in the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open as a snake hunt and the with drawal of Lee Trevino caused some dismay.

title: Soviet Said to Bar Help In Building Truck Plant
description: MOSCOW April 30West European businessmen have reported that the Soviet Union has decided to con struct, without foreign help, a huge truckmanufacturing complex. Last year the Ford Motor Company rejected a role in building the plant.

title: Alaska Oil Well Tested
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany announced yesterday that its West Sak River State No. 1 well on the North Slope of Alaska flowed 1,340 barrels of 21degree gravity oil from a test made with a threequarter inch opening. The well is 25 miles west of the Prudhoe Bay State No. 1 discovery well.

title: Newburgh Area Leaders Drop Political Feuds to Oppose Jetport
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., April 30 When Governor Rockefeller announced last Sunday that he would ask the Legislature for $30million to begin expanding the former Stewart Air Force Base into the fourth major jet port for the New York City metropolitan area, those favor able to the idea thought that no politician or civic leader would dare resist it.

title: JUDGE DELAYS CUT OF 2,800 CITY JOBS
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday temporarily halted Mayor Lindsay's pro gram to eliminate 2,800 full time and parttime jobs.

title: The Great Quark Hunt
description: Man's curiosity about the ultimate nature of matter goes back many millennia. About 2,500 years ago the Greek philosopher Democritus made the first great advance with his speculation about the atomic nature of all substances, but in this century even his profound insight has proved to be a gross oversimplification.

title: Msgr. Joseph Cleary, Aide In Hartford Church Tribunal
description: GEORGETOWN, Conn., April 30Msgr. Joseph Francis Cleary, former secretary of the tribunal of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Hartford, died yes terday in the rectory of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here where he had been pastor. He was 61 years old. Monsignor Cleary was ordained in Paris on June 29, 1933, after receiving his theololagic train ing at the Seminary of St. Sul pice in Eissy, France. He re ceived his doctorate in canon law in 1936 from Catholic Uni versity in Washington.

title: Western Electric Improves Pact Offer
description: The Western Electric Com pany made a second and im proved wage and benefit pro posal yesterday to two unions representing 29,000 installers and 25,500 manufacturing em ployes.

title: Pickets in Albany Protest Bank's Dealings With Defense Contractors
description: ALBANY, April 30 (AP) At least two persons were injured and two arrested to day in a demonstration to protest a bank's alleged in volvement with Federal de fense contractors.

title: Bunkers Seized Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (Reuters)American troops uncovered a strongly fortified bunker complex yes terday less than half a mile from a heavily traveled road northwest of here and fought an eighthour battle to cap ture it, the United States com mand reported today.

title: Excerpts From Letters in Berrigan Case
description: Following are excerpts from letters contained in new Gov ernment indictments against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and others. According to the indictment, the first letter is from Sister Elizabeth Mc Mister to Father Berrigan, in prison in Lewisburg, Pa., and was sent about Aug. 20, 1970. The second letter was al legedly transmitted from Father Berrigan to an address in New York on Aug. 22, 1970.

title: Making a Cheesecake May Not Be an Exact Science, but It Is a Fine Art
description: There's seldom agreement on it, even among those who love it. Cheesecake fanciers are a breed unto themselves.

title: 3 HURT IN MELEE OUTSIDE THE TIMES
description: Three men were injured yes terday in a melee that broke out in front of the New York Times Building at 229 West 43d Street when members of a group picketing the newspaper set fire to a truck they had driven to the scene.

title: Roundup: Royals Revolt And Overthrow Orioles
description: Fred Patek, the smallest player in the major leagues, wielded a mighty big bat in making Kansas City Royals history last night.

title: MINGUS STARRING AT THE VANGUARD
description: Charlie Mingus is closing out that period of his career in which he has been known ex clusively as a jazz musician. Alfred A. Knopf will pour a literary cocktail party Monday to introduce his autobiographi cal book, Beneath the Under dog, and from then on, for better or for worse, he will be author and musician.

title: $40.5Million Deal
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Justice Department an nounced today that it would not object to the sale of the Okonite Company by Ling TemcoVought, Inc., to Omega Alpha, Inc., providing that LTV and OmegaAlpha remain completely unaffiliated with each other.

title: Elmo Roper, Pollster, Is Dead; Predicted '36 Roosevelt Victory
description: WEST REDDING, Conn., April 30Elmo Roper, the pub lic opinion analyst who was among the first to develop modern political polls, died to day in Norwalk Hospital at the age of 70.

title: Wyman for WorkOriented Welfare
description: ALBANY, April 30The State Social Services Commissioner, George K. Wyman, today broke his silence on recent state wel fare restrictions, defending them and declaring that wel fare will be workoriented in the future.

title: Wilson Says President Will Back Lockheed Aid
description: President Nixon has decided to ask Congress to authorize a Government guarantee of loans to the financially strapped Lock heed Aircraft Corporation, ac cording to Harold Wilson, for mer British Prime Minister.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profiles of today's newsmakers in a loose leaf edition. Write: The New York Times, Library Services, Box FP480, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10035.

title: New Jersey G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The Defense Depart ment announced today that Walter E. Demsey Jr., of Glen dora, N.J., an Army Specialist 4, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Two Teachers Start Class to Help Veterans Find Jobs
description: In the dusty room over looking Rivington Street, the class of Vietnam veterans bent over their work. You wouldn't believe the bitter ness that comes out here, the teacher said. It's as if they suddenly realized they left one war and now they're in the middle of another one.

title: THREE CITIES ADDED TO LIST OF JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Labor Department added three major cities today to its list of substantial unemploy ment areas. In each, 6 per cent or more of the work force is unemployed.

title: 4 TRADE STUDIES SET BY U.S. TARIFF BODY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Tariff Commission an nounced today four major studies relating to the nation's trade, all requested by the Sen ate Finance Committee. The studies, with no deadline for completion, include the fol lowing:

title: Dessoff Choirs Recalls 3 Poles' Work
description: Although an amateur group, the Dessoff Choirs have given voice to an enormous amount of unknown music since their inception in 1924. Most of it was out of the distant past, and some of the works are now among the frequently heard masterpieces of choral literature.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Series E Bonds On Sale for 30 Years
description: The United States Series E Savings Bond is 30 years old today. Born as a war baby, it has grown into an impor tant instrument for channel ing wages into savings. On May 1, 1941 the late Treas ury Secretary Henry Morgen thau Jr. sold the first Defense Bond to President Franklin D. Bonds, then Savings Bonds have been sold to nearly every family in the United States. Since 1945, purchases have averaged $5billion year.

title: Saigon Evicts a Critic
description: Saigon's eviction order to Don Luce, 36yearold Amer ican social worker turned correspondent, is a blow at the right of the American people to know the truth about a conflict in which their Government is still expending lives and resources at a prodigious rate.

title: Engelhard Raising Prices Of Palladium $1 an Ounce
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemical Corporation said yes terday that it would increase prices for palladium by $1 troy ounce to a new selling range of $37 to $39 per troy ounce, beginning Monday.

title: GRAND JURY HEARS GIRL IN BOMB CASE
description: SEATTLE, April 30Leslie Bacon, arrested in Washington, D.C., as a material witness in an investigation of the March bombing of the Capitol, testi fied before a grand jury today. Her lawyers said she had not been asked about the Capitol bombing.

title: Paris Censors Release a Movie By Arrabal on War in Spain
description: PARIS, April 29 Vive La Muerte (Long Live Death), the first film written and di rected by the controversial Spanishborn dramatist, Fernan do Arrabal, has received clear ance to open in Paris. It had been detained by the censors.

title: Sonny White, Jazz Pianist, Headed Own Band in '30's
description: Sonny White, a jazz pianist, died on Wednesday of a liver ailment in the Veterans Ad ministration Hospital, First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 53 years old and lived at 15 East 151st Street in the Bronx.

title: A Paddle Wheel Picks Up Oil Slicks Along Coastlines
description: Patents of the Week

title: $50,000 in Textiles Hijacked
description: Three men wearing ski masks hijacked a truck laden with bolts of cloth valued at $50,000 yesterday after ordering the driver and his helper from the vehicle. The police reported that the driver, Woodrow Sut tles of Spartanburg, and his helper, Grover Childress, of Piedmont, both South Carolina, were accosted by the gunmen at 4:20 A.M. on 25th Street be tween 10th and 11th Avenues. One gunman drove the truck away after the truckmen were ordered into a sedan and driven to Plainview, L. I. They were released unharmed

title: $1Million Derby Total in Sight As City Goes on Betting Spree
description: New Yorkers went on a wild Kentucky Derby betting spree here yesterday that sent the offtrack handle on today's fa mous horse race zooming to ward the $1million mark.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 30One of the most trying dilemmas for a country with moral notions in its foreign policy is what to do about awkward friends. People generally opposed to American intervention abroad will suddenly de mand that the State Department do something when a friendly government behaves unjustly. But do what? In terms of practicalities as well as politi cal wisdom the answer is seldom clear.

title: For Generations, Railroads Gauged the Nation's Growth
description: The American has a per fect passion for railroads.Michel Chevalier, a French economist, after witnessing the construction of new rail roads in America, 1835.

title: Rogers Stresses U.S. Aim Of Overcall Mideast Pact
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 30 Secretary of State William P. Rogers stressed today that the United States sought a con tractually binding and lasting settlement of the Middle East crisis, in addition to its current efforts to promote an interim agreement between Israel and Egypt to reopen, the Suez Canal.

title: Milton A. Pearl, a Counsel For House Interior Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) Milton A. Pearl, a special counsel for the House Interior Committee, died today of a heart attack at the age of 57.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES POSTS DROP IN NET
description: Northeast Utilities reported yesterday a 15.5 per cent de cline in net income for the first quarter despite a rise of 15.8 per cent in operating revenues. The company's report placed operating revenues at $108, 664.831 against $93,809,962. However, net income slipped to $12,285,112, or 32 cents a share, from $14,534,276, or 41 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, 1970. Operating subsidiaries in Con necticut and Massachusetts have filed for rate relief.

title: U.S. Command in Vietnam Bars Battle Hymn of Calley From Radio Network, Citing Pending Appeal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30  The American Armed Forces Radio Network in Vietnam, where the hits just keep on coming, has been told to stop playing The Bat tle Hymn of Lieutenant Calley.

title: Bridge Pledged, but Sicilians Wonder
description: The Talk of Messina

title: Plan for Obelisk Here Opposed
description: A 125foothigh stainless steel obelisk to rise from a blocklong bed of flowers on the center mall of Park Ave nue between 68th and 69th Streets will be donated to the city by George T. Delacorte if the Art Commission approves the proposal when it meets this month.

title: Berkeley Election Results Unchanged by Absentees
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 30 Warren Widener retained his slim hold on the post of Mayor tonight after the results from 100 absentee ballots were added to tabulations in the election here April 6.

title: KLINE OF YANKEES TOPS BREWERS, 51, WITH FOURHITTER
description: Using a new bat, but the same old sinking fastball, Steve Kline sparked the Yankees to one of their easiest victories of the season last night, a 51 de cision over the Milwaukee Brewers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Mets Defeat Astros, 4 to 3, In 12th for Fifth in a Row
description: HOUSTON, April 30The New York Mets, who had won only two games under a roof in two years, won one tonight on the first try. But they had to go 12 innings before subduing the Houston Astros, 43, as they opened a weekend series in the Astrodome.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS VOLUME EASES
description: The stock market proved anew yesterday that what goes up must come downat least for a while.

title: Kahane Jury Deadlocked; New Trial Set for June 28
description: The second trial of Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of the Jew ish Defense League, and two of his followers on 1969 charges stemming from an in cident at the Soviet press agency here ended yesterday in a hung jury. The first trial had also ended in a hung jury.

title: Albany Layoffs Delayed
description: ALBANY, April 30 (AP)An appellate judge delayed today the further layoff of state work ers for at least a few more days.

title: GOLD PRICE IN LONDON HITS 18MONTH HIGH
description: LONDON, April 30 (UPI) Gold prices increased today at a new high and the United States dollar sagged further amid continued speculation in European financial centers that the United States may be forced to raise the price of gold.

title: Interior Nomination Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Senate Interior commit tee approved today the nomina tion of W. T. Pecora, a career government scientist, to be Under Secretary of Interior.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: The revenuesharing debate is set in the wrong frame of reference. The policy change should focus on broad ening the availability to all levels of governmentnational, state and local of contemporary abundantly yield ing tax sources.

title: Derby Week Isn't What It Used to BeThe Party Has Moved to Outskirts
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 The Kentucky Derby has been atomized, blasted to smithereens. Trying to feel its mood on the streets of Louisville is almost as hard as picking a winner from 20 horses.

title: Bridge: Bidding a Weak NoTrump Can Be Formidable Weapon
description: The weak notrump can be a formidable bidding weapon, although it is out of fashion among the leading players of this country. One advantage is that the opponents can have bidding troubles with good hands because they have to start their operations at the level of two.

title: EUGEN BERDE
description: Eugen Berde, director of quality control for Russ Togs, Inc., died Thursday in Albert Einstein Hospital, after an ill ness of two months. He was 57 years old and lived at 3013 Eastchester Road, the Bronx.

title: American National's Slate Wins
description: GALVESTON, Tex., April 30 (AP)In a stockholders meeting filled with anger and accusations, shareholders of the American National Insur ance Company elected today a board nominated by its present management. Mi nority stockholders an nounced plans to file suit testing the legality of the meeting.

title: To a Returning Visitor, China Is Faultlessly Clean
description: CANTON, China, April 27 The most visible change in China since the Communist takeover in 1949 is cleanliness. The People's Republic of China is faultlessly clean. Dirt is a dirty word.

title: Mrs. Mary Hopkins Is Wed on L. I
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., April 30  Mrs. Mary Wanamaker Hopkins, a greatgrand daughter of John Wanamak er, the Philadelphia merch ant, was married here today to H. Robertson Fenwick of Glyndon, Md. The Rev. John Felmeth performed the Pres byterian ceremony at the home of Rodman Wanamak er, father of the bride, in the presence of members of the immediate families.

title: Wilson Is in Texas to See Johnson After Nixon Visit
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 30 (AP) Britain's former Prime Mini ster, Harold Wilson, arrived in Texas today for a weekend of rest and to renew an old friend ship with former President and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: State's New Copter Draws Ire of Staff Hit by Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY, April 29  The acquisition of a new $700,000 conservation helicopter at the same time as the dismissal of 8,400 state workers is proving to be an embarrassment to Henry L. Diamond, the state's Com missioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: Swiss Bank Policy Defended by Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 A known mafia member or other criminal figure would have a hard time opening a bank account in Switzerland, numbered or otherwise, a lead ing Swiss banker said today.

title: Buffalo Mayor Urges Cuts
description: BUFFALO, April 30 (UPI)  Mayor Frank A. Sedita today proposed dismissing 208 city workers and said more layoffs would be necessary unless the State Legislature restored full revenue sharing with cities. Presenting a record $184.7mil lion budget to the Common Council, the Mayor, a Demo crat, also called for a property tax increase of $6.98 on each $1,000 of assessed valuation, higher water rates and rises in all city fees.

title: Music: All Stravinsky
description: Originally the New York Philharmonic program was to have contained music by Mo zart, Ives and Stravinsky. But Stravinsky died early last month, and Pierre Boulez switched music on this week's series, starting Thursday night, to make it an allStra vinsky program.

title: Ousted Curator Assails Guggenheim
description: Edward Fry, dismissed as as sociate curator of the Guggen heim Museum after a policy dispute over its cancellation of a show by the artist Hans Haacke, has issued a statement questioning the museum's atti tudes toward contemporary art and thought.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill on Bar Hours Signed
description: HARTFORD, April 30 (UPI) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill signed a bill today permitting bars to stay open until 11 P.M. on Sun days and said he would support a proposal extending drinking hours to 2 A.M. on Fridays and Saturdays. Under the bill, ef fective immediately, bar own ers can continue to close at 9 P.M. if they wish.

title: WHEAT PRICES OFF IN HEAVY SELLING
description: With the first new crop of wheat of the season moving into markets from a farm in Texas, futures of such com modities were heavily sold, sending prices down, on the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday.

title: Providence Editor Named
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 30 (AP)Michael J. Ogden, for 11 years executive editor of The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, has been named editor of the two newspapers, John C. A. Watkins, president and pub lisher, announced yesterday.

title: Liquori, Tuning Up for Ryun, Runs His First 5,000 Meters and Sets Record
description: QUANTICO, Va., April 30 In a surprising appearance de signed to strengthen him for his May 16 mile showdown against Jim Ryun, Marty Liquori won the 5,000meter run today at the 15th annual Quantico Re lays.

title: What Good Came of It at Last?
description: AHMADABAD, India  The English poet Robert Southey (17741843) wrote an admirable poem, After Blenheim. It could have been written about Indo china. The battle of Blenheim was fought in Bavaria in August, 1713, when the English and their allies, under the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene of Savoy, gave a crushing de feat to the French and their allies.

title: Submarine Tests Poseidon
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 30 (AP)The nuclear sub marine Tecumseh launched a multiplewarhead Poseidon mis sile on a 2,500mile test flight down the Atlantic tracking range tonight.

title: A BANKER CHARGED WITH EMBEZZLING
description: CHICAGO, April 30 (UPI) Four persons, including a for mer bank vice president, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of em bezzling nearly $7million from the Cosmopolitan National Bank of Chicago.

title: H.R.A. Aide Resigns Here
description: John Dean, first deputy ad ministrator of the Human Re sources Administration, has re signed to join the staff of the Congressional Black Caucus in Washington, Administrator Jule M. Sugarman announced yes terday. The caucus, which is composed of the 13 black mem bers of Congress, was formed late in 1970.

title: Thompson Lang, Publisher Of The Albuquerque Journal
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 30 (UPI)  C. Thompson Lang, president of the Albuquerque Publishing Company and pub lisher of The Albuquerque Jour nal, died apparently of a heart attack last night at his home. He was 59 years old.

title: For 2 Cities: New Political Eras
description: CLEVELAND, April 25Two elderly men in their early 40's, in almost identical steps taken just days apart, have pushed two major industrial cities into new eras of urban politics.

title: StreetClosing Series Will Begin Tomorrow
description: A series of afternoon en tertainments, Five Street Closings in May, will start tomorrow in Harlem and con tinue on succeeding Sundays in BedfordStuyvesant, Coney Island, Brighton Beach, the Bronx and Queens.

title: Buchs Sweep Bullets, Tale Crown
description: BALTIMORE, April 30  Led by Oscar Robertson, the one extra needed ingredient to make the presence of Lew Al cindor fully productive, the Mil waukee Bucks won the National Basketball Association cham pionship tonight. They com pleted a fourgame sweep of a final round only the second one in the 25year history of the league.

title: Container Slate Wins
description: The management of the Uni versal Container Corporation has retained control of the company, although a dissident group succeeded in winning three seats on the ninemember Board.

title: YUGOSLAVS END PARLEY ON CRISIS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 30Top Yugoslav Communists ended a threeday, closeddoor meeting today that observers had believed would be a show down on differences between the country's rival nationalities.

title: ALBERT L. COPELAND
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 30  Albert L. Copeland, a minister of the Western Yearly Meeting of Friends (Quakers) for 62 years until his retirement 10 years ago, died Sunday in Mount Vernon Hos pital. His age was 96.

title: Police Monthly to Close
description: Spring3100, a Police De partment monthly house organ since 1930, will cease publica tion after its May issue, Deputy Police Commissioner Wilfred N. Horne announced yesterday.

title: MRS. OLIVER FREUD
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 30 (AP)  Mrs. Henry Fuchs Freud, widow of Oliver Freud who was the son of Sig mund Ferud, died yesterday at a nursing home at the age of 79.

title: S.E.C. ORDER BARS ECOLOGY CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  The Securities and Exchange Commission obtained a court order today forbidding the Eco logical Science Corporation from misrepresenting its tech nological achievements and business prospects in the file of pollution control.

title: AIR QUALITY RULES FOR 6 POLLUTANTS GIVEN FOR NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 William D. Ruckelshaus, admin istrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced today what he called tough national air quality standards for six principal pollutants.Mr. Ruckelshaus conceded that the standards could be achieved only by drastic al terations in industrial practices and in the commuting habits of millions of persons living close to large urban centers.The Clean Air Act of 1970 stipulated that the E.P.A. ad ministrator must set standards for common pollutants. Under the law, the states have until Jan. 1, 1972, to submit plans for achieving the standards.

title: New Berrigan Indictments; Letters on Plot Released
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 30 A Federal grand jury here today brought new indictments against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five other per sons on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser.

title: SalvadorHonduras Clashes Are Reported by the O.A.S.
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 30 (AP)Military observ ers of the Organization of American States reported today there had been three border clashes during the last week between Salvadorean and Hon duran soldiers.

title: Karen Moras Sets 4:22.6 Swim Mark For 400 FreeStyle
description: LONDON, April 30 (AP) Karen Moras of Australia bet tered the world record tonight for the women's 400meter free style swim with a time of 4 minutes 22.6 seconds in a 14 nation meet at the Crystal Palace.

title: 11 Seized in 2 Brooklyn Raids Along With $300,000 in Heroin
description: More than $300.000 worth of heroin that the police said was being prepared for sale in $5 bags this weekend to welfare recipients was seized yesterday in two Brooklyn raids.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet ABM Plan Confirmed at Vienna
description: VIENNA, April 30  Soviet and American negotiators at the arms limitation talks here met for another twohour ses sion today.

title: IMPASSE REMAINS ON INSPECTOR PACT
description: Talks between the Allied Building Inspectors Union and the city broke off last night with each side blaming the other for walking out of the negotiations.

title: Hungry Ones to Bow
description: The Hungry Ones, a pro gram of three oneacters by Paul Rawlings, will open at the 13th Street Theater, 50 West 13th Street on May 4. Janis Flynn, Ray Durand and William Leet will appear in the plays. Dale Shields is directing.

title: JAZZ TRUMPETER, 8, REPEATS A TRIUMPH
description: Eightyearold Enrico Tom asso, whose trumpet playing and singing on Louis Arm strong's theme When It's Sleepy Time Down South startled audiences at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Fes tval last weekend, repeated that triumph yesterday afternoon at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street.

title: Sirik Matak Turns Down the Premiership of Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 30Lieut, Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak declined today to form a Government, deepening Cambodia's political crisis.

title: Nationalists Reject U.S. Suggestions on Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 30 Nationalist China expressed serious concern and very strong objection today to a State Department suggestion this week on the sovereignty of Taiwan.

title: Tyrant, Shut Eye Head 14 Today In Carter Handicap at Aqueduct
description: Kevin Brennan, a half owner of KeyHill Stable's Shut Eye, the second choice on the over night line for today's $50,000 added Carter Handicap, was talking with Jack Bradley, the 5yearold gelding's trainer, in the horsemen's room at Aque duct yesterday.

title: George Rickey's Kinetic Constructions Are Shown
description: The rational aspect of George Rickey's kinetic con structions has always been emphasized in assessments of his work. It is true that Mr. Rickey's preoccupation with sculptural movement through time and space has been con ceived, studied and organized with the laboratory precision of an exacting scientist. His use of geometric shapes and his sense of equation in the balance of forces as well as the austerity of his material, stainless steel, and the total suppression of any detail not related to the behavior of movement have certainly en hanced the aura of scientific analysis and rationale in his work.

title: DRUG CURB FEARS ALLAYED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. Charles C. Edwards, assured Congress and the drug industry today that there would be no massive withdrawal of medicinal drugs from the mar ket.

title: Ailing Traynor Satisfactory
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30 (UPI) Pie Traynor, former third baseman of the Pitsburgh Pi rates, was reported in satisfac tory condition today at Alle gheny General Hospital, where the 71yearold Hall of Famer was admitted last Monday for treatment of an undisclosed ailment.

title: Donizetti's Maria Stuarda Slated by City Opera for '72
description: The New York City Opera will present next year what is assumed to be the first stage production in this country of Donizetti's Maria Stuarda. The production is planned for the company's 1972 spring sea son at the New York State The ater. The title role will be sung by Beverly Sills.

title: Art: Huge Andy Warhol Retrospective at Whitney
description: Presuming that the place survived last night's private initiation ceremonies, the Whitney Museum opens its Andy Warhol retrospective to the public today and is ex pecting the biggest crowds since the retrospective of an other Andy  Wyeth  who holds the record. That the naughty boy of the 1960's and stanch purveyor of the virtues of 1776 should be the two biggest box office draws in American art gives one pause to think and could, in truth, reduce the mind to jelly if thought about long enough. Better let it ride.

title: Executive Changes
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced yesterday in St. Louis the election of Sanford N. McDonnell as president. James S. McDonnell, founder of the aerospace company, continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Sanford Mc Donnell, 48 years old, has been serving as the corporation's executive vice president since March of this year and as chairman of the McDonnell Aircraft Company Division, a posttion he will con tinue to hold. He was elected president of the Mc Donnell Aircraft Company in 1966 and a director of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in 1967.

title: Mass Production of Male Flies Raises Hopes for Eradication
description: The discovery of a way to mass produce only male house flies has raised hopes that such pests can be eradicated without sprays or fly swatters.

title: 330 PROTESTERS HELD IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The police arrested today 330 members of a civil rights and antiwar group conducting a weeklong peoples' lobby in the capital.

title: Amex List Turns in Worst Performance of Week; Volume Off
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in its worst per formance of the week yester day as declines outnumbered advances by more than a two toone ratio in slower trading.

title: SUPPORT LACKING FOR PENSION BILL
description: ALBANY, April 30Legisla tive leaders indicated today that a bill to expand pension benefits for state legislators, the Lieutenant Governor, the Controller, the Attorney Gen eral, judges and many court employes would not be acted upon during this session of the Legislature.

title: DR. HARRY BONE, 72 WAS ANALYST HERE
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., April 30 Dr. Harry Bone, training and supervising psychoanalyst at the William Alanson White In stitute of Psychiatry, Psycho analysis and Psychology, New York, died yesterday of cancer. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Lawyers Stage Rally to Protest War
description: Hundreds of lawyers took to the streets here yesterday in an uncharacteristic protest against the war in Vietnam.

title: State Urban Agency Considering Building a Buffalo Stadium
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is studying the feasibility of build ing an 80,000seat stadium in a Buffalo suburb as a home for the National Football League's Buffalo Bills.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Simeon L. Eppel, an Official With Bell Laboratories, 64
description: Simeon L. Eppel, head of the field quality department at Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, N. J., since 1961, died Wednesday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N. J. He was 64 years old and lived in Little Silver, N. J.

title: Slow and Shy Youths Learn How to Be Teachers' Aides
description: A group of young men and women with severe learning difficulties are discovering the sweetness of being need ed by someone in a program that trains them to be aides to kindergarten and nursery school teachers.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ISRAELIS. Founders and Sons. By Amos Eton. 359 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Win ston. $10.

title: Threat to Peace Coalition
description: A small group of disrupters, putting their revolu tionary fantasies above the cause of peace, are nibbling away the effectiveness of last week's impressive mass appeals to end the war in Vietnam. The thrillseeking chaos of the fringe groups' Washington encampment and the escalation of their upheavals, including plans to paralyze Washington traffic next Monday, appear de signed to attract those domestic guerrillas whose primary interest Is in political warfare.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Books that refuse to separate athletics from our other major preoccupationssex, money and politicsare often treated as the pornography of sports, reviled not so much for being untruthful as for being unhealthful. Three such dirty books are in the stores now, each interesting, read able, selfserving, incomplete and valuable for its implica tions and provocations.

title: A Stolen Amati Violin Is Found After 5 Years
description: A 300yearold violin, inlaid with rubies and diamonds that was made for King Louis XIV of France by the master violinmaker, Nicolo Amati, has reappeared here five years after it was stolen from an auto in Brooklyn.

title: Market Place: I.T.T.'s Report: A Closer Look
description: When the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation issued its quar terly report Thursday invest tors got the kind of news they have come to expect: record results for the first quarter on sales of almost $1.54billiona 12 per cent gain over the 1970 period  and earnings of 66 cents a share, also a 12 per cent gain.

title: SWEDEN BLAMES U.S. FOR RADIATION RISE
description: STOCKHOLM, April 30 (Reu ters)The Swedish Govern ment said today that there had been an increase in radio activity over Sweden in De cember, 1968, and attributed it to an American underground nuclear test in Nevada.

title: Lindsay Vetoes a Bill on Tardy Pensions
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ve toed a bill to require the city to pay interest to retired city employes who did not receive a pension payment within 120 days after retirement.

title: Former Gregory Partner Is Suspended by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that William H. Gregory 3d, former managing partner of Gregory & Sons, had agreed to a 21month suspension for caus ing his firm to violate the ex change's net capital rule in 1969.

title: Judge Lets the J.D.L. Hold A Vigil at Soviet Estate
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 30 State Supreme Court Justice Bernard S. Meyer ruled today that the Jewish Defense League had the right to conduct a prayer vigil this Sunday out side the gates of the Soviet Mission's estate in Glen Cove.

title: Times Sq. Table Tennis Accents P.O.W. Plight
description: A 24hour table tennis match is being played on a traffic island in Times Square by wives, mothers and chil dren of men who are prison ers of war or missing in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Pan Am Begins Service Linking U.S. and Poland
description: WARSAW, April 30 (UPI) A Pan American World Airways Boeing707 landed at Warsaw's Okecie Airport to day to inaugurate the first direct airline service be tween Poland and the United States.

title: $1,157,703 Given Seatrain
description: The United States Economic Development Administration said yesterday it had issued a $1,157,703 check to the Sea train Shipbuilding Corporation of New York. The money repre sented the first payment of a $5,850,000 loan to help Sea train establish shipbuilding op erations at the former Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: RAY JORDAN PLAYS A RECITAL ON PIANO
description: Ray Jordan, a pianist who made his debut at Town Hall in 1966, appeared at Carnegie, Recital Hall on Thursday night to play Chopin's Four Ballades and Scriabin's 12 Etudes (Op. 8).

title: INVENTORIES FALL 2D MONTH IN A ROW
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Manufacturers' inventories de clined again in March, making it the third month of the last ??our when stocks were reduced, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Keino Upset in 3,000 By Ethiopian Soldier
description: JERUSALEM, April 30 (UPI) A 23yearold Ethiopian soldier who had never run 3,000 meters easily defeated the world recordholder, Kip choge Keino at the Hebrew University Stadium today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, April 30  Atomic Energy Commission of ficials said today they were puzzled by the report from Sweden. Of about 30 under ground atomic weapons tests in 1968. a spokesman for the com mission said, only one caused a very small amount of radia tion detectable outside the test site.

title: Westinghouse Awarded Large Nuclear Contract
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company has awarded the Westinghouse Electric Cor poration contracts for four 900,000 kilowatt nuclear steam supply systems and the nuclear fuel. This is believed to be the largest single nuclear order ever placed in the industry.

title: Airport Priorities
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposal to buy land for a fourth metropolitan area jetport is understandable in view of the steadily growing congestion of New York's airports and overcrowded skies. But the choice of New burgh, 65 miles from this city, is at least questionable and the timing no less so if it is allowed to preclude other and more urgent approaches to the problem.

title: TRUDEAU AND QUEBEC IN A RIFT OVER LAW
description: OTTAWA, April 30The fed eral Government's decision to let its special antiterrorist legis lation expire at midnight to night has brought a rift in rela tions between Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Pre mier Robert Bourassa of Quebec.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. Chiang Kaishek was to have been in New York today for the funeral of her brother, Dr. T. V. Soong. She canceled her trip yesterday, after she was informed that the Communist Chinese might send her sister here too.

title: Ballet: Lust in the Dust
description: The most positive aspect of John Cranko's new ballet Carmen, being danced at the Metropolitan Opera House by the Stuttgart Ballet, is, in fact, Carmen and her tor tured lover, Don Jos. At the first night these two were played by Marcia Haydee and Egon Madsen, while at the second performance Wednes day afternoon we were given Birgit Keil and Heinz Clauss. At today's performances, in cidentally, the HaydeeMad sen team will dance the mat inee, while the KeilClauss duo will be seen again in the evening.

title: American Children Are Slaves
description: There is another subculture of youth today, a group differentiated from the main body by race, economics and education. It is composed of the des perately poor, largely nonwhite chil dren of our urban slums. These chil dren are set apart from the rest of society not only by these conditions but also by law. Often it is the law itself which causes hostility, anti social behavior and despair.

title: JOSEPH C. MARK
description: ROSSMOOR, N. J., April 30 (AP)Joseph G. Mark of Ross moor, a prominent New Jersey banker, died of an apparent heart attack today at the Sea view Country Club in Absecon. He was 65 years old.

title: DR. JACK SCHULTZ, GENETICIST, 66, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30 Dr. Jack Schultz, a leader in genetics and nucleic acid re search, died yesterday of a heart attack in a hospital here. He was 66 years old and lived on Pine Road in Huntington Valley, a Philadelphia suburb.

title: Charlie Brown to Return
description: You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown will reopen at the Edi son Theater, 47th Street be tween Broadway and Eighth Avenue, on May 15. The musi cal based on Charles M. Shulz's Peanuts, closed a fouryear offBroadway run last Febru ary, It will play four matinees and four evening performances on a Wednesday through Sun day playing schedule.

title: Widow of Soong to Receive Half of $1Million Estate
description: Mr. T. V. Soong, financier and brotherinlaw of Chiang Kaishek, President of Nation alist China, left half of his estate, estimated at more than $1million, to his wife, accord ing to his will which was filed for probate yesterday in Man hattan Surrogate's Court.

title: HEALTH CARE SYSTEM SCORED BY KENNEDY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that millions of Americans might be better off without the treatment they get under the nation's present healthcare system. He also questioned whether surgeons were not the worst offenders.

title: 3 MortgageSale Bids Rejected by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters)  The Federal Na tional Mortgage Association announced today that it re jected the three bids in yester day's mortgage sale auction totaling $7,350,000.

title: PSST! ROOSEVELT HAS A RACE, TOO
description: WESTBURY, LI., April 30 The $104,469.48 Realization Pace, the richest harness race in North America so far this season, also looms as the most wideopen stakes test to date. At least six of the 11 starters in tomorrow night's 10th edi tion of the event at Roosevelt Raceway must be regarded as strong contenders.

title: U.S. Announces It Will Boycott Moscow's World Film Festival
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The United States will not par ticipate in the Moscow Inter national Film Festival this year and will not accredit a delega tion to it, the State Department announced today.

title: This Garden Sprouts Sewing Machines
description: In the large trench that Arman dug for his bunker like house, even broken down upright pianos and rusty sewing machines make the view seem less desolate.

title: Plants for Sale
description: THE City Gardens Club is celebrating its 25th garden tour year. On Tuesday and the fol lowing Tuesday, May 11, 12 private home or penthouse gardens in Manhattan will be open to the public from 2 to 5:30 P.M. Different gar dens will be open on the two tour days., Single one day tickets are $8; tickets for both Tuesday tours are $15. Tickets are sold only at the club's headquarters, 829 Madison Avenue. Proceeds benefit civic and welfare projects in the city.

title: Billboards:
description: I think that I shall never see/ A billboard lovely as a tree. A good many scenerysensitive mo torists who agree with this bit of derivative doggerel by Ogden Nash had reason to think five and a half years ago that they would soon never see a billboard again in place of a tree. The banishing from the rural land scapes of America of biggerthan life blandishments for whiskey and automobiles and motels seemed to be at hand when Presi dent Johnson, promising to pro tect nature from the recklessness of man, signed the Highway Beautification Act of 1965. The act banned billboards from the flanks of all interstate and pri mary intercity highways except in commercial and industrial areas.

title: Young Israelis determined to survive
description: An excerpt from a journal I kept during and after the SixDay War at Kibbutz May aan Baruch, on the Syrian and Lebanese frontier, in the north ern Galilee:

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON The antiwar pro tests in the capital are based on the notion that if you keep people from going to their offices in Washington you interfere with the efficiency and policies of the Government, but this is obviously ridiculous.

title: Brooklyn Is Back in Goldman Band Series
description: Lemonade made in the shade by an old maid? Gone. The nickel icecream soda? Gone, gone.

title: St. John's U. Appoints Woman Vice President
description: Miss Margaret B. Kelly has been named executive vice president and vice pres ident for academic planning at St. John's Universitythe highest academic post held by a woman in any Roman Catholic university in the United States.

title: Riverdale Dean Named Fieldston School Head
description: Kenneth Barton, dean of students at the Riverdale Country School for Boys, has been appointed principal of the Fieldston School, one of the leading independent schools in the metropolitan area.

title: Et A1.
description: By Timothy Leary. 154 pp. Country Press. Cloth, $6.95. Paper, $2.95.

title: Photography
description: AMONG the many new products introduced at Photo Expo 71, which closed last Sunday aft er a nineday, run at McCor mick Place, were a number of new and improved cam eras and projectors of var ious kinds (last week's col umn described a variety of new 35 mm cameras that were displayed at the show).

title: Long Island Tours Are Set by Railroad
description: The Long Island Railroad has planned 76 excursions to his toric, scenic and cultural sites on Long Island and in Connec tient as it starts its 16th tour season, which will begin this month and run through Thanks giving Day.

title: Out There
description: In an early 21stcentury set ting, Adrien Stoutenburg chron icles the adventures of Zebrine Vandebrook (Aunt Zeb) and her remarkable Nature Squad five children who study wild animals and plants that are now almost extinct. Determined to go where the animals are, they leave climatecontrolled, astrodomed New City to explore the barren, offlimits wasteland of the Sierra Nevada in search of animals which Aunt Zeb can only remember and none of the children has ever seen.

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To The Editor: I recently sat through Har old Prince's latest contribu tionFollies. One can only express shock and amaze ment at those reviewers who hailed this musical as a fresh and brilliant new experi ence in the theater. With the exception of Mr. Prince's kaleidoscopic direction and Boris Aronson's brilliant de sign, the production is boring and lifeless.

title: Science
description: Twentyfour centuries ago the Greek philosopher. Democritus proposed that, if one could divide him, flesh, water or any other substance into smaller and small er bits, one would ultimately reach the basic building blocks of all matter. From the Greek for indivisible (atornos) these units became known as alons.

title: U.S. LIMITS EASED FOR HOUSING HERE
description: The Federal Government an nounced yesterday that it was easing its cost limitations on lowrent public housing here, enabling the city to expedite several projects that had been stalled because of their high costs.

title: First, Who Are You?
description: In the foreign correspondent's lexi con, every country has its clich. Reports from the Congo, my first foreign post, always included one steaming, equatorial rain forest. Korea, when I served there briefly, was this frozen cold war battle ground. And, in India, correspond ents were always striding through the teeming masses.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: Chandler Packer Aide
description: MARSHFIELD, Wis., May 1 (AP)The Green Bay Packers have hired Don Chandler to help improve their weak kick ing game.

title: Announcements
description: Engagements

title: A Is for Alphabet, B Is for Book...
description: To borrow from the title of one of the books being re viewed: What? Still another number book!

title: Reader's Report
description: Secrets assembles some of Nancy Hale's nostalgic inter ludes into a semifictional me moir. What was it like to be an only child of artist parents, in a Boston suburb, in the 1920's? Pure heaven, that's what it was like. The Welch children in the remodeled coaching inn next door were instant play mates, and summers were full of innocent secrets. Only Daddy Welch, parvenu and spoilsport, casts an occasional pall over things, with his incessant so cial climbing that turns even a children's fair into a charity drive. Coming out in Boston in 1926 is bliss; the Cabots are still speaking mainly to the Lodges; very few Irish are in vited to debutante parties; and Black Friday is three years away. These palmy days glow softly in the author's pastel shaded style.

title: Company Helps Workers To Pay New State Tax
description: NORTH SMITHFIELD, R. I., May 1 (AP)Each of the ap proximately 900 fulltime work ers of the Tupperware Company received an additional $100 bill in his paycheck this week to assist you in paying the recent ly enacted state income tax.

title: The Good Word: Men's Women, Women's Men
description: The basic Women's Lib letter seems to have subsided slightly  the one that used to turn up even in the sports pages, embroidered round the line. You wouldn't say that about a black man. Maybe someone over at Womentern realized alt last.that the worse we treat people in this country, the more delicately we talk about them; and that if we ever talk as nicely about women as we do about blacks, women are in trouble indeed.

title: Barbara Finkelstein to Be Wed Aug. ??
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., May 1 Mr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Finkelstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Fin kelstein, to Mark Mutterperl, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mutterperl of Great Neck. The wedding is planned for Aug. 8 at the home of the bride's parents.

title: The Backyard Gardener As a Practical Ecologist
description: ONE realization which has come to us through the environmental crisis, is that virtually anything we do to alter our world has far reaching implications beyond our pres ent ability to assess. We can make only vague judgements as to the relative severity of a given act.

title: RARE CANCER TYPE LINKED TO A DRUG
description: Three Harvard physicians have reported a link between a rare form of vaginal cancer in some young women and a hormone drug that their moth ers took during early preg nancy.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: This book is dedicated to the housewife, or should be. It also has a message for businessmen who have a hand in supplying food. From it, almost any woman can learn some money  saving ways of buying food. After she has read it, her head will come up with a sigh and she will feel let down by quite a few food companies and su permarkets. Too many greedy hands want her dollar.

title: So This Is America's Fashion Showplace?
description: THE THEORY; of course, was that the midi would bury the mini and women would have to rush out and buy new clothes. But, like so many theories, it didn't work. The minis still outnumber the midis. And lots of women took to wear ing pants.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: In 78 years, according to a calculation by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, everyone in the United States civilian labor force will be working for some level of government.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: My personal experience and knowledge of the plight of women in need of abortion both before and after passage of New York's liberal and humane abortion law contra dicts at least one of the conclusions arrived at by Susan Edmiston, author of the article, A Report on the Abortion Capital of the Coun try (April 11). In that article Miss Edmiston stated, Gov ernor Rockefeller has recom mended that the State Legis lature reduce the gestation period for justifiable abortion to 20 weeks. Virtually all doctors favor this recommen dation.

title: Look Away!
description: To the Editor:

title: The San Quentin Story The Prisons Are Getting
description: WHEN I recently went back to San Quentin Prison for the first time in more than 10 years, it turned out to be on the eve of one of the most protracted sieges of uncomplicated racial vio lence to have broken out in the prison in recent memory. (I say uncomplicated because the troubles didn't involve general rioting or de thands on the administration, but the violence of prisoner against prisoner, black against brown against white.) In a period of three weeks, 17 men were stabbed with prisonmade knives or otherwise assaulted. Two of these prisoners died. As I write, the trou bles are still going on and half the prisoners are locked up 24 hours a day.

title: Marilence ViannaRibeiro Is Fiancee
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Miss Marilene ViannaRibeiro and Axel de Tristan plan to be married on June 19 in the Georgetown University Chapel.

title: Movies
description: star and director of Bananas, now at the Coronet.

title: Family Planners in Morocco Find Women Hard to Convince
description: EL JADIDA, MoroccoAt 9 o'clock in the morning the sun was high enough to shine full on the onestory health center on the outskirts of this farm town, 70 miles south of Casa blanca.

title: Son to the Silvermans
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Silverman of Boston on April 19 in Beth Israel Hospital there. Mrs. Silverman is the former Miss Penelope Bedingfield, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bedingfield of New York. The child, whose father expects to receive his med ical degree this month from the Boston University Med ical Center, is named David Richard.

title: School Lunch Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, an nounced today the beginning of new hearings into the workings of the national School lunch Act. He said that four million needy school children will go without lunch every day.

title: Bridge
description: CIVILIZED men may look down condescendingly on those primi tive people who stick pins in models of their enemies, but they do much the same thing, in another way, at the bridge table. While the savage is limited in the number of pins he uses only by his supply, the bridgeplayer is much more restricted. He has fairly numerous opportunities to stick two pins into one opponenta simple squeeze. Rather rare is the opportu nity to stick two pins into each of his opponentsa double squeeze. But rarest of all is to stick three pins into one opponenta triple squeeze.

title: 3dParty Endorsements Out in Nassau
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., May 1 Nassau County today became the third county in the state in which local units of the Repub lican and Democratic parties have banned crossendorse ments by third parties.

title: Roadside Rest, Famed 30's. Bandstand, Reborn
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., May The Roadside Rest, one of the legendary bandstands for the bigname bands of the nineteenthirties and forties, is back in the music busi ness again.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sabah Is Southeast Asia in the Raw
description: KOTA KINABALU, Sabah, Malay sia  On a recent journey to Southeast Asia, a tourism pro moter from Los Angeles made a oneday visit to Sabah, the eastern state of Malaysia, and discovered, to his surprise, a new, interesting offthe beatenpath stop. The promoter said, however, that even in his short stay he could see that the thriving, pro gressive country needed to change its image abroad, discarding the wild men and savages of Borneo reputation and reflecting instead a modern civilization attractive to tourists.

title: Ages 9 to 12: Echoes of Other Days, Other Ways
description: Over at the railroad yards they said No. 88 was jinxed she had certainly had more than her share of accidents. Dave Brennan put the mishaps down to human error; still, he wasn't exactly pleased to be posted to the badluck locomo tive for the third time in a row.

title: Lawyers in Coast Poverty Unit Defend Reform Efforts
description: MARYSVILLE, Calif., May 1 Joe Benningfield is poor, white, and considerably over 21. Several years ago he was injured in an explosion and could not work any more to support his 11 children.

title: Plans Under Way to Restore Abandoned Sunset Park Homes
description: A deteriorated part of the Bush TerminalSunset Park dis trict of Brooklyn may get a re birth if community plans for renovation of abandoned homes come to fruition.

title: Christine McLain Plans Nuptials
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 1  Miss Christine Frances McLain who expects to be graduated this month from Sweet Briar College, plans to be married Aug. 21 to Craig Eric Buck, an economic re search analyst with the Na tional Association of Home Builders in Washington.

title: NEGRO IS ELECTED EPISCOPAL BISHOP
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Rev. Canon John T. Walker was elected today as Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal dio cese of Washington.

title: Headliners
description: Miracle

title: M. G. Smith to Wed Elise Becket
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., May 1 The engagement of Miss Elise Barr Becket, a senior at the Stanford University School of Law, to Martin Gregory Smith has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. George Campbell Becket, parents of the future bride. Her fiancd, who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree from Stanford next month and an M.A. in economics in August, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Gregory Smith of St. Albans, England.

title: Look What They've Done to Lawrence of Arabia Now
description: BEFORE Lawrence of Arabia was rere leased a few weeks ago, it was rumored that Columbia planned to re store a homosexual scene that had been deleted in 1962, in order to take advan tage of the sophistication of contemporary audiences of course no such scene ever existed, but the rumors and the cries of outrage that they aroused have effectively camouflaged a much more important alteration in the film: Lawrence of Arabia is still clean, but it is not intact; approximately 15 min utes absolutely crucial to the plot, characterizations, and dramatic rhythm of the film have been removed.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Prof. Milton Handler argues (April 4), in essence, that class actions are a liability.

title: Mailbox: N.Y.U. Sports
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Diana M. Oakes Bride in Capital Of W. F. Conger
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Miss Diana Meredith Oakes, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George W. Oakes of Washington, was married here today to William F. Conger, son of Louis H. Conger, chief statistician of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, and Mrs. Conger of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi E. William Sea man performed the ceremony at the home of Miss Ethel Kalman.

title: Maternity Leave: An Employe Right?
description: The oldest form of non occupational hazard is sud denly being reappraised by employers and government agencies in the light of a civil right.

title: ROYALS SET BACK ORIOLES AGAIN, 52
description: KANSAS CITY, May 1 (AP) Kansas City chased Balti more's Dave McNally today with a rash of doubles and went on to a 52 victory, the Royals' second straight over the Orioles.

title: Et Al.
description: The author, with his illustra tor friend Richard Brown, has filled a thick book with mean dering accounts of his voy ages in alleys, bayous, swamps, rivers, creeks, canals and open sewers... through such places as New Orleans, Rhode Island, Cape May, Mys tic, Jamestown. Thoreau, Ke rouac, even Richard Bissell might have carried it off; but the talent here is minimal. The drawings are kinda nice.

title: Clearly, It's a Match. Made by the Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 1 (UPI) Demme Hummel, 23 years old, of Pasadena, Calif., received a marriage proposal from James Miller, 23, of Al hambra, Calif.on the Cali fornia Angels' message board.

title: Juliet or Carmen? Hayde Is Both
description: OFFSTAGE, ballerina Marcia Hayde is not beautiful. Aside from her large, liquid brown eyes (her most arresting feature), the 31yearold Brazilianborn dancer, currently the stel lar attraction of John Cranko's Stuttgart Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera, does not present the image of the ethereal, perfectly shaped dancerthe compell ing, magical vision of an artist whose very presence evokes myriad illusions of poetic sensuality or personal mag netism.

title: Argentine Colt Wins Rich Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 1 (UPI)  Argentine  bred Big Shot II went to the front at the start and staged a wire towire victory today in the fourth running of the $108,100 Century Handicap on the turf at Hollywood Park.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To The Editor:

title: Hospital Ship Leaves Danang
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, May 1 (AP)The United States hospital ship Sanctuary sailed from Danang harbor today, clos ing out four years of duty in the Vietnam war zone. Officials said the 27yearold ship would be retired upon her return to the United States.

title: Text of Mayor's Message to Council and Board of Estimate on Proposed Budget
description: Following is the text of Mayor Lindsay's expense budget message to the City Council and the Board of Estimate:

title: Americans Visiting China Face Taiwan Retaliation
description: TOKYO, May 1 (AP)Amer Jeans' visas for Taiwan will be canceled by travel to Com munist China, the Nationalist Chinese Embassy said here to day.

title: Virginia Crew Ends Reign Of Marietta in MidAmerica
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, May 1 (UPI)The University of Vir ginia ended six years of domi nation by Marietta College in the MidAmerica regatta by winning the varsity race today. But Marietta came out on top in other races to win the J. Ellis MacDonalld allpoints trophy with 29 points.

title: Eban Says Visit by Rogers Won't Lead to Breakthrough
description: JERUSALEM, May 1 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Abba Eban warned today against any ex pectation that the visit of Sec retary of State William P. Rogers to the Middle East would lead to any dramatic transition of present tension in the area.

title: Buckley After 100 Days in Washington: At Ease in Senate Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 James L. Buckley, who com pleted his first 100 days in the United States Senate to day, should not have an identity problem.

title: The World
description: SEOULI swallowed my tears and voted for President Park, 70yearold Yun Kwan Ho said last week after casting his ballot in South Korea's seventh Presidential election. We Kor ean people earnestly desire a peaceful transition of power, but I know that if we elected Mr. Kim Dae Jung [the opposition candidate], the Government would never allow him to come to power.

title: HARVARD OARSMEN WIN CUP RACE AGAIN
description: PRINCETON, N. J. May 1 Harvard's undefeated light weight crew captured the 46th Goldthwait Cup Regatta for the 14th consecutive year to day, finishing four lengths ahead of Princeton and eight lengths ahead of Yale.

title: Growing pains on Packett Island
