description: If we are to believe Her man Raucherand I suppose we are to believe him, since his 15yearold protagonist is named Hermie and the author seems quite at home inside Hermie's headboys in their middle teens think constantly of sex, plan endless sexual es capades that never happen, find sexual overtones in all that surrounds them, including everyday events and homely artifacts. Even the young Alex Portnoy had an occasional in trusive daydream about base ball. Hermie has settled into his preoccupation with admi rable fidelity.

title: I Believe In Me
description: George Mendoza is what is known in the trade as a phenomenon. He has written, created, produced and otherwise brought to publication 35 books since 1959, 12 of them new this year. Mendoza himself is 36 years old, handsome in an early Wil liam Holden style, and currently sell ing his apartment in New York and moving his wife and 2  year  old daughter out of the city. He speaks softly, often in colorful fragments.

title: Poor Get Training as Legal Secretaries
description: ColonySouth Brooklyn Hous es, a settlement house special izing in manpower training, has begun a new program to train black and Puerto Rican women as legal secretaries.

title: Et Al.
description: Pieces by or about members of Weatherman, from sources as divergent as New Left Notes and Time. The editor's intro duction explains the emergence of Weatherman from the ashes of S.D.S. and discusses its ideol ogy and goals. There is poetry, reportorial and think articles, portraits of New Left radicals, communiques from the under ground. The big names are here Boudin, Dohrn, Cleaver, Leary and despite the scattergun effect the book is informative.

title: SIR PEARL VICTOR ON JERSEY GRASS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May (UPI)Sir Pearl won the first division of the $20,000added Valley Forge Handicap by 1 lengths and North Flight took the second section by 2 lengths today at Garden State Park.

title: HAVANA DISCLOSES ARREST OF WRITER
description: MIAMI, May 1The Castro Government has acknowledged the arrest of Heberto Padilla, a wellknown Cuban writer.

title: Frances Anne Guest Married To Ernest Martin Johnson Jr.
description: LONDON, May 1Miss Frances Ann Guest, daugh ter of the Dowager Viscount ess Wimborne and the late Viscount Wimborne, was mar ried this afternoon to Ernest Martin Johnson Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Johnson of Gardner, Mass.

title: Drug Use and Abuse: Policemen Examine the Books
description: For parents who know net to nothing about drugs, this is a very good book, wellwritten and easy to read. It provides the basics and deals with the right concerns, like the need to keep communication open be tween parent and child and the fact that it's not always the parents' fault if a child takes drugs. The reader gets a good surface look at the subject. We would have liked the book done in a different sequence with the discussion of the need for new perspectives after the facts on drugs.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE Job of installing window shades is a fairly simple one that often runs into uneces sary complications because the homeowner or apartment dweller is not familiar with the wide variety of mounting brackets available, or be cause they do not know about the various installation techniques that have been developed for specific win dow styles.

title: The Mud Snail Son
description: In this unembellished ver sion of a Japanese folk tale, a couple who wish for a child are given a mud snail in re sponse to their wish. They tend him devotedly for 20 years, then at his own request send him to town to seek his fortune. There he gains the admiration of the king and the hand of a beautiful princess whose devo tion eventually transforms him into a handsome prince.

title: Trashing
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: LABOR TALKS OPEN ON COPPER PACTS
description: DENVER, May 1 Prelimi nary bargaining has begun on new threeyear contracts be tween 26 unions and the na tion's copper industry, with both sides hoping to avoid a repetition of the eightanda halfmonth struggle that mark ed their 19671968 negotiations.

title: Mrs. Evelyn Boggs Donaldson Is Wed
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 1Mrs. Evelyn Boggs Donaldson, a greatgreat granddaughter of Marshall Field, the Chicago merchant, was married here this after noon to Peter Mannering Thompson, an account execu tive with the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York.

title: Science
description: At approximately 6 A.M. last Feb. 9 there was a mighty cleav age some nine miles beneath the San Gabriel Mountains of California. The fracture trav eled rapidly upward, at an an gle of 45 degrees, until it broke the surface along the edge of those mountains and, extending further west, crossed the neatly ordered streets, avenues and homes of San Fernando, a sub urb of Los Angeles.

title: Oil Truckers' Strike Perils Gas Supply
description: Two unions representing tanktruck drivers and inside workers struck six major oil companies yesterday, threaten ing a shortage of gasoline at 85 per cent of the service sta tions in the metropolitan area.

title: Music
description: WATCHING the Heifetz show on Channel 4 the other week brought back mem ory after memory. Jascha Hei fetz has been around for a long, long time, and his con cert appearances always were a highlight of any music sea son. To the public, he was the violinist. Maybe Kreisler had more charm. Maybe Szigeti was his intellectual superior. Maybe Elman made prettier sounds. Maybe Huberman was a better musician. It made no difference. Heifetz remained the criterion.

title: Boy Sopranos to Perform
description: The 48th annual concert of the Catholic Diocesan Choris ters a group of boy sopranos, will be held on May 7 at 8 P.M. at the Bishop Ford Diocesan High School, 500 19th Street, Brooklyn. Inquiries about tick ets, which range from $1 to $3, may be made by calling ES 71333.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS ACTIONS TO SPUR ECONOMIC UPTURN
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 1President Nixon said today that he would do everything in his power, even seek a tax cut if necessary, to keep the econ omy on an upward curve.

title: OTB Prices
description: Following are the possible win payoffs calculated by OTB in its offtrack parimutuel pool on the Derby. Horses are listed In order of their finishes.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Every so often in Washington a man is com pelled by events to pass harsh, un pleasant judgment upon himself. This is such a time. Is the F.B.I. tapping your telephone? a man asked over lunch the other day. It was an invita tion to a selfjudgment.

title: For Forty Girls, a Friendly Place to Stay
description: An inexpensive girls' dor mitory in the Biltmore Hotel next door to Grand Central Terminal? Yes indeed.

title: ARMY TOPS TERPS IN LACROSSE, 167
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 1 Three northern college la crosse teams invaded the Balti more area today. Only one went home a winner.

title: Green Cards 69 for 206 Total And Shot Lead at New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 1 Hubert Green, a tour rookie from Birmingham, Ala., set the 54hole pace in the $125,000 New Orleans open today. With a third round of 69, the former Southern Amateur champion champion, gained a onestroke edge with a total of 206.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: Dream Mile Berth Is Left for Keino; Liguori, Ryan In
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 1 A field of eight milers has been invited for the dream mile at the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. International Freedom Games May 16 in Philadelphia.

title: Stony Brook Gets New Program For Training Physicians' Aides
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., May 1 A new program designed to train physicians' assistantsa program that could enable mili tary corpsmen and others with health training to enter medical school without a college degree will begin at the State Uni versity Center here next fall.

title: Indonesia Opens Campaign for First National Election in 16 Years
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 1 Indonesia took a small step down the road toward represen tative democracy this week when the Government officially opened the campaign for the first national election in 16 years.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Poor E. J. Kahn Jr. Show him a throbbing, bobbing, just invented machine and he's more likely to ask how it works than what it does. Awed by the inventiveness of the Japanese mind, that he mentioned in his Won ders Under the Rising Sun article (Travel section, April 11), he enters a taxi in Tokyo and focuses his attention on the rate system, wholly neg lecting the final fare. The whirling numbers on the taxi meter must have so bemused him that he doesn't remem ber what he paid.

title: School Amendment Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Representative C. W. Young, Republican of Florida, has pro posed a constitutional amend ment designed to preserve neighborhood schools. Mr. Young's amendment would pro vide that the right of a student to attend the public school nearest his home would not he denied for reasons of race, color, national origin, religion or sex.

title: ST. CECILIA SUNG BY CHORAL SOCIETY
description: As there were many Baths in musical history, so also were there many Scarlattis, who were contemporaries of the Bachs. Domenico Scarlatti, the man who wrote the famous harp sichord sonatas, is the best known, but his father, Alessan dro, was no slouch as a com poser. By the time he died at 65 in 1725, he had turned out about 100 operas, upwards of 600 cantatas and countless other works.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Et Al.
description: The doctor takes a swing at modern medicine. He doesn't like communitycontrolled med ical care, familypracticing G.P.'s, current waste in medical procedures, unethical practices, etc. The style is breezy, the viewpoint limited for the most part to Dr. Gerber's experience (he is a surgeon).

title: Whittier Elm Dies
description: HAVERHILL, Mass. May 1 (AP)The Whittier elm, a 300 yearold tree described often in the poems of John Greenleaf Whitter, fell over and died this week. City officials said the tree had been hit by Dutch elm disease 15 years ago and ap peared increasingly fragile in recent months.

title: A Menace to Liberty
description: There is no more subtle, more quietly debilitating men ace to the liberty of citizens than to have high offices of government occupied by men with no clear under standing of the nature and requirements of liberty. Evi dence accumulates that such men are now in power in Washington.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankee Ingenuity Wins For Prep Relay Team
description: New Bedford, Mass., High School made its first appear ance in an outdoor meet in New York yesterday and it was a smashing success.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: This is a humorous little story about the children of a village who tease and torment a nice little old lady named Bunya and call her a witch. Now Bunya didn't think she was a witch, but she even surprised herself when she said, Hocus pocus! and all the children turned into a bunch of green, hopping youknow whats! And then, by mistake, Bunya turned the outraged parents into pigs. But it all ends happily, and the pigs get turned back and the frogs get turned back, and even Bunya decides that she's not unhappy to be a witch. This is not one of your great frog books, but it's a nice little book and kind of fun to read out loud.

title: A Walk Through Epping Forest to See England As It Was
description: LONDONAn Englishman in his 80's said that if you close your eyes and put your hands over your ears and then open one eye, just a little, you can catch a glimpse of Great Britain as it used to be. To help save this fading glimpse of the country the Essex County branch of the Council for the Protection of Rural England of fers prizes for essays describing a three day walk from Epping Forest to the sea, a distance of about 50 miles.

title: Dr. Reed, Surgeon to Thoroughbreds
description: ELMONT, L.I., May 1 When the 97th Kentucky Derby was run in Louisville today, the horse that had been the overwhelming favor ite in the winter book was continuing his recuperation at Belmont Park following an operation whose technique was developed by a Long Island veterinarian.

title: Sour Ball Wins 3 Events In Fairfield Horse Show
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 1 Buddy Brown rode Sour Ball to the working hunter cham pionship with 16 points today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club Junior Horse Show.

title: David Levine Restores The Art to Caricature
description: Oscar Wilde looks like a mountain of a man, a kind of oneman Mount Rushmore, gazing condescendingly down on the world.

title: $92,000 Winnings Divided by Knicks; 14 Get Fall Shares
description: The New York Knickerbock ers voted 14 full shares of $6,000 each as they divided the $92,000 they earned for their combined firstplace finish in the Atlantic Division and their efforts in the National Basket ball Association playoffs. In ad dition to the full shares, the players voted cash awards to others in the organization.

title: Mrs. Erica James Will Be Married Next Month to Henry Babcock
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., May I Mrs. Erica Hohner James and Henry Denison Babcock Jr. of New York plan to be married next month.

title: Miss Pamela J. Harris, Teacher, Fiancee of Lieut. Kim J. Kaiser
description: SEATTLE, May 1Mr. and Mrs. John R. Harris have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Jean Harris, to Second Lieut. Kim John Kaiser, U.S.A.F.

title: Moustache Keeping a Cover Boy Out of the Picture
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 1 The cover boy on the current National Collegiate Track and Field Guide will not compete in the N.C.A.A. out door championships next month, but not because he could not qualify academi cally or athletically.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: Hobbs of England Retains Pole Position at Monterey
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 1 (AP)David Hobbs's qualifying time from the opening day stood up today and put his car on the pole for tomorrow's $25,000 Continental 5000 Grand Prix.

title: Music
description: WHEN Abba Bogin gave his debut re cital in Town Hall in 1947, as the re sult of having won the Naum burg Competition, he was greeted as one of the most promising young pianists around. He gave another re cital in 1949, appeared at Lewisohn Stadium in 1950, recorded Brahrns cello so natas with Janos Starker, played chamber music. He was pianist for the Philhar monic for several years.

title: Dartmouth Outrows Cornell And Retains Baggaley Cup
description: HANOVER, N.H., May 1  Dartmouth's varsity light weight oarsmen got off to a good start and went On to win by a length from Cornell on the Connecticut River today.

title: POST OFFICE TALKS REACH AN IMPASSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Contract negotiations between the United States Post Office and seven postal unionsthe first true test of collective bar gaining between the Federal Government and Government employeshave reached an irritable impasse.

title: The Making of Joshua Cobb
description: The Making of Joshua Cobb is an amusing story of what Joshua Cobb, age 12, grade eight, made of a New England prep school; and what, during his first year, with mother 300 miles away, the school made of Joshua Cobb.

title: Letters
description: This is not a novel of plot and character, of reasons and whys. The literary landscape of Brossard's fiction is like the moon's ... forbidding, danger ous, and set for generations to come. The timid, the oldfash ioned  and creativewriting teachers like Broyardwill find such terrain hostile. Obviously, they should not venture into its space.

title: Miss Victoria Galbraith Affianced
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 1The engagement of Miss Victoria Galbraith to George West Saltonstall has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Archibald S. Galbraith, parents of the future bride. Her fianc, who is known as West, is the son of Mrs. Endi cott Peabody Saltonstall of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Mr. Saltonstall.

title: 2 L.I. Yacht Clubs Mark Their 100th Anniversary
description: PORT WASHINGTON, May 1Two of the oldest yacht clubs in the country  the North Shore Yacht Club here and the Seawanhaka Co rinthian Yacht Club in Oyster Bayare celebrating their 100th anniversaries this sum mer.

title: DroughtRavaged Areas Widen
description: MIAMI, May IThe droughts that have severely damaged Florida and the Southwest ap peared this week to be moving into the Ohio Valley and Middle Atlantic States, according to national weather officials.

title: No Tame Kiddy Trader He
description: Harlin Quist. If that dashing, ele gant, slightly improbable moniker suggests to you the hero of a boy's adventure storythe brave knight in quest (quist?) of Truth, the plucky prince who slays a fiery dragon, the fearless foot soldier whose strategy routs a regiment

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Announcer: Perhaps we did shade the truth a little and tell you that our mouse trap was smoother working, quieter and more effective than any other mousetrap in its price range, and we are indeed sorry if we misled any of you. The trouble is we had this copywriter at our agen cy who couldn't think of any thing new to say about mousetraps, and so he lied. Anyway, we all know that all mousetraps do pretty much the same, but please do come and look at ours.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: This is a delightful little picture book that can be read by everybody, even little kids who can't read, be cause it doesn't have any writing to read. In a lovely series of drawings, it tells a warm and charming story about a boy and his dog and his frog, who go fishing and end up catching a turtle. Unfortunately, the star of the book is the turtle, or possibly the dog. Certainly not the frogsigh.

title: Television
description: TUESDAY night at 9 on Channel 13, Public Broadcasting will pre sent a dramatic version of John Dos Passos' trilogy U.S.A. Al though this version was originally writ ten for the stage by Paul Shyre and Dos Passos himself, television is such a bossy medium (as different from the stage as the stage is from a novel) that the director, George Schaefer, is likely to do his own experimenting with the three novels  The 42nd Parallel (1930), 1919 (1932), The Big Money (1932). Even _in our period, so rich in novels as novelties, these novels con stitute the most massive single experi ment in 20thcentury American fiction.

title: CORNELL CREW WINS CARNEGIE CUP RACE
description: DERBY, Conn., May 1 Cornell held off a challenge from Princeton on the Housa tonic today to win the Carnegie Cup for the first time since 1967.

title: Country Fair in Bedford
description: BEDFORD, N.Y.  On Saturday this northern Westchester town will begin the first in a 10 year program of historical commemorations that will wind up in 1980 with the 300th anniversary of the set tlement of Bedford. The event, Old Bedford Days, will combine attractions such as historical exhibits, antique sales, demonstrations of Colonial crafts and sales of the many treasures always on sale at country bazaars. The fair will be on from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

title: Miss Webster Married
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., May 1 Miss Carolyn Partridge Webster, a descendant of Noah Webster, the lexicog rapher and philologist, was married in the Westwood United Methodist Church to day to Thomas Joseph Moly neaux. The Rev. E. Randall Bean performed the cere mony.

title: Six Nations to Boycott Winter Olympics in Japan If Pro Skiers Are Barred
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, May 1 (AP)  Six Alpine skiing nations vowed today they would boycott the 1972 Winter Olympics in Sapporo, Japan, if the International Olympic Com mittee bars any competitor for alleged professionalism.

title: News of Dogs
description: The largest dog show to be held in the United States in three decades takes place next Sunday, when the Tren ton Kennel Club stages its 42d fixture. The site will be Washington Crossing State Park at Washington Crossing, N. J., five miles north of Trenton.

title: U.S. OBSERVERS AID LATIN PEACE
description: AMATILLO, El Salvador, April 29A littlepublicized but apparently quite success ful international peacekeeping operation is being carried out by military observers from the Organization of American States at this and other paints along the HondurasEl Salva dor border.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTIN OF RAHWAY SETS HURDLES MARK
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 1 Two 16yearolds posted im pressive victories today in the Englewood Memorial track meet at White Stadium.

title: Miss DuPont Captures Final In College Tennis, 63, 62
description: STAUNTON, Va., May 1 (AP) Laura DuPont of North Caro Enna defeated Marjorie Gengler of Princeton, 63, 62, to retain her singles championship in the Middle Atlantic Lawn Tennis Association women's collegiate tournament today.

title: WINNER NOTABLE FOR LARGE GIRTH
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 The stall was empty and in conspicuous, just another room among the thousands in the stable area of Churchill Downs.

title: Sale of Rams May Be an Inside Job
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 They hung a Not For Sale Just Yet sign on old Reeves Tech this week.

title: Two Newcomers To the City Ballet Dance Lead Roles
description: The New York City Ballet's repertory comprises such a large number of ballets that even a principal dancer with the com pany may go for years before dancing the leading role in one of its bestknown works.

title: Bell Posts Top Time
description: ADENAU, West Germany, May 1 (UPI)  Derek Bell of England today posted the fast est time in final practice runs for tomorrow's Eifel Formula two auto race. At the wheel of a March, Bell lapped the 14.2 mile circuit in the Eifel Moun tains in 7 minutes 59.7 seconds to be the only driver to crack the eight minute barrier.

title: David Yarian to Wed Miss Jane Helen Lowy
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Charles Lowy have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jane Helen Lowy, to David Logan Yarian, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Yarian of Angola, Ind.

title: Ginzburg Appeals Again
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Ralph Ginsburg, the New York publisher who has been trying to stay out of jail since the Supreme Court affirmed his obscenity conviction for ob scenity in 1966, has brought his care to the high court again. The publisher was convicted in June, 1963, for sending Eros Magazine, The Housewife's Handbook on Selective Prom iscuity and Liaison newsletter through the mail.

title: Ages 9 to 12: Echoes of Other Days, Other Ways
description: Captive Yankee officers were confined in Libby Prison in Richmond, Va. Conditions in the Confederate capital in 1864 were bad, those in the jail were deplorable, and the hope of escape from it more nour ishing than the scanty rations allowed the prisoners.

title: The Story of The Great Chicago Fire, 1871
description: Amazing! There really was a Mrs. O'Leary and the Great Chicago Fire did start in her barn. We can't say for sure that one of her cows actually knocked over the lantern; but Mary Kay Phelan assures us that the blaze certainly began on the O'Leary property, at 137 DeKoven Street on the West Side of Chicago. From that point, the fire raged through the tinderdry, crudely carpentered city  even the sidewalks were made of wood destroyed about 17,500 build ing, left almost 100,000 home less and killed between 100 and 300.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In reference to the article (April 18), Gadfly's Sting is $1Million, what would hap pen should another stock holder put forward the suggestion, Resolved that henceforth any stockholder must be the registered owner of no less than 1 per cent of the current outstanding stock in order to submit a proposal before the meeting? Would not a successful vote then override that of such char acters as Shields and Gilbert?

title: The Jew as a Surfer, Superego
description: Once upon a time, according to the catechism of the public schools, the noble White An glo Saxon Protestant culture brought the wretched great grandparents of today's Jews to the glistening shores of America to give them a try at the great brass ring of Waspi tude. Of course none of them ever caught it, but that was hardly America's fault. The System exists to give us all another chance.

title: We're Off To See The Wizard
description: A young student of English liter ature at Bard College, Michael Pat rick Hearn, is busy on a curious proj ect. He is writing scholarly footnotes for a volume to be published next year in Clarkson Potter's wellknown series of annotated classics. The book? The Wonderful Wizard of Oz!

title: Lt Al.
description: A study of the German policy toward the Ukraine at the end of World War I. German in tentions, the occupation, the Ukrainian independence move ment. Specialized and academic.

title: BREWERS BLANK YANKS
description: The Yankees and the Brewers had a lot of trouble with the husbands of ex  airline stew ardesses yesterday, but Tommy Harper avoided it just long enough to hit a home run that gave Milwaukee a first  class victory, 10.

title: Fire Bomb Thrown On Subway Train; 3 Persons Burned
description: A man threw a fire bomb on a subway car last night, burn ing three of the six persons aboard, the police reported. One injury was serious.

title: HARNESS WRITERS TO CITE ABBATIELLO
description: Carmine Abbatiello, Leonard Levin and the Pine Hollow Stud Farm Of Pine Bush, N.Y., will be the recipients of awards at the New York Harness Writ ers dinnerdance May 16 at the Four Seasons Country Club in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Black Group Plans Mobilization of Aid for Harlem Five, on Trial as Plotters
description: A small group of prestigious black New Yorkers sought yes terday afternoon to mobilize support for the Harlem Five, a group of youths on trial for allegedly consptrmg to kill po licemen.

title: Pearce Defeats Giles, 5 and 4, in 36Hole Final of North and South Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 1 (AP)Eddie Pearce, a 19year old Wake Forest freshman from Temple Terrace, Fla., shot four under par today to beat the Walker Cup player, Vinny Giles of Richmond, 5 and 4, in the 36hole final of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: 3 Killed as Youths Clash With Riot Troops in Manila
description: MANILA, May 1Young dem onstrators clashed with antiriot troops in front of the legislative building here today and three persons were reported killed by gunfire. Fifteen others, includ ing two soldiers, were reported injured from bullets and ex plosions.

title: BALL STARS' TOUR OF CUBA IS SOUGHT
description: CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) Manager Preston Gomez of the San Diego Padres says he plans to organize a major league allstar team for a tour of Cuba this fall if the State Department approves.

title: Hospital Meeting Today
description: The Malmonides Medical Cen ter, halfway through a 10year, $50million development pro gram, will honor founders and review plans for its final phase of development at a ceremony today at the stilltobecom pleted clinical services center at 4802 10th Avenue, in Brooklyn.

title: Cougars Sign Adams
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., May 1 (AP)The Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Asso ciation made it three of five today by signing Luke Adams, their fifthround draft choice. With No. 1 Jim McDaniels, thirdround selection Ted Mc Lain, 11th  rounder Bob Mc Kenney and Adams signed, the Cougars have concluded their most successful draft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dolls' Party By Annemie and Margriet Heyman. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $2.95.
description: Here are two simple little stories, short on text and long on pictures, that tell about the activities of two groups of dolls and toys. One group, starting from one end of the book, makes its troublous way to the birthday party for Duck while the other group, starting at the other end, is already at Duck's house preparing for the party. The two meet in the middle of the book. Am I making myself clear? You can start at one end and read one story or turn the book upside down and over and start at the other end. It doesn't matter which comes first. The two come together in the center in a textless double spread, with no up or down, that shows the party in progress.

title: G. T. Sulcer Weds Miss Smallwood
description: CALDWELL, N.J., May 1 Miss Barbara Lee Smallwood and Gordon Thearle Sulcer were married here this after noon in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Edward J. Fleming.

title: AMTRAK CHUGS IN WITH FEW ABOARD
description: The National Railroad Pas senger Corporation, known as Amtrak, took over the rem nants of the nation's longneg lected, deficitridden intercity passenger railroads yesterday with little evident confusion, customarily low patronage and a number of whistlestop cere monies.

title: Architecture
description: THIS is a tale of three banks, some Intrepid Ladies, and some strange bedfellows. In Exeter, N.H., there is the Rockingham National Bank. There is also Front Street, a row of serene clapboard structures in the classic New England urban image, a genre increasingly recognized as a special treasure of the Ameri can scene:

title: Drug Use and Abuse: Policemen Examine the Books
description: One that should appeal to the upper high school and college students who have a genuine interest in not only the history of drugs, but also how they af fect the individual. It covers all aspects of drugs, uses, sources, statistics, drug laws, withdrawal, methadone main tenance, etc. Its main concept of posing questions and follow ing up with answers is excel lent. But we find that this pres entation is a too involved and wordy for the students that we are now working with.

title: The Economics of a Global Antipollution Code
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department an nounced today the imposition of antipollution penalty duties on imports of chemical products from Sludgeland.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The three March 8 letters on Jeru salem's future are but exercises in rationalization to justify Israel's deter mination to absorb and blot the cen turiesold Arab character of Jerusalem in the face of censure by the world community.

title: Thousands in Moscow March in Square
description: MOSCOW, May 1Thou sands of men, women and children marched in a chilling rain through Red Square today to exchange May Day greetings with the Soviet Union's top political and military leaders.

title: Gardens
description: I HAVE met gardeners who were not strongly prodahlia. I've always felt they were missing a great deal of pleasure. Dahlias are relatively easy to raise and are longseason bloom ing. They demand a minimum of care. There is a wide variety of forms and the blooms look magnificent either in the garden or as arrangements in the drawing room. Although dahlias generate no perfume, the variety of forms, textures and shades provide spectacular beauty.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Hot Couture

title: On Ethnicity
description: It would be getting on to thirty years ago that, as a freshman at C.C. N.Y., I was having lunch with a friend, a Rabbi's son from Brooklyn, who was engrossed in an article describing the admissions practices of wellknown colleges and universities.

title: The World's Greatest Freak Show
description: Alastair Pflug may be the most insufferable antihero of the current picture  book sea son. When times are tough and food and money scarce, he re sorts to pawning his grandfa ther's teeth to buy himself a velvet cape; he also eats his pet cat. It's enough to turn you off by the second page of this odd and garish tale.

title: Braves Overtake Dodgers, 75, On Milan's Home Run in 9th
description: ATLANTA, May 1 (UPI) Felix Milian hit a tworun home run with two outs in the ninth inning tonight to cap a threerun rally and give the Atlanta Broves a 75 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Tito Hints at Crackdown On Domestic Dissenters
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 1President Tito today placed much of the blame for Yugo slavia's current political crisis on opponents abroad but also intimated that he would crack down on domestic dissent and probably shuffle both the Gov ernment and Communist party.

title: Television
description: AFTER you've wowed them with The Forsyte Saga, what do you do for an encore? The answer, at least for the Public Broadcast ing Service, is Masterpiece Theater.

title: Miss Madden Is Bride Here
description: Miss Patricia Ann Madden, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John L. Madden of New York, was married here yes terday afternoon to Roger Paul Favale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Favale of the Bronx.

title: City Official Asks Law Making Health Insurers Disclose More
description: The city's Health Service Ad ministrator proposed a state law last week requiring health insurance companies to tell pur chasers exactly what their poli cies do and do not cover.

title: Are Communists against Jews because Jews are against Communism?
description: In Prague slang udelat diru do sveta means making it. A clerk who takes over management of a small branch of his bank makes it: An tonin Novotny made it when he be came the President of the Republic, first secretary of the party, and had a mountain in the Kirgiz Soviet Re public named after him. The literal translation of the phrase is to make a hole in the world. The Czechs know that the world does not like having holes made in it. Failure is the integral part of their success stories.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: This is really a story about bunch of other animalsa bear and a pig, a squirrel, a hen and a hedge hog. The story is about a picnic that these animals have, on a raft in a lake. There are frogs in the story and they are even responsible for the happy ending, but it isn't like this is a significant contribution to the body of frog literature. It's simple story told in a friendly way with the happy illustrations of Quen tin Blake. But it's not something that a frog would get all excited about.

title: NORTH SEA WASTE WORRYING DUTCH
description: The HAGUE, April 30The Dutch have discovered that in fighting pollution their work is never done.

title: GORDON CAPTURES STAR CLASS RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 1 The first attempt at racing in midLong Island Sound on one of the Yacht Racing Asso ciation's new Olympictype courses couldn't be made to day when Larchmont Yacht Club opened the season with the first regatta of its pre Y.R.A. spring series.

title: RAID ON PANTHERS HAUNTING DALEY
description: CHICAGO, April 30Seven teen months ago, policemen attached to the Cook County state's attorney's office kicked in the door of a cramped, grubby apartment on the city's shabby West Side at 4:40 A.M.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Dr. Irving Gellman, 48, Dies; N.Y.U. Sociology Professor
description: Dr. Irving P. Gellman, associ ate professor of Sociology and chairman of the department of sociology at Washington Square College of New York Univer sity, was found dead by an as sociate in his apartment yester day. He was 48 years old and lived alone at 1 Washington Square Village. Death was at tributed to a heart attack.

title: Philadelphia Recalls An Alamo of Its Own
description: PHILADELPHIAThe tourists go to Independence Hall and Valley Forge but with the nomination of Philadelphia as the principal site for the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976, more visitors will be including Old Fort Mifflin in their round of Revo lutionary War monuments.

title: Stamps
description: DESIGNS, some new; some old, for new rate postage stamps have been released by Postmaster General Winton M. Blount. Mr. Blount has al so announced plans for two additional propaganda stamps this year  one to combat drug use, the other to recommend family plan ning. There will also be a commemorative postal card honoring Paul Revere, a fine silversmith, who really didn't complete the historic. the British are coming ride to Lexington and Concord as noted by the poet, Henry Wadsworth Longellow.

title: Bulls Enroll Weatherford
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)  Larry Weatherford of Purdue, a fifthround choice by the Chicago Bulls in the National draft, Association player draft, signed with the club today.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: ALMOST all the background news last week was decidedly constructive, but the stock market failed to take heart from it and instead endured a mild period of consolidation.

title: The World
description: Following hundreds of bomb ings, a rash of bank robberies and kidnappings and 19 deaths in student riots over a period of two years, Turkey's powerful military leadership last March 12 overthrew the government of Premier Suleyman Demirel be cause it had failed to end the chaos. A new regime under Nihat Erim was installed. Last Monday, the military decided that Premier Erim was not acting vigorously enough either. The generals forced the Government to de clare martial law in 11 of Tur key's 67 provinces, including the cities of Ankara, Istanbul and Izmir.

title: The Israelis Won It and I Was Going to Swim There whether or Not The Egyptians Liked It
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Occupied Terri tories, IsraelWhen I visited Is rael for the first time in 1968, I did the typical tourist bit and dropped in at a night club in Old Jaffa, outside Tel Aviv. A song was sting that evening called Sharm el Sheik and it celebrated both Israel's victory in the SixDay War of the previous year and the nation's capture of this remote point at the southern tip of the Sinai Peninsula. The tune haunted me (I didn't know what the words meant) and I bought an album containing the mel ody. Each time I listened to the record, I thought about how Sharm el Sheik lay virtually uninhabited and desolate at the edge of a desert well within the aircraft and missile range of hostile forces. I wondered whethr the Israeli soldiers stationed in Sharm  as the Israelis call it  lived in terror over their continual proximity to danger, and I was glad to be nowhere near that zone where death might strike in an in stant.

title: WALTER WAS A FROG
description: This is a nicely illustrated story of a young frog who thinks for awhile that birds and fish and turtles seem to have more fun than frogs. And they don't have to eat Lily Petal Broth. His mother watches with motherly love as Walter tries being something other than a frog. He is very funny and not very successful. Eventually, Walter learns that it's much better being a frogas I could have told you all alongand Lily Petal Broth isn't half bad with crackers.

title: The Bucks: Right Moves at Right Time
description: The 25th championship of the National Basketball As sociation belongs to the Mil waukee Bucks today and in that bare fact one can dis cern angles within angles within angles, almost like a physicist unraveling layer after layer of components within the apparently simple atom.

title: Rebuilt Plant Is a Symbol of Hope in Brooklyn
description: One of the most impressive of the 1,878 buildings that the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation has either rehabil itated or facelifted in Brooklyn is the organization's own $3.5 million home.

title: Ages 9 to 12: The Rails and the River
description: The many American young sters who have never ridden on a trainor even seen one will like this book. So will those who have. They'll find it a wellillustrated and fact filled history of our country's railroads told in terms of the trains and of the people who built and operated them.

title: Et Al.
description: A useful symposium on the interaction of U.S. and Soviet foreign policies within the United Nations arena. Seven papers in all, dealing with such matters as conflicting views of the U.N.'s role, U.S. and Soviet ideological systems, disarma ment, decolonization, seabed law and the inevitable conflict between large and smallpower interests, peacekeeping forces and the obstacles to the rule of international law binding the two giant powers. The tone is sober and not unduly pessi mistic.

title: 1776Before Broadway
description: With the approach of the bi centennial of the American Revolution, a proliferation of volumes on the historical back ground is expected: already, this movement has spread into the field of books for young people. An examination of the contents of the current spate reveals a surprisingly interest ing and colorful approach, and, in some cases, an original point of view.

title: Hospital Association Picks Officers
description: Charles Gellman, execu tive director of Jewish Me morial Hospital in Washing ton Heights since 1963, has been elected president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.

title: Lawrence E. Davies Dies at 71; Led Coast Bureau of The Times
description: COLLEGE, Alaska, May 1 Lawrence E. Davies, a New York Times reporter for 44 years, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. His age was 71. For the last year, since retiring from The Times, he had been the University of Alaska's Director of News Services.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: This frog book is not about your ordinary run of the mill, North Amer ican, U.S.A.type frog at all. No, in deedy. It's about a family of Latin Americantype frogs with names like Ranita and Dona Feliciana Ruin and Grandfather Don Rancual. In the story, a little girl frog known as Ranita the greenest, Ranita the lazi est, goes to market to buy a talking machine. And her grandfather sits in the cool shadows of a toadstool, drinking rum. And she eventually comes back with a parrot. It's all very Latin  American, and I didn't feel very comfortable with those LatinAmerican frogs. But the illus trations by Jacqueline Duhne are filled with fantasy and colorand a few rather unflattering renderings of frogs.

title: Et Al.
description: The marriages, divorces, trav els, political and social encoun ters that have made the Aga Khans the gossip  monger's delight. Rather well done, not the sexploitation job one might expect from the subject matter.

title: Art
description: THREE days hence, on May 5, the Museum of Modern Art will open an exhibition devoted to multiple works of artnot only prints but also three dimensional molded and as sembled objectsproduced in the California workshop en terprise known as Gemini G.E.L. (Graphic Editions Lim ited). The artists represented in the exhibition are not ex actly undiscovered: Josef Al bers, John Chamberlain, Ron Davis, Jasper Johns, Donald Judd, Ellsworth Kelly, Ed ward Kienholz, Roy Lichten stein, Claes Oldenburg, Ken Price, Robert Rauschenberg and Frank Stella. Whatever audacities Gemini G.E.L. may have ventured in the realm of technical productionand clearly, this workshop has already made an important contribution to the advance ment of the multiples in dustryit is not in the busi ness of ferreting out new talent. This is an enterprise strictly circumscribed by an interest in highly salable commodities that bear the names of very well known or very wellconnected artists.

title: Drug Use and Abuse: Policemen Examine the Books
description: By Mark Lieberman. 141 pp. Praeger. $5.95.

title: Finding Alex Hay: Gentle Maverick
description: ONE of the most fre quently and solemnly repeated artworld ut terances in the early 1960's was Robert Rauschen berg's gnomic remark, Painting relates to both art and life. Neither can be made. (I try to act in that gap between the two). It is difficult here in relatively unexcitable 1971 to credit with a Delphic ring this brash bandying of imponder ables (art and life, what ever they are, and that gap, as though it were the neighborhood pothole). But the early heyday of Pop and Minimal was a time of ar tistic boosterism, and Rauschenberg's motto ele gantly set forth one popular myth of the periodthat of the artist as a kind of demo cratic shaman, reconciling in his activity the opposite ex periences of the esthetic and the real, art and nonart, the special and the everyday.

title: Take a Closer Look
description: Handsomely produced on glossy stock, these two books are eyeopeners.

title: Windy Way Takes Realization Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 1 Windy Way, in command through most of the 1 1/16mile Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, yielded the advantage to Colonial, dropped a length behind, and with a furlong to go, Bob Williams, driving Windy Way, was ready to settle for second place.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The decision of the Department of Justice to ask for the dismissal of an injunction against veterans demon strating against the waran injunc tion which the Government had pressed as an emergency In the United States District Court for the District of Columbia through a threejudge panel of the Court of Appeals to the Supreme Court bespeaks contempt for the judicial processes which were invoked. [Editorial April 24.]

title: Wedding Is Set By Alicia Silva
description: PARAMUS, N. J., May 1 Rene Silva, professor of modern languages and chair man of the department at Fairleigh Dickinson Univer sity in Rutherford, and Mrs. Silva have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Alicia Silva, to Daniel G. Ritchie, a loan officer with the World Bank in Washington. The wedding is planned for July 31.

title: GALLORETTE WON BY COLD COMFORT
description: BALTIMORE, May 1 Al fred G. Vanderbilt's Cold Com fort, the oddson choice of a crowd of 14,904, outraced Dar ing Step in a thrilling stretch duel today and won the $32,650 Gallorette Handicap bY a nose at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Soviet Five to Tour U.S.
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., May 1 (UPI)The Soviet Union's na tional basketball team will op pose a team of college all stars here May 13 during a tour of the United States. The Soviet team will make its first stop May 11 at Rochester, N. Y., and, after playing here, go to Indianapolis, Amarillo, Tex., Lexington, Ky.; Cincinnati, Hicksville, Ky., and Salt Lake City.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Just a year ago, General Motors stated that a cor poration can only discharge its obligation to society if it continues to he a profitable investment for its stockhold ers. But it is time to re arrange these priorities: A corporation can only con tinue to be a profitable in vestment for its stockhold ers if it discharges its obliga lions to society.

title: Do Gooder in Action
description: SALT LAKE CITYJohn Dmytrick threatened to shoot his wife and himself. He didn't.

title: Housing: Where the Poor May Not Live
description: The town fathers of San Jose, Calif., decided three years ago to seek Federal financing for 1,000 lowrent housing units for the city's poor. But under a 1950 California law, such action by the City Council required ap proval by a majority of the com munity's voters (eight other states have similar laws). The project was vetoed by the voters.

title: Et A1.
description: Human interest account by the prolific British popular his torian (he has a book around on the Battle of Saratoga) of the imprisonment and deaths of the French King and Queers and the fate of their children. O.K., but nothing new.

title: The World
description: Henry Cabot Lodge, with an uncompromising vigor remini scent of his grandfather, spent eight years at the United Na tions resolutely resisting the seating of Communist China. In deed, as chief United States rep resentative, he prevented the problem from even being con sidered, through keeping it off the General Assembly agenda.

title: Jefferson Crowther, Bank Aide, And Alison Remy Are Married
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 1 Miss Alison Jane Remy, daughter of. Dr. Frank John Remy Jr., a dentist, and Mrs. Remy, was married here this afternoon to Jefferson Hay Crowther, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bosley Crowther of White Plains and Chilmark, Mass. The bridegroom's father is a former film critic of The New York Times.

title: ROGERS IN ARABIA ON PEACE MISSION
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 1 (AP)  Secretary of State William P. Rogers began his Middle East mission tonight with a message from President Nixon expressing United States willingness to play any reason able and useful role toward achieving a durable peace.

title: How to Throw Your Money AwayWith the Best of Them
description: OVER the last 50 years a total of 285 people have committed suicide at Monte Carlo. Some have been known to smile wryly as they slipped a pearlhandled Beretta out of a breast pocket and drilled an efficient, little hole in one temple. Others have cast themselves with an elegant flourish off the rocks into the nightdark sea. The suicides (and the authorities who must cope with these minor un pleasantnesses) always seem to play their roles with decorum. That's what one notices about gambling in Europe. Once, for example; when a man died of natural causes in a casino in the south of France where I was flirting with Lady Luck (as they used to say), the stretcherbearers were on the spot in less than 50 seconds and thus the gaming was not interrupted even by death.

title: CALIFORNIA FIGHTS OFFSHORE DRILLING
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 1 (AP)California has told nine oil companies to stop looking for oil along its 1,100mile coastline, scoring a victory for environmentalists who contend that geophysical activity will inevitably lead to drilling.

title: News of the Rialto
description: FOR even Tennessee Williams, one of the century's more prolific playwrights, ideas are not like bananas. They don't come in bunches and, when he gets one, he seems to hold onto it as if it might be his last. You need only recall the number of versions of The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore which, after failing the first time on Broad way, was rewritten and offered again still unsuccessfullyby a different pro ducer.

title: Festival in France
description: AFESTIVAL of avant garde music in an out ofseason French sea side resort may sound like a Dantesque penitentiary for delinquent critics. In fact, Royan, a small town on the estuary of the Gi ronde, some 80 miles north of Bordeaux, is one of Eu rope's most lively and enjoy able festivals of new music.

title: The Political Tidal Wave That Struck East Pakistan
description: IT would be professionally grati fying but inaccurate to say to day that on Feb. 28 when our plane landed routinely on the airfield of East Pakistan's capital city, Dacca, we had premonitions of the gripping, tragic human and political drama that was to be played out in its sprawling, disheveled precincts dur ing the succeeding weeks.

title: Miss Bacon, Before a U.S. Jury, Denies Knowing of Capitol Blast
description: SEATTLE, May 1  Leslie Bacon has told a Federal grand jury that she knows nothing about the bombing on March 1 of the United States Capitol, her attorneys said today. She testified under detention as a material witness.

title: The New Movies In Town
description: DERBY is discussed by Vin cent Canby on Page 1.

title: David Wartels, Publishing Aide, To Marry Penelope W. Johnson
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 1Miss Penelope Wyatt Johnson, assistant to the food and wine editor of House and Garden magazine in New York, will be married to David E. Wartels, adminis trative assistant to the vice president in charge of opera tions of the Crown Publish ing Company in New York.

title: Blazers Sign Yelverton
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 1 (AP)  The Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basket ball Association today signed Charles Yelverton, a guard from Fordham, to a threeyear contract. Terms were not dis closed.

title: Not built in a day
description: For Cuba the years since the Revolution have been so tu multuous that it is easy to forget or ignore the previous four and a half centuries of the island's history. Yet there is much in that history that explains how Fidel Castro could come to power in 1959 and ??ain power so effectively since then.

title: Letters:
description: The interesting article by Arthur S. Harris Jr. about Boston's Logan International Airport (Travel section, April 11) reminded me of an experi ence my wife and I had. When we decided to come home from a European trip we recalled with dismay how our vacation had started with a terrible trip from our home in New Jersey to Kennedy Airport and all the headaches associated with that airport. So I inquired in London if, on arriving back at Kennedy, we could get a free helicopter ride from there to Newark Airport, or at least a trip at halfprice. (We live only a few miles from Newark.) I was told that this was not possible, but the ticket agent offered a great solution. He said that if we would return via Boston's Logan we would be entitled to a free flight to Newark by either National or Eastern.

title: ABORTION CLINIC STIRS UP MADISON
description: MADISON, Wis., May 1  A threat from the state medical examining board to suspend his license to practice has forced Dr. Alfred L. Kennan to delay the reopening of Madison's first abortion clinic. The clinic was closed in a police raid on April 19.

title: Sirhan as a patriot, Ray as a decoy
description: The silly season apparently is over so far as the critics of the Warren Commission are concerned. The whole business left Mark Lane with a pot of money, Jim Garrison with a badly tarnished reputation and mil lions of American liberals with a feeling of having been taken.

title: Semantics of Budgets Spell Ouch to Taxpayer
description: A survival budgetMa yor Lindsay's capsule of the spending plan for 197172 that he made public yester daywas the latest in an annual series of such charac terizations by the Mayor and his budget aides.

title: Parents Urged to Immunize Children Against Polio
description: Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin, the City Health Commissioner, has warned parents to make sure their children are fully immunized against polio before summer.

title: Gary Player Will Compete In Canadian Open July 14
description: MONTREAL, May 1 (UPI) Gary Player will be in the field for the 1971 Canadian open at Montreal's Richelieu Valley Golf and Country Club July 1 through 4.

title: Reader's Report
description: Like Call It Sleep and Good Morning, Midnight, Ali & Nino is an artifact of the 1930's, miraculously sal vaged from obscurity. (It was originally published in Vienna in 1937, its pseudonymous au thor subsequently vanishing into Italy.) The achievement of Kurban Said, was to make a distillate of two points of viewEast and Westto tinc ture a chapter of social history that reads like an epic poem.

title: Gardens
description: GARDENERS in the Northeast often plant bright red borders of salvia around their homes and patios. They may not realize it, but this plant has some fascinating relatives in South America.

title: Twins Down Red Sox, 73
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)Jim Perry yielded three quick runs, then settled down and pitched and batted the Minnesota Twins to a 73 victory today over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Port Jefferson, Fond of Yesterday, Copes With Today
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., May 1  My grandfather and greatgrandfather built squarerigged sailing ships in the boatyards here, said Charles Bishop, who is 84, from a seat in the dining room at the Elk Hotel here.

title: QUEENS BANK PLAN ANGERS RESIDENTS
description: A swimming pool, a tennis court and plans for a new bank form the improbable in gredients of a controversy in the normally quiet Linden wood section of Queens.

title: Wedding on June 20 For Laura Kaplan
description: NEWTON, Mass. May 1 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard I. Kaplan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura J. Kaplan, to Bruce E. Wexler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Wexler of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for June 20.

title: CHINA SEES MORAL IN A MING TOMB
description: PEKING, May 1  The tomb of Wan Li, a 16th cen tury Ming Emperor, situated in a gentle valley of fruit trees and wheat fields 50 miles northwest of Peking, has been made into a prime propaganda showpiece by the People's Re public of China.

title: Reelected Leader Promises Koreans Positive Diplomacy
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 1 President Chung Hee Park, who won a third fouryear term in Tuesday's national election, said in a victory statement to day that he would pursue a positive and pragmatic diplom acy in the future.

title: Black to Join French Team
description: PARIS, May 1The French Rugby Committee reversed it self today and selected a black player, Roger Bourgarel of Toulouse, to join an allstar team to tour South Africa. The original omission of Bourgarel from the 27man squad aroused strong protests by French fans who suspected the committee of submitting to South Africa's racial policies.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: There's No Damper on Derby Day
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1It must be assumed that the folks who thronged Churchill Downs for the Kentucky Derby were all good little boys and girls who went to bed early and didn't listen to the premidnight weather forecasts. Or maybe they were not so good and were doing too much partying to pay attention to meteor logical soothsaying. At any rate, they de scended on this ancient cavalry post in what seemed to be nearrecord numbers today.

title: Cards Purchase Zachary
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals pur chased Chris Zachary, a right handed pitcher, from their Tulsa farm club last night.

title: Uganda President to Curb Nationalization Plans
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 1 Uganda's President, Gen. Idi Amin, announced today that his Government would substan tially curtail the programs of the deposed former President, Milton A. Obote, aimed at na tionalizing industry and com merce.

title: Students Test Skill At a Flying Contest
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 1 The singleengine plane flew out of a silver haze and leveled off. It was about 200 feet above a white automobile tire on the ground. A tiny pink balloon filled with water dropped out of the plane, fell toward the tire and splashed about 20 feet away from the target.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONThis is going to be our last big fight, an American officer said before the allied op eration in the Ashau Valley be gan. But subsequent events have not borne out his prediction.

title: City Club Calls for Overhauling of Government Here
description: A thorough overhaul of New York City's government  to eliminate some functions and bureaucracy, turn over other tasks to private enterprise and seek state legislative relief from some city employe benefits was proposed yesterday by the City Club.

title: Et Al.
description: A young Briton tells of his trip from the seedy depths of a hippy community in Istanbul to anticipated nirvana in Kat mandu. Assorted companions join and drop out as the group wends its way via friendly Turkish lorrydrivers (who try to charge fare at the end of the line), primitive buses, trains, foot; they encounter ar bitrary policemen, suspicious border guards, venal innkeep ers and breathtaking scenery. The writing is vivid, impres sonistic, novelistic, giving an unforgettable picture of the shabby horde Evelyn Waugh, writing in 1945 of other people in other places, presciently de scribed as lean, lawless, aim less couples with rucksacks, joining the great army of men and women without papers, without official existence, the refugees and deserters who drift everywhere today between barbed wire. They all share the belief, as the author points out: that in a different place they will become different people.

title: NORTHPORT CURBS A YOUTH PROBLEM
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., May 1 The Northport Village Park closes at 11 P.M. now, and gardeners have removed many Aruba and pruned others se verely.

title: Art
description: THERE is a big Drer show in Washington just now at the Na tional Gallery of Art, celebrating the 500th anni versary of the, artist's birth in Nuremberg on May 21, 1471, and there is also a little show called The Art of the Comic Strip at the University of Maryland in College Park, a hamlet lying somewhere between Wash ington and Baltimore, that must also have attention here this week.

title: C. W. POST WINS IN TRACK CONTEST
description: Ron Stonitsch scored an easy double in the mile and two mile to lead C. W. Post to vic tory in a triangular track meet with St. John's and Adelphi at St. John's yesterday.

title: Miss Gould Sets World Swimming Mark
description: LONDON, May 1 (AP)Shane Gould, 14 years old, bettered the world record for the wom en's 200meter freestyle today while helping Australia top the United States by 1 point in a 14nation swimming tourna ment.

title: C. W. Post Alumni May Take Classes Free in September
description: GREENVALE, L.I., May 1 A free tuition plan that will enable all alumni of C. W. Post to take undergraduate courses at the college will go into ef fect in September.

title: Ecology Corps Created For C.O.'s by Reagan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 1 (AP)Creation of a Cali fornia Ecology Corps made up chiefly of conscientious ob jectors to the draft has been announced by Gov. Ronald Reagan. The men would vol unteer to work in conserva tion camps at $15 a month.

title: STAN SMITH GAINS PARIS TENNIS FINAL
description: PARIS, May 1 (UPI)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., won a grueling service duel with the French Davis Cup player Pierre Barthes, 62, 57, 62, 64, today to advance to to morrow's final in the Paris open tennis championships.

title: Leads and Arsenal Register Shutout Victories in British Soccer League
description: LONDON, May 1, Reuters The English Soccer League championship remained wide open today after firstplace Leeds United beat Nottingham Forest, 20, and Arsenal edged Stoke City, 10.

title: Pilyo The Piranha
description: Can a picture book that stars a greedy piranha and has a supporting cast that includes a sloth, a boa constrictor, a jaguar and a harpy eagle be all bad? The answer is no. But it's not all good, either. Pilyo, the book's antihero, swims in a school (or perhaps I should say a cavity) of snagglemouthed piranhas. The sloth resembles Margaret Rutherford in a hairy fur coat. The boa constrictor is obviously first cousin to Tomi Ungerer's Crictor. But for all the expres sive line drawingsthey are delightful and amusingthe tale itself is curiously inept. It has a Perils of Pauline flavor with out a resolution. Pilyo saves the sleeping sloth from one would be gormand after another, saves it for his own supper, that is. But the sloth is neither eaten nor saved, but merely stored away, still sleeping. For the next Pilyo book?

title: Is He Really Serious About Becoming President? Yes.
description: HIS hamburger is getting cold, his glass of milk warm and his time short. George McGovern is strolling around Mavis's Sun nyside Cafe, an old diner on the road from the Milwaukee airport, intro ducing himself to all the people who hadn't recognized him a few minutes before: Hello, I'm George McGovern ...Hello, I'm... He seems genu inely content talking plain talk with plain people. Nice guy.

title: Ohio Beautician Is First in W.I.B.C. AllEvents
description: ATLANTA, Ga., May 1 (AP) Karen Van Cleave of Barber ton, Ohio, a 19yearold beauti cian in only her second season of adult bowling competition, rolled into first place today in Division Two allevents of the Women's International Bowling Congress tournament.

title: Brigadier Gerard Wins 2,000 Guineas Classic
description: NEWMARKET, England, May 1 (AP)  Brigadier Ge rard, an 112 shot, galloped up the final hill at Newmar ket today and scored a three length victory in the one mile 2,000 Guineas race for 3yearolds.

title: Vermont College Post Filled
description: LYNDONVILLE, Vt. May 1 (AP)Dr. H. Franklin Irwin, dean of Castleton State College, has been named president of Lyndon State College. His ap pointment as successor to Dr. Robert E. Long was announced last Wednesday.

title: Rosalie C. Aldrich Is Affianced To Hugh Allen West, a Student
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., May 1The engagement of Miss Rosalie Choate Aldrich, a senior at Stanford Uni versity, to Hugh Allen West, a doctoral candidate in his tory at Stanford, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nelson W. Aldrich, parents of the prospective bride.

title: The Last Knife
description: The Last Knife is a brave book about bravery  not the bravery of the mob or the militia, but of the individual strong enough to stand up against organized power when he believes it is evil.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: When a little boy like Andy finds a neat thing like a frog he has to find a good home for it. A number of places turn out to be very much not good homes for frogsMother's mixing bowl, the canary's cage, the bath tub, etc. A sad ending is just around the corner when a friend comes along and shows Andy what to do. It is a pleasant story told in simple sentences that beginner readers can handle, and the book is colorfully illustrated. It rates a frog recommendation.

title: A most seductive dessert
description: That clear white spirit called kirsch, a fine brandy distilled from cherries, imparts a seductive flavor to many European desserts. The torte described below is among the most agree able of kirschflavored desserts. Note, please, that imported kirschfrom Switzerland, Germany or France's Alsace is infinitely superior to our domestic product, which is not even cm acceptable imitation.

title: A Race for Listings
description: The stock market, as every investor knows, is off and running these days.

title: United Fund Drive Opens
description: The United Fund of Greater New York has started its third annual campaign to help 425 hospital, health and so cial service agencies and the Red Cross the world's largest local network of community services. Last year, United Fund agencies assisted nearly four million people from all walks of life. Contributions to the fund help these community serv ices to meet many problems that may sooner or later af fect all of us. By pledging to support hospitals, the aged, blood collection disaster re lief, the handicapped, the blind, emotionally disturbed, donors insure that their dol lars will quickly go to help people with problems that must be dealt with immedi ately, minute by minute, and every day throughout the year.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: Here's the best frog book of all, and it's not even about frogs, hardly. It's a quiet, sensitive story about a boy, Christopher, who decides to catch a frog. The book is illustrated with beautiful, delicate drawings by Deborah Ray, who must be a very nice person. In her drawings, she has found the tender moments be tween a child and his mother. Chris topher talks to his mother while she takes care of the baby and does all those everyday mothertype things. I'm going to catch a frog, Christo pher says. You'll have to stand very still and be very quiet, his mother says. After several frogless attempts, Christopher finally sees some frogs, but he doesn't try to catch them, he just watches them. He watches them for a long, long, long, long time. And then he runs happily home and tells his mother all about the frogs. She kisses him on the cheek, and the book ends very quietly, and somehow I feel all mistyeyed and lumpy in my throat because it's all so lovely and just right. This is a very special book and rates the very highest frog rec ommendation.

title: Trade War At Airports Stirs Berlin
description: BERLIN, May 1 (AP)A busi ness war is under way between airports in East and West Ber lin.

title: Ford never refused to help a lame dog or a promising genius
description: What the reader hopes most to see in a biography is the work of the intelligent scholar who also feels an affinity for his subject. For Ford Madox Fordwho had greatness, who did so much for the cause of letters, who was intuitively kind to other writers everywhere but to whom un kindness has often been done in re turn  for Ford, in particular, his reader would hope he would fall into good hands.

title: CONGRESS IS CALM ON CHINA MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, May 1In contrast to the political storm that many people believe would have erupted in the past, Pres ident Nixon's initiatives toward closer relations with Commu nist China have been calmly approved on Capitol Hill.

title: Ambassador's Home Is Target of Bomb in Paris
description: PARIS, May 1Extra police were stationed at the American Embassy and other American installations here today follow ing a bomb blast that blew out windows at the residence of Ambassador Arthur K. Watson.

title: A RABBI PROPOSES 10 COLLEGES IN U.S.
description: American Jews must estab lish 10 colleges throughout the country as a powerful coun terthrust to secular influences on Jewish youth, according to Rabbi Bernard L. Berzon, presi dent of the influential Rabbini cal Council of America.

title: Kristts Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born April 14 to Dr. and Mrs. Donald A. Kristt of New York at the University Hos tal. Mrs. Kristt is the former Miss Margaret Haines, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Haines of Forest Hills, Queens. Dr. Kristt, an interne at Bellevue Hospital, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Kristt of Bronxville, N. Y. Mr. Kristt is president of the Mackay Publishing Corpora tion, publisher of trade mag azines. The child has been named Alisa Lynn.

title: Olympic Standards of Today More Rigid Than Ever Before
description: Olympic officials in an ef fort to reduce traffic jams in track and field events at Mu nich, are making it tough to qualify for the 1972 games. Most of the athletes who won gold medals from 1896 to 1952 wouldn't be allowed in the field if they had to qualify under rigid standards now in effect.

title: Rangers Fit, Hawks Tired For Chicago Finale Today
description: Only a dozen fans said good by and good luck to the Rangers yesterday after the club finished a workout and left for Chicago, where they were to face the Black Hawks today in the sev enth and deciding game of their Stanley Cup series.

title: CANONERO II, $19.40, WINS DERBY;
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1  Canonero II bombarded the form players today by crashing through to one of the most sur prising victories in the 97year history of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Veiled Wonder Wins Dash At Golden Gate, Pays $5.60
description: ALBANY, Calif., May 1 (UPI)  Veiled Wonder became the first 2yearold to win two stakes races this season in Cali fornia when he dashed to a 2length triumph today in the $25,000 added Juvenile Dinner Stakes at Golden Gate Fields.

title: Violets
description: May means violets, and violets mean spring. Hepatica blooms before the violets, and usually the anemones and bloodroot are in bloom when the first violets manage to come to flower. But violet time really marks the turn. After the violets appear, the whole flowery flood May begins.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: A virtual revolution has taken place in the types of fabric going into apparel. On Seventh Avenue, the source of most fashioned wo men's wear, and on Sixth Avenue (Avenue of the Americas if you will) from whence flow styled men's garments, the topic most dis cussed is availability of knit goods, now a mainstay for all clothing makers.

title: Turning a Profit With Computers
description: The Union Carbide Cor poration has turned a com puter problem into a profit.

title: Lowenstein Named A.D.A. Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, Ieader of the Dump Johnson movement in the Presidential campaign of 1968 and active now in a drive to oust President Nixon in 1972, was elected chairman of Ameri cans for Democratic Action to day at the group's 24th national convention.

title: The Easiest Iris To Grow
description: DARK pansypurples, bright pure blues and sparkling whites are the major colors of the Siberian irises. They bloom about the same time as the more popular tall bearded irises, but are easier to grow. A few varieties have extended bloom periods, putting forth sporadic displays until midsummer.

title: STUDY OF SPEAKING IN TONGUES ISSUED
description: A study conducted by the Lutheran Medical Center of Brooklyn has concluded that persons who engage in glossa lalia, or speaking in tongues, are no more or less emotion ally healthy than other persons but that they tend to have strong needs to submit them selves to some external au thority.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: O'Brien Wins Mile, 2Mile As Princeton Defeats Yale
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 1  Dennis O'Brien, a Princeton senior, won both the mile and twomile races today to help the Tigers to an 8668 track victory over Yale.

title: Taxi Industry Takes Diplomatic Initiative
description: The city's taxi industry has begun a campaign to change its most popular slogan from Off duty to Let's be friends.

title: BRITISH BAND MAKES DEBUT AT FILLMORE
description: There must be some relation ship between audiences who go to stock car races to see crashes and ones who go to the Fillmore East to watch somebody drop an organ.

title: Mr. Nixon's Nyet
description: There is much to be said for President Nixon's argu ment, repeated at his latest news conference, that setting a date for American withdrawal from Vietnam would destroy any incentive the enemy might have to nego tiate. But that argument loses much of its force when the Administration rejects out of hand two new Commu nist peace proposals in Paris, as it did that very day. Limited and ambiguous as those proposals are, they deserve exploration, if only because they include an overture for secret talks.

title: Wombats in the Outback
description: Would you rather be some place else? You're not alone. A recent Gallup Poll found one American in eight nursing a desire to move abroad, and a third of those interviewed named Australia as the place they'd like to go. Why Aus tralia? Why not, when they seem to have most of the good things we once had  an un polluted land, an unfettered way of life, a sense of un tamed frontierand none of the bad ones, like unsatis factory air and garbage that won't go away.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. and Rumania in Late Stage Of Talks on Joint Oil Ventures
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Rumania is in an advanced state of negotiations with United States corporations for joint ventures in offshore oil drilling in the Black Sea and the building of petroleum re fineries in Rumania.

title: Danny tries to avoid the draft and to evade life
description: Getting Out is a novel about the curse of being young and middle class. Deadcenter middle class. Our hero, one Danny Mordi, is a war baby, conceived at the end of the last war, come of age at the beginning of this one. Grow ing up in between, in the fif ties, in the middle of the mid dle class, meant growing up thinking you can get out of anything  from mowing the lawn to dying. Even, you think, being middle class. There is no past to live up to, like the rich, none to live down, like the poor. The future seems as permissive as Dr. Spock parents.

title: Mrs. Nell Guntharp Married to the Rev. Ernest Stires
description: FREDERICA, Ga., May 1 Mrs. Nell Kilgore Guntharp, postmaster in Sea Island, was married in Christ Episcopal Church here today to the Rev. Ernest Van Rensselaer Stires, who has made his home in Sea Island since retiring as rector of St. James's Episcopal Church in Lake George, N. Y.

title: Andrew Namm Becomes Fiance Of Anne Bresler
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., May 1  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Bresler of the en gagement, of their daughter, Miss Anne M. Bresler, to Andrew Irving Namm. He is the son of Mrs. Benjamin Harrison Namm of New York and the late Mr. Namm, who had been chairman of Namm Loeser's, Inc., which operated Brooklyn and Long Island de partment stores.

title: On the Banks Of the Hudson
description: A View of Its History and Folklore. By Beman Lord. Illustrated by Rocco Negri. 63 pp. New York: Henry Z. Watch. $4.50.

title: Theater: Equity Revives a Musical
description: What a novelty it would be, in a musical needling thick skulled, set American tradi tions, to see the bad guys the old reactionary ostriches presented as something less than diehard dimwits. The good guys? They're alto gether admirable. The other side  impossible, except to long for the simple life. That's their one attribute.

title: Law
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Wil liam S. Lynch, the special prosecutor for the Depart ment of Justice in the case against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five others, turned a restrained grin to questioning reporters here last Friday and assured them he was being a conservative lawyer when he termed new kidnapping charges just banded down by the grand jury as substantially the same as the earlier charges they were designed to replace.The wording, Mr. Lynch said carefully, is exactly the same.

title: The Flip Side of Books
description: I haven't read the book but I heard the record.

title: Sience/Medicine
description: Since the dawn of time, mankind has been locked in mortal struggle with the in sectand it has, for the most part, been a losing battle. Straining his ingenuity to the utmost, man has conceived of a virtually infinite number of weapons to accomplish his lethal ends: the production of sex attractants to lure the enemy into a trap ... the loosing of natural predators on the pests ... the devel opment of chemical killers ...the sterilization of insects, which are then sent forth to mate fruitlessly.

title: Rhythm Is Used to Teach Pupils To Find Their Own Beat in Life
description: All the children at Pub lic School 57 in the Bronx have rhythm and the educational ob jective is for each to find his own beat.

title: President Describes Auto He Uses in Vacation Driving
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) President Nixon has what he calls an unobtrusive Lincoln for pleasure driving in Washington and at his vacation spots, he told Henry Ford 2d at the White House this week.

title: Merrill: New Stage
description: Wall Street history will be made in a month or so when Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, throws open its doors to the public with a fourmillion share offering of its own stock.

title: Expos, Cards Play Tie
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP)The Montreal Expos and St. Louis, Cardinals played to a 22 tie tonight in a game called after seven innings because of rain. There had been a 35minute rain delay in the fourth inning.

title: Nurse of the Year Honored
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) Vivian Patridge, this year's Nurse of the Year, was hon ored this week by Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, and officials of the American Psychiatric Associa tion.

title: RUTGERS CREW WINS FROM LIONS' EIGHT
description: Rutgers varsity heavyweight crew outrowed Columbia from the start and defeated the Lion eight by four lengths in a dual race on the Harlem River yes terday

title: Ages 9 to 12: Echoes of Other Days, Other Ways
