description: I believe in The Borrow ers, those brave, resourceful little people who live hidden in old houses and are respon sible for all items that disap pearpins and thimbles and matchboxes  which they use ingeniously to sustain their lives. Everybody who has read any of Mary Norton's four books about them must believe their world is quite real and so are the characters, foremost among them practical Pod (fa ther), homeloving Homily (mother) and their adventurous freesoul daughter Arrietty, who talks to humans despite the dangerous consequences of being seen and having to emigrate from safe lodgings into the unknown world be yond.

title: Dunning of Indians Fans 13 and Limits A's to Six Hits in 2to1 Triumph
description: OAKLAND, May 1 (AP) Steve Dunning, a strong right hander, allowed only six hits and struck out 13 men in pitch ing the Cleveland Indians to a 21 triumph over the Oakland Athletics today. He had ninth inning help from Chuck Mache mehl.

title: Prolonged Fight to Save Albany's 70YearOld Union Station Appears to Be Ending in Final Defeat
description: ALBANY, May 1The citi zens of this city who Sought for years to retain their 70 yearold Union Station as a railroad depot and, when that failed, tried to keep it as a his toric landmark, appeared today to be facing final defeat.

title: Account of Writers' Ouster Disputed by South Vietnam
description: A spokesman here for the South Vietnamese Government said yesterday that a dispatch in The New York Times on Wednesday contained an error in its account of how Don Luce, an American writer, was ordered to leave South Viet nam.

title: TENNIS CHALLENGES THE OLYMPIC CODE
description: LONDON, May 1 (AP) World tennis officials have challenged the International Olympic Committee to think again about professional and amateur athletes to competing together.

title: Yale Students Take Workers' Demands To Brewster Home
description: NEW HAVEN, May 1More than 150 Yale students, chant ing Support Yale workers and carrying lunch trays, marched this noon to the home of Yale's president, Kingman Brewster.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: Now here's a great book. Here is a delightful story. Here is frogdom at its finest. It's all about this really neat froggylooking frog, who's great fun and who really enjoys being frog. And he meets this witch who comes swimming across the pond wearing her goggles and carrying her soggy peanut butter sandwich. And she turns him into a Prince, which he doesn't like being, because, as some of us know, being a frog is pretty good life. Anyhow, the story goes on, and it has some more magic spells and some funny and warm and witty dialogue and it all works out in the end, and I loved it. And most of all, it's all delightfully illus trated with a free and easy sense of humor by John Heinly. This is the first book for both Elinor Horwitz and John Heinly, and I hope they will do many more.

title: Dance: Stuttgart's Best Program Yet
description: Although the reputation of John Cranko's Stuttgart Bal let has, to a very large ex tent, been based upon their fullevening spectaculars, the company's first mixed bill of the season, given at the Met ropolitan Opera House on Friday night, proved the best program of the engagement so far.

title: Fairfax's New Problem: Rowing Across Pacific
description: Many of John Fairfax's hardships, as he puts it, are nobody's fault but his own. After all, nobody made him hunt jaguars in the Amazon, bicycle across North America, run from Customs agents in Central America or row singlehanded across the Atlantic.

title: HATCHER BATTLES FOR 2D GARY TERM
description: GARY, Ind. May 1On two occasions this week, Mayor Richard G. Hatcher asked a Fed eral court to prevent the re moval of the names of 3,500 voters, most of them blacks, from the election rolls in next Tuesday's primary. Both times he lost.

title: Et Al.
description: Still another account of the riots at Columbiaperhaps the most reported event since the Crucifixion. Rosenkrantz, who was doing research at the School of Journalism at the time, intersperses his wry, tough narrative with tapere corded recollections of the stu dents. Interesting, shirtsleeve contemporary history.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: TIE WIGGLER

title: A Friend, A Father And A Nephew
description: The Bearman had two friends: the bear and Dear God. ... There were only three unusual things about himhe could understand the lan guage of bears, he was kind, and he could juggle seven balls. The bear, a dancing bear, is the protagonist in this tender story, a creature more humane than human around whom revolve the people, the animals, the seasons in prose as peaceful and remote as the stars in the Bearman's nightly tales. Events are like whirl pools in a quiet riversudden, vio lent, brief: a fight with the jealous Dudas, an attack by fierce dogs, a dreary trek with gypsies. Otherwise, it was always the same, with the Bearman and the bear traveling slowly along the roads and through the years, taking three steps to each breath.

title: Columbia Lightweights Top Rutgers and Georgetown
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 1Columbia's lightweight varsity crew rowed to an easy victory over Rutgers and Georgetown today under ideal conditions on the Raritan River.

title: Bay State Heroin Deaths
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)The head of the Federal Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs Bureau in Boston says there were 130 heroin deaths in Massachusetts last year. Richard D. Callahan, in making the statement Wednesday, opposed efforts to liberalize laws on marijuana saying, There is not enough research data to show what the longrange effects of fre quent use of marijuana would produce.

title: President's War Powers Face State and Federal Legal Tests
description: HARTFORD, May 1In at least 10 state capitals as well as in Washington, lawmakers have begun to question the ex tent of the President's author ity in undeclared wars such as Vietnam.

title: Football's Labor Woes Persist
description: About Pro Football

title: Miss Nicole Sweedler Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Eisen berg of Brooklyn Heights and Ludingtonville, N. Y., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nicole J. Sweedler, to Rich ard R. Metzner of New York.

title: Criminals At Large
description: They assure us, at the Penta gon and from the White House, that our nuclear system is fool proof. But we remember things: hydrogen bombs falling in Spanish waters; sheep killed from nerve gas. And it all con tributes to the international angst. How much have we not been told? We shiver. And three books dealing with the subject may make us shiver a bit more. All have to do with the Bomb. All suggest that in our crazy world every even tuality is possible.

title: LINDSAY SUBMITS SURVIVAL BUDGET PUT AT 9.13 BILLION
description: Mayor Lindsay disclosed yes terday the details of a $9.13 billion city budget for the next fiscal year in the formal pres entation of what he called a survival budget and nothing more.

title: Derby Victor Pays City's Bettors $59
description: Bettors who backed Cano nero II yesterday in the Ken tucky Derby through the New York Offtrack Betting Cor poration's pool on the race will collect three times as much money in win wager ing as the horse's supporters at Churchill Downs in Louis ville, Ky.

title: South African Welcomes Move by Ivory Coast Chief
description: PIETERMARITZBURG, South Africa, May 1 (Reuters)For eign Minister Milgard Muller today welcomed the offer by President Felix Houphouet Boigny of the Ivory Coast to enter into a dialogue with South Africa.

title: DANCE FOR 6 GIVEN BY AILEY COMPANY
description: Joyce Trisler's Dance for Six is not a ballet for thinking about but simply for enjoying. It places three boys, and three girls upon stage to weave beautiful and sometimes star tling patterns for the duration of a Vivaldi concerto. Friday evening the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater presented the work for the first time during its City Center season.

title: 3 INDICTED IN JERSEY ON EXTORTION COUNT
description: NEWARK, May 1A key figure in the alleged organized crimeteamster union alliance in the air freight business has been indicted on conspiracy and extortion charges with two New York teamster officials, it was announced this week.

title: U.S. Hijacker Out of Jail To the Bravos of Italians
description: ROME, May 1Raffaele Mini chiello, the AWOL United States marine who hijacked an airliner at rifle point from California to Rome 18 months ago; timidly stepped out of jail today, a free man and something of an Italian folk hero.

title: Mail Service Ended By U.S. Consulates In Western Europe
description: Beginning yesterday, Ameri cans living or traveling in West ern Europe may no longer pick up their mail at United States embassies and consulates.

title: Litter Is Making Expressways Junkyards
description: The Long Island Express way, sometimes called the world's longest parking lot, is fast becoming the world's longest junkyard as well.

title: Drug Use and Abuse: Policemen Examine the Books
description: The concept and presentation of the book is terrific. The idea of using large type with not too many words on a page backed up by illustrations is excellent. It answers the basic questions on drugs in a simple and direct manner that will reach the kids that we deal with. It will in form them about drug abuse and how it affects the abuser, and it comes very close to stimulating the reader with creative thought.

title: NATIVE ROYALTY VICTOR IN CARTER
description: Harbor View Farm's Native Royalty, blanked in seven pre vious attempts this season to get into the winners' circle, finally made it at Aqueduct yesterday by winning the $58, 800 Carter Handicap before 43,269 fans.

title: B52's Attack Ambush Area in Ashaul
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May I (AP)  United States R.52 bombers staged new raids in the Ashau Valley sector in the north Saturday in an at tempt to strike at North Viet namese troops who ambushed an American patrol.

title: SHIFT IN CAROLINA PERILS A WAR FOE
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 1Re alignment of North Carolina's Congressional districts has threatened the political career of Representative Nick Galifi anakis, a moderate antiwar Democrat first elected in 1966.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: A.A.U. Award Voted To Cheryl Toussaint
description: Cheryl Toussaint of Brook lyn's Atoms Track Club, a threetime allAmerican, has won the annual Meritorious Award of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONA promise to dis cuss means nothing from the North Vietnamese, President Nixon said at his news conference. Maybe not, but would be hard to prove it the way the President tried to do.

title: Chileans Win Doubles
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (UPI) Jaime Fillol and Patricio Cornejo of Chile won the men's doubles championship in the 79th Rio De La Plata tennis tournament today with a 75, 86 victory over Tomas Koph and Jose Mandarino of Brazil.

title: ANNUAL MEETING TAKES GOLD CUP
description: WARRENTON, Va., May 1 (AP)Annual Meeting, ridden by J. L. Aitcheson Jr., overtook Chapel Street after the 21st fence today and galloped to a threelength victory in the 46th running of the Virginia Geld Cup.

title: Shazam! Here Comes Captain Relevant
description: Envision a scene in a comic book: In Panel 1, two New York City policemen are pointing skyward with their jaws hanging open and one is saying, Wha . . .? They are looking at four or five men and women, shown in Panel 2 plummeting through the air feet first, as though riding surfboards. The dominant fig ure has a black long coat thrown over his shoulders, wears a peaked, flatbrim hat and carries a cane. As the group lands on the street and enters the Vision Building, Panel 3, a hairy hip figure on the sidewalk observes to a friend: Fellini's in town.

title: Nicholas Ryder Parks Marries Miss Carole S. Leonard Here
description: St. James's Episcopal Church here was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Carole Susan Leonard, daughter of Warren Grant Leonard of Houston, and Antigua, W. I., and Nicholas Ryder Parks, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Parks of New York and Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: Vietnam Veteran Seeks Discharge as Objector
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 1 (UPI)An Army major, a vet eran of Vietnam, filed suit in Federal District Court this week asking his discharge on the ground that he is a con scientious objector.

title: $100,000 Duel in Women's Tennis
description: The duel is on for $100,000 in women's tennis.

title: Finally a Pope who believed in God
description: Meeting Borges is like reading him; to meet Borges is to read him. He talks mostly about literature or the life he has led in literature, and in shapely clever English sentences he says things about himself that You have to read or will read in his es says, stories, legends, lampoons  so many of which deal with the life he has led in literature, with the favor ite late19thcentury English authors from whom he regularly takes off, with the blindness that regularly steals up on members of his family. Now nearblind (I can see that there are windows there but I cannot see your face), his gentlemanliness even more pronounced than his gentleness, his tremulous but controlled sensibil ity (which seems located in the large flaring nostrils turned up to receive the outside world, in the uplifted at tentively humble face of the blind) the face he presents is that of a writer writing.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The net income of the na tion's farmers, which slipped slightly last year, is expected to decline further this year.

title: Education
description: A quiet revolution is tak ing place among graduates of the highprestige colleges. Many are losing interest in advanced degrees.

title: Study Finds Priests' Morale Here Is Low
description: A study sponsored by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has found that a majority of the priests within the diocese have lower morale and less job satisfaction than that of comparable groups of professionals.

title: Offstage Drama: Hoist the Flag Gets A New Cast on Leg
description: In the quiet of Belmont Park, far from yesterday's noisy proceedings at Louis ville and the Kentucky Derby, Hoist the Flag passed an im portant test.

title: Teenage Fiction: Finding Out
description: It's a small book, lean and very tight; it does not do much more than map a young man's first romantic odyssey. And yet that is where its strength lies. For by remaining faithful to itself in style and purpose it is, from start to finish, honest, touching, believable and in volving. That it all takes place in England should not make it foreign to the American reader.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Earlier this month, Gov. Bob Scott of North Carolina asked the State Legislature for support in carrying out a farreaching program of en vironmental protection, in cluding a request that the Legislature initiate condem nation proceedings to bring Smith Island into public own ership.

title: How to Rock and Be Happy
description: NEW SEEKERS: Beau tiful People (Elektra). Maybe I get carried away with my fond ness for British pop music, but this is no blind prejudice. Faced with huge American successes in the Sugar, Sugar, Yummy, Yummy vein. I turn with relief toward England where, it seems, a guy would rather love a girl than digest her. The British have, not reached America's level of cynicism. Not yet.

title: Did India have it coming? Yes says a book, no says the review
description: Neville Maxwell was in India as a correspondent for The Times of Lon don from 1959 to 1967. Since then he has devoted several further years of research in London to writing an exhaustive account of the climactic event of his sojourn in India, the IndiaChina war of 1962. Of the score of books that have appeared to date dealing with aspects of this confron tation between the world's two larg est countries, Maxwell's is the clearest and most comprehensive.

title: Science/Medicine
description: Concern over the world's population explosion, and the attendant dissemination of birth control devices and the liberalization of abortion laws, have had their effects in the United States: a marked decline in the birth rate. But they have also spawned a growing contro versy over the implications of the zeropopulationgrowth movement for racial and ethnic minorities within the nation.

title: Edward Kittredge Weds Miss Silver
description: Miss Francine Helen Silver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silver of New York, was married here last eve ning to Edward Kittredge, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Kittredge of Long meadow, Mass. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Photography
description: THE most visible asset of the Floating Foun dation of Photography is a purple and white houseboat that brings small photographic exhibitions to various landings around New York Harbor and the lower Hudson River. It first ap peared one hot, steamy night last summer at Morton Street pier in a blaze of floodlights, a blare of rock and a frenzy of frugging. Since then, the houseboat has docked at Bellevue, Wards Island, Harts Island, Sheepshead Bay and Riverside Park. This summer, powered by a couple of out board motors, it will try to make it up the Hudson as far as Piermont and maybe Bear Mountain.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  The irony surrounding the current impasse in the strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) in Vienna became sharper last week when Nixon Administration officials dis closed that the Soviet Union had provided more specific de tails of its proposal to limit antiballistic missile (ABM) sys tems. When the United States first proposed the talks in 1967, the American interest was in banning ABM systems. The So viets responded by insisting that offensive forces be discussed as well, and Washington agreed. Now the situation has come full circle with the Soviets propos ing an ABMonly agreement and the Administration insisting that offensive forces must also be controlled.

title: Reader's Report
description: The author, an English nove list, announces his intention of writing a novel that depicts an office complex as a place where unfortunates are stifled, crushed, buried. So why not write the novel as a film? (The cinema is an immensely powerful visual medium.) Hmm. Too late to change matters now  for, after his introductory mani festo, Mr. Gathorne  Hardy rushes headlong into a docu mentary screen treatment of a day in the life of some London business premises, conducting us by trick shot and handheld camera into filing cabinets and heaven knows where else.

title: A Switching Point for Rails?
description: An era that began in 1825, when a small locomotive built by John Stevens chugged around on a circular track in Hoboken, N.J., came to an end yesterday. The Na tional Railroad Passenger Corporation, or Amtrak, set up by the Congress to take over the unprofitable duties of hauling passengers from the private railroads, came into being.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HONG KONG, May 1 (AP) Fifteen Filipino businessmen received visas from Communist China today.

title: MISS HAYNIE'S 65 TAKES GOLF LEAD
description: DALLAS, May 1 (UPI)San dra Haynie carded her best competitive round ever today a sixunderpar 65which moved her into first place by four strokes after two rounds of the Dallas Civitan women's open.

title: Coaches Vote Award To Scolnick of Hunter
description: Dr. Anthony Scolnick, whose Hunter College basketball team captured the Knicker bocker Conference champion ship, has been named coach of the year by league coaches.

title: Bolivia Seizes AmericanOwned Mine
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 1 President Juan Jos Torres marched today at the head of a May Day parade of workers who cheered the nationaliza tion of the largest United States mining investment in Bolivia.

title: Sirhan as a patriot, Ray as a decoy
description: As Robert F. Kennedy lay dying on that kitchen floor in Los Angeles, Rafer Johnson, the former decathlon champion then acting as one of Ken nedy's bodyguards, turned to the young assassin he had pinned to the steam table and shouted a ques tion which soon reverberated in the minds of millions of Americans:

title: Necklace For Laurie
description: That's no princess, whis pered the lizard. She's not wearing...a necklace of precious jewels.But I have no jewels to make a necklace, Laurie shouted and began to cry. There are precious jew els everywhere, whispered the lizard. We will find some for you.

title: Anatomy Of a Primer
description: It will never make the best seller lists. As a matter of fact it was not intended to be sold (it's free) but it's certainly the best of breedSimon & Schus ter's spring juvenile catalogue.

title: PIRATES DEFEAT PADRES, 64, IN 11
description: PITTSBURGH, May 1 (UPI) Gene Alley singled to score Bob Robortson in the 11th inn ing today and give the Pitts burgh Pirates a 54 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Englewood Pupils' Poems Are Made Into a Record
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 1 Pupils in the eighth grade of Dwight School and the Engle wood School for Boys, which are on adjoining campuses here, will make their debuts next week as recording artists. The pupils have macle a longplay ing record, Promises to Be Kept, which will be released next week by Spoken Arts, Inc., of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Fears and Resentments of Vietnamese Living Near American Bases Are Reflected in Agency Surveys
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 1American officials in Saigon are now learning of the distrust and anger felt by many Vietnamese who live near American military bases, and how much they resent the be havior of American soldiers toward them.

title: OTB PAYOFF IS $59;
description: Offtrack betting's Kentucky Derby Special surged to an intoxicating finish yesterday with a handle of $1,030,432 and a winner who paid three times as much here as at Churchill Downs.

title: Miss Susan K. McCrensky to Wed
description: BELMONT, Mass., May 1 Miss Susan Kaye McCrensky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. McCrensky of Bel mont and Ogunquit, Me., plans to be married here early next month to Bruce F. Heitler, whose father, Em mett Heitler of Denver, is ex ecutive vice president of the Samsonite Corporation, man ufacturer of luggage, out door furniture and toys. The future bridegroom is the son also of Mrs. Heitler, whose father, the late Jesse Schway der, founded Samsonite.

title: Ware Sprints 100 Yards in 9.3 Seconds, Equaling Meet Record at Quantico
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 1 Track and field produced its first find of the outdoor season today when an unknown 21 yearold sprinter named Robert Ware ran 100 yards in 9.3 sec onds at the Quantico Relays.

title: ITALIANS ADVANCE IN ZONE CUP TENNIS
description: Italy, Portugal, Rumania and Hungary all advanced into the second round of the Davis Cup tennis tournament Saturday, with victory sweeps in the threeoffive European Zone B according to United Press Inter national.

title: Aid Drive Begun for Burned Lab Used for A rrowsmith Research
description: Efforts to restore a tradi tionladen medical laboratory in Brooklyn that was badly dam aged by a recent fire have be gun modestly with a collection of $300.

title: CARE OF ELDERLY AROUSES CONCERN
description: Should the elderly be insti tutionalized in homes for the aged, where services can easily be provided for them? Or should they be encouraged to live in homes and apartments and con tinue as members of their communities?

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: TREASURY SECRETARY John B. Connally Jr. and J. Dewey Daane of the Federal Reserve Board denounced a policy of benign neglect for the nation's balance of pay ments and Mr. Connally said restoring equilibrium was a matter of priority. Nevertheless, Raymond Barre of the Common Market and PierrePaul Schweitzer of the Inter national Monetary Fund warned of the dangers of massive payments deficits. Mr. Connally also said that political considerations had motivated critics of the Nixon Admin istration's plans to reduce business taxes by $3billion a year.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: Oh, what a beautiful book this is My bulgy froggy eyes nearly popped as I gazed upon the magnificence of this art work. Peter Parnall has really done it. He has illustrated this book with a brilliance of technique that dazzles the eyes and nearly, but not quite, blinds the reader to the book's fatal flawit's got no story. Oh, sadness! I wept bitter frog gy tears when I came to the end of the book and realized it hadn't said anything, or done anything, or told a story or anything. What this is is an allegory about a big, self important bullfrog, and his neighbors, who are all nice quiet little frogs. Unfortunately, to make the allegory work, I the author had to sacrifice the story. It's happened before, and if I were the publishers I prob ably would've printed it, too, because it really is a beautiful bookcroak.

title: Pop
description: Is IT significant that Andy WarholLord High Pooh Bah of Pop Art in the sixties  was chosen to do the cover art for the new Rolling Stones album?

title: NEW PANEL TO STUDY NOISE LEVEL TREND
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has announced estab lishment of an office to find out how noisy the United States is now, and how much noisier it is likely to get.

title: Discharged Workers Aided
description: To help find jobs for city workers laid off because of the current austerity dis charges, a job referral center has been opened. The office is in Room 329 at 220 Church Street and will be open Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Mayor Lindsay appealed to potential employers to call the center at 4336700.

title: SKEET TEAM LED BY MRS. ARMOUR
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 1 (AP) The marksmanship spotlight swings to the women's side of the firing line this year in se lections by Jimmy Robinson for the Sports Afield allAmer ica skeetshooting team.

title: ICEBOX IS READY FOR ESKIMO TOWN
description: COLLEGE, Alaska, April 28 An enormous walrus freezer will be dedicated for Eskimo residents Sunday on treeless, tundrapocked St. Lawrence Is land, a sentinel guarding the Bering Strait where the Pacific and Arctic Oceans meet. No longer will selling iceboxes to Eskimos be a joking matter.

title: Letters
description: Mr. Broyard replies:

title: V.A. Hospital Gets Director
description: Dr. Milton Ginsberg, chief of staff at the Brooklyn Veterans Administration Hospital since 1968, has been named director. He will succeed Dr. Philip R. Casesa, who is retiring May 30 after more than 10 years at the hospital.

title: CARACAS REFORMS ITS BUS SERVICES
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 1 The Caracas City Council has voted unanimously to abolish the municipally owned bus system and create a mass trans part corporation jointly with private capital to operate a new one.

title: Center Is Opened At Wildlife Ref age In Jamaica Bay
description: Parks, Recreation and Cul tural Affairs Administrator Au gust Heckscher broke ground last week for an Interpretive Center at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge on Cross Bay Boulevard in Queens.

title: British Columbia Bans Tobacco Ads
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, May 1The Government of British Columbia has banned all liquor and tobacco advertis ing starting Sept. 1.

title: Penguins, of All People!
description: Don Freeman has written and illustrated a full shelf of pic ture books for very young read ers. The best of the books use an exotic or dramatic setting and with wit and gaiety give considerable information about itas his Pet of the Met does about Mozart's magic flute and the opera house, or his The Guard Mouse does about London and the Queen's home.

title: Ecology Exhibit on Capital Mall Is Planned by U.S. Park Service
description: WASRINGTON, May 1The National Park Service is devel oping a 12acre exposition here to show how man must learn to redeem the environment he has polluted.

title: Miss Sharon Stevenson Is Bride Of Charles Griffith Jr., Adman
description: PRINCETON, N. J. May 1 Miss Sharon Stevenson was married tonight to Charles T. Griffith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith of Bradford, Pa.

title: Carroll of Reds Fined, Suspended in Dispute
description: CINCINNATI, May 1 (UPI) Clay Carroll, the Cincinnati Reds' ace relief pitcher, drew a threeday suspension and a 150 fine today for a runin with the plate umpire, Nick Colosi, in last night's game.

title: Pakistan to Ask a Moratorium on Debts
description: KARACHI, May 1With financial resources sorely strained by the political condi tion in the Eastern part of the country, Pakistan announced today that she would ask creditor nations for a sixmonth moratorium on payments of her external debt.

title: A Friend, A Father And A Nephew
description: One of the hazards facing prolific writers is a tendency on the part of the reading public to greet a new book less on its own terms and more in relation to its predecessors. This is unfair; but, when the writing fol lows a formula, comparison becomes inevitable.

title: Reader's Report
description: What the ancients said was quite a mouthful: Sicilian prov erbs that helped to season an East Harlem boyhood in the 1940's, even when their mean ing was a trifle obscured. For every situation there was an aphorism, like Raise high the foot, for I touch straw. If this loses something in the transla tion, a reverse English process adds something. Gaetano (Tom my) Martana's mother did piecework for Li Roggispita and was requested to register as an enemy alien by Rosa Verde. Much more lilting on the tongue than Rogers Peet and Roosevelt.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1It was the roughest Derby I was ever in, said Jimmy Nichols, the rider of the big and sturdy List. They came at you from front and back, in and out, up and down.

title: PATENT PENDING HUNTER WINNER
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 1 Patent. Pending, who spent four years lounging in his barn before he was sent into the ring, captured the limit work ing hunter championship today at the Junior Essex Troop horse show.

title: Collis Jones to Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, May 1 (UPI)  Collis Jones, a 6foot8inch forward for Notre Dame, signed a multiyear contract today to play for the TeXas Chaparrals of the American Basketball As sociation. Jones, a firstround draft choice of the Milwaukee Bucks, was Texas's firstround choice.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Sadat Is Cautious on His Talks With Rogers
description: CAIRO, May 1President An war elSadat said today that he would speak with an open mind in talks with Secretary of State William P. Rogers here next week. But he warned that there could be no compromise on his terms for an Israeli pull back in the Sinai Peninsula to permit a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Sinclair Lewis By Richard O'Connor. 143 pp. New York: McGraw Hill Book Company. $4.72.
description: Red Lewis was freaky, even by today's standards. At age 5, he chewed up a square foot of the family lawn; at 13, he ran away from home; in high school, he set fire to some equipment in the chemistry lab. Gawky and clumsy, cursed with chronic acne, he was scorned as a bookworm. Yet he was an erratic student who ranked 17th in his eighthgrade class of eighteen. A cantankerous exhibitionist, at the height of his fame he stood up in a pulpit and challenged God to strike him dead within 15 minutes. But few other novelists have equalled his understanding of mid  Americans, whom he anatomized in four brilliant nov elsMain Street, Babbitt, Arrowsmith and Dods worthand in the powerful, lessrenowned Elmer Gantry. Written in a single decade, these novels won him the Nobel Prize but not the regard of his father, who spurned his son's overtures to reconciliation.

title: Bird Used as Barometer of Ecological Balance in Marshes of L.I.'s South Shore
description: FREEPORT, L. I., May 1  A winged barometer of pollution is under study in the marshlands of Long Is land's South Shore.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa With some reluctance but considerable common sense, the United States has concluded that the only possible policy it can apply to the Republic of South Africa is one called communication whidh, in fact, means straddling the question.

title: Coast Lawyer in Drug Case Is Upheld
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 The California District Court of Appeals has ruled against the state's attempt to continue prosecuting a lawyer in whose house narcotics agents found marijuana.

title: The Gypsy Bears
description: The New Yorker's reaction to immigrants can be distinctly unfriendly at times, at least if the immigrant strikes him as odd. And the performing gypsy bears from Rumania are hardly off the boat before they discover that they are indeed considered odddisturbing enough to the natives, in fact, to be trapped and imprisoned in the zoo. While languishing behind bars, however, father bear devises an ingenious means of escape; and the bears manage to hitch a ride to friendlier territory out west.

title: The Heckschers remodel
description: The Heckschers remodel

title: LETTERS
description: I write in response to an article (April 4) by attorney Milton Handler.

title: State Aid Cut Squeezes Youth Board in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 1 The 14 neighborhood youth programs run by the Nassau County Youth Board have been operating virtually in the red since March 1 as a result of a 50 per cent cut In state aid.

title: Baltimore Suburb Is Afflicted With Growing Pains
description: TOWSON, Md.  Towson may be the fastestgrowing state of mind in the nation.

title: Appellate Judge Named
description: ALBANY, May 1Governor Rockefeller this week desig nated State Supreme Court Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. of the Bronx as an associate justice of the Appellate Divi sion, First Judicial Department. Justice Murphy, who is 44 years old, was named to fill a vacancy created by the retire ment of Justice Samuel W. Eager last Dec. 31.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Rose and Graffman in Recital Noted for Its Communication
description: Any worthy piece of music sets up a distinct tonal ambi ance, and one valuable aspect of the recital by Leonard Rose and Gary Graffman on Friday night was the way they pre served and communicated the quality in each of the four works they played. The cellist and pianist were appearing at the Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as part of a BrahmsSchumann se ries, They performed the two Brahms sonatas, Schumann's Fantasietcke and, by way of contrast, the Debussy sonata.

title: Mars Satellite Launching Postponed From May 7 to 8
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 2 (UPI)The launching of the first of two Mars television satellites was postponed yester day from May 7 to May 8 be cause of an electrical problem in one of the instruments in the spacecraft.

title: AUSTRALIA SEEKS BETTER CHINA TIES
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 1 An Australian table tennis team is still touring mainland China after the American players have returned to the United States. And like President Nixon, Aus tralian Government leaders are talking about improving re lations with Peking and about getting the Chinese Communists into the United Nations.

title: Polio Epidemic Fought
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., May 1 (UPI)More than 2,000 units of oral polio vaccine have been flown to Santo Domingo, Do minican Republic, to help medical authorities there fight a nationwide epidemic. The vaccine was received yester day by the Dominican Medical Association from its Puerto Rican counterpart.

title: 200 SEEK POSTS IN SLUMAID VOTE
description: The city's Model Cities Ad ministration has announced that nearly 200 residents of three slum neighborhoods have filed as candidates in the May 21 election of new community based Model Cities boards.

title: Reds Edge Giants, 3 to 2, and Stop San Francisco's Streak at Four in Row
description: CINCINNATI, May 1 (AP) Don Gullett, the only Cincinnati pitcher to go the distance this season, drove in the decisive run but needed help from Wayne Granger for the last out tonight as the Reds slowed down the Sin Francisco Giants, 32.

title: What's Opened in the Theater?
description: METAMORPHOSES, a play with music based on Ovid and adapted for Paul Silis's Story Theater company by Arnold Weinstein, received four favorable, three mixed and three unfavorable re views. Clive Barnes: Those hoping for a possible Dirty Story Theater are in for a slight disappoint ment. Arnold Weinstein's adaptation of Ovidean love and frolics is tactful almost to the point of chastity. But like its predecessor it has charm, originality and imagination. The concept of stories being acted out and related with story, mime, dance and song re mains the mixture as be fore. To some extentper haps to a large extentthe Grimm fairy tales are more suitable for the Sills treat ment than Ovid. They con tain more variety within their scope and have a vital sense of grotesquerie that adds enormously to their dramatic impact. There is surely a sensu ality to Ovid, but a sensu ality that is here lost in a pink cloud of good humor; it does mean that a valuable part of Ovid's insights go begging for a voice. Of course the joy of this Metamorphoses and any sensible man, woman and reasonably sophisticated child will make it essential viewing just at is the original Story Theateris the act ing of the cast, and the concept and staging of the remarkable Mr. Sills. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE Department of Transportation is mounting a nationwide attack on one of the principal dangers to everyone who travels by auto mobile or bus or on foot in this country the drunken driver. And, as usual, the gimmickry of the campaign is receiving more public acclaim and applause than the grinding realities of the drive, which is where success is more likely to be achieved.

title: TANNEN ACCEPTS JETS' CONTRACT
description: Steve Tannen, the New York Jets left cornerback, has signed with the club for the coming season, head coach and general manager Weeb Ewbank an nounced yesterday. Ewbank de clined to anounce the terms of the contract.

title: The Most Popular ManMade Lake In America
description: BUFORD, Ga.  Out of the Hills of Habersham, Down the Valleys of Hall, wrote Sidney Lanier de scribing the course of the Chat tahoochee River a century ago. Today, with a United States Corps of Engineers dam backing up the waters of that fa bled river just north of here, Georgia can lay claim to the most popular man made lake with the largest inland pleas ure sailing fleet in the United States.

title: No. Illinois to Head East
description: NEWTON, Mass. (AP)Bos ton College and Northern I11i nois will meet in football for the first time Nov. 13 here, completing an 11game schedule for both teams.

title: New Editor of Ohio Paper
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 1 (AP) Franklin K. Arthur Jr., editor and publisher of The Peninsula Herald in Monterey, Calif., has become editor of The Toledo Times.

title: Lime Rock Steps. In to Preserve DonohueJones Racing Rivalry
description: About Motor Sports

title: White Sox 53 Victors
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) Carlos May extended his hit ting streak to nine games with two singles and a home run to night as the Chicago White Sox beat the Washington Sena tors for the third straight time, 53.

title: 640 WOMEN CALL BIRTH SERVICE
description: A service offering an al ternative to abortion has re ceived more than 640 phone calls since it was begun by the Roman Catholic Archdio cese of New York on April 12.

title: CALTECH BEMOANS POOR JOB MARKET
description: PASADENA, Calif., May 1 (AP)  The job market for graduates of the California In stitute of Technology, alma mater of 11 Nobel laureates, is the worst since the Depression of the nineteen thirties, the school's placement director says.

title: Venezuelans Excited, Proud Over Triumph
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 1 (AP)The victory of Can onero II in the Kentucky Derby set off a wave of ex citement today.

title: Shades of H. L. Mencken! He wrote bushels of letters (some of thrm now on view at the Public Library). Which gives rise to the conclusion:
description: MY feeling toward the citizens caught in the British mail strike was pure envy. Not be cause I'm one of those people who feels oppressed by unsolicited letters offering me a selection of New Jer sey cheeses or an eternal subscrip tion to Look magazine. In fact, I'm always relieved to open my mailbox and find nothing but thirdclass mail. Thirdclass mail requires no response except, perhaps, an easily marked coupon that might win me a fully furnished  Colonial  stylesplit level ranchettehaciendahome. I don't mind receiving letters; it's writing them I hate.

title: It's a Champagne Bubble on the Breeze
description: THERE is one entrancing moment, among many, in Paul Sills's im provisational leafing of Ovid's Metamorphoses, now alternat ing with the successful Story Theater at the Ambassador, in which a very wifely wife dies happily. She is the mate of Cephalus, that phenomenally fortunate hunter whose spear not only unerringly lances its prey but instantly returns to him with its powers intact. Both she and he have cause to lament the spear. It has, Cephalus tells us early, utterly ruined his marriage, and that is no doubt the understatement of the con. Ruined his marriage? It has run his wife clear through, terminating their association once and for all. She has, you see, suspected her hunterhusband of having an affair with Zephyr and she has spied on him from the bushes, where he has mistaken her for fair game. Now she lies in his arms, breath ing her jealous last. But he is able to reassure her, so that she can go to the netherworld with a forgiving smile on her lips. Zephyr, he explains, was only a breeze.

title: Ages 9 to 12: Echoes of Other Days, Other Ways
description: If Horatio Alger met Jackie Robinson in Central Park and the two of them were 8 years old, things might have gone just as they did for Tony and MacDougall tin George Panetta's Shoeshine Boys. This is a fable of American Life so pure that only a hardnosed Marxist could remain unmoved.

title: Bullets Get $10,965 Each
description: BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets eased the pangs of defeat today with an announcement that each los ing share in the National Basketball Association playoffs would be worth $10,965.

title: Turkish Premier Vows to Halt Illicit Opium Traffic
description: ANKARA, May 1Premier Nihat Erim pledged today to remove Turkish opium from the illicit market by licensing poppy cultivation and buying the en tire 1971 crop.

title: Dr. B. A. Eissner And Judith Pick Engaged to Wed
description: CHICAGO, May 1  The engagement of Miss H. Judith Pick to Dr. Bruce Allyn Eissner of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. M. Thomas Eissner of Balmville, N. Y., ?? been anno?? by the prospective bride's brother, Grant Daniel Pick of Chicago.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: HiHo, Kermit the Frog here, and I'm writing this article to call your attention to the fact that there are a number of frogtype children's books out this year.

title: A 4DAY AMNESTY BEGINS IN CEYLON
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 1 The Government announced to night that 250 rebels had sur rendered today as a fourday amnesty period began.

title: MAYDAY MARCHES ENLIST FEW HERE
description: Rallies and marches blos somed left, right and center for May Day in the city yesterday, but crowds at the scattered demonstrations were generally sparse and the impact minimal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: P.S.C. Takes Action to Halt Surcharges for Phone Use
description: The State Public Service Commission has moved against improper charging for tele phone service by hotels, motels marinas, clubs, apartment hous es and hospitals.

title: Recordings
description: THE peculiar reluctance of major American opera houses to stage Idomeneo, an incontest ably important opera by Mo zart, meanwhile scraping the 19th Century barrel and com ing up with feeble concoc tions by this or that Cilea or Giordano, may be shaken a bit by the appearance of another recording of the 1781 work. There is, at least, that hope; we must live with is though vice may die in de spair. Just how grimly the Metropolitan, for instance, hangs onto the standard repertory as it was estab lished and delimited by pop ular American taste half a century ago and more is no where plainer than in the Met's insistence, in spite of rather weighty evidence, that Mozart wrote only three op eras. Of those ignored, Ido meneo is not the greatest, but it is the one that perhaps lends itself best to a large house, calling for storms at sea and other grandopera effects.

title: Head of Jewish Unit Named
description: The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies announced last week the election of Dr. Morris N. Kertzer, rabbi of Riverdale Temple in the Bronx, as presi dent of the organization's com mission on synagogue relations.

title: Music Studies at Brooklyn
description: An Institute for Studies in American Music has been es tablished at Brooklyn College. Among its aims will be the encouragement and support of research projects in American music, such as publications, recordings, bibliographies, sym posiums and archives.

title: RE: PROXMIRE'S STUBBORNNESS
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Et Al.
description: A serious discussion: pornog raphy as art. In its highest manifestations, Peter Michel son sees pornography as an im portant exploration into taboo territory, Lesser pornography, he defines by its formula me chanics. No pornography, how ever, would he ban, since it is part of man's most basic myth making urges. Civilized.

title: Muskie Says Nixon Knew TaxCut Plan Was Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie, citing a confidential Treasury Depart ment memorandum as evidence, accused the Nixon Administra tion today of knowing that it was violating the law when it decided to order a $3billion annual reduction in the taxes paid by business.

title: National Notes
description: So you've lost your job, and you've applied for weekly un employment benefits. Assuming the reasons you present for your jobless state are deemed offi cially reasonable, you can look forward to that weekly check unless, that is, your former em ployer appeals the decision and claims that you really quit with out cause or were fired for cause. Then, unless you live in Rhode Island, you're not going to re ceive any payments until the appeal is decided by unemploy ment compensation officials.

title: Target Date Is June 23 For Balanced Budget
description: Mayor Lindsay's budget submission yesterday set in motion mandatory action leading to final adoption of a balanced budget on June 23.

title: Olmedo Upsets Edlefsen
description: KANSAS CITY, May 1 (AP) Alex Olmido, the 35yearold former Wimbledon champion, gained the final of the $13,750 Glenwood Manor invitation tennis tournament with a 4.6, 63, 63 upset victory over Tom. Edlefsen today. Edlefsen is ranked 12th in the country.

title: The World
description: PARISThe ghost of Mos sadegh was conjured up by France last week. Paris bran dished the threat of a West ern embargo of Algerian oil, but neither the Algerians nor their Western clientele nor the French themselves seemed much impressed.

title: Navy Crew Upsets Harvard and Penn
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 1 Navy's underestimated crew won the Adams Cup today, up setting the Harvard and Penn eights that had been unbeaten hitherto.

title: We're Washed Up, Jane! Up! Up! Up!
description: Dick and Jane, who, along with their pets Spot and Puff and all their friends, have taught children to read for four decades, are being phased out by their publishers and replaced by an innovative Reading Systems program.

title: With A Hop And A Croak
description: I have the feeling this story is real ly about a toad. A fat, lumpy, wrinkly sort of toad, not the goodlooking, appealing kind of frog that you and I know and love. Anyhow, it's a realistic story of a couple of 8year olds, Anna Belle and Toby, who find thistoad. And Anna Belle wants to kiss it to turn it into a Prince, but Toby is much more scientifically minded. This isn't my favorite kind of book, although it is nicely illus trated by Joseph Cellini's pencil drawings. But, after all, it's about a toad, and I don't really care much for toad stories.

title: BreakProof Egg Is Goal
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 1 (AP)Students in a graphical analysis and design class at Worcester Polytechnic Institute are working to design a break proof package. They must test it by putting a fresh egg inside and dropping it onto the pave ment from a fourthfloor win dow.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt was Lyn don Johnson, at the start of the massive involvement in. Viet nam, who used to act out the anguish that Richard Nixon must be feeling now that the involvement is moving toward an end.

title: Sure, Hollywood Is Collapsing, But ...
description: THE movie industry is collapsing. Everybody knows that. All you have to do is read the financial pages (Proxy War. Threatened at 20th CenturyFox), or look at a mar quee (My Secret Life at Loew's State 2), or listen to your friends (I read all of your reviews even though I never go). Can it possibly survive through the end of May, much less until next year when, according to Time Maga zine, we'll be in the midst of a Roman tic Revival of a scope undreamt of by even Olive Higgins Prouty? I don't know. In the meantime we're making do with everything from The Conform ist and Claire's Knee and Summer of '42 to Raid on Rommel, The Beast in The Cellar and The Water bed Caper.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: A man with an idea went to see W. Clement Stone some 15 years ago to discuss a small cosmetics business he wanted to expand.

title: The World
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti Every sign indicates that Presi dent Francois Duvalier's decision last January to make his pudgy 19yearold son, JeanClaude, his official heir as PresidentforLife a move ridiculed outside the country as the whim of a dying dictatorwas a masterstroke of political foresight. As one Haitian put it last week, if the old man had died without a nominated heir to take over, blood would certainly have run in the streets. And blood would have run if it had been anyone but Jean Claude.

title: Brown Scores by a Length Over Syracuse Oarsmen
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 1 Brown's heavyweight eight led from start to finish and posted a length victory over Syracuse today in the third Holding Tro phy race on Onondaga Lake.

title: Ferryboat Return Pleases San Francisco Commuters
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 There are some people in this city who actually enjoy the morning traffic jams on the Golden Gate Bridge. They are the former motorists who now commute on the new ferry from Sausalito, across San Francisco Bay in Marin County.

title: 66Unit Apartment Project In Red Hook Is Approved
description: The Board of Estimate has approved construction of a federally subsidized develop ment consisting of 66 apart ments in seven lowrise build ings in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

title: Amtrak Limps on Track
description: None of the national jubilation that greeted the driving of the Golden Spike a century ago attends the inaugura tion this weekend of what passes for service on the new National Railway Passenger Corporation. Quite the op posite. It is too clear to everyone that Amtrak is a pitiful apology for a rail system adequate to restore the pride and pleasure Americans once took in the passenger trains that knit the country together.

title: 12 Nominated for Tryouts In PanAmerican Volleyball
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 (AP) Twelve collegiate volleyball players have been named to compete in the PanAmerican Games trials Wednesday through Saturday at Bingham ton, N. Y.

title: Troops Mass Near Capital as Protesters Assemble
description: WASHINGTON May 1 Several thousand armed Federal troops from nearby states rolled into the capital's suburbs tonight to support policemen and National Guardsmen in dealing with threatened civil disobedience on Monday.

title: Catholic Primate in Ulster, Assessing the Role of Church in the Crisis, Says the Issue Is Not Religious
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, May 1 Tensions between Protestants and the Roman Catholic minority persist in Northern Ireland despite leg islative reforms because many Catholics doubt that a change of heart has accompanied the change of law.

title: Teenage Fiction: Finding Out
description: Natalie Babbitt spins a web for her story. She sets us down in a delicious English country side, shows us a frosted sugar cake of a house (suggesting dark secrets), introduces a gyp sy, a baggypanted tutor (Her cules), a poor little rich boy (Willett Goody) and his strange mother. She then hints that the master of Goody Hall, Midas Goody, who is supposed to be buried behind the house, is not dead at all. Of course, we're caught in Mrs. Babbitt's web and we expect to be lost and bewildered and perhaps a little scared before she sees fit to release us.

title: Black Activist Mayor Takes Berkeley Post
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 1 (UPI)Warren Widener, young black activist, took over as Mayor of Berkeley today, singing We Shall Overcome.

title: Miss Fenton Hetherington Bride
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., May 1Miss Fenton Hethering ton and John Tarleton El mendorf were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's father, James A. Hetherington 2d. The Rev. James J. English, an Episco pal clergyman and headmas ter of the Happy Valley School in Pomona, N. Y., per formed the ceremony.

title: A Friend, A Father And A Nephew
description: Losing is part of the American way of life. For every smiling face of success there are 10 sour men whistling Born to Lose. How many men made a bundle in the gold fields, struck it rich in oil, built a dynasty of cattle or wheat? Comparatively few. Yet the myth of American pio neers creaking happily along in their Conestogas persists in juvenile lit erature, with seldom a word about the countless losers whose bones fer tilize the prairie. Since it is terribly difficult to dramatize losing, Gone and Back is a special triumph, a human comedy of errors told in per fect pitch.

title: Mr. Biddle And the Birds
description: Swinging in a hammock, lunching with birds, Mr. Biddle is the sort of man who longs to travel in the sky. So he designs a beautiful contrap tion: a boat suspended from two poles, with two birds in front, two in the rear, winging it smoothly along.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To The Editor:

title: Good, Bad, Neutral Black
description: Gretchen and Hazel are eyeing each other. The race is over and Hazel won. We stand there with this big smile of respect between us. It's about as real a smile as girls can do for each other, considering we don't practice real smiling every day you know, cause maybe we too busy being flowers or fairies or strawber ries instead of something honest and worthy of respect . . . you know . . . like being people.

title: CITY UNIT ASSAILS STATE DRUG STUDY
description: Mayor Lindsay's Narcotics Control Council issued a point bypoint denunciation yester day of the conclusions reached by the State Commission of In vestigation after public hear ings on the city's narcotics problem.

title: LEON L. CONSTON
description: Leon L. Conston, president of Transmittal Securities Corp oration, a brokerage concern, died yesterday at his home, 245 Bennett Avenue, at the age of 77.

title: Chill Greets Yorty in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 1  The visit of Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles to New Hampshire has left the state's professional politicians cool, but has warmed the heart of the publisher of New Hampshire's only statewide newspaper.

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: General Patton
description: A rational biography of Gen. George S. Patton Jr., in which his merits and failures were held in just proportion, would be most welcome, particularly at this time, when youth only too soon has been called to a war notoriously less heroic than the one against Hitler. This, alas, is not that book.

title: Is This Any may to Run a Railroad? Ask Tancsik, Age
description: BUDAPEST  Children operating switches, serving as signalmen and conductors, selling tickets, handling money, writing daily reportsis this any way to run a rail road? The Hungarians believe it isand they are delighted that this educational project in their capital also has turned out to be a tourist attraction.

title: U.S. Food Restrictions Called Harmful to Nutrition Overseas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1 One of the world's leading au thorities on nutrition has warned that emotional but un scientific campaigns challeng ing the safety of some foods and food additives in the Unit ed States have deprived other countries of needed products.

title: Polish Celebration Modest
description: WARSAW, May 1Poland celebrated May Day in a casual mood and on a modest scale today, the first such holiday under Edward Gierek, the new Communist party chief.

title: Miss Dooley Plans Nuptials
description: Edward W. Dooley of New York has announced the en gagement of his daughter, Miss Kathleen Mary Dooley, to Midshipman Lawrence F. Nolan, a first classman at the United States Naval Acade my. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Nolan of Stamford, Conn.

title: Marian McCarthy Wed to T. J. Bryan
description: Miss Marian Carol Mc Carthy and Thomas James Bryan, an assistant district attorney in New York County, were married yesterday at noon by the Rev. John Duf fell, in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church at the United Nations.

title: Queens Chamber Slates Met Luncheon for May 10
description: Fivehundred members of the Queens Chamber of Commerce will attend the chamber's ninth annual tribute to the New York Mets May 10 in the Diamond Club of Shea Stadium.

title: Chess
description: OF the forthcoming matches that will ultimately determine the challenger to world champion Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the one that has attracted the most attention both here and abroad is that between Bobby Fischer and the Russian Grandmaster Mark Taimanov.

title: Coins
description: FORTYEIGHT Ameri can dealers, from 10 states have been as signed bourse space for the Metropolitan New York Numismatic Conven tion, which opens its four day run on Thursday at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Sev enth Avenue and 56th Street. Two English companies, Spink & Son and B. A. Seaby, both of London, also will be represented.

title: Tales of Mortals and Immortals
description: Certain things in life cannot be simplified, and I suspect that the Greek myths are among them. Complex and pow erful, these stories symbolize the unchanging truths of ex istence; their gods and heroes are emotional beings; and the fate of many of them is tragic. To abbreviate the myths, even in the interests of children, is like condensing War And Peace for the Reader's Digest.

title: Glenda Farrell, Film Star, Dies at 66
description: Glenda Farrell, who appeared in 122 movies, as well as in many plays on stage and tele vision, died yesterday in her home at 480 Park Avenue. She was 66 years old and was the wife of Dr. Henry Ross, a phy sician.

title: Kate Webb Flies Back to Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 1 (UPI)Catherine M. (Kate) Webb, the United Press International corre spondent captured by the Vietcong April 8 and given up for dead, emerged from the Cambodian jungle today, describing her captors as tough, very tough. She said they talked of winning ultimate victory in the Indochina war.

title: San Miguel Is Where the Action Is For Art Students and Other Swingers
description: SAN MIGUEL DE ALLENDE, Mexico  Early this spring, the students of the Instituto Allende, the biggest art school in this very arty hill town 175 miles north of Mexico City, staged an outdoor show that rocked the town to its 16thcentury foundations and also, according to most observers, reinforced San Miguel's reputation as a sort of Montparnasse of Mexico.

title: The World
description: BELGRADENationalistic ri valries, the oldest problem in the Balkans, have risen again to haunt the present and endanger the future of Yugoslavia and her brand of Communism.

title: Autos of Good Old Days Are Sold for $300,000
description: RADNOR, Pa., May 1More than $300,000 worth of auto mobiles from the days when cars had running boards, rum ble seats,honest bumpers, bal loon tires, manual transmission and boattail rear ends were sold today at an auction of antique and classic cars on the grounds of a church in this suburb of Philadelphia.

title: Son to Mrs. Henderson
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., May 1 A son was born on Tuesday to Mr. and Mrs. John Byron Carlton Henderson at Doc tors Hospital in New York. Mrs. Henderson is the former Miss Sara Fraad of Scarsdale.

title: The Cracked Looking Glass
description: A small, curious note from the publisher accompanied the review copy of this book: It is the decision of the medium as to whether this book be re viewed as a Young Adult or an Adult title. Of course it is the decision of the medium, but that is not the point. The point, it seems to this reviewer, is that it is still felt that some sort of arbitrary distinction must be made between Young Adult and Adult. I will assume, or the sake of definition, that by Young Adult the publisher meant young people between, say, the ages of 14 and 19, and that by Adult he meant people over that age. None of this is intended as rebuke, none of it is intended to be admonitory. It is simply an ob servation. The distinction need not have been made. If there is any intention at all, it is only to encourage readers, Adults and young Adults.

title: By land or by sea
description: Summer is dead ahead and fashion is set on a nautical course. Bold anchor and sailboat appliqus brighten city dresses as well as easyliving play gear for all ages. An added sea touch: Bright plastic anchor pins that can be worn two and three at a time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I wish to open the American peo ple's eyes on the subject of the sal mon war. Danish fishermen are catching salmon, 200,000 tons a year, for only one reasonto provide food for the Eskimos. American industry is killing forty million tons every year through pollution. If the Americans refuse to stop their salmon slaughter, we Danes are going to make American soldiers leave Greenland and we will give the base to the Russians.

title: Better Jobless Pay Urged For Veterans of Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) A bipartisan group of 45 Congressmen has introduced legislation to guarantee a mini mum unemployment benefit for Vietnam veterans of $75 week for up to 52 weeks.

title: HARLOW REED, 52, OLIN EXECUTIVE
description: WESTON, Conn., May 1  Harlow John Reed, executive vice president and chief oper ating officer of the Olin Corpo ration, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 52 years old and lived at 18 Buttonball Lane

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenage Nonfiction: Mavericks of Their Time
description: What relevancy can the life of the Anarchist Queen of the 1900's have for today's readers? A great deal, it would seem, for the causes Emma Goldman defended  and for whose advocacy she was called the most dangerous woman in America  remain contem porary issues. They ranged from birth control and feminism to pacifism and ob struction of the draft. More than that, the core of her being was a hatred of every authority that put fences around the human spirit. Unlike other revolutionaries of her day, Emma defined freedom in more than economic or political terms; freedom was one's right to individuality. Her cry for bread and roses  love, beauty and human dignity  surely marked her as one of the first of the flower children.

title: Milwaukee Throng Greets Bucks on Arrival Home
description: MILWAUKEE, May 1 (UPI) The National Basketball Asso ciation champions, the Milwau kee Bucks, arrived here this aft ernoon from Baltimore and were greeted by a cheering throng.

title: The Cost of One Shattered Career Is Placed at $75,000 a Year
description: Last fall Kenny Kunken was a linebacker on Cornell's 150pound football team. To day Kenny Kunken, 20 years old, lies in a hospital bed, paralyzed from the neck down.

title: A Family Outing to Connecticut
description: TUCKED tidily away in the north western corner of Connecticut is an unspoiled wildernessa high, cliffbordered plateau of jungle like greenery, clear streams, sparkling lakes and frothing waterfalls known as the Mount Riga Forest Preservethat can be the focus of a one or two day lamily driving and hiking trip from New York City.

title: College Given $3.8Million
description: EASTON, Pa., May 1 (AP) Lafayette College has received its largest gift ever from an individual  $3.8million from John W. Reuf, a New York City lawyer who was member of the class of 1901 and who died 10 years ago.

title: Ann Tweedy and Stephen Remp, Fellow Students, Are Affianced
description: Miss Ann Sellett Tweedy and Stephen Edward Romp, who are working for master's degrees at the School for Advanced International Stu dies of Johns Hopkins Univer sity in Washington, plan to be married the end of this month.

title: An Ode to the Tomato
description: NO ONE has written an ode to A tomato, but someone should. The most glorious product of the home vegetable garden is a work of art. Thriving in the hot sun, the tomato red dens gradually against a background of deep green leaves and blushingly beck ons to an orgy ?? ??este.

title: Cubs Subdue Phils, 74
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (UPI)  Billy Williams hit two home runs and a double, batted in four runs and scored three to day, leading Ferguson Jenkins and the Chicago Cubs to a 74 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Raby du Posty Arlequin, a Bouvier des Flandres, Takes Wilmington Best
description: STANTON, Del., May 1A Bouvier des Flandres, Raby, du Posty Arlequin, imported last year by Chester Collier of IrvingtononHudson, N. Y., was named best of 1,649 dogs today at the Wilmington Ken nel Club's 30th show at Dela ware Park.

title: U.A.R. Is Considering Return to Name Egypt
description: CAIRO, May 1President Anwar elSadat said today that he was considering re viving the old name, Egypt, and dropping the formal name, United Arab Republic, which was adopted in 1958 at the time of a union with Syria.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The un certainties that continue to surround the planned rescue of F.I. du Pont, Glore Forgan & Co. by H. Ross Perot, the Texas industrialist, raise anew the old questions of how a major brokerage firm could get into such a mess and whether adequate steps have really been taken to prevent a recurrence.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Boulder Brook Club in Scarsdale, along with about nine acres of land, has been purchased by its members from C. T. Chenery, the rac ing magnate, who owned the facility for many years.

title: Where the Wild Mustangs Play
description: LOVELL, Wyo.  Saturday morning, nine o'clock, in front of the town hall. Gathered at the curb: nearly a dozen fourwheeldrive vehicles, some 30odd natives, a ranger from the Bureau of Land Management and two New Yorkersmy wife and me. A mustering of explorers!

title: Finally a Pope who believed in God
description: What can a writer do  I mean the kind of writer who yields him self to the political struggles of his time yet wishes to remain faithful to his calling and his craft? He can bear witness and tell the truth. He can assault the cant of brutal men in power and of hardspirited ideologues lusting for power. He can tell us stories and fables that recall the imagination to humaneness. And if he is brave, stubborn and unafraid of loneliness, he can even help redeem the age in which he lives.

title: EDWARD GETTINGER
description: Edward Gettinger, a lawyer who for more than 50 years specialized in banking matters died yesterday in his home at 28 East 63d Street. His age was 76.

title: Transcript of President's San Clemente News Conference on Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in San Clemente, Calif., yesterday, as re corded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: John L. Taylor, Coached Marquette Football Team
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., May 1 (AP)John L. (Tarz) Taylor, an early professional football play er, died in a Green Bay hospital today. His age was 75.

title: Nassau and Brooklyn Legislators Poll Voters on Issues From Daylight Time to Abortion
description: ALBANY, May 1  Who cares that a predominantly white, middleclass Roman Catholic area of Nassau County shows a strong preference for keeping Daylight Savings Time year round?

title: Twins for Mrs. Janklow
description: Twin daughters were born last Sunday to Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Janklow of Port Wash ington, L. I., at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Janklow is the former Miss Lisa Nelson of New York. Her husband is a vice president of Dobbs Ad vertising Company. The aid dren have been named Jill and Marnie.

title: Emily Jane Learned Whiting Betrothed
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 1Miss Emily Jane Learned Whiting, a junior at Marl boro College in Vermont, and Neil Leonard Whittelsey, who designs and makes lutes, dulcimers and other musical instruments, plan to be mar ried here on July 1.

title: Despite Protests in Forest Hills, Housing Project Plan Proceeds
description: Despite widespread opposi tion by community and politi cal leaders the city is contin uing its plan to begin construc tion of an 840unit lowincome housing project in the middle income Forest Hills section of Queens.

title: Drug Use and Abuse: Policemen Examine the Books
description: While many people complain about Manhattan's drug prob lem, Patrolman Mike Nixon is doing something about it. His ??at: the lower east side. A young cop, with jacket and tie, a low voice, a frequent smile and an open manner; he handles community relations for the Seventh Precinct. And the most important part of his job for the past four years has been working with teenagers, listening and sharing their troubles, trying to tell them the score on drugs, being the man they can come to for advice.

title: Festival in Ghana
description: IT Is written that the Af roAmerican, privileged to visit Africa, will set foot there and automatic ally begin to tremble. Invited to Africa on short notice re cently, I dared to approach her objectively and not live off the experience of James Baldwin or somebody. I hate clichs. But heaped upon this challenge to my cool was the fact that in order to take this wholly unexpected trip, I would have to travel with my hosts, whose names I now sock to you: Ike and Tina Turner, Wilson Pickett, San tana, Roberta Flack, Voices of East Harlem, the Staple Singers, Les McCann and Eddie Harris. Shepherded by Atlantic Records and a Cine rama Releasing film crew headed by Tom and Edward Mosk, these stars of black American music were flying to Ghana to join certain Afri can performers in staging an allnight concert on March 6, Ghana's 14th Independence Day, the concert to be the basis of both a film and a record album. Soul to Soul they were calling it, and it did seem enough to set a body trembling.

title: Emphasis Is Placed on Hospitality to Visitors
description: PEKING, May 1The new, more outgoing attitude of the People's Republic of China in foreign relations was reflected in May Day celebrations here today that were generally more relaxed than usual and showed special consideration for the largerthannormal number of foreign visitors present for the occasion.

title: Miss Heyman Becomes Bride
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., May 1 Miss Harriet Olga Heyman was married here this after noon to Stratis Savvas Kora kas. Algernon Black of the Ethical Culture Society in New York performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ezekiel Heyman, also of Jamaica, Queens.

title: Bit of Old West Clops On in Commack
description: COMMACK, L. I., May 1 Gene Waithe is called Black Bart and Black Cowboy by some of his friends, and the 33yearold computer operator, who was born in Trinidad and raised in Brooklyn, is an ad mitted addict of the Wild West. He says he became hooked while watching cowboy movies on television.

title: New York
description: ALBANYThat nowtradi tional battle of, well, Titans erupted in dramatic public fashion last weekbut this time Governor Rockefeller had most of the lines, and Mayor Lindsay was relatively quiescent. The issues included some of the most sensitive a politician must face: the city budget, rent control and wel fare.

title: Powers Gets N.A.I.A. Post
description: KANSAS CITY, May 1 (UPI) Donald L. Powers has been named director of public rela tions for the National Associa tion of Intercollegiate Athletics (N.A.I.A.), it was announced by Executive Secretary A. O. Duer. Powers replaces Mike Klein man, who resigned April 16.

title: Mother's Day Services
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) President Nixon will be at the White House on Sunday, May 9, for a Mother's Day wor ship service scheduled there.

title: Eggs Thrown at Brandt
description: HANOVER, West Germany, May 1 (Reuters)A barrage of eggs was thrown at Chancellor Willy Brandt here today as he addressed a trade union May Day rally. Mr. Brandt was not hit as the eggs splattered on to the speakers stand.

title: Books About Children's Books
description: One of the many problems of educa tion is that, although we like to learn, we do not really like to be taught. We prefer to feel that we are doing the whole thing by ourselves, and it is one of the endless joys of literature that it lets us go on thinking so.

title: College President Named
description: BLAIR, Neb., May 1 (AP) Dr. Earl Meeoff, 46yearold vice president of Lebanon Val ley College, Lebanon Pa., has been elected president of Dana College in Blair Neb., suceed ing Dr. C. C. Madsen, the re gents announced this week.

title: A Late Education
description: It was in the Bar Basque at St. Jean de Luz, on the fringes of the Spanish Civil War, that the nervously ambitious young newspaperman from Australia met the taciturn English man and asked the way. The one was Alan Moorehead and the other Alexander Clifford.

title: Four Generations of Mellons
description: PITTSBURGH  A new generation of Mellons, mem bers of what may be the na tion's secondrichest family after the du Ponts, is taking over the purse strings of a fortune estimated at $3bil lion to $5billion.

title: Ithaca Eight Wins O'Hare, But Manhattan Takes Sulger
description: Ithaca College, understroking the opposition all the way, won the Brother O'Hare Cup yester day for the second straight year over the 2,000meter Orch ard Beach Lagoon course in the Bronx.

title: Teenage Fiction: Finding Out
description: The similarities between James Forman's Song of Jubi lee and William Styron's The Confessions of Nat Turner are numerous.

title: Are Communists against Jews because Jews are against Communism?
description: Having observed the mood of young Jewish radicals and the Jewish com munity's hectic debate as to wheth er the Jews should be on the side of the Establishments or on the side of the underdogs of the world, I came to the conclusion that Paul Lendvai's book AntiSemitism Without Jews: Communist Eastern Europe will deep en this dilemma even more.

title: Alain Resnais: La Garbage Est Finie?
description: FRENCH director Alain Resnais had decided to follow the lead of such illustrious fellow Europeans as Michelangelo Antonioni, Agnes Varda, Jaques Demy, Milos Forman, Jan Kadar and Roger Vadim. The man responsible for Hiroshima, Mon Amour, Last Year at Marienbad and La Guerre Est Finie, will make a movie in Amer ica. He has signed with Martin Ransohoff's Filmways to direct The Monster Mak er, a project on which Res nais has been working for over a year with Stan Lee, one of our top comic book creators.

title: Kerr one Long Day's Journey Into Night
description: IT'S not until we reach the last fogbound banshee scream of Long Day's Journey Into Night that Eugene O'Neill's most moving play finds its dark, drunken voice in the revival at the Promenade. Then, as Robert Ryan digs his heels into the floor to resist the fury that Is coming from his tubercu lar youngest son across a shabby summerplace table littered with playingcards, the spleen of the play and the rotted affection of the Play leap together to make a blaze like the points of an arc lamp fusing.

title: Riverboat Loses Trophy But Wins Ohio Welcome
description: CINCINNATI, April 29  She chugged up river without a trophy, without the tradi tional gilded deer antlers, but the people of Cincinnati cheered her anyway.

title: Most French Bets Made Offtrack
description: PARIS, May 1  The French racing industry doesn't think much of New York's offtrack betting operation. One highly placed official said the greatest weakness lay in the small amount of money New York planned to plow back into rac ing  reported to be only about 1 per cent.

title: Sience/Medicine
description: Some 2,500 years ago, the Chinese practiced an elab orate form of medical treat ment that called for the sticking of needles into vari ous parts of the body. The needles, of differing sizes and thicknesses, were inserted at points defined by maps of the body surface. And the technique, called acupunc ture, was used to cure all manner of ailments: head aches, stomach pains, paral ysis, rheumatism, heart palpitations, appendicitis, nervous disorders, mental illnesseven blindness.

title: Let 'er Buck!
description: If I were my tomboy, horse crazy, 12yearold self again and had just finished this book I would darn well pack up my levis, my neatly pointed Western boots, that old leather belt which came in handy as an emergency lead strap, and head for the nearest rodeo grounds. What a life! One that takes plenty of guts, vast ego tism, drive, strength, and a fat gambling streak. Today's pro fessional rodeo cowboy, says Barbara Berry in this robust, lively book, is the most rugged, durable athlete in existence and possibly the most courageous.

title: ASTROS SET BACK METS, 31;
description: HOUSTON, May 1  Tom Seaver and the New York Mets both came to the end of the line tonight when Larry Dierker pitched the Houston Astros to a 31 victory before 23,571 customers in the Astrodome.

title: 15 POLICE TRIALS BEGIN TOMORROW
description: A series of 15 Police Depart ment trials is scheduled to begin tomorrow in what has developed into New York's single largest police corruption case since the Gross bookmaking scandal al most 20 years ago.

title: Social Events: A Box Lunch Auction?
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Rene Bauchat, Student, Is Bride
description: MADISON, N.
