J., May 1 Miss Rene Bauchat, a stu dent at Mount Vernon Junior College, and David Stephen Rosenbloom, president of the Baltimore Colts, were married here this afternoon, a year to the day after they met at a party in Washington. The Rev. John L. Rollins per formed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: Daughter to the Dublirers
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., May 1A daughter was born April 10 to Mr. and Mrs. Eric Dub lirer in the Framingham Union Hospital. Mrs. Dublirer is the former Miss Ellen Belkin of Brooklyn, N. Y. The child has been named Jennifer Lynn. Her father is a sales represen tative.

title: Et Al.
description: Just what the subtitle says: A Comparative History of American Imaginative Litera ture: 19191932. The second volume in a series edited by Quentin Anderson. The first was The Ferment of Realism 18841919 by Warner Berthoff (1965). Responsible and thor ough.

title: From Ghetto to College
description: About 200 business end professional people in the New York area have been spending their leisure time getting innercity youngsters into college.

title: Defending Our Show in India
description: To The Editor:

title: ANOTHER OFFERED CAMBODIAN POST
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 1A third candidate in three clays today turned down the task of heading a new Cam bodian Government, and a fourth was offered the post. The new candidate is Brig. Gen. In Tam, president of the National Assembly.

title: Et Al.
description: A beautiful account of one year in the life of a fisher, a kind of large marten that lives in the North Woods coun try. With empathy but without sentimentality or anthropomor phism, Mr. Langford takes us on the fisher's lonely round of hunting, eating, sleeping and surviving. A pleasant affirma tion of the dignity and unique ness of one of God's creatures.

title: Griffith Powerboat Race Setfor Friday
description: Bill Wishnick, who lost a chance to pickup some ground in the race for the national offshore powerboat title when the Long Beach, Calif.toEn senada, Mexico, race was post poned last week, will have his next opportunity Friday in Fort Lauderdale's Sam Griffith race.

title: STUDY HINTS NEED FOR HIGHER TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A Brookings Institution study has concluded that increasing out lays under existing government programs and those proposed by President Nixon would use up the entire normal growth in Federal tax revenues in the next three years.

title: ONASSIS CHALLENGES GREECE ON CONTRACT
description: ATHENS, May 1 Aristotle S. Onassis charged that because of deilays by the Greek Govern ment, his $600million invest ment contract would produce a loss of at least a billion dollars, which Greece would have to make good. He asked that the contract be canceled.

title: Retired City Businessman Gets American Irish Medal
description: The American Irish Historical Society presented its gold medal, given annually to an outstanding American of Irish lineage, to John A. Mulcahy, a retired New York City indus trialist and philanthropist who now lives in Ireland.

title: Northeastern Boats Win 3 Races From Boston U.
description: BOSTON, May 1Northeast em University's heavyweight crew won its third straight race, today as it nipped an improving Boston University eight over the 2,000meter Charles River course.

title: Pulga
description: Pulga (flea in Spanish) is the child of the Bogota slums, un dersized, underfed, unshock able. When the rains flood the squalid room he shares with his sisters, brother and grand mother, he spends the night beneath a truck. The driver, Gilimon, finds him before he is crushed and hires him as his helper. They make a round trip, gathering and delivering cargo, including some contra band, through the mountains, along the Venezuelan border to Baranquilla, by the Caribbean Sea, back to Bogot.

title: Brooklyn Slum a Backdrop for TV Training
description: Fortytwo men and women from slum neighborhoods of Brooklyn are preparing for sobs in the broadcasting in dustry by producing televi sion and radio shows that focus on their community.

title: Muscovites Turning Up Noses at Kamamber Cheese
description: MOSCOW, May 1Without advance publicity, Moscow dairy stores last fall began sell ing a new Sovietmade cheese called Russkii Kamamber, which sounds and smells like its French ancestor but which has encountered considerable sales resistance here.

title: DE JESUS AND COLLINS WIN ON P.S.A.L. MAT
description: Schoolboys from Stuyvesant and Art and Design captured four events yesterday to domi nate the second annual Public School Athletic League wres tling championships at Spring field Gardens High School. Fifteen teams competed in the six weight classes.

title: JUDGE IMPOUNDS DUES OF TEACHERS
description: NEWARK, May 1 (AP)A Superior Court judge ordered yesterday that all dues paid by members of the Newark Teach ers' Union be impounded to pay $255,000 in fines imposed on the union during its recent strike.

title: WISCONSIN OARSMEN WIN COCHRANE CUP
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 Wisconsin's varsity crew made an impressive season debut on the Charles River today, de feating Dartmouth by three feet for the Cochrane Cup.

title: L.I. POLICE TO TEST TWO COMPUTERS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 1 Computers will be installed in Nassau County police cars as part of a test to determine the type of communications system that will ultimately be used by all law  enforcement agencies in the state.

title: Fans Jam Infield Early And Lend Festive Mood
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 Mike Bryan had cold fingers. He had the coldest fingers in the commonwealth of Ken tucky. He had cold fingers from clawing through a million ice cubes.

title: Miss Goolagong Takes Tennis Final in England
description: SUTTON, England, May 1 (AP)Evonne Goolagong, 19 yearold Australian tennis star, won the women's title in the Rothmans hardcourt tournament today.

title: Anne Cassebaum Bride of John Herold
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 1 Miss Anne Melyn Cassebaum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Wil liam Henry Cassebaum of Englewood and Nantucket, Mass., was married here this afternoon at her parents' home to John Craig Herold, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Herold of Rome, N.Y. The Rev. David Gillespie of St. Paul's Episcopal Church here performed the cere mony.

title: BusTruck Crash Kills 15
description: BURDWAN, India, May 2 (UPI)Fifteen persons were killed and 45 were injured to day when a bus and a truck collided near this town about 60 miles north of Calcutta, of ficials reported.

title: Births
description: POLANSKYDr. and Mrs. Steven Polansky announce the birth of their son, Jonathan Evan on May 1, 1971.

title: Women Get Vote in Glarus
description: GENEVA, May 2Women were granted the right to vote in cantonal elections today at the annual Landsgemeinde, orl openair meeting, of men voters in Glarus, in eastern Switzer land. The decision was taken by a show of hands. About half of the 22 Swiss cantons now allow women in vole in cantonal or local elections, or both.

title: Richey Triumphs
description: KANSAS CITY, May 2 (AP) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., the No. 1ranked player in the nation, had to battle to defeat 35yearold Alex Olmedo, 75, 57, 62, to take the $3,500 first prize in the Glenwood Manor invitation tennis tourna ment today. Olmedo is a teach ing pro in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Two Chinas or One?
description: The proposal for two China seats in the United Nations urged on President Nixon by a commission under the chairmanship of Henry Cabot Lodge might have helped to protect Taiwan a few years ago, while bringing main land China back into the world community. Now, how ever, a solution of this kind has been greatly complicated by the U.N. General Assembly vote last November which, while not decisive, showed that a majority favors the ouster of Taipei and the transfer of its seat to Peking. The best current chance to resolve the China problem probably lies in the direct negotiation for normalization of relations toward which Washington and Peking are tending. If those negotiations are to go very far, they will have to find a Taiwan compromise.

title: Addict Center Gives Hope in 2 Languages
description: The newest antinarcotics project in the drugridden South Bronx gave a party for itself yesterday to cele brate its establishment in the depressed community and some early success in its bi lingual program.

title: Head of Jewish Unit Named
description: The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies announced last week the election of Dr. Morris N. Kertzer, rabbi of Riverdale Temple in the Bronx, as presi dent of the organization's com mission on synagogue relations.

title: Hogberg Beats Keino in Tel Aviv
description: TEL AVIV, May 2 (UPI)Ulf Hogberg of Sweden defeated the world record holder, Kip choge Keino, with a blistering finish over the last 100 meters to win the 1,500 meters gold medal in the Hapoel Games today.

title: Legislators' Tension on Rise in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 2The 1971 Legislature enters its fifth month this week, and tension among the lawmakers is show ing.

title: EDITH DAY, STARRED IN LONDON MUSICALS
description: LONDON, May 2 (Reuters) Edith Day, a Minneapolisborn actress who starred on the British stage between the two World Wars, died yesterday in a London hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: Rumania, Hungary And Italy Register Davis Cup Sweeps
description: Rumania, Italy and Hungary completed sweeps in the Eu ropean Zone Davis Cup tennis competition yesterday.

title: British Auto Makers Feel Better Times Have Begun
description: LONDON, May 2A breath of spring is blowing through the British automobile industry following years of recession, and auto men are cautiously predicting their best year since 1964. Two events last week added to the air of optimism.

title: Taiwan Holds to a Rigid Policy As Peking Changes Diplomacy
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 2 One of the May Day slogans is sued by Communist China, 26 on a list of 32, declared: We are determined to liberate Tai wan.

title: ELLIOT HOCHSTEIN OF CORNELL STAFF
description: Dr. Elliot Hochstein, clinical professor of medicine at Corn ell University Medical College, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South.

title: Austrian Cardinal Celebrates Mass in a Warsaw Cathedral
description: WARSAW, May 2Franz Cardinal Knig, the Austrian Primate and one of the Vati can's key links with the Com munist bloc, neared the end of a weeklong visit to Poland to day by celebrating mass in one of Warsaw's major cathedrals.

title: Bangla DeshTagore's Ironic Legacy
description: The 110 million Bengalis who inhabit the Ganges Delta in the eastern regions of India and Pakistan  75 million Moslems in the secessionist province of East Pakistan and 35 million Hindus in the Indian state of West Bengal have been described as the Irish of the Indian subcontinent.

title: Husky Oil Appoints
description: The appointment of Gene E. Roark, president of Husky Oil, Ltd., as chief executive officer was announced over the week end by Glenn E. Nielson, chair man. Jams E. Nielson was named as an executive vice president.

title: Union Tries to Organize City's 400 Prosecutors
description: A public employes' union is trying to organize the city's 400 assistant district attorneys to represent them in collective bar gaining.

title: 30,000 Protesters Routed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The metropolitan police ordered 30, 000 antiwar protesters from their encampment on the banks of the Potomac in a sudden strike that began just after dawn today.

title: Fox Attacks Dissidents
description: In a letter to shareholders, the Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation yesterday said that five of the 12 dissident candi dates for the Fox board are directors of the Sun Chemical Corporation which sustained a net loss of $2.77 a share, includ ing an extraordinary loss of $4.53 a share, in 1970.

title: Ryan Takes Yonkers Run
description: YONKERS, May 2  Howie Ryan of the New York Athletic Club won the Eastern regional 10,000meter run today at Tib betts Brook Park. The 25year old Yonkers schoolteacher cov ered the distance in 31 minutes 10.8 seconds

title: A.D.A. ADVOCATES NIXON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) Americans for Democratic Action urged Congress today to impeach President Nixon for high crimes in Indochina and to create a commission to in vestigate the conduct of the war.

title: Body of Sailor Found in Fire At Ripley's Wax Museum
description: An 18yearold sailor was found dead yesterday, apparent ly from smoke inhalation, by firemen who were extinguishing five small fires in Ripley's Be lieve It Or Not Museum at 1539 Broadway, near 45th Street.

title: Nancy Hartley Wed To Martin Richter
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 2 Miss Nancy Hartley was mar ried this afternoon to Martin Richter at the Ethical Society of Philadelphia by Kenneth Smith.

title: $4.3Million to Aid Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transportation, approved today spending $4.3million on proj ects in 10 cities to ease traffic congestion. The cities are Washington, New York, Los Angeles, Atlanta, Dallas, Phila delphia, MinneapolisSt. Paul, Cincinnati, Louisville, Ky., and Dayton, Ohio.

title: CYNTHIA ROGERS
description: Cynthia Rogers, an actress who made several Broadway appearances, notably with Helen Hayes and Philip Mei. vale in Mary of Scotland in 1933, died yesterday at her home, 171 East 62d Street. She was 62 years old.

title: Roundup: Cards' Carlton Posts No.5
description: Minutes after the Cards heat the Montreal Expos, 10, in St. Louis yesterday, Steve Carlton and Carl Mor ton were back in their dress ing rooms, apparently won dering what a difference a year makes.

title: Miss Wampler Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 Miss Crystal Elizabeth Wampler, daughter of Capt. French Wampler Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Wampler of Alexandria, Va., was married here this afternoon to Robert Steven Span, son of Mrs. A. Noel Span of New York and the late Mr. Span, who was a lawyer. The Rev. Edward Morgan 3d, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Alexandria, performed the ceremony in the Navy Chapel.

title: Outboard Racer Injured
description: MIAMI, May 2 (AP)Bruce Heil, a 25yearold rookie out board racer, was injured when his twin engine power boat overturned during a marathon race today at the City of Miami Marine Stadium.

title: Fulbright and Percy Worried by Protests
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he was wor ried that the actions of the antiwar protesters in Washington might jeopardize chances for Senate passage of a bill setting a date for withdrawal of United States forces from Vietnam.

title: LOUIS F. STERN
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 2 Louis F. Stern, retired district manager for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and ac tive in state insurance activi ties, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 9 Stone Drive, Westport.

title: CONTINENTAL RACE CAPTURED BY HOBBS
description: MONTEREY, Calif., May 2 (AB)David Hobbs of England swept two heats today and won the $35,000 L&M Conti nental 5000 race at Laguna Seca Raceway.

title: French Economy Spurting After Series of Setbacks
description: PARIS, May 2Three years ago students took to the streets of Paris and workers began a series of strikes that drained the nation's energy and led to a devaluation 15 months later.

title: ALDONA KEPALAITE IN PIANO PROGRAM
description: For her piano recital at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon, Aldona Kepalaite brought in a program consisting of Faure's Theme and Variations, Bee thoven's Sonata in C (Op. 53) and Chopin's Twelve Etudes (Op. 25).

title: Demonstrations in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2 Demonstrators protesting Mr. Rogers's Middle Eastern visit drove through the streets of Beirut today and dumped hand bills condemning American pol icy. But the public paid little attention.

title: Muskie Expects Country To Recapture Excitement
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (UPD Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that the war in Indochina had caused Americans to lose confidence in their country but that it would recapture thit sense of excitement about both our past and our future.

title: NIXON PROMISES TO HELP FARMERS RAISE NET INCOME
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., May 2President Nixon hailed the surging vitality of our agricul ture today and pledged to help farmers realize more of its rewards.

title: NEWCOMBE WINS FINAL FROM ASHE
description: DALLAS, May 2 (UPI)John Newcombe turned back Arthur Ashe, 76, 64, in the final of the $50,000 Rawlings tennis tournament today for his third triumph on the $1million World Championship Tennis tour. He earned $10,000 to Ashe's $5,000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a comment on the marvelous OpEd article by Marya Mannes (April 22) about Central Park, may I say Hurrah for Miss Mannes.

title: Miss Peggy Bissinger Is Married To Dr. Peter Pressman, Surgeon
description: Miss Peggy Bissinger, daughter of Mrs. Paul A. Bissinger of San Francisco and the late Mr. Bissinger, was married here yesterday to Dr. Peter I. Pressman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Press man of New York.

title: Pumps Run Dry in Gasoline Strike Here
description: The effects of a strike by 1,600 gasoline truck drivers and warehouse workers be gan to be felt in the metro politan region yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: Even before he reaches the first page of this autobiographical work, the reader hears a thundering in the index. The dedica tion is to Nel King, who worked long and hard editing this book, and who is probably the only white person who could have done it. The dust wrapper describes the book's contents as a world few white people know. Threatened with revelation, the reader pauses. Is he going to be excluded again? After years of reading about the black experiencein Ralph Elison, James Baldwin, LeRoi Tones, Claude Brown, El dridge Cleaver and a score of othersis he still an absurd and uncomprehending sightseer, touring Harlem or Watts in a sealed, airconditioned bus?

title: Bridge: Louisiana State Duo Captures The Intercollegiate Pair Title
description: A pair from Louisiana State University captured the 1971 Intercollegiate Pair Championship title by a nar row margin at Dc Kalb, Saturday night. Dennis Con lon and Charles Crosby scored 90 victory points out of a possible 156 to head a field of 14 pairs, the sur vivors from the qualifying and semifinal stages of an original entry of 1,500 pairs.

title: Sabry Removed by Sadat From Vice President's Job
description: CAIRO, May 2Vice Presi dent Aly Sabry has been re lieved of his post by President Anwar elSadat, it was an nounced tonight.

title: Israel Draws Up Position
description: JERUSALEM, May 2  The Israeli Cabinet completed work today on the bargaining posi tion to be conveyed later this week to Secretary Rogers on his first visit to Israel. Spokes men gave no hint of a softening in Israel's position to meet Egypt's terms for a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: PAKISTAN ACCUSES INDIAN AIR FORCE
description: KARACHI, May 3  Amid signs of a deterioration in the already hostile relations be tween India and Pakistan, Paki stan charged that Indian fight er planes had violated Paki stani air space today on two occasions.

title: Cambodia Headquarters Fire
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 2 (AP) fire broke out in the arms room at the Cambodian command's headquarters in downtown Pnompenh tonight, touching off dozens of small explosions. Soldiers there said the fire apparently had been an accident.

title: Chess:
description: The elimination match scheduled to begin on May 13 at Sochi, the popular Soviet resort city on the Black Sea, will find two top Soviet grandmasters, Yefim Geller and Viktor Korchnoi, pitted against one another. The winner will go on to other matches and, possibly, to challenge the world cham pion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, for the title.

title: A Senior Partner Leaves Meehan
description: M. J. Meehan & Co.. one of Wall Street's leading spe cialist firms, is undergoing a toplevel reorganization in volving the departure of one of its senior partners with the specialist books in four major stocks, including the Ford Motor Company.

title: Unhandcuffing the Police?
description: NEW HAVENFor generations, we have tolerated a situation in which police have often searched or interro gated or eavesdropped illegally. As it became plain that police and legisla tors were unwilling to deal realistically with the problem, judges reluctantly concluded that they would have to fill the vacuum. Their solution was the exclusionary rule, an awkward device which is built on a principle of deter rence. It assumes that police miscon duct will be reduced if evidence ob tained illegally is excluded from use at trial. The fact that, in Justice Cardozo's words, a criminal may go free be cause the constable has blundered is regarded as a price worth paying in order to serve the larger social interest.

title: CASTRO SEEKS RISE IN OUTPUT BY LABOR
description: MIAMI, May 2In a three andonehalfhour speech in Havana last night, Premier Fidel Castro acknowledged that low labor productivity contin ued to be the most serious prob lem facing his Government.

title: Forever Slow
description: In an increasingly crowded and polluted nation, it imperative to set aside lands which are still virtually untouched by man. Such lands are essential to preserve an ecological balance for nature and to provide an oppor tunity for solitude for human beings. Recognizing this need, Congress in 1964 passed the Wilderness Act, which established procedures by which lands could be declared Forever Wild.

title: Latest Cambodian Candidate Doesn't Seem Hopeful
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 2Brig Gen. In Tam'made clear today his willingness to be come Cambodia's Premier, but after a day of consultations he returned home tired and ap parently discouraged.

title: CHAPLIN AWARDED A BRANDEIS PRIZE
description: Two men known for their subtle mastery of motion and gesture  Charles Chaplin, vir tuoso of the solitary art of pan tomime on film, and George Balanchine, chroreographer of more than 130 ballets  are among nine winners of the 1971 Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards.

title: Baker, in a Dodge, Gains Victory in Rebel 400 Race
description: DARLINGTON, S. C. May (AP)  Buddy Baker, driv ing a Dodge, passed Don nie Alison with 10 laps to go Sunday to win Rebel 400 stock car race before 46,500 at Darlington Raceway.

title: Abolishing Schools: I
description: CUERNAVACA, MexicoThe en trenchment of institutionalized school ing in the U.S. social structure was recently checked by the Supreme Court in Griggs et al. v. Duke Power Company.

title: TV: Juvenile Offenders
description: Despite some recent bat tering from inside and out side the broadcasting studios, news and documentary fea tures still manage to hold their own nicely on tele vision.

title: LOANS DISCLOSED IN SWISS FAILURE
description: PARIS, May 2More than 80 banks lent a Swiss company that has just gone into volun tary bankruptcy about $80mil lion of high powered money known as Eurodollars, Paris in formants have reported.

title: Lawrence E. Davies
description: Conscientiousness and courtesy were the notsosecret weapons on which Lawrence E. Davies depended to achieve journalistic distinction in his 44 years as a cor respondent for The New York Times. He never succumbed to the myth that a newspaperman had to be either obnoxious or unscrupulous to accumulate an impressive list of exclusive stories. The thousands of persons, from highranking public officials to policemen and clerks, whose first impulse was to call Larry Davies whenever anything newsworthy happened were reacting to some thing more than his sympathetic personality. They quickly came to know that he wrote not just with unfail ing clarity and accuracy but with penetrating under standing as well. Styles in journalism changed, but he was as much a newspaperman's newspaperman when he retired last year as he had been when he was making Alaska and Hawaii part of the everyday consciousness of mainland Americans long before either outpost achieved statehood.

title: Ontario Officials Adapting to New Mood
description: TORONTO, May 2  Premier William G. Davis's Ontario gov ernment, just two months old, has begun to respond in its own way to Canada's surging sense of nationalism.

title: Bodies Found in Wreckage
description: SCRANTON, Pa., May 2 (AP) The bodies of three men were found today in the wreck age of a light plane missing since Feb. 17 in a heavily wooded Pennsylvania game preserve in Susquehanna Coun ty. The state police identified the wreckage as that of the missing plane piloted by Ken neth Granger of Englewood, N.J. Passengers were listed as Benjamin Dokter and his son, Robert, also of Englewood.

title: YANKS SWEEP PAIR BY 21, 54 MARGINS
description: Danny Cater, who had been hitless in five previous official times at bat, lined a tiebreak ing double to center field in the seventh inning or the second game to give the Yankees a sweep of their doubleheader with the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday before a crowd of 21,461 at Yankee Stadium.

title: Cevert, in Tecno, Triumphs And Widens Formula 2 Lead
description: ADENAU, Germany, May 2 (AP)  Francois Cevert of France increased his European Formula Two championship lead today by winning the 34th Eifel race in a Tecno at the Nuerburgring.

title: 12 Bucks Voted Full Shares Of $17,000 Apiece for Title
description: MILWAUKEE, May 2 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks di vided into 12 full shares today the $212,000 for winning the National Basketball Association Championship.

title: SENATE MAY BALK PACT ON OKINAWA
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Be cause of the Senate's insistence on its foreignpolicy preroga tives, the future status of Okinawa, an inflammatory po litical issue in Japan, is becom likg entangled in the lively domestic political issue of tex tile imparts.

title: HENRY C. TAYLOR, TEXTILE AGENT, 77
description: Henry C. Taylor, a textile commission merchant, who was widely known as a bibliophile and a yachtsman, died Satur day at his home here. He was 77 years old and also had a home in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: Mills Says He Would Accept Nomination for President
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that he would accept the Democratic Presi dential nomination in the un likely event the party nomi nated him, but added that he would not campaign for the office before the party's na tional convention next summer.

title: SOUTH MAY PLAY MAJOR ROLE IN '72
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Re cent legislation raises the possi bility that the South, for the first time in decades, may play a major role in the preconven tion campaigning for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination next year.

title: He's Proud of His Home but Doesn't Think a Decorator Would Be
description: Richard Conlon considers himself a lucky and happy man. He sees hun dreds of friends daily and at night re turns to a midtown apartment that is decorated exactly the way he wants it. He refers to it as early American Irish boy style.

title: TableTennis Group Enrolls the President
description: DETROIT, May 2 (UPI) President Nixon has been made an honorary member of the United States Table Tennis Association, the group, that will be host to table tennis players from Commu nist China when they visit the United States.

title: IMPORTS OF STEEL APPARENTLY EASE
description: PITTSBURGH, May 2  Do mestic steel producers were moderately encouraged last week by what appeared to be a slowing of imports.

title: CEYLONESE SEARCH FOR REBEL LEADER
description: KEGALLE, Ceylon, May 2 Col. Fernando Mahendran stabbed a blunt finger at the lush green hills around him and snapped, the rascal, he's still alive unfortunately, but we hope he'll come in quietly and surrender.

title: U. S. Stars Ponder Throwing Races
description: Top United States track and field athletes may run for fun instead of first place at the men's Amateur Athlet ic Union outdoor champion ships next month in order to skip the PanAmerican Games at Cali, Colombia, July 30 through Aug. 13.

title: Mrs. Sarah E. Collins Dies; Centenarian Was a Slave
description: TALLAPOOSA, Ga., May 2 (UPI)  Mrs. Sarah Elizabeth Collins, an American Negro who was born into slavery, died yesterday. Her age was said to be 116.

title: BOOBYTRAPPED BAG KILLS BROOKLYN MAN
description: A Brooklyn man was killed yesterday when he picked up paper shopping bag that con tained an explosive device in the hallway of his, building, the police said.

title: Something for Granted
description: People are taught that they should never take good things for granted. However, there is an im portant excep tion  United States Savings Bonds. Millions of Americans everywhere al ready take bonds for granted. They re ceive them regularly through Payroll Savings and BondA Month Plans. The bonds are purchase automatically. The money is not missed. It is amassed.

title: Advertising:
description: The same Harvard Business School professor who sur veyed businessmen's attitudes toward advertising in 1962, has checked them again. He finds on most key issues, opinion has moved some 5 to 10 percentage points toward an antiadvertising position.

title: AMEX TO AUTOMATE ORDERS IN ODD LOTS
description: The American Stock Ex change announced over the weekend that it had developed a system for the computerized execution of investors' oddlot market orders. Oddlot orders are those involving fewer than 100 shares.

title: Vigil at Summer Compound
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., May 2 About 250 to 300 persons held an orderly prayer vigil spon sored by the Jewish Defense League outside the summer compound belonging to the So viet Mission to the United Na tions here tonight, the Nassau County Police Department re ported. The police said the group, many carrying memorial candles, dispersed without inci dent shortly after 8 P.M.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: ROME, May 2 (UPI)  Ken Rosewall, the Australian pro fessional, withdrew today from the Italian international tennis tournament because of a back injury he suffered in the Dallas invitation last week.

title: Man Whose Vote Passed Abortion Law Honored
description: No regrets but rather a deep inner peace.

title: MISS HAYNIE'S 68 WINS DALLAS GOLF
description: DALLAS, May 2 (UPI)San dra Haynie won the Dallas Civitan women's open today by carding a 68 on the final round for a 54hole score of 201, one stroke over the Ladies Profes sional Golfers Association rec ord for this distance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If only the people of this country would unite behind our President to day, then Hanoi would get the mes sage tomorrow and the war would be over before the dawn of another day.

title: Bombs in Belfast Damage Homes of 2 Police Officials
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 2 (UPI)  Bombs exploded tonight at the homes of the chief and the Superintendent of Belfast's Special Branch detec tion division Police sources blamed the outlawed Irish Re publican Army.

title: Richard Vanderwarker Is Dead; Headed SloanKettering Center
description: Richard D. Vanderwarker, president since 1964 of the Memorial SloanKettering Can cer Center, died yesterday of Cancer in the center's hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Pawling, N. Y. and at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Javits Urges U.S. to Help Red China Get U.N. Seat
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, urged yesterday that the United States help find a formula that would give Communist China a seat in the United Nations with continued membership for the Republic of China on Tai wan.

title: Smith Victor in Paris
description: PARIS, May 2 (UPI)Stan Smith, the United States Davis Cup star from Pasadena, Calif., swept to a 62, 62, 75 victory over Francois Jauffret of France today to win the Paris open tennis final.

title: Wife Keeps Long Rein on Trot Driver
description: Although harness racing's second world driving cham pionship series doesn't start until tonightat Roosevelt RacewayAdolf Ubleis of Austria, the youngest of the eight drivers in the interna tional competition, already, has problems.

title: MYRON E. DOUCETTE, STONY BROOK AIDE
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., May 2, Dr. Myron E. Doucette, an engineer who played a key part in the planning and develop ment of laboratories and other facilties at the State University of New York campus here, died of cancer today in Mather Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on North Road in Setauket.

title: M'GOVERN DECRIES MINE SUIT DELAYS
description: WASHINGTON. May 2 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, ac cused the Justice Department today of conscious but un conscionable inaction in a sevenyearold case involving the right of members of the United Mine Workers of Amer ica to elect their own district leaders.

title: Ansbacher & Co. Holdings Sold by the Fidelity Bank
description: The Fidelity Bank, Philadel phia, announced over the week end that it has sold its 30 per cent interest in Henry Ans bacher & Co. of London to Robert Fraser Holdings, another British merchant bank.

title: Seoul Asks Training Reform
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 2 (UPI)The South Korean Edu cation Ministry has instructed colleges and universities to propose improvements in the campus military training pro gram, which college students demonstrated against for two weeks last month.

title: North Salem Polo Victor
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 2Ed McNamara scored nine goals to lead North Salem (N. Y.) to a 215 polo victory over the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today in the losers' arena.

title: New Council of Ministers Appointed by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, May 2 (UPI) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi formed a new Council of Min isters today, adding 18 mem bers of Cabinet or subcabinet rank drawn largely from the younger members of her New Congress party. She also pro moted two leftists.

title: Exodus From Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2  Canonero II rested this morn ing, grazing and walking, and appearing in fine shape after his surprise victory. The colt was at home, for he is a prod uct of these parts, a Kentucky bred son of Pretendre and Dixieland II.

title: YOUTHS WONDER WHO HEARD THEM
description: WASHINGTON, May 2'We are listening; we do care and do want to know what are your concerns and how you rank the priorities among these con cerns, Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told the opening session of the White House con ference on Youth two weeks ago today.

description: Shop Talk

title: Col. Louis Bowler, 81, Aide Of Wainwright on Corregidor
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., May (UPI)Col. Louis J. Bowler, chief of staff for Gen. Jonathan Wainwright during the Corregi dor campaign of World War II, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., May 2Miss Paula Rosen feld, a social worker with the Westchester County Commu nity Health Center here, was married this afternoon to Daniel Schram, a commercial artist. Rabbi Hirschel Jaffe performed the ceremony at Sinai Temple.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 2Two of America's most famous political namesLa Follette and Taftwill be matched against each other in a local election May 25. The Taft is the more liberal.

description: At the $125aplate testi monial dinner given for him March 22, Joseph Colombo S. posed for a traditional family portraitthe benign patriarch surrounded by his wife, four sons, two daugh tersinlaw and a 5yearold daughter.

description: Mayor Lindsay warned yes ??day of prospective new lay ??s of city employes, saying, ??e're getting ready for an ??her round of bloodletting. dications later were that is would involve hundreds of ??rkers.

title: Church Honors a Governor
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May (AP)Gov. Dale Bumpers was made an honorary member to day of the predominantly Negro Mount Pleasant Baptist Church. The Rev. J. H. Corbitt said that the event was symbolic of the progress in Arkansas when the state's Governor will accept such a certificate from a church that was founded by slaves in 1875.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 2There was a rally in London recently in behalf of George Jackson, the black prisoner who wrote Soledad Brother, and Angela Davis, who is charged with complicity in the kidnap and murder of a California judge by Jackson's brother Jonathan and others. It was in many ways an extraordinary public meeting for Lon don.

title: Advertising:
description: Although it didn't quite match the frantic quality of secondquarter selling during the first of March, last week's thirdquarter sales for night time network television were reportedly great.

title: DR. ALFRED PASSERA, INTERNIST IN QUEENS
description: Dr. Alfred E. Passera, an in ternist, who retired recently as director of the department of medicine at St. John's Queens Hospital, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home, 4141 50th Street, Woodside, Queens. His age was 65.

description: Legislative sources indicated yesterday that agreement was near on a plan to more than double the $28million in special state aid to parochial schools approved last year.

description: To the Editor:No wonder there is a credibility gap. May I quote from the April 26 issue of The Times:

title: Gellineau Manages To Beat the Crowd In Bike Race Here
description: Louis Maltese, who has held legal and illegal bike races in Central Park since 1936, conducted one of the former yesterday in memory of his older brother, Carlo. Patrick Gellineau of Brook lyn set a course record in it.

title: Quadruplets Born in Texas
description: DALLAS, May 2 (AP)Quad ruplets were born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. Clifford J. Ward and were doing fair today, a spokesman at Presbyterian hos pital said. The four infants, two boys and two girls were deliv ered prematurely by Caesarean section in about five minutes.

title: Miles City, Mont., Mourns End of Passenger Trains
description: MILES CITY, Mont., May 2  Casey Barthelmess, 80 years old, once a bronc buster and a cowpoke, shifted on his crutches outside the de pot. He tried to sound unin terested in what had hap pened.

description: WASHINGTON, May 2The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: PAUL VINCENT JOHNSON
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., May Paul Vincent Johnson, an im porter with Charles B. Martin & Co. in Manhattan, died today at his home on Pequot Road. He was 52 years old.

title: CourtApproved Wiretaps By Police Doubled in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  A new report to Congress on po Ilice eavesdropping shows that the number of courtapproved wiretaps used by Federal and state law enforcement agencies almost doubled in 1970 over the figure for 1969.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ISRAELAID GROUP OPENS FUND DRIVE
description: The National Committee for Labor Israel began a drive yes terday to raise $30million over a fiveyear period from wills and legacies to supper humani tarian programs carried out by Histadrut, Israel's labor federa tion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Burke Marshall can, of course, speak for himself as to the meaning of his comments (OpEd April 10), but Maj. Gen. John H. Cushman's letter (April 26) misses the point of the question of war waged against civilians in Viet nam. Since missing the point has be come an endemic intellectual failure in modern America, the difference here worth pointing out.

title: Moscow's MiniExodus
description: A dramatic and positive change has taken place the last five months in the Soviet Government's attitude toward its alienated Jewish citizens who wish to migrate to Israel. Last Christmas the world was shocked at the death sentences pronounced upon two defendants who had conspired with other Jews to hijack a Soviet plane. The global revulsion at that barbaric verdict not only saved the doomed men but apparently put Soviet policy on this matter into reverse gear. Since last Jan. 1, about 2,500 Soviet Jews have been permitted to emigrate. Last month alone more than 1,300 departed, probably the largest number of such emigrants in any single month since Israel became a state.

title: Montclair School Race Issue Renewed
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 2 The issue of race and schools has moved to the forefront once again in this welltodo suburb, following the decision by the Superintendent of Mont clair's public schools, an nounced last Wednesday, not to rehire Robert B. Lee, the high school's only black male counselor.

title: The Dance: Clockwise Charms Anew
description: With four dance companies in town, no one can be everywhere. One nice aspect of the arrangement is that with the Stuttgart Ballet playing a schedule of Mon daythroughSaturday nights, with Wednesday and Satur day matinees, and the three American companies play ing the traditional Tuesday through Sunday, it does mean that the American dancers can get to see something of John Cranko's Stuttgart com pany and the Germans can see what is happening in American dance.

title: The Mayday Tribe: Creativeness, Joy and Life Against Bureaucracy and Grim Death
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Mayday Tribe says that May day is an action, a time period, a state of mind and a bunch of people.

title: Medical Teachers Oppose Separate U.S. Cancer Unit
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 2A group of faculty members from medical schools around the country voiced opposition to day to establishing a separate national cancer authority. They argued that it would hamper, rather than help the fight against cancer.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are one of the nine million people who own small boats, now is an advanta geous time to review your insurance coverage. And if you know how to go about it, you might even be able to save yourself money.

title: Mets Triumph in 10th, 65 After Astros Score 3 in 9th
description: HOUSTON, May 2The New York Mets dissipated a three run lead in the ninth inning today and almost lost a one run lead in the 10th, but they finally subdued the Houston Astros, 65, for the sixth vic tory in their last seven games.

title: Japanese Aid, Up 44% in '70, Nears Target Set by the U.N.
description: KUALA LUMPER, Malaysia, May 2Japanese economic aid to underdeveloped countries, long criticized as stingy in the terms offered and directed to ward promotion of exports, has come within striking distance of a major target: 1 per cent of the annual gross national productthe total of goods and services produced in the coun try each year.

title: Suez Canal Impasse: What All Sides Want
description: CAIRO, May 2The guns have been quiet along the Suez Canal front for almost nine months. Egyptian and Israeli soldiers stand in the open be side the blocked waterway, watching each other warily but hurling nothing more deadly than occasional abusive re marks.

title: Shirley Clarke Film Show
description: Eleven short and feature films made by one of the few American woman directors, Shirley Clarke, will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art starting Thursday, when The Cool World will be screened at 8 P.M. A program of shorts including Dance in the Sun, In Paris Parks, Bullfight, A Moment of Love, Bridges GoRound, Loops, Sky scraper and A Scary Time will be shown at 2 and 5:30 P.M. Subsequent features to be screened are The Connection (1961) and Portrait of Jason (1967).

title: Dr. Theodore K. Lawless Dead; Won N.A.A.C.P. Prize in 1954
description: CHICAGO, May 2Dr. Theo dore K. Lawless, a leading dermatologist, who won the 1954 Spingarn Medal of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People for distinguished merit and achievement among American Negroes, died yesterday in Michael Reese Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Rogers and King Confer In Arabia and in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 2  Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred for more than two hours today with King Faisal of Saudi Arabia before flying here from Riyadh on the second leg of his Middle East ern tour.

title: RALLY BIDS SOUTH FIGHT URBAN ILLS
description: ATLANTA, May 2An or ganization of young Southern progressives ended a twoday conference this weekend with a call for mutual defense against the greatest threats to Southern cities since the armies of Gen. William T. Sherman  urban blight, pollution and racial po larity.

title: HOWARD F. M' MILLIN, FLUID POWER EXPERT
description: WINNETKA, Ill., May 2 (AP) Howard F. MacMillin, pioneer in the modernday fluid power industry and manufacturer of hydraulic plastic molding ma chines, died yesterday. He was 73 years old.

title: Similar Effort in Rockland
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., May 2 About 5,000 teenagers walked distances up to 30 miles in Rockland County today in a project that is expected to raise about $80,000 for the American Freedom From Hunger Founda tion.

title: EVERETT FRANK
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 2 Everett Frank, a former chair man of the Childs Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 14 Woodfield Drive. He was 77 years old.

title: Big Oil Search Is Planned in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2 More than a century and half ago the hard riding llaneros, the Western Hemisphere's first cowboys, played a vital role in freeing Colombia from Spanish rule.

title: SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS PUNISHED BY JERSEY
description: TRENTON, May 2 (AP)Offi cials of New Jersey's Division of Motor Vehicles reported over the weekend that 380 school bus drivers had their special operator's licenses lifted by the state last month.

title: CREDIT MARKETS DIVIDED ON RATES
description: The credit markets are unus ually deeply divided about which way interest rates will move next.

title: Adoption Agency Rebuts Attack By Court in Baby Lenore Case
description: The SpenceChapin Adoption Agency, in its first official com ment on the Baby Lenore adop tion case, has rejected a court criticism of the speed of its ac tion in placing the baby with an adoptive family.

title: Hawks Win by 42, Oust Rangers
description: CHICAGO, May 2The im posing presence of Bobby Hull, with his extraordinary slap shot, proved more potent than the Rangers' depth today and the Black Hawks triumphed 42, and won their semifinal Stanley Cup series. The Hawks will play the Montreal Canadiens in the final, with the first game sched uled at Chicago Tuesday night.

title: Witness in Bombing of Capitol Refuses to Answer Questions
description: SEATTLE. May 2Leslie Bacon, in her third day of questioning as a material wit ness in the investigation of the bombing of the United States Capitol on March 1, refused to Answer some questions today as a matter of privilege, her attorneys said tonight.

title: Sabotaging Medical Care
description: In a period of universal agreement on the need for more efficient and more economical medical care, the State Legislature is considering two bills that would go in the opposite direction.

title: 32,000 Youths Hike to Help Charities
description: ROCHESTER, May 2Thirty two thousand young people carrying litter bags and lunches hiked 25 miles around Roches ter today to raise funds for the international programs of Project Hope and several local charitable organizations.

title: KILLING OF CIVILIANS LAID TO A GENERAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) An Army brigadier general is under investigation by mili tary officials for allegedly shooting to death six Vietna mese civilians as he flew over them in 1968, Pentagon sources said today

title: Scientists Glum on Disarmament Pace
description: Scientists who helped arm the nation with nuclear bombs and a host of other terrifying weapons, or who watched their colleagues do so, took stock last week of efforts to curb the arms race.

title: Two Women Share Lead In Atlanta Title Bowling
description: ATLANTA, May 2 (AP)A split in the final frame pre vented a 23yearold St. Peters burg, Fla., housewife from tak ing the undisputed lead in the open allevents division of the women's International Bowling Congress championship tourna ment.

title: ROTA SCORES 31, TO GAIN U.S. FINAL
description: New York Hots, playing fine soccer, moved to within one game of the United States Challenge Cup championship yesterday by defeating Danube of Cleveland, 31, in the East ern final before 1,100 fans at Park Stadium in Franklin Square, L.I.

description: Governor Rockefeller yester day rejected recent suggestions by city officials that members of the uniformed forces be re quired to live in the city.

title: Week's Votes In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

title: SOUTH FLORIDA RAIN MITIGATES DROUGHT
description: MIAMI, May 2 (UPI)  A clamp, dreary Sunday brought hope to south Floridians who during the weekend saw their first heavy rain since last Sep tember. But weather officials warned that the area's worst drought in history was not broken.

title: Music Charms Strollers In Closed Harlem Street
description: The slow cadence of music for Swahili dancers and the quick beat of rock drew ap preciative followers in Har lem yesterday.

title: Cambodians Report LinkUp
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 2 (UPI)Cambodian forces re ported fighting a major battle with the enemy 55 miles south west of Pnompenh yesterday and spokesmen said Cambodian troops had linked up by land with the embattled Govern ment garrison at the Pich Nil Pass.

title: Foe Remains Elusive in Ashau Valley
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 2The South Vietnamese Army has reported no new con tact with the enemy in its 18 dayold operation in the moun tains around the Ashau Valley.

title: Beard's 276 Beats Green by Shot in New Orleans Open
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 2If I could only play in one tourna ment a year, it would be the New Orleans open, Frank Beard said today after win ning by one stroke and dupli cating a triumph he scored here in 1966.

title: Class 44: Childish Fantasy Is More Than MakeBelieve
description: Unknown to the rest of the school, unicorns, dragons, monsters too monstrous to be named, Martians, beauti ful princesses with hair like golden flax, their paladins and frenzied, battling frogs have been inhabiting a drab lunchroom for teachers in the depths of Public School 198.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was highly dismaying to read the appeal of Clinton E. Knox, the Ameri can Ambassador in Haiti, for more at tention to and financial support of the handpicked successor of the late dic tator Francois Duvalier.

title: DE LEYER EXCELS IN RIDING EVENTS
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., May 2Harry de Leyer, master of Hollandia Farms in St. James, mastered his competition today at the Rice Farms' horse show at the Middle Island Arena.

title: Susan Korey Bride of John Miller
description: SEATTLE, May 2  Miss Susan Ruth Korey of Mercer Island and John Ripin Miller were married here this after noon. Rabbi Norman Hirsh performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Am.

title: Airline in Peru Halts Flights As Finances Are Examined
description: LIMA, Peru, May 2 (AP) Aerolineas Peruanas, Peru's pri vately owned international air line, canceled all flights today until further notice amid re ports of growing financial dif ficulties.

title: SUPPORT OF RADIO BY C.I.A. MAY END
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Nixon Administration is report ed to be preparing to ask Con gress to authorize a public private corporation that would finance Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty through annual Congressional appropriations of $36million.

title: Moss Seeks Panel on Ads
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Senator Frank E. Moss, Demo crat of Utah, said today that he would introduce a bill tomor row to create a National Insti tute of Advertising, Marketing and Society. In a speech pre pared for the Senate, Mr. Moss said that there were profound and unsetting questions con cerning the social role of ad vertising.

title: Pipelines Viewed as Economic Threat to Suez
description: JERUSALEM, May 2Israeli and other economists believe that the most serious longterm threat to the Suez Canal comes, not from war or deadlocked diplomacy, but from the eco nomic challenges of the oil pipelines.

title: U.S. Jet Attacks in North
description: SAIGON, Monday, May 3 (Reuters)A United States Air Force Phantom fighterbomber attacked an antiaircraft posi tion in North Vietnam late yes terday, the United States mili tary command announced to day.

title: Quake Jolts Alaska Base
description: ADAK, Alaska, May 2 (AP) An earthquake registering 7.1 on the Richter scale shook the naval station here last night. No injuries or damage was re ported. The 1964 Alaska earth quake that took 130 lives and caused more than $300million damage registered 8.3 on the Richter scale.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Three weeks ago, Jim Schindler, a junior on the New York University track team, heard rumors that impending budget cuts might affect his school's sports program. I remember thinking, he said recently, they wouldn't let us have the new nylon running shorts, there'd be no new shoes, and they'd have to turn off the airconditioning in the athletic department. When they announced the whole program was dead, I was really shocked. It happened so suddenly, it was like last year when they suddenly can celed R.O.T.C. I was in that too and there was nothing I could do.

title: OTB, a Winner on Derby, Eyes Preakness Betting
description: The malady lingered yester day from a siege of Kentucky Derby fever that spread on Sat urday all the way from Louis ville, Ky., to New York. Here were the developments:

title: Poll Majority Backs F.B.I. But Would Retire Hoover
description: A majority of Americans be lieve the Federal Bureau of Investigation is doing a good job, but believe the director, J. Edgar Hoover, should retire, according to a poll conducted by the Gallup organization for Newsweek magazine.

title: Nixon Farm Salute Scored
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) Lawrence F. O'Brien, Demo cratic national chairman, said today that President Nixon was misusing $100,000 in Depart ment of Agriculture funds to boost his sagging relations with the American farmer. He de manded that a salute to agri culture scheduled for Friday on a White House lawn be financed by the Republican National Committee instead of the Gov ernment.

title: Eliahu Inbal, Israeli Conductor, Bows With American Symphony
description: A cultural agronomist could no doubt analyze the soil of Israel and tell us why that fairly small, relatively young nation has sprouted so many firstclass musicians. The latest of the crop to be exported here, the Jerusalemborn conductor Eliahu Inbal, made his New York debut yesterday afternoon with the American Symphony Orchestra. He proved to be a worthy addition to the list of talents.

title: LAURETTA FELDMAN GIVES SONG RECITAL
description: A program of vocal chamber music was offered by Lauretta Mennone Feldman in her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night. The so prano was assisted by the Da Vinci String Quartet, Robert Kaufman, piano, Patricia Spen cer, flute, and Jill Castillo, bass.

title: Dignity in Dying Is Goal of New Studies
description: ROCHESTER, May 1  A growing league of profes sionals is trying to throw new light on a longtaboo subject that sooner or later touches every human being death.

title: Nature Center Offered
description: MILWAUKEE, May 2 (AP) A 185acre tract of woodlands and ravines on the shore of Lake Michigan north of Mil waukee has been offered to the National Audubon Society by the Schlitz Foundation for use as a nature center and environ mental education site. The Schlitz Foundation is a private charitable and philanthropical organization supported by con tributions from the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company.

title: Italian Social Democratic Aide Asks Talks With Communists
description: ROME, May 2The Minister of Labor and Social Welfare, Carlo Donat Cattle, and other leading left  wing Christian Democrats called today for constructive discussions with the Communist party.

title: Harlem Company to Share Stage With City Ballet
description: The Dance Theater of Har lem, the twoyearold black ballet company founded by Arthur Mitchell, and the New York City Ballet will share the State Theater stage Thursday night for a single performance of a ballet choreographed by George Balanchine and Mr. Mitchell. The new work will be pre sented as part of the City Ballet's annual gala benefit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 77 in J.D.L. Seized in Sitdown On 3d Ave. Near Soviet Mission
description: Seventyseven members of the militant Jewish Defense League were arrested yesterday after noon on charges of disorderly conduct for staging a sitdown that obstructed traffic on Third Avenue, near the Soviet Mis sion to the United Nations.

title: Woman Lawyer Still Awaits a Bid to Board
description: The woman whose name has been cropping up at an nual meetings as the logical choice for a first woman di rector of a major corporation feels like the bride whom the groom neglected to propose to.

title: WAGES FOR STEEL Pill Al CAN LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 Some of the closest advisers of President Nixon are already re signed to a wage settlement in the steel industry as high as that won by the same union in the can industrya settlement that the Council of Economic Advisers said publicly would be too large for the health of steel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: School Registration Begins For Younger Children Here
description: The Board of Education has announced advance registra tion for kindergarten and first grade pupils will take place this week in the city's 652 pub lic elementary schools.

title: A Polish Leader Drops From Public View
description: WARSAW, May 3  The monthlong absence from the public eye of a prominent Pol ish Politburo member has be come a major political puzzle in Warsaw.

title: SCRIBNER NAMES 23 TO ADMISSIONS UNIT
description: A 23member committee, which includes three students, has been appointed by School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner to study admission policies to the city's four specialized aca demic high schools.

title: Boulez Brings Clarity, Control To Chamber Society's Concert
description: Blinding clarity, precise bal ance of relationships, detail graded minutely into grand schemesin short, perfect con trol as translated into sound by an extremely keen ear and a brilliant musical intelligence: these were the paramount qual ities when Pierre Boulez con ducted members of the Cham ber Music Society of Lincoln Center and guests at Tully Hall late Sunday afternoon.

title: Summary of Actions Taken on Cases Before the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Doubts of Change in Poland
description: WARSAW, May 3The change of leadership in East Germany was seen here tonight as unlikely to alter links within Eastern Europe or in ties be tween the Communist bloc and the West.

title: Slimming the City Budget
description: There is one astonishing omission in the socalled sur vival budget of $9.13 billion Mayor Lindsay has sub mitted to the City Council and the Board of Estimate. contains not the remotest suggestion that the city could save many millions of dollars without diminution of use ful service to its citizens by increased efficiency in the operation of every municipal agency.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS REVERSEBIAS CASE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal filed by 10 white teachers in Newark, who contended they were vic tims of discrimination in re verse because their school board promoted black teachers to principals, partly because of their race.

title: ROCKEFELLER SEEKS CONTROLS ON CAN
description: ALBANY, May 3Governor Rockefeller proposed legislation today to permit the state's Public Service Commission to join Federal and municipal agencies in regulating the growing cable television (CATV) industry.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The award, for all his work on The Los Angeles Times in 1970, was his second Pulitzer . . . Won the first in 1964 for his previous year's work on The Denver Post . . . Re ceived the Sigma Delta Chi Distinguished Service Award for 1962, 1968 and 1970, and the George Polk Memorial Award last year . . . Was born in 1924 in Cedar Rapids, Iowa . . . Graduated from high school in Des Moines in 1942 . . . Served three years in the Army Corps of Engi neers, including 18 months in the Pacific Theater in World War II . . . Began drawing cartoons on The Daily Iowan while attending the Univer sity of Iowa . . . After grad uation in 1950, joined The Post art department and be came a staff cartoonist six months later . . . His work eventually was syndicated in 80 papers . . . Transferred to The Los Angeles Times in February. 1964 . . . Married Kay King, a former society writer for The Denver Post.

title: U.S. Experts Think Ulbricht May Have Gotten Mild Shove
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  American experts in Communist affairs said today there were indications that Walter Ulbricht might have received a mild shove to resign now in the in terest of orderly transition before the East German Com munist party's congress in June.

title: Cut in Water Use Ordered In Florida's Drought Area
description: MIAMI, May 3 (UPI)The Central and Southern Florida Flood Control District ordered today a 20to25 per cent man datory curtailment of fresh water use for more than two million residents of the drought stricken area.

title: VATICAN SETTLES BIRTH CURB CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The dispute between Patrick Cardi nal O'Boyle and 19 priests sus pended for publicly dissenting from the 1968 papal ban on artificial birth control ended in a draw last week, according to clergymen close to the case. Both sides claimed a victory.

title: Court Fight Aggravates Dispute at Dalton School
description: A court fight this week over the presidency of the Dalton School parentteachers associa tion has further entangled the continuing dispute over the policies of the prestigious pri vate school.

title: POTATO FUTURES POST SHARP GAINS
description: Maine potato futures closed up sharply yesterday in fairly active trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange here. The May contract, which will be closed out on Monday, rose 35 cents to $4.03 from $3.78 a hundred pounds on Friday on the sale of 2,312 contracts. A total of 2,336 contracts changed hands.

title: Leisure Money Seen Rising
description: America's discretionary in come  the money left after necessities have been paid for will total $850billion a year by 1975, according to a leisure time marketing study conduct ed by OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation.

title: KENT STATE HOLDS A 4DAY MEMORIAL
description: KENT, Ohio, May 3Quiet, not loud, that's the way it should be. People should go to the candlelight vigil and then go back to their own thing.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: A 31yearold South Caro linian, he has been Washing ton Post correspondent in Africa since 1969... His prize articles on apartheid in South Africa were based on sixweek visit he made there in April and May, 1970... Born in Rock Hill, S.C., Jan. 22, 1940... Graduated from University of South Carolina and served three years in Air Force as first lieutenant... First newspaper job was on The Rock Hill Evening Herald From 1964 to 1966 was deskman and occasional jazz critic for international edition of The New York Times in Paris... Joined Washington Post in 1966 and covered ur ban problems in Washington ... Received 12stitch wound in head while covering racial trouble in Orangeburg, S. C., in 1968... Was Ford Founda tion Fellow in international reporting at Columbia Uni versity in 196869... Lives in Nairobi, Kenya, when not roaming Africa.

title: MinimumWage Rise Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said today he would introduce legislation soon to raise the Federal minimum wage 65 cents an hour to $2.25 an hour and extend coverage to 13 mil lion more workers.

title: South Vietnam Rail Strike
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 3 (Reuters)South Viet nam's coastal railroad system virtually came to a halt today when almost 4,000 rail workers conducted their first strike, 24hour action to underline requests for wage increases.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 3 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp re scinded today a ban on open fires and smoking in and near woodlands following a weekend of rain.

title: Mario Davidovsky Music
description: Lecturer in music at Co lumbia University since 1966, and also now associate pro fessor of music at City Col lege. . . . Born in Buenos Aires, March 4, 1934, came to United States in 1958.... His prizewinning composi tion, Synchronisms No. 6, for piano and electronic sound, was introduced at the Berkshire Music Festival, last August.... Numerous hon ors and awards, including the Broadcast Music Incor porated prize, Brandeis Uni versity Award, Aaron Copland Award, election to American. Institute of Arts and Letters, commissions and grants from Rockefeller, Guggenheim, Koussevitzky, Fromm Foun dations, Library of Congress. ... Tall, dark, curlyhaired scholarly looking.... Mar ried Elaine Blaustein, 1962. ... They have two children, Matias Gabriel and Adriana, and live on West End Ave nue, New York City.

title: FIERY ALLEY TROUPE LIFTS JOPLIN LAMENT
description: Alvin Ailey's Flowers, a lament for Janis Joplin, the late popular singer, is not a strik ingly good ballet but received a stunning performance Sunday evening at the City Center from Consuelo Atlas who danced the Girl for the first time. She showed awareness in charac terizing the changing fortunes of the cocky selfassured star on the way up, slowly becoming the inwardly hemorrhaging shell of a falling personality.

title: Humphrey Assails A.D.A. On Impeachment of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today described as irresponsible and unwarranted the resolution adopted by Americans for Democratc Action calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: News Analysis
description: ATLANTA, May 1There are only 556 days left in the 1972 Presidential campaign, which may be why the Democratic frontrunner, Senator Edmund S. Muskie, is starting to sprint in spite of himself. Though there is not much to be said yet for the quality of the race, the pace is fast becoming debilitating. I keep telling my advance men that if they were wom en they'd all be pregnant, the Senator remarked between a roller coaster ride here and an airborne leap to Macon to meet some weekly newspaper editors. They just can't say no to anything.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: Looking very much like a Vassar undergraduate, which she was only three years ago, she seemed an ideal choice to investigate the life of Diana Oughton, the radical student who met death in a Green which Village bomb factory... Frequently confronted by an tagonism and hatred for the establishment press, she and her partner, Mr. Powers, pur sued their story. It led them into sparsely furnished apart ments serving as communes. There were furtive meetings on street corners. Some were fruitful, others were not, and sometimes the contacts never showed up. But ultimately she was able to enter into the culture of youthful radi cals . . . She had covered young people at demonstra tions, rallies and rock con certs since joining United Press International three years ago. During most of that time she was stationed in London . . . Born in Chi cago in 1940, she grew up at Wellesley.

title: EDWARD P. DOZIER, INDIANS' LEADER
description: Dr. Edward P. Dozier, a Pueblo Indian, who was a lead ing authority on the anthro pology and linguistics of Amer ican Indians, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 55 years old.

title: Car Rental Industry Favors National NoFault Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  The car rental industry en dorsed today proposals for nationwide system of nofault auto insurance.

title: Jersey City Municipal Clerk Blocks Recall Vote
description: JERSEY CITY, May 3City Clerk Thomas F. X. Smith blocked a recall election in volving Mayor Thomas J. Whelan, declaring today that more than 1,000 of the petitions seeking the election had been forged.

title: National Fuel Study Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Senate approved today a bill calling for a national fuel and energy policy study. The bill would authorize the Senate Interior Committee to conduct an investigation of the nation's fuel and energy requirements had supplies.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT EXPANDS PROFIT
description: Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation moved slightly higher during the first quarter of 1971 despite a de cline in sales, it reported yes terday.

title: Books of The Times
description: PROMISES TO KEEP: My Years in Public Life, 19411969. By Chester Bowles. 657 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. A Cass Canfield Book. $12.95.

title: JUSTICES TO HEAR 2 ABORTION SUITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Supreme Court agreed today to consider if state antiabortion laws violated the constitutional rights of pregnant women by denying them the right to de cide whether or not they will have children.

title: Harness Tracks Ask Right To Book Off track Wagers
description: ALBANY, May 3Republican majority leaders of the Legislature reacted favorably today to an offtrack betting bill that would establish the eight harness racing tracks as exclusive offtrack betting op erators in all parts of the state outside New York City.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday in slow trading although a late rally erased many of the earlier losses.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION HITS A PEAK LEVEL
description: Steel production rose last week to the highest level in history, breaking a record set four weeks earlier, the Ameri can Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday in Washing ton.

title: WOMEN PROFESSORS SCARCE AT HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 A special Harvard faculty committee on the status of women in the university has called the number of women professors at Harvard dis gracefully small.

title: Escobedo, of '64 Decision, Loses Surveillance Plea
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Daniel Escobedo of Chicago, whose 1964 appeal sparked the Court's first major opinion restricting police questioning of suspects.

title: 5 KENT STATE SUITS FILED IN CLEVELAND
description: CLEVELAND, May 3 (UPI) Five separate suits, seeking more than $57million in dam ages, were filed today, on be half of two Kent State Univer sity students killed by Ohio National Guardsmen and two students who were wounded.

title: SHOW OF ANTIQUES GETS 100 DEALERS
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 3 Some came to the opening to day of the Eastern States An tiques Fair here because it was too wet for gardening; others stayed away because of the stock market performance. But, altogether, the turnout for one of the favorite shows in the East was generous and justified.

title: WILBUR C. DAVIDSON, CORPORATE LAWYER
description: Wilbur C. Davidson, a lawyer here for 47 years, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 1111 Park Avenue.

title: Resor, in Vietnam, Expects Difficulties As Troops Pull Out
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor, ending a 10day review of the Vietnamization program today, said that while progress to date is encouraging, a difficult period lies ahead because of the continuing pullout of United States troops.

title: Construction Men Seem Confused on Wage Order
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A month after President Nixon issued his executive order on wageprice stabilization in the construction industry, construc tion workers across the country still appear to be confused about how the action will affect them.

title: A Tax on G.I.'s
description: If the Administration were to tell Congress that since the nation cannot afford its new $76billion defense budget, the cost of new arms would be taken out of the pay of privates and other lowranking G.I.'s, the law makers would be rightly indignant.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 3It was good, but not good enough, for President Nixon to assure us from San Clemente that this isn't a police state and isn't going to become one. It was good, but not good enough, for him to declare that his Administration is against any kind of repression, any kind of action that infringes on the right of privacy.

title: I.R.S. CHIEF PLEADS FOR A RISE IN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Treasury has lost about $1.8billion in revenue because the Internal Revenue Service made manpower and spending economies that saved only $280 million, according to the out going commissioner of the tax service, Randolph W. Thrower.

title: Market Place:
description: Is it possible for a com pany to follow acceptable ac counting methods and still bring about a picture so col ored as to completely infs lead the shareholder?

title: JEWISH GROUP ASKS ONEWAR OBJECTION
description: The coordinating agency for Orthodox, Conservative and Re form Judaism in the United States has called on Congress to extend the concept of con scientious objection to individ uals who object to a particular war only, rather than all wars.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Barbed Wire, or How the West Was Won
description: LaCROSSE, Kan., May 3  Tradition says the sixgun won the West.

title: Washington Does Most of Its Business as Usual
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Rush hour came two hours early, around 5:30 this morn ing.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: When his executive editor called him yesterday to tell him of his prize, Mr. Davis replied with the simplicity that characterizes his edi torials: This is a great coun try when an old farm boy like me can win something big like that ... A fulltime professor of journalism at the University of Florida, he does most of his writing for The Gainesville (Fla.) Sun late at night ... Born July 14, 1924, in Manchester, Ga., and start ed in journalism as state Cap itol correspondent of The Florida TimesUnion of Jack sonville ... Serves as na tional vice president for cam pus affairs of Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journal ism fraternity ... Known for clarity and sincerity in his writing ... It is the second time since 1965 that a mem ber of The Sun, with a circu lation of 25,000, has won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing ... Known to his friends as Buddy.

title: John Theodorvich, 83, Dies; Headed Ukrainian Church
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP) Metropolitan John Theodor vich spiritual leader of 200,000 members of the Ukrainian Or thodox Church of the United States, died here today. He was 83 years old.

title: DR. DAVID H. ORGEL
description: Dr. David H. Orgel, a retired surgeon, died Sunday at a nurs ing home in Mamaroneck, N. Y. He was 94 years old and lived at 51 East 90th Street.

title: Weary Protesters Say They Were Not Prepared For Police Action
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4I don't feel we have ac complished our objectiveswe weren't prepared for the police and their tactics.

title: Zapata to Exchange Southdown Stock
description: Merger News

title: High Court Overturns New York's Antibusing Statute
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 The Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court's ruling made last Oct. 1. that New York State's socalled anti busing law was unconstitu tional.

title: In Australia's Vineyards, a Touch of Old Germany
description: TANUNDA, Australia  As it does every two years around this time, part of 19thcentury Germany seems to come to life again in the vinecovered Barossa Valley, a leading wineproducing area of Australia.

title: U.S. Seeks to Compel Miss Bacon to Testify on Plan to Bomb Bank Here
description: SEATTLE, May 3  Federal prosecutors asked the United States District Court today to compel Leslie Bacon to answer questions about her partici pation in plans to bomb the First National City Bank branch at Madison Avenue and East 91st Street in New York on Dec. 4.

title: Webster Electric Agrees To Settle U.S. Trust Suit
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Justice Department to day simultaneously filed suit and achieved a settlement in a complaint against a Racine, Wis., electronic concern ac cused of allocating territories among its 200 distributors for sale of sound equipment.

title: Last Ulbricht Coup: Thwarting Brandt on Ties to Bloc
description: BONN, May 3  Before step ping down tonight, Walter Ul bricht had effectively demon strated the power of his coun sel by putting the brakes on attempts by Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany to normalize relations with the Soviet Union and the rest of the Communist bloc.

title: BUSWELL REVIVES GOLDMARK WORK
description: Antique hunting can be great sport, and sometimes even profitable( according to dedi cated hobbyists. So why not dig out Karl Goldmark's Violin Concerto in A minor, James Buswell may have thought, and see if there is anything solid under the coat of dust. Gold mark wrote the Rustic Wed ding Symphony and some pretty parlor music for the piarfo, and as an offtrack bet his forgotten concerto must have seemed as promising a longshot as the next forgotten score. But, in fact, Mr. Bus well's performance suggested that those who forgot the score knew what they were doing.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: A photographer for The Chicago SunTimes since 1965, Mr. Dykinga's series of sensitive pictures of the Lin coln and Dixon State Schools for the Retarded illustrated overcrowding and other de plorable conditions . . . born 28 years ago in Chicago, he attended St. Procopius Col lege in Lisle and Elmhurst College, both in Illinois . . . began his career with Metro News, a freelance group of photographers that special ized in taking pictures at Chi cago's O'Hare airport . . . before joining The SunTimes, worked for a year for The Chicago Tribune . . . in 1969 won six of 32 awards made by the ChicagoPress Photog raphers Association to The SunTimes . . . hobbies are tropical fish and white water kayaking . . . lives with wife and two children at 1445 Newberry Street, La Grange Park, Ill.

title: Pan Am Accuses Aeroflot of Stealing Passengers
description: Pan American World Airways has accused the Soviet airline Aeroflot of having illegally siphoned away MoscowtoNew York passengers.

title: Taylor Wins Decision
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, May 3 (AP)Arnold Taylor, South African bantamweight and featherweight champion, out pointed the Filipino, Willie Cor dova, tonight in a 10round bout.

title: Executive Changes
description: Textron, Inc., announced yesterday the appoint ment of Robert S. Ames and John Henderson as senior vice presidents.
