Mr. Ames has been a group vice president, engaged in the supervision of a number of Textron Divisions, Mr. Henderson has been vice president, general counsel and secretary of the company.

title: Theater Book Award Is Given to Atkinson
description: Brooks Atkinson, former drama critic of The New York Times, received the 1970 George Freedley Memorial Award yesterday for his book, Broadway, at a cocktail re ception at the Dramatists Guild, 234 West 44th Street.

title: TV: From Crushing Coils of Drugs to a Trek South
description: Young drug addicts in San Francisco. A Frenchman tak ing a look at life in Missis sippi. Worlds apart, obviously but they are being brought together this evening via two halfhour programs on the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem.

title: After Ulbricht's Fall
description: Many years of history give evidence that the head of a ruling Communist party does not resign voluntarily, whatever the official communiqus may say. Khrushchev in 1964, Novotny in 1968 and Gomulka only last Decem ber all technically resigned, but actually were forced out of office.

title: DUMPING STUDY SET ON GLASS IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  The Treasury Department began an investigation today to determine whether clear sheet glass imported from France, Italy and West Ger many was being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

title: SHIFT IN ISRAELI LAW OPPOSED BY U.S.RABBI
description: A spiritual leader of Ameri can Orthodox Judaism appealed yesterday to Israel's political leaders to declare a moratori um on conflicts with Israel's religious community.

title: Hoist the Flag Suffers Paralysis Scare
description: Hoist the Flag, the missing giant of last Saturday's Ken tucky Derby, provided his veterinarian, Dr. Mark egrard, with another scare on Sunday when he suffered a temporary muscle paralysis in his Belmont Park barn.

title: Rogers in Beirut on 3d Stop of Tour
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3 Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here late this afternoon on the third stop of his tour of four Arab countries and Israel.

title: Bayh Terms Business Tax Cut Hearing a Charade
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Internal Revenue Service be gan three days of hearings to day on the Administration's plan to cut business taxes by allowing bigger deductions for depreciationhearings that the first witness, Senator Birch Bayh, characterized as an elaborate charade.

title: CHANGES SUPPORTED IN DAVIS CUP FORMAT
description: LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) The abolition of the challenge round will be recommended at the annual meeting of the Davis Cup tennis nations here July 1, officials said today.

title: 2 ISSUES SETTLED
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Supreme Court rejected a ma jor challenge to capital punish ment today, clearing away le gal questions that have blocked executions in many states while the nation's Death Row popu lation has risen to 648.

title: L.I.R. to Cut Service
description: The Long Island Railroad said yesterday that service on the Island Park to Long Beach branch of the carrier will be suspended between 9:15 A.M. and 3:15 P.M. beginning tomor row. The curtailment is re quired to install new trestle piling. Shuttle bus service be tween the two points will be provided by the carrier.

title: ARGENTINA DEVALUES THE PESO ONCE AGAIN
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 3  The Argentine peso was devalued today for the second time within a month. The Cen tral Bank announced that the new parity would take the peso to 4.12 to the dollar.

title: Jersey Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Chief War rant Officer 2 George P. Berg of Belford, N. J., of the Army, had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: COURT TO TAKE UP PRESS SUBPOENAS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The question of whether the Consti tution shields newsmen from being forced by subpoenas to testify before grand juries or to disclose sources' names will be decided in its next term by the Supreme Court.

title: Coats With Asbestos in Fabrics Termed Hazardous
description: Consumers and workers have been exposed to a serious health hazardincluding the possibility of lung cancer from women's coats made with cloth containing asbestos fiber, an officer of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union said yesterday.

title: Judge Rules Priest at St. John's Is Qualified for Social Security
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn reaffirmed yesterday a decis ion he made two years ago requiring St. John's University to make Social Security pay ments on behalf of a Roman Catholic priest, a faculty mem ber.

title: Jersey Legislature Passes Stadium Plan
description: TRENTON, May 3Gov. William T. Cahill's plan to at tract the New York Foot ball Giants to northern New Jersey cleared the Legisla ture this evening.

title: Total Executions by States
description: Following is a table showing the states that still main tain the death penalty, the number in each of these states presently sentenced to death, the year of the last execution in each state and the total number of executions in the period 193070. The figures were compiled by Citizens Against Legalized Murder, a private organization with head quarters in New York.

title: PRIMES TOP CARDS ON BOWA'S HIT, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UPI) Larry Bowa's single with the bases loaded and two out in the eighth inninghis fourth hit of the gamedrove in the two runs that gave the Phila delphia Phillies a 32 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: Postal Service Names A Consumer Advocate
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 The United States Postal Service announced today that it had created an Office of Consumer Affairs, to be headed by a consumer advo cate, or postal ombudsman, who would represent the in terests of individual consum ers in Postal Service matters.

title: Money Woes of U.N. Refugee Unit Eased
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. May 3The financial predicament of the United Nations' aid program for Palestinian Arab refugees has been eased, and some So vietbloc states have promised to make their first contribu. tion to the 21yearold relief undertaking.

title: 2 Back Mills for President
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Two more House Democrats announced their support today of a move to draft Representa tive Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas for the Democratic Presidential nomination. They are Repre sentatives Martha W. Griffiths of Michigan and Omar Burleson of Texas, both members of the Ways and Means Committee, which is headed by Me Mills

title: Patterns of American Protest
description: WASHINGTONThree major strands of opinion and action are identifiable within the confused and shifting welter of radical protest that is visible in the capital and country today.

title: Barton of Eagles Quits N.F.L. for Toronto Club
description: The Canadian League dropped a bomb yesterday on the National Football League and the Philadelphia Eagles. The Toronto Argo nauts signed the Eagles' No. 1 quarterback, Greg Barton, to a fouryear contract.

title: Dissident Fox Shareholders Issuing Another Challenge
description: A dissident group seeking to unseat the incumbent manage ment of the Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation charged yesterday that the concern's management had not been re aligned and challenged its abil ity to make the concern profit able.

title: MRS. W. GOLDSMITH
description: Mrs. Edith Herman Goldsmith, wife of William Goldsmith, for mer Commissioner of Public Works of Yonkers and presi dent of the Woodcrest Con struction Company, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 250 East 39th Street.

title: Scheduled Copter Flights Offered at Wall St. Again
description: New York Airways brought scheduled helicopter service back to Manhattan yesterday via the Wall Street Heliport after a lapse of 18 months. At the same time it began, a new service, to Wall Street and the three major airports, from Morristown Airport in Morris County, N. J.

title: Construction Spending Down
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reu ters)  Construction spending fell by 1.5 per cent. or $1.5 billion, in March to a season ally adjusted annual rate of $102.7billion. This reversed February's upward revised in crease of $2.4billion, to $104,2 billion, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: ULBRICHT RESIGNS AS PARTY LEADER IN EAST GERMANY
description: BONN, May 3  Walter Ui bricht stepped down tonight from the leadership of the East German Communist party, a position he had held for a quar ter of a century. He cited old age and ill health.

title: Senate Votes for Extending Nixon WagePrice Power
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The Senate voted 67 to 4 to day, to extend until next May 1 the President's authority to impose controls on wages, sal aries and prices.

title: Canadiens, Black Hawks Begin Cup Final Tonight
description: CHICAGO, May 3  The search for a new Stanley Cup champion begins at Chicago Stadium tomorrow night when the Black Hawks face the traditionbound Montreal Canadiens.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: Thomas Powers

title: HORACE PORTS JR.
description: Horace Ports Jr., a social studies teacher at Edgemont High School in Scarsdale, N.Y., died Saturday in Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 36 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Did you know that the cur rent television advertising by Pratt & Whitney is not only its first consumer campaign in its 45 years, but also its first extended venture in the medium?

title: Lubitsch Film Fete Set
description: Five feature films directed by Ernst Lubitsch will be revived at the New York Cultural Cen ter in Columbus Circle, starting tomorrow. Each film will be screened for two days, at 4 and 6 P.M., as part of the $1 admis sion charge to the museum. The opening attraction is the 1919 silent drama, Passion, star ring Emil Jannings and Pola Negri. Subsequent features in clude The Marriage Circle (1924), The Love Parade (1929), Trouble in Paradise (1932) and Desire (1936).

title: Education Officials Pleased
description: The State Education Commis sioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, said yesterday that the Supreme Court decision affirming the unconstitutionality of the New York State antibusing law re inforces my conclusion that school desegregation will con tinue to be a national priority.

title: Ender Takes Division Lead With 719 in Detroit Bowling
description: DETROIT, May 3 (UPI)Vir gil Enger of Minneapolis domi nated action in the American Bowling Congress tournament today.

title: East Berliners Show Little Surprise
description: BERLIN, May 3East Ber liners heard the news of Walter Uulbricht's resigna tion tonight without any no ticeable shock or signs of surprise.

title: Bank in Basel Wins Delay
description: BASEL, May 3 (Reuters)  The United California bank in Basel said today it has been granted a sixmonth extension by the legal authorities of the moratorium settlement in which the orderly liquidation of the bank is to be carried out. The moratorium originally expired on Feb. 28 and is extended un til Aug. 31, the bank said.

title: ESSEX INDICTS 3 IN NEWARK CASE
description: NEWARK, May 3  Three men were indicted here today by an Essex County grand jury on charges of assaulting, robbing and threatening to kill Fox Butterfield, a New York Times reporter, last April 6 at a public meeting of the Board of Education during the twomonth teachers' strike.

title: Nixon Is Kept Informed On Actions by Police
description: SAN CLEMENTE. Calif., May 3 (UPI)President Nix on kept in close touch today with the developments in the antiwar demonstrations in Washington, the Western White House said.

title: Liquidonics Industries Sets Conversion of Junior Debt
description: Liquidonics Industries, Inc., reported yesterday that it had agreed with holders of some of its junior debt to purchase, ex change and convert $16,071,000 of that junior debt for an ag gregate of $715,000 in cash, $4.2million of 5 per cent subordinated convertible in come notes due 1983 and 446, 955 common shares.

title: 7,000 Arrested in Capital War Protest; 150 Are Hurt as Clashes Disrupt Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4About 7,000 antiwar protest ers were arrested yesterday morning after fighting running skirmishes with metropolitan police and Federal troops throughout large areas of the nation's capital.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The trouble with New York is that Richard Nixon decided to run for President instead of Mayor. Some will say that this is also the trouble with the United States, but never mind that just now; we are on to bigger intellectual exercise than Presidentbaiting. The purpose here is to illustrate how the positive thinking of a Mayor Nixon could again make New York a genuine Fun City, or even a BaghdadonHudson, and for that purpose we take you now, through the miracle of human imagina tion, to Mayor Nixon's citywide tele vised news conference.

title: Bittrick of U.S. Wins Title In World Junior Wrestling
description: TOKYO, May 3 (AP)Mark Bittrick of Middleton, Idaho, captured the 192pound title to day for the United States' lone victory in the world amateur junior freestyle wrestling championships. The Soviet Un ion and Iran took three cham pionships each, but Bulgaria won the team title.

title: Schools Ask $100Million More And Are Rebuffed by the Council
description: School officials called on the City Council yesterday to add $100million to the $3billion recommended for the school system in Mayor Lindsay's new survival budget. But all they got for their efforts was a verbal rap across the knuckles from the Council's leaders.

title: Baby Lenore Case Due For Appeal to High Court
description: The foster parents of Baby Lenore will have to turn the 11monthold girl over to her natural mother unless they ob tain a new ruling by tomorrow afternoon from a Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: MARION H. VAN BERG, OWNED RACE HORSES
description: OMAHA, Neb., May 3 (UPI) Marion H. Van Berg, one of the nation's leading racehorse owners, died here today at the age of 75.

title: Pecora Is Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of William T. Pecora as Under Secretary of the Interior. He has been di rector of the Geological Sur vey. The nomination was con firmed by voice vote along with those of Ethel Bent Walsh as a member of the Equal Op portunity Employment Com mission and Phillip V. Sanchez as an assistant director of the Office of Economic Opportu nity.

title: Lindsay Opens Fund Drive
description: Mayor Lindsay opened a campaign yesterday by 7,000 teenagers to raise $100,000 for the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.

title: LONDON DAILY MAIL BECOMES A TABLOID
description: LONDON, May 3The Daily Mail appeared today as a new morning tabloidsize newspa per, 75 years to the day after it was founded as a fullsized one. It will eventually merge with its sister paper, The Daily Sketch, as a result of rising costs and declining circulation.

title: Empty Victory
description: Aimed at shutting down the Federal Government, the Mayday demonstrations in Washington from the outset had much more potential for suffering and tragedy than for practical effect on Vietnam war policy. Because of skillful work by the Washington police backed by Fed eral troops, this tragic potential did not materialize.

title: 2 Held on Drug Charges
description: HARTFORD, May 3 (UPI) Federal and state narcotics agents arrested two men near here today when they allegedly attempted to claim four suit cases at Bradley International Airport containing 200 pounds of marijuana. The two men, Thomas A. Tyson, 23 years old of Tucson, Ariz., and Leo S. Cahrtrand, 19, of West Halifax, Vt., were held in lieu of $25,000 bond each.

title: BONDS BACKSLIDE AFTER EARLY RISE
description: The bond market early yes terday made a stab at contin uing the advance that took place last Friday. Then it gave up, and prices slid back down.

title: Troy Music Hall, an Acoustical Gem, is in Peril
description: TROY, N. Y.The Music Hall in Troy, almost a hun dred years oldit was opened in 1875sits over a bank like a dowdy hen over eggs. It has no elevators and people have to climb two long flights to reach the audi torium floor.

title: Dollar Weakens Abroad; Revaluing of Mark Urged
description: PARIS, May 3The dollar weakened today in agitated European currency markets as the debate intensified in West Germany over the advisability of another upward revaluation of the mark.

title: U.S. Steel Focusing on Ecology
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 3 Ecology looms almost as large as low lividends in the minds of many stockholders of the Unit ed States Steel Corporation.

title: Theater: Oh, Symbolism
description: Somewhere in the second act of And Whose Little Boy Are You?, a play that opened last night at the Mc Alpin Rooftop Theater, a Con gressman says to a Cardinal, Just don't walk out on the Son of God. The Cardinal subsequently has second thoughts about what others accept as the Second Coming, but at that precise moment I sympathized with him. That statement needs some explan ation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Woodrow Wilson Professsor of Government at Williams College...Engrossed in Roosevelt scholarship for more than 15 years...Says I believe that Presidents all Presidentsshould be held to account...Previous Roos evelt study, The Lion and the Fox, published in 1956, won Tamiment Prize and Woodrow Wilson Foundation Award...Latest study won National Book Award...Also author of works on John F. Kennedy, party politics, Pres idential government...Ran unsuccessfully for Congress as Democratic candidate in 1958...Born i n Melrose, Mass. in 1918...Received B.A. from Williams in 1939 ...Served as Army combat historian in Pacific in World War II... Has taught at Wil liams since 1947...Has served on staff of Hoover Commission...Married in 1969 to the former Joan Simpson Meyers...Has four children by a previous mar riage.

title: U.S. Acknowledges Use of B52's for Raids Over Northern Laos
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The State Department acknowl edged today that the United States, in support of the Lao tian Government, has been using B52 bombers to strike at enemy targets in northern Laos.

title: LEONARD FRIEDMAN
description: Leonard Friedman, a shoe wholesaler and past president of the Shoe Club, died yester day at his home, 930 Fifth Avenue. He was 75 years old.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: When he heard uncon firmed reports alleging that the Chicago police were be ing bribed to steer hospital call cases to private ambu lance companies, he thought it worth following up. . . . He trained as a firstaid man and got a job as a ambulance driver. . . . The information he gathered became the basis for a sixpart expose deal ing with the collusion be tween city officials and the private companies. . . . The articles, in turn, became the basis for a grand jury that handed up 16 indictments, 10 of them against policemen. . . . He is 35 years old and has specialized in court and investigative reporting .. For six years, he has been at The Chicago Tribune . . . For the three years before he joined the paper, he was in the Marine Corps.... Before that he obtained a master's in journalism from North western and B.S. from the University of Wisconsin. . . . He is married and the father of two sons.

title: Undesirable Byproducts Called A Threat to Growth of Economy
description: DETROIT, May 3 (UPI)A top Administration economist said today that the nation's gross national product may ex pand by 50 per cent within the next five years but that much of this growth may have to be allocated to pollution con trol rather than improved living standards.

title: Internazionale Gains Crown
description: ROME, May 3 (AP)Inter nazionale of Milan, twice European and Intercontinental champion, clinched the Italian major league soccer champion ship yesterday.

title: Nixon Bids Hanoi Back a Swedish P.O.W. Plan
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 3President Nixon called on North Vietnam today to take advantage of an offer by Swe den to intern prisoners of war for the duration of the Vietnam ese conflict.

title: Football Speedsters to Run 100
description: An exhibition 100yard dash, bringing together John Carlos, Jimmy Hines and Earl McCullouch, is being ar ranged for the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. International Freedom Games May 16 in Philadelphia, officials an nounced yesterday.

title: These Girls Lost, but They Won, Too
description: Someone told us the sweetiepie bit was out, but we said, not with us, we don't feel that way at all.

title: BILLS ON COURTS SUPPORTED HERE
description: Mayor Lindsay and four Dis trict Attorneys joined yesterday in support for 11 bills before the Legislature to improve the administration of criminal jus tice.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Poet, critic and translator ... Won prize for The Car rier of Ladders, his seventh book ... His first, A Mask for Janus, won first prize in the Younger Poets competi tion in 1951 ... Frequently reviews and criticizes poetry ... A prolific translator, chiefly from Spanish and French, but also from Portu guese and Latin ... Critic said his poetry is like a broad river flowing through peaceful land, rather than like a cataract causing rain bows in dashing over rocks ... Born in New York City in 1927, reared in Union City, N. J., and Scranton, Pa.... Graduate of Princeton ... Refused last year to sign loyalty pledge at Buffalo campus of State University of New York, saying he felt that I couldn't better sup port the Constitution of the United States than by de clining to pledge to uphold it ... Married, no children.

title: Gold Price Drops by 27c
description: LONDON, May 3 (Reuters) London dealers today cut 27 cents an ounce off the price of gold, to $39.43 from $39.70. The market's atmosphere com pletely changed from last week when an absence of sellers sent up the price of bullion by 75 cents an ounce. Turnover was on a small scale.

title: Davits Suggests That New City Levies Be 90% Credited in Federal Income Tax
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits pro posed yesterday that a tax credit system be established under which a person's Federal income tax would be reduced by 90 per cent of the amount he paid in new city income taxes.

title: PARTY POLL HERE SUPPORTS MUSKIE
description: Democratic district leaders in New York County, polled by the county chairman on whom tney liked for 1972 Democratic Pres idential nominee, have put Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine at the top of their list.

title: Building Aid Plan Advances in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 3The Sen ate today approved a proposed amendment to the State Consti tution empowering the state to make gifts or loans to private individuals for the construction of housing, industry and com munity facilities.

title: Seoul Students Demonstrate
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May (AP)Groups of university stu dents rallied and demonstrated in Seoul today, charging that South Korea's presidential elec tion was dishonest and de manding a new election. Pres ident Chung Hee Park won a third fouryear term last Tues day.

title: RCA RAISES PRICES FOR ITS COMPUTERS
description: The RCA Corporation an nounced yesterday that it was increasing rental, purchase and maintenance prices on its second and thirdgeneration computer systems. The com pany's most recent computer systems will not be affected by the increase.

title: James Earl Ray Is Captured in Abortive Jail Break
description: PETROS, Tenn., May 3 (UPI) James Earl Ray, who was con victed of slaying the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., broke out of his cell today but was captured before he could get out of the Brushy Mountain State Prison.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is unfortunate that Melina Mer couri (OpEd April 21) and other in stant revolutionaries seem to imply that the installment of the Greek junta in power represents a radical depar ture from the traditional model of Greek politics. It is equally unfortu nate, but perhaps more understandable, to blame the Americans (it used to be the British and the French before that) for the miseries of the Greek people.

title: Notes on People
description: To help British Columbia celebrate its 100th anniver sary as a Canadian province, Queen Elizabeth II arrived yesterday for a 10day tour. She seemed obviously tired after her recent bout with a cold and sinus infection, but she smiled broadly for her welcomers, who included Prime Minister Pierre E. Tru deau and Mrs. Trudeau.

title: Cards Set Expo Replay
description: ST. LOUIS, May 3 (UPI)  The St. Louis Cardinals' tie game with the Montreal Expos Saturday night will be replayed in a twinight doubleheader July 15, at Busch Memorial Sta dium, the Cardinals said today.

title: Miss Walsh Victor
description: GUILDFORD, England, May 3 (Reuters)  Sharon Walsh of San Rafael, Calif., the 12th ranked American, gave her in jured shoulder the first test in a month at the Surrey tennis championships today.

title: STOCK LIST IS NIT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking, as it must to all bull markets, came to Wall Street yesterday.

title: Senate Confirms Directors For the Board of Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Senate confirmed today eight members of the board of directors of the National Rail road Passenger Corporation, known as Amtrak, the semipub lic agency that now runs the nation's intercity passenger trains.

title: HARRY R. LEVINE, 64, SCHOOL EXECUTIVE
description: Harry R. Levine, a teacher and administrator in the public schools here, died Sunday while on a visit to Philadelphia with his wife. He was 64 years old and lived on Pennington Road in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Overseas Teachers Lose Court, Fight on Back Pay
description: WASHNGTON, May 3 (AP) The Supreme Court let stand today lower court rulings deny ing back pay increases sought for 20.000 teachers of over seas United States military de pendents.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STARS WIN, 136117, ON 50POINT QUARTER
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 3 (AP)The Utah Stars, paced by a recordbreaking 50point out burst in the second quarter to night, rolled to a 136117 vic tory over the Kentucky Colo nels in the first game of the American Basketball Associa tion's championship playoff.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: More and more bloodshed and mis ery is caused in every corner of the world by the misunderstanding and misinterpretation of the principle of selfdetermination of nations. When this principle was proclaimed by the United Nations, everyone understood it to mean that all peoples had the right to nationhood, to their own sovereign state, to choose the form of government they wanted and to be come independent members of the United Nations with equal status to all the other members of the organization.

title: Nixon Hack in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) President Nixon returned to the capital tonight from El Toro Marine Air Station, Calif.

title: Letter From Underground
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3  Radio station KSAN received a copy today of a letter signed Weather Underground ad dressed to Mrs. John W. Bacon, which said that your confi dence in Leslie is justified be cause she is completely inno cent of any involvement in the, bombing of the U.S. Capitol.

title: JAKOBSON OPPOSES 2 CHINAS IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 3  Max Jakobson of Finland, a candidate to succeed U Thant as Secretary General, declared today that the admis sion of Communist China to the United Nations was a real possibility this year. He dis missed the socalled two Chinas concept as unrealistic.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: When prizewinning pic ture was made last May 4, Mr. Filo was 21yearold photography student at Kent State University . . . Was also a summer intern news photographer for two small Pennsylvania newspapers, the Valley Daily News of Taren tum and The Daily Dispatch of New Kensington ... Says he closed photo lab on troubled campus to get some lunch and took his camera with him as usual. . . I was curious about the situ ation . . . I went with my camera to get some pictures just for myself... First be lieved National Guard was firing blanks . . . Stunned when he realized live ammu nition was being used. . . Prizewinning photo appeared in thousands of newspapers here and abroad and became a symbol of protest against Vietnam war . . . Mr. Filo, a native of Natrona Heights, Pa., will be graduated this summer from Kent State. . . Was married last December to Marge Emerson of Natrona Heights.

title: Thomson Wins Japan Golf
description: HASHIMOTO, Japan, May 3 (AP)Peter Thomson of Aus tralia shot a twounderpar 70 today and captured the second Wizard international golf tour nament by one stroke with a tworound total of 143.

title: Arsenal Downs Hotspur, 10, for Title
description: LONDON, May 3 (AP)  Arsenal defeated Tottenham Hotspur, 10, with a goal two minutes from the end tonight and won the English soccer championship.

title: U.S. Rights Unit Finds Chicanos Isolated in Southwest Schools
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The United States Commis sion on Civil Rights says that a study of MexicanAmericans in the nation's schools reveals that Chicano students are severely isolated in the Southwest.

title: PLAN FOR RESERVE DIES IN SENATE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Senate Banking Committee, in a littlenoticed action, has de cided against giving the Federal Reserve Board controversial au thority to fix varying Reserve requirements against bank as sets.

title: Northern Illinois Gas Lists Rises In Net and Revenues for Quarter
description: The Northern Illinois Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first quarter. Marvin Chandler, chairman, placed operating revenues at $145,394,469, up from $130,400,230 a year ear lier. Net income rose to $23, 315,645, or $1.90 a share, from $22,192,553, or $1.81 a share, in the quarter ended March 31, 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GORMAN CONQUERS ULRICH IN 3 SETS
description: ROME, May 3 (AP)  Tom Gorman and Ray Barth, the only Americans to see action, won firstround matches today in the Italian open tennis championship, the first major tournament on the European circuit. First prize is $10,000.

title: Thousands of Washington Demonstrators Held Outdoors Before Releases Start
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, May 4The 7,000 arrests here yesterday filled the courtyard of the District of Columbia Jail for several hours and clogged the city's courts.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: In a column called Simeon Stylites, for the fifthcen tury Syrian hermit who spent 35 years in meditation atop a pillar in the desert, he has been writing about Bergen Conuty, N. J., for more than 40 years... associate edi tor of The Record, of Hack ensack... he was awarded the prize for distinguished commentary in articles that often urged the conservative community to take a more active role in local affairs... born in Butler, Pa., Dec. 5, 1906 and grew up in Titus ville, Pa., where his father was managing editor of The Titusville Herald... after working as a parttime re porter, he joined The Record (then The Bergen Evening Record) in 1926 and has re mained there ever since... in addition to his column, he writes editorials... received an honorary LL.D. last June from Rutgers University... lives with his wife at 936 Glen View Road, Ridgewood, N. J. ... they have two grown daughters and a son.

title: OTB Bets Stand Despite Shift in Races
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 3 Two earlymorning scratches in tonight's sixth race at Roosevelt Raceway failed to disturb officials of the Off track Betting Corporation, al though they might have up set some of the earlybird bettors had they been aware of the withdrawals.

title: FORGE IN VIETNAM CUT 8,000 IN WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4 (AP)The yesterday that American mili tary strength in Vietnam drop ped by 8,000 troops last week, the second largest weekly reduction this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Said to Free Latvian Dissident
description: MOSCOW, May 3A once prominent political dissident was reportedly released today after nearly two years of con finement in a Latvian mental hospital.

title: VATICAN AND POLAND BEGIN DISCUSSIONS
description: ROME, May 3The Vatican announced today that Polish Government officials and aides to Pope Paul VI held talks here last week.

title: Shop Talk
description: The shop, which at first glance looks not much bigger than a walkin closet, is a jumble of yarns, threads, cords, knitting needles, looms, needlepoint canvases, crochet hooks, needlecraft kits, and finished examples of ponchos, rugs, handbags, belts, tapestries, skirts, wall pictures and shawls. This is The Ladies Hobby Shop at 2350 Broad way (just north of 85th Street), and the cramped quarters buzz with activity from 9:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. on Wednesdays. That's the day that wearing and macrame classes are held from 6:30, when the store closes, to 8:30.

title: RUTH B. JOHNSON
description: Ruth B. Johnson, an assistant professor of library science at Queens College, died Sunday, apparently of a stroke, in her home at 9261 Phlox Place, Flushing, Queens. She was 54 years old.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Yields on United States Treas ury bills were unchanged on 91day bills and rose on 182 day bills in the Government's weekly competitive sale to day of these shortterm se curities.

title: Yankees' Pitchers Sound For First Extensive Trip
description: The Yankees left yesterday on their first extensive trip of the season. Eight games are scheduled in the next nine days against Minnesota, Chicago and Milwaukee.

title: Ban on Horses Lifted
description: ALBANY, May 3 (UPI)Don J. Wickham, State Commission er of Agriculture and Markets, revoked today an order ban ning the importation of horses from Puerto Rico. The quaran tine was imposed Feb. 26 be cause of an outbreak of infec tious equine influenza on the island.

title: Penalty Applies to Many Crimes
description: It was known as the Bloody Code and in its hey day, in early 19thcentury England, it killed 2,000 to 3.000 persons a yearindi viduals who had committed murder or burglary or pick pocketing or any of 220 other crimes.

title: Soviet Moves 4,000 in Tribe From Asian Mountains to Plain
description: MOSCOW, May 3  The So viet Union has completed the resettlement of 4,000 Centrai Asian tribesmen from a harsh mountain valley to a newly developed cottonirrigation dis trict in the plain.

title: Moscow Moves Quickly
description: MOSCOW, May 3The So viet Union moved quickly to night to indicate that the change in the East German party leadership presaged no fundamental shift in East Ger many's close relations with Moscow.

title: Pay Bill Is Issue in Puerto Rico
description: Gov. Luis A. Ferre of Puerto Rico warned yesterday that proposals before the Con gress to increase Federal minimumwage levels might force some businesses in Puerto Rico to close.

title: PROF. EDWIN HOWARD
description: OXFORD, Ohio, May 3 (UPI) Edwin J. Howard, a retired Miami University English pro fessor and an authority on early English literature, died yesterday in McCulloughHyde Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Southwest League Takes in Houston As Its 9th Member
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.0 MAY 3 (AP)The Southwest Conference voted the Univer sity of Houston into the league today, the first change in the membership since Texas Tech was admitted 15 years ago.

title: Gasoline Runs Short In Strike's Third Day
description: Gasoline continued in short supply in the city and suburbs yesterday as the strike by 1,600 drivers and warehouse employes of six major oil com panies went through its third day with no end in sight.

title: U.S. PANEL ISSUES OILPRICE STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 The President's Office of Emer gency Preparedness recom mended in effect today that the Administration do nothing to roll back an increase in the price of crude oil imposed last fall by the oil companies.

title: HARLEY H. TIMBERS
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., May 3 Harley H. Timbers, a patent at torney who retired as patent license manager of Western Electric Company in 1941, died yesterday at his home, 60 Sher man Avenue. His age was 83.

title: CHOU REMINISCES WITH OLD FRIEND
description: PEKING, May 1Strains of music and noises from half a million people assembled for a May Day celebration in Tienan men Square drifted in through the open doors of the Hall of the People as Premier Chou En lai welcomed an old friend.

title: Junior College Quintet Forfeits 273 Record
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., May 3 (AP)Columbia State Com munity College forfeited to day all 30 of Its 197071 basketball games because the school used an ineligible player.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Began research for his prizewinning work on Rob ert Frost in 1939 by becom ing the poet's confidant, trav eling companion and inter preter, with the understand ing that the biography would not be published during Frost's lifetime . . . Previ ously had published six peri pheral works on Frost and biographies of Henry Wads worth Longfellow and Her man Melville ... Born April 3, 1906, in Franklin, N. H. ... Received Bachelor's De gree from Wesleyan Univer sity in 1928 and his Ph.D. from Columbia in 1939. .. . After teaching for a year each at Columbia and Wes leyan, entered the Navy in World War II . Joined Princeton faculty in 1947, be came a professor of English in 1951 and is now the Holmes Professor of Belles Lettres there ... He and his wife live in Princeton, N. J. ...They have four children.

title: Pickup in Consumer Sentiment Reported at Retailers' Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Consumer buying has picked up, reflecting better consumer sentiment and brightening prospects for the entire economy this year and next. This was reported by executives and economists today at the annual meeting of the Ameri can Retail Federation at the Washington Hilton Hotel.

title: U.S. Concedes It Hit Enemy Hospitals
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Defense Department acknowl edged today that allied forces in South Vietnam had destroyed enemy hospitals, but it contend ed that such actions had oc curred because these installa tions were not marked.

title: Advertising:
description: Joseph Wagner, advertis ing manager of The New York Times, has announced that Stuart Falk has been named financial advertising manager effective May 15. He replaces Curtis R. Troe ger, who will join Doremus & Co. as a vice president.

title: Man in the News
description: BONN, May 3When we have critical problems we can always get in touch with our friends in the Soviet Union, said the East Ger man Communist official. We have a hot line to the Soviet generals who used to be in command here.

title: NAVY TOPSEEDED IN SPRINT ROWING
description: Navy, conqueror of unbeaten Harvard and Penn last Satur day, was seeded first yesterday for the eastern sprint cham pionships Saturday on Lake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass. Seventyfour crews from 16 colleges are entered in the six lightweight and heavy weight categories.

title: Mays Is Out Until Friday With a Shoulder Ailment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (UPI)Willie Mays has been having troubles with his right shoulder and Charlie Fox, the San Francisco Giants' manager, said today he would rest Mays for a few days.

title: 3 Former Nazis Go on Tried For the Babi Yar Massacre
description: REGENSBURG, Germany, May 3 (AP)Three former Nazi police officials went on trial today for the massacre of 33, 771 Jews in 1941 at Babi Yar in the Ukraine. The trial is ex pected to last three months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sondheirn Explains Craft of Lyricist
description: Stephen Sondheim, com poser and lyricist of Follies and Company, gave a com pact seminar on the art of lyric writing Sunday evening at the final session for this season of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Associa tion.

title: Saigon Plans Holiday Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 4 (Reuters)  Vietnam will observe a cease fire Sunday to observe the anni versary of Buddha's birth, presidential spokeman an nounced here today.

title: 2 Planes of Peruvian Airline Impounded by U.S. Creditors
description: LIMA, Peru, May 3 (AP) Aerolineas Peruanas, Peru's fi nancially ailing international airline, reported today that two of its jet airliners had been impounded in the United States by American creditors.

title: Gregory Play Group Seeking New Areas
description: Immediately after Andr Gregory's version of Alice in Wonderland opened last Oc tober, he was flooded with suggestions that he adapt other children's classics, such as The Little Prince and The Hunting of the Snark. Mr. Gregory turned them all down.

title: Guerrillas Step Up Raids, Ceylon Says
description: GALLE, Ceylon, May 3. The Ceylonese Government to day reported a sharp increase in raids by insurgents as police men searched the alleys of this old fortress town for guerrillas.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Only the Mets and the Yankees are left as rooting interests for New York's sports fans. Over the last exciting weekend the Rangers joined the Knicks in cold storage while all hopes for the big one were put on ice for another year. At last the circus people are able to purr contented. No longer are they in danger of having performancesly pre empted by tall guys in short pants or padded guys on skates.

title: LON NOL AGREES TO TITULAR ROLE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 3Gen. Lon Nol agreed today to end the twoweekold Gov ernment crisis by serving as titular Premier of a govern ment in which Lieut. Gen. Siso wath Sirik Matak will hold the principal executive power.

title: Obstetricians' Group Backs Contraceptives for Minors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (AP) The American College of Ob tetricians and Gynecologists urged last night that legal re strictions against prescribing contraceptives for minors be lifted throughout the nation.

title: Senators Told of Brutality to Young Offenders
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Stories of brutality, corruption and flouting of the law by juvenile judges, parole officers and those who run detention homes for children unfolded here today before a Senate sub committee headed by Birch Bayh of Indiana.

title: City and Con Ed Start Drive to Save Power
description: A major campaign to con serve power in New York City was announced yester day by Mayor Lindsay and Charles F. Luce, board chair man of the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Classes Called Off In Racial Tension At Montclair H. S.
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 3 Afternoon classes at the high school here were canceled to day because of tensions at tributed by school officials to a controversy over the refusal of the school board to renew the contract of a male black guid ance counselor in the school.

title: Antiwar Editorialist Retires
description: ST. LOUIS, May 3 (UPI) Robert Lasch, who won the 1065 Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing, has retired as editorial page editor of The St. Louis PostDispatch. Mr, Lasch, 64 years old, won the Pulitzer Prize for his editorials denounc ing the Vietnam war.

title: Leader of City Employes Warns on Pension Plan
description: Victor Gotbaum, executives director of District Council 37 of the State, County and Municipal Employes, warned yesterday that the city would be faced with the biggest, fattest, sloppiest strike it had ever had if the Legislature failed to approve a new pension plan negotiated by his union last summer.

title: McCracken and Volcker Optimistic on Payments
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers said today there were heartening signs that the worst may be over in the re cent heavy outflow of short term capital from the United States to other countries.

title: Pound Strength Seen for 1971
description: CHICAGO, May 3 (Reuters Barring a major multilateral realignment of currencies, the pound should be able to main tain its $2.40 parity throughout 1971, but may come under pres sure next year, Lord Shaw cross, a former president of the. Board of Trade, told the International Economic Forum, which was sponsored by the Lincoln National; Corporation.

title: Obscenity Suppression Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today the Government's power toprosecute people who send pornography through the mails and to seize obscene material brought into the country for commercial sales.

title: Paul Zindel Drama
description: Author of The Effect of Gamma Rays on Maninthe Moon Marigolds, which he wrote in 1962 ... The play was produced several times in regional theaters and four times on television before it arrived off Broadway ... It received the New York Drama Critics Award as best American play and won a Drama Desk Award for the author ... A bachelor, he was born May 15, 1936, in Staten Island, where he still lives .. Received B.S. and M.S. in science from Wagner College and taught chemistry and physics for a period in Staten Island high schools ... Has written for the stage, films and television, and is the author of three novels about teenagersThe Pig man, My Darling, My Ham burger, and I Never Loved Your Mind ... His most re cent play, And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little, is now on Broadway ... Described as having a dry humor and a vivid recall for details of his childhood.

title: PEROT INDEMNITY ON WONT TIE SET
description: A group headed by H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer mil lionaire, would be indemnified for up to $15million in its take over of troubled F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co. under a plan agreed to yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jersey Is 27th State to Approve Lowering Age for Voting to 18
description: TRENTON, May 3  New Jersey became today the 27th state to ratify an amendment to the United States Constitu tion that would lower the vot ing age to 18 in all elections.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: YOU can unvell secrets of your future Get a copy of How To Consult the ?? 86.95 at bookstores ??. Putnam ??

title: Abolishing Schools: II
description: CUERNAVACA, MexicoThe hidden curriculum of compulsory schooling discriminates by its very nature. It serves as a means to apportion scarce resources and jobs to the person Who qualifies for them through the largest consumption of public funds. It makes out of the loser a failure. Compulsory schooling establishes the presumption that the person who has corsumed more professional treatment under the supervision of certified teachers is therefore socially more usefuland unquestionably entitled to the choice privileges society has to offer.

title: Ballet: The Stuttgart's New Seasons
description: There is a particular qual ity of exultance to the Stutt gart Ballet at its best. Its spirit is an international cross between the Bolshoi Ballet and the City Center Joffrey Ballet, and it dares things few more staid companies will dare.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BELCHERTON, Mass.  There are many asinine en deavors open to anglers, and fly fishing for trout in the cold, high waters of spring is near the top of the list.

title: Istanbul University Reopens
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 3 (Reuters)Istanbul University, closed for more than a month because of student violence, reopened today with strict security measures, and students began taking their postponed spring examinations.

title: Mets Down Cubs in 11th On Agee's Pinch Hit, 32
description: Tommie Agee, who couldn't play because of a pulled muscle near his ribs, dragged his ach ing frame to the plate in the 11th inning and stroked a 32 pitch into right centerfield for a single that gave the Mets a 32 victory over the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium last night.

title: U.S. Hospital in Texas to Halt Treatment of Narcotic Addicts
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The 600bed Public Hdalth Service hospital in Forth Worth, Tex., one of two that serve as treat ment facilities for narcotics addicts, has been ordered to stop accepting new patients.

title: 15 Junior College Transfers in Big Eight Ruled ineligible for Football in '71
description: KANSAS CITY, MO., May 3 (UPI)Fifteen football players at four Big Eight Conference schools have been ruled ineli gible to play next fall because of the National Collegiate Ath letic Association's interpreta tion of the controversial junior college transfer rule.

title: Defense Rests in Panther Trial; Murtagh Paroles Mrs. Shakur
description: Summations in behalf of 13 Black Panthers on trial for an alleged bomb conspiracy were completed yesterday and one of the defendants, 25yearold Afeni Shakur, eight months pregnant, was released from jail.

title: SHANKER CLASHES WITH SCHOOL HEAD
description: A dialogue last night be tween School Chancellor Har vey B. Scribner and Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, was marked by a heated exchange over the issue of teacher selec tion.

title: Latin Lands Turning to Europe for Arms
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 27 All over South America, na tions that for 20 years planned, trained and equipped their armed forces with United States guidance and supplies have been ordering jet interceptors and warships, automatic weap ons and tanks from Western Europe.

title: Sadat Aides to Meet on Sabry Ouster
description: CAIRO, May 3  President Anwar elSadat has called a meeting for tomorrow of the Egyptian leadership following his decree relieving Aly Sabry of his post as one of Egypt's two Vice Presidents.

title: Draft Deferments Granted To Essential Physicians
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Curtis W. Tarr, the director of the Selective Service Sys tem, announced today the au thorization of deferments for physicians whose services are essential to their communities.

title: Lines Short, Wait Is Long For OTB Derby Winners
description: Canonero, said Dorothy Gallagher with a trace of an Irish lilt. The name sounded kind of unusual. Romantic, I suppose. That's why I bet on him.

title: 2d Off Broadway Play Wins Pulitzer
description: An Off Broadway play, The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man intheMoon Marigolds, by Paul Zindel, won the 1971 Pulitzer prize for drama yesterday. The first Pulitzer prize for an Off Broadway play was awarded last year.

title: States Expected to Delay Any Action on Executions
description: In the 38 states where the death penalty is still on the books, there was little indica tion yesterday that the Supreme Court ruling would have any immediate impact on the future of many of the 648 men and women facing execution.

title: John Toland General Nonfiction
description: Won prize for The Rising Sun, book on World War II in the Pacific primarily from the Japanese viewpoint ... book also won Overseas Press Club's George Polk Memorial Award last March .. Now 58 years old, he began writ ing at age 40 after many years in jobs ranging from teaching actors to running a gift shop ... Author of numerous books, including The Last Hundred Days, The Dillinger Days, and But Not In Shame ... His book reviews have appeared in The New York Times since 1959 ... Born in LaCrosse, Wis, on June 29, 1912 ... Graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1932, and from Williams College in 1936... Settled in New York in 1952 with $50, a type writer and a plan to become a writer ... First won nation al recognition in 1959 with his book Battle: The Story of the Bulge ... Married in 1960 to Toshiko Matsumura .. They live in Danbury, Conn.

title: Ubleis Registers Triple at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. L, May 3 Adolf Ubleis, at 33 the young est of the eight international reinsmen seeking harness rac ing's world driving champion ship, soared to a tremendous lead by sweeping the first three events in the ninetrack tour, which was launched tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Bridge: Obscure Situations Disrupt WellEstablished Partners
description: Blackwood and Gerber are deceptively simple conven tions. They both have various builtin possibilities for abuse and confusion.

title: Chase Defends Its Pennsy Sales
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) The Chase Manhattan Bank was not acting on any inside information obtained through banking business pipelines when it sold large blocks of Penn Central Company stock shortly before the financially stricken railroad went into re organization, David Rockefeller testified today.

title: Dr. Warren W. Knox Dead at 73; Left State School Post in 1968
description: ALBANY, May 37Dr. Warren W. Knox, who retired as the State Education Department's assistant commissioner for in structional service in 1968, died yesterday at his home in Sel kirk. He was 73 years old.

title: New Consultant Muses on Poetry
description: WASHINGTON  It's a good time for poetry but a bad time for people. This is the opinion of Josephine Jacobsen, the first woman to serve as Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Con gress in 21 years. It's a bad time, and bad times produce poetry.

title: Article 29  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Tariff Commission ruled unani mously today that a domestic industry was not being injured as a result of dumping of im ports of brass key blanks from Canada.

title: Maternity Leave for Men? Two Fathers Who Say It's Only Fair
description: If a male teacher gives birth, he'll be entitled to a maternity leave. But as things stand now, the Board of Educa tion says it's very unlikely that a man will get time off just because his wife had a baby.

title: Baruch College Chief Is Named; Now a Southern Methodist Aide
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion yesterday appointed a new president of Baruch Col lege. He is Dr. Clyde J. Wing field, professor and director of the graduate program in public administration at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.

title: A. A. U. MAY BLOCK TRIPS FOR REBELS
description: United States track and field athletes who qualify for the Amateur Athletic Union outdoor championships but do not enter the meet may not receive travel permits this summer, Ollan Cas sell, the track and field ad ministrator for the A. A. U., said yesterday.

title: Encyclopedia Sales Called Deceptive In Suit by the City
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Department said yesterday that it had filed a suit charging Na tional Education Products, Inc., with unfair and deceptive trade practices in the door todoor sale of a $268 package of children's books and ency clopedias.

title: U.S. JURY RECESSES IN ALABAMA INQUIRY
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 3 A Federal grand jury called to investigate campaign contribu tions to Gov. George C. Wal lace and the records of his brother has recessed without returning any indictments.

title: New Pakistani Protest to India Charges Shelling at the Border
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 3  Pakistan charged India to day with creating an atmos phere of confrontation and accused Indian border units of having shelled Pakistani posi tions.

title: G.M. EVALUATING MICROFILM DATA
description: DETROIT, May 3The Gen eral Motors Corporation began today a massive evaluation of microfilmed records of 106,000 Chevrolet owners complaints that it purchased two weeks ago for $20,000, sight unseen, from a pair of suburban junk dealers.

title: 4 U.S. Car. Makers Gained As April Output Rose 14.1%
description: Automobile production rose 14.1 per cent last month, com pared with output in April, 1970, the four major United States manufacturert reported yesterday. Gains were posted by all fourthe General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corpo ration and the American Motors Corporation.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Senior music critic for The New York Times since 1960 . . . Decided at 12 to become music critic . . . Drawn to it by love of music and com pelling early realization that you can get paid for listen ing to music . . . Volunteered with typical lan for jump school in World War II, made nine jumps in France, ending with broken leg . . . Began piano lessons at age of 3 . . . Started writing paid criticism in 1936, while at Brooklyn College . . . Soon had monthly column in Musical Advance . . . Earned Master of Arts in music and English at New York University . . . Worked first for American Music Lov er magazine, from 1939 to 1942 . . . Joined New York Sun after war as a music critic, Times in 1950 . . . Books include The Great Pianists, The Great Con ductors, The Lives of the Great Composers . . . Skilled at chess, poker, unskilled but unflagging at golf . . . Born here in 1915 . . . Lives with wife, Rosalyn, on Riverside Drive.

title: KATZ GETS POST AT METROPOLITAN
description: Karl Katz, who resigned ear lier this year as director of the Jewish Museum, will become chairman for special exhibi tions and loans at the Metro politan Museum of Art on June 1, according to Thomas Hoving, museum director. The position is a newly created one and will place Mr. Katz in the top hier archy at the museum.

title: Moderate Arabs of West Bank Feel U.S. Is Abandoning Them
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, May 4The moderate Palestinians here on the west bank of the Jordan River feel abandoned as Secretary of State William P. Rogers makes his widely heralded swing across the Middle East.

title: 3 WITH 71'S LEAD DODGE OPEN GOLF
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 4 Despite gusty winds and tem peratures that chilled the hands, three subpar rounds of golf were turned in today as the eighth annual Dodge open tour nament began a 72hole run over the Rockaway River Coun try Club course.

title: Indianapolis Mayor Wins
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 (AP) Mayor Richard G. Lugar over whelmed three opponents today to win the Republican nomina tion for asecond fouryear term. Mr. Lugar, 39 years old, presi dent of the National League for Cities, will face John F. Neff, 34, an attorney who captured the Democratic nomination with 21,503 votes to 4,693 for his closest opponent.

title: ELLWOOD SARGENT, ARMY LAWYER, 65
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Col. Ellwoody W. Sargent, who at his retirement in 1959 had been an Army lawyer in the Judge Ad vocate General Corps for al most 20 year's, died in Arlington Hospital, Arlington, Va., on Sat urday. He was 66 years old and lived at 300 Old Dominion Road, Alexandria, Va.

title: Expert at Curbing Demonstrators Jerry Vernon Wilson
description: Man in the News

title: Writers' Collaboration Is a Marriage of Plots
description: The collaboration of Maj Sjowall and Per Wahloo in writing crime novels began several years before they met or before either knew that the other existed.

title: Senators Lining Up for Visas to China
description: Washington Notes

title: End the Draft  Now
description: WASHINGTONContinuation of the draft when the Selective Service Act expires on June 30 is now planned by the White House. This move is, of course, supported by the Pentagon, but the decision rests with the Congress.

title: Badillo Says U.S. Programs Are Excluding Puerto Ricans
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 Representative Herman Badillo of New York City said today that the United States main land was facing another mas sive migration of Puerto Ricans and urged Congress to end what he called discrimina tion against Puerto Rico in number of Federal programs.

title: Tracks' Suit Fails As Court Decrees Off track Bets Valid
description: ALBANY May 4 (AP)State Supreme Court Justice T. Paul Kane ruled today that offtrack betting was legal, thereby denying a suit brought by two harness tracks and one flat track.

title: Installment Credit Rose By $495Million in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Con sumer installment credit rose by $495million in March, the largest increase since November, 1969, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: METS DOWN CUBS ON SINGLE IN 7TH BY HARRELSON, 21
description: Baseball's inherent contempt for its paying customers was strikingly demonstrated at Shea Stadium last night in the Course of a 21 victory the New York Mets scored over the Chi Cago Cubs.

title: ShakeUp in Cairo
description: The dismissal of Egyptian Vice President Ali Sabry on the eve of Secretary of State Rogers's arrival yester day in Cairo serves as both an encouragement and warning to Mr. Rogers's peaceseeking mission.

title: Angela Davis Loses Appeal To Have Judge Step Down
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UPI)  The California Supreme Court has rejected Angela Davis's assertion that the judge in her murderkidnap ping case should withdraw be cause of racial prejudice.

title: STOCKS REBOUND AS TRADING RISES
description: The stock market bounced back yesterday after three ses sions of profit taking in a broad recovery that surprised some observers.

title: Blacks and Jews in Melee at Brooklyn College
description: A ?? between black and white students, the latter mem bers of the Jewish Defense League, was broken up shortly after noon yesterday on the Brooklyn College campus by 100 city policemen and college se?? guards after a 20 minute freeforall in which four person were hurt.

title: Ben Schlanger, Theater Architect, Is Dead at 66
description: Ben Schlanger, an architect and a leader in contemporary theater design, died Monday after a brief illness in French Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 20 East Ninth Street.

title: PHILIP H. ERBES, 64, WRIGLEY EXECUTIVE
description: CHICAGO, May. 4Philip H. Erbes, secretary of the William Wrigley Jr. Company and vice president in charge of public communications, died yesterday at his home. He was 64, years old.

title: ACRYLICRESIN PRICE IS RAISED BY DU PONT
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had raised prices by from 4 cents to 22 cents a pound on Lucite acrylic resins In custom colors. The company also increased the size of min imum orders for custom colors from 300 pounds to 1,200 pounds.

title: Cuts in Narcotics Funds Fought by 1,500 in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 4I sent them an animal and I'm get ting back a human being, said Marion Tabasco of Howard Beach, Queens, as she demon strated near the Capitol today to protest cuts in the budget for state narcotics addiction programs.

title: Westbury Horses Sidelined With Virus Now Reach 100
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 4 Three coughing horses were scratched today from tonight's harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway. With the withdrawal of Tommy IC. Butler and Imperator from the first event and Remember James from the seventh, the number of afflicted standardbreds here was increased to 100.

title: Twins Beat Yanks, 65, On Holt's Homer in 10th
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 4There's nothing wrong with Minnesota's relief pitching that the Yankee relief pitching can't cure.

title: JOSEPH HAAS
description: CHICAGO, May 4 (AP)Jo seph Haas, book editor of The Chicago Daily News; died yes terday after losing conscious ness while swimming in a hotel. He was 41 years old.

title: OTB TO RESTRICT PREAKNESS BETS
description: Offtrack bettors whose Ken tucky Derby horses owe them money will get a chance to re coup in the Preakness.

title: Ervin Sponsors Bill to Allow Trials of Former Soldiers
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (Reu ters)Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Judi ciary. Subcommittee on Consti tutional Rights, introduced yes terday legislation designed to allow trials of former service men for offenses committed while in uniform.

title: NEW U.S. LOAN AlU TO PENNSY FOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)  The major creditors of the bankrupt Penn Central Trans portation Company threatened today to begin liquidating their more than $500million hold ings if the Government agreed to back more loans to keep the railroadoperating company alfoat.

title: Bistate Inquiry Examines Role Of Underworld on Waterfront
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has been conducting a secret inquiry into the alleged efforts of under world figures to reassert their once dominant position on the waterfront here.

title: 3 in Cell Block at Stormville
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., May 4K Gallery, the formal name for New York's new Death Row, is on the third floor of the central building of the Green Haven Correct ional Facility, a maximum security prison in this tiny Dutchess County hamlet.

title: L.I. Jury Acquits Girl of Lying When She Said She Killed Uncle
description: A 19yearold girl was acquitted last night of a charge of lying at a murder trial two years ago.

title: Monetary Flap
description: Waves of speculation in European money markets have driven up the price of gold, knocked the dollar down to its lowest pegged rate, and forced the German mark up to its ceiling rate of nearly 28 cents against the dollar.

title: Kent Marks 4 Deaths in Varied Ways
description: KENT, Ohio, May 4  A memorial service attended 6,000 persons, a sitin by about 1,000 students in front of the R.O.T.C. building and a candle light vigil by individual stu dents were some of the ways that the deaths of the four students one year ago were remembered at Kent State Uni versity today.

title: Taiwanese Discern a Bad Omen for the Nationalists
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 4The Taiwanese river whose Chinese name means Muddy Water ran clear last week for the first time in a quarter of a century.

title: Pollution of the Park...
description: Central Park is one of the past glories of urban plan ning, but like the city itself it is becoming a victim of abuse, of the losing battle between maintenance and decay.

title: Panther Is Released Because of Wiretap
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4A Federal judge abruptly dis missed today an indictment against David Hilliard, a Black Panther leader, who had been charged with threatening the life of President Nixon.

title: Taiwanese Admits Attempt To Murder Chiang's Son
description: A 33yearold native of Tai wan pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of illegal possession of a weapon and attempting to murder Chiang Chingkuo, Vice Premier of Nationalist China.

title: Favored One Nation Captures $20,000 4Horse Dash at Aqueduct
description: Quite a few followers of form in yesterday's crowd of 23?? a. Aqueduct wondered about the slim turnout of four juveniles for the third race de spite the sizable inducement of a $20,000 purse.

title: Two SiciliesOne Is Modern, One Is Mired in the Past
description: PALERMO, SicilyMainland politicians flocking to this is land to help in the campaign for the nationally important regional election on June 13 are seeing a new Sicily of eco nomic growth and social change along the coastline.

title: Curb on Liquor Discounts Is Approved by Governor
description: ALBANY, May 4Governor Rockefeller signed into law to day a bill requiring retailers to sell liquor at a price at least 12 per cent above its wholesale price.

title: CONSTRUCTION FIRE IGNITES PROPANE GAS
description: A series of propanegas ex plosions set off by a tar fire on the roof of a nearly completed 27story apartment building on the northeast corner of Colum bus Avenue and 96th Street rattled windows for blocks around the area yesterday.

title: Broken Promises Mark Barton's Path to Canada
description: About Pro Football

title: Quake Rocks Jakarta
description: JACARTA, Indonesia, May 4 (AP)An earthquake of me dium intensity shook the Indo nesian capital this morning, sending hundreds of office workers in the downtown area fleeing into the streets. There were no reports of damage.

title: LABOR PRESSING ITALY ON REFORMS
description: ROME, May 4Italy's three major labor organizations start ed talks today with political parties in an effort to get long promised social reforms.

title: Proposed Bomber Termed Unneeded
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  A bipartisan Congressional group fired its first salvo in the bat tle over the defense budget to day by attacking the Air Force's proposed new supersonic man ned bomber.

title: THRONG FORECAST BY VICTORY NOW
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The Rev. Carl McIntire, the rightwing, fundamentalist preacher, declared today that his Victory Now in Vietnam March here this Saturday would attract more participants than did the peace march of April 24.

title: BRITISH RESERVES ROSE EAST MONTH
description: LONDON, May 4Britain continued to pile up a fat posi tion in gold and foreignex change reserves last month de spite the onepoint reduction in the bank rate to 6 per cent, Treasury figures showed today.

title: 2,680 More Demonstrators Arrested in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 5The District of Colum bia police arrested 2,680 more antiwar demonstrators yester day in minor confrontations and at the end of a twohour dem onstration at the Justice De partment.

title: Big Board's Revenues Up $2.8Million in Quarter
description: Net revenues of the New York Stock Exchange in the first quarter of 1971, before in come taxes and special pay ments to member firms in liqui dation, rose to $4.4million from $1.6million in the first three months of 1970, the ex change disclosed yesterday.

title: C. H. CLARAHAN JR., BRIDGE DESIGNER, 74
description: Charles H. Clarahan Jr., an engineer and bridge designer, died Monday after a brief ill ness in Avon, Conn., where he was visiting his sister. He was 74 years old and lived at 3556 77th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Bandit Flees Commandeered Truck in a Traffic Jam
description: A holdup man abandoned a sawedoff shotgun and a police revolver across the street from City Hall yesterday and escaped through a noonday crowd.

title: CAMPUSES CALLED HARMFUL TO JEWRY
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 4 (AP)Liberal arts colleges with their sexual permissiveness and emphasis on agnosticism are a destructive influence on Jewish students, says the president of the largest Orthodox rabbinic body in the United States.

title: The Role of Economics
description: Economic Analysis

title: HARRY D. COOPER
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., May 4 Harry D. Cooper, president of Harry D. Cooper & Sons, Inc., British Continental Sales Com any and Cooper Woolen Sales Company, textile manufactur ers, died today at his home.

title: MRS. H. E. SCHNIEWIND
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., May 4 Mrs. Helen Greeff Schniewind, widow of Henry E. Schniewind, who was president of Susque hanna Silk Mills, died yesterday lat her home, 19 Oak Lane. She was 90 years old.

title: Thaw Is Mild So Far
description: News Analysis

title: No Change in Policies
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Sec retary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. issued a statement tonight in response to in quiries that said, in effect, that the latest international monetary turmoil would not cause any change in American policies nor produce any dra matic United States measures.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation an nounced the election yes terday of Hobart Taylor Jr., as its first black di rector. Mr. Taylor, who is 50 years old, is a mem ber of the Washington law firm of Dawson, Quinn, Riddell, Taylor & Davis and former special counsel to President Johnson. He served as a director of the Export Import Bank from 1965 to 1968. He is a direc tor of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio and the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company. He is also on the board of the Aetna Fund and a member of the Federal, InterAmerican, Michigan and Detroit Bar Associations. In 1961 he became a special counsel to the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity and served as exec utive vice chairman of the Committee from 1962 to 1965. Westinghouse Electric also announced the formation of a new division to develop the concept of platform mounted nuclear power plants for off shore locations to serve major metropolitan areas in the United States. The company's special proj ect division, will be headed by A. P. Zechella, gen eral manager.

title: FUTURES OF CORN ARE OFF SHARPLY
description: Based on reports of favorable weather for the completion of field work, cornfutures prices dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Sellers far outnumbered buy ers for a time.

title: China Policy: The Balance Sheet
description: From the time of Mao's conquest of the mainland in 1949 until the Great Proletarian PingPong Revolution of 1971, this country has held to as two part policy on China: (a) political and economic boycott of the Communist regime in Peking, and (b) recognition and support, of the Nationalist regime in Taipei. Now that we, are preparing to think along with Mao, it is easy to predict how this interlude in Chi neseAmerican relations is going to be embalmed in the accepted mythology.

title: City Drafts Dating Rules on Freshness of Foods
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner Bess Myerson issued set of proposed regulations yes terday designed to make it eas ier for shoppers to tell that the dairy products, eggs and baked goods they buy are fresh.

title: Rights Unit Seeks to Drop Teacher Examiners' Board
description: The city's Commission on Hu man Rights recommended yes terday the abolition of the Board of Examiners, the con troversial, 73yearold body that passes on the qualifica tions of all city public school teachers and most supervisors.

title: Casey to Speak to Writers
description: William J. Casey, recently named as chairman of the Se curities and Exchange Commis sion, will be the guest speaker at the annual spring dinner of the New York Financial Writ ers' Association. John J. Con cannon, the association's presi dent, said the dinner would be held in the Americana Hotel on Monday, June 7.

title: MARIJUANA SEIZED AFTER A SEA CHASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 (UPI)A yacht carrying five tons of marijuana was seized by customs agents and the Coast Guard after a sea chase near the Golden Gate, Treasury agents disclosed today.

title: Hostos College Appoints Puerto Rican Acting Head
description: Dean Edward W. Aponte of Hostos Community College was named acting president of the college yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

title: PRISON BRUTALITY CHARGED AT TRIAL
description: Two prisoners who were in the Queens House of Detention for Men in Kew Gardens during a riot last fall testified yester day that they had been beaten by guards after the prison was retaken.

title: Casey Feels Fees Brokers Get Are Too High
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Wil liam J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, believes that the public cannot indefinitely be asked to pay stock market com missions that are as high as they are now just because too many brokerage firms are in adequately capitalized.

title: Teamster Trial Set in Butte
description: BUTTE, Mont., May 4 (AP) Edward Grady Partin, a key figure in the Government's prosecution of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, will go to trial June 14 in Butte on Federal criminal antitrust charges. Mr. Partin, a Louisiana teamsters union official indicted in June, 1969, in New Orleans, will appear on a change of ven ue from Baton Rouge.

title: U.S. Seeks Order Against Ling Ties
description: Merger News

title: Roundup: Unser Takes Up HittingStreak Challenge
description: The consecutivegame hit ting streak is one of base ball's more esoteric refine ments in consistency. Usually it goes unnoticed until some disciplined hitter comes along to challenge Joe DiMaggio's majorleague record of 56, set 30 years ago.

title: DISMISSAL ASKED IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, May 4De fense attorneys for the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and seven other persons indicted by Federal grand jury on conspir acy charges have asked that the indictments be dismissed and rodent officials held in contempt of court for abuse of the grand jury process.

title: Troy Appears Assured of Election as Queens Democratic Chief
description: ALBANY, May 4City Coun cilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. to day was virtually assured of election as Queens Democratic leader in a contest with political ramifications extending into the Lindsay administration and state Democratic politics.

title: ExG.O.P. Leader In Jersey Admits Accepting a Payoff
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., May 4, (AP)A former Hudson County Republican chairman, John Beier Theurer, admitted today that he had accepted money from Joseph Zicarelli, a re ported crime figure, to influence the selection of a new pros ecutor who would protect Zie arelli's gambling operations.

title: POLICE SAVE L.I. MAN, HOLD HIM IN KILLING
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 4 About 12 hours after he alleg edly shot and killed his wife, Walter Nealy was found yester day by Nassau County detec tives who then saved his life and arrested him for murder.

title: Priest's Home Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland May 4 (UPI)A bomb blew in the door of a Roman Catholic priest's home in east Belfast early today but caused no in juries, a police spokesman said. The bomb, the 131st exploded so far this year in Northern Ireland, caused minor damage to the house of the Rev. Patrick Fullerton, a priest in Belfast's St. Anthony's parish.

title: All You Do Is Flick a Finger...
description: Shop Talk

title: Philadelphia Panel Moves to Drop 1976 World's Fair
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 4 After four years and $2.5mil lion were spent in planning, the steering committee of the Phil adelphia Bicentennial Corpora tion recommended today that plans for playing host to a world's fair in 1976 be scrapped.

title: Teacher Left 3 Children
description: Horace G. Ports Jr., a social studies teacher in Scarsdale, N. Y., who died on Saturday, left three children, Lyn, Terry and Sumiko, in addition to his wife, the former Suki Terada, An obituary in yesterday's New York Times said he had left two children.

title: L.I.R. Rider Pays $125 Fine For Changing Date on Ticket
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., May 4 (UPI)A Long Island Railroad rider paid a $125 fine in Suffolk County First District Court to day after he admitted altering his commutation ticket to ob, tain free rides.

title: Une de Mai Beats Tidalium Feb by 1 Lengths in French Trot
description: ENGHIEN  LES  BAINS, France, May 4  JeanRene Gougeon, the leading trainer and driver of French trotters, did a lot better today at this Paris suburb than he did last night at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: 8 COPIER CREWMEN ACCUSED OF MURDER
description: SAIGON, May 4  Murder charges have been placed against eight helicopter crew men accused of strafing inno cent civilians while on a flight in the Metkong Delta last year a United States Army spokes man disclosed today.

title: HATCHER IS VICTOR IN GARY PRIMARY
description: GARY, Ind., May 4Mayor Richard G. Hatcher over whelmed the Democratic ma chine's candidate tonight to win his party's primary and take a long step toward a sec ond fouryear term in this hard fisted steel city.

title: Astronauts' Lunar Car Proves Easy to Operates
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 4When better cars are built, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration may not necessarily have the better ideaunless it has to do with a strippeddown, fourwheel runabout for exploring the moon where the Apollo 15 as tronauts plan to land in July.

title: Opera Premiere Opens Schwetzinger Festival
