He succeeds James Boyd who has retired but will remain as chairman. Mr. Ensign, 46 Years old, was named president and chief operating officer one year ago.*

title: The Brownsville Way of Life: Grinding Poverty and Squalor
description: There is scarcely a fluctua tion in the state or city budg ets that is not felt directly by the people who still live in the decaying ruins of Brownsville, among the heatless tenements, along the glasslittered streets.

title: Dr. Donald Van Slyke Chemist, Dead
description: Dr. Donald Dexter Van Slyke, an internationallyrenowned bi ological chemist, died of can cer on Tuesday evening at the home of his son in Garden City, L. I. He was 88 years old on March 29. He and Mrs. Van Slyke had been living in Gar dent City for a year because of his failing health. Their home was in Belle Terre, a Long Is land community adjoining Port Jefferson.

title: Metals Futures Gain Sharply; Silver Coins Score Advance
description: The precious and semipre cious metals futures as well as the silver coins futures market took off here yesterday as result of the news from Europe that dollars were being ex changed for marks and other strong European currencies.

title: NEW YORK TRADING IN MONEY IS HEAVY
description: The volume of trading in the New York foreignexchange market was exceptionally heavy yesterday, bankers re ported, but changes in currency values were modest.

title: She Designs Fashions to Endurefor 3 Generations
description: When Clodagh O'Kennedy the sparkling, greeneyed Dublin fashion designer, packed up her fall collection to show to clients in New York, she tossed in the man uscript of a cookbook. She calls it, At Least You Can Eat Your Mistakes, and it's Irish in flavor, like the clothes. It's filled with tips for busy women (like her self) who don't have time to fuss over food but who like to look as if they had.

title: Planners Seek Data Tracing Illnesses To Queens Pollution
description: A medical survey showing the Long Island CityAstoria area in Queens to be the second worst in the city in chronic illness among children could lead to changes in the new Master Plan for that section.

title: STATE AIDE SCORES RAND RENT REPORT
description: The state's Commissioner of Housing and Community Re newal said yesterday that Gov ernor Rockefeller's proposal to phase out rent control would, in 80 per cent of the cases, in crease rents to amounts no higher than those authorized under the city's current law.

title: Eastern Reaffirms Order For 50 Lockheed Tristars
description: Eastern Air Lines yesterday became the first of nine com panies that had orders for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's 1011 Tristar jet aircraft to re affirm its purchase agreement since last February, when Rolls Royce, Ltd., the builder of the RB211 engine for the plane went bankrupt.

title: Pepsico Shuffles Top PostsPearson Is New President
description: Pepsico, Inc., will realign its top management when its board of directors meets today it was disclosed yesterday at the com pany's annual meeting in Wil mington, Del.

title: Modern Museum Offers Works of Multiple Art
description: The director must have in toned, once more with feel ing, boys, and a good part of his cast went through the routine again, but not much with feeling. Perhaps they had already done it well enough so that they no longer felt much inspiration or they didn't like the theater they were rehearsing in.

title: WAR RALLY HERE ATTRACTS 10,000
description: More than 10,000 people gathered at Bryant Park yester day to commemorate the killing of students at Kent State Uni versity and Jackson State Col lege a year ago and to protest against the war in. Vietnam.

title: Rev. John F. X. Sweeney, 71, Jesuit Theology Professor
description: The Rev. John F.X. Sweeney, S.J., died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 352 Riverside Drive.

title: Roundup. A's on a Blue Streak
description: Vida Blue, the Oakland A's lefthander who is being com pared with Sandy Koufax and Johnny (Double NoHit) Van der Meer, last night bceame the first pitcher in the majors to post seven victories this season.

title: Ousted Essence Magazine Chief Accuses Playboy
description: The founder of Essence, a nagazine published for black women, charged yesterday that Playboy was making a bla tant attempt to take over his magazine.

title: 2 Staten Island Ferry Runs To Be Cut in Economy Move
description: Rushhour service on the Staten Island ferry will be cut back in each direction in the latest economy move, Charles Leedham, the Marine and Avia tion Commissioner, said yester day.

title: The Currency Situation
description: WHAT HAPPENEDCentral banks of West Germany, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Belgium and Austria stopped supporting the value of the United States dollar. Some of these currencies rose modestly in relation to the dollar in heavy trading. In some countries, Americans had trouble cashing travelers' checks.

title: A NEW FORAY IS MADE AT 5TH AVENUE LINES
description: The insurgent group seeking liquidation of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., made anoth er attempt yesterday to force distribution of the company's assets to stockholders.

title: MAX F. W. HEBERLEIN
description: RAHWAY, N. J., May 5Max F. W. Heberlein, who was chief metallurgist of the U. S. Metals Refining Company of Carteret at his retirement in 1962, died yesterday at his home here. He was 74 years old and lived at 1120 Midwood Drive.

title: Hatcher's Victory
description: News Analysis

title: NAMATH ASKS JETS TO ACQUIRE HAYES
description: With his wrist and spirit healed, Joe Namath suggested yesterday the New York Jets needed to regain George Sauer or to obtain Bob Hayes as a wide receiver if they were to win the Super Bowl game.

title: 5 Accused of Draining 2 L.I. Companies of Assets
description: A Federal grand jury indict ed five men yesterday on charg es of taking over two Long Is land concerns, converting com pany checks into cash at gamb ling casinos and forcing the copanies into bankruptcy.

title: Charge of Dangers There
description: MONTREAL, May 5 (Cana dian Press)The Montreal Star said that the village of St. Jean de Vianney was described as a dangerous zone in a geolo gist's report prepared last year for the Quebec Resources De partment.

title: Death Row Survives
description: The Supreme Court's decision with regard to capital punishment failed to reach the substantive issues. By 6to3 vote, the Court ruled that it is not a violation of due process for the states to give juries absolute discre tion in imposing the death penalty. It further held that it is not necessary for the states to require juries, having decided that a prisoner is guilty, to hear additional evi dence before determining sentence.

title: State Is Planning to Build Power Plant to Assist City
description: A Schoharie Creek and moun tain site, 100 miles northnorth west of New York City near the village of North Blenheim, was announced yesterday as the tentative location for a new millionkilowatt pumpedstorage plant to supply electricity to the metropolitan area in time of peak needs.

title: Humphrey Calls for Release Of Impounded Health Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, called today on the Nixon Adminis tration to release $226million in health funds impounded for economy reasons.

title: Flintkote Company
description: At the annual meeting of the Flinkote Company at corporate headquarters in White Plains, it was announced that James D. Moran had been elected president and chief executive officer, succeeding George J. Pecaro, who was elected chair man of the board.

title: CONTRACTORS GET THE WORD: SHHH!
description: Jackhammers, drills and a pile driver tore into a worn out street in lower Manhattan yesterday with relatively little of the usual construction din.

title: JOEL LIEBER DIES; NOVELIST WAS 35
description: Joel Lieber, author of the novels How the Fishes Live, Move!, The Chair and The Circle Game, fell to his death Monday from his apart ment at 785 West End Avenue. Detectives of the 24th Precinct said he left two notes and listed his death as a suicide. He was 35 years old.

title: 3 Representatives Decry Arrests on Capitol Steps
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Don't you guys believe in the Constitution? Representative Bella S. Abzug, her gaucho hat askew on her head, shouted Representative Roman C. Pu cinski, Democrat of Illinois, the foot of the House steps.

title: 4 CITIES ARE TO GET RACIAL HIRING PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)The Nixon Administra tion will soon impose racial hir ing plans on construction un ions and companies in Chicago, St. Louis, San Francisco and Atlanta, Similar action may fol low in 15 other cities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Amtrak Picks Roger Lewis As Chairman of the Board
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Roger Lewis, former head of the General Dynamics Corpora tion, has been elected chair man of the board of the Na tional Railroad Passenger Cor poration (Amtrak), it was an nounced today.

title: U.S STEEL SETS SOME PRICE RISES AVERAGIN 6.25%
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's leading steel producer, announced yes terday that it would raise prices by an average of about 6.25 per cent on products that account for perhaps a third of all American steel shipments.

title: CHIC COREA'S TRIO BECOMES QUARTET
description: The trio formed by Chic Corea, pianist, after he left Miles Davis's group (with Dave Holland, bass, and Barry Alt schul, drums) has been ex panded to a quartet with the addition of Anthony Braxton. The foursome has moved into the Village Vanguard, where they are playing a fascinating phantasmagoria of sounds.

title: Harlan Bars DeMartino Plea on Baby Lenore
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Supreme Court Justice John M. Harlan today rejected a plea that he permit Baby Lenore to remain with her adopted parents a little longer.

title: Theater: Earl of Ruston Begins Run
description: Earl was crazy and he lived in Ruston. His nephews have written a country rocker about him, and his mother appears in it and it is called, reasonably enough, Earl of Ruston. It opened last night at the Billy Rose Theater.

title: Where Lies Authority?
description: Is it true that irresponsible politicians are trying to make a raid on Port Authority coffers and will destroy a viable agency in their quest for funds for mass transit? Austin Tobin, Execu tive Director of the Port of New York Authority, apparently thinks so. He has called criticism of his agency scurrilous, irresponsible and utterly baseless, and insists that his agency can do nothing for mass transit proj ects which are not selfsupporting.

title: PUBLICUNION POWER DISMAYS STEEL AIDE
description: A Republic Steel executive said yesterday that labor bar gaining involving public em ployes was having an increas ing impact on business and industry, and he warned against excesses.

title: Bricklayers Local in Ohio Agrees to Forgo Pay Rise
description: MARION, Ohio, May 5 (AP) Bricklayers Union Local 47 and the Ohio Contractors As sociation agreed today on a oneyear contract that carries no wage increases.

title: Degas Sculpture Is Sold For a Record $380,000
description: An awkward little girl in bronze, La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans, made beautiful by, her youth and the artistry of Edgar Degas, won a world auc tion record for a sculpture last night. It brought $380,000 from the Wildenstein Galleries of New York in a sale of 74 works of art from the private collection of Norton Simon, the California industralist.

title: Defense Witness Testifies Sams Sought to Get Even With Seale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 5George Sams Jr., the only person who has testified that Bobby G. Seale ordered Alex Rackley killed, was described in court today as a vicious man who hated and resented Mr. Seale and wanted to get even with him.

title: Lawrence N. Murray, 76, Dies; Led Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, May 5Law rence N. Murray, a former president of the Mellon Nation al Bank and Trust Company, died today at the age of 76.

title: Wars Studied in Effort at Prevention
description: Almost from the day some prehistoric tribesmen picked up their clubs and spears and started the first war to avenge a stolen wife or the malpractices of a witch doc tor, man has had reason to wonder what causes the deadly quarrels that afflict his species.

title: Genesco Plans TakeOver Of Beeline Fashions, Inc.
description: Merger News

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: YOU can unveil secrets of your future: Get a copy of Row To Consult the I Chins. $6.05 at bookstores now. Putnam.Advt.

title: U.S. COURT REJECTS ACTION AGAINST JURY
description: The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here decided yesterday that a New York County grand jury, that looked into 1964 Harlem rioting had not been picked in a way that denied due process or equal protection of the laws.

title: INSTANT RESPONSES TO NIXON TV URGED
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has called on the heads of the three broadcast net works to provide time for im mediate response to televised Presidential speeches by per sons holding opposing views.

title: U.S. Aide Accused of Trying to Recruit Soviet Scientist as Spy
description: MOSCOW, May 5  A So viet newspaper said today that the United States Embassy's chief cultural affairs officer had tried to recruit a Soviet scientist for espionage.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
EXEMPTIONS UPHELD IN RENT RISES HERE
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the constitu tionality of a city statute that exempts certain elderly tenants with low incomes from paying rent increases approved for rentcontrolled housing.

title: Bank Blast on Coast
description: CHICO, Calif., May 5 (AP) A small explosive device blew a 10inch hole in the front window of a Bank of America branch office, the police re ported today. They said there had been no injuries. The de vice was apparently taped to the window and detonated late last night, investigators said. There was no immediate esti mate of the damage.

title: Herbert L. Lewis, Editor Of Papers in St Paul, 72
description: ST. PAUL, May 5 (UPI)  Herbert L. Lewis, former editor of The St. Paul Dispatch and The Pioneer Press, died beer to day. He was 72 years old.

title: MONETARY CRISIS LIFTS BOND RATES
description: Interest rates climbed and fixedincome security prices sank yesterday as the credit markets worried about an in ternational financial crisis.

title: Lindsay and 4 Other Mayors Seek Greater U.S. Effort Against Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Mayor Lindsay appealed to day for the creation of a unified Federal narcotics treat ment and research agency with the goal of a $1billion annual program within three years to fight drug addiction.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: May 5, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

title: War With India Possible, Pakistan General Asserts
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 5 The chief of Pakistan's mili tary intelligence service por trayed his nation today as facing large Indian military forces along the frontiers and said he could not discount the possibility of war.

title: Soviet Assails U.S. Step in China
description: MOSCOW, May, 5A leading Soviet political commentator said today that the recent visit, to Peking by an Americana table tennis team was an in significant step toward nor malizing ChineseAmerican re lations but was being used by the Nixon Administration for antiSoviet objectives.

title: Enemy Shells Danang
description: SAIGON, Thursday, May 6 (Reuters)  Vietcong gunners shelled the northern base city of Danang last night, killing six civilians and destroying three houses, a military spokes man announced here today. The spokesman said three soldiers and four civilians were wounded in the shelling attack just before midnight.

title: A Deaf Boy at Protest Is Helped by Policeman
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 A teenage boy, wandering aimlessly on the Mall today near the Capitol, got instruc tions on how to take part in an antiwar demonstration from an unlikely sourcea District of Columbia police man.

title: Hoffman Arrested By F.B.I. for Role In Capital Protest
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader at his Manhattan apartment late tonight on charges of interstate travel to incite a riot and as saulting a police officer during antiwar demonstration here.

title: Rogers in Israel After Seeing Sadat
description: JERUSALEM, May 6Secre tary of State William P. Rogers flew here from Cairo today carrying assurances from Pres ident Anwar elSadat that Egypt was ready to listen to any reasonable Israeli proposal to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Senate Unit Asks Pakistan Arms Cutoff
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee called unanimously to day for an immediate suspen sion of American military aid and arms sales to Pakistan un til the civil conflict there is re solved and the distribution of relief supplies is resumed.

title: STOCKS OFF A BIT IN FACE OF CRISIS
description: The stock market weighed yesterday the international cur rency crisisblack headlines and alland finished with a modest retreat.

title: Detained Peking Official Asks To Return to China From Paris
description: PARIS, May 6 (Reuters)A Chinese official, taken semi conscious to a hospital by the French police after ?? airport row with Peking diplomats here last week, has asked to leave for China as soon as possible, the police said tonight.

title: Relief Recipients Go to Work Upstate
description: ENDWELL, N. Y., May 6 Amid the jabber and song of the birds along the Susque hanna this springtime there is the drone and rasp of the buzz saw clearing away the dead trees and brush of the riverbank Here.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
The Old Newspaper Game
description: LACONIA, N. H.For the last four years I have lived in Laconia. It is a small town in central New Hampshire. I am a junior at Laconia High School, and am a member of the student council.

title: Quenching Brownsville's Fires
description: Calm has been restored to Brownsville, said Mayor Lindsay yesterday after touring this terribly deprived section of New York City that was still smoldering from the disturbances of the day before.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The despicable acts of violence and harassment conducted by the Jewish Defense League in the U.S.A. are ob viously the work of a small minority not connected with American citizenry as a whole, Jew or Gentile.

title: Role of the Supplemental State Budget
description: ALBANY, May 6Tucked away in the $7.7billion budget passed on April 2 is $30million to cover the lastminute money bills that are annually rammed through the Legislature in the frenzy and fatigue of every session's ending.

title: Second Cast Gives Taming of Shrew At Stuttgart Ballet
description: Despite a mild and even sluggish start, the Stuttgart Ballet's The Taming of the Shrew gathered its wit and momentum Wednesday after noon at the Metropolitan Opera House to finish with a light, thrusting and stylish lan. The performance featured a covey of major cast changes, with Judith Reyn dancing Katherine, Susanne Henke, Bianca, and Heinz Clauss as Petruchio, all seen for the first time this sea son.

title: Screen:
description: REPORT FROM CHINA, directed by Toshio Tokleda; screenplay by Junpei Yoshihara; photographed be Suehiko Fulise and Shigeharu Watanabe; mu sic by Akira Mlyoshl; an Iwanami Film Production, released by Raclin) Films, At the New Yorker Theater, Broadway and 18th Street. Running time: 90 minutes. (Not submitted at this time to the Motion Picture of America's Production Codo and Rating Administration for rating u to audi ence suitability.)

title: Amex Prices Decline Sharply in Heavy Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange took their worst beating in two and a half months yesterday as the list declined in more active trading.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The State Department said today that naturalized United States citizens of Polish origin should exercise caution in making plans to visit Poland.

title: Night Schedule Will Grow For World Series in 1972
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday the signing of a fouryear con tract with major league base ball for exclusive national cov erage of games on television and radio. The contract, which will cost the network a report ed $70million, provides that, starting next year, all midweek games of the World Series will be played at night.

title: Confusion in Steel
description: The vapidity of the Administration's program for curbing the wageprice spiral has never been more dismayingly evident than in its approach to the steel industry. Even now, with the dollar in acute trouble in world money markets and with the wholesale price index signaling another upsurge in domestic inflation, the White House has thrown a mantle of total confusion over developments in this most basic of American industries.

title: Dr. CavagnaMartinez, 66, Foreign Minister for Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 6 (UPI)  Dr. Ildefenso F. Ca agnaMartinez, who served as Argentina's Foreign Minister under President Juan D. Pern, died of cancer yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: Texas Gulf Gas Price Raised; Costs Here Likely to Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Federal Power Commission set higher prices for Texas Gulf Coast natural gas today and established other incentives to stimulate exploration for new natural gas supplies.

title: Saigon Reports New Clash in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 (AP)  South Vietnamese troops, led by tanks and under cover of air and artillery strikes, reported fighting about 400 North Vietnamese today near the town of Snuol, a few miles inside Cambodia.

title: Egypt Voices Disappointment
description: CAIRO, May 6  Egyptian spokesmen made it clear today that they were disappointed that Mr. Rogers was unable during his talks here to submit Israeli proposals on a reopen ing of the Suez Canal.

title: TRADING IN MONEY EASES A BIT HERE
description: The frantic pace of trading in the New York foreign exchange market subsided a bit yesterday, as participants in the market began to assess the longerrange implications of the decision by five European cen tral banks not to support the value of the dollar in relation to their currencies.

title: 83 Cezanne Works Gathered for Show
description: CHICAGOWe hear from every quarter nowadays that the age of the great loan ex hibitions is quickly drawing to a close. Collectors, includ ing many museums that for merly practiced very open handed policies on loans, are increasingly reluctant to ex pose their major holdings to the risks of carless handling and dubious shipping condi tions. Then, too, the costs of mounting such exhibitions are soaring. Moreover, the sheer quantity of time and energy that must now be invested in the delicate diplo matic wheedling that goes into prying a precious mas terpiece loose from its suspicious owner, all for an exhibition lasting only a month or two, begins to look more and more onerous to museum curators beset with so many more compelling problems to solve on their own beleaguered premises.

title: Sirik Matak's Cabinet Backed In Cambodian Assembly Vote
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak, Cambodia's Premier in all but name, appeared before the National Assembly today with the Cabinet he had chosen and won a resounding vote of approval. That ended the gov ernment crisis that began with the resignation of Premier Lon Nol on April 20.

title: 2 WAR FOES FACE U.S. JURY INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 6As 18 days of antiwar protest wound down here today, the Justice Department was seeking a grand jury investigation of at least two participants who were arrested on conspiracy charges.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Dover Corporation announced yesterday the election of Thomas C. Sutton as chairman of the board. Mr. Sutton, who will continue as chief executive officer, succeeds Fred D. Durham, who has retired but continues as adviser to the office of the chairman. Mr. Sutton will be succeeded as president by Anthony J. Ormsby, who pre viously was executive vice president. Robert S. Bethe, treasurer and controller, has been elected vice president and treasurer.

title: City Aide Is Appointed To Head Medical School
description: The senior vice president of the city's new Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dr. Stanley S. Bergen, will leave July 1 to become president of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry.

title: Goodyear to Expand Plant
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 6 (AP) The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company said today it would start construction on a $23 million expansion project at its Danville, Va., truck and air craft tire production facility later this month. When com pleted, employment will be in creased by 300 persons.

title: Merger News
description: Directors of Allegheny Air lines, Inc., and Mohawk Air lines, Inc., agreed yesterday on definitive terms that could lead to a merger of the two carriers. Under terms of the previously announced merger, Allegheny would be the surviving airline. To become effective, the mer ger must be ap proved by the Civil Aeronautics Board and President Nixon as well as by lenders, subordi nated lenders and stockholders of both companies. The merged carrier would be the sixth larg est in the nation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Toko Shinoda Displays Precision in Sumi Paintings
description: It is a rare artist whose modernism is rooted in tradi tion without compromise in either direction. Toko Shino da, in a new exhibition of Sumi paintings at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, is such a rarity.

title: SEALE IS PRAISED AS PEACEFUL MAN
description: NEW HAVEN, May 6An Episcopal priest from California testified today that Bobby G. Seale, now on trial on charges that he helped kidnap and kill Alex Rackley, was one of the foremost upholders of peace and quiet in the San Fran ciscoOakland area.

title: Chase, Fox Trustee, Is Ordered To Reply on Stock Vote Rights
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, as trustee for the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation's pension fund, was ordered to appear in State Supreme Court today to explain why it should not be prevented from voting about 200,000 Fox shares in the fund for the company's present management slate.

title: Man in the News
description: BURBANK, Calif., May 6 The boys here at the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation, as Daniel Jeremiah Haughton, chairman, calls his manage ment team, have long ad mired the boss's resiliency. That trait was severely test ed over the last year as the chief executive of the nation'.s largest de fense contractor set a whirlwind transcontinental and transAtlan tic travel pace in an effort to save his com pany from bankruptcy. To day, he was in Washington when it was announced that President Nixon would ask Congress to guarantee $250 million in loans to the be leaguered company, a chief goal of Mr. Haughton's nego tiating efforts.

title: Japan Says She Will Maintain Rate of 360 Yen to $1
description: TOKYO, May 6Finance Min ister Takeo Fukuda said in a statement today that Japan would maintain the present par value of 360 yen to $1.

title: 1971: For These Three, It's Memory Lane
description: The rallying cry among designers as fall sweeps over Seventh Avenue is return to the classics. It's their way nut of the present slough of despond, when many women regard clothes as found objects, things made lovingly at home or an abomination.

title: Berkeley Board Moves
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (AP) After years of bombings, demonstrations, raids, deface ments and miscellaneous vio lence, the Berkeley draft board has moved to a quieter neigh borhood. From Grove and Ad dison Streets, the traditional, ground zero for Berkeley anti war protesting, the board this week moved to the well guard ed Armed Forces Induction Center in Oakland.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: VACOAS, Mauritius Russian na tional instincts have shown remark able persistence, ignoring the ideolog ical contradictions of Russian Govern ments. Thus, on the one hand, Red Star could write last year: The age old dreams of our people have be come a reality. The pennants of So viet ships now flutter in the most re mote corners of the seas and oceans. And, on the other hand, one can re member that a lesser known naval project of Czar Peter the Great in volved penetration of the Indian Ocean and annexation of Madagascar.

title: Atrocities by Army Against Insurgents Charged in Ceylon
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 6 Charges that Ceylonese police men and troops had committed atrocities in their fight against young ultraleftist insurgents were made at a tumultuous ses sion of the House of Repre sentatives late yesterday.

title: 2 MINE UNIONISTS GUILTY ON FUNDS
description: PITTSBURGH, May 6 (AP) A Federal jury convicted two officials of District 5 of the United Mine Workers today in what the Government said wa a union conspiracy to divert funds into the 1969 reelection campaign of the U.M.W. presi dent, W. A. Boyle.

title: Less Initial State Relief Shown In House Panel's Welfare Data
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  Officials of the Nixon Adminis tration, in a homestretch drive to sell welfare reform to Con gress, have predicted that the states will save $3billion to $3.5billion a year by 1977 if the plan is adopted.

title: Roundup: McNally Rolls On
description: Dave McNally, the Balti more Orioles' highsalaried lefthander who shared Amer ican League honors for most victories at 24 with his teammate, Mike Cuellar, and Jim Perry of Minnesota, last season, notched No. 5 last night as he tossed a four hitter to beat the California Angels, 31.

title: Truman Blocks Move For Medal of Honor
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  Former President Harry S. Truman, who said on several occasions while presenting the Medal of Honor that he would rather have it than be President, has blocked an attempt by the House to give him the award.

title: GreekAlbanian Links Resume After 31 Years
description: ATHENS, May 6Greece and Albania have agreed to resume full diplomatic rela tions, ending a 31yearold feud, it was officially an nounced in Athens and Tirana today.

title: SOVIET WRESTLERS WIN IN TITLE MEET
description: TOKYO, May 6 (AP)The United States won one gold medal, two silvers and a bronze today in the world amateur junior GrecoRoman wrestling championships.

title: DR. JACOB KROLL, 75, RADIOLOGIST HERE
description: Dr. Jacob Kroll, a radiologist who has been on the staffs of Goldwater Memorial Hospital and the New York Cancer In stitute, died Wednesday of a heart attack at Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 60 Sutton Place South.

title: Schools in China, Despite Changes, Retain Many Conventional Subjects
description: CANTON, China, May 6 The changes that have been made in primary and secondary schooling in China do not ap pear to be as drastic as official publicity has depicted them.

title: Jets' Jones to Redskins
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Washington Redskins ac quired Jimmie Jones, a reserve defensive end, from the New York Jets today for a future draft choice. Jones, a three year man, missed most of last season with eye and ankle in juries. He is 24, 6 feet 5 inches and 215 pounds.

title: Little Available Here
description: Very little fresh or frozen swordfish has been available in New York City since last De cember, when the Health De partment began testing incom ing shipments for mercury con tamination, a spokesman for the Health Services Administration said yesterday.

title: Music: Baltimore Symphony Is Sharp
description: The program handed out at Wednesday night's Carnegie Hall concert looked promis ing, certainly. P. Tchaikow sky, the eminent Russian composer, was down to con duct one of his own works, and Walter Damrosch to lead the Symphony Society Or chestra in other numbers. The tenor Italo Campanini would sing.

title: Babcock Gets Contract
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Com pany has received a $12million contract to build a 550,000 kilowatt power generation sys tem for Cia. Sevillana de Elec tricidad.

title: TASS SAYS U.S. ACTS AT ALLIES' EXPENSE
description: MOSCOW, May 6 (Reuters) Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that the United States was trying to shore up the dollar at the expense of its Western European allies.

title: After the Cambodian Political Crisis: Lon Nol Is Still Key Figure
description: News Analysis

title: Apollo Audience Turns On Black Troupe
description: At Harlem's Apollo Thea ter, there are performers on both sides of the footlights. Because of their instant and uninhibited reactions to the happenings on stage, the au dience is acknowledged to be an integral part of the per formance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Jerome Alan Cohen's realistic and attractive option for the U.S. to handle the China issue at the U.N. [OpEd April 24] is nothing but to ad mit Red China to the U.N. at the ex pense of the expulsion of the Republic of China.

title: First of 2 Mariners Ready for Mars Trip
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 6  Two spacecraft, equipped with television cameras and ex tremely sensitive instruments, are undergoing final prepara tions for a sixmonth voyage to Mars, where they will make the first attempts to orbit an other planet.

title: Swiss Doubt Mark Revaluation
description: GENEVA, May 6Swiss fi nancial experts seriously doubt ed today that West Germany would revalue the mark up ward.

title: UAL Files Data on Stock
description: UAL, Inc., said yesterday it has filed a registration state ment with the Securities and Exchange Commission on previously announced offering of 2.5 million shares of com mon stock.

title: Books of The Times
description: MYSELF AMONG OTHERS. By Ruth Gordon. 389 pages. Atheneum. $10.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The action of some 1,000 youths who stopped traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike as a gesture to end the war was as thoughtless and inconsiderate andinhtimane as the policy being pro tested. It was an action that anyone could easily condemn. Moreover, it was an alarming thing for socalled Conscibusness III  the generation that is supposed to be loyal to tales anceto be caught doing..

title: NATHAN BEHRIN, COURT REPORTER
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., May 6 Nathan Behrin, who in 1922 set the world's shorthand speed record of 350 words a minute for 2 minutes, with only 2 in significant errors, died today in East Orange General Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 44 South Munn Avenue.

title: M'GEE CARDS A 66 FOR 2STROKE LEAD IN NELSON CLASSIC
description: DALLAS, May 6As the last of the field finished ahead of a threatening storm today, Jerry McGee, a 145pound pro fessional from Lake Worth, Fla., held the top spot with a 66 in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: Soviet Union, Lacing Restaurant Workers, Suggests He Also Serves Who Only Waits on Tables
description: MOSCOW, May 6The So viet Union, faced with a con tinuing manpower shortage in the service trades, has begun to put the weight of its news papers behind a campaign to raise the prestige of waiters.

title: F.D.A. Advises the Public To Stop Eating Swordfish
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Food and Drug Administra tion advised the American public today to stop eating sword fish because more than 90 per cent of samples tested by the agency contained excessive amounts of mercury. agency contained excessive amounts of mercury.

title: Books of The Times
description: RISK. By Rachel MacKenzie. Viking. 59 pages. $3.95.

title: Ilse Koch's Posthumous Rehabilitation Sought by Son
description: BONN, May 3I want to clear my mother's name, said Uwe Kohler, who is 23 years old and makes a good living selling insurance.

title: What Went Wrong?
description: A new Republican Administra tion will arm the American people with the truth.Richard Nixon, 1968.

title: U.S. Aids Russian Seaman
description: BOSTON, May 6 (AP)The Coast Guard sent a helicopter to the aid of a wounded Soviet seaman today aboard a Russian fishing factory ship at sea. He was airlifted from the Soviet ship Trudovaja Slava 42 miles, southeast of Nantucket.

title: MIDONICK SEEKING SURROGATE POST
description: Family Court Judge Millard L. Midonick announced yester day that he was a candidate for surrogate in New York County.

title: Baby Lenore Parents Face Criminal Contempt Charge
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas De Martino, the adoptive parents of Baby Lenore, were direct ed by the State Supreme Court yesterday to show cause next Tuesday why they should not he held in criminal contempt for failure to surrender the in fant by court order last Mon day.

title: STAN SMITH, KODES GAIN IN ROME TENNIS
description: ROME, May 6 (AP)  Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., play ling as an amateur, upset Antonio Zugarelli of Italy to day and gained the fourth round of the Italian open tennis championships.

title: LAYOFFS CONFIRMED BY BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust Company said yesterday that it had laid off 350 employes this week, and, through a spokesman, the bank indicated that earlier in the year it had separated about 50 officers and allowed attrition in its work force to eliminate 434 more jobs. The total reduction of 834 cut the bank's staff to 10,607 from 11,441 at yearend.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK CONGRESS TO BACK LOCKHEED LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr. announced today that President Nixon would ask Congress for $250million in loan guarantees to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from possible bankruptcy.

title: COUNCIL PUTS OFF ACTION ON BUDGET
description: The revenue package to fill the builtin billiondollar gap in Mayor Lindsay's budget will be sent to Albany unchanged, some City Council leaders indi cated yesterday.

title: CHARLES A. TOSI
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., May 6 Charles A. Tosi, vice president and treasurer of the Pastene Company, Inc., a New York wholesale food distributor, died today at his home, 160 Blau velt Avenue, after a long ill ness. He was 57 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A few days ago, winter's grudging retreat from the East Coast had me appre hensive and wondering if one could no longer count on the shift of seasons.

title: Horovitz Hero to Be Given
description: Israel Horovitz's new play, Hero, will be presented to night and tomorrow night at the New York Shakespeare Fes tival's Public Theater at 10:30 P.M. It will be performed by members of the Independent Study Committee of Amherst College. David Runner has staged it. There is no admission charge.

title: AGNEW SAYS TV MAN IS INTIMIDATING HIM
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 6 (AP) Vice President Agnew inter rupted a meeting with North Carolina state and local offi cials today to accuse a televi sion news executive of intimida tion.

title: Senior Management Group Realigned by J. P. Morgan
description: Ralph F. Leach has been elected chairman of the ex ecutive committee of J. P. Morgan & Co., Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany, and Thomas Rodd has been named a vice chairman of the board of both com panies.

title: Hawks Conquer Canadiens, 53
description: CHICAGO, May 6  In a game so bitterly frustrating for the Montreal Canadiens that even inanimate objects con spired against them, the Chi cago Black Hawks took a leap toward the Stanley Cup tonight by scoring a 53 victory.

title: WILFRED BROWN, 77, OF CUBAN RAILROADS
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 6 Wilfred Jacobs Brown, retired chairman and president of the Consolidated Railroads of Cuba and affiliated companies, died today at his home. He was 77 years old and lived at 66 Aller ton Street.

title: INVESTMENT BANKER CHARGED WITH FRAUD
description: An investment banker whose operation grew from a oneman desk on 42d Street to a 125 employe company within two years was indicted yesterday, along with two of his corpora tions, on charges that they de frauded 500 victims of $1mil lion.

title: Seaver, Gibson Hold Rematch Tonight
description: The New York Mets post poned their game with the Chi cago Cubs yesterday because of threatening weather and there by created a return match be tween Tom Seaver and Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardi nals tonight.

title: Screen:
description: Two documentary films, Phillip Greene's 60minute The Long Walk and Barry Brown's 30minute Subver sion?, make up the new Whitney Museum film pro gram relating two of the more depressing, lessproud moments of American history.

title: ADULTAT18 BILL BLOCKED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, May 6An un likely coalition of conservative Republicans and minority Dem ocrats seeking to embarrass Gov. William T. Cahill came within four votes today of ap proving a bill in the Assembly that would lower the age of legal majority to 18 and there by wipe out state laws that, in book form, weigh about 20 pounds.

title: Royal Dutch Shell Raised Its Profit 15% in 1st Quarter
description: The first quarter of 1971 continued to be good to the oil industry as the Royal Dutch Shell Group of Companies re ported yesterday a 15 per cent rise in earnings.

title: Theater: Scratch Opens
description: Scratch, by Archibald MacLeigh which opened last night at the St. James Thea ter, has little to declare except its aspirations to seriousness.

title: Dutch See No Fluctuation
description: THE HAGUE, the Netherlands May 6The Dutch Finance Minister said today he did not expect that the rate of the Ger man mark would be allowed to fluctuate. At a news conference here, Dr. Johan Witteveen said he believed that the German Government would not take a decision on the mark before the meeting of European Economic Community ministers Saturday in Brussels.

title: Merger Groups Meet; No Decision Is Made
description: After meeting for about seven hours yesterday, club owners of the National Bas ketball Association adjourned without making any decisions about merger possibilities and set another session for this morning.

title: Common Market Divisions Impede Solution of Crisis
description: PARIS, May 6Wide divi sions within the European Eco nomic Community and inside West Germany complicated to day efforts to deal with one of the gravest monetary crises since World War II.

title: HorseDrawn Barges Now a Memory in France
description: MARSEILLELES AUBIG NY, FranceIn the dawning age of the supersonic boom, the sound of another age of transport, the muffled clip clop of hooves on the tow path has vanished into mem ory.

title: First National Realty Ban
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to ban short selling in the warrants of the First National Realty and Construction Corpo ration, effective today. The ex change noted that the warrants expire at the end of this year and said it had in recent years prohibited short sales in war rant issues ahead of their ex piration.

title: Fast Start for Florida Track
description: MIAMI, May 6  South Flor ida's second summer racing season got off to a flying start today when a crowd of 16,263 turned out to see the new $20million Calder race course, an airconditioned establish ment on the Miami side of the DadeBroward County line.

title: Hearings Held in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 6Governorl Rockefeller's proposal to decon trol vacant apartments was praised by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York and denounced by New York City officials at informal legislative hearings here today.

title: Troubles in the Farm Belt Pose 1972 Peril to Nixon
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 6 The farm belt is turning fresh green now that spring is here, but the mood of the men upon the tractors is dirt black.

title: HAVANA ANNOUNCES RELEASE OF WRITER
description: MIAMI, May 6Cuba has announced the release of He berto Padilla, a wellknown writer who was arrested in Havana on March 20.

title: Wholesale Price Index Higher in April;
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Wholesale prices, whose rise had moderated in recent months, went up more rapidly in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: City Aide Says Con Edison Plan On Cutback Could Pollute River
description: A city water pollution offi cial said yesterday that a Queens sewagetreatment plant's power would be cut off, ?? raw sewage flow into the East River, under the Consolidated Edison Company's plans to cope with power short ages.

title: F. B. I. SEIZES 150 IN GAMBLING RING
description: DETROIT, May 6Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation rounded up 150 persons, including 16 Detroit policemen, from throughout Michigan to day of charges of being part of a $15millionayear gambling ring that the bureau said op crated out of a downtown bar here.

title: Striking Unions Won't Oppose Sending Gas to Vital City Units
description: A sufficient supply of gaso line to maintain police and fire protection as well as providing for city hospitals and prisons was assured yesterday by a union agreement not to inter fere with deliveries in the present strike here.

title: Westchester Revisited: Recent Issues a Dim Memory
description: Three years after leaving Westchester County for as signments in Germany and Vietnam, a correspondent who lived and worked in the county from 1966 to 1968 returned to see what had happened on a range of is sues that have troubled this and other suburban areas.WHITE PLAINSFor those who watched or joined the civil rights demonstrations at the construction site in New Rochelle that bitter winter of 196667, the nowcompleted glittering shopping mall and Macy's store will always evoke memories of protesters blocking the snowy excava tion.

title: QUEENS DEMOCRATS ELECT TROY AS HEAD
description: City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. was elected Queens Democratic leader by a unani mous vote late yesterday.

title: G.O.P. in Albany Delays Vote on Disputed Taylor Law Revisions
description: ALBANY, May 6  The As sembly today deferred action until Monday on a bill to re vise the Taylor Law and re strict the areas of negotiation that Civil Service labor unions could bring to the bargaining table.

title: Concern Voiced on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) Industry spokesman said to day that some California fish ermen would have to go out of business and some companies might face large financial losses as a result of the warning on swordfish.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Allow Hiring of Girl Pages
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Ad vocates of girl pages in the Senate scored a breakthrough today when the Senate Rules Committee voted to allow the appointment of girls if their sponsoring Senators assumed responsibility for their safety.

title: India Appeals on Refugees
description: NEW DELHI, May 6The In diandian Government, growing in creasingly concerned about its ability to cope with the mount ing flow of East Pakistani refu gees fleeing the Pakistan Army, issued a new appeal today for outside help and said the refu gees were an international re sponsibility.

title: GENESCO RAISES 3MONTH PROFIT
description: Higher sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Genesco, Inc., for the third fis cal quqarter ended April 30.

title: Obstetricians Get Warning They May Have Less Work
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (UPI)  Obstetricians were warned today of future unem ployment because of a declining birth rate in the United States.

title: Wonderful Ohio!
description: ATHENS, Ohio, May 6On the Class Gateway here at Ohio University, the first college in the Northwest Territory, founded in 1804, there is a quotation from the Ordinance of 1787: Religion, morality and knowledge being neces sary to good government and the hap piness of mankind, schools and the means of education shall forever be encouraged.

title: Speculators Raise Mark and Swiss Franc 2 to 3% Above Par
description: LONDON, May 6The West German mark and the Swiss franc were kept well above their maximum permissible rates today by speculators bet ting on higher official values soon.

title: Stretching Construction Dollars
description: Hope seems to be fading that Albany might do at least one useful thing this year to assist New York City in utilizing its scarce fiscal resources to greatest advantage. Opposition from the socially regressive but politically powerful unions in the building trades has reportedly stalled chances for legislative approval of changes in contract procedure that could bring sizable savings in municipal construction costs.

title: Paper Begins 2d Century
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 6 The Norwalk Hour started its second century of publication today. The newspaper was started by Brainerd W. Maples, a teacher who commuted to New York City. He went into the publishing field to oppose highhanded tactics of the New Haven Railroad, after a conductor put him off a train one day because he couldn't produce his commutation ticket.

title: Advertising:
description: This month Homelite, which will soon be celebrat ing its 50th anniversary, will make its three millionth saw. See? But more germane, per tinent, interesting and timely, it has switched ad agencies, moving its approximately $1.5million account to Need ham, Harper & Steers.

title: Alice Tissot, Actress, Dies; Star of Many French Films
description: PARIS, May 6 (UPI)Alice Tissot, a stage and screen ac tress, died last evening of can cer of the larynx. She was 81 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: MARGARET CLIFFORD OF SKIDMORE WAS 63
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 6Prof. Margaret E. Clif ford, chairman of the drama department at Skidmore College since 1951, died in a hospital here Tuesday after a long ill ness. She was 63 years old.

title: Amtrak Restores Cleveland Rail Route
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The pledge of state subsidies will restore passenger trains be tween New York and Chicago by way of Buffalo, Cleveland and Toledo starting next Mon day, according to the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, which had canceled the service.

title: Statement by Connally
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reu ters)Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr. said today that any decisions to change cur rency parities rested with other countries, although the United States stood ready to cooperate to the fullest degree in restor ing world monetary equilibrium.

title: U.N. BODY PREPARED TO FIGHT POLLUTION
description: PRAGUE, May 6Janez Sta novik of Yugoslavia, executive director of the Economic Com mission for Europe, said today that the organization was pre pared to assume the role of an allEuropean regulatory body to control pollution.

title: Waterfront Agency Told To Reconsider Decision
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered the Waterfront Commission yes terday to reconsider its denial of a stevedoring license to a marine carpentry company whose principals had allegedly obtained a $200,000 loan with the aid of Anthony Scotto, the Brooklyn longshore union leader.

title: Oil Spill Hits Virginia
description: YORKTOWN, Va., May 6 (UPI)A ruptured line at the Amoco refinery plant here spilled thousands of gallons of fuel oil into the York River, creating a slick six and half miles long and 150 to 200 feet wide, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Twins Defeat Yanks for Sweep
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May Steve Braun, a rookie whose childhood ambition was to play for the Yankees, rapped a two run single with two out and the bases loaded in the eighth inning tonight, giving the Min nesota Twins a 53 victory and a sweep of their threegame se ries with New York.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the New York Football Giants were first clawing and scratching for survival, they faced early disaster in 1926, the second season of their existence. A year earlier, a tantalizing glimpse of what the future might hold had been flashed to Tim Mara, the founder of the team.

title: Research and Development Leveled Off in U.S. in 1970
description: Research and development expenditures by United States business leveled off to a figure of $18.33billion in 1970, Mc GrawHill Publications reported yesterday. This year business plans to spend a total of $19.39 billion or 6 per cent more than expenditures last year.

title: White House Names Members of Tricia Nixon's Bridal Party for June 12
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 The White House announced today the members of Tricia Nixon's bridal party for her wedding to Edward Cox Finch in the White House Rose Garden June 12. There will be only four attendants, all relatives of the couple.

title: BONN RULES OUT UNILATERAL MOVE TO REVALUE MARK
description: BONN, May 6  West Ger many will'not arbitrarily set a higher trading value on the mark, the Government's spokes man, Conrad Ahlers, said to night.

title: BILL WOULD HELP ADDICT VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Rep resentative Paul G. Rogers, Democrat of Florida, announced today that he was introducing legislation to add $10million immediately to Veterans Ad ministration programs for treat ment of narcotics addicts and to require the armed forces to treat addicts before returning them to civilian life.

title: LATIN GROUP BARS CUBACHILE MOVE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 Cuba and Chile are trying with little success to gain wider currency for socialist ideas through the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America.

title: HEAD OF I.L.F.W.U. ASSAILS IMPORTS
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 6 Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, called today for higher wages and improved social benefits for members, but warned of the growing threat of imports to the apparel industry.

title: Pound Circulation Decreases 29.73Million in the Week
description: LONDON, May 6 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: 8 Fire Bombs Found In Trunk of a Car On the East Side
description: Eight molotov cocktails were found in the trunk of a car stopped by the police on the Lower East Side last night. Tac tical Patrol Force men, who stopped the car, said it had been headed for Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kent State Sitin Ends
description: KENT, Ohio, May 6 (UPI) About 50 antiwar students to day abandoned their twoday sitin at entrances to a Kent State University building that houses the R.O.T.C. head quarters.

title: NEW EFFORTS TO HALT SICILY'S CRIME URGED
description: ROME, May 6The special antiMafia commission of the Italian Parliament met today to recommend new measures to Sicily.

title: HELENE WEIGEL DIES BRECHT'S WIDOW, 70
description: BERLIN, May 6 (AP)Helene Weigel, widow of playwright Bertolt Brecht, died in East Berlin today, five days before her 71st birthday, the East Ger man news agency ADN re ported.

title: House Panel Votes Money Bill But Drops Ceiling on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 House Democratic leaders suc ceeded today in avoiding the potentially embarrassing posi tion of telling President Nixon both to spend and don't spend.

title: They Followed the Spirit, and Letter, of Their Father's Words
description: WASHINGTON  Many years ago, The Tate Municipal Court Judge James S. Watson, the first black elected to judgeship in New York City, admon ished his two young daughters: You were not put here just to take up space.

title: MATTHEW J. DONOHUE
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., May 6 Matthew J. Donohue, who re tired in 1958 as chief of police for Bergen County, died last night at his home here. He was 75 years old.

title: Alcindor Gets a Car for His Efforts
description: Lew Alcindor of the Mil waukee Bucks, accompanied by his parents and sur rounded by, a hundred or more luncheon guests at Leone's Restaurant, picked up a new sports car yester day, his prize for being named the outstanding player of the final round of the Na tional Basketball Association playoffs.

title: IaLINOWITZHOWITZ ASSAILS EYES TO SUBURBS
description: Sol M. Linowitz, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, directed a sharp attack yester day at businesses that move out of cities and into exclusive, segregated suburbs, charging that they were helping to ex acerbate the problems of an already deeply divided coun try.

title: Work Center Planned
description: The Maryland Workshop of the Blind has announced plans to construct a model train ing and work center in the Northwood Industrial Park, Salisbury, Md. The 27,000 squarefoot facility is scheduled to become operational early next year.

title: CAR MAKERS TOLD TO CLEAN ENGINES
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  If any automobile maker develops a cleanburning car engine by 1975, the other car makers would be out of business until they matched it, William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today.

title: The Politics of Money
description: With the suspension of support purchases of United States dollars by West Germany's Bundesbank and other European central banks, the international monetary crisis is temporarily on ice. The Brandt Government is defer ring announcement of its plans to deal with the rush to the mark until after a meeting tomorrow in Brussels the finance ministers and central bankers of the Euro pean Economic Community.

title: GREEN GETS HELP IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6  David C. Cohen, liberal candi date for Mayor in the May 18th Democratic primary, withdrew today, throwing his support to Representative William J. Green.

title: Hard Times at Adelphi
description: An important judgment on the role of varsity athletics in the college system is moving toward a significant showdown at Adelphi Univer sity in Garden City, L. I.

title: Ohio State Demonstration
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP)  About 100 demonstra tors shouted antiwar slogans and threw eggs, mud and marshmallows at R.O.T.C. (cadets during a military review at Ohio State University today.

title: MISS MESNEY SINGS U.S. MUSIC SURVEY
description: The great quantity of social, religious, popular and folk music that Americans enjoyed during the 18th and 19th cen turies has had some exponents, but not enough. The literature deserves to be better known, if performed in the right spirit.

title: Protesters of School Fund Cuts Tie Up Traffic in East Harlem
description: Hundreds of demonstrators, mainly teachers and parents, blocked traffic at several major intersections in East Harlem for up to 15 minutes yesterday morning to protest threatened budget cuts for schools and other city services.

title: Colombia Bus Fall Kills 7
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, May 6 (UPDSeven persons were killed and 14 injured today when an overloaded jeep bus fell off a mountain cliff in the municipality of Fyedonia, in central Colombia. The police said the vehicle had been li censed to carry only 10 pas sengers but that 21 had been aboard when the accident oc curred.

title: Dining Out on L.I.: Gastronomic Treat
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none. based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Columbia Says Adieu to Four Scholars
description: In a shower of affectionate prose and poetry, the English department of Columbia Uni versity bade farewell last eve ning to four of its most illus trous members, all scholars of international distinction who were obliged to retire because of age.

title: E.E.C. Unit Meets
description: BRUSSELS, May 6 (Reuters) The Common Market's mone tary committee ended a four hour meeting here today on the dollar crisis without taking any decisions, informed sources said today.

title: Pakistani General Disputes Reports of Casualties
description: The writer of the following dispatch is a member of the first group of foreign newsmen granted permission to enter East Pakistan since the Govern ment expelled correspondents in late March. News articles from both East and West Paki stan are subject to censorship.DACCA, PAKISTAN, May 6 Gen. Tikka Khan, the mili tary governor of East Pakistan, said today that his staff had estimated that 150 persons were killed in Dacca on the night of March 25, when the army moved to reassert control over this province.

title: Advertising:
description: A most unusual thing hap pened at the annual meeting yesterday of Ogilvy & Ma ther International. Someone asked a question, a genuine rarity at annual meetings in this industry.

title: JUDGE DROPS POST AS ADMINISTRATOR
description: State Supreme Court Justice Miles F. McDonald resigned yesterday as administrative judge of the Second Judicial District, saying that he was frustrated by the policy of low bail in the criminal courts and the failure of the police to apprehend fugitives.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE UP FROM '70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended May 1 were both above the volume in the corresponding 1970 week.

title: Marke Place:Little Guy Hurt By Surcharge
description: The latest word from Washington is that the Se curities and Exchange Com mission under its new chair man, William J. Casey, will allow the surcharge of up to $15 to continue on small transactions for at least two more months.

title: Bonnie and Gay Takes Aqueduct Dash
description: Bonnie and Gay made her season's debut in glamorous fashion at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Group Sees Housing Spurt If Rockefeller's Plan Wins
description: A group that represents 500 major builders and owners of buildings in the metropolitan area said yesterday that it would embark on a multibil liondollar housing program in New York City, if Governor Rockefeller's housing proposals are passed by the Legislature.

title: Greenfield Securities Accused in S.E.C. Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that Henry C. Schmidt, doing business as Greenfield Securi ties, was operating as an un registered brokerdealer in vio lation of the Securities Ex change Act of 1934.

title: Federal Reserve Injects Credit Into Bond Market
description: The Federal Reserve injected an extensive amount of credit into the money market yester day to keep it running smooth ly during the international cur rency disturbance and the Treasury's refinancing.

title: U.S. Bids Hanoi Discuss Own Pullout
description: PARIS, May 6The United States said at the Vietnam peace talks today that there could be no negotiations on total withdrawal of American troops unless the withdrawal of North Vietnamese troops was also included.

title: Dr. John Paul, Polio Researcher, Dies
description: NEW HAVEN, May 6Dr. John R. Paul, a leading re searcher in the field of polio myelitis and other diseases, died today at YaleNew Haven Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived on Old Quarry Road in nearby Guilford.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In Europe, after centuries of inces sant wars, a period of tranquillity en sued largely because a socalled Concert of Europe emerged from the Congress of Vienna. In the decades following 1815 many critical situations brought the big five powers of Europe together to maintain the peace while carefully preserving each country's prestige.

title: Wider Gas Supply Is a New Program Of Brooklyn Union
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company is actively pursuing a program aimed at developing new gas supplies, John E. Heyke Jr., chairman, told about 150 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at 195 Mon tague Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was most gratified that The Times recognizes the need for new taxing au thority for the city. Your support is welcome, if a bit belated. However, other statements in your editorial sug gest that you have not yet given suffi cient study to the relevant documents to know why you favor new taxes. Perhaps a brief review of the questions you raise will be of some help in this regard.

title: Young Paid Emotional Tribute At Urban League Dinner Here
description: The late Whitney M. Young Jr. was eulogized last night as a black prince who will be remembered with the lives grown out of his life.

title: Giant U.S. Plows Clear Scrub Along Foe's Route
description: DUCHUE, South Vietnam, May 6The flat, fertile land scape of this former rice paddy district is undergoing one final disfigurement of war. After having been dug up by the enemy for bunkers and tunnels, and, after the bomb ing, defoliation and napalm, the Rome Plowsgiant United States Army buildozersare now cutting through the re maining scrub and abandoned farms to leave the soil bare, gray and lifeless.

title: DETECTIVE TESTIFIES HE NEVER TOOK BRIBE
description: A suspended detective ac cused of receiving a $200a month bribe from a Bronx num bers operator and his wife tes tified yesterday that never in my life have I taken money from these people.

title: 993841 Wins in Jersey
description: VOORHEES TOWNSHIP, N. J., May 6 (AP)The winning num ber in this week's New Jersey lottery, drawn here today, is 993841.

title: Bridge:Aces Defeat American Team In Defense of World Title
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 6 The world champion Aces made a good start here tonight in the defense of their title by crushing the rival American team in a match they seemed likely to lose in the early stages. The international matchpoint margin was 98 to 50, giving the Aces 19 victory points and their opponents one.

title: ABORTION REPEAL TO BE PUT TO VOTE
description: ALBANY, May 6State Sen ate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges pledged today that there would be a vote on a bill repealing the state's abortion law. The pledge followed a dra matic confrontation on the Sen ate floor with the leading pro ponent of repeal.

title: New Dramatists in Fund Drive
description: The New Dramatists, the nonprofit organization that supports and ministers to the needs of developing play wrights, has raised $66,109 during its current campaign for funds.

title: The Talk of Ft. Rucker
description: FORT RUCKER, Ala.  Freda Johnson, a 22yearold bride from Spartanburg, S.C., has been living in the first home of her married life for only four weeks, but every time she calls it home she makes an ironic grimace. That is because she is living in a rented trailer on a bare rectangle of red Alabama dirt, with vistas of row on row of trailers just like hers.

title: ARTHUR J. WEBER
description: Arthur. J. Weber, vice presi dent of Charles Francis Press, Inc., a commercial  printing plant at 461 Eighth Avenue, died yesterday in the Will Rog ers Memorial Hospital in Sara nac Lake, N. Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 930 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Colombo Pleads Not Guilty To Gambling Charge Here
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed head of a Brooklyn crime organization, and 26 others pleaded not guilty yes terday to charges of operating a gambling syndicate that alleg edly grossed $10million a year.

title: OTB Lists 65 Windows For Preakness Betting
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation plans to open its Preakness Special next Wednesday with an initial lineup of 65 windows.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose slight ly higher to 108.9 from 108.6 last week.

title: Notes on People
description: The most admired person in the world, according to a Gallup poll of leaders repre senting 70 nations of the nonCommunist world, is Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.

title: More Producers of Steel Join in Price Increases
description: Major steel producers began yesterday to match price in creases of about 6.25 per cent on important product cate gories, which had been initiated Wednesday by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: 130 Arrested in Antiwar Protest at Federal Building in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 6A crowd of demonstrators estimated at between 2,000 and 4,000 per sons laid siege to the John F. Kennedy Federal Building today in a protest against the Indo china war.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Uncertainty about the effect of the currency crisis in Europe resulted in a highly nervous atmosphere at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Soy bean prices, which had risen sharply the day before, closed higher again in an erratic market.

title: Judge Bids Miss Bacon Reply To Questions on Bank Bombing
description: SEATTLE, May 6Leslie Bacon, held as a material wit ness in the March 1 bombing of the Capitol, was ordered to day to answer questions about the attempted bombing of an East Side bank in New York City last Dec. 4.

title: ChesebroughPond's Is Hopeful
description: ChesebroughPond's, which produces such diverse products as Vaseline jelly, spaghetti sauce and face makeup, told its shareholders yesterday that 1971 would probably be a high ly profitable year for the company.On the adverse side, the Right Rev. Francisco Reus Froylan, Episcopal Bishop of Puerto Rico, criticized the plans of Amax and the Kennecott Copper Corporation to mine copper on the island. He had read a similar protest at Ken necott's meeting on Tuesday.

title: PENTAGON CANCELS TWO MORE VESSELS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The Pentagon scuttled plans today to build two nuclear powered guided missile frigates, bringing to more than $1.3 billion the value of naval ship construction either, dropped or postponed indefinitely in the last week.

title: Big Retail Chains Show Gains in Sales
description: American consumers are slowly increasing their buying of general merchandise, raising the sales level for spring to the best performance for a sea cent in April, but there is

title: LEADERS REFLECT ON BROWNSVILLE
description: Several members of the Brownsville Community Coun cil seemed to have run out of words as they took a moment out for lunch yesterday follow ing an allnight effort to quell disturbances in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: TRIAL OF TAIW ANESE IS CLOSED TO PUBLIC
description: Reporters and spectators were barred yesterday from the criminal trial of a Taiwanese accused of attempting to mur der the vice premier of Nation alist China here last year.

title: NO. 125 IS CUTOFF FR DRAFT IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  The Selective Service System announced today that men with lottery numbers over 125 would not be drafted through June.

title: Firemen Say They'll Balk Without Protection in Riots
description: Union leaders said yesterday that the city's 14,100 firemen would no longer fight fires in riot areas unless they received adequate police protection.

title: FRENCH ACADEMY LISTS AMERICAN
description: PARIS, May 6  For the first time in its history, the French Academy today received the candidacy of an American. He is Julien Green, the novelist. There is every likelihood he will be coopted into the acad emy when his name comes up in an election a month from now to fill the seat vacated by the late Francois Mauriac.

title: Case, Citing Gains in Detection, Suggests Full Test Ban Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  Senator Clifford P. Case said today that scientists had made so much progress in distinguish ing earthquakes from under ground atomic explosions that it should now be possible for the United States to enter into a treaty prohibiting all nuclear tests.

title: State Senate Votes to Ease Adoptions
description: ALBANY, May 6The State Senate passed a bill today that would help insure the right of a couple to retain custody of a child placed with them for adoption in the event the na tural mother changed her mind.

title: ZIOBRO TRIUMPHS IN GOLF PLAYOFF
description: DENVILLE, N. J., May 6  Billy Ziobro, a 22yearold as sistant pro at Tammy Brook, playing in his first professional event, won the $26,000 Dodge open tournament today, beating Babe Lichardus of Shackamaxon on the first hole of a sudden death playoff.

title: 12 Killed in Arizona Crash Of Apache Airlines Plane
description: COOLIDGE, Ariz., May 6 (UPI)An Apache Airlines plane crashed into a cotton field five miles southwest of here today, killing all 12 persons aboard.

title: Snead Misses Deadline For National Open Golf
description: Sam Snead, who has en tered every United States Open golf tournament since 1937, apparently missed the deadline this year and failed to file his entry for the only major tournament he has never won.

title: Two Mars Spacecraft Are SunPowered Electronic Laboratories
description: The twin mission to Mars is scheduled to be carried out by two sunpowered elec tronic laboratories like the one shown at the top left above.

title: POLAND SENTENCES U.S. CITIZEN AS SPY
description: WARSAW, May 6 (Reuters) Adam Mueller, a Polishborn engineer from Dayton, Ohio, to day was sentenced to five years in jail by a military court for giving industrial and military secrets to the West almost 13 years ago.

title: Protest In Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, May 6 (AP) Antiwar protesters, clapping hands and chanting We Want Peace Now, paraded in a cir cle at the entrance to the Fed eral Building in downtown Buf falo today.

title: Loan Approval Held Likely
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Reu ters)Senate Democratic lead er Mike Mansfield said today the proposed Governmentloan guarantee for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is likely to win Congressional approval but after some delay.

title: Consolidated Gas in Deal
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company announced yes terday the signing of a letter of intent to purchase additional liquefied natural gas (LNG) from El Paso Algeria Corpora tion for delivery around 1977. The new contract calls for pur chase of LNG equivalent to approximately 250million cu bic feet of natural gas a day. El Paso Algeria is a subsidiary of the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

title: CURTISSWRIGHT EXPECTS A PROFIT
description: T. R. Berner, chairman and president of the CurtissWright Corporation, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Delaware, that 1971 does not look like a good year for the company because of con ditions of the aerospace indus try and business in general.

title: CHINESE FLIES HOME AFTER PARIS INCIDENT
description: PARIS, May 7The case of the Chinese physician closed inconclusively today with his departure for Canton.

title: RABBI CHAIM ROSEN
description: Rabbi Chaim Rosen, vice president, of the Union of Or thodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, died yes terday of a heart attack in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rocka way, Queens. He was in his 60's and lived at 3005 Besse mund Avenue, Far Rockaway.

title: JAMES A. WILLIAMS OF TIMES NEWS UNIT
description: James A. Williams, who re tired from The New York Times News Service in March, 1970, died yesterday. He was 71 years old and lived at 1583 Yates Avenue, the Bronx.

title: 2 Hospital Guards At Maffeawan Held In Death of Patient
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y:, May 7  Two guards at the Mat teawan State Hospital were arrested today on indictments handed up by a Dutchess County grand jury charging them with manslaughter in the death of a patient.

title: Poor in Nation Rise by 5%, Reversing 10Year Trend
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The number of the poor in the na tion increased sharply last year, reversing a 10year trend, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Mariner 8 to Be Launched Toward Mars Orbit Tonight
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 7The first of two spacecraft designed to orbit Mars was pronounced ready today for launching tomorrow night.

title: Phone Units Were Picketed
description: A technician's objection to cleaning a supervisor's desk re sulted yesterday in a work stoppage by about 1,400 em ployes in several longlines de partment operating, centers of the American Telephone & Tele graph Company. Picket lines went up here and in West chester County, affecting the big overseas operating center in White Plains. Circuits were being kept open by supervisory personnel, the company said.

title: Sean E. Indian, $5.40, Wins As Calder Draws 5,961
description: MIAMI, May. 7 (AP)H. M. Schwartz's Sean E. Indian took the lead at the top of the stretch and went on to score a 1length victory today at Calder Race Course.

title: OHIO POWER FILES FOR HIGHER RATES
description: The Ohio Power Company filed yesterday with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio for higher rates that would in crease annual revenues by an estimated $24million.

title: GOVERNOR'S BILL ON RENT SNAGGED
description: ALBANY, May 7  Gover nor Rockefeller's controversial proposal to end rent control of 1.3 million appartments in New York City as they are vacated hit a snag today when three Republican Senators expressed opposition to it and four others were reported to be undecided.

title: 5 STEEL COMPANIES FOLLOW PRICE RISES
description: Price increases on important categories of steel products continued to spread quickly through the industry yesterday. The action, an average advance of 6.25 per cent for hotrolled and coldrolled sheet and strip, was initiated Wednesday by the United States Steel Corpo ration.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO GIVE ISRAEL ASSURANCE ON SUEZ PULLBACK
description: TEL AVIV, May 7  The United States and Israel found common ground today on crucial issues involved in negotiating a reopening of the Suez Canal, according to American and Israeli diplomats.

title: State Senate Votes to Cut Penalties for Marijuana
description: ALBANY, May 7A bill that sharply reduces the penalties for possession and sale of marijuana was passed over whelmingly by the Senate, here today.

title: March Retail Sales Rose 2% for Gain 4th Month in a Row
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  The Commerce De partment said today that re tail sales increased in March for the fourth consecutive month. A Nixon Administra tion official hailed the rise as a sign that consumers are gaining confidence in the economy and loosening their purse strings.

title: AMEX RALLY FAILS TO ERASE LOSSES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day in slower trading even though an afternoon recovery wiped out many of the earlier losses.

title: U.S. Approves Acquisition By Northwest Industries
description: Merger News

title: CHARLES B. TEDESCO
description: STANFORD, Conn., May 7 Charles B. Tedesco, assistant clerk of the Stamford Superior Court, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 956 Hope Street.

title: 100% Memorex Margin Set
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that it will impose 100 per cent mar gin requirements on all deal ings in the Memorex Corpora tion common stock, effective Monday. Memorex closed yes terday at 59  up .

title: Newark Paper Raises Price
description: NEWARK, May 7 (UPI)The Evening News announced today that its newsstand price would be 15 cents effectively Monday. The News said the raise from 10 cents was necessitated by increased production costs. There will be no increase in the homedelivery price.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: Welfare. Just mention the word in New York City and you likely trigger a heated discussion. No one defends the System.
