Those who believe in freedom and personal responsibility argue for a reduction of the fiscal and social burdens placed so heavily on our once great city. The paternalists disagree. They begin with a false premise and construct sand castles atop it.

title: Concert in Drag By Alice Cooper, A Boy and Band
description: Alice Cooper, a boy, played at Town Hall Thursday night with his rock group, which is also called Alice Cooper.

title: Pakistani Press Is Warned On Irresponsible Reports
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 7 The military Government of President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan warned the news papers today not to jeopardize efforts to bring the country back to normalcy by publishing irresponsible reports.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JOBLESS LEVEL UP SLIGHTLY IN APRIL; NEGRO RATE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The nation's unemployment rate edged up slightly in April but, over all, the job situation re mained essentially un changed, the Labor Depart ment reported today..

title: BERIO INSPIRES BALLET RAMBERT
description: LONDON, May 7For the opening of Ballet Rambert's London season at the Cochrane Theater last night, Norman Morrice produced a work that is original in both form and content.

title: Learning to Be Free
description: During the academic year, I visit a college campus every ten days or so as a guest lecturer and listener. Two student preoccupations invariably be come the core of our dialogues: What am I here for? How does here connect with what I'm going to be doing out there?

title: JOHN P. GRANATO JR.
description: MADISON, N.J., May 7  John P. Granato Jr., postmaster here since 1967, died yesterday of a heart attack in his office. He was 56 years old and lived at 45 Park Avenue.

title: FLOATING MARK SEEN AS TROUBLING SWISS
description: GENEVA, May 7The Swiss Government would be placed in a quandary if the value of the West German mark was left to the determination of the normal play of the money mar kets, Swiss banking sources said today.

title: Patricia A. McKenna Bride of James Egan
description: WESTBURY, L. I. May 7 Miss Patricia Ann McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph McKenna of Carle Place, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. James Garland Egan, U. S. A. F., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Bur roughs Egan of West Islip.

title: Robbers Get a Chicken Feed
description: Three gunmen attempted to rob a supermarket employe car rying a bag containing the store's payroll today but in the confusion, grabbed another bag insteadand escaped with six ovenready chickens. The inci dent occurred shortly before 7 P.M. near the intersection of Tremont and Prospect Avenues in the Bronx. The victim was Augustino Ortiz, an assistant manager of a nearby Daitch Shopwell supermarket. The three chicken thieves fled in a a car.

title: Peoria Ill.: Jobs Oasis in a Period of Recession
description: PEORIA, IllThis medium size, moderately affluent Mid west city, the symbol of Main Street normality in a thousand wornout jokes, underwent a very atypical economic experi ence last yeardeclining un employment.

title: BANK RATE IS CUT TO 5.6% BY JAPAN
description: TOKYO, May 7Japan an nounced today that she would lower her official discount rate by onequarter of 1 percentage point, to 5.5 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: Judith A. Nolte, Editor, Married To R. H. Reimer
description: DOVER PLAINS, N. Y., May 7  Miss Judith Ann Nolte, editor in chief of Motherstobe/American Baby magazine in New York, was married here this evening to Randers Halyard Heimer, a vice president of Basford, Inc., a division of Coordi nated Communications, Inc., New York advertising agency.

title: Doctors, Husband and Wife, Shot to Death in Georgia
description: MARIETTA, Ga., May 7 (UPI) Bandits who may have been looking for drugs broke into the fashionable home of a hus band and wife doctor team today and beat and shot them to death.

title: Japan Will Press the Swordfish Issue
description: TOKYO, May 7 Japan, which once exported about 7,000 tons of swordfish a year to the United States, will try to persuade the United States that the Federal Food and Drug Administration's warning against eating swordfish is un founded.

title: It's Just in Time for Mother's Day...
description: The American Mothers Com mittee judges were ago nized and prayerful. Two refused ever to serve again because, as the outgoing president, Mrs. Dorothy Lewis put it, the distress of having to eliminate all those nice mothers is a real and terrible burden.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS TRADING EASES
description: Stock prices moved slightly lower yesterday, as most in vestors remained stoic in the face of the latest international currency crisis.

title: Mark and Swiss Franc Stronger in Active Trading
description: LONDON, May 7  Amid market expectations of floating rates on Monday, the West German mark and the Swiss franc strengthened further against the dollar today in ac tive foreignexchange trading.

title: Marietta Eight Fails to Qualify in Dad Vail Regatta for First Time in 12 Years
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7The chief topic along Boathouse Row on the Schuylkill today was the failure of Marietta to qualify its varsity eight in the opening phase of the twoday Dad Vail Regatta.

title: Still Too Many Jobless
description: The most poignant reflection of the continued slug gishness of the economy comes in the monthly report on national unemployment. The April jobless rate of 6.1 per cent translates into 4.7 million persons looking for work they cannot find. To be told by Administration economists that unemployment statistics always respond slowly to an economic upturn is no comfort to these hapless Americans, especially when prices keep edging up and the vigor of the upturn is far from clear.

title: COLONELS SUBDUE STARS BY 116110
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7 (AP)  The Kentucky Colonels held off a late rally by the Utah Stars tonight and posted a 116110 victory in the third game of the American Basket ball Association 4of7game series for the championship. Utah won the first two games.

title: Second Simon Auction Brings $253,765 at the ParkeBernet
description: The golden touch of Norton Simon, the Los Angeles indus trialist who is liquidating part of his huge art collection at auction, was evident again yes terday as more of his holdings on the block brought $253,765, about $70,000 over estimate.

title: More Than a Break in the Office Routine
description: I think I messed it up, said Douglas Fileppo, a freshman at Baruch College of the City University of New York, as he handed over an algebra problem to Dr. S. Thomas Clark the other day.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE, The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profiles of today's newsmakers in a loose leaf edition. Write: The New York Times Library Services, Box FP480, 220 West 13d Street. New York, N.Y. 10036. Advt.

title: YoYo Ma, Cellist, Now 16, Performs An Enviable Recital
description: YoYo Ma is said to have been a prodigy when he was a child, and although he is grow ing older now  he is all of 16  one can well believe it. The cello recital he gave at Carne gie Recital Hall Thursday night was of a quality to make many an older man green with envy.

title: NEW ISSUES SHOW STRONG ADVANCE
description: The newissues market scored another strong advance this week although the number of companies going public de clined.

title: BENVENUTI READY FOR IIIONZON FIGHT
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 7Nino Benvenuti took a haircut last night. Unlike Sam son, it is intended to make him stronger.

title: Richard H. Valentine, Head Of Warren Woolen Firm
description: STAFFORD Springs, Conn., May 7Richard H. Valentine, chairman of the board of the Warren Woolen Company, died yesterday at the age of 83.

title: Nonpolluting Cars Will Require More Gasoline, Hearing Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Au tomobiles will use more gaso line and be somewhat harder to drive when nonpolluting ma chines are introduced, witness es before a hearing of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I heartily endorse the goal of using higher education as the tool to break the cycle of poverty. However, I be lieve that free tuition, suggested by four college presidents, letter April 21, is not the mechanism necessary, or even desirable, to achieve this.If tuition is charged those who can afford it, rebates to the poor could be larger than merely tuition. That is, not only tuition but also part of the forgone earnings could be de frayed for those who are needy. These scholarships should be automatic ac cording to need. Moreover, as an incentive, bonuses might be attached, based on achievement and standing while in high school and subsequent progress in college.

title: Cuevas Displays His Mastery of Line
description: The art of the 20th cen tury in Mexico has primarily been an art of propaganda, an art that used the image as a kind of manifesto or platform for political mes sages. The pictorial propa ganda of Oroszco, Rivera and Siqueiros were like giant tabloids with militant scare heads about the abject human condition. To get across their ideas with one visual punch, the artists used the fresco, for they had to make their pictures big and noticeable, they made their forms steno graphic and they dressed them up in brilliant eye catching colors. Finally, when their message lost its impact, their art lost its muscle.

title: Greeks Here Are at Odds Over Parade
description: Anyone who knows the history of the Greeks, said George J. Pyle, president of the Federation of American Helenic Societies of Greater New York, knows they live by argumentand they im prove by argument.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 7Martin Wood hams is a 13yearold boy who lives in Croydon, a modest London suburb. His father drives a van. His mother works as a cleaning woman in Croy don Hospital, cleaning up the wards and bathrooms.

title: Brownsville Back to Normal Despair
description: The Brownsville section of Brooklyn, wracked by poverty for years and by two days of streets disorders this week, just about returned to its normal state yesterday.

title: CAREY URGES A RISE IN AID TO THE POOR
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that the Nixon Administration's welfarere form legislation should be changed drastically.

title: The Look Is Tailored, but Not Stodgy
description: Young men in their twen ties or thirties who've been trained as coat and suit de signers are giving a new tone to Seventh Avenue as the pace of fall openings quick ens. They think of them selves as craftsmen rather than mad geniuses. They in vite their wives and children to their showings. They try to make clothes for ordinary people.

title: Record Savings Inflow
description: Savings banks in New York State had a record net inflow of deposits of $396million during April, the Savings Banks Association of New York State announced yesterday. This com pared with a net deposit out flow of $196million in April 1970.

title: Pompidou Flies at 1,315 M.P.H.
description: TOULOUSE, France; May 7 President Pompidou, in an explicit challenge to critics of the FrenchBritish supersonic aircraft venture, flew at twice the speed of sound today in a Concorde. With the President aboard, the Concorde 001 flew at 1,315 miles an hour for 17 minutes. On his arrival at this birth place of the Concorde, Mr. Pompidou told its builders that France had taken a gamble in constructing the plane and would go through with it. The long, slender white craft, looking like a praying mantis with a droop ing nose, took off with Presi dent Pompidou from Le Bour get Airport and climbed in 10 minutes to an altitude of 32,800 feet. Passing over Le Havre at about 700 miles an hour, it soared above the ocean to avoid a sonic boom over the mainland.

title: West Seeks Practical Steps To Improve Berlin's Status
description: BERLIN, May 7The West ern Allies sought to break the deadlock in the fourpower negotiations on West Berlin today by engaging the Russians in discussion of practical im provements for this isolated city, leaving controversial is sues of status aside.

title: Scratch Closing Tonight
description: Scratch, the play by Archi bald MacLeish, suggested by Stephen Vincent Benet's The Devil and Daniel Webster, will close after tonight's perform ance, the fourth, at the St. James Theater. The play was presented by Stuart Ostrow and directed by Peter H. Hunt.

title: A Soviet Military Training Mission Is Reported to Arrive in Ceylon
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 7 Wellplaced unofficial sources reported the arrival here today of a Soviet military training mission and a shipment of East German police equipment.

title: TEXTILE MEN TOLD TO ACT ON QUALITY
description: The great expectations in the knittedfabric field will never be realized if the mills and cut ters do not act quickly in mat ters of production and quality, two executives in the textile in dustry warned yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting in Ceylon Eases, but No End Is in Sight
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 7  Behind a barbed wire fence, hundreds of rebels who sur rendered this week moved restlessly to and fro.

title: Tombs Library Has Lots of Books but Little to Read
description: If the library at the Man hattan House of Detention were open, which it is not, the 1,230 inmates there could read Dining Out in Any Language.

title: N.B.A. and A.B.A. Will Seek Merger
description: A peace treaty that may mark only the beginning of the real war was arrived at yes terday by the National and American Basketball Associa tions when they decided to pro ceed with seeking Congres sional approval of their project ed merger.

title: F.D.A. Warns of Poisoning From Imported Candy Beads
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)  The Food and Drug Admin istration warned today that a nationally distributed brand of candy beads, linked to 15 cases of child poisoning, contains high levels of toxic cadmium.

title: East Asians Now Stressing Rural Development
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 5A new realism pervades the economicdevelopment plans, of many Southeast Asian coun tries, according to participants in a ministerial development conference here.

title: San Marino Will Open Relations With Peking
description: SAN MARINO, May 7 (UPI) San Marino, the world's smallest republic, announced Friday night it was establish ing diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.

title: Miss Bacon's Case Delayed
description: SEATTLE, May 7The Fed eral grand jury for this district was recessed today until next Wednesday, as Miss Bacon's lawyers tied up the Govern ment's investigation with a se ries of legal moves.

title: Charles Kingsley Is Dead at 78; A Retired Grumman Executive
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., May 7 Charles Kingsley, retired vice president and general counsel of the Grumman Aircraft Engi neering Corporation, died yes terday at his home, 81 Davis Road, Port Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: Caso Proposes a Coalition of 12 Suburban Counties
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 7 Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso has proposed a coalition of 12 New York coun ties with large suburban pop ulations to obtain appropriate recognition and cooperation from Federal and state authori ties.

title: State Leaders Invited to See Genocide in Brownsville Area
description: The principal antipoverty or ganization in Brownsville in vited Governor Rockefeller and the entire State Legislature yes erday to come to the decaying, impoverished area of Brooklyn to see firsthand the geno cide it said was foretold by proposed state budget cuts. The area has been racked by dis orders this week.

title: COURT ORDERS HIRING OF A CROSSING GUARD
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice has ordered the Police De partment to hire as a school crossing guard a woman it had earlier rejected as lacking good character.

title: HERMAN JAFFE, 77; PRINTED ART STAMPS
description: Herman Jaffe, a printer and publisher who reproduced mas terpieces from the Metropolitan Museum of Art on small poster stamps and also printed, postage stamps for Liberia, died Thurs day of a heart ailment in St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. His age was 77. He lived at 9312 68th Avenue, For est Hills, Queens.

title: Las Vegas Busing Opposed
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 7 (Reuters)  Fifteen thousand students stayed out of Las Vegas metropolitan area sdhools today, largely to protest an integration plan by which stu dents would he bused to achieve racial balance in the 61,400pupil school system.

title: Mobil and a Union File Suits as Strike Ends Its First Week
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Petroleum Trades Employes Association filed suits against each other yesterday as the gasoline delivery strike against six major companies by two un ions completed its first week.

title: U.S. Removes Curbs on the Use Of Dollars in Trade With China
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The United States formally cleared the way today for the resump tion of direct trade with China for the first time in 21 years.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Walking up the steps of the visiting team dugout, Astrud Gilberto, who recorded The Girl From Ipanema, seemed momentarily stunned by the sudden green dazzle of the Yankee Stadium outfield grass. She paused on the top step, blinking at the lights blazing out of a smoky gray twilight. Her American husband murmured, You ever hear of Babe Ruth? and when she looked at him vacantly he shrugged and smiled and led her out onto the field where the New York Cosmos awaited her ceremonial kick off to open their first home season.

title: Bill Specifying Teachers' Hours Recalled as Educators Protest
description: ALBANY, May 7  Strong Protests by leading educators led today to the recall from Governor Rockefeller's desk of a bill approved by the Legis lature specifying the minimum number of hours college and university teachers should spend in the classroom each week.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHITE TERROR: The Ku Klux Klan Conspiracy and Southern Reconstruction. By Allen W. Trelease. 557 pages. Harper & Row. $15.

title: Foes of Chemical Spraying By State Get Court Order
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 7 (AP) State Supreme Court Justice Frank S. McCullough of West chester County has signed a showcause order, returnable next Thursday, in a suit brought by four individuals and the Scarsdale Audubon Society seeking to bar state spraying'of an insecticide from the air.

title: AL CAPP IS ACCUSED OF MORALS OFFENSE
description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis., May 7 (AP)  District Attorney Law rence W. Durning said today that a warrant charging Al Capp, the cartoonist, with a morals offense against a 20 yearold Eau Claire State Uni versity coed had been issued by County Judge Thomas H. Berland.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DUKE ELLINGTON WILL TOUR SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 7Duke El lington and his orchestra will visit five Soviet cities this fall as part of the SovietAmerican cultural exchange agreement, the United States Embassy an nounced today.

title: Blast Hits Police Station
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 7 (AP)A bomb explosion dam aged a building housing the police station in this university town early today. The blast followed two nights of dem lonstrations but the authorities would not link the incidents.

title: West German Leaders Confer on the Monetary Crisis
description: BONN, May 7  The West German Cabinet today drew up a whole array of international monetary controls and stiff domestic reforms to put to the Common Market ministers sum moned to an emergency meet ing in Brussels tomorrow.

title: Margaret A. Smith, Poet, Composer and Missionary
description: MADISON, May 7Mrs. Margaret Armstrong Smith, a former missionary in the Phil ippines and a poet and com poser, died today of cancer. She was 73 years old and lived at 675 Woodland Avenue.

title: Valachi Buried Upstate
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 7 (AP) The body of Joseph Valachi, a convicted murderer who described underworld ac tivities before a Senate subcom mittee, has been buried in near by Lewiston, it was disclosed today. A spokesman for the Gate of Heaven Cemetery said Valachi was buried there April 7. He died four days earlier in the La Tuna Federal Correctional Institution in El Paso, and the body was claimed by a person whom the prison officials re fused to identify.

title: Ormandy to Have Surgery
description: Eugene Ormandy, music di rector of the Philadelphia Or chestra, said yesterday that he would undergo hip surgery this summer and would have to can cel appearances in Philadelphia, Chicago and Saratoga, N. Y. The 71yearold conductor post poned the surgery, on a hip injured when he was in his teens, last summer. William Steinberg, conductor of the Boston and Pittsburgh Sym phonies, will fill in for him Aug. 4 at the opening of the Saratoga Performing Arts Cen ter.

title: 70 SITES CONSIDERED TO LAUNCH SHUTTLE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said to day that more than 70 loca tions in 19 states were being studied as possible sites for assembling, testing and launch ing the proposed space shuttle vehicle.

title: Coast of East Pakistan Is Lashed by Cyclone
description: NEW DELHI, Saturday, May 8 (Reuters)A cyclone lashed the coast of East Pakistan early today and swept northeast across the country, the Pakistan radio reported.

title: Who Needs Poets?
description: The poet's trade, the writer's trade, Is a strange one. Chesterton said: Only one thing is needful  every thing. To a writer this everything is more than an encompassing word; it is literal. It stands for the chief, for the essential, human experiences. For example, a writer needs loneliness, and he gets his share of it. He needs love, and he gets shared and also unshared love. He needs friendship. In fact, he needs the universe. To be a writer is, in a sense, to be a daydreamerto be living a kind of double life.

title: MSGR. BRADY DIES; LED BRONX CHURCH
description: Msgr. Charles A. Brady, pastor of Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church, the Bronx, since 1959, died Thursday in Misericordia Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Armstrong Leaves Hospital
description: Louis Armstrong was dis charged from Beth Israel Hos pital yesterday. The 70year old jazz trumpeter returned to his home in Queens after eight weeks treatment for a heart condition. He was admitted to the hospital and placed in the intensive care unit March 15. His condition at one time was so serious that a tracheotomy had to be performed to case his breathing.

title: 14 Pianists Gain Semifinals In Leventritt Competition
description: Fourteen pianists from seven countries qualified for the semi finals in the 27th Leventritt International Competition, now going on here.

title: Cambodia Shelves Plan for Closer Taiwan Relations
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 6 Cambodia has quietly shelved consideration of a proposal by Nationalist China that the two countries exchange embassies and has delayed sending a per manent diplomatic mission to Taipei.

title: Jersey Nun, Jailed For Balking Jury, Free After a Night
description: JERSEY CITY, May 7 (AP) A Roman Catholic nun was released today after spending a night in jail because she re fused on religious grounds to answer a grand jury's ques tions about a murder.

title: THEKLA HOLLINGSWORTH
description: Thekla Hollingsworth, a com poser and poet, died on Thurs day in Fordham Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 2914 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.

title: 7 AWARDS ARE GIVEN IN JOURNALISM HERE
description: Seven awards for excellence in print, broadcast and photo graphic Journalism have been made by the Deadline Club, the New York chapter of Sigma Delta Chi.

title: Most of Island Off Georgia To Be National Seashore
description: CUMBERLAND ISLAND, Ga. After years of being coveted as a site for resort housing, a rocketlaunching base or a state park, most of this wild, lush island with its 18 miles of flat, hard beach, is now assured of becoming the country's ninth Federally operated public seashore.

title: MARIE KATZ LAZARE, JEWISH LEADER, 82
description: Mrs. Marie Katz Lazare, long a leader in Jewish educational activities, died Thursday at her home at the age of 82. She was the wife of Max Lazare, a re tired textile manufacturer, and lived at 2].1 Central Park West. Mrs. Lazare had served for many years as president of Iv riah, the Women's Division of the Jewish Education Associa tion.

title: Franklin Simon Plans DressesOnly Chain
description: The Franklin Simon Com pany, the New Yorkbased readytowear apparel chain, will shortly open another chain of minisize stores, sell ing dresses exclusively in leading shopping centers.

title: COODY, WITH 135, LEADS BY 2 SHOTS
description: DALLAS, May 7 Charles Coody, the Masters champion, finding his putting touch as keen in Texas as it was in eorgia, gained the lead with a 36hole aggregate of 135 today in the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: U.S. Says Planes Destroy Antiaircraft Guns in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 8 (AP)  Two American fighterbombers de stroyed three antiaircraft guns in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command re ported.

title: Repression on Capitol Hill
description: The arrest of more than a thousand persons on the steps of the Capitol on Wednesday brought the week's antiwar protests to an ominous climax. In a crass display of arbitrary power, the constitutional rights of these citizens were ignored as they were hauled off to a makeshift detention center. It was a spectacle of lawless ness and repression hardly to be expected in a republic of free men.

title: Roundup: Morgan Is Key As Astros Rout Phils, 81
description: Whatever the Houston As tros pay Joe Morgan to play second base, he earned it last night. The 5foot7inch, 150pound Morgan, who natu rally is nicknamed Little Joe, rapped out four hits, scored three runs, drove in two and stole two bases as the Astros pounded out 13 hits in routing Jim Bunning and the Phillies, 81.

title: INQUIRY IS THWARTED BY EXG.I.'S SILENCE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Army and a former sergeant have reached an impasse over whether he will divulge more information about an alleged killing of about 30 Vietnamese civilians by American soldiers in April, 1969.

title: How to Crush a Tin Can
description: Like most Americans, I am quite content to sit idly by while young people tell their President the way it is, the Pentagon tells the people of Asia the way it is, and the television set tells my wife the way it is. Every body today knows everything better than everybody else.

title: U.S. PENTAGON GETS EMMY AWARD
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, Selling of the Pentagon, won an Emmy award last night for out standing achievement in news documentary programing.

title: Good Behaving Strong Choice in Withers Today
description: The Withers Stakes, one of the oldest thoroughbred races on the continent, will have its 96th running today when 10 compete in the onemile event at Aqueduct.

title: CEAUSESCU FAVORS COMECON EXPANSION
description: VIENNA, May 7President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today called for the expansion of Comecon, the East European economic community, to other countries, socialist and non socialist. He also underscored Rumanian interest in intensify ing economic relations with capitalist countries on the basis of mutual advantage, the of ficial Rumanian press agency reported.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: Evening up holdings for the weekend sent most commodities futures prices down yesterday in desultory trading.

title: JULIA LOUISE OWENS
description: BRIDEPORT, Conn., May 7 Julia Louise Owens, a retired Brooklyn history teacher, died yesterday at her home, 3030 Park Avenue, at the age of 87.

title: Art: Nevelson's 7th Decade Garden
description: Louise Nevelson's new ex hibition, which opens today at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, proves once again that the woman sim ply cannot be trusted. For several years now, from show to show, she has im plicitly capped off her ca reer with a final demonstra tion of her powers of inven tion, but each following year she comes up with some thing new. This refusal to set tle into a rut is very wear ing for us art reporters.

title: Heroin Raids in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 7 (AP) Federal agents announced to day the arrest of four persons in raids on what was described as the largest heroin ring ever found in the state. Dean Paulus chief of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, said the arrests ended months of investi gation that netted $5,000 to $10,000 worth of drugs.

title: Bridge: French Emerge as Factor In World Play in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 7 The French team served no tice today that it would be a strong title contender in the 1971 world championships here by scoring a crushing victory over the Aces.

title: Money Abroad Is a Corporate Crisis Here
description: George C. Sheinberg, the 36yearold treasurer of the Bulova Watch Company, shook his head in wonder ment and sagged back in his swivel chair. On his desk were scribbled notations of foreigncurrency fluctuations and remnants of the lunches he had eaten at his desk.

title: ACCUSED DETECTIVE SAYS HE GOT THREAT
description: Ramon Rodriguiz, a sus pended Bronx detective accused of receiving a $200amonth bribe, testified yesterday that one of the major witnesses against him had threatened him with revenge.

title: Degrading the Courts
description: By making an end run around the city's principal bar association in his two new appointments to the Court Claims, Governor Rockefeller has failed to live up to his pledge that proposed judges would be investigated by their peers for qualifications. This is a dangerous mis step toward more politicizing of the judiciary.

title: 2,000 AT MARYLAND U. DISPERSED BY GUARD
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 7 (UPI)  Acting under orders from Gov. Marvin Mandel, Na tional Guard troops using tear gas swept the University of Maryland campus today to rout 2,000 antiwar demonstrators who attempted to disrupt classes and tossed a tear gas canister into a cyclotron. A 9 P.M. curfew was imposed.

title: Examiners Give Data on School Tests
description: The Board of Examiners, winch is under attack by crit ics who say it should be abol ished, released data yesterday that it contends demonstrate that its tests are not biased against blacks or Puerto Ric ans.

title: EURODOLLAR REIN SOUGHT BY BONN
description: BONN, May 7The European Economic Community was faced today with a demand by the Bonn Government to take ef fective joint action to restrict the use of dollars in Europe.

title: PUBLIC IS SKITTISH AT U.S.REFUNDING
description: The Treasury's effort this week to refinance a portion of the national debt fizzled, the Government's debt managers disclosed yesterday.

title: MRS. JUSTIN STURM, NOVELIST'S WIDOW
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 7 Mrs. Katherine McCormick Sturm, widow of Justin Sturm, playwright, novelist and sculp tor, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. She was 71 years old and had been a resident here since 1927.

title: The Talk of Peking
description: PEKING, May 1For for eigners Peking is still a tense and touchy place to live, though large areas of the capital long closed to them are in bounds again.

title: Sid Abel Is Appointed Sf. Louis Blues Coach
description: ST. LOUIS, May 7 (UPI) Sid Abel, affiliated with the Detroit Red Wings for more than 30 years as player, coach and general manager, was named coach of the St. Louis Blues today, replacing Scotty Bowman, who resigned one week ago.

title: 25th Anniversary Ball Aids Runyon Fund
description: Sometimes you just can't win. Take, for example, the case of Mrs. Bunty Lawrence, chairman of last night's 25th anniversary ball of the Da mon Runyon Memorial Fund for Cancer Research.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ubleis of Austria Increases World Sulky Drivers Lead
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 7 (AP)Adolf Ubleis of Austria capitalized on tonight's three Harness Tracks of Amer ica world driving championship races at Saratoga Raceway, winning all three to extend his lead in the touring series' point totals.

title: May Day in Peking: Relaxed Celebrations End With Traditional Fireworks
MIDDAY PROGRAMS BY THOMASANSELMO
description: In an unusual midday oasis, the Cabaret Theater at St. Peter's Gate, 132 East 54th Street, Andy ThomasAnselmo, a singer who is normally heard after dark in such clubs as the Copacabana here or the Cre scendo in Hollywood, is pre senting two halfhour programs of songs Monday through Fri day at 12:15 P.M. and 1:15 P.M.

title: Soviet Says Census Shows Assimilation of Jews
description: MOSCOW, May 7  Two Soviet demographers said to day that a decline in the num ber of Jews reported in last year's census reflected a proc ess of assimilation.

title: Abbott Lab Charged With the Mislabeling Of a Hepatitis Drug
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Ab bott Laboratories, Inc., of Chi cago, two of its officers, and a subsidiary in California were charged today by the Justice Department with mislabeling product used in hepatitis de tection and distributing it in interstate commerce without a license.

title: COURT MOVE SEEN ON OTB IMPASSE
description: Kent Brown, chairman of the State Offtrack PariMutuel Bet ting Commission, said yester day he would go to court if necessary to prevent anybody from shutting down offtrack operations in New York City.

title: Connally Says U.S. Plans No Shift in Money Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said today it was the view of the United States that maintenance of cur rent parities could provide basis for reopening Me markets in various European coun tries.

title: For Mother's Day
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y.Mother's Day, 1971, marks the third anniversary of our son's death in Vietnam. It also marks the third anniversary of the Paris peace talks. Once again we moth ers cry Peace, but there is no peace.

title: Seaver Defeats Gibson 2d Time
description: The New York Mets scored two runs in the eighth inning last night to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3.1, and defeat Bob Gibson for the second time in 12 dayswhich is nice work if you can get it.

title: 5 in Bomb Plot Here Sentenced; 3 Get Maximum 4Year Terms
description: Five of six persons who pleaded guilty to a conspiracy to dynamite or firebomb sev eral buildings in the city were sentenced to prison yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Harold Birns.

title: GUATEMALA GAINS IN WAR ON REBELS
description: GUATEMALA CITY, May 4 Almost six months after im posing a state of siege and suspending most constitutional rights, the Government of Pres ident Carlos Arana Osorio ap pears to be making headway in its battle against Guate mala's leftwing guerrillas.

title: Snead Definitely Out
description: Sammy Snead will not be able to play in next month's United States Open despite the fact that he said he had not yet received an application for the championship, Eddie Miller, ex ecutive assistant of the United States Golf Association, said yesterday. The deadline for en tries was reached Wednesday.

title: Diversion of Taxes Charged
description: A 34count criminal informa tion was filed in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday charg ing that the president of a heat ing and airconditioning busi ness in Queens, Samuel Schlos berg, 65 years old, had failed to send to the Government $314, 160 in income taxes withheld from his empoyes. I convicted, he could be sentenced to a one year jail term and a $5,000 fine on each count.

title: Coriolanus Proves An Incoherent Tale In London Version
description: LONDON, May 8  Since Christopher Plummer dropped out of its cast, rumors of re hersal conflict have dogged the National Theater's singularly incoherent production of Co riolanus.

title: 10 IN HOUSE OPEN AN ANTIWAR TOUR
description: CLEVELAND, May 7Presi dent Nixon never had a plan to end the Vietnam war and still does not, Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Demo crat of the Bronx, said here today as he and nine other House members began a barn storming effore in behalf of peace efforts.

title: Little Decline Forecast
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 A group of economists who work for some of the nation's largest corporations predict that unemployment will drop very little in the near future and will he around 5.5 per cent at the end of this year.

title: Judge at Seale Trial Bars Visit At Night to Offices of Panthers
description: NEW HAVEN, May 7The jury in the case against Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins was barred today from making a nighttime visit to the area of the apartment where Mr. Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party, is alleged to have given the order to kill Alex Rackley.

title: Knicks Deal Russell for Warriors' Lucas
description: The New York Knickerbock ers, who were dethroned as champions of the National Bas ketball Association last month after a oneyear reign, traded Cazzie Russell to the San Fran cisco Warriors last night for Jerry Lucas, an authoritive source said. A Knicks' official, however, could not be reached for comment.

title: Governor Heckled at Meeting on Aged
description: About 300 elderly people heckled Governor Rockefeller to protest state budget cuts as he began a speech yesterday at the 10th Annual Governor's Conference on Aging at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Imada Leads by a Stroke
description: IKEDA, Japan, May 7 (AP)  Kenosuke Imada of Japan shot a fourunderpar 68 and took a onestroke secondround lead at 139 today in the $27, 778 Dunlop international golf tournament. Next was Aus tralia's Peter Thomson.

title: Meager O.A.S. Results
description: The only immediate practical result of the recent First General Assembly of the Organization of American States in Costa Rica was achieved outside the agenda and off the floor. It was the agreement of Honduras and El Salvador to resume talks looking to a definitive settlement of their brief armed clash in 1969.

title: Antiques: An Appeal to OldFashioned Collectors
description: The antiques show at the Westchester County Center in White Plains is one that appeals to oldfashioned col lectors.

title: LINDSAY ORDERS 1,000 JOBS ENDED
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that 500 public em ployes would be laid off by June 1 and 500 other jobs would be eliminated or go unfilled.

title: Dance: City Ballet Gala
description: When you give a gala give a gala. On Thursday night at the New York State Theater the New York City Ballet gave a gala. It was a gala.

title: REP. MILLS WARNS NATIONS ON TRADE
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 7 (AP) The United States cannot maintain its freetrade policies if individual nations and re gional blocs continue to dis criminate against this country's exports, Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today.

title: Capital Jail Is Ruled Cruel Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  A judge ruled here today that 600 persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations were being held under conditions that inflicted cruel and un usual punishment.

title: LAYER TOPS SMITH IN 3 SETS AT ROME
description: ROME, May 7 (UPI)Rod Laver of Australia shook off an erratic second set today to down Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6.1, 26, 62, and move into, the semifinals of the Italian tennis championships.

title: Textile Imports Still High
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The fantastic growth of textile imports did not abate in the first quarter of this year, a Government official dealing with the textile problem said today.

title: KENNY BARRON FIVE PERFORMS AT MUSE
description: The quintet that Kenny Bar ron brought to Muse, Bedford Avenue at Lincoln Place, Brook lyn, Thursday night was drawn from some of the best jazz sources. In addition to Mr. Bar ron on piano, it consisted of Herbie Hancock's drummer, Billy Hart; McCoy Tyner's saxo phonist, Sonny Fortune; the Tonight show's bassist, John Williams, and the director of Muse's Jazz Workshop, Bill Bar ron, Kenny's brother, on saxo phone and flute.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Howmet Corporation announced yesterday the election of Andre Jacomet to the newly cre ated position of vice chairman and Robert Jensen as president. Mr. Jacomet, formerly presi dent, will continue as chief executive officer. Mr. Jensen joined the company in 1967 as vice presi dent of the aluminum group and since 1968 has served as executive vice president and chief oper ating officer. He was made a director in 1970.

title: 2 Gunmen Steal Family's Gems After Threatening to Kill Son
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 7 Two masked gunmen entered a mansion in this Westchester County town through an un locked cellar door last night and escaped with an undeter mined amount of jewelry after holding the family at gunpoint and threatening to kill a 10 yearold boy.

title: MISS HAYNIE GETS TEXAS GOLF LEAD
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May (UPI)  Sandra Haynie of Dallas carded a birdie on the 18th hole today for a four under par 69 and took the lead in the $20,000 Alamo open golf tournament.

title: Editor of The Catholic Reporter Dismissed in Dispute on Policy
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 7 The editor of The National Catholic Reporter, one of the most influential Roman Catho lic publications in the United States, has been dismissed in dispute over whether the weekly should continue its aggressively liberal policy.

title: T.W.A. Outlines Terms For Deal With Lockheed
description: Trans World Airlines dis closed yesterday a lengthy se ries of terms and conditions it has presented to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. T.W.A. in dicated that these were its re quirements before it would proceed, if possible, with the Lockheed L1011 program.

title: Aaron Ehrlich Weds Miss Evalyn Frumkin
description: Miss Evelyn Frumkin, a television commercials pro ducer with Norman, Craig & Kummel, Inc., a New York advertising agency, was mar ried here yesterday to Aaron Ehrlich, a vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc.

title: Yanks Win, 43, Near 6,000 Victories
description: CHICAGO, May 7A home made sign in the stands pro claimed the Yankees as the best team in the East, but they were lucky to escape as the better team in Chicago tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPP BACKS GREEN IN PHILADELPHIA BID
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7  Gov. Milton J. Shapp discarded his previously announced neu trality today and endorsed Rep resentative William J. Green for Mayor of Philadelphia.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Dr. Seymour Z. Lewin, pro fessor of chemistry at New York University, was granted a patent this week for a method of preserving lime stone and marble. The process is being used to protect works of art and national monu ments here and abroad. Patent 3,577,244 is assigned to the university, at whose Institute of Fine Arts the pre liminary research was done. Dr. Lewin an nounced the development at a meeting of the International Council on Museums in Brus sels five years ago.

title: Fastest in the World, but ...
description: HELSINGBORG, Sweden, May 7 (UPI)Karen Moras of Aus tralia, 17 years old, became the first woman swimmer in the world to better 9 minutes in the 800meter freestyle when she was timed in 8 minutes 59.4 seconds tonight, but it was not a world mark since the race took place in a 25meter pool and not the required 50meter pool.

title: ERIE IS HAILED. BY GARMENT UNION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May Senator Edmund S. Muskie was given a warm reception today at the the convention of the. International Ladies Gar ment Workers Union where he directed a barrage of criticism at the Nixon Administration's economic policy.

title: Mitchell Rejects Virginia Plan For Reapportionment as Biased
description: WASHINGTON, May 7At torney General John N. Mitchell rejected tonight a plan for re apportioning Virginia's legisla tive districts on the ground that the plan discriminated against Negroes.

title: President Praises U.S. Farms For Efficiency and Productivity
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Nixon praised Ameri can farms again today for their efficiency and productivity as word of a restless farm vote filtered into the White House.

title: Annual Meeting of May 28 Postponed by Penn Central
description: The annual meeting of the Penn Central Company, origin ally scheduled for May 28, has been postponed at least until June because financial state ments of the Penn Central Transportation Company and its subsidiaries are not available, the company said yesterday.

title: Pentagon to Pay Lockheed For C5A Starting June 7
description: WASHINGTON. May 7The Defense Department announced today that it would put into effect June 7 a new contract with the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration under which the Gov ernment will begin paying out $200million to maintain prod uction of 81 C5A transport planes.

title: French Report Brezhnev Will Visit Paris in the F all
description: MOSCOW, May 7Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, today told the visiting French Foreign Minister, Mau rice Schumann, that he intended to lead a Soviet delegation to Paris later this year, French sources said.

title: BROKEN RIBS FAIL TO DETER INSKO
description: WESTBURY, L, I., May 7 Two fractured ribs and a dented vertebrae will not keep Del Insko on the sidelines long. Insko, whose career as a harness racing driver began in 1946, when he was a week short of his 16th birthday, said today that he would return to Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night to drive in five events.

title: Higher Campaign Fund Ceiling Asked
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Re publican Senators contended to day that spending ceilings im posed by a campaign finance bill now heading for floor de bate should be raised to re flect the actual expefience of the 1970 elections.

title: Erich Segal Is on Riviera As Juror at Film Festival
description: NEW HAVEN, May 7Erich Segal, the 34yearold associate professor of classics at Yale University who wrote the hit movie and bestselling novel Love Story, flew to the French Riviera today. It was reported yesterday that he in tended to take a leave of ab sence from the university.

title: SAIGON ASKING PARIS TO RENEW RELATIONS
description: PARIS, South Vietnam, May 7  South Vietnam's Foreign Minister announced here today that his country was seeking to reestablish diplomatic relations with France.

title: Ford to Close Truck Plant In Chile, Laying Off 600
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6 The Ford Motor Company has decided to close its truck plant in Chile, laying off 600 work ers, it was learned today.

title: DISPOSAL TO START ON GERM WEAPONS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  The Defense Department an nounced today that the Army would start Monday on its 48 week destruction of the Nation's entire stockpile of antiperson nel germ warfare weapons, all stored at the Pine Bluff, Ark., Arsenal.

title: APARTHEID IN U.S. SEEN BY MONDALE
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale declared yesterday that the sickening truth is that this country is rapidly coming to resemble South Africa.

title: Auto Production
description: DETROIT, May 7 (AP)  Fol lowing is the weekly auto pro duction table:

title: Boulez Leads Schubert With the Philharmonic
description: As he had conducted Haydn earlier in the season, so Pierre Boulez conducted the Schubert Sixth Symphony with the New York Philhar monic on Thursday evening. This means an emphasis on contour, steady rhythms, a classic approach with re duced orchestra, and under rather than overinterpreta don.

title: Quaker Oats Net Down in Quarter
description: Net income of the Quaker Oats Company including spe cial charges moved lower in the quarter and ninemonth pe riod ended March 31, figures re leased yesterday indicated.

title: Censure of Dellums Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  Clay Claiborne, national di rector of a group called the Black Silent Majority Commit tee, urged the House today to censure Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of Cali fornia, for his support of recent antiwar demonstrations. A spokesman for Mr. Dellums, who is black, dismissed the committee as a Republican front organization and asked, Who is the black silent major itv?

title: Leslie Jane Ward Has Nuptials
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., May 7 Miss Leslie Jane Ward and Michael Richard Borasky of Orange were married here this evening in the Prospect Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Gustavus Warfield.

title: Shop Talk
description: Furnishings designs con tinue to look like anything but, judging by the exhibi tion of about 30 imported chairs and lighting fixtures that Is now on view through June 12 at Sachs New York, Eighth Avenue at 35th Street. Chairs, for instance, take the forms of a harp, a boa con strictor, a drum, a book, a leaf, a spinnaker sail, a tractor seat, a bi cycle seat and a stirrup. As for the lamps, they come shaped like a cobra, a smokestack, a grasshopper, an angle iron, a periscope and the Leaning Tower of Pisa.

title: Ruling That Land Isn't Theirs Angers Australia Tribe
description: YIRRKALA, Arnhem Land, Australia, April 30  Gloom and anger have pervaded this isolated tribal settlement on the remote Gove Peninsula of Arn hem Land, in northern Austra lia, since a white judge ruled that the wilderness occupied by the carkskinned aborinincs for thousands of years does not be long to them.

title: Councilmanic CopOut
description: In this time of fiscal austerity, as unemployment rises and tax revenues continue to lag, the State Legis lature in Albany waits for word from New York City on its budgetary priorities. It waits to hear precisely what new taxing authority the city expects to use to raise funds to meet essential needs. It waits ... and waits....

title: Market Place:
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. L, May 7 The Magnetic Head Corpo ration is a tiny, precision manufacturing company in this Long Island community that is preparing to manu facture modular computer units the company hopes to harness together in clusters powerful enough to compete with some of the largest com puters in the world.

title: KEROSENE POLLUTES OYSTER BAY HARBOR
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., May Oyster Bay harbor was or dered closed this morning be cause of kerosene spills of an undetermined origin.

title: SOVIET CALLS JAVITS TEL AVIV'S SENATOR
description: MOSCOW, May 7  The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, published a vitriolic personal attack today against Senator Jacob Javits, labeling him Senator from Tel Aviv, blood brother of Israeli hawks and their man in Washington.

title: Scribner Blocks Early Tenure When Violating New State Law
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner told community school boards yesterday that they could not prematurely grant tenure, or job security, to teachers and supervisors in an effort to circumvent a new state law that takes effect tomorrow.

title: LAWRENCE COHEN
description: Lawrence Cohen, a realty and estate lawyer, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 1095 Park Avenue. He was 65 years old.

title: Man in the News
description: BONN, May 7This week, as West Germany's mark grew shinier than ever under the massive rubbing of hot dollars pouring into the coun try, a Bonn journalist ap proached Economics Minister Karl Schiller with a wicked gleam in his eye. Has it occurred to you, Herr Minister, he said, that Saturday, when the Com mon Market Six will meet in Brus sels to decide whether to take joint steps on currency will be the 26th anniversary of the capitula tion of the Third Reich and that Sunday, when you will meet with Chancellor Brandt, is the second anniversary of the day when the Federal Cabinet ruled against your request for revaluation of the mark?

title: YearbyYear Totals Of Persons in Poverty
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 The following table, based on Census Bureau figures, shows the number of Americans be low the poverty level, and their percentage of the total population, for the years 196670. For a family of four, the poverty level was $2,973 in 1959 and $3,968 in 1970.

title: Drama Critics Circle Selects Home and Follies as Bests
description: The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday picked Home, a British import, as the best play of the 197071 season and Follies as the best musical.

title: India's Position Is Wait and See On Recognition of Bangla Desh
description: NEW DELHI, May 7Prime Minister Indira Gandhi report edly told Opposition leaders today that her Government wanted to watch developments for a while before deciding whether to recognize the gov ernment proclaimed by the Ben gali independence movement in East Pakistan.

title: Stans Finds Consumers in U.S. Satisfied
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 7 Secretary of Commerce Maur ice H. Stans said today that consumers receive full Satis faction from nearly every one of the purchases they make from American businesses.

title: RECITAL ON PIANO BY CRISTINA ORTIZ
description: Cristina Oritz was 19 years old when she won the Van Cli burn International Piano Com petition two years ago. At the ripe age of 21, but still looking 19, the Brazilian pianist finally gave on Thursday night the Carnegie Hall recital that was one of her prizes. (Another prize was $10,000.) Her youth was evident in her perform ances, but she is immensely gifted, and there is little doubt that she will have a successful career.

title: MAN WITH FIRE BOMB SEIZED IN SUBWAY
description: A Brooklyn man tried unsuc cessfully to throw a Molotov cocktail onto the crowded rushhour platform of the BroadwayNassau subway sta tion on the IND line at 5:45 yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: THE ANSWER IS . .
description: Letters:

title: O.T.B.: Howie The Horse Picks a Winner
description: When Howard J. Samuels was running for the Democratic nomination for Governor last year, he could walk for blocks along Broadway and, sadly, no one would notice. ,Occasionally, someone would pass and say, Aren't you Howie Samuels?it would make his day.

title: Dump Nixon Meeting Set By Liberal G.O.P. Group
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI)  A group of liberal Republicans plans to meet here May 16 to lay the groundwork for national Dump Nixon organization.

title: Paris Denies It Refused Asylum to Chinese Aide
description: PARIS, May 8 (Reuters) The Foreign Ministry denied and described as slanderous today a newspaper report that said France had refused to give asylum to a Chinese Communist official. The paper was apparently The International Herald Tribune.

title: Revenue Sharing
description: To the Financial Editor: To overcome the rising plight of American cities, revenue sharing should he increased to between $25billion and $50billion annually, It is a Federal problem, for the Constitution assigns to the government, not states and municipalities, the unlimited power to issue or borrow money.

title: Inside, Looking Out A Personal Memoir. By Harding Lemay. 273 pp. New York: Harper's Magazine Press. $6.95.
description: A story of suffering drained of suffering

title: Fans Go on Rampage
description: LONDON, May 8 (UPI) Four soccer fans turned themselves into human flies and hunAreds of others went on a rampage as the craze for the game swept the country where it was born centuries ago.

title: Twins Rout Senators, 92
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 8 (UPI)Tony Oliva raised his American League batting lead to 395 with four hits, including a threerun homer, today as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Washington Senators, 92.

title: Planners May Act on Medical School in Queens
description: The idea or establishing a medical school in Queens has been discussed by political and civic leaders in the county for almost 20 years. Although no formal plans for creating a medical school have been developed, it appears that action on the proposal may begin soon.

title: Brick, Wood Or Cement?
description: MOST homeowners feel that a paved outdoor patio or terrace of some kind is essential to enjoy the comforts of outdoor living and entertaining. Some careful planning beforehand will avoid disappointment with the final results. Here are some factors to take into consideration before starting actual construction.

title: Charles Otto to Marry Wendy Halsey
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May SMr. and Mrs. Bates Halsey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Ann Halsey, to Charles Edward Otto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Otto of Manhasset, L. I.

title: Mississippi Seeks To Arrest Leaders Of Black Republic
description: BROWNSVILLE, Miss., May 8Warrants were issued yesterday for the arrest of the paramilitary group attempting to form a black nation in Mississippi.

title: Antipollution Training To Start in Brooklyn
description: A program for training environmental technologists to combat air and water pollution has been approved by the Board of Higher Education for Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.

title: I.M.F. Heads Meet Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Directors of the International Monetary Fund are scheduled to meet here tomorrow. They met twice in the last week.

title: Padres Rout Reds, 100
description: SAN DIEGO, May 8 (AP) The San Diego Padres scored nine runs in the first two innings tonight and went on to wallop the Cincinniti Reds, 100.

title: Jonathan M. Hornblower To Marry Alix Tower
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 8Mrs. Hugh Whitney Fosburgh of Bedford and Whitney Tower of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Cheston Tower, to Jonathan Marshall Hornblower. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hornblower of Washington where Mr. Hornblower, a lawyer, is a partner of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering.

title: Soutar's 4Game 995 Breaks A.B.C. Record
description: DETROIT, May 8 (UPI)Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Calif., rolled a 995 series to crack a tournament record today in the first fourgame block of the qualifying round in the American Bowling Congress Masters tournament at Cobo Hall. He had games of 267, 269, 236 and 223.

title: Listening Between the Lines
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Allpurpose American conversations for 1971's Now people.

title: Avedon Photographs a Harsh Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Richard Avedon, the American portrait photographer who came to Vietnam six weeks ago to take pictures for his new book, believes that all Americans who choose to come to Vietnam have one terrible thing in common.

title: TIGERS TRIUMPH ON CASH HOMERS
description: DETROIT, May 8 (UPI) Norm Cash hit two straight home runs today and Fred Scherman bailed out Joe Coleman with one pitch to give the Detroit Tigers a 21 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Recession and Layoffs in Industry Promise a Generally Bleak Summer Job Market for Students on L.I.
To THE EDITOR:
description: The Motion Picture Academy redeemed a lot of lost prestige when it chose excellence over popularity in awarding this year's Oscars.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: Drama Mailbag

title: $700,000 Offer to Purchase Canonero IITurned Down
description: CARACAS, May 8 (UPI)  The owners of the Venezuelan horse Canonero II, who won last Saturday's Kentucky Derby, rejected today a purchase proposal on behalf of Mrs. Richard du Pont for $700,000.

title: Karen Kersten Plans Wedding
description: WAUSAU, Wis., May 8 Miss Karen Kersten and Terry J. Fox plan to be married June 12 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. Mr. Fox is president of Iroquois Industries of Buffalo, a marketing organization in health foods and food flavoring, and has homes in Buffalo and New York.

title: U.N. to Honor Postal Union
description: FORTHCOMING from the United Nations on May 28 will be two stamps to commemorate the first anniversary of the opening of the new building of the International Bureau of the Universal Postal Union in Berne, Switzerland. The stamps will be the latest in a United Nations series commemorating buildings that have played roles in the work of the world organization.

title: 55 Men, Women and Grandfathers
description: ONE day last October, Edward B. Garvey Falls Church, Va., a retired government employe, plodded to the summit of Baxter Peak, the 5,200foothigh topmost elevation of Maine's Mount Katandin, and photographed the sign there which reads: 2,025 miles to Springer Mountain, Georgia. He had just hiked every last one of those 2,025 milesthe entire length of the Appalachian Trailand in so doing, Garvey joined a select circle of outdoorsmen.

title: RUSSIAN HOSPITALITY
description: TO THE EDITOR: Of all my varied travels, my warm welcome to the city of Leningradthe subject of an article by Robert Deardorff (Travel section, April 18)must rank among the beet experiences I have encountered in any foreign city. During a recent, fiveday stay, I found Leningrad much brighter than somber Moscow and more vibrant than phlegmatic Kiev. On the day of its arrival in Leningrad our tour party was approached by two women from the Soviet Friendship Institute who offered to escort us anywhere we wished in the city and environs. I was among the few members of the group to accept the invitation. I asked to see the Peter and Paul Fortress. We went there by subway and were given a thorough tour. In the process we passed the cruiser Aurora, the vessel that fired the initial shot in the Bolshevik Revolution and is akin to our Independence Hall as a symbol. When I expressed interest, one of our guides secured a signed pass for us and a naval officer welcomed us aboard, gave us brochures in English and apologized for the lack of an Englishspeaking guide. We had unlimited time to tour the vessel and the museum on board.

title: Jersey Cites Shore Area Water Pollution Crisis
description: TRENTON, May 8 Commissioner Richard J. Sullivan of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said today there was a water pollution emergency in lowlying shore areas that stretch from Sandy Hook to Cape May.

title: After Withdrawal
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Computer Is Set Up To Find Luggage That Goes Astray
description: Frank Bender, a Nevada businessman whose luggage has gone astray now and then, has devised what he believes is the solution to the problem of baggage that goes off on trips of its own.

title: Scenario for Steel Confrontation?
description: The stage was set last week for what could be a disruptive confrontation between the Nixon Administration and the steel industry.

title: JERSEY RACE WON BY I'M FOR MAMA
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 8 (AP)I'm For Mama, second choice of the crowd of 23,845, scored a 3length triumph today in the $27,800 Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park.

title: False Alarms in City Rose 30% in First Four Months
description: There were 27,606 false alarms turned in to the Fire Department in the first four months of 1971, an increase of 30 per cent over the same period last year, Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL CAUTIOUS ABOUT ANY GAINS
description: JERUSALEM, May 8The Israeli authorities sought today to dampen any premature enthusiasm about progress in the peacemaking effort during the twoday visit here of Secretary of State William P. Rogers.

title: OntheJob Crime
description: One reason for the high cost of construction these days is the high level of dishonesty in the industry.

title: Australia Has A Wild West, Too
description: ALICE SPRINGS, AustraliaMany of the loungers and pedestrians one comes across along Todd Street, the wide main thoroughfare of Alice Springs, are bronzed stockmen  as Australian cowboys are called many of them aborigines, In their standard garb of widebrimmed hat, checked shirt and blue jeans tucked into highheeled boots, they look as if they had stepped right out of a TV western.

title: Bridge Dispute Spans History of New Orleans
Soleil Pierre de Blu Crest, a Great Pyrenees, Named Best at Bucks County
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 8 The Great Pyrenees is a dog long on history, big in stature but on the short end when it comes to winning top awards at dog shows.

title: Speculative Tide Of Dollars Abroad Brings New Crisis
description: DESPITE a renewed wave of speculation in the West German mark and other currencies that created a new international monetary crisis last week, financial markets in this country remained remarkably cool.

title: Stout and Frankel, Newsmen in Capital, Get Clapper Award
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) Jared D. Stout of the Newhouse News Service and Max Frankel of The New York Times were awarded the annual Raymond Clapper Memorial Award today for exceptionally meritorious Washington correspondence in 1970.

title: AUSTIN D. BARNEY, UTILITY EXECUTIVE
description: HARTFORD, May 8 (AP)Austin Dunham Barney, retired board chairman of the Hartford Electric Light Company, a former State Senator and a founder of the University of Hartford, died today at the age of 74.

title: The Patent Story
description: What are 10 patents that shaped the modern world? This is a good question to think about in connection with one of the most fascinating and little known aspects of American industryinventions.

title: Drivers to Make Bid Saturday For Pole in Indianapolis 500
description: Weather permitting, there should be close to 250,000 spectators at Indianapolis Motor Speedway next Saturday. With an admission price of just $2, the first Saturday of the two weekends of qualifying is one of the best bargains in racing, an exciting day of dramaticepisodes building up to a climax. Because Indianapolis policy favors firstday qualifiers, next Saturday's program determines who wins the pole for the running of America's greatest race on May 29; it also allocates the best starting positions behind the polesitter. The subsequent trials, next Sunday and SaturdaySunday, May 22.23, simply fill out the field to 33 cars.

title: On an Estate in Virginia, Ancient Art of Topiary Is Renewed Each Spring
Caso Scores G.O.P. Partners
description: Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who successfully campaigned six months ago on a promise of partnership in government with Republican administrations in Albany and in Washngton, now says his G.O.P. partners are taking too much of the county's tax revenues while we get all the lumps.

title: Roots of the Money Crisis
description: Consultations are continuing in Europy today as members of the Common Market seek to devise measures to prevent a recurrence of the massive selling of United States dollars for German marks that forced the Bundesbank and four other European central banks to cease supporting the dollar at its official price last week. But even if the immediate crisis is contained, the underlying conditions that brought on the monetary turmoil could breed new difficulties for the world economy in the months ahead.

title: HITTING THEM OUT OF YANKEE STADIUM
description: To THE EDITOR: Robert Peterson's article about the black baseball leagues and players (Josh Gibson Was the Equal of Babe Ruth, But . .., April 11) makes heartwarming reading, particularly to those who were privileged to view such great craftsmen as Satchel Paige in their prime.

title: BRUNDAGE AGAIN: NO PAY FOR SKIERS
description: VIENNA, May 8 (AP)Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, made it clear today that he has no intention of changing his tough stand on Alpine skiers.

title: Uncommon Men at Odds in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, May 8 The bored chauffeurs dragged on their cigarettes and waited outside a Brussels building called Charlemagne today as financial officials of six European countries sought to prevent the world's new monetary crisis from tearing apart their Common Market.

title: THE HUN SCORES IN JUMP CLASSES
Being knocked about
description: The homosexual novel has distinct subgenres. One type is written for the homosexual reader, intended specifically to stimulate the fantasylife of an audience that might not otherwise be catered to. Another is aimed at a heterosexual market. In the past, possible contributors to either subgenre Wilde, Forster, Somerset Maugham, to take but three names from our literary Who's Whohave preferred to avoid both, concentrating instead on asexual themes. This is surely a better and more honest procedure than performing for the larger of the two audiences i.e., presenting homosexuals as objects of pity, even of tragedy (but, above all, of curiosity) for the diversion of heterosexuals.

title: Computer Scare Talk
description: Computers are threatened, but not by outsiders in the dramatic and distracting fashion conjured up by some selfappointed experts in computer security. The main threat is from insiders.

title: The Inn Way To Explore The Danish Peninsula Of Jutland
People's Festival at the Zoo Will Highlight Bronx Da.
description: The city's northernmost borough will celebrate Wednesday as Bronx Day, an occasion that will feature a free people's festival in the Bronx Zoo, a folkrock music concert, a parade and an appearance by Dr. Detlev Bronck, a direct descendant of Jonas Bronck, who gave the borough its name.

title: POLAND URGES BONN TO RATIFY TREATIES
description: KATOWICE, Poland, May 8 Premier Piotr Jaroszewicz called upon Bonn today to start as soon as possible ratification procedures on the Moscow and Warsaw treaties signed last year.

title: LongLines Strike Goes Beyond City; Supervisors Fill In
description: A local strike by American Telephone & Telegraph Company workers who maintain equipment used in longdistance domestic and overseas calls spread yesterday to facilities of the utility outside the city.

title: Imperialism By George Lichtheim. 183 pp. New York: Praeger Publishers. Cloth, $7.50. Paper, $2.45. The Enemy What Every American Should Know About Imperialism. By Felix Greene. 391 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $8.95. Vintage Books. Paper, $1.95.
description: Did Cromwell ravage Ireland for the potatoes?

title: We Have So Little To Lose Here
description: The visiting Mayor of Boston, Kevin White, wondered last month as he visited Brownsville's dilapidated houses and saw the rubblestrewn lots and streets and its derelicts, warming themselves around small fires, whether this may be the first tangible sign of the collapse of our civilization.

title: Sheri Rashkoff Bride Of Dr. Seth Eisengart
description: EASTCHESTER, N. Y., May 8Miss Sheri Pam Rashkoff and Dr. Seth W. Eisengart were married here this evening at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ira A. Rashkoff. Rabbi Jack Bemperad performed the ceremony. Dr. Eisengart is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Eisengart of South Miami, Fla.

title: John Dewey H.S.: What Price Reform?
description: When educational reformers complain about resistance to change, they usually point the finger at the central bureaucracythe Establishment. But an exchange of letters in last week's issue of The United Teacher, the weekly publication of the United Federation of Teachers, showed that the problem reaches down through all echelons of the professional power structure.

title: National Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor: In intervening in the Calley case, President Nixon has unintentionally performed a valuable public service: He has illuminated the wide gulf which separates stated national goals from national actions. Such diverse elements as the outcry about prisoners of war in North Vietnam, our South American policy, the issue of law and order here at home all have this basic dichotomy in common.

title: The Search for a Suez Agreement
description: Diplomatic maneuvering in the Middle East is focused on an Egyptian proposal negotiate the reopening of the Suez Canal as a step toward ending the ArabIsraeli conflict. The canal has been closed since the 1967 war. To the left and right of map below are the primary advantages of a Suez agreement to Egypt and Israel.

title: The Antarctica Tourist
description: To THE EDITOR: The implication in P. J., Laine's article Tourists Give the Admiral the Fits (Travel Section, April 25) that tourists are ruining Antarctica's ecology and hampering scientists in research projects has made me boiling mad because it is not true. I have spent many years in Antarctic operations as deputy commander for the United States Navy in its scientific support activities, as a writer and onthespot investigator for a new station, and, for the last several, as director, ship and polar operations with. Lindblad Travel, Inc., which currently takes tourists to Antarctica each year on cruises that I have accompanied.

title: THE PURRFECT JOURNEY
description: How I beat a 90day Federal rap (Norwegian) and got a practically free flight from New York to Oslo (with help from my 14yearold mistress) is described here for the edification of future likemiscreants. But don't get too anxious: getting there isn't half the fun.

title: Gertz Is Voted a 7th Term By Jamaica Hospital Board
description: Stanley B. Gertz, a Jamaica real estate executive and a member of the Gertz department store family, has been reelected to a seventh consecutive term as president of the board of trustees of Jamaica Hospital.

title: Team Handball Is on View Here, but It Isn't Handball
description: More than 90 accomplished young athletes spent yesterday competing for the national championship in team handball, a sport that has no relationship to the handball familiar to most Americans.

title: Tito, in Vigorous Reassertion of His Personal Authority, Demands Party Unity and Economic Discipline
description: SARAJEVO Yugoslavia, May 8In a vigorous reassertion of his personal political authority, President Tito called his party and his countrymen to order today, demanding unity of the country's leaders and economic discipline from ordinary citizens.

title: Camera World News
description: A TWOWEEK summer institute for teachers, students and enthusiasts will be conducted by the University Film Study Center and Hampshire College. To be called Film and Photography, the institute will meet at Hampshire's new campus near Amherst, Mass. from June 20 to July 3, but registration is being field now and the deadline for registering is this coming Saturday. Those interested should write the University Film Study Center, Box 275, Cambridge, Mass. 02138, or call (617) 8940920.

title: Olivia Hedelind Rutter Is Bride In Darien of John G. Petrasch
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 8 Miss Olivia Hedelind Rutter, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Ormsby Rutter and the late Mr. Rutter, was married this afternoon to John Garrit Petrasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Schurz Petrasch Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y. The Rev. Robert N. Back performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: God's Cruelest Joke
description: PAMPLEMOUSSES, MauritiusThis tiny country is notable for the botanical gardens of Pamplemousses (which means grapefruits), the last dodo bird (which died 300 years ago), the eighteenthcentury French romantic novel, Paul et Virginia, the ancestral forebears of France's former Premier Maurice Couve de Murville and a racially mixed society as complex as anywhere on earth.

title: U.S. Asks High Court to Uphold Wiretaps on Domestic Subversives
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to uphold the Nixon Administration's assertion that it had the legal authority to use wiretapping against allegedly subversive domestic groups without obtaining prior court approval.

title: Airports Expanding In Size and In Traffic
description: Air travelby people and cargohas climbed sharply in the last decade and promises to continue upward in the decade ahead.

title: The Incurable By Nell Dunn. 110 pp. New York: Doubleday &
description: Reader's Report

title: Philanthropist to Get Medal
description: Joseph I. Lubin, New York business executive and philanthropist, will received the S. Y. Agnon Gold Medal from the American Friends of Hebrew University at the organization's annual dinner at the Plaza Hotel on May 24.

title: Nassau Weighs Reapportionment Plans
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 8A 56yearold lawyer who has spent 18 years in Nassau County government has been wrestling for the last few years with the problem of providing a plan for the reapportionment of the County Board of Supervisors.

title: Racism
description: To the Financial Editor: Your article on Lloyd M. Cooke (April 25) was both revealing and sobering, for it brought into sharp focus the inherently pervasive racism in American big business, The hierarchy of American big business is still very much and very firmly denied to the racial minorities. The idea that American business is an equalopportunity employer is only a halftruth and is in reality a blatant and bigoted lie, Dr. Cooke being a living testimonial to that truism.

title: Consumer Group Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)Establishment of an independent Consumer Product Safety Commission to regulate the manufacture of products that may he hazardous to consumers was proposed Thursday by Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California.

title: POMPIDOU TALKS WITH HEATH SET
description: PARIS, May 8  President Pompidou agreed today to receive Prime Minister Heath on May 20 and 21, at a critical moment in the history of the Common Market and Western economic relations.

title: Day's Allied Ce seFire Marks Buddha's Birthday
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8United States and South Vietnamese armed forces began a 24hour truce in South Vietnam at noon today in honor of Buddha's birthday, but the fighting in Cambodia and the bombing of enemy supply routes in Laos are continuing.

title: Wind, Rain Cancel Regatta
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 8 The third event of the Larchinont Yacht Club's annual sixrace spring regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets on Long Island Sound was called off today because of a strong easterly wind, a downpour and high seas.

title: Slow Number
description: The American Stock Exchange, scene of many a frantic flurry in stock trading, bade farewell last week to one of its slower moving numbers, the convertible preferred stock of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company.

title: Police to Stage Tours Of Stations This Week
description: The Police Department will celebrate Law Enforcement Week starting today by opening its 76 stations to visits by the public.

title: Daughter to the Jaffes
description: A daughter was born on April 8 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Jaffe of New York in the LyingIn Hospital here.

title: Sally Stone Is Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 8Miss Sally Wilson Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Partridge Stone, was married at noon today to Jeffrey Robert Weichel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ludwig Weichel of Stroudsburg, Pa.

title: Emile Griffith Marries
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., May 8 (AP)Emile Griffith, a former boxing champion, and a schoolteacher from the Virgin Islands were married here today. The best man was Joe Frazier, the heavyweight champion. Griffith, the former lightweight and middleweight champion, married Mercedes Donastorg of St. Thomas.

title: Hospital Names a Director
description: Dr. Nicholas A. De Francis has been appointed director of medicine at St. John's Queens Hospital in Elmhurst. Dr. De Francis has been director of the coronary care unit of the hospital since it was opened in 1967.
