title: The Last Year Of Leo Tolstoy By V. F. Bulgahov. 235 pp. Dial. $7.95.
description: In January, 1910, a bright college dropout named Valentin Bulgakov joined Leo Tolstoy's household at Vasnaya Polyana. The master was 81, 10 months from death and still in the throes of his mystical conversion begun years earlier. The diary kept by the worshipful young man suggests the moral crisis that misshaped Tolstoy's family life; it records his apt judgments and arbitrary resentments on matters as various as writing, love, the meaning of God, ways to cook. The text was first published in 1911, fortified with additional material in 1924. This first English translation by Ann Dunnigan, is lumpy and incomplete. George Steiner's introduction reads like a TV culture lecture.

title: Brillo Boxes, Red Cows And the Great Soup Can Manipulation ...
description: AS it must to all men, middle age came to Andy Warhol last week, descending upon him in the form of a retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum. Or at least a partial retrospective limited, at his request, to five of his major themessoup cans, Brillo boxes, portraits, disasters, and flowers, plus, as a background, his redcowonyellowground wallpaper.

title: YOUNG TRIUMPHS IN COAST 2MILE
description: FRESNO, Calif., May 8 (AP) George Young continued his track comeback tonght by winning the twomile run in the best United States time this season in the 44th West Coast Relays.

title: ARBITRATION PUN WINS N.Y.U. VOTE
description: An agreement to submit a contract dispute to binding arbitration ended a 12week strike by 150 maintenance workers yesterday at four campuses of New York University.

title: Policeman Is Stabbed to Death During Scuffle While Off Duty
description: An offduty policeman was stabbed to death near a Harlem housing project early yesterday morning during an argument with six men, who fled after the killing. Last night the police arrested three persons and charged them with the killing.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Attention, Swordfish Lovers
description: MENEMSHA, Mass.  Everett Poole, owner of Poole's Fish Market on Martha's Vineyard Island, says he will continue to buy and sell broadbill swordfish until Federal or state authorities inform him that it is illegal to do so.

title: 12 Students in City Among 700 Getting Merit Scholarships
description: The names of more than 700 winners of collegesponsored National Merit Scholarship, including those of 12 New York City residents, were announced yesterday.

title: Margaret H. Staley Is Married
description: MERCERSBURG, Pa., May 8Miss Margaret Hannah Staley and Edward Hitchman Sehon were married this afternoon in the Chapel of the Mercersburg Academy by the Rev. Don Creager of the United Church of Christ.

title: Fordham Women to Be Cited
description: Forty Fordham woman studentathletes in four intercollegiate activities at Rose Hill will be honored at the Fordham University's women's sports dinner tomorrow evening in the Rose Hill Faculty Dining Room. Members of the women's basketball, fencing and rifle teams and the women's cheerleading squad will be honored.

title: The EasyCare Perennials
description: THERE are such things as perennial plants that (1) stay neat and attractive all summer; (2) seldom need dividing; (3) need no staking; (4) are not bothered by bugs and disease; (5) do not take over the whole, garden.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: What we need far more urgently than the perfect contraceptive is more widespread use of the reliable ones we now have. One hundred thousand abortions in nine months cannot all be the result of diaphragm and pill failures. Our legislators have done well to make abortion as available as it now is in New York State. But legalizing abortion without developing programs to encourage the use of contraceptives is essentially condoning abortion, which should ideally be performed only in extreme and unusual cases, as an acceptable method of birth control. We need to develop a system in which it is as easy for a womanor a highschool girlto obtain a reliable birthcontrol device as it is for her to become pregnant.

title: Unlikely Officer Fighting Ouster
description: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, May 6Second Lieut. Rory J. Sutton of Algonac, Mich., does not look or act like an Army officer. His hair hangs too far over his eyes, he does not associate with his fellow officers, most of his friends are enlisted men, and he is an outspoken opponent of the war.

title: The Annual Spring Scare
description: The oldest dodge in the Pentagon's bag of tricks at budget time is the selective declassification of scare stories about an increasing Soviet threat, while contrary evidence is minimized or kept secret. Defense Secretary Laird's dire annual report on new Soviet missile deployments has had more help from the Russians this year in the form of big new holes for ICBM silos  but nevertheless it may turn out to be just as misleading as last year's warnings.

title: Micronesian Nationalists Accuse U.S. of Plan to Keep Islands
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 8 A purportedly official document being distributed by Micronesian nationalists says that the United States adopted a policy under the Kennedy Administration of making the strategic Central Pacific Islands of Micronesia a permanent American possession in spite of opposition expected in the United Nations.

title: Miss Porter Bride Of Donald Fidler
description: Miss Margaret Ann Porter, an accountant with the Shell Oil Company, and Donald Alvin Fidler, an assistant engineering manager for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: How to Set a Date For Getting Out of Vietnam
description: THE graphic failure of the Laotian operation, begun with trumpets in February and prematurely terminated with heavy casualties and disorderly retreat before the end of March, produced a deeper (though at first a less clamorous) change of public sentiment than the extraordinary uproar occasioned by President Nixon's decision to send American forces into Cambodia a year ago. The Laos affair punctured the sturdy illusion that the South Vietnamese Army was moving steadily toward splendid selfreliance; it brought home to millions of Americans that, whatever contrary hopes are sincerely held in the White House, the Nixon policy means in fact endless American military participation in an endless war; and that, so long as the war continues, there can be no return of American prisoners and no surcease from domestic turmoil and division.

title: Olympian
description: GREECE has commemorated the 75th anniversary of the 1896 revival of the Olympic Games as an international event in Athens. Two stamps have been issued, one of 3 drachma, depicting the arrival in the Athens stadium of the Greek runner Spyridon Louis, first victor in the revived Marathon race; and an 8drachma, with a portrait of Pierre de Coubertin, a Frenchman, who was instrumental in the Games international revival. This stamp also shows the memorial column erected in his honor which is at the site of the International Olympic Academy at Olympia.

title: China: For Most Of the Peasants Things Are Better
description: CANTONWith their patchwork of wellgroomed fields and their little villages of tileroofed, bambootufted houses, the farmlands of China in the springtime were always among the charms of the country's peasantbased society. Today, the beauty of China's mural landscape is, if anything, more pronounced than ever.

title: The 'Black Gold Rush
description: UP IN Scarsdale the other day they held a giant giveaway of black gold. Suburban housewives drove up in their station wagons and, with the help of Boy Scouts, loaded the stuff in bushel baskets, tubs and boxes and carted it home to mulch their lawns and gardens.

title: True Champion Seen
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 (AP)There is a strong possibility of a playoff between American and National Basketball Association league champions to determine a true world champion after the 197172 season, the A.B.A. commissioner, Jack Dolph, said today.

title: STATE DISTRICTING RUNS INTO A SNAG
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The redrawing of Congressional and legislative districts in New York has been delayed because of inconsistencies discovered in the population data sent to the state by the Census Bureau

title: Kill the Dutchman! By Paul Sann. 347 pp. Arlington. $8.95.
description: Et Al.

title: The Last Word: What Is to Be Done?
description: One of the nice things about Hamlet is that Polonius is stabbed. So says Saul Bellow in the winter issue of Philip Rahv's new quarterly, Modern Occasions. Mr. Bellow's particular Polonius is William Phillips of Partisan Review. But there are other Poloniuses in other magazinesone thinks of Hugh Hefner in Playboy, of Norman Podhoretz in Commentarylike spiders spinning rhetorical silk out of their abdomens; and they doubtless set their readers dreaming about a knife. Why, then, The Last Word, another column of opinion? Who needs another halfdozen Poloniuses, even if we are members of the Book Review staff? Each of us will have to spin his individual web of excuses in the weekly installments to come, but let me try a few of my own.

title: Amber Light, $7.40, Scores By 3 Lengths on Coast
description: ALBANY, Calif., May 8 (UPI) Amber Light ran away from five rivals today to win the $20,000added San Juan Bautista Handicap at Golden Gate Fields by 3 lengths.

title: Jewish Day Schools Becoming Important Factor in U.S.
description: The Jewish day school, its facilities and enrollment growing each year, is becoming an increasingly important factor in America, educationally, socially and politically.

title: A Gift of Summer
description: Spring is in the air, and summer vacations are only weeks away. The more fortunate of city children have begun to daydream about the glories of imminent escape from traffic lights and asphalt into the world of trees and lakes and the airconditioning of country breezes.

title: U.S. Sculptors To Get More Aid
description: we have talent in abundance in this country. It remains only for those of us interested in the fine arts to uncover and promote it, said Mrs. Elvira ClainStefanelli in her address before 150 members and guests of the newly formed Collectors of Art Medals, Inc., at the New York Hilton.

title: Acccounting Principles
description: For more than a decade, the public accounting profession has been moving to define and codify the financial ground rules governing American business. In recent years, as the pronouncements of the Accounting Principles Board the 18man group charged with this taskhave become increasingly tougher and more specific, criticism of its efforts has become louder.

title: Ashe Defeats Emerson, Kodes Upsets Newcombe in $45,000 Italian Tennis
description: ROME. May 8 (UPI)  Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia upset topseeded John Newcombe, 26, 6.1, 75, and gained the semifinals of the $45,000 Italian open tennis championships today.

title: Jonathan Schwartz Still Digs Sinatra
description: THE number one rock disk jockey on FM radio in New York these days is a 32yearold short story writer with a frail, highpitched whisper of a voice whose favorite singer is, of all people, Frank Sinatra.

title: CITY NOTES JUMP IN WELFARE ROLLS AS JOBS DECLINE
description: A new acceleration in New York City's expanding relief rolls was made known yesterterday, reflecting in part a quadrupled loss of jobs by parents forced on to welfare.

title: BRITISH HEALTH CARE (CONT.)
description: Dr. Bruce A. Harris Jr. (Letters, April 4) is wrong on two counts. Everyone in Britain does not pay for health care under the National Health Service. It is free to those who do not pay any taxes at all, just those groups most in need of it, in fact. This includes visiting Americans, by the way. It is also free in the much wider sense of the word, in that everyone, regardless of income, feels free to use it just as much or little as he wishes.

title: ANTIOCH TO BACK URBAN LAW GROUP
READING ASSISTS YOUTHS SPEECH
description: A New York University research project has determined that slum children speaking nonstandard English, especially those in kindergarten, expand their language ability dramatically when involved in oral language, based on children's literature.

title: Patrick J. Buchanan Weds Shelley Scarney
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 Miss Shelley Scarney, a White House receptionist, was married here this afternoon to Patrick J. Buchanan, special assistant to President Nixon and Presidential speechwriter. The nuptial mass, at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament, was performed by Msgr. W. Louis Quinn before 400 guests, including Washington officials.

title: In Texas, even the Galleries Grow Bigger
description: THERE I was, thinking about Chicago and New York, when all of a sudden I realized that I was sitting in the middle of the most fantastic city in the country.

title: Louise Pomeroy, Bourne Dempsey Wed in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, May 8Miss Louise Aldrich Pomeroy and Bourne Pope Dempsey were married here this afternoon. The Rev. F. Washington Jarvis performed the ceremony in St. Martin's Chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church. There was a reception at the Chagrin Valley Hunt Club.

title: Stanley Dancer Wins With Quick Pride, Loses With Albatross at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 8 Stanley Dancer drove Quick Pride to a halflength victory over A. C.'s Orion in a leisurely 2:05 35 in the $30,200 United States Harness Writers Association Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight after he wound up third with Albatross, a 15 favorite, in the Tar Heel pace. Colonial ($28) and Carbine Hanover were one, two in the Tar Heel.

title: The Faded Lady of Troy, N. Y.
Some Flooding in City Area Follows a Heavy Rainfall
description: The heavy rainfall that began Friday night and continued into late yesterday afternoon resulted in flooding of various sections throughout the metropolitan area and the stranding of automobiles on the Grand Central Parkway.

title: Popularity of Nixon Is Found Steady
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Public confidence in Richard M. Nixon's performance as President, which consistently declined during his first two years in office, has remained steady in the three months since the Laotian incursion, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: Roots of Involvement
description: To the Editor: John Franklin Campbell's piece on our hook, Roots of Involvement. The U.S. in Asia, 17841971, is plainly not a serious review. It is a putdown, glib, cute, condescending. For this reason, we feel obliged to take issue with certain statements.

title: Hawks Enroll Drake Star
description: ATLANTA, May 8 (AP)The Atlanta Hawks today signed Jeff Halliburton of Drake, the club's thirdround draft choice.

title: The Big Lonesome By Will Bryant. 352 pp. New York: Doubleday &
description: The time is 1866, in the Rockies, where the elk and the grizzlies still roam, and a black hat is not necessarily a bad guy. Here, he's a miner in his characteristic felt headgear, prospecting with his 15yearold son. Mr. Bryant cooks up a yeasty batch of sourdough Americana out of their adventures. Seeking a fabled, goldladen creek somewhere around Idaho, they run into hard times, claim jumpers and an infestation of grizzlies. One of thesea cub named Gabrielis domesticated by the boy, and becomes a nice parallel theme to the quest for El Dorado. Gabriel makes it bigger than his owner (he winds up a star in Buffalo Bill's show), but success isn't everything. Father and son have a lot of fun in the 19thcentury outdoors, and so can the escapist reader.

title: C5A + L1011 = Lockheed's financial crisis What Price Lockheed?
730 Bicyclists Tour L.I. On 27Mile, OneDay Trip
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 3 Lured by the promise of fresh salt air and miles of green open countryside, 730 young metropolitanarea bicyclists descended on the 27mile North Fork between here and Greenport for a leisurely day on the road.

title: GOVERNOR URGES AGENCY FOR PARK
description: ALBANY, May 8Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to authorize the establishment of a State Adirondack Park Agency to oversee the use and development of private and public lands in the six million acre Adirondack Park.

title: N.Y.U. Concert Wets Whistles for More
description: To say that Max Neuhaus was all wet during his 15hour musical marathon is only the simple truth, Furthermore, so was his audience. The place was the pool of New York University's Hayden Hall, and hundreds of people, mostly young adults, came, swam and listened on and off from 9 P.M. Friday until yesterday at noon.

title: GERMANS DECIDE TO FLOAT MARK IN MONEY CRISIS
Belgian Chateaus Lower Drawbridges In Drive to Make Tourists Castle Crazy
description: BRUSSELSOne morning not long ago I drove out from Brussels through the rolling, peaceful fields where the armies of Napoleon and Wellington clashed to Les Ecaussinnes, two neat, redbrick villages separated by a meandering stream. On a high, steep rock above one of them I saw Lalaing, a chateaufort, or medieval fortress, that is said to be the most imposing in Belgium. A huge gray stone structure, with a steep slate roof, it was built in the 14th century to dominate the countryside and the waterway below. And dominate them it does. From its founding right up to the present it has been a stronghold in time of war. During World War II the Belgian Resistance met there secretly; and the owner's son was killed in a concentration camp. For many years, tourists have been permitted to visit one of the wings of Lalaing, but this year for the first time the chateau's private apartments will be open to the public.

title: Barnes, a Former Player, Paints a Penetrating Portrait of Pro Football
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Long before Dave Meggyesy, George Sauer and Chip Oliver retired and expressed their reservations about football, another pro player, Ernie Barnes, was putting his hostility for the game into a collection of impressionistic paintings.

title: A Lot Happens In Ten Years
description: IT'S too had about Paterson, N. J., and New London, Conn. Both have something of value. Both are about to lose it through those fates of our time the highway system and the urban renewal.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins
description: GUILDFORD, England, May 8 (UPI)  Evonne Goolagong of Australia won her sixth successive final in Britain today when she beat England's Jill Cooper, 64, 63, for the Surrey championship.

title: Rabbis Denounce Rise in Abortions; Ask Reevaluation
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 8A major American Jewish Orthodox organization says legislatures throughout the country should reexamine what it describes as permissive religious laws.

title: Brooklyn College Artist And Teacher Honored
description: Philip Pearlstein is one of those magic hybrid men, practicing two arts that seem to he at odds in nature and feeling and yet, in his case, locking them together in close harmony.

title: Indiana Publisher Honored
description: ANDERSON, Ind., May 8 (UPI)Richard G. Blacklidge, publisher of The Kokomo Tribune, was named recipient last night of the annual Ball State University Journalism Award. Mr. Blacklidge was cited for his recent election as president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: Mrs. Helen Brandt Receives Award for Settlement Work
description: Mrs. Helen Brandt, former president of the Victory Guild of New York Women, received the first Robert F. Kennedy Humanitarian Award last night for her community work for the University Settlement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that the national debate over segregation turns on the question whether the racial composition of public schools is the result of the bigotry of school boards or the benefice of realestate agents, one is left wondering what happened to Brown v. Board of Education. Perhaps it is too embarrassing to remember.

title: Comment From Texas
description: To the Editor: This is just a fan letter to tell Arthur Daley how right he is in his Plea for Students column of April 20.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  For almost four years, no prisoner has been marched from his death row cell past the other doomed prisoners and down to the execution chamber to be killed by hanging, gassing or electrocution. But for the 648 condemned men and women on penitentiary death rows across the country, Supreme Court decisions last week on appeals by two condemned men gave an indication that the moratorium may be almost over.

title: SIEGEL RESIGNING AS WNYC'S CHIEF
description: Seymour N. Siegel, who has guided the growth of WNYC for decades, announced his resIgnation yesterday following deep budget cuts made by the Lindsay Administration in operations of the Municipal Broadcasting Stations.

title: Freedom for Hess Urged
description: BONN, May 8 (Reuters)Two light planes flew over Bonn and Cologne today trailing banners calling for the release of Rudolf Hess, who is serving a life sentence for war crimes in Spandau Prison in Berlin.

title: Germans Suspicious of Money Parley After a History of Woes
description: BONN, May 8 A medieval German poem still seems to have pertinence here. Some of the lines read:

title: BRIDGE LEAD KEPT BY FRENCH TEAM World Champion Aces Also Stay Near Top in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 8The powerful French team and the world champion Aces retained the top places in the qualifying standings as a result of today's play in the Bermuda Bowl contest here.

title: HIGHBINDER IS 2D
description: Bold Reasoning overcame an awkward start to assume the lead early, hold it all the way, and win the $58,500 Withers mile by two lengths over Highbinder at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Japanese to Market RotaryEngine Auto
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8A new Japanese automotive name, Mazda, and a new kind of internal combustion engine will enter the California market next week.

title: New Life in the Nude and the Still Life
description: IN the right hands, those classic subjects in paintingthe nude, the still lifeare still capable of yielding up surprises. The nude figure, for example, that serves as the focal subject in the paintings of Nicholas Marsicano, now on view at the A.M. Sachs Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, is not the voluptuary image one ordinarily associates with that timehonored theme in painting.

title: Angels Top Indians, 52
description: CLEVELAND, May 8 (UPI) Roger Repoz smacked his second homer of the season and Syd O'Brien drove in two runs with a triple in a fourrun sixth inning that gave the California Angels a 52 victory over the Cleveland Indians today. It was Cleveland's fourth straight defeat.

title: CONSUMER ATTITUDES TOWARD DIRECTTOHOME MARKETING SYSTEMS. By Marvin A. Jolson. Dunellen Publishing. 166 pages. $8.50.
description: What are the best prospects for home selling! Or, to put it more bluntly, who are the best suckers? As a result of some surveys, the author finds the best prospects are youngunder 25 years of agehave less than $10,000 in annual income and are grateful for the attention.

title: BENGALIS DEPICT HOW A PRIEST DIED
description: JESSORE, Pakistan, May 8 In the Catholic hospital grounds of this smashed and burned city is the fresh grave of an Italian priestthe only foreigner known to have been slain in the fighting that has gripped East Pakistan for the past two months. The grave is that of the Rev. Mario Veronest, 56 years old, who worked at the Roman Catholic mission here for 18 years.

title: Donohue's Javelin Takes Schaefer Trans Am
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 8 Mark Donohue won today what could be called an amphibious 200mile race, winning the Schaefer TransAm in a downpour of rain that lasted the entire 2 hours 39 minutes of the race. The race was run over the 1.53mile road course of Lime Rock Park in the Litchfield Hills of western Connecticut.

title: Gerald C. Gross Is Dead at 67; Expert on Telecommunications
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 8 Gerald C. Gross, a leader in world telecommunications, died yesterday at a nursing home here. He was 67 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Stanford Crew Triumphs
description: OAKLAND, Aug. 8 (UPI)For the sixth straight year, the Stanford varsity crew defeated California. Stanford's lead was little more than a length, and the times were 6:26.7 and 6:31.8. California's junior varsity beat Stanford's, 6:35.8 and 6:42.7, and the Stanford freshmen beat their opponents, 6:26.8 and 6:36.6.

title: Lacrosse Tickets Available
description: Ticket orders are being accepted at Hofstra University for the first national collegiate lacrosse championship game June 5 at 2 P.M. Reserved seat tickets at $3 each are available from Walter Stone, Business Manager of Athletics, Hofstra University, Hempstead, L. I., 11550.

title: TRANSPLANT ADDS ZEST TO PATIENT
description: STANFORD, Calif. May 8 (AP)For a man of 46, Richard Cope of East Patehogue, L. I., is more active than the average man. For a heart transplant patient, what Mr. Cope does in a day is literally staggering.

title: Antiquities Society Finds Bonanza on L.I.
Clean Air
description: To the Financial Editor: The article (April 25) Little Progress in Cleaning Up the Air blames power companics for much air pollution which is not theirs.

title: The Trailer Comes Back
description: Mobile homes have come full circle.

title: Apollo Crew to Visit France
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Apollo 14 astronautsCapt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. and Capt. Edgar D. Mitchell of the Navy, and Lieut. Col. Stuart A. Roosa of the Air Forcewill attend the Paris air show May 30 to June 6 and visit a number of French cities, it was announced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times has recently reported on European concern as to the viability of the Eurodollar market. This concern stems from the nature of the Eurodollar system, which, like a domestic banking system, is based on fractional reserves.

title: Manhattan Bows in Track
description: Central Connecticut State defeated Manhattan College, 7875, yesterday in a dual track meet at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the Bronx. Bob Brady of Manhattan triumphed in the shotput with 54 feet 9 inches and in the discus throw with 158 feet.

title: VILLAGERS ATTACK CEYLONESE REBEL
description: ANDIRAMADA, Ceylon, May 8A small funeral pyre smoldered at the edge of this village today, sending smoke curling over the rice fields and the palms.

title: The Conquerors
description: Et Al.

title: Cultural Exchange Still On?
description: I READ with interest the article by John Browning entitled Don't Let Cultural Exchange Die! There is one misstatement of fact which I would like to correct. Mr. Browning writes: Right now the future of this [ the exchange] program is in jeopardy. Its renewal has been delayed for several months, and the outcome is still uncertain.

title: Moods of Farewell Mark Dance Works At the Theater Lab
description: Farewells, some long and clingy and others tossed by ironic sentiments and angular contrasts were the preoccupation Friday evening on Choreoconcerts Experimental Workshop program at the American Theater Lab. The moods varied but the individual approaches were clear and provocative.

title: Brother of Rights Victim Guilty in Florida Murder
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 8 (UPI)Ben Chaney, 18yearold brother of James Chaney, the slain civil rights worker, was found guilty of firstdegree murder today in Broward County Circuit Court.

title: Robin Aronsohn Planning Bridal
description: Miss Robin Aronsohn and Ivor Braka, vice president of Braka & Co., a banking firm here, and president of the Midland Credit Corporation, plan to he married June 27 in Congregational Shearith Israel, known as the SpanishPortuguese Synagogue.

title: Fund Redemptions Growing
description: The mutualfund industry may be approaching for the first time a situation to which a number of nervous investors, including some professionals, have long pointed with alarm  being forced to cash in more shares than it sold.

title: Book Ban Splits a Queens School District
description: The banning of a book about life In Spanish Harlem persists as a source of controversy in a middleclass area of Queens that is very much unlike Spanish Harlem.

title: Dollars, Eurodollars and G.N.P.
description: Prof. Edmund Phelps's attack (letter April 29) on Leonard Silk's perceptive appraisal of current economic policy problems in two preceding financial page columns amounts to a flat claim that Professor Phelps knows what's wrong and how to fix it. Actually. Professor Phelps mistakes the facts and prescribes a policy certain to make matters worse.

title: Air Cargo Thefts a Record
description: LAS VEGAS, May 8 (Reuters) Pilferage and hijackings of air cargo reached a record $110million last year, Senator Alan Bible said yesterday. The Nevada Democrat is chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee, which has held two years of investigations into cargo thefts.

title: Retired Queen Mary Begins New Career
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 8 (AP) Sightseers thronged aboard the Queen Mary today as the retired ocean liner made her debut as a tourist attraction.

title: Law Student Fiance Of Miss Sternberger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Sternherger of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Hollywood, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Irene Sternberger, to David Roy Freundlich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mike Freundlich of Jamaica Estates North, Queens. The wedding is planned for early fall.

title: CHICAGO'S BLACKS VEXED BY TRANSIT
description: CHICAGO, May 8The Chicago metropolitan area possesses one of the most efficient and comfortable commuter systems in the nationprovided the commuter follows the usual pattern of traveling from the suburbs to the inner city.

title: MONZON RETAINS TITLE, STOPPING BENVENUTI IN 3D
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 8  Nino Benvenuti was knocked out by his manager's hasty towelthrowing tonight before Carlos Monzon could finish the job.

title: NOT ALONE
description: TO THE EDITOR: Having left New York to run a college drama department the same year Robert Brustein left to take over Yale's, I have followed his Sunday Times progress reports with some care. Mr. Brustein, appears pleased with the prospects for the Yale Repertory Theater, which naturally pleases those who care about the future of the theater, but he need not think that he is entirely alone in this naughty world.

title: Facing Up in the South
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.During the twelve years Ruben Askew spent in the Florida Legislature, it was seldom possible even to get out of committee a severance tax on phosphate, lime rock and other minerals; Florida industry was just too powerful. But it's Governer Askew now, and the severance tax has been passed.

title: NO WORLD CONTROL SEEN ON POLLUTION
description: PRAGUE, May 8Delegates to a United Nations meeting here on environmental problems have indicated after a week of deliberations that they see no present need for any uniform system of pollution control.

title: Miss Tory Henry, Travel Agent, Is. Married to Eric Bidder Jr.
description: LEBANON, Pa., May 8 Miss Catherine Victoria Henry, known to her friends as Tory, was married here this noon to Eric Ridder Jr., whose father is publisher of The Journal of Commerce.

title: Nastase, Tiriac In Final
description: MADRID, May 8 (AP) Ilia Nastase defeated Marty Mulligan of Italy, 64, 63, 86, and Ion Tiriac downed Harald Elsembroich of West Germany, 61, 64, 61, today to set up an allRumanian final in the Madrid international tennis tournament.

title: Catholic Church Challenged in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, May 8  The Roman Catholic Church in Ireland, one of the most conservative bastions of the Catholic world, is coming under increased attack from both within and without.

title: Crisis Bonus?
description: There may be a silver lining or two in the gray clouds of the dollar crisis.

title: Tornado Blanks Darts
description: DALLAS, May 8 (AP)The Dallas Tornado defeated the Washington Darts, 20, tonight in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Mariner 8's Rocket Fails After Liftoff, Dooming Mars Trip
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 8 A planned Mariner 8 mission to orbit Mars failed tonight when its rocket tumbled wildly a few minutes after liftoff and dumped the $60million spacecraft into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Headliners
description: Thanks, but No Thanks

title: Carmen Is a Slut But Rather Dull
Fire Department Restricts Vehicles in Fuel Shortage
description: The Fire Department has curtailed building inspections and the movement of its vehicles other than to respond to fire alarms as a result of the gasoline delivery strike, now in its eighth day.

title: Princess
description: PRINCESS GINA VON LIECHTENSTEIN, the former Countess Gina von Wilczek, descendant of an ancient Silesian aristocratic family who married the ruler of Liechtenstein, Prince Franz Joseph II, on March 7, 1943, is the subject of a lovely portrait stamp from that tiny nation on June 11.

title: East Germany: Ulbricht Steps Part Way Out, But He'll Be Around
description: BERLINTo be honest, my decision didn't come easily after holding this job for two decades, Walter Ulbricht told his Central Committee last Monday in announcing that he was retiring from the key post of First Secretary of East Germany's ruling Communist party.

title: Much of Rome Has No Water But Lots of Garbage and Strikes
description: ROME, May 8A thirsty and dirty weekend began for Romans and tourists when water taps in half the city ran dry at noon today, coincidentally the fourth day of a sanitation workers strike.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE time has come for this column's second annual report on the progress, or lack thereof, in the planning for America's 200th birthday party  the Bicentennial observance of 1976. That anniversary of the start of the Revolutionary War, the Declaration of Independence, the Liberty Bell and all that, is racing toward the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission like the proverbial express train. No, that simile is no longer valid in the United States of America, where express trains no longer race along tracks. They sputter, rather, like a damp fuse, they sputter and crawl whether the sign on their engines reads Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Penn Central or Amtrack, the Madison Avenue restyled name for the Federal railroad corporation formerly called Railpax.

title: Son for the Nemeths
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Michael Nemeth of New York on Monday in the LyingIn Hospital. The child, whose father is executive vice president of Varied. Industrial Products, Inc., an electronics firm in Paterson, N. J., is named Marc Schuman. His mother is the former Miss Gale S. Numan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Numan of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: Sweetback': Does It Exploit Injustice?:' It's a Funny Old World'
description: THERE'S a very short, practically subliminal sequence in Melvin Van Peebles's new film, "Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song," in which a jaunty black shoeshine man polishes the shoe of his white customer by riding it with the seat of his pants. With his rear end more or less pointed at the face of the customer, the shoeshine man glides, half-dancing, back and forth across the toe of the shoe, mocking the shoe, his customer, himself, the conventional gestures of joyous sexual transport, and about 400 years of American social and economic history.The shoeshine man grins the traditional good-darkie grin and the customer laughs, mostly with embarrassment. The white man knows he's being made a fool of, and yet his shoes are being shined. The black man is completely aware of the spectacle he's creating, but he's performing the service for which a contract was made, while maintaining a franchise, ever so shaky, on his own sovereign independence."Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song," however, is not about the shoeshine man. The film, which Van Peebles dedicates to "all of the black brothers and sisters who have had enough of The Man," is about a black man who refuses to go on role-playing, who, quite literally, stands up to assert himself. Sweet Sweetback (Van Peebles), having been raised from childhood in a black, Southern California whorehouse, is the establishment's Lucky Pierre, the indefatigable star of its nightly exhibitions who, through no fault of his own, is forced to beat up a couple of white cops and then escape to the Mexican border.The movie is the story of Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Flight, accompanied by lots of soundtrack song, a journey made eventually intolerable not only by the hardships and the duplicity (of even white counter-ulturalists like the Hells Angels), but by the simplistic sensationalism of the treatment and the eye-disorienting visual style that substitutes film school technical complexities (such as the superimposition of double, triple and quadruple images) for dramatic content. Instead of dramatizing injustice, Van Peebles merchandizes it. With the exception of perhaps a dozen scenes, the movie is composed almost entirely of the sort of fancy montages with which television the goal. Still to be found are a director and a choreographer to guide a cast of about 25.HAPPY JOURNEYArvin Brown, who has just directed the remarkably successful revival of O'Neill's monumental "Long Day's Journey Into Night," was 24 (six years ago) when he staged his first full-length play for the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven"Long Day's Journey into Night." Included in the cast then were Mildred Dunnock and Frank Langella and, Brown recalls, "I was scared to death. I can never be grateful enough to Millie for the warmth and support she gave me then."In the years since, he has become artistic director of Long Wharf and during his regime, which began with the 1968-69 season when Long Wharf's fortunes had touched bottom, he has succeeded in raising the theater to national status: mounted two world premieres of Gorky plays never done before in English, "Country People" and, this season, "Yegor Bulichov," in which Morris Carnovsky played the title role, as well as Robert Anderson's latest, "Solitaire Double "Solitaire." In September, at the invitation of the Edinburgh Festival, he takes Long Wharf to Scotland where it will present the Anderson play prior to its New York entry and a revival of "You Can't Take it With You," with which Long Wharf will launch its new season.A man standing no more than 5 feet 5 inches, with thinning hair and a soft, gentle manner of speaking, Brown's assumption of the director's mantle is attributable in part to the fact that from childhood he knew he wished to be involved with the theater. But, as he grew older, he also knew he could not be an actor. "Actually," he says, "my original aim was to be a writer-teacher." With that in view, he took his bachelor of arts degree at Stanford, received a Fulbright in theater research techniques which he utilized at the University of Bristol in England. There he did his first directing, then took a master's degree from Harvard on a Wilson Fellowship and finally took off to the Yale Drama School. He was only months away from the Yale degree when two of his schoolmates, Harlan Kleiman and Jon Jory, raised $125,000 and launched Long Wharf, taking Brown with them. Brown took charge of the children's theater. It was at the end of that first season, in 1965, that he got his shot at O'Neill.His approach to "Long Day's Journey" then was pretty much what it was for the current edition, which stars Robert Ryan, Stacy Keach and Geraldine Fitzgerald. "I try to get the material out of the actor rather than lead an actor to the material," he says. "Especially in a play like this you can't have a concept. You try to find out what in an actor resembles the role he is playing and then help him develop it out of himself. I don't believe in imposing an abstract idea on an actor. I try also to develop a rehearsal atmosphere, by which I mean I want my actors to feel free to expose themselves. In this way they make mistakes that I can see. Only the director can have a sense of the total structure of the play. If an actor has a sense of the structure, then he's not sufficiently involved in his own work." And, thinks Brown, his own involvement with writing helps him to understand better how words are put together, how and what the playwright wished to achieve.Will Long Wharf lose him to the allure of the big time? At this writing, hardly, Brown has no wish to leave the comforts of his home base, the support of a growing audience, the loyalty of the group of actors he has formed around him or the house he has by the sea. And his wife, the talented Joyce Ebert, a member of the Long Wharf company, feels much the same way. "Besides," says Brown, with a happy smile, "she really likes keeping house and we want to have a family. You can't do that too well when the two of you are running off in all directions."TOURIST TIPAs the season of the itchy feet begins to engulf us, theater buffs bound for England this summer should keep the Chichester Festival in mind. What promises to be one of the most striking sessions since the festival began nine years ago opened the other day with Margaret Leighton appearing as Mrs. Malaprop in Sheridan's "The Rivals." On May 19 Lucienne Hill's translation of Jean Anouilh's "Dear Antoine" gets under way with Edith Evans and Joyce Redman. John Gielgud and Anna Calder-Marshall will be seen in "Caesar and Cleopatra," commencing July 7. Robert E. Sherwood's "Reunion in Vienna" shows off Miss Leighton and Nigel Patrick, beginning July 21. Running nine weeks, the season will be Chichester's longest. . . . The English Stage Company will be providing its patrons with a trio of aces starting May 24Lynn Redgrave, Barbara Ferris and Anna Massey who have signed for the new production of David Hare's "Slag." . . . What could be termed the British equivalent of New York's Lincoln Center or Washington's John F. Kennedy, has finally won approval, and construction of the Barbican Arts Center is under way. When it is completed, along about 1976-77, it will provide a theater for the Royal Shakespeare Company, whose London base has been the Aldwych: a concert hall for the London Symphony, a home for the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, a library, and an art gallery.ROUNDUP"The Incomparable Max!" by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee, will be offered next season by Michael Abbott. Dealing with the English critic-caricaturist, it will star Richard Kiley. . . . Robert Fryer, among whose Broadway productions have been "Wonderful Town," "Redhead" and "Auntie Mame," has succeeded Elliott Martin as the managing director of the Los Angeles Ahmanson Theater . . . A World Shakespeare Congress, claimed to be the first, will be held in Vancouver, British Columbia, Aug. 20-28, as part of the Canadian province's centennial year. Sponsoring the conclave, which is expected to be among the largest gatherings of Shakespeare scholars ever held, will be Simon Fraser University.

title: Printed Fabrics Dominating Fashion
description: Prints  in a variety of patterns and colors  dominate the fashion scene today and seem destined to have even greater influence in the months to come. Prints are leading a revival of woven cotton fabrics even while printed knit fabrics are in greater demand.

title: PRESIDENT ELECTED BY BUILDING TRADES
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The executive council, of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations elected Frank Bonadio as president of the department.

title: Imada Posts 71 for 210 For 2Shot Lead in Japan
description: IKEDA, Japan, May 8 (AP)Kenosuke Imada of Japan shot a oneunderpar 71 today and maintained a twostroke lead after three rounds of the $28,000 Dunlop international golf tournament.

title: VERNON IS FIRST IN LOUCKS TRACK
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 8 They held a track meet here today on the high school field. That was the first mistake made by the officials of the fourth annual Glenn D. Loucks Memorial Games.

title: TWO VOTES FOR McGOVERN
description: To THE EDITOR: It came as a surprise and some annoyance to us that Richard Reeves, in his article, Any Number Can Play Scenario (April 11), completely left out Senator George McGovern as a serious Presidential candidate in his list of principal actors in the beginning of the article.

title: Doctor Finds Most People's Tics Are Harmless
description: Everybody does it, and Dr. Oliver W. Sacks studies it.

title: Heath's Meeting With Pompidou Fateful for the Future of Britain
description: LONDON, May 8  Prime Minister Heath's meeting with President Pompidou of France is likely to he a fateful one for Mr. Heath, his party and his country

title: Order vs. Constitution
description: Shortly before Rennie Davis was arrested for organizing last week's Spring Offensive, he was heard to grumble that President Nixon had suspended the Constitution. Davis was referring to the Administration's tactic of sweeping the streets and detaining those arrested long enough to keep them from returning to the bridges and traffic circles they sought to block. The tactic has been credited by many with having prevented a breakdown in the traffic system. It has also been condemned by some as having created a breakdown in the justice systema breakdown deliberately engineered by the Government to buy valuable time by delaying the processing and release of thousands of arrested demonstrators.

title: Sour Land
description: This book will be well received by the child who has never known a black person except in legend or myth. Unlike Sounder, Mr. Armstrong's first book, which was painful, stunning poetry and made me cry, Sour Land is a crushing disappointment. It presents a boringly supergood black man, Moses Waters, whose main purpose in life seems to be to make himself agreeable to the Stones, the white family he sort of eases himself into (at their gentle urging, of course), somewhere in Virginia. Waters is a quiet, meditative, older man with graying hair and a philosophic turn of mind. He's seen troubles, sure, but you'd never hear him complain about them. He's wise, steady, dependable and tells exciting and often sad stories to Anson Stone's motherless children. And though he's a fine schoolteacher and speaks perfect English in a stiff, rather rhetorical style, he is easily recognizable as guess who?

title: MAGEE RECEIVES ACCLAIM IN COURT
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., May 7 They came at first out of their support for Angela Davis but it is Ruche11 Magee, the inmate from San Quentin prison, they now cheer in the courtroom.

title: Players With Leadership Trait Strengthen Penn State's Eleven
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 8Penn State's football team went through a readjustment last spring as most of the frontline players who had carried the Nittany Lions through an unbeaten string of 30 games were no longer around to provide needed direction.

title: Knicks Switch Site For Training Camp
description: The New York Knickerbockers announced yesterday that they would train for the 197172 National Basketball Association season at Monmouth College, West Long Branch, N.J.

title: ScholarAthletes
description: To THE EDITOR: In his April 20 column, Plea for Students, Arthur Daley wrote, It's probably half a century since any college authorities even thought of returning to the simplicities and the niceties of our earliest traditions. Once upon a time the members of all athletic teams were students who attended college primarlly for an education.

title: Peking Residents Ride the Subway Just for Fun
description: PEKING, May 8For two cents you can ride the entire 15 miles of the Peking subway from the Military Museum station in the outskirts to Peking Station and back. Every day, officials say, some 60,000 people take the ride just for the fun of it.

title: Wrigley: A 7Cent Bonanza
description: CHICAGO  Back during the nineteenthirties, when it was often hard to find anything to laugh at, there was a popular jingle that pondered the difference between a gumchewing secretary and a cudchewing cow.

title: Crime Thrives on Bootlegged Cigarettes
description: Cigarettes are the morning cough, the other half of a cup of coffee. But increasingly across the country they are also a major source of worry for revenuehungry state legislatures and of profit for organized crime.

title: Cubs Beat Expos, 30
description: MONTREAL, May 8 (UPI) Joe Pepitone hit a tworun homer in the sixth inning tonight as the Chicago Cubs shut out the Montreal Expos, 30, behind Ken Holtzman's threehit pitching.

title: Strawberry salute
description: STRAWBERRY NUT TORTE

title: College Breaks Ground
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May (AP)Officials of Babson College have broken ground for the first two buildings in a $6.25million education center. One building is named for Paul and Edith Babson of Boston and Sarasota, Fla., who gave $750,000 toward its costs.

title: Shell's Chief Typifies World's Oilmen
description: Oil is the most international of all industries.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: It was with dismay that I read Edward Albee's hysterical remarks, particularly what he said about The Philanthropist, Christopher Hampton's beautifully and wittily written comedy, All Over was a play everyone in the theater awaited with considerable excitement, and obviously an important one for the author. In these circumstances one truly sympathizes with Albee that it should turn out to be such a gigantic and spectacular flop.

title: Festivals and Awards
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., will open its annual Dogwood Festival tomorrow. It will continue through May 23. Scheduled during the season when the area's dogwood is in bloom, the festival will feature a variety of New England church fair activities.

title: 42 Violations Charged
description: SAIGON, Sunday, May 9 (APIAllied headquarters accused the Vietcong today of 42 violations of the ceasefire for Buddha's birthday.

title: Registration to Begin for Fresh Air Fund Summer
description: One day this week 9yearold Laura Dailey will go with her mother to a small church in East Harlem and there; in a crowded basement room, she and dozens of other children will register for the 1971 Fresh Air Fund.

title: Drivein Snack Bars Mature
description: The drivein snack bar, closely identified with the young, is growing older with them. The appeal no longer is to teenagers alone. Increasingly, it is to young marrieds and their children.

title: SOVIET PIPELINE LEAK REPORTED IN CONTROL
ElisabethAnn Boyd Bride at St. James'
description: Miss ElisabethAnn Boyd, daughter of Mrs. Locke Boyd of New York and the late Dr. JohnIlyer Boyd, was married here yesterday to Robert Adrian Failey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Failey of Oil City, Pa., and Winter Park, Fla. The Rev. Addison Grant Noble, who performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church, also performed the ceremony when the bride's parents were married in 1937 in the chapel at Williams College.

title: Death: Making It Easier for Patient And Family
description: The 58yearold woman was dying of cancer. She had faced her illness with courage and dignity, maintaining a cheerful facade. But during her last hospital admission she became severely, depressed.

title: The Israelis Founders and Sons. By Amos Eton. Illustrated. 359 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.
description: So moving was the scene in Jerusalem on May 2, 1968, that some people in the vast crowd wept. Many more felt their blood quicken in a mood of rare exaltation. . . . Few Israelis could remember a more massive celebration, nor one as touching or spontaneous as this; yet it was overcast by a strange melancholy.

title: Psychologists Report Finds New Towns in West Germany Boring to Children
description: NUREMBERG, West Germany, April 23In the new towns of West Germany, amid soaring rectangular shapes of apartment houses with shaded walks, big lawns and fencedin play areas, the children for whom much of this has been designed apparently feel isolated, regimented and bored.

title: Rogers and Pope Paul Confer at the Vatican
description: ROME, May 8 (Reuters)Secretary of Stale William P. Rogers spent. 45 minutes toddy with Pope Paul VI.

title: Troy Hopes to Give a Key Role To New 18to21 Queens Voters
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. of Queens, newest of the city's five Democratic county leaders, plans to put the new 18to21yearold voters to work to make Queens a major factor In state politics.

title: Way Uptown In Another World By Shane Stevens. 302 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $6.95.
description: The most adequate response to Shane Stevens's second holocaust novel would be a review written in the language of the book itself. Rolling Stone might print it, but The Times would require so many bleeps that the piece would end up sounding like one of John Cage's more esoteric compositions. That evidently means we can't deal with Way Uptown in Another World on anything approaching its own terms, but must fall back on the same prudent terminology we'd apply to such Establishment figures as Hubert Selby and Ed Bullins. Okay, we'll work within those limits.

title: HEAVY RAIN FALLS ON THE EVERGLADES
description: MIAMI, May 8 (AP)Cloudbursts splashed rain at the rate of five inches an hour today on the parched heart of the Everglades, where 40,000 acres of grasslands have been besieged by fires.

title: Revolutionary Priest
description: Agitator, organizer, guerrilla, as well as cleric

title: SOVIET SAYS SST IS IN PRODUCTION
description: MOSCOW, May 8The designer of the Soviet Union's supersonic plane, the. TU144, said today that it was now in assemblyline production. but he did not say when commercial operation was scheduled to begin.

title: Miller, 2d in the Masters, To Play in Canadian Open
description: MONTREAL, May 8 (Canadian Press)Johnny Miller, 24 years old, who tied Jack Nicklaus for second place at this year's Masters tournament, will compete in the $150,000 Canadian open golf championship.

title: 16,000 Sign in Queens For 18to21Year Vote
description: Sixteen thousand people in the 18to21yearold range have registered to vote so far in Queens County, according to figures released by the Queens County New Democratic Coalition Issues Committee. The citywide total was put at 73,000.

title: Viveca Lindfors Replies:
description: AFABULOUS Russian analyst once said to her patient, You make littlehere and little there and the result is only had smell. It just about sums up my reaction to Paul Avila Mayer's piece as well as his behavior during an otherwise most rewarding experience with August Strindberg's Dance of Death.

title: KOOSMAN TO FACE CARLTON OF CARDS
A $4Million Drawbridge Planned for Westchester
description: The state's Department of Transportation will replace an old bridge in Westchester County with a double drawbridge at an estimated cost of $4million, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday.

title: James W. McHugh, Head Of Amusements Magazine
description: CHICAGO, May 8James W. McHugh, publishing director of Amusement Business, a weekly news magazine for the amusement field, died Wednesday.

title: Wichita State, Marshall Get Rose Bowl Donation
description: PASADENA, Calif., May 8 (UPI)Participants in the 1971 Rose Bowl football game announced they had donated $10,000 each to Wichita State and Marshall Universities, whose football teams were decimated in airplane crashes last fall.

title: Singing Songs & Swigging Beer With Austrian Hikers
Funds for Rail Line Sought
description: HARTFORD, May 8 (UPI) Connecticut has applied for $25.5million in Federal funds to continue rail modernization on the New Haven commuter line, according to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill. The modernization phase calls for rehabilitation of 92 commuter cars, improvement of the electrical system, and expansion and improvement of service and maintenance facilities.

title: Two Men and a Lion: A Wildlife Dilemma
description: WESTCLIFFE, Colo., May 8Donald P. Tesitor and Bob J. Peters, both licensed hunting guides, are men who lead others to the kill and many times in the last 10 years they have shared the brotherhood of the hunt.

title: Negro Leads Charlotte Voting; May Become Mayor Pro Tern
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 8 A Negro apartment manager, Fred D. Alexander, was the top votegetter among candidates for the sevenmember city council yesterday and is expected to be named Mayor pro tens.

title: 15,000 Rally in Capital to Urge Vietnam Victory
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Several thousand people, including such varied groups as New York construction workers and Fundamentalist Bible classes of Appalachia, demonstrated peacefully here today in behalf of a military victory in Vietnam.

title: Visa to U.S. Barred by Manchu Law
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has made a ruling, based on what it asserts was Manchu dynasty law, that may prevent hundreds, and possibly thousands, of Chinese women from joining their families in the United States.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: The abortionreferral agencies appear to have been shortchanged in my article because, for lack of space, the following paragraph was deleted:

title: Mary Lueders, Singer, to Wed
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8  Miss Mary Cross Lueders, a mezzosoprano with the New York City Opera Company, and Frank Andrew Corsaro, a stage director with the company, plan to he married May 30.

title: To Curb War Power
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Boys Group to Honor Eastment Wednesday
description: The Christian Brothers Boys Association will honor George T. Eastment on Wednesday at Manhattan College. The former track and field coach, dean of men and director of personnel at Manhattan from 1945 to 1970 has been chosen boy of the year.

title: AQUARIUS DECLARED OCEAN RACE VICTOR
description: ENSENADA, Mexico, May 8 (AP)Aquarius, a 35foot sloop sailed by Dr. John Holiday of the Long Beach (Calif.) Yacht Club, was declared the overall winner today in unofficial handicap results of the NewporttoEnsenada race.

title: Queens Man Honored For Pursuing Robbers
description: A 46yearold Jackson Heights man who attempted to thwart the escape of four bank robbers earlier this year has received the Queens District Attorney's Honor Award.

title: College Invites Evers
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 8 (AP)Student leaders at the College of William and Mary have invited Charles Evers, black Mayor of Fayetteville, Miss., to speak on campus June 6, the same day Representative Thomas N. Downing, Democrat of Virginia, delivers the cornnencement address.

title: SISCO FLIES BACK TO SEE EGYPTIANS
description: CAIRO, May 8Joseph J. Sisco, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, returned to Cairo tonight to report to President. Anwar elSadat on the outcome of consultations in Israel by Secretary of State William P. Rogers on efforts to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: DRAKE WINS CROWN IN MISSOURI VALLEY
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 8 (AP) Drake, placing in every event but the discus, won the 61st Missouri Valley Conference track and field championships today at Wichita State University.

title: CATHOLICS STUDY NEW AID TO POOR
description: The formation of an Institute for Human Development to propose new ways to help the poor has been announced by Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: IVY CONCERT BANDS TEAM UP WITH GUSTO
description: Princeton and Harvard played Friday night, but their only goal was making music and the scores were those of Shostakovich, Elgar, et al. The Concert Bands of the two universities each presented a 30minute program at Philharmonic Hall, then joined forces for a roofraising second half.

title: A Plan to Get M.D.'s Into the Ghettos
description: Medical education has, with occasional exceptions, remained the preserve of the welltodo because of the time and expense involved in preparing for the M.D. This situation, in turn, has aggravated the problem of providing proper medical care for the poor, particularly in the decaying inner cities.

title: Lord Malvern, Prime Minister Of Rhodesia for 20 Years, Dies
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 8 Lord Malvern, a former Prime Minister of Rhodesia, died at his home here today, He was 87 years old.

title: Helene Duncan To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John V. Duncan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Hollis Duncan, to Peter Durfor Bilks, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hyland Dilks of Philadelphia. A July wedding is planned.

title: FOUR PLAN TO QUIT DISTRICT 3 BOARD
description: Two of the eight members of the District 3 Community School Board on the West Side plan to resign because, they say, the board has been ineffectual. Two other members will leave the board for personal reasons.

title: Life for a Life
description: This crisp tour de force reverses the old Oriental tradition that he who saves a life is thereafter responsible for it. Laurence Carpenter, a London businessman on the way home from the latest of his squalid little affairs (his wife's description), pulls a drowning man from the water. The man is a professional murderer known us Ossie, and he wants to repay his savior with his specialty. In fact, he insists on it.

title: New B.&B. President Is Business Oriented
description: John S. Bowen's first real job in an agency was as a newbusiness getter in Boston where, as he remembers, Harvard Grad advertisers gave their accounts to Harvard Grad admen.

title: Jane Rosenthal to Be Bride June 27
description: TRENTON, May 8 Miss Jane Marilyn Rosenthal and Marshall Pressman will be married June 27.

title: THAT FIVELETTER WORD FOR ORGANIZED CRIME
description: To THE EDITOR: After reading Fred J. Cook's article, The Black Mafia Moves Into the Numbers Racket (April 4), I begin to understand the anguish of my fellow ItaloAmericans at the use of the names Cosa Nostra and Mafia.

title: ROGERS FINDS GAP ON SUEZ REDUCED
description: ROME, May 8Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that he had found some narrowing of the gap between the Arab and Israeli positions on reopening the Suez Canal during his discussions this, week in Egypt and Israel.

title: Young Gallic classicist
description: To the fashionwise, French classics are not the works of Voltaire and his ilk, but those of Sonia Rykiel. This young French designer's cool, calm and thoroughly classic clothes are collected as if they were rare editions. (And rare editions they often are, disappearing from shelves almost as soon as they land there.) Miss Rykiel works on a basics principle, often designing no more than three or four basic shapes to make up an entire collection. But those shapes, including her nowfamous, tight little sweaters, all work together and are classic enough to go on almost indefinitely.

title: American Theater Dead or Alive?
description: TO THE EDITOR: THE American theater? In 1971? Who cares? asks Robert Brustein. Let me tell you about Brustein's Complaint, an affliction which takes the form of an outburst against the New York theater. Named after the director of the Yale Repertory and Drama School, this lashing out at New York often follows disppointment in New Haven, such as Yale's recent Macbeth. Symptoms include a dismissal of commercial theater as tired and of the avant garde as faddish, and a blind thrust at the Village Voice critics for being virtually indistinguishable spreaders of the latest gospel according to St. Mark's Place.

title: Reggio Calabria Bombing
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, May 8 (Reuters)  A bomb destroyed a store and two cars here last night.

title: Marian McPartland Puts Jazz to Work for L.I. Students
description: WEST BABYLON, L.I., May 8  Marian McPartland is a jazz pianist and, by the nature of her work, she is normally just going to bed at 6 A.M.

title: Penny Stocks Boom Again
description: SALT LAKE CITYPessimists to the contrary, the recession, and possibly inflation, may be over.

title: Naggers vs. Nagged
description: THERE is nothing quite like a hearty national study or survey for satisfying the appetite of the professional pessimist. For present instance, it has been found that between November 1968 and January 1971 the percentage of Americans choosing television as the most believable mass medium jumped five points to 49 per cent.

title: Alaska Land Hearings End
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) A House Interior subcommittee ended hearings yesterday on proposed legislation to settle aboriginal land claims of Alaska natives. Final witnesses at the weeklong series of hearings before the Indian Affairs Subcommittee urged that any land grants to the 55,000 natives come out of the 103 million acres given to Alaska under its Statehood Act.

title: Moriches Bay Dredging
description: To THE EDITOR: The article in the March 28 boat section, Clam Fleet on Ecology Reef, completely skirts the issue of the reasoning behind the dredging of Moriches Bay.

title: Football Date Changed
description: MIAMI, May 8 (AP)  The NorthSouth college allstar football game will be played the night of Dec. 27 this year instead of Christmas Day, according to Bill Brown, game chairman for the sponsoring Mahi Shriners.

title: New Sound of Summer: The Roar of Minibikes
description: BAITING HOLLOW, L.I., May 8Two minibikes burst out of a clump of weeds and wild grass on a field here the other day and roared by a small cluster of gaily dressed young people.

title: The Board's Actions
description: Since 1960, the Accounting Principles Board has issued 19 rulings (or opinions as they're called) on topics as diverse as accounting for taxes, leases, pensions, mergers and banksnot to mention a voluminous set of guidelines for presenting earnings per share, rules for accounting for convertible bonds, and the requirement for a statement of the source and application of funds.

title: It's a Funny Old World
description: LOOKING backward was a mistake for Mrs. Lot. But, for writers, it has been a helpful habit over the centuries. Latest among the overtheshoulder lookers are Anthony Newley and Leslie Bricusse, who once proclaimed, Stop the WorldI Want to Get Off. Now they are going right back to the dawn of time for a new musical, It's a Funny Old World We Live In, But the World's Not Entirely to Blame. To make their point, the team focusing on the chronicle of a small family unit and its struggle to cope with life through the ages. The family unit, whose head will be acted by Newley, will not, however, get older, It simply will he transplanted from age to age and even from one nationality to another.

title: Mr. Pow Wow, $5.20, Wins $20,000 Chicagoan by Neck
description: CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)Mr. Pow Wow outhustled Felonious to win the $20,000 Chicagoan Handicap by a neck before 21,217 at Arlington Park today.

title: Robert Yunich. Becomes Fiance Of Miss Gitlitz
description: The engagement of Miss Libby Sue Gitlitz to Robert Hardie Yunich, son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Yunich of Scarsdale, N. Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gitlitz of Brooklyn.

title: Nets Get Rights to Roche
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May (UPI)The Kentucky Colonels announced today they had sold their draft rights to John Roche, who starred at South Carolina, to the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association. The New York native was the first draft choice of the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association.

title: YANKS TURN BACK WHITE SOX IN 11TH
description: CHICAGO, May 8The Army says it makes men out of boys, but it apparently also has made a hitter out of Thurman Munson again.

title: Vietnam:
description: WASHINGTON  Beyond the din of strident protest, the flailing of police nightsticks and the sting of tear gas here last week could be seen a new form of antiwar dissent.

title: Kimball First in Marathon As Mueller Runs Second
description: SYRACUSE, May 8Mike Kimball of the Summitt Athletic Club, Akron, Ohio, won the First Trust Marathon today in 2 hours 24 minutes 43 seconds. The 30yearold Kimball finished a halfmile ahead of Ken Mueller of the Boston Athletic Association, who was clocked in 2:27:05.

title: The Infinite River
description: Et Al.

title: ON ALBEE
description: Drama Mailbag

title: POOR SAID TO LACK FAMILY PLANNING
description: A countybycounty nationwide survey has indicated that only one out of five of the country's medically indigent women of childbearing age was receiving subsidized family planning services in 1969.

title: Nixon Backs Gateway Recreation Area
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Af ter months of delay, the Nixon Administration has decided to seek Congressional approval for a somewhat altered Gateway National Recreation Area ac the entrance to New York Harbor.

title: COODY KEEPS LEAD BY A SHOT ON 207
description: DALLAS, May 8 Charles Coody, the Masters champion, continued to lead the $125,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic today, but his advantage was reduced to one stroke. With a third round of 72, two over par, Coody's 54hole total of 207 was just a step ahead of a hardpressing trio.

title: NEW TORN STATE'S ABORTION LAW (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR: As a native New Yorker, it was with shame that I read A Report on the Abortion Capital of the Country (April 11), by Susan Edmiston. The article stated that Kings County Hospital allows abortions up to the 24th week of pregnancy, apparently on the supposition that a premature fetus this young would have little chance of survival if actually subjected to birth. The article also stated that the fetus is generally considered viable at 28 weeks.

title: Escalator Clauses Are Inflationary
description: Cost  of  living escalator clauses, a major goal of organized labor in collective bargaining over the next two years, are inflationary.

title: LAWYER TO HEAD JEWISH SERVICE
description: When 39yearold Lawrence B. Buttenwieser is elected tomorrow as the 21st president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, he will be the second youngest man to achieve that post in the 54yearold history of the organization.

title: Uplands
description: Life is an affair of people not of places. But for me, Wallace Stevens wrote, life is an affair of places and that is the trouble. That trouble, that strain in American writing has continued to prompt some of our best verse: solitary testings of the mind against a landscape, as if these were the only really telling encounters. Anyone who responds to Frost or Stevens, or knows A. R. Ammons's earlier books, will be prepared for Uplands, for its tough wry explorations, as well as for the intensity and buoyancy with which Ammons makes a familiar kind of poetry his own.

title: Editor Named in Georgia
description: MACON, Ga., May 8 (AP)Don E. Carter has been named executive editor of The Macon Telegraph and The Macon News. Mr. Carter, 53 years old, resigned as executive editor and vice president of The Record of Hackensack, N.J., to take the post.

title: A'S GET EPSTEIN FROM SENATORS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 8 (AP)The Washington Senators traded a relief pitcher, Darold Knowles, and a first baseman, Mike Epstein, to the Oakland Athletics for three players, including a first baseman, Don Mincher, last night.The trade was announced here after the Senators defeated the Twins, 65, in a game saved by Knowles.

title: ENGLISH BACH GROUP PERFORMS AT HUNTER
description: It must be assumed that Paul Steinitz's Bach Society and Players of London make a useful contribution to the musical life of their native city, but, on the basis of the concert they gave at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Friday night, it was difficult to understand why they were brought all the way from England for performances here.

title: HOSPITAL PAVILION OPENS IN MANHASSET
description: MANHASSET, L. 1., May 8 North Shore Hospital has begun to staff and operate its new Cohen Pavilion that adds 120 beds and many new services to the 170bed hospital complex.

title: Russian Criticizes U. S. Plan for a Tour of the Outer Planets by Unmanned Craft
description: MOSCOW, May 8A Soviet space scientist questions whether the grand tour missions of American unmanned spacecraft planned for the late 1970's are the most effective way of exploring the distant outer planets of the solar system.

title: The Speculators
description: LONDONIf you had a spare $10million last week, you could have made $200,000 by speculating on the future of the West German mark.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Announcements

title: Great Mystery Is First
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May (AP)B. A. Dario's Great Mystery scored an easy victory in the $20,000 Louisville Handicap today at Churchill Downs.

title: Big Swinger Pays $14
description: BOSTON, May 8 (AP)Big Swinger scored by a neck today in the $22,475 My Fair Lady stakes at Suffolk Downs. He paid $14, $5.20 and $3.40,

title: HOYA CREW TAKES DAD PAIL REGATTA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8Favored by a steady six to seven knot tailwind that helped it spin over the placid Schuylkill at a merry clip, Georgetown's varsity eight captured top honors in the Dad Vail Regatta today.

title: Democrats in Youth Drive
description: A drive to encourage 18to21yearolds to register as Democrats was announced yesterday by the New York City Democratic Committee. The campaign will attempt to emphasize that by failing to register as Democrats young people are giving up a major opportunity to participate in shaping the direction of the party and of the city.

title: Many Students Are Turning Away From Protest to Seek Own Goals
Red Sox Top Brewers, 4 to 2, for Sixth in Row as Smith Drives in Four Runs
description: MILWAUKEE, May 8 (UPI) Reggie Smith drove in all of Boston's runs with a home run and a pair of singles today and Sonny Silbert won his fifth game without a loss as the Red Sox defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 42, for their sixth consecutive victory.

title: ANNE EATON DIES; WROTE FOR YOUNG
description: Anne T. Eaton, author, children's librarian and a former editor of the children's department of The New York Times Book Review, died Wednesday at her home, 118 East 31st Street. She would have been 90 years old yesterday.

title: STARS WIN FIRST IN SOCCER BY 20
description: ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP)The St. Louis Stars notched their first North American Soccer League victory of the season tonight with a 20 decision over the Montreal Olympics.

title: National Notes
description: Blackout: a turning off of the stage lighting to separate scenes in a play; a period of darkness enforced as a precaution against air raids.

title: Ryun Says It All, Crediting Wife for His Comeback
description: EUGENE, Ore., May 8 (AP) Anne Ryun, only four months a bride, was shocked when her world champion husband gave up in the middle of a national title race.

title: Site for Women's Golf Picked
description: CHICAGO, May 8 (AP)The 1972 Women's Western amateur golf will be played July 17 through 22 at the Blue Hills Country Club in Kansas City.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Star of Here Are Ladies I WAS recently offered $100,000 to do television commercials here, voiceovers in which I would heard but not seen. I turned the offer down. It's not that I wouldn't love to get $100,000 to bring home to Ireland, because there are loads of things I could do with that money. But I won't do television commercials, no matter how much money I could make from them.

title: ARE LESBIANS SICK? (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR: I should like to clarify my views which I believe were inadequately presented in The Disciples of Sappho, Updated, by Judy Klemesrud (March 28).

title: Don Price Jr., Harvard Dean, Weds Mrs. Fels
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8Mrs. Harriet Sloane Fels, widow of William C. Fels, former president of Bennington College, was married here this afternoon to Don K. Price Jr., professor of government and dean of the John Fitzgerald Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. The Rev. Charles P. Price, an Episcopal clergyman and preacher to the university, performed the ceremony in his study at the Harvard Memorial Church.

title: Labor Radical
description: De Caux had to live down his comfortable youth in New Zealand and at British public schools: when he landed in America he rode the rails with the Wobblies, worked in harvesting fields and packing houses, did turns as millhand and deckhand, edited labor publications, ending up as the first national publicity director of the C.T.O. SomewhereDe Caux is vaguehe slipped in and out of the Communist party. This colorful, sensitive autobiography illuminates the history of the U.S. labor movement of the past half century from the viewpoint of one who was at its center.

title: Carolyn F. McInerney Bride Of Francis Gerard McGrath
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., May 8The marriage of Miss Carolyn Frances McInerney to Francis Gerard McGrath took place in St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church here today. Msgr. Timothy F. O'O'Leary performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Joseph Scannell.

title: Ohio Bans Bass Fishing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 8 (UPI)Gov. John J. Gilligan banned commercial white bass fishing in Lake Erie yesterday for 60 days because of a high level of mercury contamination. The Governor said that mercury contamination in white bass for the last few weeks has run as high as 91 parts per million.

title: Miss Lesley Clare Vine, Writer, Engaged to Lawrence P. Lavan
description: Announcement has been made here by Dr. and Mrs. Russel Stockman Vine of Farington, England, of the engagement of their daughter Miss Lesley Clare Vine, to Lawrence Peter Levan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter I. B. Lavan of Palm Beach Fla., and New York.

title: U.S.C. DOWNS U.C.L.A., SETS 5 MEET MARKS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (UPI) The University of Southern California came through with five meet and five school records today to defeat the University, of California, Los Angeles, 7570, in a Pacific8 track and field meet at Westwood before a capacity crowd of 12,584.

title: Lunokhod's Adventure
description: MOSCOW, May 8 (UPI)The Russians disclosed today that man and machine, separated by more than 200,000 miles, overcame the hostility of the alien moon when their robot exploring vehicle became stuck in crater.

title: Elizabeth Dunham Plans Wedding
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., May 8Miss Elizabeth Anne Dunham, a music teacher at the New Lincoln School in New York, will be married May 29 to Hugh Alexander Blachly, who is studying for a doctorate in musicology at Columbia University.

title: Gates of Jerusalem
description: INDEPENDENCE D A Y stamps of Israel depict historic gates of Jerusalemthe Jaffa, The New, the Damascus and the Herod. The stamps have been issued in two formsin 15stamp panes, each stamp about 2 inches square, and in a souvenir sheet with smaller stamps that are just under 1 inches square. In both instances the stamps, designed by E. Weishoff, are multicolored.

title: Social Events: How Gambling Pays Off
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:,

title: Braves, Shut Out for 7 Innings, Top Giants, 52, on Boyer and Aaron Homers
