description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 (AP)The Atlanta Braves, shut out for seven innings by Ron Bryant of the San Francisco Giants, scored five runs in the eighth on Clete Boyer's tworun homer and Hank Aaron's, threerun homer to record a 52 victory today.

title: SOVIET SERVICE
description: To THE EDITOR: I enjoyed Mr. Deardorff's piece about Leningrad but was surprised by his complaint about service in the dining room of the Europa Hotel. I have never had anything but good to excellent service in its magnificent art nouveau dining hall, and the same applies to Leningrad's Aurora Hotel and the Metropole in Moscow. Perhaps it was because I always seemed to be on one of those group tours. I have even hit a fairly high average of service with a smile, which is a bonus I do not often receive in the restaurants of New York. Room service in the Soviet Union is something else. On occasion it is possible to read The Brothers Karamazov clean throughand In Russianwhile waiting for it.

title: Dryden the Key Canadien In Hockey Playoff Today
description: What kind of a goaltender wears glasses, wants to work for Nader's Raiders, and gets his law school professors to put off his examinations so he can compete in the Stanley Cup playoffs?

title: Set of Four Gobelins Tapestries Is Climax of ParkeBernet Sale
description: A magnificent set of four Gobelins tapestries, commissioned by King Louis XVI for the Grand Duke Paul Petrovitch, later Emperor of Russia, was the climax of yesterday's auction salethe third and last of works of art from the private and foundation collections of Norton Simon.

title: Variety in modules
description: Architects are experimenting with modular construction as a means of solving the housing crisis. Modules, prefabricated offsite, could be set on prepared foundations in a matter of days, cutting building costs and taking advantage of assemblyline production. Architect Myron Goldfinger designed his own vacation house as a prototype of modular building and disproved the notion that a modular system is dull boxes, arranged in dull, monotonous ways. Three basic modulesa 15foot cube, a triangular roof section and a cantilevered deckhave been brilliantly manipulated in Goldfinger's spectacular fourlevel house, rising out of a rocky site in Westchester County. No dull rooms herethe interiors are equally diverse. This prototype was expensive, but if the modules were massproduced, the cost of each module could be as low as $5,000.

title: 3 Men in Stolen Cadillac Slain On Street in High Bridge Area
description: Three men with false identification papers were shot to death early yesterday as they sat in a stolen Cadillac that was doubleparked on a Bronx street.

title: Help for Millions
description: The United Fund of Greater New York is the world's largest local network of community services and helps nearly four million people annually. In 1970, a total of 1.3million people were served in fund hospitals, convalescent homes and institutions for the chronically ill, medical, health and home nursing agencies. A total of 145,000 children were cared for in temporary shelters, foster homes, daycare centers and guidance clinics and 850,000 people utilized family and adult agencies, About 1.8million people participated in activities of neighborhood houses, clubs and vacation camps.

title: Camping Booklet Offered
description: ALBANY, May 8 (UPI) The State Commerce Department has published the 1971 edition of its book, Camping in New York State, which lists 461 public and private campgrounds open to the public. Free copies are available by writing to the Department of Commerce, 112 State Street, Albany, N. Y., 12207.

title: TAX ALTERNATIVE TO SHARING GIVEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee announced today his alternative to President Nixon's plan for revenue sharing with the states and cities.

title: MISSION IN AFRICA STAKES ORE CLAIM
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 8After marking off land with pegs in an operation described by a witness as like something from a gold rush western, the American Methodist Church in Rhodesia has registered a claim to copper mining rights on mission land it wons near Inyati.

title: Computer Shows Handicaps in Golf Unfair to Duffers
description: A computer analysis of 2,000,000 golf matches indicates that highhandicap amateurs do not receive enough strokes when they compete against lowerhandicap players in twoball or fourball matches.

title: R.P.I., Winning 9 Events, Takes I.C.A.C. Track Meet
description: TROY, N. Y., May 8Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute won the Independent College Athletic Conference track and field championship today. R.P.I., which scored 88 points, took nine firsts on the 17event program. Rochester Institute of Technology was second with 79 points, Alfred third with 64.

title: Lighthouse in L. I. Sound Is Saved
description: ROWAYTON, Conn., May 8  Yachtsmen and others alarmed by reports that the Coast Guard planned to destroy a local landmark, Greens Ledge Light, have just been reassured by the Federal agency.

title: Grimshaw Quits Tufts Post
description: MEDFORD, Mass., May 8 (AP)George W. (Woodie) Grimshaw resigned today after 18 years as head basketball coach at Tufts University.

title: The Lords and Manors Have Gone, But Descendants Remember Well
description: One of the world's most exclusive organizations held its 60th annual meeting here last week and, as usual, most of the time was devoted to refreshments and conversation.

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: Commenting on the Academy Awards Vincent Canby  by accident or design omitted any reflections on the best foreign film selection. This particular category has, over the years, intrigued me.

title: OTB: What Makes It So Slow
description: Offtrack betting lurches into its second full month of operation tomorrow, a hornblowing jalopy steadily picking up speed despite locked brakes, flat tires, defective safety belts and smokebillowing exhaust pipe.

title: Real Life By Deborah Pease. 188 pp. New York: W. W. Norton &
description: Hilary, a nice girl drifting through New York on private means, is old fashioned enough to drink crme de menthe, take sips from an escort's glass, and refer to whiskey as a yellowish intoxicant. But she is not so much of a back number as to play hard to get, a lack of dissimulation that involves her in a futile love affair with a loutish banker named Al.

title: Owner's Plight in Incinerator Case Detailed
description: To the Editor: I was very much interested in the April 18 letter by Robert N. Rickles, Commissioner of the Department of Air Resources, on air pollution. The letter says that direct rent adjustments will now be granted on a sevenyear, no longer a 10year, amortization of half the cost.

title: Springfield Draws Record 1,458 For 44th Dog Show on Saturday
description: New Englanders long have been active in the dog show world. A clipping from The Spirit of the Times, The American Gentleman's Newspaper, framed on a wall of the Westminster Kennel Club here, tells of the Grand Bench Show of Dogs, The Rod and Gun Club of Springfield, Mass., will hold their Second Annual Bench Show, April 26 & 27, 1876 at City Hall.

title: U.S. Group Urges Free Use by U.N. Of Satellite Radio
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 A private organization of prominent Americans recommended today that the United Nations be given limited, costfree access to the Intelsat satellite communications system for peacekeeping operations and disaster warning and relief.

title: Religion
description: Theologians may do a lot of talking about the next world, but over the centuries their discipline has been strongly influenced by what happens in this one. Kings in the Middle Ages justified their authority by religious sanctions. Max Weber and other sociologists found a causal connection between the Calvinist ethic of frugality and the rise of capitalism. Some historians have even asserted that the imperative in Genesis to assert dominion over the natural world has helped cause the current environmental crisis.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Star of The Gingerbread Lady I WISH Siobhan would tell me the name of the sponsor who offered her $100,000 to do a television commercial. I'd be delighted to do it. You see, I don't feel that a lack of money is particularly ennobling. fact, I think it's souldestroying. Poverty to me is a crime, and it leaves irreparable scars.

title: Peter O'Malley, Dodgers Head, To Wed Annette Zacho July 10
description: Miss Annette Zacho and Peter O'Malley, president of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball club, will be married July 10 in St. Ansgar's Roman Catholic Church in Copenhagen.

title: Few States Expected to Act This Year On Proposals for NoFault Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Bills to put nofault automobile insurance into effect have been introduced in 28 state legislatures this year, but few if any are likely to be enacted.

title: Son to Mrs. Gardner
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Bradford Gardner of Brooklyn on April 22 in the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. Mrs. Gardner is the former Miss Susan Beth Ross, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Ross, the theatrical agent of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The child, whose father is a professional artist and an assistant professor of art at Rutgers University, is named Damion Ross.

title: 3 Critical Articles in Australia Produce a ProAmerican Backlash
description: SYDNEY Australia, May 8  Three articles containing some of the harshest criticism of life in the United States seen in a newspaper of general circulation here in years have produced a strong proAmerican backlash among readers.

title: Theater: Magic in the Intermission
description: There is theatrical magic in the Spanishlanguage staging or Alfredo Dias Gomes's allegorical play, El Pagador de Promesas, also known as Journey to Bahia, from Brazil. The magic is the intermission at the small loft showcase of the ADAL Performing Arts troupe, 682 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Oscar: Post Morterms
description: To THE EDITOR: THE Academy Awards may be only a joke to critics and George C. Scott, but the gaudy, televised meat parade apparently provides muchneeded glamour for a glamourstarved audience  not, as one might suppose, in Sioux City or Omaha, but in that fabled bastion of upper middleclass culture, the Upper East Side.

title: Money: Dollar and MarkWho Is Doing What to Whom?
description: That most baffling of eventsan international monetary crisis erupted last week.

title: Foreign Notes
description: When the United States Congress killed the American supersonic transport plane project (SST) six weeks ago, there was speculation that the BritishFrench version, the Concorde, might also be doomed. To combat any such thought the French Government mounted a strenuous publicity campaign. Last Friday, President Georges Pompidou made a personal contribution.

title: The Great New People
description: Mr. Trevelyan, a Cambridge graduate, kinsman to statesmen and great historians, was 28 in 1898, when he set forth on a ninemonth Grand Tour of North America and the Pacific. These easy, familiar letters he sent home reflect a liberal's concern for popular education, social betterment, honest politicians and the art of government in his encounters with the likes of Theodore Roosevelt, William Jennings Bryan, Carl Schurz and Sockless Jerry Simpson. He was impressed with the surging power of the United States but was more comfortable in Australia and especially New Zealand (attentive English waiters, no iced water.).

title: Wildcats Pick CoCaptains
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 8 (UPI) Maury Daigneau, a quarterback, and Eric Hutchinson, a defensive safety, named cocaptains of Northwestern's 1971 football team.

title: Retailing: Skies Brighten
description: Major retailers who completed their first fiscal quarter April 30 are expected to report improved net earnings for the period, as a result of improved consumer buying and the installation of better inventory & expense controls.

title: Taste for Business Builds Brooklyn Knish Empire
Tyler Will Oppose Morales On Garden Mat May 24
description: Tarzan Tyler of Montreal and Pedro Morales of Culebra, Puerto Rico will meet in a heavyweight wrestling exhibition that will highlight the card for the return of professional wrestling to Madison Square Garden on Monday night May 24.

title: Bruce Miller Weds Carolyn Lee Jones
description: Miss Carolyn Lee Jones and Bruce Gorty Miller were married yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of All Saints of Trinity Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Davis Given.

title: Navy's Crew Ends Harvard's Reign In Eastern Sprints
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 8 Navy's powerful crew, which came from out of the depths of the rowing establishment this season, won the Eastern Sprint championships today on Lake Quinsigamond. The results of the heavyweight final marked the end of an era in eastern rowing, the Harvard era.

title: CUBAN'S ORDEAL AROUSES ARTISTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 8  The arrest and humiliation of a Cuban poet, Heberto Padilla, has opened a wide breach between Premier Fidel Castro and leftwing intellectuals in Europe and Latin America who had been cultivated by the Cuban regime.

title: . . . Or, Has Andy Warhol Spoiled Success?
description: IT was a gas In Pasadena, a panache in Paris, and terrific at London's Tate. Now, after a triumphal fourstar tour of world art capitals (like it says in the press release) Andy Warhol's peripatetic Popshow has slipped into town for its final appearance at the Whitney Museum. There, generating nostalgia like a bunch of old TV reruns, are the fruits of a decade's labor, going back to 1961  the Brillo boxes, the soup can and flower paintings, the portraits (of Jackie, Ethel, Marilyn), and the disasters (explosions, car crashes, electric chairs)  that rocketed Andy to sixties superstardom.

title: The Heights Of Zervos
description: The trouble with the British Expeditionary Force in 1941 was that it didn't have enough Macombers. Macomber  a 6foot3 demolition expert capable of blowing up a Rumanian gasoline dump singlehanded . . . fluent enough in German to pass as an agent of Nazi intelligence . . . shrewd enough to outthink, outbluff and annihilate an entire assault regiment of the Alpenkorps . . . Macomber!

title: Writers Right Wrong in Citing Curtis
description: Last January's Super Bowl game, won by Baltimore over Dallas, had more goats than heroes. The automobile that goes to the game's alleged outstanding performer was voted to Chuck Howley, a linebacker for the losers. The balloting had been done in the press box before Mike Curtis of the Colts intercepted a Dallas pass with 59 seconds to go and before Jim O'Brien kicked the winning field goal with five seconds left.

title: EDITOR OF A PAPER IS FREED IN GREECE
description: ATHENS, May 8 lonnis Kapsis, editor of the Liberal Athens daily Ethnos was freed today after serving twothirds of his 20  month prison sentence passed for printing an interview favoring the restoration of democracy in Greece.

title: NO AIRPORT
description: To THE EDITOR: The second of E. J. Kahn Jr.'s articles concerning his Far East trip, this one about Taipei, Saigon and other places (Travel section, April 18), was as entertaining as the first, though I suspect not always intentionally. His reference to the Saigon airport as Cain Hut Thuoc was surprising, since news dispatches when the airport has been under Vietcong fire have referred to it as Tansonnhut. Remembering a few words of Vietnamese, however, I realized that Mr. Kahn had miscopied the words from a sign which said Cam Hut Thuoc, which means No Smoking! In this respect he has joined another unwitting punster, Robert S. McNamara; the former Secretary of Defense originally pronounced the name of that sad country Veet Nam, to rhyme with fleet Sam, apparently thereby designating it in Vietnamese as sick duck!

title: Budget Cut Closing State's Middle Island Game Farm, a Favorite of Children
description: RIDGE, L.I., May 8  A staterun game farm here, which was developing as a canter in which children could find the nature that is being pushed back everywhere, will close Monday, a victim of budget cuts by the Legislature.

title: Shopper's Guide to Paint Brushes
description: A GOOD quality paint brush will not only make almost any painting or finishing job easier, it can also spell the difference between a smooth, professionallooking finish and a streaky, uneven appearance. The sensible doityourself painter should, therefore, acquaint himself with the features to look for when shopping for a good quality brush.

title: Agnew Says U.S. Won't Change Economic Policy
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 Vice President Agnew said tonight that the Nixon Administration would not switch back to severe deflationary policies despite the international currency crisis.

title: Bright Song Style Of Linda Ronstadt Lights Up Fillmore
description: Linda Ronstadt sang at the Fillmore East this weekend. That she doesn't appear here more often should be declared a crime against humanity.

title: Lentneks Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Capt. Arnold L. Lentnek, U.S.A., and Mrs. Lentnek of Louisville, Ky., on April 28 in the Methodist Hospital in Louisville. Mrs. Lentnek is the former Miss Sherrie Josephart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Josephart of Lido Beach, L. I.

title: Basketball Tricks Come Easily for the 6YearOld Son of Former Jet
description: The number on the back of his blue basketball uniform is 6for his age.

title: Food Thieves Sentenced
description: MIAMI, May 8 (AP)Cuban revolutionary tribunals have sentenced 99 persons to prison terms of up to 15 years for stealing food and selling it in the black market, the Havana radio said in a broadcast monitored here.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Walker Married To Henry Darbee, an Architect
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Young Walker of Sarasota, Fla., and Henry Darbee of Hartford were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Young Reynal, son and daughterinlaw of the bride, in Nassau, the Bahamas, by Magistrate John Bailey. Mr. Reynal is president of the First National City Trust of Nassau.

title: Cluster of 8 Satellites Is Orbited by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 8 (AP)The Soviet Union has launched a cluster of eight satellites into orbit aboard a single carrier rocket, Tass announced today.

title: Thousands Walk in Poverty Fight
description: Singing, exuberant and coltish despite sore feet and aching legs, tens of thousands of young people hiked distances up to 30 miles in 125 communities across the nation yesterday to raise funds for domestic and international antipoverty programs and to focus attention on the plight of the world's poor.

title: Mrs. Hoyt to Discuss Art At Dog Fanciers Luncheon
description: Mrs. Hayes Blake Hoyt will discuss The Dog in Art, at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon in the McAlpin Hotel on Wednesday. She will illustrate the talk with paintings from her collection and also some from the American Kennel Club.

title: Suffolk Buildings, 1659 to 1971, Are Shown in Photos
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I, May 8 When parts of Long Island were a hotbed of revolutionary activity in 1649, a house of handsplit logs was built in Southold. The house, which was moved to Cutchogue in 1659, is still standing and it is perhaps the oldest building in the state.

title: PHILADELPHIA PAPER SHUT BY 2 UNIONS
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8 A work stoppage by pressmen and mailers halted production tonight on the Sunday edition of The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: The Druid Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: The Untold Tale By Erik Christian Haugaard. Illustrated by Leo and Diane Dillon. 211 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $3.95.
description: The Untold Tale by Erik Christian Haugaard is set in Denmark early in the 17th century. Dag is a 7yearold boy. His people are small tenant farmers on the king's land, and times are bard. On his way to the capital for help, the father freezes to death; at home the sick mother dies. In the stable the animals lie dead of starvation. The child sets out to find the king who will put everything right, and we accompany him across country to his own death.

title: Rock's We Are One Myth
description: You will not be able to stay home, brother.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
description: Letters:

title: Elizabeth Cox Norwood Is Bride
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 8In St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Elizabeth Cox Norwood and Kevin Patrick Callahan, graduates of the University of Denver, were married by the Rev. Albert Wickens.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May (Reuters) Glasgow's crosstown soccer rivals, Rangers and Celtic, battled to a 11 tie today in their Scottish Football Association Cup final.

title: New for the Home
description: THE new intruder alarm unit pictured at right can be quickly and easily installed in homes or in apartments to sound an alarm when a door or window is being opened by an unauthorized person. The unit itself mounts on any wall with pressuresensitive tape. It comes with 30 feet of wire and a set of magnetic switches which can be inconspicuously installed on the door (additional switches can he ordered to use on other doors or windows). Designed so that a loud alarm sounds when the door or window is opened, the device has a timedelay switch so that a person can activate the unit and leave without sounding the alarm. The alarm itself is in the control unit, which can be disarmed or activated with a special key (two keys are supplied). A test switch tells if it is in working order and it is powered by three Dcell batteries. An auxiliary horn can be added to sound the alarm in other parts of the house. S80 Alarm, $46.95. (NuTone Div. Scovill, Madison and Red Bank Roads, Cincinnati, Ohio 45227).

title: Yale Defeats Princeton, 122, In Lacrosse as Fagan Stars
description: NEW HAVEN, May 8Tom Fagan scored three goals and assisted on three others today as Yale routed Princeton, 122, in lacrosse. Rain fell throughout the game.

title: Man Sam Sets Track Record
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., May 8 (AP)Man Sam, with Paula Werber riding, won the $2,100 Canandaigua purse today before 5,446 at Finger Lakes race track and paid $42.40 for $2.

title: Equality Is Not Debatable
description: There is a serious weakness in the civil rights legislation of the last decade. The Equal Employment Opportunity. Commission established by the comprehensive civil rights law of 1964 has never had enforcement power. It can investigate a case of job discrimination and try to conciliate the issues, but if conciliation fails, nothing further is done unless the aggrieved individual files a private civil suit in Federal court.

title: Three Lovers By Julia O'Faolain. 255 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $5.95.
description: Bad enough to be a novelist. But to be an Irish novelist? Much worse: too many giants breathing down your neck. Added to which, Julia O'Faolain is Sean O'Faolain's daughternot easy: maybe like being Trollope's daughter in 19thcentury England. In the circumstances, she writes firmly, with a voice all her own, the voice of her New Yorker stories expanded into a novel: well planned, intelligent, concise, more pointed than her father, with a cold female eye for the egocentricities of masculine behavior.

title: What ill Alan King Think of Next?
description: ALAN KING, a comedian who is very much at home in night clubs and on TV, would like to make himself more at home in movies. It's true that he has matte occasional appearances in the past most notably in Sidney Lumet's Bye, Bye, Braverman and that he will be seen in Lumet's The Anderson Tapes, which opens here nest month. But for some time King has had an urge to nroduce movies, too. Now, at last, he will get his chance, with the film version of Next, Terrence McNally's oneact comedy that ran for more than 700 performances Off Broadway. King will collaborate on the project with Wolper Pictures, Ltd.

title: Briefings Poems Small and Easy. By A. R. Ammons. 105 pp. New York: W. W. Norton &
description: Poems Small and Easy is the subtitle of this most important group of poems whose matter is in fact larger than their length, and whose meditative structure is rather harder than their syntax. A. R. Ammons's work is probably to embody the major vision of nature in the poetry of our part of the century. But the 87 short lyrics which record part of that vision have no obvious formal counterparts. Neither the looselyversified scout manuals and ecological gospelsongs of the moment, nor epigrammatic modes of moralizing landscape descending from Robert Frost, nor the constantly refocusing, relentlessly uncaptioned snapshots of the unarranged that some poets have learned to take from William Carlos Williams, provide models for Ammons's intense and profound imaginative excursion.

title: Ban on Gill Net Turns Fishermen to New Ventures
Truman Receives A Humphrey Visit On 87th Birthday
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo. May 8 (UPI)Former President Harry S. Truman had a surprise visit on his 87th birthday today from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who called Mr. Truman his hero and one of the great men of all time.

title: Backpacking: I Go to the Wildentess to Kick the Man  World Out of Me
A View From the Hills
description: FIERY RUN, Va., May 8There is newsand not bad eitherfrom China and the Middle East these days, but life goes on in America too. In the last 25 years, this area of the United States, from Tidewater, Md., and Virginia to the Blue Ridge, has been transformed by the movement of people and capital.

title: Soviets Train in Tournaments
description: HIGH ranking officials in the governing body of Soviet chess have grown increasingly alarmed during the past few years over the failure of their statesubsidized program to develop young players fast enough to assure the continuation of Russian world chess supremacy. One method by which they are trying to bring their more promising young players along is to give them ample opportunity, in training tournaments, to play against topclass opposition.

title: Run It Down the Flagpole
description: Et Al.

title: MEMORIES OF A SHIP
description: To THE EDITOR: The Ankara may be just an old Turkish vessel converted from a World War (she should have said World War II) American hospital ship to Peggy Thomson, who mentioned her in her article on Swans Hellenic cruises (Travel section, April 25). But for a few of us still around the ship brings back memories of a time when the Greek isles were strictly from Homer and Americans could cruise majestically in their own home waters for about $10 a dayfirst class. The Ankara began life in 1927 as the Iroquois, crack ship of the Clyde Line (later Clyde Mallory) whose fleet was named, delightfully, after American Indian tribes. She and her sister ship Shawnee were fitted out like miniature luxury liners. They spent the winters steaming between New York and. Miami with occasional calls at Jacksonville. Summers they frequently went up to Quebec or cruised the Maine coast on charter to the Eastern Steamship Lines. The Iroquois did many cruises to the West In dies in the late 1930's and id 194041 was running regularly between New York and Havana. Like so many other American liners, she was sold to a foreign buyer after World War H. It's good to know she Is still alive and well.

title: Miss Wignott Married
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 8 Miss Dianne Ellen Wignott and Frank Julius Naple Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nagle, were married here this morning in St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John J. Filip. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James H. Wignott of Farmingham. Mass., and Stamford.

title: CROWN JEWELS GIVEN AT CUBICULO
description: Spring is the season when new operas bloom all over the place, most of them doomed to wither and die, never to be seen again. Their production does give librettists and composers a chance to tackle a form that is supposedly dying, and out of them, hopefully, will develop some creative artists to flourish in the future.

title: Wilkes Five Gets Coach
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., May 8 (UPI)  Rodger Bearde was named head basketball coach at Wilkes College today by the school's athletic director, John G. Reese. Bearde, from Spring City, Pa., replaces Ron Rainey, who resigned earlier in the week to accept a teachingcoaching post at the University of Delaware. The 31yearold Bearde is a 1961 graduate of West Chester State College.

title: Miss Haynie's 66 Widens Golf Lead To 6 Shots on 135
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May (UPI)Sandra Haynie of Dallas continued her excellent play today with a sevenunderpar 66 for a 36hole score of 135 in the $20,000 Alamo women's open golf tournament.

title: Rip Torn Replies:
description: PAUL MAYER'S snide references to Miss Lindfors' ability to read Strindberg's original text arise from his own inability to read Swedish and his preference for, and reliance on, Victorian translators of this fiery poet whom Ibsen called that madman. Any changes in the text were done under the supervision of director Alfred Ryder and approved last year by Mayer.

title: OIL MEN FIND IRAQ ADAMANT IN TALKS
description: LONDON, May 8Western oil companies are encountering trouble with Iraq in their efforts to nail down the last agreements for longterm price stability in the volatile Middle East.

title: Georgia Wins Tennis Title
description: OXFORD, Miss., May 8 (UPI) The Georgia Bulldogs swept to their first Southeastern Conference tennis championship today with five victories in six singles matches and two in three doubles. The Bulldogs chalked up 34 points, third highest in the tournament's 33year history. The defending champion, Tennessee, was second, with 17 points.

title: L.I.U TEACHERS TO VOTE ON AGENT
description: In the first such election sponsored by the National Labor Relations Board at a major university, faculty members of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center and the university's C.W. Post campus will decide this week whether they want to be represented by a labor organization.

title: Congress vs. President
description: WASHINGTONAs the youthful Mayday demonstrators were skirmishing in Washington last week in protest against the Vietnam war, the Nixon Administration had its own confrontation on Capitol Hill with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on legislation to end the war.

title: Aussie Express Clatters Over the World's Longest Stretch of Straight Track
description: PERTH, AustraliaThe Nullarbor Plain, thrust up from the sea millions of years ago, has remained virtually impassable. Rain falling on the surface of this treeless wasteland is quickly absorbed by the limestone, which is rutted with caves and deep subterranean blowholestrumpets for wind. Part of it, however, is crossed by the world's longest stretch of straight track297 miles, twin fingers of steel pointing to Perth In the west and Sydney in the easta section of Australia's new transcontinental railroad.

title: Jan Ting Fiance Of Helen Page
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 8  Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Page have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Hamilton Page, to Jan Chiang Ting, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sik Woo Ting of Dearborn, Mich.

title: Couple Robbed and Shot in Staten Island Home
description: A Staten Island couple were shot and critically wounded last night after the wife was held at gunpoint for over an hour while two intruders ransacked their home.

title: Mideast: The Rogers Gamble Seems to Have Been Worth It
description: ROME  It was, from the outset, a highrisk venture. The chances for dramatic success were remote, if not nonexistent, and the danger of a diplomatic boomerang was too obvious to be ignored. But despite the potential pitfalls, Secretary of State William P. Rogers decided the gamble was worth it and set out last week on a fivenation tour of the Middle East.

title: FrazierAli Bout Income Near $20Million Mark
description: Two months after the Joe FrazierMuhammad Ali heavyweight title fight, the money is almost all counted.

title: Celler, Honored at 83, Hopes to Go On and On
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Representative Emanuel Celler, dean of the House of Representatives in service and age, marked his 83d birthday Thursday by telling his New York colleagues, I hope to go on and on.

title: University for Indians and Chicanos Faces Problems
description: DAVIS, Calif., May 8How would you like the job of composing a school cheer for DeganawidahQuetzalcoatl University?

title: Bridge
description: THE beginner is told, Always cover an honor with an honor, and he dutifully does so. This is profitable advicefor his opponents. They never go astray when missing the queen of trumps; they simply lead the ten or jack at him, confident that he will cover if he can.

title: Engineering Dean Named
description: BROOKINGS, S. D., May 8 (AP)John Lagerstrom, dean of the College of Engineering at South Dakota State University, will become chairman of the electrical engineering department at the University of Nebraska July 1.

title: Bohernia, Such AS It Is, On the West Side
Tonight We Open, Tonight We Close
Chompion Awarded Triumph in Dixie Handicap as Fort Alarcy Is Disqualified
description: BALTIMORE, May 8Rokeby Stable's Fort Marcy, horse of the year in 1970, finished first by six lengths in the $56,800 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today but was disqualified and first money of $39,920 went to Chompion from the Colonial Farms.

title: An Epitaph Of Hopes On Future Budgets
description: WASHINGTON  With apologies to Percy Bysshe Shelley and his Ode to the West Wind;

title: RALLY BY PIRATES TOPS DODGERS, 53
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (UPI) Jose Pagan hit a tworun homer. and Willie Stargell knocked in his 33d run of the season to spark a fourrun burst in the seventh inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5.3.

title: SNOOKIE
description: To THE EDITOR: Ruth Gordon sounds a lot like my best friend, Elspeth (Snookie) La'rush, who is 97 and a real swell broad. Even though I'm only 13, she's my number one favorite perSon in the world, and we make it regularly and get stoned on grass and Snookie even freaks out on Dristan every once in a while, which she claims is a great trip and clears her sinuses to boot. Otherwise, Snookie's in great shape, and her homemade porno films are selling better than ever. You wouldn't guess she's a day over 701 My Snookie, like Ruth, is full of vitality and lots else.

title: FLEET SURPRISE WINS LOS ANGELES STAKE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 8 (UPI)Fleet Surprise, making a rare start on dirt, raced to a head victory at Hollywood Park today in the 19th running of the $65,900 Los An'geles Handicap, richest in the coun. try for older horses.

title: Courting Danger on the Colorado River: The Hazards Are Part of the Excitement
HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ME PRESIDENT'S Office of Emergency Preparedness, in effect, recommended that the Administration do nothing to roll back increases in crudeoil prices imposed last fall. The office issued its findings after a sixmonth study. President Nixon had expressed concern at the 25centabarrel increase last November.

title: The Old Man of the Rapids
description: GRAND CANYON, Ariz.A motion picture that has chalked up the longest run in history is currently in its 55th year here and is being shown to tourists on a fourtimesaday basis by its 90yearold producer. The film records a 1,200mile rowboat trip through the Grand Canyon made by Emery C. Kolb and his late brother, and since 1915 it has been shown to more than 1.5 million tourists in Kolb's home at the head of Bright Angel Trail on the Canyon's South Rim.

title: Miss Mary E. Stout to Wed July 10
description: WEST ALLENHURST, N.J., May 8  State Senator and Mrs. Richard R. Stout have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Stout, to Stephen M. Foehl, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Charles Allen Foehl Jr. of Williamstown and Hyannis Port, Mass.

title: Udaipur: If You Don't Mind Being Amazed
description: UDAIPUR, India  I don't know why you travel, but I travel to see ways of life foreign to my own in places where great civillzations of the past have left their monuments. I don't want to share these ways of life, but I do want to see them at close range, and I want them to be so different from my own that I am constantly amazed. (This is what 19thcentury tourists meant by travel is broadening. You are amazed, and you adjust your way of thinking to take care of that amazement.) There's no country like India for this kind of travel, and in India surely there's no better place for it than Udaipur and the surrounding countryside.

title: EVIDENCE REBATES FIRST SLAV STATE
description: MOSCOW, May 8  A Ukrainian archeologist has reported evidence that early Slavic tribes on the present territory of the Soviet Union formed an organized state in the fourth to sixth centuries, or about 500 years earlier than commonly assumed.

title: The Boys Behind the Illicit Cigarette Operations
No. Carolina Central Wins Track Title as Black Stars
description: BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) Larry Black set a meet record today in the 220yard dash and anchored two recordsetting relay teams as North Carolina Central captured the 50th annual Central Intercollegiate Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships at Morgan State.

title: Nancy Richardot to Marry June 5
description: Miss Nancy Tucker BleyfusRichardot and William Ash Tenney plan to be married June 5 in Barrington, R. I., at the Tillinghast estate, which is owned by the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence. She is a junior at the school, from which he was graduated last year.

title: Fund Transactions
description: Vickers Associaties, Inc., the Huntington, L. I., company that monitors stock transactions by mutual funds, has issued its preliminary report on fund purchases and sales during the first quarter of 1971.

title: AMNESTY GROUP MARKS 10TH YEAR
description: LONDON, May 8In narrow office quarters near Fleet Street, the men and women of Amnesty International pore over the letters and documents that arrive each morning about the prisoners of consciencea teacher in Mexico, a trade union leader in Greece, a Russian intellectual, a Rhodesian nationalist.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In recent years, Peter Dickinson has been attracting attention for a series of lowkeyed mysteries written with extraordinary concentration. It is not so much that the man is an unusually fine prose stylist. Even more, he has the ability to suggest, to leave things unsaid, and over his books hangs a suspended cloud that can scare the reader.

title: Son for the Fendelmans
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 8 A son was born April 22 to Mr. and Mrs. Burton M. Fendelman at the St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. Mrs. Fendelman is the former Miss Helaine Woll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Wall of Evansville, Ind. The child, whose father is a partner and general counsel of the securities firm of Jas H. Oliphant & Co. in New York, has been named Jonathan Woll. He is the grandson also of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Fendelman of St. Louis.

title: Britain's Nations Cup Assigned To Hickstead for First Time
description: The United States Isn't the only place the big horse show season is getting under way.

title: Syracuse Appoints Bonney
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 8 (UPI)  Alan Bonney, acting track coach at Syracuse University, was appointed head coach today Bonney 24 years old, took over as acting coach following the illness and subsequent retirement of Bob Grieve.

title: Saul Bellow Of Chicago
description: Saul Bellow is the premier American novelist: the best writer we have in the literary form that has been dominant in the literature of the past hundred years. He has come to his eminence not through the mechanics of publicity, selfadvertisement or sensationalism, but through slowly building up a body of work, an oeuvre, that with each new novel has displayed greater range, solidity, penetration and brilliance.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Arson Charge on Rap Brown
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., May 8 (AP)A Maryland judge refused tonight to dismiss a charge that H. Rap Brown, the black militant, committed arson during racial disorders in Cambridge, Md., in July, 1967.

title: Bud and Leaf
description: We seek out and cherish the early wildflowers, the hepatica, then the bloodroot, the anemones, the violets, the columbines. We watch the crimson flush of blossoms on the soft maples and exclaim at the frosty dazzle of shadblow. But all the while we are being surrounded by a subtle newness and beauty that we take for granted. The leaves are bursting bud.

title: Color and Fragrance for the Patio
description: AN attractive, colorful and fragrant spot for family picnics can he attained with annuals, trees and shrubs. A terrace or patio, perhaps a barbecue pit or portable grill in a corner of the property doesn't have to be hot and drablooking.

title: Kathe M. Bova Wed in Capital To John Dyson
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Miss Kathe Maria Bova, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George S. Bova of Toledo, Ohio, was married here this morning to John Stuart Dyson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Dyson of Scarsdale and Millbrook, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, by the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper.

title: Report Card On Open Admissions: Remedial Work Recommended
description: As of last September, 8,500 blacks and Puerto Ricans were registered as freshmen at the City University of New York, in a total undergraduate enrollment of 155,000. This figure represents, at least on the surface, something of a revolution. Last year's freshman class included less than half that number, or a total of 3,820 blacks and Puerto Ricans. We are witnessing, in other words, one of the most massive attempts in our history to provide a college education for members of minority groups, many of them from ghetto areas.

title: Small Planes May Fill Rural Travel Needs
description: SIDNEY, Neb., May 6There aren't any stewardesses on the airliner that calls twice a day at this remote wheatfarming town of 6,400 citizens on the Nebraska panhandle. There aren't any cocktails, movies, lavatories, or inflight movies, either. The plane is so small that passengers can't stand up and they have to sit almost as close together as rushhour commuters in a Manhattan subway.

title: O'Brien Says Vietnam War Should Not Be Issue in 72
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Lawrence J. O'Brien, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he hoped the Vietnam war would not be a campaign issue in 1972.

title: Swiss Act to Prevent a Dollar Influx
description: GENEVA, May 9The Cabinet revalued the Swiss franc upward tonight.

title: Sterling Parity Unchanged
description: LONDON, May 9 (AP)  The Treasury said today that the pound sterling was not directly involved in the international currency crisis and there is no change in the sterling parity or in dealing margins.

title: Performance of Festival Mass By Benevoli an Extravaganza
description: This time last week it might have been difficult to associate Salzburg Cathedral with the Hunter College Assembly Hall, but henceforth they will live in history together. Both have housed performances of Orazio Benevoli's Festival Mass in 53 parts.

title: Guyana Volunteers Build Road for Nation
description: CAMP HAMARAPARU, GuyanaA reddishbrown slash here in the dark green jungles of central Guyanaa 12mile, serpentine stretch of new road is symbolic of the hopes and gambles this nation is taking 14 months into its new status as a Cooperative Republic.

title: Harvard Takes Tennis Titlel
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 9 (AP)Harvard, led by Bill Washauer and Joe Cavanagh, captured five of the last six matches today to win the New England intercollegiate tennis championship. The Crimson recorded 49 points. Williams was second with 32, 1 more than Dartmouth.

title: Yellowstone and Other U. S. Parks Prepare for Another Bout With People Problems
description: WEST YELLOWSTONE, Mont., May 6Yellowstone National Park, which will celebrate its centennial next year, has probems. Most of them, as with Many other national parks, can be summed up in one word visitors. Yellowstone had 2,297,300 last year, and expects 2,361,000 this year.

title: Youth Vote Likely to Aid Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 The Republican and Democratic parties have begun preliminary efforts to recruit the new voters who will be between 18 and 21 years old in 1972and the initial evidence suggests that the Democrats will attract the larger share of them.

title: Many Prisons Strained by Overcrowding
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Four men, grinding on one another's nerves in a hundred ways and unable to help it, are crowded together now in some small, close and cluttered cells at the New Jersey State Prison in Trenton.

title: 3 Crewmen, on Moscow TV, Affirm Success of Soyuz 10
description: MOSCOW, May 9 (UPI)The Soyuz 10 astronauts were the stars of an hourlong television program today, restating the official assessment that their flight had gone without a hitch.

title: Lucy Oppenheimer Wed to C.D. Hickey
description: PUTNAM VALLEY, N.Y., May 9  Miss Lucy Oppenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Oppenheimer, was married here today to Charles D. Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Hickey of Rockford, Ill. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Roundup: As Sweep O's With Pair of Aces
description: It was Bat Day in Baltimore yesterday but the Orioles bats were stilled in a doubleheader by Jim (Catfish) Hunter and Vida Blue, the Oakland pitchers.

title: Wardlaw School Triumphs In Title Track at Fieldston
description: Wardlaw School of Plainfield, N.J., won the Intersuburban Track Conference title yesterday at the Fieldston School in the Bronx. Wardlaw scored 32 points, with Englewood 7 points back. Other team scores were Birch Wathen 12, Fieldston 11 and St. Hughes 7.

title: Uncertain Money Markets
description: An atmosphere of confusion and uncertainty is likely to prevail today as the world's money markets reopen. Last week's tidal waves of money movements across borders forced the decisions yesterday to revalue float different currencies. Too many powerful forces are affected and have been set in motion to permit any easy, dogmatic judgment as to the future of the financial storm.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Margaret Rosenblum Is Married
description: Miss Margaret Louise Rosenblum and Paul Eric Hammerschlag, thirdyear students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, were married yesterday afternoon at the WaldorfAstoria. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, the Jewish Chaplain at Columbia University.

title: FREDERIC F. AUSTIN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 9 Frederic F. Austin, a publisher's consultant and former circulation director of Field & Stream magazine, died yesterday at his home, 13 Bacon Court. He was 62 years old.

title: The Expensive Majority
description: The distinction between a campaign contribution and a bribe is almost hairline's difference, according to Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, who is not counted among the nation's inflammatory reformers. Political scientists of a more academic cast put the proposition with less color but with a fullness that no legislator can care to dwell on. They suggest inevitable relationships between the campaign contributions of oil men, bankers and manufacturers, for random example, and the subsequent votes of their Congressional beneficiaries on oil depletion allowances, banking regulations and tariffs, respectively.

title: Happy Birthday for Gonzales
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9 (UPI) Pancho Gonzales celebrated his 44th birthday today by whipping Jimmy Connors, a U.C.L.A. freshman, 64, 46, 61, in the final of the Southern California sectional tennis tournament.

title: CREDIT MARKETS WEATHER UPSETS
description: The credit markets stumbled last week as the result of the currency disturbance in Europe, but by Friday they seemed to be regaining their footing.

title: All Serious Armed Opposition Seems Ended in East Pakistan
description: The following dispatch is by one of the six foreign newsmen allowed into East Pakistan this week by the Pakistani Government for a tour with official escorts.

title: 51 CeaseFire Violations Charged to Foe by Allies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9  The 24hour allied truce in honor of Buddha's birthday ended at noon today with the South Vietnamese and Americans accusing the enemy of 51 ceasefire violations, including the mining of a ferryboat that took the lives of 36 South Vietnamese civilians.

title: PARSONS NOTCHES NASCAR TRIUMPH
description: SOUTH BOSTON, Va., May 9 (AP)Benny Parsons of Ellerbe, N.C., won the first Grand National race of his eightyear career today when he took the Halifax County 100 NASCAR race at South Boston Speedway.

title: RICHMOND BUSING WIDENS AS ISSUE
description: RICHMOND, May 9When the Supreme Court ruled last month that busing could be a legal means of erasing the vestiges of segregated schools, some Southerners were relieved.

title: MEROLA, IN SHIFT, BACKS INCOME TAX URGED BY LINDSAY
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee swung over yesterday to support Mayor Lindsay's bid for a new payroll income tax on city residents and commuters, and predicted disaster without its $500million added revenue.

title: DIMITRI C. TOUFEXIS WINS WQXR CONTEST
description: Dimitri C. Toufexis, an 18yearold senior at the Professional Children's School, has been named firstplace winner in radio station WQXR's sixth annual Young Artists Competition for pianists.

title: Susan Honig Bride of Raymond J. Scott
description: Miss Susan Harriet Honig, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Honig of Rego Park Queens, was married here yesterday to Raymond Joseph Scott.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Jackson Berkey Plays 20th Century Pieces
description: Early in the program, a man who described himself as music lover, Richard Adams Whipple. 38 years old, of Jersey City, climbed a 100foot scaffold just to see the show.

title: Rogers Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Secretary Rogers returned to Washington tonight and said that he had been advised by Mr. Sisco that Israel and Egypt were seeking ways to accommodate their views on an agreement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Nixon's Strategy for 1972 Beginning to Take Shape
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Witho.ut completely doffing the Presidential hat ha pledged to wear after his disappointment at the 1970 elections, President Nixon has begun to channel larger amounts of his time and the resources of his staff to the political tests that await him in 1972.

title: POLL OF CATHOLICS SET IN BRIDGEPORT
description: The 300,000 Roman Catholics of the Diocese of Bridgeport are being asked to vote this ihonth on a series of sweeping changes in the organization and procedures of their churches.

title: Mayor Sets Worth Of Parking Agency At 156 Policemen
description: The work of the city's new Parking Violations Bureau has been equivalent to having 156 additional police officers, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday in a report.

title: Paris Bank Adds Unit Here
description: Full ownership of the French American Banking Corporation, 120 Broadway, has been acquired by the Banque Nationale de Paris, it was announced over the weekend. The Banque Nationale de Paris has become the sole stockholder of the corporation through the purchase of each of the onethird interests in it that were held by the Banque de L'Indochine and the Compagnie Financiere de Suez et de L'Union Parisienne.

title: Group Sex: Is It Life Art or a Sign That Something Is Wrong?
description: Changing sexual patterns are posing stew problems for marriage counselors. The most recent development is group sex.

title: CENTRAL BANKERS HOPE FOR ORDER
description: BASEL, Switzerland, May 9 Central bankers meeting in Basel are hopeful that the changes in European currency rates announced today will restore order to the official foreign exchange markets tomorrow.

title: Advertising:
description: While in Japan Eastman Kodak is trying to get a bigger piece of the amateur film market from the dominant Fuji Photo Film, Fuji is over here trying to do the same to them. It's called international marketing.

title: Real Home Rule
description: There is a lot of Jefferson in the nation. The Virginian's early fear of urban areas lingers on, the old agrarian belief in the corruptibility of cities having been reinforced by the subsequent development of big city political machines that are only now being disassemblednot always with happy consequences. The cities remain constitutional stepchildren. In a period of budgetary difficulties, they are now close to being disinherited by unsympathetic states.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I liked your article in your paper (editorial April 29) about the AllAmerican Robin. My name is Robyn. I am 6 years old, in kindergarten in Middle Road School, Hazlet, N. J.

title: Alba Bogin Returns In Beethoven Concert
description: Absent from the New York concert stage for the last 20 years, Abba Bogin returned to Carnegie Hall at midnight Saturday to play (and conduct) two Beethoven piano concertos, Nos. 3 and 4, and the Prometheus Overture.

title: MISS HAYNIE RAISES STREAK IN GOLF TO 3
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 9 (UPI)Sandra Haynie of Dallas scored a twounderpar 71 today and won the 54hole Alamo open golf tournament by six strokes with a 206 total. Kathy Whitworth, last year's winner, was the runnerup.

title: Financial Analysts Calm After Currency Changes
description: Financial analysts here took a cool, almost detached view yesterday of the realignment in European currency values.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With the energy crisis upon us and crime in the streets rampant, why can we not, as does Europe, stay on daylight time the year round? The savings would be abundant.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on ColonialismSubcommittee on Caribbean Territories10:30 A.M.

title: Berio Conducts 2 of His New Works
description: Two splendid, angular teeming works by Luciano Berio were given their first New York performance by the American Symphony, led by the composer, at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon.

title: Soviet Veterans Gather to Recall World War
description: MOSCOW, May 9As a late Moscow twilight fell over Sverdlov Square in front of the Bolshoi Theater, hundreds of World War II veterans, men and women, infantry soldiers and field hospital nurses, gathered in tight little clusters, sang and danced and exchanged wartime memories.

title: College Bulletin Board Notices Open Wide Horizons
description: Would you like to buy a Lowery organ? Take trumpet lessons? Own a secondhand pair of black ballet slippers?

title: The Villian of the Crisis: Eurodollars
description: LONDON, May 9If there must be a villain in the current monetary crisis, it could well be the vast, relatively uncontrolled and somewhat mysterious entity known as the Eurodollar market.

title: DAVID G. MOYER
description: STURGEON BAY, Wis., May 9 (AP)David G. Moyer, retired vice president and director of the International Harvester Company, died yesterday in Door County Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: McGovern Renews Attack Against Hoover Over Pilot
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern said today that J. Edgar Hoover, who begins his 47th year in office tomorrow, had violated the Constitution in seeking to discredit a Trans World Airlines pilot who had criticized the F.B,I.'s handling of a hijacking case.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Despite the springtime beauty of the flowering trees and shrubs, states your editorial of May 5, Central Park has never looked worse. That seems to me an extraordinary statement. It is a little like saying that despite man's radiant good health he has never looked sicker.

title: Canadiens Conquer Hawks, 42
description: MONTREAL, May 9The two Mahovlich brothers and Yvan Cournoyer provided the goals but a 31yearold defenseman, Terry Harper, provided the drama today as the Montreal Canadiens converted 17,441 fickle spectators at the Forum with a 42 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in their Stanley Cup championship series.

title: Yen Parity Unchanged
description: TOKYO, Monday, May 10 (Reuters)  Officials of the Bank of Japan said today that Japan would maintain the rate of 360 yen to one United States dollar.

title: Levitt Says Laxity of 3 Led to L.I.R. Car Trouble
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday accused the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a car manufacturer and a consulting firm of significant laxity in accepting new Long Island Railroad cars for service two years ago despite numerous defects.

title: CANADA EXPANDS EUROPEAN TRADE
description: TORONTO, May 9  The European Banks International Company, a joint venture by four of the Continent's great banks, opened a representative office in Toronto last week. It was a noteworthy event because it was part of the gradual proliferation of Canada's Economic links with Europe.

title: World Monetary Crisis Is the Fifth in 3 Years
description: The current turmoil involving the United States dollar and the West German mark is the fifth crisis in the international money market in the last three and a half years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Lost in the polemics of the abortion debate is the question of what an abortion kills. A typical victim is the fetus at eight weeks gestation. The eightweek fetus has a human baby face, arms, legs, fingers, toes, a strongly beating heart and a brain that emits recordable Impulses.

title: HELENE SPRAGUE, 64, LEADER IN CHARITIES
description: Mrs. Helene Coughlin Sprague, a leader in charitable and civic affairs here and in Massachusetts, died Saturday at her home, 1 East 66th Street, at the age of 64. She was the widow of Julian King Sprague, who was president of the Sprague Electric Company.

title: ALBERT HKWKES, EXSENATOR, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Former Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican of New Jersey, died today at Palm Desert, Calif. He was 92 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On April 19, the present administration of New York State announced that economics demanded the layoff of personnel. Of the 8,250 people who would be laid off, 2,800 would be taken from the Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: DR. GORMAN M'VEIGH, SURGEON, DIES AT 54
description: Dr. Gorman J. McVeigh died yesterday in St, Clare's Hospital, where he was an attending surgeon. He was 54 years old and lived at 425 East 86th Street.

title: Murder Victim Identified
description: The second of three men shot fatally in a car in the High Bridge section of the Bronx early Saturday morning was identified by the police yesterday as Donald Phillips, 24 years old, whose address is unkown. The fingerprints of the third victim, about 28 years old, have been sent to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington for identification.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PERFORMING SELF. Compositions and Decompositions in the Languages of Contemporary Life. By Richard Poirier. 203 pages. Oxford. Cloth, $6.50. Paper, $1.95.

title: G.O.P. Support Aids Housing Bills
description: Although the Lindsay administration is battling Republicans in Albany over rent control, the city's other housing legislation has met with some approval because of key Republican support that had been missing in the past.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARISCertainly, Jacques Duhamel did not suspect that he was echoing a literary trend when he moved from the Ministry of Agriculture to the Ministry of Culture. For more than a century French literature has been largely urban, the earth giving rise to writings that were mostly provincial survivals or nostalgic revivals. That this is no longer the case is demon strated by three poets, Francis Ponge, Rend Char and Philippe Jaccottet, who belong to what might be called the vanguard of French literature. They have little in common except that all three live in the south of France, close to but at safe distance from the mobbed Mediterranean coast, and have turned to nature for inspiration.

title: SHOOTING REPORTED AT HAITIAN MEETING
description: A reporter told the police that he was pistolwhipped and that an unidentified man was shot in a clash that erupted yesterday after a meeting of Haitian emigres at a rented hall in St. Albans, Queens.

title: FOUR TEAMS SCORE DAVIS CUP SWEEPS
description: France, Finland and the Soviet Union registered 50 sweeps in the first round of the European Zone Davis Cup yesterday by taking the last two singles.

title: SNOWFLURRY WINS HUNTERS LAURELS
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., May 9J. Basil Ward's Snowflurry, who customarily stands in the shadow of his stablemate, Dunraven, captured the regular working hunter championship with victories in the final two classes today at the St. Clement's Horse Show.

title: Safety Is Key Item At Annual Enclave Of Eastern Skiers
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 9A growing concern about skier safety and the continued growth of the Eastern Division of the National Ski Patrol were among the chief items discussed during the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's annual threeclay convention, which was concluded at the Concord Hotel today.

title: N.Y.A.C. CREW WINS WHALEN CUP RACE
description: Stroked by 17yearold Dan Rooney of New Rochelle, the New York Athletic Club won the elite eightoared event in the Father Knickerbocker Regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Orchard Beach Lagoon today.

title: Personal Finance: Auto Insurance
description: If you are one of the estimated six million New Yorkers who owns an automobile, don't be surprised if your auto insurance rates go up when renewal time rolls around.

title: ClosedCircuit Card Lists 6 Heavyweights Tonight
description: George Foreman, the leading challenger for Joe Frazier's world title, and two former World Boxing Association champions will fight tonight in a heavyweight tripleheader that will be seen on closedcircuit television from three locations.

title: Employe Is Shot to Death In Holdup of Cheetah Club
description: A 24yearold lighting technician for the Cheetah Discotheque was shot and killed in a holdup of the club early yesterday by three masked gunmen.

title: Class 44: Shaun, a Profile of Progress
description: Shaun Sheppard, the grand old man of Class 44, marked his 12th birthday last week.

title: 5 Vietnamese Women Support Former G.I.'s Report of Slayings
description: NGHIAHANH, South Vietnam, May 9 (AP)Five Vietnamese women say the Americans came in the morning and burned the houses, returned in the afternoon and killed 60 people in two groups, then bombed the village.

title: PARTY HEAD QUITS IN SOUTH KOREA RIFT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9 The head of South Korea's leading opposition party resigned today in a factional dispute that seems likely to affect the party's prospects gravely in the National Assembly elections just over two weeks away.

title: STENNIS TO SEEK WAR POWER CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Senator John C. Stennis, who has been a strong advocate of the Vietnam policies of Presidents Johnson and Nixon, said today that he would sponsor legislation that would prohibit a President from involving the United States in another extended war without Congressional approval.

title: Bad Start for Postal Bargaining
description: The initial ninetyday period of collective bargaining under the Postal Reform Act of 1970, the first of its kind in a basic Federal service, has ended in frustration. The Government's failure to make any wage offer has left union negotiators fearful that the intent is to leave the ultimate contract to compulsory arbitration with no serious effort to arrive at a direct agreement.

title: Orlovsky's 1,854 Total Sets EightGame Bowling Mark
description: DETROIT, May 9 (UPI) Mike Orlovsky, a pro from Endicott, N. Y., rolled a record total today to pace the qualifiers for the 49 open spots in the American Bowling Congress Masters tournament.

title: Scott and Lee Grant Get BestActing Emmys
description: George C. Scott, who had earlier turned down a Motion Picture Academy Oscar, last night won a television Emmy for outstanding single performance as the selfsacrificing brother in Arthur Miller's drama The Price. The program was carried on the National Broadcasting Company's Hallmark Hall of Fame.

title: Beyond Contemporary Consciousness:
description: ANALOGY ONE: Imagine insects With a life span of two weeks, and then imagine that they are trying to build up a science about the nature of time and history. Clearly, they haven't seen enough of the seasons to build a model on the basis of a few days of summer. So let us endow them with a language and a culture through which they can pass on their knowledge to future generations. Summer passes, then.autumn, and finally It is winter. The winter insects are a whole new breed and have perfected a new and revolutionary science on the basis of the hard facts of their perceptions of snow. As for the myths and legends of summer: clearly, the intelligent insects are not going to believe the superstitions of their primitive ancestors.

title: Spotted Fever Is Resurging Across the U.S. as Population Rises in TickInfested Nonurban Areas
description: The population growth in previously sparsely inhabited, tickinfested areas outside cities has led to a resurgence of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a sometimes fatal infection that is spread throughout this country, a health official has reported.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The monthly meeting of the Athletic Conference was called to order by the president, who recognized E. L. (Pete) Knerke, the longtime athletic director at the university. Like the song says, gentlemen, times is changingo. We've got a new breed of kid who won't take because I said so for an answer. And I for one am damn proud of them. This may sound strange coming from an old white shoe like me, but maybe the problem is we haven't been responsive enough. Gentlemen, sometimes the difference between a winning season and a losing season is an inch the width of your tic or the length of your sideburns. Adjust. Remember what. Vinnie said. Knerke sat down to sustained applause, especially from the older coaches.

title: PATROLMAN'S DEATH IS RULED NONDUTY
description: The death of Patrolman Lawrence M. Powell, who was stabbed fatally early Saturday morning during a fight with three young men in Harlem while offduty has been designated officially as not in line of duty, it was learned yesterday. The designation limits the financial benefits that will be paid to his survivors.

title: New York Blind Institute Wins Eastern Track Meet
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9Richard Jennings scored all 16 points for the New York Institute of the Blind Saturday in Eastern Athletic Association for the Blind track tournament.

title: Twentieth Century Fund Urges Foundations to Pool Resources
description: The Twentieth Century Fund has proposed that foundations pool their talent and resources to help resolve problems confronting the nation.

title: Yarbrough Crashes in TuneUp But Escapes With Minor Burns
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 9 (UPI) Lee Roy Yarbrough suffered slight burns today when his car crashed into a wall of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway during a practice run over the 2mile oval.

title: Bridge World Champion Aces Lead
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 9The world champion Aces moved into the lead here tonight in the qualifying stages of the 1971 world bridge championship.

title: Popovic of Yugoslavia Is Dead; Parliament President Was 57
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 9 (AP)Milentije Popovic, President of Yugoslavia's Parliament and member of the Presidium of the ruling Yugoslav Communist party, died last night, an official announcement said. He was 57 years old.

title: Evans Wins Decathlon
description: EMMITSBURG, Md., May 9 (AP)Ron Evans, a University of Connecticut sophomore, scored 7,356 points to win the second annual United States Track and Field Federation Eastern decathlon championship today.

title: Moscow Looks to Moon Rovers
description: MOSCOWThe past decade of the space age was an era in which man for the first time broke out into space, emerged from a spacecraft into open space and landed on the surface of the moon.

title: Mr. Circus Rises to Challenge of Ringling Tigers
description: Gunther GebelWilliams, an animal handler of nearly Noahic ambition, looks strapping and roughly 6 feet tall when he works in a cageful of tigers at the circus.

title: Wallace Hailed at Texas Dinner; He Says Parties Ignore Worker
description: DALLAS, May 9The campaiga fund of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was about $40,000 richer today after boisterous thirdparty political affair that was billed as an appreciation dinner but had all the trappings of a campaign kickoff.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 9On May 8, 1970, shortly after American forces entered Cambodia, a dozen of Henry Kissinger's old colleagues at Harvard went down to Washington to talk with him. Mr. Kissinger or someone later put about that they had threatened to keep him from returning to Harvard, which was false. What they did do was express their despair at the Administration's war policy and their bewilderment at the part played in by a man of his intellect and experience.

title: $5MILLION IS RAISED IN HIKES FOR CHARITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)  About 639,000 volunteers raised more than $5million in weekend charity marches around the country, the American Freedom From Hunger Committee said today.

title: Harness Council Says Offtrack Betting Hurts Roosevelt Raceway's Business
description: Harness track owners who are vying with the city's OffTrack Betting Corporation reported yesterday that the betting handle at Roosevelt Raceway had dropped an average of $64,032 a night since the offtrack windows opened in the city April 8.

title: PAKISTAN WEIGHS DEVALUING RUPEE
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Pakistan is sending a senior economist here to persuade the Nixon Administration to resume economic aid suspended on March 25 when the civil conflict there erupted.

title: Labor Dispute Is Settled At Philadelphia lhquirer
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Inquirer reached a settlement today of a oneday wildcat strike by mailers and pressmen that halted publication of the newspaper's Sunday edition.

title: Israel Reports Firing At 2 Egyptian Planes
description: TEL AVIV, May 9Military spokesmen here reported that Israeli gunners fired at two Egyptian Air Force jets today in the Suez Canal zone. They made no mention of any hits.

title: Purchasing Agents Note Some Pickup For April Business
description: Most purchasing agents last week described business in April as improved but were quick to use such qualifying words as gradual, spotty or slightly, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Frederick Sheffield Dies at 69; Lawyer Headed Carnegie Fund
description: Frederick Sheffield, a corporation lawyer who was a leader In phitanthropic endeavors, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Wilton, Conn, His age was 69. He also lived at 215 East 72d Street.

title: PASSAIC TO ELECT NEW CITY COUNCIL
description: PASSAIC, N.J., May 9Passaic voters will name a sevenmember City Council on Tuesday in a lowkey, nonpartisan election highlighted by the candidacy of Paul McCauley who was dismissed by the Council as city manager last March.

title: CHILE LIKELY TO BUY FOUR FOREIGN BANKS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 9The four foreign private banks that operate in Chile, including two United States banks, are said to be very close to selling out to the Government.

title: Thomson Wins Dunlop Golf
description: IKEDA, Japan, May 9 (AP) Peter Thomson of Australia shot a fourunderpar 69 today for a fourday total of 280 and won the Dunlop international golf championship. Thomson scored 34's on both nines on the 6,697yard, par72 Minoo Country Club course.

title: CHARLES B. WOLFE
description: Charles B. Wolfe, vice president of Roy Duffus Associates Inc., a New York public relations firm, died Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in Marlboro, N.J. His age was 36.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: President Nixon either doesn't know or chooses to Ignore how, in 1954, Pierre MendesFrance ended the French war against the people of Indochina. Otherwise, his tactics of gradual withdrawal from Indochina, Interspersed with sporadic counterattacks and invasions, would make even less sense than they do now.

title: Asian Fete Makes It Far East 64th St.
description: The Asia Society, with little help from its friends, transformed East 64th Street into an Oriental bazaar yesterday afternoon and those who came by appeared to enjoy themselves thoroughly.

title: Japanese Worried About Effects Of China's Friendly Diplomacy
description: TOKYO, May 8Reverberations from Peking's pingpong diplomacy last month are still echoing here, and Japanese diplomats freely confess that they fear Peking's smiles far more than its frowns.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your April 22 editorial The AntiEnvironmentalists effectively demolishes the argument of those who want to create artificial oppositions between those concerned with the quality of life and those who also want to improve society.

title: Oil Sought Near Belfast
description: The Marathon Oil Company of Findlay, Ohio, will begin drilling an exploratory oil well in Northern Ireland about June 1. The site is near Ballycarry, 15 miles northeast of Belfast.

title: JEWS PRESS TALKS ON AID FROM STATE
description: MONSEY, N. Y., May 9A conference of leaders of all branches of Judaism that opened here in Rockland County today reflected a widening fissure in the oncesolid unanimity of the Jewish community in its interpretation of the principle of separation of church and state.

title: A Very Practical Gift
description: Children grow so fast it's almost impossible to buy them something practical that will last. United States Savings Bonds are practical. Children never outgrow their need for security. And there is a bonus interest rate on all United States Savings Bondsfor Series E bonds, 5 per cent when held for five years 10 months. That extra onehalf of 1 per cent, payable as a bonus at maturity, applies to all these bonds issued since June 1, 1970, with a comparable improvement for all older bonds.

title: JAZZ MESSENGERS PLAY AT TOWN HALL
description: Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers have gone through innumerable changes of personnel during, the last 15 years. But no matter who made up the trumpetsaxophone  piano  bass  and drums combination, the group has always, projected a rough, crackling, driving sound. The current Messengers, heard Saturday night at Town Hall with Betty Carter, the singer, and Gene Ammons's quintet, is one of Mr. Blakey's more polished ensembles but it still plays with that raw, identifying bite.

title: Dance: 2 Elevate Shrew
description: There is nothing much wrong with John Cranko's The Taming of the Shrew that better music and choreography would not put right. This Stuttgart Ballet production will probably appeal most strongly to people whose experience or ballet is limited and like to see a good story.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, May 9  Look at the numbers in the Legislature and the Republicans have hardly comfortable majorities.

title: The Guardian
description: Still known to incorrigible traditionalists as The Manchester Guardian, it is one of the great newspapers of the Englishspeaking world. Founded as a radical weekly in 1821, converted into a daily in 1855, and having dropped Manchester from its masthead after a recent move to London, The Guardian now celebrates its 150th anniversary.

title: Wisconsin Plans Bike Paths
description: MADISON, Wis., May 9 (UPI) Plans have been announced for a 28mile bicycle path system in Madison. The system, much of it on the University of Wisconsin campus, will be developed over a twoyear period at a cost of $80,000.

title: Awakening Consumer Stirs Corporate Profits
description: Has the consumer begun to loosen his purse strings to satisfy his whims? Has he grown resigned to inflation as another problem of today's life style and thrown caution to the winds?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The decision of the Supreme Court upholding the District of Columbia's abortion statute appeared to be a disaster to the efforts now being made to prevent the overpopulation of the world. But the situation was saved by the statement that the court would rule on the further question of whether the antiabortion laws violated women's right of privacy.

title: Russell Views Trade for Lucas As Chance to Get Off the Bench
description: MIAMI, May 9 (UPI)Cazzie Russell, traded by the New York Knicks to the San Francisco Warriors for Jerry Lucas, said today his first reaction was, How could anybody trade a great player like Lucas for me? However, the San Francisco coach, Al Attles, already was trying to talk Cazzie out of that attitude by calling him one of the most spectacular shooters in basketball.

title: Fram Strike Settled
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 9 (AP)The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers has ended a weeklong strike against the Pram Corporation, a union spokesman reported today. He said the membership had voted to accept a twoyear contract with the engine filter company calling for a total increase of 48 to 58 cents an hour. He said hourly wages now ranged from $2.41 to $3.79.

title: Yale and Penn State in Tie For Eastern Golf Crown
description: NEW HAVEN, May 9Yale and Penn State tied for the Eastern intercollegiate golf championship today with fiveman team totals of 391.

title: Look, Y'Tink Noo Yawkiz Like to Tawk Like Dis? Nah
description: A great many New Yorkers feel that it's a compliment to be told, You don't talk like a New Yorker, said Williams Labov, a professor of linguistics who has been studying the local blight.

title: NICKLAUS IS VICTOR AT DALLAS ON 274
description: DALLAS, May 9Why doesn't Jack Nicklaus win all the tournaments in which he plays? asked an impressed teenager near the 18th green of the Preston Trail Golf Club today.
