The observer had just seen the big, blond glofer hole out for a closing 66 that won the Byron Nelson Classic by two strokes with a 72hole aggregate of 274.

title: WILLIAM H. HUSSEY, A MT. VERNON MAYOR
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 9William Hart Hussey, Mayor of Mount Vernon from 1940 to 1952, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital following a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 55 Alder Lane.

title: Mets Top Cards 6th Time, 95;
description: The St. Louis Cardinals left town talking to themselves yesterday after they had lost their sixth straight game this season to the New York Mets, 95.

title: Argentine Boys Chorus Very Good at Tully Hall
description: Children's choirs can be like the little girl with the curl in the middle of her forehead, so it is a pleasure to report that El Coro Nifios Cantores de Murialdo was very, very good at its Tully Hall concert Sunday afternoon.

title: Mariner 9 Still Scheduled Despite Mariner 8 Loss
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 9The space agency moved ahead today with plans to launch another Mariner to Mars on May 18, despite the failure soon after launching last night of the Mariner 8 mission.

title: Rothschild Turns an Eye to the Pacific
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 9When a Rothschild journeys to la new part of the world, can capitalistic venture be far behind?

title: Coast Teams Win Volleyball
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., May 9 (AP)  Four California teams, led by the Santa Monica YMCA, swept the United States national volleyball championships yesterday. Santa Monica upset last year's winners, the Charthouse of San Diego for the men's division title.

title: White Poodle Best of 3,785 Dogs
description: WASHINGTON CROSSING, N. J., May 9Ch. Tally Ho Tiffany, a white miniature poodle owned by Frank and Susan Dale of Calabasas, Calif., was named best of 3,785 dogs at the 42d Trenton Kennel Club show at Washington Crossing State Park today.

title: Soccer Results GERMAN AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: Dalmatinac 4, Austria 0.

title: Leningrad Trial of 9 Jevis Expected to Open Shortly
description: MOSCOW, May 9The longdelayed trial of nine Soviet Jews reportedly charged with organized antiSoviet activity is due to open in. Leningrad on Tuesday or Wednesday, reliable sources said today.

title: New Controls Expected To Keep Them Guessing
description: BONN, May 9The West German Government decided today to loosen the reins on the mark, but introduced a series of tough new monetary controls, some of them secret, to stop the inflationary flow of speculators dollars into the country.

title: U.S. Writer Leaves Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (Reuters)Don Luce, the American who disclosed the use of the socalled tiger cages  small stone cells at Con Son prison  left South Vietnam today after nearly 13 years as a journalist and social worker here. He went to Bangkok, Thailand, after having been refused permission to stay in this country any longer.

title: Haden Jazz Group Presents a Program At the Village Gate
description: Two years ago Charlie Haden, the bassist who has been prominent in jazz since he played in Ornette Coleman's quartet in the early nineteensixties, formed his Liberation Music Orchestra to make a recording of music dedicated to creating a better world. A large part of the recording was devoted to instrumental arrangements by Carla Bley of songs associated with the Spanish Civil War. The rest was compositions by Miss Bley, Mr. Haden and Ornette Coleman.

title: Sisco and Sadat Confer for 4 Hours
description: CAIRO, May 9  Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco conferred for four hours today with President Anwar elSadat on the outcome of Secretary of State William P. Rogers's meeting with Israeli leaders in an endeavor to work out an agreement for an Israeli pullback from the Suez Canal.

title: ARTS BRING UNITY IN. HENRY STREET
description: Despite inclement weather, togetherness proved to be a success on the Lower East Side at the first annual threeday festival of the arts conducted by the Henry Street Settlement House. The festival ended yesterday.

title: GERMANS WILL FLOAT MARK TODAY; DUTCH JOIN
description: BONN, May 9 The West German Government decided today to permit the mark to floatwithin a limited rangein relation to the United States dollar.

title: Nicholas Afonsky, 77, Led Orthodox Cathedral Choir
description: Nicholasa Afonsky, conductor since 1950 of the choir of the American Russian Orthodox Cathedral here, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 59 East Second Street.

title: A Fashion Designer Who Knows About Children
description: Although fashion may be going out of style, babies never do. So designers, looking for new markets, try a little cradle snatching.

title: New Zealand Opens Big Aluminum Plant
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 9An aluminum smelter, which in a few years is expected to be the largest in the Southern Hemisphere, began production late in April in the extreme south of New Zealand.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Equatorial Guinea Under Harsh Rule
description: SANTA ISABEL, Equatorial Guinea, May 6 Africa's youngest nation, this tiny tropical land also has one of Africa's most repressive governments, even on a continent where authoritarian regimes are the rule.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: PRICE INCREASES IN STEEL STUDIED
description: PITTSBURGH, May 9  Last week's steel price increases appear to qualify as prudent from a market as well as a Government standpoint.

title: RELIGION INVOKED IN CEYLON DRIVE
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 9Government and religious leaders used Ceylon's Buddhist traditions today as a weapon in the struggle against young ultraleftist rebels.

title: They Hang Loose on Soul Day In BedfordStuyvesant Streets
description: Youngsters painted on the fronts of stores on Fulton Street in Brooklyn yesterday with the blessings of the stores owners, the police and community organizations.

title: LAVER, KODES REACH ITALIAN TENNIS FINAL
description: ROME, May 9 (AP). Fourthseeded Rod Laver of Australia smashed his way to a 63, 62, 61 victory over secondseeded Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., today in a men's singles semifinal of the Italian open tennis championships.

title: Miss Bokara Legendre Is a Bride
description: GOOSE CREEK, S. C., May 9Miss Bokara Hennen Legendre of New York was married in St. James Episcoml Church here this afternoon to Richard Gerstle Mack, a film producer.

title: Lunokhod Back in Action
description: BOCHUM, West Germany, May 9 (Reuters)The Soviet moonmobile Lunokhod 1 has resumed its activities in the Sea of Rains, according to signals picked up at tracking stations here. The signals from the remotecontrolled vehicle showed that it had again withstood the extreme temperatures of the 14day lunar night. Lunokhod 1 was launched last November.

title: Little Immediate Effect on Dollar Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The outcome of the latest international monetary crisis appears to have left the United States, and the dollar largely unaffected for the time being, financial experts here believe.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: News Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9People start pollution. People can stop it. That is the slogan of a new advertising campaign started by industrial interests with the admitted aim of deflecting some of the blame that has tended to focus on industry for the deteriorating environment. Among the campaign's possible constructive effects, one of the chief ones may be to generate public thinking about the real causes of pollution. And in a literal sense, the slogan is true, of course if the earth were inhabited entirely by shrimps or armadillos rather than people, there would exist none of the present aggravated air pollution, water pollution and other environmental ills.

title: MacDermot's Mass in F Joins Hair at Cathedral
description: The program given out at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon, printed by Playbill, announced on its cover: Hair, Birthday Celebration. Under that, in appropriately smaller and lighter type, came: Galt MacDermot's Mass in F. In what certainly must be the publicity coup of the year, the producers of the Musical arranged to mark the third anniversary of the Broadway opening in a ceremony at the cathedral, at the invitation of the church authorities. The Broadway opening, you will note, not the original, less commercial Public Theater one.

title: Foreign Aid Shambles
description: President Nixon's proposals for a radically revised foreignaid program have provoked sharp initial criticism in Congress, some of it clearly warranted, some grossly unfair. Unless the Administration and Congress can reconcile their differences and agree on the basic need for a substantial longrange international development effort, the nation's 24yearold foreignassistance program may indeed be reduced to the shambles Senator Fulbright says it is.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Yanks Deal White Sox 61 Loss
description: CHICAGO, May 9  Jack Aker overcame his Melton block today and the Yankees gained their longest winning streak of the seasonthreeby whipping the Chicago White Sox, 61.

title: J. MYER SGHINE, 78, HOTEL MAN, DEAD
description: J. Myer Sohine, multimillionaire real estate, hotel, theater and broadcasting operator, died Saturday evening of a brain tumor at the Neurological Center. He was 78 years old and lived at 4 East 66th Street.

title: Advertising:
description: Boston After Dark, youthoriented weekly tabloid has found a way of making money with free classifed ads. Find sponsors.

title: EXCHANGES PLAN A CLEARINGS POOL
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange, the nation's two largest central securities markets, disclosed plans over the weekend to consolidate their direct clearing departments in what could be a precursor of a total merger.

title: COLONEL AIM: PULL IT OUT OF THIN AIR
description: Louisville, Ky., May 9 (UPI) Fresh from two straight victories over the Utah Stars here, the Kentucky Colonels feel they are overdue to win a game in Salt Lake City where the two teams resume their American Basketball Association final playoff series on Wednesday night.

title: Bunker Assays Vietnam Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9  Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker has just completed his fourth year in America's most crucial diplomatic post, conscious of past mistakes here, proud of the progress, confident of the future but aware of the dangers that lie ahead.

title: Ches: The Root of All Evil Dictates
description: A grandmaster in this country is sometimes compelled to lead a kind of double life. When he is invited to an international tournament in Europe he plays chessand fine chess it is much of the time. When he plays in weekend Swiss system tournament in the United States, he plays cashprize chessa game closely analagous to the international variety, but different in one basic way, a draw is almost the same as a loss.

title: Lowery Unhurt in Collision
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery escaped injury yesterday when he was involved in a twocar collision on the Upper West Side. The police of the West 100th Street station said the accident occurred shortly after 9 A.M. when the Commissioner's car and another collided at 108th Street and Broadway. They said there were no injuries and damage to both vehicles was slight.

title: Trade Experts Assess Money Moves
description: What effects will the European monetary measures have on international trade?

title: RODRIGUEZ IS FIRST IN SPORTS CAR RACE
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, May 9 (AP)  Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico won a track recordshattering duel with a Porsche teammate, Jo Siffert of Switzerland, today for victory in the Francorchamps 1,000 kilometer race for sports cars. The triumph added to Porche's lead for the manufacturer's championship. Rodriguez and codriver, Jackie Oliver of England, drove the 71 laps (632 miles) in a record 4 hours 1 minute 9.7 seconds average speed of 154.427 miles an hour. The former marks were 4:09: 47.8 and 149.081 m.p.h.

title: How a Food Club Can Avoid Trouble
description: Consumer buying clubs now number more than a hundred in New York City, and although some have been operating for years, organizational problems still plague many of them.

title: Israeli Cabinet Briefed on Rogers Talks
description: JERUSALEM, May 9  Premier Golda Moir and Foreign Minister Abba Eban gave the Israeli Cabinet detailed reports today of last week's meetings with Secretary of State William P. Rogers, the Cabinet spokesman said.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: French Preparing to Examine Big Copper Deposit in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, May 9  SovietFrench discussions about development of a huge copper deposit in eastern Siberia are entering a new stage as a French technical team is preparing to conic to the Soviet Union next month for an onthespot study of the mineral site.

title: MRS. MITCHELL FED AN ELUSIVE DINNER
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) John N. Mitchell has become the first wife of a Cabinet member to be allowed to attend the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner in its 57year history. But she almost was not fed.

title: Consumer Affairs Meetings
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Office of Consumer Affairs will conduct several regional meetings in the coming weeks to bring various consumer officials and community leaders together in discussions of consumer problems, Mrs. Virginia Knauer, special assistant to the President for consumer affairs, said today. The series will start Wednesday with a meeting in New Orleans at Louisiana State University.

title: Buddhist Priest in Hue Burns Himself to Death
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9 (AP)  A young Buddhist priest burned himself to death in Hue today in a protest against the war in Vietnam.

title: Catholics Disburse $586,000 to Needy In SelfHelp Funds
description: The Roman Catholic Church in the United States has allocated $586,000 of the $8.5million that it raised last year to support selfhelp projects for the poor.

title: New Hebrides, in South Pacific, Is Becoming Popular Tax Haven
description: VILA, New Hebrides, May 9 (Reuters)The world's newest tax haven is a sunbaked, peaceful group of islands in the South Pacific.

title: Praise for The Israelis Takes Author by Surprise
description: A capsule review of The Israelis: Founders and Sons, by Amos Elon:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The fate of the nine of 17 fish hatcheries and four game farms in New York State scheduled to close because of a cutback in state funds for the Department of Environ mental Conservation was in limbo yesterday.

title: Fire Sweeps London Hotel; Seven Are Reported Killed
description: LONDON, Tuesday, May 11 (AP)Fire engulfed the Hills Hotel in an area near Kensing ton Gardens early today. Fire men reported that seven per sons were killed.

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON A SLOW AMEX
description: The American Stock Ex change suffered its fourth con secutive decline yesterday in the lightest trading in almost four months.

title: GROUND IS BROKEN FOR WALDEN WING
description: The Walden School broke ground yesterday for its five story Andrew Goodman wing, which is scheduled for com pletion at Central Park West and 86th Street in September, 1972.

title: MILLS DOUBTFUL OF REVENUE VOTE
description: NASHVILLE, May 10 (AP) Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, predicted today that the House would not even vote on President Nixon's proposal to direct $5billion in Federal revenue to the states with no strings tied.

title: Ruling in Jersey Allows Poor Free Counsel in Local Courts
description: TRENTON, May 10  The New Jersey Supreme Court ordered Municipal Courts in the state today to provide free legal counsel to indigent defendants who faced imprisonment in Mu nicipal Courts.

title: Effect on Airline Fares Of Money Shifts Weighed
description: GENEVA, May 10 (Reuters) International airlines are ar ranging meetings to discuss the effects of the weekend cur rency upheavals on internation al fares, which are mostly cal culated in dollars.

title: LEONARD J. BRADLEY, BOTANY ENTHUSIAST
description: WILTON, Conn., May 10 Leonard J. Bradley, president of the Connecticut Botanical Society from 1952 to 1960, died yesterday at his home here, 22 Horseshoe Road, after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

title: FORCE IN VIETNAM IS CUT TO 267,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP)  The United States command announced to day the beginning of the with drawal of another division from South Vietnam, the deactiva tion of a major command and a cut of 6,300 more men.

title: NIXON INQUIRY URGED IN ALLEGED KILLINGS
description: An antiwar group and a Viet nam veteran urged President Nixon yesterday to appoint commission to investigate the alleged murder by American soldiers of some 30 civilians in the South Vietnamese ham let of Truong Khanh in April, 1969.

title: LAVER WINS FINAL OF ITALIAN TENNIS
description: ROME, May 10 (AP)Rod Laver defeated upsetminded Jan Kodes, 7.5, 63, 6.3, in the final of the Italian open tennis championship today, taking the $10,000 top prize of the $45,000 purse.

title: Suburban Senators Warn Of Retaliatory Wage Tax
description: ALBANY, May 10  Eleven suburban state Senators today threatened to seek a retaliatory work tax against city residents working in their areas if the tax package submitted by New York City included an increase in the commuter tax.

title: INTEREST RATES ON BONDS CLIMB
description: Interest rates moved higher yesterday in the corporate and taxexempt bond markets.

title: Thompson, Drafted No. 1, Signed by Football Giants
description: Ralph (Rocky) Thompson, the welltraveled sprinter and the team's No. 1 draft choice, signed yesterday with the New Yorkl Giants. Terms were not re vealed.

title: Songs of Tokyo Echoed Here
description: The Japanese men, all wearing jackets and ties, sat contentedly at the low horse shoe bar. They smiled as they put down drinks and picked up songbooks, squinting at the Japanese lyrics in the dim light of candles and a few small amber and green ceiling spotlights.

title: The Great Turnpike Bust
description: Four of us were on our way from Washington to New York on Sunday afternoon. It was the end of the April 24 weekend and we were stopped cold on the Jersey Turnpike in the same traffic jam that kept everyone, Icing hairs and straights alike, from getting home.

title: Dance: Ailey and Feld Troupes Depart
description: Sunday night two dance companies completed their New York spring seasons: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the New York City Center and Eliot Feld's American Ballet Com pany at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music.

title: Dana to Phase Out Plants
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 10 (UPI) The Dana Corporation plans to phase out operations of its T. & G. division in Warren, Mich., and of its Victor Seal Oil plant in Chicago by Aug. 31. About 450 workers will be dropped, the company said today.

title: Roundup: Jenkins No. 6 a Blazing Job
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cubs, who started his majorleague career as a relief pitcher in 1965 and then went on to break a 1920 record for games started set by Grover Cleveland Alex ander, fashioned a fourhitter last night and became the first National League pitcher to win six games this year.

title: Ruling Reserved In Legal Challenge To State's Budget
description: ALBANY, May 10The Ap pellate Division today reserved decision on a challenge to the constitutionality of the state's $7.7billion budget.

title: JEWISH SCHOLAR TO LEAVE SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 10A well known Soviet scholar in Per sian and Arabic literature was one of at least 25 Jews who received permission today to emigrate to Israel, reliable Jew ish sources reported.

title: AUBREY PANKEY DIES; EXPATRIATE SINGER
description: BERLIN, May 10 (Reuter) Aubrey Pankey, a black, Ameri canborn baritone who had lived in East Germany for the last 17 years, was killed in an automobile accident over the weekend, friends in East Ber lin disclosed.

title: U. S. Denies Aid Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 10A State Department spokesman said tonight that there were no plans to send United States military equipment of any sort to Ceylon.

title: Man in the News
description: Thirty years ago, a boy growing up in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brook lyn was either procop or anticop, never neutral. For Frank Serpico, a key witness in the Bronx police corrup tion case, there was no choice:

title: Critics Circle Ceremony
description: The New York Drama Critics Circle will present its 197071 awards for the best play, mu sical and best American pro duction on Thursday at the Algonquin Hotel. The three winners are Home, produced by Alexander H. Cohen, the Royal Court Theater and Clin ton Wilder; Follies, presented by Harold Prince, and The House of Blue Leaves, pro duced by Warren Lyons and Betty Ann Besch.

title: AliFrazier Bout Promoters Are Sued for $10Million
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (AP)Two buyers of $15 tickets to see the closed circuit telecast of the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier heavyweight championship Illoght filed a $10million suit against the promoters today.

title: At Fair Time, No Rest for the Weary Father
description: Dr. Jack Graham, a New York orthopedic surgeon, missed dinner to go.

description: Article 5  No Title

title: Edward S. Haines, Directed Organizing for A.F.L.C.I.O.
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Edward S. Haines, assistant director of organization for the A.F.L.C.I.O since 1966, died of a heart attack yesterday in Montgomery General Hospital in Olney, Md. He was 53 years old.

title: Army Relaxes Hair Rules But Only by a Whisper
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)The Army slightly re laxed its hair style regula tions today. Sideburns can now extend to the bottom of the ear openings, which could be between a 16th and a quarter of an inch longer than before. The Army also eliminated the threeinch re striction on hair length. But that does not mean shoulder length locks.

title: FOREMAN SCORES KNOCKOUT IN 10TH ON TV BOXING CARD
description: TORONTO, May 10Chipping away at boxing's version of the Canadian Rocky Mountains, Jim my Ellis earned a unanimous 10 round decision over George Chuvalo tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Prosecutor Asks Panther Jury To Listen to Police Tapes A gain
description: The prosecutor at the trial of 13 Black Panthers accused of a bomb conspiracy urged the jury yesterday to listen again, after they begin deliber ations, to tapes made of Pan ther conversations by police undercover agents.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Freighter Deal Set
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI) Universal Airlines has agreed to rent or sell four Project Argosy freighters to Sagittair, Ltd., a British air freight line estab lished last year. The deal amounts to about $1.6million. She Argosy is a fourengine plane with swing nose and tail for rapid loading and unloading.

title: New Harvard Law Chief Named to Succeed Bolt
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10Albert M. Sacks, a pro fessor at Harvard Law School since 1952, has been elected clean of the school, succeed ing Derek Bok, who will be come president of Harvard on July 1.

title: State Insists Housing Is Needed at Floyd Bennett Site
description: Governor Rockefeller intends to continue his drive for con struction of 45,000 units of highrise housing at Floyd Ben nett Field, despite President Nixon's proposal to include the entire air base in the vast Gate way National Recreation Area.

title: Robert van Deusen, Headed Stone & Webster Securities
description: Robert H. van Deusen, chair man of the Stone & Webster Securities Corporation from 1949 until his retirement in 1951 died Sunday on a visit to his son here. He was 79 years old and lived in Roxbury, Conn.

title: Economic Analysis
description: PARIS, May 10The world is not quite the same as it was before the dollar crisis erupted in the foreign exchange mar kets five days ago. The French are incensed at the Germans. The Germans chafe at the French. France Is looking with a fonder eye to ward Britain. And virtually all of Eu rope is embittered at the United States. The mone tary disagreements have had their major impact inside the Common Market, where the FrenchGerman rift now threat ens to check the process of economic and political integra tion,which is what the Com mon Market is all about.

title: Big Board Selects DeNunzio and Peck
description: Ralph D. DeNunzio and Stephen M. Peck were elected yesterday to oneyear terms as chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the New York Stock Exchange, the exchange announced.

title: Advertising:
description: There's a considerable amount of interest in the agency business as to the kind of response Warren Pfaff got from a twopage ad announcing the formation of his carteltype agency.

title: I.T.T. Unit Wins Contract
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday its British subsidiary, Standard Telephones and Ca bles, Ltd., has obtained a $22 million contract to lay a 160circuit submarine cable be tween Brazil and the Canary Islands for service by 1972.

title: and Abroad
description: Then there remains the problem of the Russian and AngloFrench SST's. The opposition in this country a subsidizing an Americanbuilt plane was based in part on the judgment that it would be a misuse, if not an outright waste, of public funds. But equally important were the concern about the plane's excessive noise and the fear that it would pollute the thin air of the stratosphere. These latter objections weigh just as heavily against foreign SST's as they do against an Americanbuilt plane. Yet the Russians, the French and the English are going ahead with their planes. The danger is very real that SST's may soon be flying regularly across the Atlantic because these Governments are prepared, if necessary, to subsidize their publicly owned airlines to operate an unprofitable plane. President Pompidou's remarks after his flight in the Concorde the other day demonstrate that national prestige rather than economic or environ mental common sense is the controlling consideration.

title: PHILIP AARONSON
description: Philip Aaronson, who headed Leo H. Hirsch & Co., button manufacturers, when that con cern was absorbed by Cresthill Industries, died yesterday at his home, 200 East 57th Street, after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: SST Backers, With Nixon. Support, Seek to Revive Project in House Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 A bipartisan coalition will seek tomorrow to revive the Gov ernment's supersonic transport program.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Intergovernmental Working Group on Declaration on Human Environment 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Union to Weigh Decision
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., May 10 The 10man executive board of the teamsters that is meet ing here this week is expected to discuss who should rim for the presidency of the 2.1mil lion member union at the con vention in July.

title: China Visitor Finds A Return to Stability
description: HONG KONG, May 10Perhaps the most important message a visitor to China gets these days is that order and stability have returned to a society that was convulsed with the purges and factionalism of the Cultural Revolution bout two years ago.

title: Scholar Warns Media to Resist Attack
description: A specialist in constitutional law has surveyed the develop ment in this country of freedom of information since Colonial times and has concluded that this basic freedom is now un dergoing its most formidable challenge.

title: 12 Starters Listed for Preakness
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 (UPI) The probable field for the 96th running of the $150,000 added Preakness was increased to 12 today with the announce ment that Walter D. Fletcher's Spouting Horn will be in the starting gate Saturday at Pim lico.

title: Baker Is Philosophical on Yank Bench
description: MILWAUKEE, May 10 The Yankees had a day off today, but that was nothing unusual for Frank Baker. He's been off most of the season.

title: Site of a Ritual Burial By Neanderthals Found
description: A Columbia University anthropologist has reported finding the bones of a dismembered deer ritually buried by Neanderthals some 50,000 years ago.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In as slick a move as Walt Frazier snaking out a quick hand to steal the ball from the opposition, the New York Knickerbockers reached across the continent the other day and filched Jerry Lucas from the San Francisco Warriors. It was disguised as a trade, Cazzie Russell for big Luke. But it looked suspiciously like larceny.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Peking Is Handsome, but Other Cities Are Grim
description: HONG KONG, May 10  Peking gets the best of everything is a common saying among foreigners who have spent sonic dine In China.

title: Mets Top Astros on Harrelson's Hit, 21
description: Bud Harrelson, Jerry Grote, Gary Gentry and Tug McGraw, four of the people who have transformed the New York Mets from a tailender to league leader, fashioned a 21 victory over the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium last night.

title: G.E. Expands Its Network Of Distributors for Parts
description: The General Electric Com pany's television receiverprod ucts department announced yes terday a step up in its net work of franchised, independent parts distributors.

title: Hanoi Leader in Peking
description: PEKING, May 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  The North Vietnamese Communist party chief, Le Duan, arrived at Pe king today from Moscow after a long stay in the Soviet Union during which he attended the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party. Mr. Duan was welcomed at the Peking airport by a highranking Chinese delegation led by Pre mier Chou En Lai.

title: Aiken Opposes Lockheed Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Senator George D. Aiken, Re publican of Vermont, said today that he opposed President Nixon's plans for the Govern ment to guarantee a $250mil lion loan to Lockheed.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Orr Again Voted Top Player, Best Defenseman Awards
description: MONTREAL, May 10 (AP) Bobby Orr, Boston's outstand ing 23yearold player, equaled two National Hockey League records today by winning the Hart Trophy as most valuable player for the second time and capturing the James Norris Tro phy as top defenseman for the fourth consecutive time.

title: U.S. Screen Festival Opens Today at Hilton
description: The Educational Film Li brary Association's 13th American Film Festival will begin today at the New York Hilton.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF POTATOES RISE
description: With yesterday the last day for trading in the old crop of Maine potatoes, prices rose sharply on the New York Mer cantile Exchange.

title: ISRAEL PUTS DEATHS OF FEDAYEEN AT 1,915
description: TEL AVIV, May 10 (AP)  Military sources here reported that Israeli forces had killed 1,915 Arab guerrillas and had jailed 3,000 more since the six day war of June, 1967.

title: American Airlines Reaches Accord With Stewards Unit
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) American Airlines announced today that it had reached agreement with the Air Line Stewards and Stewardesses Association on a new contract.

title: MRS. PHILIP E. HOFFMAN
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 10Mrs. Florence Lehman Hoff man, a civic leader here and the wife of Philip E. Hoffman, a Newark lawyer and real estate executive and national presi dent of the American Jewish Committee, died today at her home, 218 North Woods Drive. She was 62 years old.

title: The Key Words Are Elegant and Pretty
description: Seventh Avenue still hasn't made the great leap forward to what passes for a con temporary style. Not that it isn't trying. As the second week of major fall openings began yesterday, Geoffrey Beene and Christian Dior New York worked valiantly to bring back elegance.

title: 3 Men Slain in Car in Bronx Are Identified by the Police
description: The three men shot to death in an automobile in the High Bridge section of the Bronx on Saturday morning were identi fied yesterday by the police.

title: Chao Said to Offer Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 (AP)The leftist Beirut news paper Al Kifah reported today a statement by Premier Chou Enlai that Communist China was ready to negotiate with the United States on the status of Taiwan.

title: G.O.P. Unit Scores Agnew
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 10 (AP)The Young Republican League of Arkansas has asked that Vice President Agnew be dropped from the national G.O.P. ticket in the next elec tion. At its convention here yesterday the league adopted a resolution saying that Mr. Agnew was a continual em barrassment to Young Republi cans attempting to build a pro gressive party.

title: PRESIDENT FACING DECISION ON CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 President Nixon is under in creasing diplomatic pressure to define as rapidly as possible the United States policy toward Communist China's membership in the United Nations, Admin istration officials said today.

title: ELDERLY SUPPORT. BILL BY KENNEDY
description: Two thousand members of the National Council of Senior Citizens, a political lobbying group, conducted a rally here yesterday to push for Congres sional approval of a national health insurance bill.

title: Watson Pleads Insanity In Sharon Tate Murders
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) Charles Watson, the only male member of Charles M. Mat son's hippiestyle family in dicted with the clan leader in the Sharon Tate murders, pleaded nat guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity to day. His trial was set for July 19.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL STEADY FOR WEEK
description: Steel production was un changed last week, compared to output the week before. Thus, operations remained at the highest levels in history.

title: Brandt Government Finds Unity After Mark Uproar
description: BONN, May 10Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government, woke up today with a fresh sense of purpose and cohesion, according to senior officials, and began implementing its new economic stability program with determination.

title: Adelphi Fights Sports Abolition
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 10  After a brief, emotional speech by a star athlete, Adel phi University's facultystudent senate rejected a recommenda tion today to abolish intercol legiate athletics.

title: Casey Tells House Group Of Plan to Beef Up S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)William J. Casey, the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress today that he planned to strengthen the agency to protect the stock buying public. He testified be fore a House Appropriations subcommittee that he was not satisfied with current S.E.C. operations because the work load had increased much faster in the last five years than the number of people to handle it.

title: RED SEA STUDY FINDS AREA IS WARMING UP
description: Two scientific research teams studying the chemical and ther mal characteristics of the Red Sea reported yesterday they had found that the area known as Atlantis II was getting warmer.

title: On Harlem Stage, a Spiritual Journey
description: The clear, operatrained voice of Shirley McKie easily pierced the medley of conga drums, guitars and tambou rines as she sang:

title: Japan Rules Out Action
description: TOKYO, May 10 (Reuters) Japan ruled out the possibility of immediately revaluing or floating the yen today, but the nation is nervously awaiting further developments from the European monetary scene.

title: Barton Tells of Decision
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP)Greg Barton, who was traded to the Philadelphia Eagles but instead signed with the Toronto Argonauts, said to day the decisive factor in his jump to the Canadian Football League was the offer of a no cut contract.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Article 14  No Title

title: Catholic Labor Group in Italy Splits Over Ties to Marxists
description: ROME, May 10 A Roman Catholic labor movement that the present Pope helped to found 25 years ago split today over the issue of Marxism.

title: 83YearOld American Still Teaching in China
description: HONG KONG, May 10  Robert Winter, the only American who remained to teach at a university under the Chinese Communists, is still at Peking University as a professor of English.

title: Magee's Challenge Forces Another Judge Out of Davis Cas
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., May 10 Pretrial hearings involving Angela Davis, the black activist, were brought to a halt today when Ruchell Magee, her co defendant, again forced the judge out of the case.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

description: Article 13  No Title

title: IN THE NATION
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.At a fund raising dinner in Dallas Saturday night Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was characteristically coy about run ning for President again in 1972. But here In Mr. Wallace's home base, veteran Wallacewatchers are merely amused by his relative reticence; he could no more fail to run, they say, than the Alabama River could fail to flow past this historic old first capital of the Confederacy.

title: Throng Welcomes Nina Simone, Bach After Long Absence
description: Ten years ago Nina Simone was justly praised for her spell binding, jazz singing, hypnotic mood and many intricate shades of black. Then she moved more toward rhythmic, gospellike music, and finally more and more into African culture. Sun day she made her first New York appearance in a year and a half at Carnegie Hall before an adoring audience.

title: British Announce Accord With Lockheed on Rolls
description: LONDON, May 10The Brit ish Government announced to day that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had agreed to pay a further $120million for 555 RollsRoyce jet engines to pow er its Tristar airbus.

title: MortgageRate Prediction
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, advised prospective home owners today to buy now because mortgage rates were not likely to continue their de cline.

title: A WeekLong Memorial Begins at Jackson State
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 10 Student government lead ers at Jackson State College began today a weeklong me morial program, a year after two black youths were slain by police gunfire on the campus.

title: Management Slate Wins at GAF
description: The proxy fight for control of the GAF Corporation ended yesterday with an announce ment by the management that its slate of directors had been reelected by a margin of 2 to 1.

title: Blast Strikes Coast Bank
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 10 (AP)A branch office of the Bank of America was bombed last night, the third time within a month that the bank's branches in Alameda County had been hit by explosions. The police said that damage would run several thousand dollars.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: NAVY AIDE GUILTY IN ARCTIC SLAYING
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 10 (UPI)Mario J. Escamilla was convicted today of involuntary manslaughter in the shooting death of his superior on an iso lated floating ice island in the Arctic Ocean.

title: Nixon Sees Gateway Area by Air
description: NEWARK, May 10  Presi dent Nixon and top state and city officials from two states took a 30minute helicopter tour today of the proposed Gateway National Recreation Area at the mouth of New York Harbor.

title: POLISH AIDE'S KILLER DOOMED IN PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 10 A special military court sen tenced to death Mohammad Feroze Abdullah, a truck driver fore Pakistan International Air lines, today on charges of hav ing killed four persons, includ ing a Polish official. Feroze had pleaded not guilty, citing in sanity, in the death of the four last Nov. 1. He was at the wheel of a airline truck when it rammed into a reception line formed at the Karachi airport to welcome the then Polish President, Marshal Marian Spy chalski. President Spychalski, who was only a few feet away, was unhurt. But Foreign Minaster Zygfryd Wolniak and three Pakistanis were killed.

title: Books of The Times
description: DOWN THE RABBIT HOLE. Adventures and Misadventures in the Realm of Children's Literature. By Selma G. Lanes. 239 pages. Atheneum. $7.95.

title: CITY FINDS A JUMP IN COLLEGEBOUND
description: Seventysix per cent of last year's 68,400 city highschool graduates went on to some form of fulltime higher educa tion, according to a City Uni versity study released yester day.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES CUTS IN MEDICAID
description: Cutbacks in New York State's Medicaid program for the medically needy, scheduled to become effective next Saturday, were challenged yesterday as contrary to Federal law.

title: State Judge Rules Municipalities Can Select Sites for Abortions
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 10A State Supreme Court justice ruled here today that a muni cipality may regulate where justifiable abortional acts may be performed.

title: Long Island G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Defense Department said today that Pfc. Alin E. Norris of Floral Park, L.I., of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Reagan Asks High Fee To Deter Invitations
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 10 (UPI)An aide to Ronald Reagan said today that the Governor had set his speech fees at $25,000 an appear ance to discourage invita tions and thus avoid the impression that he planned to challenge President Nixon in 1972.

title: Egypt's Offensive Ability Is Viewed as Limited
description: CAIRO, May 6The Soviet Union, according to the best qualified neutral sources, has provided Egypt with strong air defenses, but not with the weapons and training required for a Major offensive against Israel across the Suez Canal.

title: ARTHUR KRAHMER, 69, FORMER EDITOR HERE
description: Arthur Krahmer, who retired as executive editor of The Journal of Commerce in 1969, died Saturday of a heart at tack in La Jolla, Calif., where he had moved. He was 69 years old and had lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Buckley Urges Local Help by Business
description: Senator James L. Buckley, warning yesterday of an ero sion of public confidence in government, attacked what he called indifference by business to community problems and flattery of the mob in con frontations like those in Wash ington last week.

title: DR. PHYLLIS WRIGHT
description: CLEVELAND, May 10Dr. Phyllis Wright who recently left St. John's University in New York, where she had been assistant professor of market ing in the College of Business Administration since 1964, died here Sunday at the age of 55.

title: Heart Transplant by Barnard Is His First in Over 2 Years
description: CAPETOWN, May 10 (UPI)  The surgeon Christiaan N. Barnard, who recently accused doctors of refusing to send him patients, performed his first heart transplant in more than two years today.

title: Civic and Labor Groups Plan Drive for Open Housing
description: More than a score of na tional civic and labor organiza tions agreed yesterday on a ma jor campaign to persuade Amer icans everywhere  in suburbs, unions, corporate leadership and politicsof the need for open housing where the jobs are.

title: Airline Cutback Approved
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized Eastern Air Lines today to suspend services tem porarily at AkronCanton, Ohio.

title: From Stretch Fabric and Yak Hair, a Background for Living
description: Sunlight and shadows play on the diaphanous walls, walls that curve and dip to form here a column, there a cave, elsewhere a tunnel and beyond, a domed ceiling over a sleeping bower.

title: Eisenhowers Rent in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) President Nixon's daughter Julie and her husband, Ens. David Eisenhower, have rented an apartment on the beach in Florida, about five miles from the Mayport Naval Station, where he will be stationed after a summer cruise. Their two bedroom apartment in Atlantic Beach is above a garage owned by Dr. and Mrs. David Cheshire, who live in the main house.

title: Burger Names Two Judges To Study Rules of Courts
description: WASHINGTON May 10 (AP)  Two Federal appeals judges were appointed today by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to head advisory com mittees on possible changes in the rules under which Federal Courts operate.

title: East Pakistan's DeepWater Port Is Still All but Paralyzed
description: CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, May 10War, sabotage and a stag gering absentee rate at key fa cilities have virtually paralyzed this deep water port on the Bay of Bengal.

title: USLIFE PURCHASES COLUMBIA SAVINGS
description: The USLIFE Corporation an nounced yesterday that it has completed its acquisition of the Columbia. Savings and Loan As sociation for a purchase price of approximately $23million, which includes $1million in US LIFE common stock.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Occidental Gets a Driliship
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (UPI) The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it had contracted with Western Offshore Drilling and Explora tion Company, a division of the Fluor Corporation, for use of its drillship in a multiwell explora tory drilling program on a 2,000,000acre tract off the coast of Peru. Drilling is ex pected to begin next month about 50 miles off the coast. Under an agreement with Texaco, Inc., Occidental holds an interest of about 90 per cent in any future production from the concessions.

title: Dr. Paul R. ColemanNorton, ExPrinceton Classicist, Dies
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 10 Dr. Paul R. ColemanNorton, an associate professor emeritus of classics at Princeton Univer sity and an authority on Ro man law, died last night at Princeton Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 81 McCosh Circle in Princeton.

title: DR. PETER I. POLLAK
description: RAHWAY, N.J., May 10  Dr. Peter I. Pollak, executive director of animal health prod uct development for Merck Sharp & Dohme Research Lab oratories here, died yesterday of a heart attack in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 52 years old and lived at 315 Pearl Place, Scotch Plains.

title: NEW RIGHTS STUDY FINDS SOME GAINS IN ENFORCING LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 The United States Commission on Civil Rights, which reported seven months ago that the Gov ernment had virtually ab dicated its responsibility in rights enforcement, said today that there had since been some progress in enforcement by the Nixon Administration.

title: Dead Monk Excommunicated
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP)The Buddhist hierarchy today excommuni cated Thich Chon The, a 27 yearold monk, who burned himself to death yesterday in Hue in protest against the war in Vietnam.

title: BENATE TAKES UP DRAFT EXTENSION
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Senate began today a na tional security debate that os tensibly focused on extension of the draft but was broaden ing to include the Vietnam war and military commitments in Europe.

title: The Talk of Parma Heights
description: PARMA HEIGHTS, Ohio This small city on the south western edge of Cleveland, with its welltended lawns and rows of neat little houses, looks like any sub urb. But there is a difference. Parma Heights is a suburb of a suburb.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Article 12  No Title

title: Quakes Rock Italy
description: ARIANO IRPINO, Italy, May 10 (AP)Eight overnight earth shocks in this Appennine Moun tain region, 60 miles inland from Naples, sent residents of a half dozen towns fleeing into the streets. No injuries were reported.

title: Nominee to Dispose Of $500,000 Stock To Get Interior Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Nathaniel P. Reed as Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Fish and Wild life and Parks after he volun teered to divest himself of $500,000 worth of oil stock.

title: No U.S. Currency Move Set Now
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 The Treasury said today that foreignexchange markets ap pear to be adjusting in orderly fashion to the weekend cur rency decisions by four Euro pean countries and added that no immediate action by the United States is called for.

title: Movie on the Nazi Occupation Stirs Social Ferment in France
description: PARIS, May 10  A four andahalfhour documentary, Le Chagrin et la Pitie (The Affliction and the Pity), concerned with the Nazi oc cupation of France, is stirring dormant memories and wide discussion in Paris. Mention of it in whatever social cir cles is apt to turn suddenly personal, bringing the abrupt inquiry: What did you do during the war?

title: CRIMINAL EFFORT ON DOCKS STUDIED
description: The Wkterfront Commission of New York Harbor questioned eight men yesterday about un derworld efforts to influence business on the waterfront here by pressuring companies active on the docks.

title: Drew U. Plans to Expand
description: MADISON, N.J., May 10 (AP) Drew University announced today a plan for a $16.2million program for building and ex panding its operations over the next four years.

title: POLICEMAN TELLS OF UNIT'S GRAFT
description: A New York police lieu tenant once offered his attic as a hiding place for some of the bribes his unit was re ceiving from gamblers, a police man testified yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Area Loses 88,000 Jobs in a Year
description: The number of jobs in the metropolitan area decreased by 88,000 in the 12 months ended March 31, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday.

title: FREDERICK B. CONANT
description: PASSAIC, N. J., May 10 Frederick B. Conant, a lawyer and former magistrate here died yesterday in the Chestnut Hills Convalescent Home. He was 89 years old and lived at 215 Passaic Avenue.

title: A Daughter for Tiny Tims
description: Tiny Tim's wife gave birth to their first child yesterday. The mother, Mrs Victoria May Khoury, 19, and the daughter were reported in good condition at Doctors Hospital. Tiny Tim is the stage name of Herbert Khoury, a falsetto singer of old songs. A year ago his wife suffered a miscarriage.

title: Aftermath of the SST at Home
description: The lobby for the supersonic transport does not give up easily. Its supporters intend to offer an amendment in the House of Representatives today to restore funds for the SST. No new arguments have emerged since the House and Senate several weeks ago voted to kill the SST. The House would be wasting its own time and the public's money if it reopened this controversy.

title: Legislature Votes 30Day Limit For Natural Mother in Adoption
description: ALBANY, May 10The Sen ate voted final approval tonight of a bill that would limit a mother to 30 days in which to change her mind after signing over her child for adoption.

title: The Death Of a Hired Man
description: ALGONA, IowaThere is one offi cial form filled out for each human being which the subject never sees. That is his obituary form.

title: Jersey Assembly Approves 18 as Age of Majority
description: TRENTON, May 10A con troversial proposal to lower the legal age of majority in New Jersey from 21 to 18 years old received initial legislative ap proval today In the Assembly before the Legislature ad journed its spring session.

title: Railroad Signalmen Call A Strike for Monday
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (AP) The Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen called a strike of its 13,000 members across the nation for 6 A.M. local time next Monday over wage and fringe benefit demands.

title: ATTORNEYS CLASH IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 10 Defense and Government at torneys in the Berrigan con spiracy case accused each other today of exploiting the news media with pretrial pub licity.

title: Rutgers Program Slates A Black World Film Fete
description: The African and AfroAmeri can sturlies program of Rutgers Collerze is presenting its 1971 Blacik Viorld Film Festival and Symposium from Thursday through Sunday.

title: 75 Die in Korean Bus Crash
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 10  At least 75 persons were drowned today when a bus with nearly 90 passengers aboard plunged into a reservoir near Chongpyong, 30 miles east of Seoul. Only 14 survived.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Yields on United States Treasury bills declined in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Hoffa Loses Plea to Serve Terms Concurrently
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI) A Federal judge denied today a motion by attorneys for James R. Hoffa to allow him to serve a fiveyear sentence for mail fraud concurrently with the eightyear term he is now serving for jury tampering.

title: State Building in Harlem Finally Becoming Reality
description: There is still little resem blance between models of the 20story Harlem State Office Building and the structure now going up, but despite re verses the black professionals involved in its construction are more hopeful about it now than they once were.

title: S.E.C.'s Staff Tells Fund To Hold Social Issues Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Mutual funds will apparently be required, in the future, to let their shareholders vote on whether fund managers should consider the social policies of corporations before investing in their stock.

title: DEFECTORSAYSHANOI HAS ALIEN ADVISERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 10 (AP)A highranking defec tor from North Vietnam said today that Soviet, Chinese, Cuban, North Korean and French military strategists were advising Communistled forces fighting in South Vietnam.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11  No Title

title: Catonsville Nine Moving
description: Daniel Berrigan's The Trial of the Catonsville Nine will move from the GoodShepherd Faith Church in Lincoln Center to the Lyceum Theater, 145 West 45th Street, on June 2. The current tenant of the Lyce um, 'The School for Wives, will close May 29.

title: Federal Paperwork Jungle Charged by Drug Concern
description: CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI) Abbott Laboratories, Inc. has charged that the Federal Gov ernment has created a paper work jungle that is seriously impeding progress in the fight against hepatitis. Hepatitis, liver disease, kills 3,000 Ameri cans yearly.

title: MAYOR DEFEATED 0N TRAILER PARKS
description: Overriding Mayor Lindsay, the Board of Estimate voted 16 to 6 yesterday against moving slum families into trailer parks pending completion of urban renewal projects.

title: DR. GERALD R. AUGBURN
description: Dr. Gerald R. Augburn, an English teacher at the Fieldston School, died Sunday in Roose velt Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 32 years old and lived at 316 West 84th Street.

title: Miss Stefanie Tashjian Is a Bride
description: Miss Stefanie Sarkis Tash jian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Tashjian of Brock ton, Mass., was married here yesterday noon to David George Woodbridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wood bridge of New York, where Mr. Wr>odhridge is associate professor of history at Bar nard College. Mr. Tashjian teaches English at Brockton High School.

title: BEETHOVEN AND ORFF OFFERED BY CHORALE
description: It would be hard to imagine two more contrasting choral works than Beethoven's Mass in C and Orff's Carmina Bu rana. The Mass is a compara tively restrained, personal re ligious statement, while the Orff cantata celebrates the pleasures of the flesh with un bridled exuberance.

title: Trials Set for 2 Panthers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Harold B. Hove today set new trial dates for Huey P. Newton and David Hilliard, two leaders of the Black Panther party. He set May 26 for the retrial of Newton in the 1968 killing of a policeman, and June 1 for the trial of Mr. Hilliard in connec tion with a Pantherpolice shooting the same year.

title: Canadian Dollar Is Steady
description: TORONTO, May 10  The Canadian dollar, which has been floating in value since June 1, 1970, traded within narrow range today. Its rela tionship to the United States dollar was unaffected by the gyrations in European curren cy markets.

title: Bridge:
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 10 The two leading teams, the world champion Aces and the French entry, battled to an indecisive result in the eighth qualifying round of the 1971 world championship here to night. The match was close throughout, with the lead changing hands frequently, and at the end the European champions led by 4 interna tional match points, giving them 11 victory points to 9 for the Aces.

title: Cigarettes Confiscated in Queens Raid
description: All right, the door is open ing. All units move in. As the words came through the walkie talkie, three cars carrying armed special agents of the State Tax Department con verged on a rundown garage on a back street in Bayside, Queens, yesterday, to seize two men and several thousand car tons of bootlegged cigarettes.

title: Retail Sales Up in April, But Less Than in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Retail sales rose again in April but not as much as the strong March showing, preliminary figures from the Census Bureau indicated today. April sales, seasonally adjusted, were put at $32,344,000,000, up $160 million from March, or one half of 1 per cent. The in crease in March over Feb ruary was $570million or 1.8 per cent.

title: Irving R. Benjamin Dead at 70; With Audubon Society 48 Years
description: Irving Robert Benjamin, who retired as vice president in charge of finance of the Na tional Audubon Society in 1965, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 2640 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Negro Scheduled to Be Named Head of School Board Today
description: Isaiah E. Robinson Jr. is scheduled to be elected presi dent of the City Board of Edu cation when it holds its annual meeting today.

title: YOUTH HANGS SELF IN JERSEY CITY JAIL
description: JERSEY CITY, May 10  A 19yearold youth hanged him self in a jail cell in Jersey City Municipal Jail today shortly after his girl friend was caught passing him narcotics, the police said.

title: Gen. Turner Given 3 Years in Prison In Gun Fraud Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 10  Carl C. Turner, a retired major general who was once the Army's chief law enforce ment officer and chief United States marshal, was sentenced today to three years in prison on charges of illegally obtain ing 136 guns from the Chicago. Police Department.

title: Drug Analysis Is Planned To Deter Students Use
description: STONY BROOK, L. 1., May 10A testing program in which illicit drugs would be analyzed for impurities or poisonous adulterants is planned by stu dents and health officials on the State University campus here.

title: Retired Admiral Is 105
description: CORONADO, Calif., May 10 (AP)  Adm. Richard Harrison Jackson, retired, celebrated his 105th birthday today. Greetings included congratulations from President Nixon and Gov. Ron ald Reagan and a fourbyfive foot card signed by 122 ad mirals.

title: Swiss Reaction to Revaluation Is Mixed.
description: GENEVA, May 10Switzer land's exportminded industrial ist is unhappy, the Swiss hotel keeper is worried but hoping for the best and the Swiss housewife will believe the promised cuts in food costs when she sees them.

title: JAMES AND BAND BRING REAL SWING
description: The real thing showed up Sun day night at Barney Google's, 225 East 86th Streeta genu ine, working, professional, swingerastyle dance band, It was Harry James's band, sneak ing into New York on its an nual dash east from Las Vegas, where it plays for 20 weeks or more every year.

title: Government and Texas Gird for Battle Over Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  A showdown battle over pollution in Galveston Bay is shaping up between the Federal Govern ment on the one hand and the state of Texas and sonic of the nation's largest industrial cor porations on the other.

title: 600 Holders Told Year Should Be Better Than 70
description: Currency movements in Eu rope will not affect operations of W. R. Grace & Co., J. Peter Grace, chairman, said following the company's annual share holder meeting yesterday.

title: Nixon Reported Weighing Revamping of Intelligence Services
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  President Nixon is said to be considering a major reorgani zation of the nation's foreign intelligence activities to im prove output and cut costs.

title: French Ease Terms for British to Join Bloc
description: BRUSSELS, May 10France took significant steps today to ward agreement on the terms for Britain's entry into the Common Market.

title: HEARING TO OPEN IN COPELAND CASE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 10 The tangled financial affairs of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. will be aired publicly to morrow against an increasingly complex backdrop of charges, countercharges and indictments surrounding his family and associates.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Advertising:
description: This fall the phenomenon of the independent media company will be five years old.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: FREDERICK W. THEIS
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 10Frederick W. Theis, who retired in 1969 as general man ager of Aetna Life & Casualty, Inc., in Brooklyn, died today in Nassau Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 123 William Street here.

title: U.S. Prices Held Firm By Foreign Concerns
description: No changes in pricing pol icies were reported yesterday by European companies do ing business here whose countries are involved in monetary changes.

title: Beyond Contemporary Consciousness
description: The unconscious is not personal. Behavioral psychologists, bringing up the rear with the dead mechanistic science of the eighteenth century, would assert that culture operates only through social interactions; for them space separates and what does not touch physically or symbolically can have no effect upon anything.

title: 6 Charged by Athens, Including ExMagistrate
description: ATHENS, May 10  Six prominent Greeks arrested in a security crackdown that began last November have been charged with conspiracy and violation of the law on explosives  offenses now tried by military courts. There have been at least 16 bomb explosions in the Ath ens area since last fall.

title: KINNEY SERVICES SET PROFIT MARK
description: Kinney Services, Inc., which includes in its operations, War ner Bros. Pictures, achieved rec ord revenues and earnings in the second fiscal quarter and six months ended March 31, according to the company's re port issued yesterday.

title: Rogers Reports to Nixon; Mildly Hopeful on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Secretary of State William P. Rogers delivered a report on his Middle Eastern tour to President Nixon today. Aides described the report as cau tiously optimistic about the prospects for an agreement be tween Israel and Egypt to re open the Suez Canal, which has been closed since 1967.

title: Honeywell Holders Defeat Dissidents Slate Soundly
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 10 (UPI)  Two dissident stockholder groups atta'ked Honeyi'ell, Inc., today for making barbaric weapons of war and proposed their own director candidates, but stockholders overwhelm ingly reelected present direc tors and turned down three pro posed changes in company pol icy.

title: Executive Changes
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., an nounced yesterday that Harold Rosner, president of its 437store apparel chain, Robert Hall Clothes, will retire on June 30. He will also retire as execu tive vice president and director of United Mer chants. Simultaneously the company announced that Achilles Suyker will assume the newly created office of chairman. His executive functions will include those of chief financial officer. Joseph Ber lin has been elected president and will serve as chief operational officer.

title: Lessons of the Money Crisis
description: The international monetary system, based on the prin ciples that all national currencies would be pegged to the United States dollar and that the dollar would be uni versally acceptable as a form of monetary reserves, has suffered a severe shock from the crisis of the past days.

title: Iran Beats U.S. Polo Team
description: TEHRAN, Iran, May 10 (AP) The Iranian national polo team beat a team from the Myopia Hunt Club in Hamilton, Mass., 10 today in the final game of an eightnation inter national tournament.

title: ESSE E. ROUTH
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 10 Esse E. Routh, who retired in 1950 as vice president and sales director of Mathieson Chemical Corporation, now OlinMathie son, died last Thursday at his home, 6 Hemlock Road, after a short illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Pravda Puts Blame on U.S In Currency War Threat
description: MOSCOW, May 10 (Reuters) Pravda put the blame for the capitalist world's money crisist squarely on the United States today.

title: Notes on People
description: Preparations for the wed dingPatricia Nixon's at the White House June 12are going ahead full steam. Yes terday Miss Nixon announced her choices of china, silver and crystal patterns, and her fiance, Edward Finch Cox, re vealed that his brother will be best man.

title: DUKE POWER RAISED INCOME IN QUARTER
description: The Duke Power Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net in come for the March quarter. The report placed electric rev enues at $110,266,000, up from $93,231,000 a year earlier. Net income of $15,547,000, or 43 cents a share, up from $13, 975,000, or 48 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, 1970. It was noted that pre ferred dividend requirements rose to $3.6million from $2.3 million a year earlier.

title: DECLINE IS FORECAST FOR WINTER WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 CAP) The Agricultural Department forcast today the production of winter wheat this year at 1,020,566,000 bushels, down per cent from 1970 output.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I respectfully disagree with your April 30 editorial which maintains that placing tolls on the four East River bridges would be for the general benefit of the city.

title: G.I. to Be Tried in Slaying Of Commander in Vietnam
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, May 10 (UPI)A 20yearold American private will be tried by general courtmartial on charge of premeditated murder in the shooting of his command ing officer, a United States Army spokesman said today.

title: Tourists Dollar Problems Show Some Easing in the Mark Crisis
description: GENEVA, May 10American tourists discovered that their dollar  acceptability problems were almost over today in the small mountainous countries that raised the value of their currencies last night7 per cent for the Swiss franc and 5 per cent for the Austrian schilling.

title: HUMPHREY SCORES NIXON ON ECONOMY
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 10  Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey delivered a stinging at tack on the Nixon Administra tion's economic policies today amid repeated cheers of dele gates to the convention here of the International Ladies Gar ment Workers Union.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices moved grudg ingly downward on low volume yesterday as ripples from the latest currency crisis abroad did little more than lap at thos feet of Wall Street. The Dow. Jones industrial average slipped 4.42 points to 932.55.

title: 2 U.S. SCIENTISTS WILL VISIT CHINA
description: Two American biologists are reported by their colleagues to be in China or about to go there from Hanoi, the North Vietnamese capital. A third American, a geophysicist from the University of California at Santa Cruz, is also said to have received permission to visit Peking shortly.

title: Thomas Gibson 3d Weds Cynthia Laura Maurer
description: Miss Cynthia Laura Maurer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd L. Maurer of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Plainfield, Mass., was married Saturday to Thomas Living stone Gibson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Jr. of Okla homa City. The Rev. George Thorns performed the cere mony in the Church of Saanen in Saanen, Switzer land.

title: FLOATING MARK RAISED FURTHER IN WARY TRADING
description: LONDON, May 10  The West German mark, floating to find a new rate, was given a wary reception today as of ficial European foreign exchange markets reopened af ter an extraordinary weekend of currency changes.

title: MURRAY RAPPAPORT
description: Murray Rappaport, a former partner in the national account ing firm of Harris, Kerr, Forster & Co., 420 Lexington Avenue, died Sunday at his home in Hallandale, Fla. His age was 73.

title: Lehman Pavilion Will Cost $8Million
description: The Metropolitan Museum's controversial Lehman Pavil ion will cost an estimated total of $8million, Thomas P. F. Hoving, the museum's director, said yesterday. The construction money has come from private funds, whose sources Mr. Hoving declined to reveal, while maintenance and operation costs of the pavilion will be assumed by the Robert Lehman Founda tion.

title: Israeli Paper Reports Sabry Is Under Detention in Cairo
description: JERUSALEM, May 10 (UPI) The Jerusalem Post reported today Aly Sabry, ousted as Vice President of Egypt last week, has been placed under house arrest in Cairo.

title: Market Place. Penn Central's Refunding Plan
description: Cancel that box lunch for May 28. The Penn Central, Company has postponed in definitely its longawaited annual meeting while it awaits financial statements from its bankrupt railroad, the Penn Central Transporta tion Company, and other sub sidiaries.

title: New Towns Here Held Essential to Ease Pressures
description: Officials from New York, New Jersey and Oonnecticut met in a seminar here yester day to talk over the problems and prospects of developing new towns and planned com munities in and around the metropolitan area.

title: ST. JOE MINERALS RAISES ZINC PRICE
description: Zinc prices were raised yes terday for the second time in less than two months, reflecting improvement in markets for the metal and a decline in the in ventories of producers and users.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster Aid for Kentucky
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) President Nixon declared to day eight counties in Kentucky a major disaster area because of tornadoes that struck on April 27.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The prog ess of paranoia:

title: Christian Democrats in Chile Favor Communitarian Socialism
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10 The Christ ian Democratic party, Chile's largest opposition force, declared itself today in favor of socialism, but not under full state control.

title: Gettysburg Golfers Take Middle Atlantic Team Title
description: ROBBINSVILLE, N.J., May 10 (AP)Gettysburg College de feated Lehigh by eight strokes today to win the second annual Middle Atlantic Conference golf championships.

title: Johnson, Former Rider, Named to Racing Hall
description: Alfred Johnson, who rode two winners in the Kentucky Derby and in the Belmont Stakes, has been chosen for the hall of fame of the Na tional Museum of Racing.

title: ScanOptics Sets Deal
description: At the annual meeting of ScahOptics, Inc., yesterday in Hartford, Anthony. B. Coburn, chairman, announced the sign ing of a preliminary agreement with the Randolph Computer Corporation for up to $18mil lion in lease financing pf opti cal scanning systems over a threeyear period. Randolph in return has been granted the rights to purchase up to 80,000 warrants of common stock at a price of $16 a share.

title: Canada Plans Launching
description: OTTAWA (AP)  Canada signed an agreement today to launch her first space commu nications satellite late in 1972 and a backup satellite six months later.

title: Union Pressure Kills Bill To Amend the Taylor Law
description: ALBANY, May 10Bowing to pressure exerted by mem bers of public employes labor unions, the Republican leader ship in the Assembly today killed a bill that would have restricted the matters on which such unions could negotiate.

title: Ali INQUIRY DELAYS MARINER LIFTOFF
description: CAPE KENNEDY, May 10 (UPI)The new administrator of the space agency said today that the launching of Mariner 9 toward Mars could be delayed until the end of May, if neces sary to make certain that it would work.

title: Clarity Is Essential
description: Secretary of State Rogers's arduous pilgrimage through the Middle East appears to have revived prospects for an interim agreement to reopen the Suez Canal and thus to reduce the danger of a fresh outbreak of fighting along this most volatile ArabIsraeli ceasefire line. By his personal intervention, Mr. Rogers has underscored the concern felt in this country over the persisting stale mate in the peace mission of United Nations Ambassador Gunnar Jarring and the rising threat of renewed conflict.

title: 100 Laborites in Parliament Back Common Market Entry
description: LONDON, May 10  The La bor party's members of Parlia ment who want Britain to join the Common Market stood up to be counted today: They numbered 100.

title: California National Park Rule Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 10A National Park Service proposal to turn over administration of the Redwood National Park to California drew strong opposi tion today in the Senate Interior Committee.

title: YEKATERINA BELASHOVA
description: MOSCOW, May 10Yekate rina F. Belashova, a Soviet sculptor, died here today at the age of 65.

title: Piano Finalists Chosen
description: Four pianists were chosen to compete in the finals of the Leventritt International Compe tition this afternoon. They are Alberto Reyes of Uruguay, James Fields of the United States, Verda Erman of Tur key, and Kun Woo Paik of Korea. The contest will begin at noon at Carnegie Hall.

title: Arms for Ceylon Rebels Reported Seized
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 10 Wellplaced sources said today that foreign fishing boats had been intercepted while bringing arms to the insurgents here.

title: ExLeader of G.O.P. on L.I. Pleads Guity to Larceny
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 10 (UPI)A former Babylon Town Republican leader, Fred Fell man, pleaded guilty today in State Supreme Court here to one count of seconddegree grand larceny.

title: Run the Gantlet Triumphs by Three Lengths in First Start as 3YearOld
description: Run the Gantlet of the Roke by Stable made his first start as a 3yearold yesterday, and the performance was eminent ly satisfactory. Competing in a sixfurlong sprint against oppo sition that included older horses, Run the Gantlet rallied in the stretch and scored by three lengths over Ogden Phipps's Plotting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Those who demand our immediate withdrawal from Vietnam have many strong arguments in their favor. Cer tainly our direct involvement in Indo china has proven to be politically un wise. The various governments of South Vietnam have not been as en lightened or as efficient as most Americans would like. Corruption, graft, and war profiteering are detesta ble anywhere.

title: TVRadio: When the Week Is Fairly Typical
description: The Emmy Awards and Hair. Federal Communica tions Commissioner Nicholas Johnson and a Puerto Rican hodega on the Lower East Side. Dr. Harvey Cox of the Harvard Divinity School and Germaine Greer, author of The Female Eunuch. Woody Allen, describing himself as the only person I know who's been booed at an orgy, and Johnny Carson ex plaining that being a tele vision vice president is analo gous to being a dance direc tor at Forest Lawn cemetery.

title: MITCHELL URGES ALL POLICE COPY CAPITAL'S TACTICS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Attorney General John N. Mit chell urged the police in other cities today to copy the de cisive tactics, which included mass arrests, used by the Wash ington Police Department to break up the Mayday demon strations last week.

title: MAURICE J. RYAN
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 10Maurice J. Ryan, who re tired in 1965 as chief claims examiner of the New York City Transit. Authority, died yester day in Sun Coast Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and had homes in Madeira Beach near here and at Sag Harbor, L. I.

title: GOV WEST REJECTS INTEGRATION FUND
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 10 Gov. John C. West has vetoed a $97,000 Federal grant sought by a 24member South Caro lina group, half white and half black, to establish a center to promote quality Integrated ed ucation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NADER PROVOKES SENATOR'S ANGER
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  Ralph Nader, the con sumer advocate, provoked a Senator into deskpounding anger today by accusing a Con gressional Committee of writ ing toothless legislation to deal with what Mr. Nader described as massive thievery by the automobile industry.

title: 25% of School Lunches Free or at Cut Prices
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)More than onefourth of all school lunches are now being served free or at cut rate prices, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 11 Are Left in Preakness As Leematt Is Scratched
description: BALTIMORE, May 11  C. Oliver Goldsmith's Leematt, a roan speedster, was withdrawn today from the $150,000added Preakness on Saturday, leav ing 11 3yearolds pointed for the middle Jewel of the Triple Crown at Pimlico race course.

title: S. M. POMERANTZ, 81, DRESS CONCERN AIDE
description: Solomon M. Pomerantz, treasurer of Leslie Fay, Inc., large dressmanufacturing con cern, died of a heart attack on Monday evening at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 595 West End Ave nue.

title: EVERY week, more than 26,000 Jobs are advertised In The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.Advt.
description: EVERY week, more than 26,000 Jobs are advertised In The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.Advt.

title: ALLEN C. SHERMAN
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 11Allen C. Sherman, who retired in 1959 as presi dent of the George E. Sherman Company of Brooklyn, now Grestco Dyes & Chemicals Inc., died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: U. S. Denies Responsibility
description: PARIS, May 11  President Nixon's chief economic adviser rejected today a complaint by some European officials that United States policies were re sponsible for the dollar flows that have rocked the monetary system.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE AS TRADING RISES
description: The stock market staged a mild rally yesterday, somewhat to the surprise of Wall Street analysts, who keep repeating that a correction appears over due and that May often sees prices going down.

title: CHAMBER MUSICIANS ENLIVEN A BENEFIT
description: If taste an choice of guest performers for a benefit con cert is any indication, the Bloomingdale House of Music is an extremely highclass organi zation.

title: 300,000 Face Tax on Mailed Cigarettes
description: Some 300,000 New Yorkers who have been smoking more and paying less by buying their cigarettes from North Carolina mailorder houses may soon find themselves paying $1.5mil lion or more in uncollected tax es and penalties.

title: Belgium Rules Out Floating
