description: BRUSSELS, May 11  The Belgian Government, after a ninehour Cabinet meeting last ing until 5 A.M. today, decided to stick by its decision reached Sunday not to allow the value of the Belgian franc worth 2 cents to float.

title: Panelists Say Theory on Black I.Q. Harms Students
description: The theory of Dr. Arthur R. Jensen, a California psychol ogist, that blacks are inherently less intelligent than whites, was attacked yesterday by four pro fessors who said it was causing a grave negative effect on how black children are taught.

title: ExAssociate Disputes Copeland in Court
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 11Thomas A. Shaheen of fered testimony today in the bankruptcy proceedings of Lammont du Pont Copeland Jr. that differed sharply from Mr. Copeland's recollections of their business relationship.

title: Zenda Breaks Out of Layoff, Scores at Aqueduct
description: A huge 3yearold filly named Zenda returned to the races at Aqueduct yesterday and, after bumping her nose on the starting gate, easily justified her 45 odds, the shortest on the program.

title: Using Toys to Free Children From the Roles Society Dictates
description: Women's liberation in the nursery? No more pink for girls and blue for boys, dolls for girls and trucks for boys, sewing kits for girls and football helmets for boys?

title: Man in the News
description: There were times some years ago when Isaiah Ed ward Robinson, then a Har lem parent leader, would get so angry that he would storm out of meeting with the Board of Education, denounc ing school officials for what he regarded as their failure to show sufficient commitmgnt to improv ing education. On one occasion, in 1963, he charged that a board plan topromoteschool integration was mere gradu alism and tokenism.

title: Relief Airlift Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called today for an immediate international mercy mission and airlift to East Pakistan. He warned that within a month the condition of about 72 million East Pakistanis would become acute.

title: Avco Plans to. Halt Output At Charleston by Yearend
description: The Avco Corporation an nounced yesterday that its Ly coming division would halt pro duction by the end of 1971 at its Charleston, S. C., plant, con centrating output at its Strat ford, Conn., plant. The division employs 2,000 workers in Charleston.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The announcement of an imminent visit to the U.S. by a Chinese table tennis team is more welcome evidence of improvement in our relations with China. It is also a good opportunity for Americans to show whether we are worth getting to know.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN BY SMALL MARGIN
description: The American Stock Exchange posted its first advance yes terday in five sessions as the list made a small gain on mod erate trading.

title: Alcohol Board Chief in Alabama Affirms Employe Phone Tap
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 11The administrator of Ala bama's Alcohol Beverage Con trol Board acknowledged today that the telephone of an em ploye of the state agency had been tapped in order to permit recording of conversations.

title: U.S. Threat Reported
description: BRUSSELS, May 11The United States threatened im plicitly to withdraw its troops from West Germany three years ago if the German central bank did not renounce its rights to convert surplus dollars into American gold.

title: CANADIENS TOPPLE HAWKS, 52, EVEN PLAYOFFS AT 22
description: MONTREAL, May 11In a festival of five goals and four quarrels that produced 86 min utes in penalties shortly before the finish, the Montreal Cana diens squared the Stanley Cup championship hockey series with the Chicago Black Hawks at two games each tonight with a 52 triumph.

title: Mrs. Huggins, on Witness Stand, Protests Innocence
description: NEW HAVEN, May 11  Mrs. Ericka Huggins took the witness stand in her own de fense today and, after nearly five hours of testimony, re peated for the jury her orig inal plea that she was not guility of the crimes charged.

title: A Black Panther Speaks
description: ALGIERSFirst, let it be under stood that the only reason that I under took to explain why it was necessary for I and Cetewayo (Michael Tabor) to leave the Fascist Farce of a Trial Presided over by the evil likes of John Murtagh is because it has come to my attention that there is confusion as to why we did it.

title: 9 Jews on Trial in Soviet; 8 Linked to Hijacking Plot
description: MOSCOW, May 11  Nine Soviet Jews went on tial in Leningrad today, charged with organized antiSoviet activity. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that eight of them were accomplices of the 12 would be hijackers convicted of trea son last December.

title: Narcotics Suspect Seeking Truth Cleared in Police Bribery Case
description: A bribery indictment against a young narcotics suspect who had been charged with trying to 'corrupt a policeman with $50 was dismissed yesterday after findings that the money was paid to induce the police man to tell the truth.

title: Reagan Shuns Further Questions About His Taxes
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 11Gov. Ronald Reagan re fused today to answer further questions about how he was able to pay no California in come taxes for 1970.

title: New Soviet Trials of Jews Called Ominous by Goldberg
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States representative at the United Nations, said yes terday that the continued trials of Jews in the Soviet Union were shocking and ominous.

title: Roosevelt Harness Racing
description: Roosevelt Harness Racing

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Edward Zigler's letter of April 19 misreads the point of my column [in a U.F.T. advertisement] in The Times of April 11 (Violence In the Schools: the Problem Persists).

title: C. W. POST KEEPS CROWN IN TRACK
description: GREENVALE, L. I., May 11 C. W. Post College won its third consecutive Collegiate Track Conference outdoor championship today. The host team had 97 points, Adelphi 59 and Southern Connecticut State 38. Twentyone metro politan area colleges were entered.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Opposition Gets Peking Bid for Talks
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 11 Peking today invited the Australian Labor party, which leads the opposition to the pro American Government of Prime Minister William McMahon, to, send a delegation to China next month for discussions con cerning relations between the two countries.

title: JUNE 1 TARGET SET ON RAIL PACT HERE
description: A Penn Central executive said yesterday that June 1 was the goal date for the signing of; an agreement for a state takeover of the railroad's Hud son and Harlem Divisions com muter lines.

title: Prints by Schongauer on View
description: The life and art of Martin Schongauer have caused their share of scholarly head aches and controversies. Ex perts on the German 15th century artist who is known more for his prints than for his few extant paintings, have vigorously quibbled about his birth date and his artistic education and about attributions. Because they have had few solid facts to base their judgment on, they have also haggled over the chronology of his art, some times dating the same work years apart.

title: Chicago Road Holds Meeting
description: CHICAGO, May 11The Chi cago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific railroad plans to create a holding company, William J. Quinn, chairman, told share holders at the annual meeting here today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Laotian Soldiers Attack Four Hanoi Diplomats
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 (AP)Laotian Government soldiers and policemen as saulted four North Vietnam ese diplomats who walked out on a speech today by Premier Souvanna Phouma when he denounced the Ha noi Government for having sent troops into Laos.

title: Jarring Is Due Here Today To See Thant and U.S. Aides
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 11Dr. Gunnar V. Jar ring, Secretary General Thant's special representative for the Middle East, will return to New York tomorrow from Moscow, where he is the Swedish Am bassador.

title: Miss Toussaint to Be Cited
description: Cheryl Toussaint of the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn, one of the outstanding women middle distance runners in the nation, will receive the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's Meri torius Award tonight at the Downtown Athletic Club.

title: Navy to Merge Mine Forces Of Atlantic and Pacific
description: NORFOLK, May 11 (AP) The mine forces of the Atlantic Fleet and Pacific Fleet will be consolidated in a single com mand July 1, resulting in deletion of 56 officer billets and 217 enlisted billets, the United States Atlantic Com mand announced today.

title: N.B.A. and A.B.A. Stars Set Up Game
description: In defiance of their club own ers and league commissioners, the players of the rival Nation al and American Basketball As sociations announced yesterday they would play an AllStar game in the Houston Astro dome on Friday night, May 28.

title: South Africa Finance Chief Scores U.S. on Gold Price
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, May 11In a broad attack on the position of the United States in the monetary crisis, South Africa's Finance Minister, Nicholaas Diederichs, called to day for a considerable in crease in the price of gold and a return to gold as the basis of international finance.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: EVERY week, more than 213.000 jobs are advertised In The New York Times,. See the Employment Columns today, Advt.

title: CATHOLICS CURB DRUG EDUCATION
description: The Brooklyn Roman Catho lic Diocese said yesterday that it would close the drug education programs in its high schools this fall because of what amounts to a drastic reduction in state financing.

title: NO APPLAUSE ROLE FOR RITA HAYWORTH
description: Rita Hayworth will not be the summer replacement for Lauren Bacall in the Broadway hit musical Applause. The noted film actress, who had been scheduled to take over the star role as Margo Charming, the aging Broadway actress, on July 19, notified the producers Monday night that she was dropping out of rehearsals be cause she was having difficulty learning the part.

title: GERALD MITCHELL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 Gerald J.F.X. Mitchell, senior research computer spe cialist with the Institute for Defense Analysis here, died to day apparently of a heart at tack while walking to work. He was 41 years old and lived at 6 Rolling Mead.

title: REV. G. G. HAGHAIER, EXPERT ON FAMILY, 47
description: The Rev. George G. Hagmaier, a Paulist priest, died at the rec tory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in West Los Angeles on Friday. He was 47 years old.

title: Murphy Defends Mass Arrests, But Cites Need to Protect Rights
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that mass arrests were sometimes necessary but that the police must be very careful about con stitutional rights.

title: DISTRICT TITLES DECIDED IN GOLF
description: Somerset Hills, Piping Rock and Round Hill won their dis trict series as the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed yesterday.

title: 4 DANCE COMPANIES TO TOUR BOROUGHS
description: Four dance companies that generally perform outside the traditional proscenium stage will be presented by the City Center in a special free series in all five boroughs, beginning Saturday and running through May 28. Most of the perform ances will be held outdoors, with locations ranging from the Chase Manhattan Plaza to the Cloisters to Prospect Park.

title: Elizabeth Journal Resumes Publication as Strike Encls
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., May 11 (AP)  The Elizabeth Daily Journal resumed publication to day after a strike by press men that forced the newspa per to lay off all its employes and close its doors.

title: Text of Nixon Statement on Plan to Defeat Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The text of President Nixon's statement today on cancer re search follows:

title: Murtagh Begins Charge to Jury in Panther Case
description: Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh began his chargel yesterday to the jury that has been sitting since last Septem ber at the trial of 13 Black Panthers accused of a bombing conspiracy.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Paul N. McCloskey has backed up his repeated threat to op pose President Nixon in the Presidential primaries unless the President changes his Southeast Asia policy.

title: Russian's Defection Reported
description: ATHENS, May 11A Greek spokesman said tonight that an unidentified Soviet diplomat had applied for political asylum to the Greek authorities at Athens International Airport. It was understood that the re quest was under consideration but that the diplomat had been granted a temporary permit to stay. The defector was said to have been questioned by intel ligence officials.

title: Joseph Wiesenthal, Officer Of Progress Stitching, 101
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 11 Joseph Wiesenthal, who found ed Progress Stitching, Inc., of New York in 1900 and was in volved in many innovations in the development of sewing machinery, died here today. He was 101 years old but had been active in the business until he retired here two years ago.

title: Western Electric Profit Up
description: The Western Electric Company yesterday repotred gains in sales and net incoroe for the first quarter. The company, wholly owned by the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, had firstquarter sales of $1, 541,710,000, from $1,342,227, 000 a year earlier. Threemonth net income rose to $67.5mil lion from $61million.

title: China's Shiny Airports Await Planes
description: HONG KONG, May 11Neat, wellfurnished rand shiny, the big International section of the Hungjao Air Terminal in Shang hai is mostly, an empty show piece.

title: FUND PLAN VOTED BY EPISCOPALIANS
description: The Episcopal Diocese of New York approved a contro versial series of resolutions yes terday that will require virtually all of its churches to pay their own way within five years and to triple the money they must contribute to the diocese.

title: ALL FINALISTS TIE IN PIANO CONTEST
description: Four young pianists played for about an hour apiece be fore a Carnegie Hall audience yesterday afternoon in the finals of the 27th Leventritt International Competition, but no top winner, was chosen. Four other times since the prestigious music award was first offered in 1940, the judges have decided against naming a single winner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We older citizens who traveled to Washington on April 24 to protest once more our Government's continua tion of the Vietnam war, made grievous error. We should have stayed in Washington and, added our support to those younger citizens who were trying by nonviolent methods to turn the policies of this nation around.

title: Advertising:
description: The head of the world's largest fullservice ad agency doesn't like that tag full service too much, because it is basically nondescriptive.

title: Parisian Is Held as $12Million Heroin Smuggler
description: NEWARK, May 11  A Fed eral grand jury indicted a 48 yearold Parisian today on charges of smuggling 96 pounds of pure heroin in a Volkswagen camper bus being shipped from France to the United States.

title: ExPrivate in Guard Gave Rennie Davis as Reference
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  A private first class in the District of Columbia National Guard, who was discharged last month because of admin istrative error, listed Rennie Davis, the antiwar activist, as a character reference on his enlistment papers.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, May 1  Signaling that adjournment must be near, five New York City Democratic legislators spent part of their lunch break today basking in unaccustomed warm sun and tossing a football about the Capitol front lawn. The relaxed mood belied the fact that the Legislature was still confronted with a long list of major legislation, even though ad journment was supposed to be only a week or 10 days away.

title: G.E. Opposing Aid to Lockheed Unless U.S. Engines Are Used
description: Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Electric Company, has bluntly told the Nixon Ad ministration that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation should not be granted loan guaran tees by the Government un less Americanmade engines are used in Lockheed's L1011 Tristar jet airbus.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 11So many plans have gone wrong for the United States in Asia in recent years that it is sometimes forgotten that other plans have gone very well indeed. For example, if Peking and Washington do finally agree to reestablish diplo matic relations, the U.S. Government will be ready with a new generation of China specialists.

title: Spending in Senate Races
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Following is a table of radio and television campaign spending by 1970 Senate candidates as compiled by the Federal Communications Commission, compared with the ceilings that would be in effect in each state in 4972 if the legislation approved by the Senate Com merce Committee became law. Winners are marked by an asterisk.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Birth Notice 1  No Title

title: Economic Analysis
description: The monetary storm that buf feted Europe has shaken the German mark and the Dutch guilder loose from their moor ings, blown the Swiss franc and the Austrian schilling higher, increased the sale of coffee, aspirin, and elec tricity in Brussels, Bonn, and Wash ington, and ruined the telephone and Telex budgets of several newspapers.

title: Adirondack AgencyNow
description: Governor Rockefeller's endorsement of a State Adiron dack Park Agency is welcome but if it comes too late for the plan to be authorized at this session of the Legisla ture, a serious possibility, then his belated timing could have graveand entirely predictableconsequences.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Rural Ireland Is Hostile
description: TRIM, IrelandDuring the last three years the West Germans have come to Coun ty Meath and other choice farm and coastal regions of Ireland and have bought up more and more cheap Irish land.

title: About Motor Sports
description: A few weeks ago the Sports Car Club of America changed its qualifying pro cedure for professional road races. It discarded the cus tom of timing all cars throughout the practice ses sions and adopted the one caratatime pattern from the oval tracks of other racing clubs. Be tween the lines was the inference that one objective was to make life easier for the timers and scorers, most of them amateurs who are not up to the demands of pro fessional racing. The new system has evoked strong criticism from Joseph J. Lane Jr., who is one of the best scorers in the business, with about 20 years experience as a chief timer and scorer in S.C.C.A. competition.

title: Labor Wins in St. Kitts
description: BASSETERRE, St. Kitts, May 11 (Reuters)Prime Minister Robert L. Bradshaw was con firmed in power today when his St. Kitts Labor party swept seven out of 10 seats ???? St. KittsNevisAnguilla ??? bly. Two opposition ??? each won one of the two seats on the island of Nevis, while Anguilla, which broke from the Caribbean federation four years ago, boycotted the election.

title: Mrs. King 61. 61 Victor In English Clay Tourney
description: LONDON, May 11 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., led an advance of four American women through the first round of the BioStrath claycourt tennis tournament today.

title: A CONGRESS GROUP SCORES NAVY JET
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Navy's plans to equip air craft carriers with a newly de signed, multipurpose swing wing fighter called the F14, at an ultimate cost of $25billion, came under attack today from a bipartisan Congressional group working to reduce de fense costs.

title: Hearing on L. I. Is Told Nuclear Reactors Appear Linked to Infant Mortality
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 11A scientist who for several years has been arguing that very low levels of radiation affect the survival of the newly horn contended today that nu clear reactors at Indian Point on the Hudson River and at Brookhaven National Labora tory on Long Island appear to have increased infant mortality in surrounding areas.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The first ball game Harry Walker ever played in New York was in Central Park. It has to sound ridiculous because no future batting champion of the National League had ever made his metropolitan debut in so unlikely a site, even in the premugging days of 1935. But his big brother, Dixie Walker, was then with the New York Yankees and the teenaged Harry visited him that summer, taking one after noon off to disguise himself as a hotel employe in some sandlot league.

title: CITY INVESTING BIDS FOR ESTES BROTHERS
description: The City Investing Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Estes Brothers Construc tion Company, one of the largest builders of single family detached homes in the Southwest, for $10million of City Investing common stock.

title: Stennis Seeks War Curb on President
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Com mittee, introduced legislation today that would curb the power of Presidents to com mit the nation to war without the consent of Congress.

title: A.F.L. C.I.O. SCORES NIXON OVER FUNDS
description: ATLANTA, May 11The Ex ecutive Council of the A.F.L. C.I.O. said today that President Nixon's decision to withhold $12billion appropriated for do mestic programs by Congress betrayed a firm determination to manipulate the Federal Treasury as a political tool in preparation for the 1972 elec tion campaign.

title: CURRENCY DEALING ABATES IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, May 11Activity in the European foreignex change markets was light today as traders waited for a trend to develop on new cur rency values.

title: L.I.R. to Complete Fleet
description: The Long Island Railroad will receive delivery of the last four of 620 highspeed Metro politan cars Friday, completing its fleet of new commuter equipment for its electrified service. The schedule on final deliveries was announced yes terday by Dr. William J. Ro nan, chairman of the Metropoli tan Transportation Authority, which oversees the railroad.

title: Books of The Times
description: CONSUMING PASSIONS. Being an Historic In quiry Into Certain English Appetites. By Philippa Puller. 278 pages. Illustrated. Lit tle, Brown. $7.95.

title: ALGER AWARD VOTED TO LOWELL THOMAS
description: Edward Durrell Stone, the architect, and Lowell Thomas, the commentator, were among 10 winners of the 1971 Horatio Alger Awards announced yes terday by the American Schools and Colleges Association.

title: KEITH H. MOULDEN
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 11 Keith H. Moulden, who had been an executive of the St. Regis Paper Company since 1962, died yesterday in Stam ford Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 49 years old and lived at 12 Revere Road.

title: Lebanon Is Seeking Support for Arabs On Jerusalem Issue
description: Wasfi Tal. He later announced that the Jordanian leaders had provided him with additional evidence of Israeli plan's to change the status and character of the Old City of Jerusalem. He charged that the Israeli au thorities were trying to turn East Jerusalem, formerly the Jordanian sector of the city, into a tourist area and the holy places there into tourist museums.

title: Business Inventories Registered Moderate Rise Again in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Total business inventories rose only moderately again in March, though the increase was larger than in January and February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ALLEGHENY LUDLUM JOINS IN PRICE RISE
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., the nation's largest pro ducer of specialty steels, an nounced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would raise published prices by about 6.5 per cent, effective May 17, on all stain lesssteel products except pipe and tube.

title: Reserve Takes Step to Aid In Rescue of F. I. duPont
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The Federal Reserve Board, in a move aimed at facilitating the financial rescue of F. I. du Pont, Glore Forgan, relaxed further today its order of April 7 permitting certain bank loans to be made without reference to margin requierments.

title: Harlem Five Say They Are Victims of a Police Plot
description: The conspiracy trial of five young black men whose indict ment attracted considerable at tention three years ago is ex pected to go to the jury today in State Supreme Court here. The defendants contended yes terday that they were victims of a police conspiracy.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS TO LEAD A DRIVE AGAINST CANCER
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Nixon pledged his own direct leadership today for a national program to conquer cancer.

title: Two Poseidon Missiles Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 11, (AP)The nuclear sub marine Ulysses S. Grant launched two Possidon milliles down the Atlantic tracking range tonight while crusing submerged off Cape Kennedy.

title: Black Caucus Backs Evers
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The Congressional Black Cau cus announced today it wouid support Charles Evers in his 1972 bid as the first Negro candidate for Mississippi Gov ernor. Mr. Evers, Mayor of Fayette, Miss., has announced his candidacy. The Black Cau cus is composed of 13 House members.

title: Market Place: Washington Govt. Of Kaler Flga
description: When William E. Chatlos, an expert on stockholder solicitation, scanned the General Motors proxy state ment, his eye quickly settled on stockholder proposal No. 5.

title: Istanbul Renews Trading
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 11 (Reuters)  The Turkish central hank today renewed dealing in foreign currencies after a one day suspension following the European financial crises. How ever, dealings in marks, guilders and Belgian and Luxembourg francs will remain suspended.

title: Group Reports Attempt to Rob L.I. Offices of F.B.I.
description: A group calling itself the People's Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday an unsuc cessful attempt to break into and steal documents from the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion's office in Garden City, L. I.

title: Johnson Describes Call By Kosygin on 67 War
description: Lyndon B. Johnson said yesterday that Soviet Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin used the hot line to warn him that Moscow was prepared to use military force if necessary during the ArabIsraeli war of 1967.

title: Two U.S. Agencies Differ On Changing Patent Laws
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Commerce Department and the Justice Department's Anti trust Division collided headon today over legislation amend ing the patent laws.

title: RAIL HOLDING UNIT FORESEES GAINS
description: CHICAGO, May 11North west Industries, Inc.'s, earn ings in 1971 are expected to be substantially higher than 1970 earnings from operations, Ben W. Heineman, president, told shareholders at the com pany's annual meeting here to day.

title: Arizona Dean Reported In Line for Egeberg Job
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)The Nixon Administra tion has chosen Dr. Merlin K. Duval, dean of the University of Arizona, to succeed Dr. Roger O. Egeberg as Assist ant Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare for Health and Scientific Affairs, in formed sources said today.

title: Mail Case Judge Refuses To Block a Rise in Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Postal rate increases scheduled to go into effect this Sunday cleared a major hurdle today when a Federal judge refused to issue an order blocking them.

title: Net for Year Sets Mark at Pete Inc.
description: Record sales and earnings were achieved by Pet, Inc., in the fiscal year ended March 31, despite generally unfavor able business conditions during the period, Boyd F. Schenk, president, reported from St. Louis headquarters yesterday. The chief executive attributed the increased results to diver sification.

title: BALANCE IS URGED IN U.S PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  A group of former high Govern ment officials, including Wil liam McChesney Martin Jr., re tired Federal Reserve Board chairman, said today that de cisive action to bring the Unit ed States balance of interna tional payments to or close to equilibrium is a national and international responsibility of critical priority.

title: Fox Meeting Delay Refused
description: Federal Judge Harold Tyler Jr., in Federal Court here, re fused yesterday to delay the May IS annual meeting of Twenieth CenturyFox Film Corporation. A onemonth post ponement had been sought by an insurgent group of stock holders seeking control of the large motion picture company.

title: RYAN'S 3HITTER HELPS METS BEAT EROS BY 8 TO 1
description: Add Nolan Ryan and Dave Marshall to the list of notpre viouslycanonized New York Mets who are carrying the club on its current streak. Ryan pitched a threehitter and Mar shall hit a grandslam homer in last night's 81 victory over the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium.

title: Amex Profit Soars 40.8% Despite a Drop in Revenues
description: The American Stock Ex change liwted yesterday that it had net income of $458,000 in the first quarter of 1971, up 40.8 per cent from the $271, 000 reported for the yearearlier period. Firstquarter revenues were $6,181,000, down 3.5 per cent from $6,405,000 in the 1971 quarter.

title: Roundup: Indians Interrupt the A's, 75
description: Steve Dunning, the Cleve land Indians $60,000 bonus baby who was the No. 1 draft choice last June in the freeagent sweepstakes, was supposed to do his pitching in the minor leagues this year.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: BIG BOARD SHIFTS AUTOMATION UNITS
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday another reorganization of its Electronic Systems Center, which is responsible for the Big Board's extensive automa tion programs.

title: Holdups Increasing Sharply At Subway Change Booths
description: Holdups of subway booths, once a negligible factor in city crime, have become major problem for the tran sit police.

title: A Challah Expert Tells All
description: When Mrs. Herman Hol lander reluctantly dictated her challah recipe recently she said: I never measured much before. I looked in the bowl and knew what to do.

title: Buchanan Halts Hernandez And Bugner Outpoints Blin
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP) Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the world lightweight champion, scored a technical knockout over Carlos Hernandez of Vene zeula in the eighth round of a scheduled 10round nontitle fight tonight.

title: AGNEW DEPLORES SCRUFFY YOUTHS
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 11 (UPI)Vice President Agnew today described the thousands of antiwar demonstrators who recently crowded the nation's capital as the same scruffy individuals that caused the dis ruptions in Chicago in 1968.

title: Japan Pushed Near Yen Choice
description: TOKYO, May 11The dollar crisis that threw the Western European money markets into chaos last week is driving Ja pan's financial leaders to the brink of a choice beset with risks.

title: Feelings of Neighbors On Germans Still Mixed
description: DOVER, EnglandIn this ancient Channel port, where thousands of German bombs and shells found their mark in World War II, suspicion and prejudice against Ger many linger on among some of the old and some of the young.

title: Executive Changes
description: Arthur G. McKee & Co., announced yesterday the election of George. McCuskey as chairman, succeeding Merrill Cox, who has retired and be comes chairman emeritus. The company also elected William F. Richards as group vice presi dent and James A. Loughran as vice president, administration and secretary. Wilmot F. Wheeler Jr., chairman and president of American Chain & Cable Company, Inc., was elected a director of the engineering and construction company.

title: Nonprofit Group Formed To Spur Legal Research
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11 Formation of the Council for the Advancement of Legal Ed ucation, a national nonprofit or ganization to spur changes in legal training and the profes sion, was anounced here today by Bernard G. Segal, past pres ident of the American Bar As sociation.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had an early morning meeting with his Cabinet and later met privately with H.E.W. Secretary Elliot Richardson. The President then issued a statement on his cancer cure program. Later in the after noon the President attended a seafood gumbo luncheon given at the Capitol by the House Rules Committee chairman, William M. Colmer, D.Miss.

title: Statement on City Budget
description: The City of New York has dumped its fiscal responsi bilities on the State Legisla ture.

title: High Court Ruling Sought On Death Penalty Question
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The Supreme Court was asked in a brief filed today to rule whether the death penalty con stituted cruel and unusual punishment as defined by the Eighth Amendment to the Constitution.

title: Johns Hopkins Troubled Over Relevance
description: BALTIMORE, May 11 Milton S. Eisenhower, the 71 yearold educator who retired four years ago as president of Johns Hopkins University, was back at his old desk the other day in Homewood House, the graceful Georgian mansion that dominates the lush green campus.

title: Dance: An Evening With Balanchine
description: Remarkably few choreogra phers can sustain single handed an evening of ballet, and remarkably fewer chore ographers realize this sad fact of life. One choreog rapher above all suitable for the oneman show is George Balanchine, and indeed the programs of the New York City Ballet that are simply and purely Balanchine are not infrequently better than those that attempt more variety.

title: Rizzo Seems to Have Lost Most of Lead in Philadelphia Mayor Bid
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11  Frank L. Rizzo, the self described tough cop who seemed a sure thing only a month ago in his campaign for Mayor of Philadelphia, appears to have lost most of his lead with a week remaining until Primary Day.

title: DON ELLIS WIDENS THE KENTON SOUND
description: Time seemed to turn back wards on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. From some of the sounds that filled the audi torium, from the enthusiasm with which the enthusiastic young audience leaped to its feet, cheering, at every extend ed climax, it might have been 20 years ago and the band on stage might have been Stan Kenton's brassy juggernaut.

title: Cardin and Valentino CollectionsToday and Yesteryear
description: When you saw those little shorts peeping out from the curving sandwich board skirts he contrived, you knew Andre Oliver had thought of everything. Now women won't have to stand around at parties awkwardly sticking out one knee to show everybody they're wearing shorts under their conventional skirts.

title: Preakness Betting to Start Here Today
description: Fresh from a milliondollar debut on the Kentucky Der by, the city's Offtrack Bet ting Corporation will start taking action today on Satur day's Preakness.

title: University Crisis
description: The warning by Chancellor Albert H. Bowker that the City University, if subjected to Mayor Lindsay's most stringent budgetary projections, would be shut down September may have the ring of political scare tactics. Dire predictions have been used in past budget battles. The politically and fiscally chaotic nature of budget planning in the city and in Albany has forced concerned and responsible university leaders to protect the stu dents interests through resort to verbal brinkmanship.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: POLICE BRIBE TRIAL DELAYED BY WITNESS
description: The trial of a police lieuten ant on departmental charges of conspiring with members of his command about the division of bribes was halted yesterday after a police surgeon said the primary witness was not able to take the witness stand.

title: Dempsey, Saints Kicker, Will. Be Honored Here
description: Tom Dempsey, a kicker who gained fame in the Na tional Football League al though he was born with only a half a right foot and a stub of a right arm, will be honored as the most courageous player by the Professional Football Writers of America.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Governor Rockefeller's proposal to decontrol vacant apartments will sure ly hasten the city's decay.

title: House Ruling May Lead to Suit Challenging Nixon Recess Veto
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  A brief ruling today in the House may have opened the way for a historic court test of Presi dent. Nixon's pocket veto of a medical training bill during the Congressional recess last Christ mas.

title: U. S. and Soviet Yield at Geneva; Experts Talks on Test Ban Set
description: GENEVA, May 11Yielding to pressure from other mem bers of the disarmament con ference, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to sponsor talks here by ex perts on how to verify pro posed bans on underground nu clear tests and on chemical weapons.

title: Husak Denies Dubcek Works as Garage Manager.
description: PRAGUE, May 11 (Reuters) The former Czechoslovak Com munist party leader, Alexander Dubcek, is living freely, work ing and has enough money, his successor, Gustav Husak, said last weekend.

title: Deal Charged on Albany School Vote
description: ALBANY, May 11  Senator Walter B. Langley, an Albany Republican, charged today that Governor Rockefeller and Earl W. Brydges, the Senate majority leader, had made a rotten political deal with the Albany Democratic machine to keep the Albany City School Board under Democratic con trol.

title: Birth Control Study Backed
description: NEWTON, Mass., May 11 (AP)  The Massachusetts league of Women Voters voted today to begin a study of the state's birth control and abor tion laws. The league, at its state convention, voted 257 to 97 in favor of the study. The action came two years after similar session voted against an analysis of the subject.

title: YankBrewer Game Off, Restated for Tomorrow
description: MILWAUKEE, May 11 While snow fell 100 miles to the north in Green Bay, rain drenched County Stadium to night and forced postpone ment of the Yankees game with Milwaukee. It was re scheduled for Thursday at 2:30 P.M., New York time.

title: Screen: Dramatic Pursuit of Elusive Killer Shark
description: Some, people, I realize have no more interest in sharks than I have, say, in coachroaches, in horseshoe crabs, in coelacanths, and in any number of other worthy, though not especially attractive vestiges of our primeval past. A coelacanth may be rare, but one can marvel at the fact of its survival without going damp in the palms with particular emotion.Sharks, however, are something else, often observed but, until comparatively recently, little known, the subject of all sorts of old-wives tales, a symbol for everything from shylocking to every man's fate worse than death, an implacable, terrifying, disinterested power, an Old Testament tribulation, as well as a force of extraordinary grace, beauty and serenity. Those of you who share my perhaps neurotic, weekend skindiver's fascination with sharks will not, I think, be able to resist the quite jolly, sometimes awesome, new documentary movie that opened yesterday at the Festival Theater."Blue Water. White Death" is the filmed record of the voyage undertaken 18 months ago by Peter Gimbel, the underwater photographer who took those extraordinary pictures of the sunken Andrea Doria some years ago, and several other hearty, quite lunatic skindivers in search of the great white shark, which is apparently the shark that has given all of its cousins such unpleasant reputations.This is the same voyageoff South Africa, Mozambique, Ceylon and Australia  that Peter Matthiessen documents, on a more introspective level, is his new book, "Blue Meridian."In its form, "Blue Water, White Death" is a rather conventional documentary of romantic experience, with much of the ingenuous Rover Boys tone of Bruce Brown's "The Endless Summer." It contains a certain number of self-conscious re-enactments of things that actually happened during the voyage, more than one blush-red sunset and, on the soundtrack, snatches of folk songs with lines like "I'm gonna go/ Where the chilly winds don' blow."It also contains some of the most beautiful and (there is no other way to describe it accurately) breathtaking underwater footage I've ever seentruly remarkable, free-swimming encounters by Mr. Gimbel and his associates with sharks gorging themselves on newly caught whales, with barracudas, with fat, pushy groupers, and, finally and triumphantly, with the great white sharks off the southern coast of Australia.I must admit that I'm not terribly familiar with the animals of marine photography, but it does seem likely that this climactic sequence is unique. The divers, suspended in frail aluminum cages, captured close-up shots of the great whites as they soared around, under and over them, occasionally dashing in for a go at the bars of the cages, sometimes threatening to carry the cages off into the open sea, sometimes just butting the cages in frustration.Why, in heaven's name, do people do this sort of thing? In his book, Mr. Matthiessen quotes Mr. Gimbel as saying:"Danger doesn't interest me . . . but I'm curious and I think everybody's curious to find out just what their limits, are under situations that exert a certain amount of stress on them."To this Mr. Matthiessen adds: ". . . this search has no real end to it but death. Still, I don't think this is a 'death wish' unless dread of death is the same thing. It is as if, by confronting death over and over, he (Gimbel) might end some awful suspense about it, or dissipate it in some way. . . ."The movie doesn't speculate. It shows, and what it shows is a group of men (and one woman, Valeric Taylor of Australia) pursuing a crazy curiosity to its outer limits. It also shows their exhilaration after their dives, and in these scenes in the flat terminology of their mysticism and in the excitement on their facesit communicates the indefinable reason why."I got the liver scared out of me at one point," Mr. Gimbel reports after an especially dangerous dive. Somehow the language is not equal to the event, but then the meaning of the event is so private that perhaps no language is adequate.Mountain climbers, free-fall parachutists, spelonkers, surfers, skin divers and the like are a very mysterious breed, and if "Blue Water, White Death" does not explain Mr. Gimbel and his friends, it at least describes them, rather as if they were Hemingway characters in fantasies imagined by Walter Mitty, with dialogue out of Harold Teen.However, the heart of the film is its action, recorded with immense technical skill, and it is so pure that it's as poetic as anything I've seen on the screen in a long, long time.

title: Alan Bateman Dies at 82; Geology Professor at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 11Alan M. Bateman, Silliman Professor of Geology Emeritus at Yale University, died today at his home. He was 82 years old and lived at 450 St. Ronan Street.

title: ELINA MOONEY GIVES PROGRAM OF DANCES
description: Elina Mooney likes to work against the grain. If music is fast, she finds ways to be in telligently slow while dancing to it; if a situation suggests allout fullness of attack, she tends to withhold commitment slightly. It sets up an interest in her dances and puts severe demands upon her dancers, Janet Aaron, Phoebe Neville, Christopher Back and Billy Siegenfeld. Monday evening she presented an evening of her works at the Cubiculo.

title: Big Garbage Removal Trucks to Compress Trash
description: Twentysix enormous new garbage trucks are expected to be in operation around the city this summer, and although the general public will rarely see themsanitation experts hope that the trucks Which do more than just haul garbage may soon revolutionize trash collection.

title: Councilmen Review City Tax Package and Pass It On
description: Mayor Lindsay's $892.4mil lion package of proposed taxes was sent to Albany by the City Council yesterday, unchanged, but with warnings that the Council might not vote into law the full extent of what ever taxes Albany authorized.

title: Chaplin Will Release 9 Films He Held 6 Years
description: A group of nine of Charlie Chaplin's bestknown feature and short films, which the comedian has kept off the general theater market for more than six years, now will be available for worldwide theatrical, television and video cassette showings. Ar rangements have been made by Roy Export, his company, which controls the rights, and Black, Inc., A. G., a recently formed European company.

title: British Schools Accused of Mishandling West Indian Blacks
description: LONDON, May 11Britain's school policies on black chil dren have come under bitter criticism by an Americanedu cated social worker and teacher.

title: Mrs. Constance Mellon Plans Marriage to Peter E. Burrell
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11 Mrs. Constance Prosser Mel lon, widow of Richard King Mellon, the financier and philanthropist, and Peter E. Burrell of Newmarket, Eng land, will be married this summer.

title: Arthur Mitchell Will Receive Capezio Dance Prize May 26
Sean Lemass, Freedom Fighter, ExIrish Prime Minister, Dead
description: DUBLIN, May 11  Sean F. Lemass, former Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, died early today in a Dublin hospital. He was 71 years old and had been ill for two months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a landmark decision, Mr. Justice Samuel A. Spiegel in the Supreme Court of the State of New York, County of New York, expressed deep rooted sympathy for tenants faced with conversion of their apart ment houses into cooperatives. Mr. Justice Spiegel urged immediate tight ening of the regulations and, specific ally, the increase of the number of tenants required from 35 per cent to 51 per cent before conversion could he approved.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: MAYOR DEDICATES HOUSING PROJECT
description: A cluster of fourstory brick apartment buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn were dedicated by Mayor Lind say yesterday and praised as examples of how community participation can speed, rather than slow, new construction.

title: Hearing Aid for the U.N.
description: When the United Nations dispatched a factfinding mission to Guinea last November to investigate com plaints of a Portugueseled invasion, the Security Council had to wait until the mission's plane returned to New York to receive its report because no suitable means communication was available in the field.

title: 5 Are Killed and 18 Injured In Guatemala Plane Crash
description: GUATEMALA, May 11 (UPI) An Aviateca Airlines DC3 twinengine plane with 35 per sons aboard crashed into a ravine about 15 miles south of here today, killing five persons and injuring 18.

title: ORANGE FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Prices of frozen orange con centrate futures rose sharply yesterday in accelerated trad ing.

title: Gaffes in Gilead
description: Then said they unto him, Say now Shibboleth: and he said Sibboleth: for he could not frame to pronounce it right. Then they took him, and slew him .

title: State Senate Passes Bill Authorizing Physicians to Use Help of Paramedics
description: ALBANY, May 11  A bill creating the stateregulated, positions of physician's and specialist's assistants was passed overwhelmingly by the. Senate here today.

title: New Jersey Court Rules Farmers Can't Prohibit Visits to Migrants
description: TRENTON, May 11  The State Supreme Sourt ruled unanimously today that New Jersey farmers could no longer invoke the state's trespass law to keep qualified visitors out of migrant farm worker camps.

title: Merchant Is Named As Retailers Chief
description: The National Retail Mer chants Association, the largest trade group in the department store field, appointed a retailer yesterday as its new president and chief staff officer.

title: NEW FILMS ASKED ON LIFE IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, May 11Leading Soviet moviemakers called to day for more films on current themes and everyday problems after the recent outpouring of productions portraying Lenin, the Revolution and World War II.

title: Art and Technology to Open on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 Unless there is a power fail ure in Southern California on Friday, the much heralded Art and Technology ex hibition, representing a col laborative effort on the part of contemporary artists and major industrial corporations, will finally open to the pub lic at the Los Angeles Coun ty Museum of Art.

title: SINGAPORE LEADER DUELS WITH PRESS
description: SINGAPORE, May 11Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has charged that Chinese agents in Hong Kong have given a news paper owner here almost $1.35 million to gain influence in his publication.

title: U.S. Reports a MIG21 Attack On Unarmed Plane Over Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) A North Vietnamese MIG21 in terceptor attacked an unarmed United States reconnaissance plane twice over the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos while a second MIG21 circled overhead Sunday, the American com mand disclosed today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar  The word sleeper can mean railroad tie and can also be used to denote a spy or foreign agent like Kim Philby who buries himself in harmless surround ings and doesn't begin to exercise his assigned functions for years. China employs both varieties of sleepers in its present policy along the eastern shores of Africa.

title: City Rejects Offer of Park Ave. Obelisk
description: The City Art Commission yes terday turned down a proposed gift by the philanthropist, George T. Delacorte Jr., of a 125foot stainless steel obelisk for Park Avenue.

title: Bernsteins Raise $35,000 for the Berrigan Defense
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bernstein, whose 1970 fund raising party for the Panthers Legal Defense Fund triggered widespread criticism, gave another civil liberties gather ing Monday nightthis time in behalf of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and his five co defendants.

title: Mansfield Asks 50% Cut in U.S. Force in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, proposed to day that the United States cut in halfto 150,000 menthe number of its troops in Europe by the end of the year to ease the dollar outflow abroad and economize at home. The Ad ministration countered imme diately.

title: Papal Letter Sets as Goal New Democratic Society
description: ROME, May 11In an apos tolic letter scheduled to be made public Friday, Pope Paul VI urges Christians to take part in the search for a new kind of democratic society.

title: Mediators Hold Rail Talks On Signalmen Strike Threat
description: WASHINGTON. May 11 (UPI)Federal mediators met today with negotiators for the railroads and the railway signal men in an effort to avert a nationwide strike next Monday, but the president of the union said prospects for a settlement were dim.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Post for Princeton Aide
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 11 Dr. Carl A. Fields, who becamp the first black administrator at Princeton University in 1964, has been named the chief plan ning officer at the University of Zambia, the only university in that Central African repub lic. Dr. Fields, now an assist ant clean at Princeton, will as sume his twoyear appointment in Zambia on Aug. 1.

title: 70 Spending Hints Curbs Would Hit Parties Equally
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 The campaign spending bill now headed for the Senate floor may help the Democrats in a Presi dential election, but it is likely to affect both parties about equally in Congressional con tests.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: MONEY RESTRAINT ASKED BY BRANDI
description: BONN, May 11Chancellor Willy Brandt asked today for a spell of restraint and pa tience in West Germany to help see the country through the monetary crisis.

title: British Find Gains and Difficulties in Market Talks
description: BRUSSELS, May 11There was progress today  and some difficultiesin Britain's negotiations to enter the Eu ropean Economic Community. The six Common Market members agreed to special arrangements for Britain to continue importing news print, plywood and 10 other industrial products at low tariff rates after joining. She will also be able to im port tea without tariffs. In a concession that was less ex pected, the six offered asso ciate membership to Com monwealth countries in the Caribbean. This would let them sell in the Common Market their bananas, citrus fruit, rum, tobacco and spices. But a hopedfor agree ment on sugar did not mate rialize. One of the basic Brit ish demands is an assurance for developing Commonwealth countries that grow sugar cane.

title: Four Parks Roads To Be Shut in Test To Draw Strollers
description: The roadways in Central Park and three other large parks will be closed to vehicles during midday hours for five days lat er this month as part of what Mayor Lindsay said yesterday was our effort to get the pub lic to use the parks.

title: Advertising:
description: O. M. Scott & Sons must have thought that the grass looked greener in the Doyle Dane Bernbach yard because that is where they are taking their national advertising ac count.

title: NEW ISSUES HEAVY IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The money and capital mar kets shouldered a heavy load of new corporate, state and Federal agency issues yester day, and they triedwith some successto do it without rais ing interest rates.

title: LINDSAY SAYS U.S. STILL FAILS CITIES
description: Mayor Lindsay, who has per sistently criticized the Nixon Administration for allegedly ignoring the problems of the cities, said yesterday that he did not believe that the Presi dent's proposed Gateway Na tional Recreation Area signified a new Federal commitment to the cities.

title: The Vultures of Bengal
description: Fat vultures brood over the ravaged towns of East Pakistan, grim testimony to the slaughter which took place during the Pakistan Army's savage crackdown Bengali separatists. The fighting has died down for the time being, with the Bengali resistance largely routed, but what may become known as the year of the vulture in East Bengal is not ended. Famine now stalks this tragic land of chronic disaster.

title: Gimbel Clan Gathers to See Peter's Film
description: When Peter R. Gimbel was a little boy, he put a bucket over his head with a hose coming out the top, dived into a swimming pool and tried to breathe underwater. He has since improved his ways.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Bridge:Aces Blank Two Opponents In Adding to Taipei Lead
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 11 The world champion Aces in creased their lead in the qual ifying stage of the world championship here today, winning, 20.0 in matches against Brazil and Taiwan. The French team, which had led earlier in the event, had a harder time, losing, 812, to the second North American team and beating Brazil, 128.

title: Eastern Life Shows Gains
description: The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York an nounced yesterday that it wrote a record $49,217,092 in new business in the March quarter, an increase of 47 per cent over the $33,520,570 written in the period last year. Insurance in force climbed 11 per cent, to $1,075,409,197 from $908,363, 947 a year ago.

title: Soviet Diplomat Asks Asylum, Athens Reports
description: ATHENS, May 11 (UPI)The Greek government announced tonight that a Soviet diplomat had asked for political asylum.

title: Swiss Seeking to Resolve Dispute Over Indian and Pakistani Aides
description: Pakistan by the independence movement.

title: J. Yale Rubin, 70, Headed Connecticut Furniture Firm
description: J. Yale Rubin, a furniture dis tributor, died on Sunday at the Neurological Institute. He was 70 years old and lived at 42 North Lake Drive, Hamden, Conn., and at Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Garment Union Deplores War But Endorses Policies of U.S.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 11  Delegates to the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union here deplored today the human and material cost of the bitter con flict in Vietnam. At the same time, however, they warned that the world faced the dan ger of other Vietnams as long as totalitarian movements re mained determined to impose their system of government and ideology on others, by force if necessary.

title: Politics vs. Justice
description: However much he may know about marketing municipal bonds or managing a political campaign, Attorney Gen eral John Mitchell has again demonstrated that he under stands very little about the interdependence of law and liberty in a free society.

title: FULL INTEGRATION IS URGED IN SOUTH
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 11 (AP) Armed with a Supreme Court decision approving the use of busing to achieve school deseg regation, lawyers for plaintiffs in 25 Southern school suits have asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to order total integra tion in more than 200 school districts by the beginning of the 197172 school year.

title: Angkor Wat Reported Damaged by Cambodian Shells
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 11Authoritative sources said today that Angkor Wat, Cambodia's national treasure and the most famous temple of the ruins of Angkor in northwestern Cambodia, had been severely damaged by Cambodian Army artillery bar rage.

title: PHONE TECHNICIANS END A 6DAY STRIKE
description: The sixday strike of techni cians in the longlines depart ment of the American Tele phone and. Telegraph Company ended last night when the com pany and Local 1150 of the Communications Workers or America settled their dispute.

title: Lenox Strings Play Some New Music
description: A concert of totally admi rable performances by the Lenox String Quartet opened the second annual May Festi val of the Composers and Choreographers Theater on Monday night at the New School Auditorium.

title: Temperature Up to 84, Highest of Year in City
description: The city enjoyed its warm est day of the year yester day when the temperature climbed to an official high of 84 degrees at 3:25 P.M.

title: Comsat Growth for 1971 Is Put At 20% After 50% Gain in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Communications Satellite Corporation told stockholders today that its business would grow another 20 per cent in 1971, after the nearly 50 per cent growth in 1970 that pro duced the first Comsat divi dend last October.

title: DAVID WEBSTER OF ROYAL OPERA
description: LONDON, May 11Sir David Webster, who in 25 years built the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden into one of the world's great opera and ballet theaters, died at his home here today. He was 67 years old.

title: Afghan Bus Plunge Kills 21
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 11 (AP)Twentyone persons were killed and six injured when a bus plunged into an irrigation canal in Lashkargah, western Afghanistan, the police report ed. They attributed the acci dent to careless driving.

title: DANIEL ZULLY DIES; BANK'S COUNSEL, 48
description: MILL NECK, L. I., May 11 Daniel J. Zully, a lawyer who was counsel and secretary of the Greater New York Savings Bank in Brooklyn, died yester day in Community Hospital, Glen Cove, after a short illness. He was 48 years old and lived on West Shore Road in Mill Neck, of which he had been Village Justice since 1969.

title: Widening of Geneva Conventions On Rebels and Guerrillas Urged
description: GENEVA, May 12  Red Cross experts have recommend ed that an international con ference of government experts convening here May 24 consid er broadening the guarantees of the Geneva conventions to include giving rebels in a civil war the status of belligerents.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Monetary Inquiry Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and chair man of the House Banking Committee, announced plans to day for a full scale investiga tion of the international mone tary crisis, with the aim of finding out how it had specifi cally affected the dollar and the United States economy.

title: Did Hanoi Open a Door?
description: In the face of President Nixon's frequently expressed desire for a negotiated settlement of the Indochina war, the Administration has taken a strangely negative ap proach to Hanoi's latestif highly ambiguouspeace overtures. Doors toward negotiation were opened a crack on ApriI 29 by the North Vietnamese and Vietcong rep resentatives but instead of exploring where they led, Ambassador David Bruce last week either ignored them or seemed to slam them shut, presumably on instructions from Washington.

title: 100 Die in Quake in Southwest Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 12 (AP)  An earthquake struck the opiumgrowing lake coun try, around Burdur in south west Turkey today. At least 100 were killed, the semiofficial Anatolian news agency said.

title: EUROPEANS APPLY DOLLAR PRESSURE
description: BRUSSELS, May 12Euro pean monetary authorities are stepping up pressure on the United States to take stronger action in the monetary crisis.

title: ROCKEFELLER LINKS CHURCH PUPIL AID TO ADDITIONAL TAX
description: ALBANY, May 12Governor Rockefeller said today that ad ditional state taxes would be necessary to finance new state aid to parochial schools and localities, including New York City.

title: TV Young Pursue Togetherness in the Commune
description: Life. Liberty. And what ever became of the pursuit of happiness? That's one of the questions being asked this evening on Tomorrow's People, written, produced, directed and narrated by Warren Wallace for Colum bia Broadcasting System's Channel 2.

title: Jersey Standard Chief Expects Gains in 71
description: MIAMI, May 12It was almost like a class reunion here today at the annual meeting of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

title: 90 COURT REPORTERS STAGE HOUR PROTEST
description: Ninety court reporters walked off their jobs in Crimi nal Courts throughout the city for more than an hour yester day after a Brooklyn Criminal Court stenographer was jailed for alleged contempt.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Bonn's Farm View Prevails in Common Market
description: BRUSSELS, May 12Follow ing a threat of a walkout by Bonn's delegation, France and West Germany reached a com promise early today to keep the farm program of the Com mon Market intact during the period of floating currency rates.

title: NEW NEWS DIRECTOR NAMED FOR WORTV
description: Paul Cleveland, producer of WORTV's 7:30 News Report, has been named news director of the station and George W. Snowden, former assistant di rector of studios for the Colum bia Broadcasting System tele vision network, is Channel 9's new director of programing.

title: Drivers Who Stop Only for Gas Don't Know What They're Missing
description: PRINCETON, N. J.Sam's BP Gas Station on U.S. 1 five miles north of here, has a diner in the building be hind the pumps. Like most diners, A Kitchen, as it is called, serves ham burgers, hot dogs and french fries. Most of the menu, however, is given over to Chinese dishesshrimp fried rice, beef chop suey and various chow mcins.

title: BLOSSOM DEARIE RINGS IN AN ERA
description: New York has retrieved one of its more pleasant, intimate nightclubs, Trude Heller's at Ninth Street and Avenue of the Americas, lost these last 11 years to the clamor of rock. Possibly to emphasize the change of direction, the first at traction under the new policy is that gentlest and sublest of singers, Blossom Dearie.

title: Economist Rueff on U.S.: Problems Out of Hand
description: PARIS, May 12Jacques Rueff, whose latest book quotes Washington's past monetary prognoses for ironic effect, had kind words for the United States this week. But they were the kind words of a mourner, grieving not alone for the United States but for the econ omy of the West as a whole.

title: Music: Night of Xenakis
description: Iannis Xenakis is an im portant composer of the school that believes in con structing music by computer and according to the laws of physical science, rather than by guess and the gift of the muse. But, he is especially interesting because he is will ing to drive reason to the point of madness.

title: Speer Concedes Stirrings of Pride on Role in Building Nazi War Machine
description: Albert Speer, whose memoirs, Inside the Third Reich, be came a bestseller in the United States and Western Europe last fall, says in an interview that he cannot help feeling stirrings of pride over his role in build ing the Nazi war machine.

title: Astros Beat Seaver for Second Time And Snap Mets Streak at Four, 54
description: The New York Mets hot streak was interrupted yester day by Tom Seaver, of all peo ple, when the Houston Astros scored four runs in the sixth inning and defeated him for the second time in two weeks, 54.

title: MARY BAKER LOSES IN WOMEN'S BOWLING
description: ATLANTA, May 12 (AP)A former chamapion and the cur rent woman bowler of the year were eliminated today during the second day of match play in the 1971 Women's Inter national Bowling Congress Queen's Tournament.

title: Wife of L.I. Dentist Found Slain in Bed On $100,000 Estate
description: PLANDOME, L.I., May 12 The 48yearold wife of a den tist was found shot to death this morning in the bedroom of her $100,000 home on threeacre estate here.

title: DAVID E. LANE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 12 David E. Lane, former presi dent of the Packard Montclair Company of Montclair, N. J., died Monday in Greenwich Hos pital after a short illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Historically, Sinai was never part of Israel. However, three times since Israel became a state in 1948, Israeli soldiers swept through the Sinai desert to avert the danger of the destruction of their country by Egypt. It is a sheer fantasy to believe that Israel will withdraw from Sinai; it is more in credible to imagine that Egypt will give up the idea of launching against Israel as many wars as she can afford in order to recover Sinai.

title: I. S. 201 Takes Classes Outside for the Community
description: There are some folks liv ing across the street who have never been inside the school, said Ronald Evans, the princi pal of East Harlem's Inter mediate School 201.

title: Notes on People
description: The wedding yesterday of Mick Jagger, lead singer of the Rolling Stones, was wild scene, somewhat remini scent of one of the Stone's more hectic concert appear ances.

title: Gentry's Wile Saves Son From Drowning
description: Gary Gentry of the New York Mets flew home to Phoenix, Aria., yesterday after he received word that his 3yearold son Chris had almost drowned in the fam ily's swimming pool.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Sadat Visits Canal Area
description: CAIRO, May 12 President Sadat paid a visit to the Suez Canal frontline today in what seems to be a series of active consultations on decisions re lated to Mr. Rogers's visits to Egypt and Israel.

title: Yahya Said to Plan Visit
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 12 (AP)  President Yahya will visit East Pakistan for the first time since the fighting broke out there almost two months ago, the president of Pakistan's Democratic party, Nurul Amin, said Wednesday.

title: Merger News
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that had applied to the Japanese Government for approval to ac quire a 35 per cent interest in the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation at a cost of $100million over a threeyear period. Under its agreement with Mitsubishi Motor, which is wholly owned subsidiary of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., Chrysler would acquire a 15 per cent interest in Mitsubishi Mo tor this year, an additional 10 per cent in 1972 and a final 10 per cent in 1973. Chrysler said that the Japanese Government was expected to approve the agreement next month.

title: Jobs for the Jobless
description: The economic recession has intensified a chronic prob lem for the less skilled people looking for work. Federally financed programs provide them with training, but once they have finished their course, they find few jobs where they can make use of their new skills. This mis match occurs because the subprofessional jobs for which they have been trained exist largely in the public service, but cities and counties are financially too strapped to hire them. Hospitals, museums, prisons, day care centers, parks and playgrounds have work that needs doing but cannot afford to hire people to do it.

title: TV LICENSE RIVALS CITE EVERS'S PAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  The Federal Communi cations Commission was asked, tody to deny a brodcast license to Charles Evers, Mississippi civil rights leader, and associ ates, because of Mr. Evers's de scription of himself as a former pimp, bootlegger and num bers racketeer.

title: College Graduates to Be Drafted, Even If Law Expires on July
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Even if Congress permits Pres ident Nixon's authority to draft most men to lapse July 1, thousands of men who will graduate from college this sum mer can still be inducted.

title: OUTLOOK IS CLOUDY IN PAPER INDUSTRY
description: No evidence of a significant upturn in the business of the International Paper Company or in the paper industry has been seen, Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president of In ternational Paper, told more than 700 stockholders at yes terday's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.

title: STARS WIN, 137127, LEAD PLAYOFFS, 32
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 12 (AP)Zelmo Beaty led Utah's balanced offense with 32 points tonight as the Stars downed the Kentucky Colonels, 137127, to take a 32 lead in the American Basketball Association cham pionship playoffs.

title: 2 Youths Cited for Contempt By Judge in Berrigan Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 12 (UPI) Two college students were cited for contempt today because they refused to answer questions by the grand jury that indicted the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan in an alleged kidnap pingbombing plot.

title: Republican Shifting Led to SST Revival
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 From a tactical standpoint, the critical element in the House, turnabout on the SST was the organized shift of nearly rt score of Republicans from op position to support for the pro ject or to nonvoting neutrality, today.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Statuettes of Mercury Restored to Fifth Ave.
description: The bronze statuettes of Mercury that adorned Fifth Avenue traffic light poles from 1931 until the poles were replaced in 1964 are being returned to the avenue.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: May 12, 1971 THE PRESIDENT Adjustments. President Nixon certified workers of the Emerson Television and Radio Company in Jersey City, N.J., and those who were formerly employed in the television industry at the Memphis plant of the RCA Corporation as eligible for trade adjustment assistance. These workers, who became unemployed largely because of increased imports, can he given cash readjustment al lowances, job training bene fits and relocation allowances under the Trade Expansion Act of 1962. Production at both plants has ceased.

title: Army Men in Pakistan See Heresy In WesternStyle Education There
description: DACCA, Pakistan, May 11 Military men in Pakistan have declared war on a Westernori ented form of education, which, in their view, is a precursor to religious and doctrinal heresy, rebellion against state authority and moral decay.

title: Relief on Imports Granted To Two Electronics Groups
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) President Nixon today grant ed relief to two groups of elec tronics workers suffering from the impact of imports.

title: To Save Legal Services
description: The Administration is on the right track in seeking to create an independent agency that would immunize Fed erally financed legal services for poor clients from the vetoes and political pressures of Governors and local officials. How to attain this goaland guarantee equal justice for the growing number of indigent persons who cannot afford lawyersis being debated in Congress.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Intergovernmental Work ing Group on Declaration on the Human Environment 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 7 IN J.D.L SEIZED AS CONSPIRATORS
description: Rabbi MeltKahane and six other members of the Jewish Defense League were arrested last night by United States Treasury agents and charged with conspiracy to violate Fed eral gun and bomb regulations.

title: ARTHUR VAN VLECK
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., May 12 Arthur Nye Van Vleck, a re tired New York banker, died today in the Christian Sani tarium, Wyckoff, after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 743 Upper Boule vard.

title: ElectionDay Selling Of Liquor Is Now Legal
description: ALBANY, May 12  With out comment, Governor Rock efeller today approved a bill permitting the sale of alco holic beverages on Primary and Election Days.

title: N.B.C. Moves to Reduce Clutter on the TV Screen
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday measures aimed at reducing ontheair clutter next sea son, adding approximately 30 seconds of every hour to pro gram content.

title: U.S. Agency Urges Waste Treatment On Pleasure Boats
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  The Government pro posed marine waste treatment standards today that it was es timated would cost pleasure boat owners $200 to $300 each.

title: $2.50 MINIMUM PAY URGED BY I.L.G.W.U.
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 12 Delegates to the convention here of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union approved today a broad legis lative program in the social and labor field, including a pro posed increase in the minimum wage to $2.50 an hour.

title: Two Democrats Clash With Nixon Aide Over Consumer Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Two Democratic members of Congress clashed heatedly to day with a top official over the Nixon Administration's record in consumer legislation.

title: Merchant Wins Million In the Jersey Lottery
description: TRENTON, May 12 (UPI) A Puerto Rican who came to the United States 20 years ago to join the Marine Corps became New Jersey's fourth millionaire lottery winner today. He is Pablo Jusino, 37 years old, of Philadelphia, owner of a small hardware store.

title: Borrowings of Eurodollars By U.S. Banks Off in Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (Reu ters)  Eurodollar borrowings by United States banks from their foreign branches dropped $162million in the week ended May 5, bringing gross liabilities to $1.996billion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: DURHAM, N. C., May 12The air port here is halfway between Raleigh and Durham. The former is North Carolina's capital and northsouth traf fic used to run right past the old State House building that distinguished the city. Durham, not too many years ago, was easily recognizable as cigarette manufacturing center.

title: I.T.T. Suggests Reverse Flow
description: SAN DIEGO, May 12The chief executive of the Interna tional Telephone and Telegraph Corporation called today for foreign holders of United States dollars to buy goods and invest in American companies as a means of helping reverse this country's balanceofpayments deficit.

title: New York Lieutenent Killed
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  The Defense Department an nounced today that First Lieut. John J. Woodrum of Stony Point, N. Y., of the Army, had been killed in action in South east Asia.

title: Rest Your Case Withstands Late Bid and Wins Youthful at Aqueduct by Neck
description: Running just as fitly as in a glittering workout last Friday morning, Rest Your Case of the Cragwood Stable scored by a neck yesterday in the $35,250 Youthful at Aqueduct, the first stakes race of the year for 2 yearolds at local tracks.

title: MURPHY DEMANDS TOP OFFICERS AID CORRUPTION FIGHT
description: Warning that the Federal Bureau of Investigation as well as the Knapp Commission had power to investigate police cor ruption, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told his top com manders yesterday that he wanted progress in this crit ical area as quickly as humanly possible.

title: Stottlemyre 3Hitter Sinks Brewers, 30
description: MILWAUKEE, May 12Un like several of the Yankees who made quick oneday visits home earlier this week, Mel Stottle myre remained with the team and let his wife come to him.

title: House Unit Agrees on Bill For New Welfare System
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The House Ways and Means Committee completed action today on an $8.8billion bill that would completely revise the nation's muchcriticized welfare system and make sig nificant changes in Medicare and Social Security.

title: Mancha Returns May 25
description: Man of La Mancha returns to Broadway May 25 at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The musical, which opened at the ANTAWashington Square The ater in 1965, moved to the Mar tin Beck Theater in 1968 and transferred to the Eden Thea ter in March of this year.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN RISE AT CHICAGO
description: In a generally bullish market, futures prices of grains and soy beans rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: A UNION RETURNS TO THE
description: ATLANTA, May 12The In ternational Chemical Workers Union, with 104,000 members, was accepted back into the fold of the A.F.L.C.I.O. today, rais ing hopes that the fragmented labor movement could be re united.

title: CARL F. MAISCH, HEAD OF SKY MARSHALS, 56
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Carl F. Maisch, director of the Federal Aviation Administra tion's antihijacking program and chief of the nation's sky marshal force, died today at hospital in Bethesda, Md., after an operation for removal of a tumor, He was 56 years old.

title: Court Frees Thousands Of Blair & Co. Accounts
description: Thousands of customers of Blair & Co., an insolvent member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, will be able to obtain their longfrozen cash and securities as a result of a court action yesterday. The United States District Court here granted an appli cation for a stay of ordinary bankruptcy proceedings and authorized Patrick J. Scorese, an exchangeappointed liqui dator, to continue transferring accounts.

title: Dollar Inches Upward
description: BONN, May 12 (UPI)The American dollar inched upward on the European money mar kets again today, but trading was light as most speculators held onto their money and waited to see what would hap pen next.

title: PROSECUTOR JABS AT MRS. HUGGINS
description: NEW HAVEN, May 12Mrs. Ericka Huggins testified today that she didn't know what was happening when she saw Alex Rackley being taken at gunpoint from Black Panther headquar ters here on the night he was murdered.

title: News of Dogs
description: An impressive collection of dog art was on view yes terday in the McAlpin Hotel during the Dog Fancier's club's last meeting until next fall.

title: Col. Florence Blanchfield, 87; ExHead of Nurse Corps, Dies
