description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Col. Florence A. Blanchfield, who as superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps directed 60,000 Army nurses in World War II, died today in Walter Reade Hospital. She was 87 years old and made her home with a sister, Mrs. Ruth Ord noff in Arlington, Va.

title: 2 U.S. JUDGES STAY CUTS IN MEDICAID

title: JOHN HOXIE DIES; A PATENT LAWYER

title: What Follows Peasant Look? At de la Renta and Brooks, the Trench Coat
description: It's official now. The peas ants and Cossacks are out of fashion. So, for that matter, are boots. Oscar de la Renta said so yesterday, right in his press release. Since he prac tically invented ethnic clothes and bootswhat he says counts.

title: Columbia Spectator Says TaxExempt Status Is Safe
description: The Columbia Daily Specta tor, the studentrun newspaper at Columbia University, an nounced yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had decided to abandon its attempt to revoke the paper's tax exempt status.

title: MRS. HART'S TEAM LEADS BY 2 SHOTS

title: Kate Webb Tells of Her 3Week Captivity
description: The following account of captivity among Communist troops in Cambodia was writ ten by Kate Webb, chief of United Press International's bureau in Pnompenh. She, Japanese newsman and four Cambodians disappeared on April 7 while covering fight ing along Route 4 about 55 miles southwest of Pnom penh. On April 20 she was re ported dead when the body of a woman fitting her de scription was found in the area. On May 1 she and those who disappeared with her were picked up by Gov ernment troops on Route 4.

title: Diary Sent by Seized Taiwan Writer
description: The diary of a popular young writer arrested last month by the political police in Taiwan has reached friends in the United States.

title: Television Camera Aboid Copter Helps Police Watch Traffic Here
description: The Police Department yes terday displayed publicly for the first time its newest de vice for keeping an eye on things: A helicoptermounted television camera that can re lay pictures instantly to Police Headquarters or anywhere else on the department's closedcir cuit TV network.

title: Ervin Calls for an End Of Preventive Detention
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina urged the Justice Department today to put aside the vain and false panacea of preven tive detention and to support legislation to secure speedy trials of Federal criminal cases.

title: Fund Siphoning Denied by Shaheen
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 12 Thomas A. Shaheen, a money broker who has been testifying here at the bank ruptcy proceeding of Lammot du Pont. Copeland Jr., denied today that he had siphoned fund from their enterprises to Europe.

title: METHEDONE IN JAIL IS CALLED SUCCESS

title: Vermont to Drop Baseball In Move to Cut Expenses
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 12 (AP)The University of Ver mont announced today its baseball program, in existence since 1888, would be dropped at the end of the current sea son.

description: WASHINGTON, May 12 In a stunning reversal of its earlier stand, the House voted today to revive the controver sial supersonic transport pro gram.

title: Setback Explained By Republic Steel
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 12Thomas F. Patton, chair man and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corpora tion, told its annual meeting here today that Republic suf fered a profit decline in the first quarter largely because of its heavy involvement in stain less and alloy steels, which have been battered by competi tion from imports.

title: Nets Get S. Carolina's Roche
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 12 The New York Nets got new home and a new home town hero today.

title: Assemblymen Clash Over Corona Plan
description: ALBANY, May 12After an emotional debate coupled with appeals to respect a colleague's right to seek what is best for his district, the Assembly today rejected a bill affecting a group of condemned homes in Corona, Queens. The bill, opposed by New York City, was sponsored by Assemblyman Vito P. Bat tista, a RepublicanConservative of Brooklyn. It would have cre ated a statewide statute pro viding for the return of con demned property with interest by a municipality to the orgin nal owners if the property was no longer required for public use.

title: RUTGERS GOLFERS CAPTURE TOURNEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 12 Rutgers University's well balanced golf squad won the Metropolitan intercollegiate team title today with a record score of 291, and the Scarlet's No. 2 man, Bob Marzoli, took the individual title with a par 70.

title: Rockefeller Sees Delay For Jetport
description: ALBANY, May 12 Citing the financial problems of the major airlines, Governor Rockefeller announced today that his plan to develop the former Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh into commercial jetport would be slowed considerably.

title: Talks on Berlin Visits Fail
description: BERLIN, May 12 (UPI)  A West Berlin city official said to day that East Germany had refused to open the wall for the Whitsun or Pentecost holiday May 30 to permit the first fam ily reunions between East and West Berliners in five years. The fifth meeting on the sub ject failed today, and the offi cial said afterward, There will be no agreement on Whitsun visits to East Berlin.

title: Amex Prices Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yes terday in light trading.

title: SST Revived
description: As Woodrow Wilson once observed, it is very hard to make the people's voice heard in the halls of Con gress. Even when it has been heard, it is difficult to hold the ear of Congressas was shown by yesterday's vote to revive the SST.

title: Dance: Romeo and Juliet Farewells
description: John Cranko's Romeo and *Juliet, which had its final two performances of the Stuttgart Ballet season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, is a most powerful dance drama. Of all the major workings of the Prokofiev sdoreand in more than 30 years they have become in numerable, this one is the best.

title: A Portrait of John Christie, the Murderer:London Crime Recalled in '10 Rillington Place'
description: Early in the morning of March 9, 1950, after a good night's sleep, Timothy John Evans, a 25-year-old Welshman with the mind of a child, was executed for the murder of his infant daughter, Geraldine. It was also believed that Evans had murdered his wife, Beryl, whose body was found alongside Geraldine's in the wash-house at 10 Rillington Place, London, but the child's murder was the only one for which Evans was prosecuted.Three years later, the Evans's landlord, John Reginald Christie, a former policeman who had been the chief prosecution witness at the trial, was himself arrested and charged with the murder of his wife, Ethel, whose body had been discovered under the floor-boards at 10 Rillington Place. Ethel wasn't the only one stashed away at that shabby address. Investigation revealed five more bodies, hidden in kitchen cupboards and buried in the back yard, and before Christie was hanged on July 15, 1953, he confessed to all of these murders, as well as Beryl's.Christie never admitted to having strangled the Evans baby, but a later inquiry into the murders, and into the two trials, resulted in a posthumous pardon for Evans, and Britain's abolition of the death penalty.This is the real-life case on which Richard Fleischer, the director, and Clive Exton, the scenarist, have based "10 Rillington Place," using Luduvic Kennedy's book of the same title as their source material. It is a solemn, earnest polemic of a movie, one with very little vulgar suspense, shot largely on the actual locations, with actors, including Richard Attenborough (Christie) and John Hurt (Evans), made to look like facsimiles of the real people, with all kinds of authenticity in everything from chamber pots to courtrooms.Ironically, for a movie that is so meticulous, at least in superficial details, "10 Rillington Place" carries very little dramatic conviction, and evokes hardly any emotion except the one relating to the barbarity of capital punishmentwhich is not enough to sustain this sort of entertainment enterprise.The problem with the film is very much the problem with the actual case, which involved small, unimaginative people in some sordid events, and which became interesting and significant only in its ultimate ramifications.Christie was a mass murderer, all right, but a very dull onemad as a hatter, of course, but so inhibited he could only effect a very tentative sexual congress with a woman who was at the point of death. That he was successful, as long as was, in his dreary pursuits of orgies, was not due to a lunatic brilliance but to incredible luck and to the incredible stupidity of the people around him.Attenborough plays Christiequite properly, I thinkwith a nasty, spinsterish fussiness, and absolutely no passion. Poor Evans, to whom the film seems to give most of its attention, is played by Hurt (in what I assume to be the director's conception) as a fairly normal fellow whose only need is a remedial reading course. By largely ignoring Evans's limited mental capabilities, the movie creates a credibility gap that is impossible to bridge.Although Fleischer refuses to senationalize the subject with the sort of lurid details that gave a film like "The Honeymoon Killers" so much of its fine, gruesome impact, he isn't above using common cinematic tricks, like a quick cut from an execution by hanging to a shot of the real murderer, safe in his home, suddenly doubled over with a back ache.Watching the film is, thus, rather like listening to someone tell an obscene story by using only nice euphemisms for dirty words and acts. "10 Rillington Place" would probably have been more effective, more moving even, had it admitted its essential vulgarity, and let us draw our own pious conclusions.

title: STATE CENSUS ERROR OF 50,000 CONFIRMED
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Census Bureau officials ac knowledged today that largely because of computer mistakes, about 50,000 New York State residents were lost in the 1970 censuscounted but not included in the final state total.

title: Headmaster at Dalton Gains in Court
description: Parents supporting Donald Barr in his fight to remain as headmaster of the Dalton School won a victory yester day in State Supreme Court here.

title: U.S. Gypsum to Increase Product Prices by a 5% to 6% Range
description: The United States Gypsum Company said yesterday that it will raise gypsum prices by 5 per cent to 6 per cent, effec tive June 7.

Galloway Jr. Mr. Hig gins, who lived at 168 Ellison Avenue, was 63 years old.

title: For $150, He Will Do His Utmost to Beautify You
description: What makes one man's makeup technique and hair styling worth $150 a session?

title: AFederal Judge Dismisses Suit by Astronaut's Widow
description: ORLANDO, Fla., May 12 (AP)A $5million suit against spacecraft builders by the widow of Lieut. Col. Virgil L. Grissom, one of three astronauts killed in a fire on the Apollo launching pad Jan. 27, 1967, was dismissed yesterday.

title: Miss Bacon Refuses to Answer Questions About Day of Bombing
description: SEATTLE, May 12  Leslie Bacon refused today to tell grand jury what she did March 1, the day the United States Capitol was bombed, her law yers said.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 There's a touch of unreality in the capital air these days, mostly because the politicians seem to be running a year ahead of the calendar. The im pression that Government has run out of things to do, there fore, seems less a case of 1971 spring fever as of 1972 only the litter of press releases, protest marches, commission reports and opinion surveys. Reorganize the government. Share the revenue. End the war now. Stop the supersonic transport. Start the supersonic transport. Bail out Lockheed. Revive the railroads. Defend Lieutenant Caney. Fire J. Edgar Hoover. Cut the troops in Eu rope. Untap the telephones. De nounce the demonstrators.

title: Pathet Lao Urge CeaseFire And End to U.S. Bombing
description: PARIS, May 12 (Reuters) The Laotian proCommunist Pathet Lao called today for an immediate halt of United States bombing and an unconditional ceasefire in Laos.

title: Screen:
description: Continuing the new trend toward schlock nostalgia for the 1940's James Goldstone's Red Sky at Morning, which opened yesterday at the Beekman and Paramount Theaters, proves with sad clarity that you can almost instantaneously have too much of a bad thing.

title: Celtic Defeats Rangers For Soccer Double, 21
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 12 (Reuters)Glasgow Celt ic completed the Scottish League and Association Cup soccer double for the third time in five years when it beat the Glasgow Rangers, 21 tonight.

title: PANEL INCREASES HEALTH BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 The House Ways and Means Committee, in completing ac tion on the welfare bill today, refused to accept the Admin istration's proposals to reduce Medicare and Medicaid bene fits by more than $800million.

title: A Ban on Special Press Rates Is Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (Reuters)  The United States Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal Communications Commission ruling abolishing special preferential press rates that news services have long received on privateline tele graph and telephoto transmis sion.

title: Rockefeller and Cahill to Seek Tighter Security on Waterfront
description: ALBANY, May 12Governor) Rockefeller and Governor Wil liam T. Cahill of New Jersey an nounced today that they would seek legislation to make possi ble tighter security of cargo on the New York waterfront.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Asks New Trade Curbs
description: ATLANTA, May 12The Ex ecutive Council of the A.F.L. C.I.O. urged Congress and the Administration today to pass new legislation and to reform laws governing trade to better protect American workers and industry from foreign compe tition.

title: Sports of The Times
description: George Chuvalo bleeds for our sins. At the end of each fight, stoic or oxlike, he awaits the decision, the accident report on his face, the road map of the coming months. He always loses the big ones and on Monday night he lost again, suffered minor cuts, saw the year ahead straighten out into another string of overnighters in Canadian towns to build up his record and his confidence again. His manager, a Toronto poultry processor famous for nagging and shrieking and cursing, had threatened to leave George if he lost to Jimmy Ellis, and as the closed circuit television picture faded, the imagination's ear could hear the manager scream: How can you do this to me, George? How can you be so ungrateful after all I've done for you?

title: 25th Cannes Film Fete Opens With Glitter and Pomp
description: CANNES, France, May 12 The Cannes Film Festival is celebrating its twentyfifth birthday with as much star spangled folderol and old time glitter as the festival director, Robert Fevre Le bret, could muster.

title: US, SAYS PLANES HIT GUNS IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (AP)  The United States command said today that Air Force Phantom jets had de stroyed 13 antiaircraft guns around the Mugia Pass in North Vietnam.

description: Tim Foli and Ken Singleton of the Mets will be the guests at an autograph party in the New Rochelle Mall shopping center tonight at 7 P.M. Marty Glickman will be master of ceremonies.

description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 12 Clarence 0. Woodbury, who had been art director of the Reader's Digest from 1945 until he retired in 1962, died yester day rf heart failure at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 38 Brook Avenue.

description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 12 (UPI)  Two American bald eagles found dead recently were victims of illegal hunt ing.

Richard Duf field Pope, pastor for 35 years until his death in 1947 of the Episcopal Church of the Advent, Westbury, L. I., died today. She was 90 years old and lived at 1 Blackfoot Road with her daughter, Mrs. Isabel Griffith.

Hutton & Co., has joined he in vestment firm as a gen eral partner and member of the executive commit tee. He will also be divisional partner for the company's Midwestern division, and will make his headquarters here. Mr. Wellin entered the brokerage business with E. F. Hutton in Chicago in 1952. He was named, a partner in 1960 and was placed in charge of the Chicago office and the Midwestern region in 1962.

description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 12 (UPI)A Government spokes man said today that North Vietnamese MIG21 jets flew bombing and strafing missions against Laotian Government troop positions in the Plaine des Jarres for the first time.

description: A Federal judge ruled yester day that a construction union must give compensatory pay to Negroes deprived of work be cause of the union's discrimina tory practices.

title: Bridge:
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 12 The world champion Aces now seem certain to meet France in the final of the 1971 Bermuda Bowl competi tion scheduled to begin here Saturday. A brave bid by the Australian team to move closer to second position failed tonight when France pulled back from a 19point deficit at halftime to tie the match, 1010, in victory points.

title: CityState Buck Passing

title: Man in the News
description: BRUSSELS, May 12  In 1956 a new Conservative party Member of Parliament, Geoffrey Rippon, joined in a motion urging the Conserva tive Government of the day to take part in forming European common market.

title: MRS. JAMES BARNES, FORMER COLUMNIST
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Mrs. James M. Barnes, a former society columnist, who was the widow of an Illinois Congress man, died today. She was 68 years old. Her husband, a Demo crat, served in the House from 1939 to 1943.

title: HARRY W. LAUTER
description: Harry W. Lauter, a director of the Home Furnishing Asso ciation of New York, died Mon day in a Phoenix (Ariz.) hospi tal after a short illness. He was 79 years old and had lived until recently at 15 West 72d Street.

title: LaBadie Runs 3:58.8 Mile
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 12 (UPI)Lee LaBadie, an Illinois junior, ran the mile in 3 min utes 58.8 seconds last night in a dual meet with Southern Illinois. He is the first Big Ten undergraduate to break the fourminute barrier.

title: Soviet Asserts Jews Consulted Israelis in 1970 Hijacking Plot
description: MOSCOW, May 12  Tass, the Soviet press agency; said today that the Israeli author ities had been consulted by the group of Sovibt Jews accused of plotting last year to hijack a Soviet plahe to flee the country.

title: IRMA ROTHSTEIN, A SCULPTOR HERE
description: Irma Rothstein, a sculptor, suffered a heart attack Tues day in her home at 17 East 31st Street and was pro nounced dead at Bellevue Hos pital Center. She was in her 60's.

title: Counts Against Panthers Here Reduced to 12 as Case Nears Jury
description: Only 12 of 30 original counts of the indictment of 13 Black Panthers accused of participat ing in a bombing conspiracy will be submitted to the jury when it begins deliberations.

title: Northwest Airlines Shows a Net Loss
description: Northwest Airlines, Inc., re ported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net loss of $11,811,866, the first kiss for the period since 1962, largely, because of reduced revenuesf resulting from the lengthy clerks strike that ended last Dec. 31. In the initial three months last year the airline had a profit of $8,610,669, or 41 cents a share.

title: But Rise Was $2Billion Below the Average for the First Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Personal income rose $4.5bil lion in April, well below the average monthly rise in the first quarter of $6.5billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In connection with your recent edi torial on the subject of Phantom Pensions in Industry, it will be of interest to you and your readers to know that I recommended the intro duction of a bill in the State Legisla tune on Jan. 13, (S. 1671, A. 1865), to establish vested pension rights for employes in private industry and to regulate and administer such employe pension funds.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are a typical inves tor, the one document you get from your broker that you probably don't pay much attention to is the broker's own balance sheet. IL usually comes along once or twice a year, stuffed into the envel ope with the statement of your personal account.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Now is the time when East Coast stripped bass fisher men face the final nerve racking wait before the fish appear everywhere.

title: Chess:
description: Andrew Soltis, one of America's most promising young players, has won the championship of New York's Marshall Chess Club for the fourth time in five years. Soltis posted a 101 score and Dr. Orest Popovych was second. Louis Levy and Al bert Pinkus were next with the allocation of third and fourth prizes still pending the outcome of adjourned games.

title: February Traffic Toll Up
description: The economic loss from traf fic accidents rose to $1,21 billion in February from $1.1million a year earlier, the Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday.

title: Uncashed Winning Tickets Enrich State by $966,729
description: ALBANY, May 12 (AP) Horserace bettors failed to cash $966,729 in winning tickets last year and allowed the money to revert to the state, the State Tax Department said today.

title: Genial and Witty 'Mrs. Pollifax -- Spy'
description: Thank you, Rosalind Russell and friends for "Mrs. PollifaxSpy," opening yesterday at the Victoria and circuit showcases. This modest, genial, often witty cloak-and-dagger comedy may lack the thrills of all those frantic James Bond cash-ins. But, a bit belatedly and without over-reaching, it comes in on target agreeably, with ample chuckles.The spice is the presence of the star, playing it cool and subdued but properly brisk, as an earthbound widow from New Jersey who presents herself to a stunned but imaginative C.I.A. Dispatched to Mexico City, she winds up a prisoner in a mountain fortress in Communist-dominated Albania.Slender as the picture is, it meshes disarmingly on three counts. There's good old Roz, who is simply darling.There is the compactness of C. A. McKnight's script, nicely flavored by some pointed, wry dialogue. Add the picturesque backgrounds of Mexico City and Wyoming (doubling for Albania) in good color. Except for one good, ugly scene of a bullet removal, the rough stuff is relegated off screen, under Leslie Martinson's trim direction.Finally, there is the general tone of wry, warm sensibility, sidestepping cuteness and outright burlesque. The star has fine support from Nehemiah Persoff, Harold Gould, Albert Paulson, John Beck and Dana Elcar. As her cynical sidekick in sleuthing. Darren McGavin is excellent."Give it to 'em, baby," he encourages, as Miss Russell is led off for interrogation. Attagirl, Roz.

title: Prof. Leon Stephens, Taught Farming and Agronomy, 89
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 12Leon M. Stephens, professor emeritus at the State Univer sity's Agricultural and Techni cal College here, died yesterday in the Berkshire Nursing Home, West Babylon, after a long ill ness. He was 89 years old and lived at 56 Powell Place.

title: Amtrak Agrees to Restore BostonWashington Route
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI) The National Railroad Pas senger Corporation, also known as Amtrak, announced today that it would restore Bostonto Washington train service via Worcester and Springfield, Mass., Hartford, New Haven and New York.

title: Quiet Drive in House By RICHARD WITHIN
description: The bipartisan House effort; to resurrect the supersonic transport program began right after Congress killed the pro ject seven weeks ago and was kept at a low key so as not to alert the opposition another $12million for admin istrative, warehousing and other similar termination ex penses. It also includes $22 million to repay clown payments made by the airlines for fin ished SST's; $58.5million to re imburse the airlines for their contributions to development: $132million for losses in taxes of 12,629 SST workers who will have been laid off by midsum mer, and $34.4million in un employment benefits.

title: FIRST TWO HORSES ENTER PREAKNESS
description: BALTIMORE, May 12 Bold Reason and Jim French today became the first two horses to be entered officially in Satur day's 96th running of the $150,000added Preakness at Pimlico race course.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS LOCKHEED BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Senator Alan Cranston, Demo crat of California, proposed to day that the board of directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration be forced to resign as a condition of the company's receiving a Government guar antee for $250million in loans that it needs to continue operat ing.

title: Yahya Tells Thant Relief Aid Is Not Needed Now
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 12  President Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan has told Secretary General Thant that United Nations emergency help for East Pakistan is not needed now but he left open the pos sibility of accepting internation al aid in the future.

title: City Hall Tries to Beat Horses Again
description: Still looking for the right horse, Mayor Lindsay dug into his pocket for some fresh money yesterday as the city's Off track Betting Corporation began taking action on the Preak ness.

title: TV Program on Pentagon Scored at House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Daniel Z. Henkin, Assistant Sec rectary of Defense for Public Affairs, criticized in Congres sional testimony today the con tent and editing of the Colum bia Broadcasting System's con troversial program, The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your editorial of April 30, Decay of a Union, demonstrates how far your great newspaper has fallen into the morass of printing opinion and not fact.

title: RollCall Vote in House on Financing of SST Project
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the House voted today to resume financing of the supersonic transport plane:

title: M'CRACKEN PLEADS FOR COORDINATION
description: BRUSSELS, May 12 (Reuters) Paul W. McCracken, chair man of President Nixon's Coun cil of Economic Advisers, said today the United States and other countries must explore ways of better coordinating economic policies.

title: TROOP CUT FOUGHT BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  The Nixon Administration fought a rear guard action to day to ward off a Senate move to reduce American military forces in Europe.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Jim Bedell, Adelphi's athlet ics director, and the students who hope to save that uni versity's athletic program may be settling a pattern that could avoid a trend to ward the abolition of sports programs. Bedell said he felt somewhat like the little Dutch boy who put his thumb in the dike. I don't really think there is a big move Across the nation to get rid of athletics, Bedell said. But if we fall by the wayside, as did New York University basketball and some other programs here and there, we could just be the one to really get the snowball rolling and a real trend could develop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am pleased to observe that you have afforded nursing an opportunity to express its views in reference to the LavernePisani bill. (Evelyn Peck, R.N., May 3 letter.) However, the editor's note inunediately following this letter indicates further misinter pretation of the bill and an attempt to sabotage Miss Peck's letter.

title: A Good Way to Save
description: Personal sacrifice and long range planning helped build America. And it takes the same qualities to be successful in saving money. That is why Americans are being asked this year to 'Take Stock in America. In doing so, they will be taking stock in themselves. Everyone can plan for a more secure future by building a nest egg with United States Savings Bonds.

title: Minnesota Kills Betting Bill
description: ST. PAUL, May 12 (AP)A bill to legalize parimutuel bet ting in Minnesota died last night when the House voted, 95 to 32, in favor of an interim study. The bill was sponsored as a means of raising tax revenue. Opposing the bill were the Minnesota Council of Churches, other religious groups and some law enforcement of ficials.

title: CITY ASKS CONTROL OF SCHOOL BUDGET
description: A bill that would permit the city to control the way the Board of Education spends its money was submitted yesterday to the Legislature by City Coun cil leaders. The measure was immediately attacked by Murry Bergtraum, outgoing president of the statechartered board, who said:

title: Report Ton Lead in Atmosphere Of Los Angeles Held Up a Year
description: LOS ANGELES, May 12 The Environmental Protection Agency acknowledged today that observations reportedly indicating excessive amounts of lead in the Los Angeles at mosphere had been withheld from public dissemination for more than a year.

title: Touring Soviet Five Wins
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., May 12 (AP)The Soviet Union na tional basketball team opened an American tour with an 83.82 victory over a team of college and Amateur Athletic Union players last night.

title: Brooklyn Alumni Elect
description: Stanley Goldstein has been named to serve a twoyear term as president of the Brook lyn College Alumni Association. Mr. Goldstein, of the class of 1959, will take office May 23, when the association has its annual Homecoming Day meet ing at the college's student cen ter.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Will some body please turn off the 1972 Presi dential election campaign? The thing has been calling for attention ever since January when Senator McGov ern announced that he was a candi date, and now the papers and tube are already filling with those displays of happily exposed teeth which, along with the visa to Israel and an appoint ment with the chief commissar in Moscow, identify candidates for the Presidency of the United States.

title: Mark Is Strong Here
description: The dollar eased somewhat in the New York foreignex change market yesterday. The pound sterling, the German mark, the Dutch guilder and the Japanese yen all gained in relation to the dollar in trading that  dealers described as starting to get back toward normal.

title: Madison Ave. Closings Stir Dissent
description: The Madison Avenue Magic Promenade, a program de signed by the Lindsay administration to bring peo ple together in the city after dark, seems to have done the opposite for some.

title: F.T.C. Bars Grocery Ads For Unavailable Specials
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Federal Trade Commission sought today to stop the advertising of grocery specials that are not available to customers when they get to the store. It issued a regulation listing such advertising as a violation of Federal laws against unfair or deceptive trade practices and against unfair competitive tactics.

title: Reflections on Calley
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.The obscene haste with which a large part of the Amer ican people rushed to the support of a man convicted of multiple premedi tated murder of men, women and Chil dren, the obscene pride with which they even identified themselves with him is one of those rare historical events which reveal a hidden truth.

title: DANCER TO LEAVE LITTLE TO CHANCE
description: WESTBURY, L. 1., May 12 Four of the 11 fillies entered this morning in the 12th an nual Lady Maud Pace to be con tested at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of May 21 are from the Stanley Dancer Sta ble.

title: Esso Workers Accept Pact, Ending Part of Gas Strike
description: The first break in the 12 dayold strike by gasoline truck drivers, mechanics and ware house workers occurred yes terday when 400 striking employes of the Humble Oil and Refining Company (Esso) ac cepted a new twoyear contract with the company.

title: INSURANCE OFFERED TO FUND'S HOLDERS
description: The National Securities and Research Corporation, which has more than $900million in mutual fund assets under man agement, announced yesterday that it had completed arrange ments to insure investors in its Fairfield Fund against long term financial losses. Fairfield is a growth fund not designed for current income.

title: QUEENS SYNAGOGUE DAMAGED BY FIRE
description: A fire caused extensive dam age last night to the Congrega tion Shaare Zedek synagogue at 3617 Edgernere Avenue in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Capitol Peace Group Is Met by Mrs. Abzug
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  Representative Bella S. Abzug, one of four legis lators severely criticized by their colleagues for welcom ing 1,500 antiwar protesters to the Capitol May 5, greeted participants in a 24  hour peace vigil on the Capitol steps today.

title: Mayor Takes a Hand
description: Mayor Lindsay canceled a trip to Seattle yesterday to take a hand in budget negotiations with the state.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Miss Jane H. Le Peyre Is Married
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 12In the First Parish in Cambridge (Unitarian) today, Miss Jane Holmes Le Peyre, a secretary at the Massachu setts Institute of Technology, was married to Dean Free man Peterson 3d, who ex pects to receive a doctorate in electrical engineering from M.I.T. next month. The Rev. Ralph Norman Helverson per formed the ceremony.

title: Stolen F.B.I. Papers Described As Largely of a Political Nature
description: BOSTON, May 12The self styled Citizens Commission to Investigate the F.B.I. says that 40 per cent of the documents it stole on March 8 from the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Media, Pa., involved investigations of a political na ture while only 1 per cent in volved organized crime.

title: JUDGES UPHOLD STATE'S BUDGET
description: ALBANY, May 12The Ap pellate Division today reversed a decision of a lower court that had declared the state budget for this fiscal year to be un constitutional.

title: Maytime Benefits for 2 Medical Institutions Draw Quiet Ones
description: Consider the plight of the social ite

title: Music: M.I.T.'s Concert
description: If the Massachusetts Insti tute of Technology wanted to alter its image with the three concerts it has given here this season, it has certainly suc ceeded.

title: James Coogan Dies at 78; A.A.U. and Olympics Aide
description: ORANGE, Conn., May 12 (AP)James E. Coogan, man ager of the 1956 United States Olympic basketball team that won a gold medal at Melbourne, died yesterday in his home. He was 78 years old.

title: CEYLON TEA TRADE IS HURT BY REVOLT
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 12 The ultraleftist revolt has badly disrupted tea exports, long Ceylon's pride and her prime source of foreign exchange.

title: Bronx Museum of Art Makes Debut
description: Citizens of the Bronx, a borough not known for its artistic riches, woke up yes terday to find the Metropoli tan Museum of Art in their midst. In the massive rotunda of the Bronx County Court house, the Manhattan institu tion has hung a show of 28 important paintings from its own collection  works by Van Gogh, Courbet, Monet, Winslow Homer, Benjamin West, and contemporaries such as Milton Avery, Romare Bearden and Robert Mother well.

title: ' The Night Digger'
description: As a study of understated tensions, vague psychopathic sexuality and somber moods, the British-made "The Night Digger," which came to local theaters yesterday, proves to be more polish than persuasive drama. It begs for empathy for its tortured principals, but despite the clearly dedicated contributions of Patricia Neal, Roald Dahl, her scenarist-husband; Pamela Brown and a young newcomer, Nicholas Clay, the strain on credibility is a good deal more notable than the impact on the emotions.Miss Neal is portraying a cured one-time victim of a stroke. She is eminently qualified by her victory over her own actual traumatic experience. So is Mr. Dahl, who helped her recover and whose script gives her and the rest of the cast sensible lines to speak.But Miss Neal, cast as an intelligent, sensitive spinster enslaved to the demanding, blind mother who adopted her at an early age, does not appear to be the type who would fall for a strange, shifty young man who has insinuated himself into the household.Suffice it to say that Miss Neal is suspicious, frightened and resentful of the ominous young intruder, Nicholas Clay, from the moment of his arrival. And while it is made evident that he's the sick, mysterious fiend who's raped, killed and buried a half-dozen girls in nearby roads that are being paved, Miss Neal's apprehension grows without knowledge of the facts.Even though it's indicated that she eventually is aware something unusual is troubling him, Miss Neal decides to help, falls in love, escapes her mother's dominance and spends a brief, romantic idyll with him before it all ends in tragedy. One can understand her yearning for happiness, but the turnabout is sudden and hardly in keeping with her adult character. Her delineation is tense but properly underplayed, and Nicholas Clay's portrayal is generally low-keyed but strong. But a viewer needs a clinical elaboration beyond brief vignettes about his being a eunuch."The Night Digger" previously bore the ironic title, "The Road Builder" and it stems from a poetically labeled novel, "Nest in a Falling Tree." Unfortunately it cries for more conviction rather than a catchy tag.

title: Veterans for Vietnam
description: Despite statements to the contrary, 2.5 million Vietnam veterans have not dropped out or disappeared. With few exceptions, they are pursuing their in terrupted careers and education, free of selfinduced breastbeating, proud of their contribution to. American defense and the Vietnamese future.

title: Miss Marlyn Rhoda Waranch Bride of Alexander Messinger
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., May 12Miss Karlyn Rhoda Wa ranch, a 1969 graduate of the University of Pennsyl vania, was married here to night to Alexander Messinger. Rabbi Yechiel Orenstein and Cantor Morris Levinson offi ciated at the ceremony in the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Calvert I. Waranch. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Messinger of Haifa, Israel. Mr. Waranch is a mer chandising executive on the staff of the Franklin Stores Corporation, and the bride groom's father is an indus trial engineer in Haifa.

title: Post Office to Merge Regional Headquarters and Reduce Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount announced today a sweeping reorganization of the Post Office Department that will affect more than 6,000 postal employes here and in regional offices during the next few months.

title: Bronx Swells With Pride on Its Day
description: With enormous enthusiasm and energy, Bronx Day was celebrated yesterday for the first time since 1935 with a mammoth parade down the Grand Concourse, a turnout of 50,000 at the. Bronx Zoo, music programs, art exhibits and glowing speeches about the assorted minorities who make up the 1,500,000 resi dents of the only borough in the City that is part of the nation's mainland.

title: Government's Price Freeze and Wage Rises Send Chileans on a Buying Spree
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 12 The string shopping bags of workingclass housewives are bulging these days with food and household goods picked from supermarket shelves and streetmarket stalls.

title: Youths Display Talents
description: About 500 exhibits went on display for three days starting yesterday at the Bankers Trust first floor exhibit room at 280 Park Avenue, at 48th Street, to demonstrate how the Police Athletic League is encouraging disadvantaged children to show their creative talents. The 50 yearold organization's, basi cally privately supported.

title: McCloskey Says Administration Employs Deception on the War
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey Jr. of California, who is preparing to challenge Pres ident Nixon in at least four Republican primaries, accugd the Administration today of ly ing to the American people and concealing information from them.

title: Francis Seeks Trade as Playoffs Resume Tonight
description: While the Montreal Ca nadians and Chicago Black Hawks await the resumption of their Stanley Cup cham pionship series in Chicago tonight, Emile Francis, the general managercoach of the New York Rangers is plotting next year's down fall of the winning team.

title: EVERY WEEK
description: EVERY week, more then 26,000 jobs are Advertised IN The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.Advt.

title: Advertising: 4A SelfRegulation Code Set
description: For Archibald McG. Foster, who this week steps down from the chairmanship of the American Association of Ad vertising Agencies, the high point of his year in office was the association's success in getting an industry accord on a selfregulating code.

title: HEARING IS HEED ON GATEWAY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 The proposed Gateway National Recreation area won a favor able reception today from Senate subcommittee, which heard varying testimony about what should  and should not be included in the project.

title: Students Given Grim Picture of Drugs
description: Patrolman John Corliss stood in the basement of the 32d precinct station on West 135th Street yesterday and watched a crowd of Harlem schoolchildren milling around exhibits on drugs and police work that he had designed and built.

title: Credit Markets: Rates Up Inc the Utility Bond Sector
description: Interest rates on highgrade utility bonds were raised ever so slightly yesterday, and the small increase in yield seemed to spark a modest recovery in the corporate sector of the capital markets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As counsel in the Supreme Court for Angelica Schneider in the case of Schneider v. Rusk, I am regretfully compelled to take public issue with your distinguished columnist, Anthony Lewis. I do so for the sole purpose of reassuring the many citizens who are relying upon the Supreme Court decision in the Schneider case.

title: City Planners Approve Hudson Sewage Plant
description: The City Planning Commis sion approved yesterday a major sewage treatment plant that will cost $420million and is intended to help clean up the Hudson River.

title: Rogers to See Thant
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 Secretary Rogers will confer in New York Monday with Sec retary General Thant and the United Nations intermediary for the Middle East, Dr. Gun nar V. Jarring, on his recent trip to the Middle East, the State Department said today. Mr. Rogers will be accompan ied by Mr. Sisco, who met this morning for more than an hour with Itzhak Rabin, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After reading the May 4 editorial A Tax on G.I.'s, I wonder if The Times is deliberately attempting to mislead its readers or has simply neg lected to consider all the facts.

title: U.S. Acknowledges Report
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The Justice Department said after the newspaper ac count was published in New Hampshire that it had received a document that purports to be a statement of Edward Grady Partin.

title: Swissair Cuts Franc Fares
description: GENEVA, May 13A 6 per cent reduction in international air fares priced in Swiss francs will become effective Monday, Swissair, the Swiss airline, an nounced today. The cut was agreed to by all the airlines that serve Switzerland because of Monday's upward revalua tion of the Swiss franc.

title: Bears Sign 3Year Lease To Play at Soldier Field
description: CHICAGO, May 13 (AP) The Chicago Bears of the Na tional Football League signed today a threeyear lease to play their home games at Soldier Field for a rental of 10 per cent of game receipts.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: U.S. Combat Deaths Pat at 34 for Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13 (Reuters)  Thirty four Americans and 360 South Vietnamese died in the Indochina war last week, military spokesmen said to day.

title: Senate Panel Approves Six for the Bench Here
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The nominations of six federal judges for courts in the New York area were screened today by a Senate Judiciary subcom mittee and sent to the full com mittee for approval, possibly next week.

title: Vestigial Featherbed
description: Among the encumbrances the railroads have carried over from the Iron Horse is the one remaining section of New York State's misnamed full crew law. In 1966 the Legislature repealed twothirds of the law, which mandates featherbedding. All that is left is the section that requires all locomotives operating in this state to carry a fireman.

title: Turks Fly Aid to Villages; Death Toll in Quake Now 54
description: BURDUR, Turkey, May 13 (AP)Army helicopters carried medicine and supplies to strick en mountain villages in south west Turkey today to relieve victims of yesterday's earth quake. The official toll was 54 dead and authorities feared it might go higher when reports are received from remote vil lages.

title: HOGAN CARDS A 9, GOES 11 OVER PAR
description: HOUSTON, May 13 (AP) Ben Hogan soared to an 11 overpar score today before withdrawing from the $125,000 Houston Champions golf tour nament. Meanwhile, Kermit Zarley and Larry Hinson were registering rounds of 67 and they shared the lead after 18 holes of play.

title: U.S. In 13 Air Freight Truckers Here
description: Two criminal antitrust in dictments were returned yes terday by a special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn against 13 trucking companies, six in dividuals and the National As sociation of Air Freight, Inc., whose member concerns con trol the bulk of air freight trucking at Kennedy Interna tional Airport.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Prices on Amex Finish Lower As Selling Erases Early Gains
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower in steppedup trading yesterday after increased selling pressure in the afternoon erased most of the earlier gains.

title: HEINIE MANUS, OUTFIELDER DIES
description: SARASOTA, Fla., May 13 (UPI)Heinie Manush, a mem ber of baseball's Hall of Fame who hit 330 during a 17year major league career, died here yesterday of cancer. He was 69 years old, and had been ill for two years.

title: LOCKHEEDAID BILL SENT TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The Administration formally sent to Congress today legislation pro viding Government guarantees for $250million in loans to the ailing Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration.

title: Reward Offered for Obote
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 13 (AP)Uganda's military Government put out a want ed notice for former Presi dent Milton Obote today with a reward of $139,200 to any one who returns him alive to Uganda.

title: RECORDS GUARDED IN NORTH BERGEN
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., May 13  Plainclothes policemen of the Hudson County Prosecutor's office and this municipality's Police Department swarmed through and around City Hall today to prevent the removal of papers, vouchers and docu ments by officials of the out going administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have read with interest the OpEd article [April 16] entitled Crisis in Newark by Imamu Amiri Baraka, also known as LeRoi Jones. Some of the items relative to the school strike that just ended that Mr. Baraka complained about are justified. I cannot under stand that he is the moving spirit in special class at the Robert Treat school wherein the students pledge allegiance to another country and are given in structions on everything except how to be a good American, and by Good American I don't necessarily mean the establishment.

title: Pay Dispute Halts Races
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, May 13 (UPI)The scheduled debut of thoroughbred horse racing at the Windsor Raceway tomor row night has been oonceled by a pay dispute that threatens the entire racing schedule. If the dispute with parimutuel clerks is not settled by noon Monday, the 4Gnight summer meet will be canceled, track officials said.

title: 2d Slaying Suspect Held
description: A second suspect in the slay ing of an employe of the Cheetah disclotheque, 310 West 52d Street, during a holdup last Sunday, was in custody, yes terday. He is Raymond Ven tura, alias Novoa Venicio, 24 years old, a Dominican. Shortly after the holdup in which Ray mond Poole, 24, an electrician of Union City, N. J., was fatally wounded, one of the three sus pects was picked up. He was identified as Claudio Marrero, 27, of 201 West 79th Street.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS HELD TO NEED NEW BASE
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh described civil rights last night as mere shadows unless greater emphasis is placed on the economic rights of the underprivileged.

title: Finance Minister in Bonn Quits in a Budget Dispute
description: BONN, May 13  Finance Minister Alex Moller resigned today from the Cabinet of Chancellor Willy Brandt. The Government said that the resig nation had nothing to do with the currency crisis.

title: The Town Women Have Run for 21 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Va.The town water system has been acting up lately, so the Mayor of this small Virginia Blue Ridge Mountain community trudged into the soggy hills the other afternoon to see about the cracks in the reservoir and the town's elusive underground mountain spring.

title: Business Loans Here Are Up
description: Demand for business loans soared at major New York City banks during the week ended Wednesday after a long period in which borrowing needs have been sluggish at best.

title: Mrs. Hart's Team Captures RainCurtailed Golf Tourney
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 13 Mrs. A. S. Hart of Baltusrol and Mrs. DeWitt Alexandre of Somerset Hills won a curtailed Women's Metropolitan Golf Association better ball of part ners tournament today.

title: Nixon Aide Rejects Spending Demands
description: The deputy director of the Federal Government's Office of (Management and Budget re jected yesterday as complete and utter nonsense Congres sional demands that the Ad ministration spend some $12.8 billion in funds appropriated by Congress but impounded by President Nixon.

title: Head of I.L.G.W.U. Sees Threat By U.S. to Union's Political Role
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 13 Louis Stulberg, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, warned today of the possibility that the Jus tice Department might chal lenge the use for political pur poses of voluntary contribu tions made by members of the union.

title: New Zealand Comments
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 13Prime Minister Sir Keith Holyoake said today that his Government would watch closely for any sign that China wished to open a dialogue with New Zealand, but he made it clear that New Zealand had no intention of breaking ties with the Chinese Nationalists.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Culture. The President signed an Executive order to preserve, restore and main tain the nation's historic and cultural sites. He ordered a twoyear Government review of Federal holdings that qual ify for listing on the National Register of Historic Places.

title: HIDEMITSU HAYASHI MAKES PIANO DEBUT
description: Hidemitsu Hayashi has stud ied in his native Japan and at the Juilliard School here, where he is working toward a Bache lor of Music degree. On the evidence of his debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday, the pianist seems in danger of becoming too Americanized. He tackled some technically very difficult works, including Balakirev's Islamey, Scriabin's Sonata No. 5 and a Sonata by Akira Miyoshi. He had virtuosity of a sort for them, the speed and the ability to hit most of the notes. He also had a flair for their dynamic or emotional excite ment. What was missing was the refinement, the attention to detail, that even these pieces need.

title: Economic Analysis
description: PARIS, May 13The dollar crisis has created tremen dous frictions in Europe, but it also may he the catalyst that brings Europe closer together. There are chances that the Europeans may gang up against the United States to get their points across. The main point is that they just do not like what the United States seems to be forcing them to do. Two main choicesholding dollars or upward curren cy adjustments are equally unpal atable politically and economically. A third is to unite and from what happened in Brussels early today when sub stantial progress was recorded in the BritishCommon Market negotiations, this may well he the route Europe takes.

title: Screen: Adaptation of Neil Simon's Plaza Suite
description: When a Broadway hit of the dimensions of Neil Simon's Plaza Suite is turned into an aggressively tiresome movie, the conven tional thing to say (at least by those critics whose loyal ties are with the stage) is that something has been lost in the play's translation to the screen. In the case of Plaza Suite, I don't have the feeling that anything much has been lost, but rather that nothing much was ever there.

title: U.S. FILM IS SHOWN AT CANNES FESTIVAL
description: CANNES, France, May 13 The Cannes Film Festival, the fanfare of opening night out of the way, got down to the competition proper today with works from the United. States and Australia that provoked diverse reactions.

title: Hawks Beat Canadiens, 20
description: CHICAGO. May 13  When tonight's Stanley Cup game ended, Pete Mahovlich of the Montreal Canadiens slammed his stick on the Chicago Sta dium ice. It lay there with the blade broken, a symbol of frus tration, as he skated off. Else where, the Chicago Black Hawks held their sticks high in triumph.

title: Soviet Five Routs. U.S.
description: BUFFALO, May 13 (AP)The Soviet Union's national basket ball team trounced a United) States squad, 86.67, tonight inl the second game of a cross country tour. Randy Smith and Julius Erving led the losers with 15 points each.

title: Yanks Top Brewers in 10th, 43
description: MILWAUKEE, May 13  If the Yankees could play Chicago and Milwaukee, the weakest teams in the Western Division, for a few more weeks, they'd probably have to be considered a legitimate contender in the Eastern Division race.

title: Wanser Captures Medal in Richardson Golf by Stroke With Par
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 13  Rain and cold greet ed the golfers as the Long Is land amateur season opened to day with the qualifying round of the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament at the Seawane Club. Despite the con ditions, Alonso Wanser Jr., a former Brookville Country Club champion, equaled the par of 72, and won the qualifying honors by one stroke.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Tiffeau and Parnis Play It Safe, Almost
description: Even Jacques Tiffeau, that erstwhile enfant terrible of fashion, couldn't resist the current hue and cry for wear able clothes. By wearable, storekeepers reviewing the fall collections on Seventh Avenue explain, they mean fashions that won't make waves. They remember the midi all too well and don't want trouble with their cus tomers next fall.

title: Ohio Pollution Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury today indicted the Allied Chemical Corporation, the I.R.C. Fibers Division of the American Cyanamid Company and two other northern Ohio concernsthe Cabot Titania Corporation and the Diamond Shamrock Chemical Company on charges of polluting Lake Erie and three Ohio rivers.

title: Singer's Trend Mixed
description: The Singer Company expects its business abroad to continue its good performance, while the improved tone here in March and April was hardly striking, Donald P. Kircher, president, told some 600 shareholders at tending yesterday's annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel here.

title: Prompted Santa Claus Editorial
description: No letter to a newspaper was ever so widely read as the one 8yearold Virginia O'Hanlon wrote to The New York Sun 74 years ago. And no editorial was more famous than the one it inspired.

title: Rural Power Plant Issue in Pollution Dispute Between 2 States
description: MOUNT STORM, W. Va., May 13 To Postmaster Ron ald Mills and many others in this Appalachian hamlet the steady roar on the roads these days of the big red 10wheel coal trucks is a real blessing, and the dark cloud of pollu tion in the mountain air is a little enough price to pay.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Books of The Times
description: I know. Black Panther books seem as common as dandelions now, and the whole subject has become a little tiresome. Besides, Huey Newton Is out of prison and living in a penthouse; the party has organized itself into Eastern and Western confer ences, and no champion seems likely to emerge; the rhetoric is growing screechier, and Leonard Bern stein has switched to Berrigans. So why bother even to read Gilbert Moore's unspecial ly titled A Spe cial Rage, let alone to review it? Well, several things drew me into this book. To begin with, it promised an eye witness account of the murder trial of the Black Panther Minister of De fense, Huey P. New ton, and while we have heard much about the symbolism of the trial and the extremes it polarized (Hang Huey! Free Huey! as Mr. Moore puts it) actual details of the proceedings have not been so readily available. Next, a sampling of the book's pages revealed an absolute minimum of the familiar lockstep rhetoric that Pantherism breeds. And finally, there was the author himself.

title: NIXON AIDE VOICES HOPE ON WELFARE
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 The Nixon Administration ex pects Congress to approve wel fare reform legislation on the ground that the new program is less objectionable than the present system.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Protest at London Consulate
description: LONDON, May 13The Foreign Office has apologized to the Soviet Union for an inci dent at the Soviet consulate today, where a group of about 50 young British Jews staged a sitin to protest the Lenin grad trial. The protesters said that they had been beaten up while inside the consulate.

title: Israelis See Egyptian Cabinet Shifts as Part of Sadat's Struggle to Maintain Power
description: JERUSALEM, May 13  Is raeli officials watched nervous ly tonight what they consid ered to be a struggle by Presi dent Anwar elSadat of Egypt to maintain his personal posi tion as the late President Gamal Nasser's heir to power.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As antiwar activity boils up this spring, I think the importance given to flat statements on the morality of the war by all concerned, including the five Democratic Presidential hope fuls mentioned on your front page on April 22, is particularly interesting.

title: CONTRACT TERMS CITED BY KENNEDY
description: The National Basketball As sociation struck back at play ers of the N.B.A. and rival American Basketball Associa tion yesterday by citing possi ble contract violations in their decison to pray an allstar game in Houston May 28.

title: Democratic Policy Council. Asks Total Federalization of Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The Democratic Policy Council pro posed today the complete fed eralization of the nation's wel fare program over the next three years and urged the im mediate enactment of a family assistance program that would provide for a minimum family income averaging about $4,000 a year.

title: Black Panther Party Members Freed After Being Cleared of Charges
description: Thirteen Black Panthers, in cluding two who fled to Algeria during their trial, were ac quitted yesterday on all 12 counts of an indictment accus ing them of conspiring to bomb department stores and police stations and to murder police men.

title: Washington Notes
description: WISHINGTON, May 13  The new game in the capital is called Gman, and it con sists of guessing who will succeed J. Edgar Hoover as director of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation. The fa vorite among those playing the game, inside as well as outside the Nixon Administration is Su preme Court Jus tice Byron R. White, whose supporters in clude career men men at the F.B.I. Others men tioned seriously and with regularity are Richard Helms, the Director of Central Intel ligence, and Evelle J. Young er, Attorney General of California.

title: 4 of Harlem 5 Guilty on Arms Counts
description: Four young black men, mem bers of the socalled Harlem Five, were found guilty last night of weapons violations that grew out of indictments accusing them of conspiring to kill a cop a week.

title: Halpern Wins Club Title
description: John Halpern won the New York City Yale Club's squash racquets championship yester day by defeating the defending champion, Del Fuller, 158, 1511, 1315, 1513.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 4 editorial Slimming the City Budget of course doesn't scratch the surface. Two examples:

title: American Arts Academy Elects 117 New Fellows
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., May 13 (AP)The American Academy of Arts and Sciences elected 117 new fellows and chose 31 persons from abroad for hon orary membership at its 191st annual meeting yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: A SEPARATE REALITY. Further Conversations with Don Juan. By Carlos Castaneda, 317 pages. Simon and Schuster, $6.95.

title: Catholic Parents in Jersey Operating Protest School
description: KINNELON, N. J.  The fa miliar sound of Hail Marys are heard in the hallways of the Holy Innocents Roman Catholic School in this Mor ris County community, but there are no nuns as teachers and the students do not wear the usual parochial school uniforms.

title: Mitchell Charges Some Protest, Leaders Have Communist Relationships
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Attorney General John N. Mit chell said today that some of the leaders of last week's anti war protest had Communist oriented or related back grounds.

title: FAVORED PATELIN 2D AT AQUEDUCT
description: Well aware of her impressive 1970 credentials, a crowd of 21,174 sent George D. Widen er's Patelin off in the rain yes terday as the 7to10 favorite in the featured $15,000 contest at Aqueduct.

title: SAIGON P.O.W. BID ACCEPTED IN HANOI
description: TOKYO, Friday, May 14 Hanoi's official press agency said today that North Vietnam has agreed to accept formally a group of North Vietnamese prisoners of war held in South Vietnam.

title: A Cold Meal Menu
description: In the menu below the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Commodity Price Index Steady From Week Ago
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials remained unchanged from 108.9 last week.

title: FOX TRADES CHARGES WITH EXPRESIDENT
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation and its former president, Richard D. Zanuck, who earlier this week said he would support an insurgent) group, traded charges yester day over the circumstances sur rounding a proposed settlement of Mr. Zanuck's contract.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It has been said that an immediate withdrawal of U.S. forces from South Vietnam would result in an immediate Communist takeover of South Viet nam and years of bloody retribution.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: ERROR IS CONCEDED BY VATICAN ON NUNS
description: ROME, May 13  A Vatican official said today that a cer tain negligence in the recruit ment of girls from India for religious orders in the West had been found and would be cor rected.

title: An Aggressive Hitter
description: In an era of aggressive hit ters in baseball, during the twenties and thirties, Henry Anton Manush of Alabama was one of the most aggressive and one of the most durable, compiling a .330 average dur ing 17 seasons in both the American and National Leagues.

title: Executive Changes
description: The SCM Corporation announced yesterday that it has combined its electrical consumer products into a new consumer appliance division. The divi sion which will include SmithCorona Typewriters, ProctorSilex appliances and Shetland Lewyt vacuum cleaners, will be headed by George F. Burma as president. Mr. Burns was in charge of SCM's SmithCorona Marchant Division. The business equipment division will be under the direction of George S, Warner, previously executive vice presi dent of GliddenDurkee, the company's largest division. The new consumer appliances divisioh will have sales of over $165million a year.

title: MARINES IN ASHAU REPORT 2 ATTACKS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 13  North Vietnamese forces reportedly made two strong assaults yesterday against South Vietnamese ma rines near the enemy's longtime operating base in the Ashau Valley.

title: Sadat Gain Seen in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Middle East specialists here interpreted the resignation of six members of the Egyptian Cabi net today as a sign of the in creasing political strength of President Sadat.

title: Wadmond Is Reelected By Metropolitan Opera
description: The Metropolitan Opera board of directors reelected Lowell Wadmond as chair man and George S. Moore as president at its annual meet ing yesterday in the opera house.

title: 3 ASSAIL A PLAN ON SCHOOL OFFICE
description: The Board of Education was charged yesterday with wast ing city funds in requesting $1.3million 15year lease for a Queens district school superin tendent's office.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Announcement Is Expected On Rail Links to Airports
description: Governor Rockefeller of New York arid Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey are ex pected to announce Sunday the details of legislation that would require the Port of New York Authority to build rail links between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Kennedy In ternational Airport, and be tween Pennsylvania Station in Newark and Newark Airport.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Mike Mansfield, the majority leader in the Senate, is a cool and sensible man, so when he tries to cut the American military forces in Europe in two it is obvious that something is seriously wrong.

title: Soviet Aid Reported
description: NEW DELHI, May 13 (UPI) The Soviet Union has promised aid to India to help care for refugees from the civil war in East Pakistan, the Indian press reported today.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: 2 Fathers of Photojournalism Recall Their Progeny
description: ROCHESTER, May 13 Two of the fathers of photo journalism, Felix Man and Stefan Lorant, have come together on American soil to pour the wine of triumphant recollection. The men thrust news photography into its modern format in Europe 40 years ago.

title: Music: An Impressive Verdi Requiem
description: The Pittsburgh Symphony's final Carnegie Hall concert of the season left a deep im pression, as any satisfactory performance of the Verdi Re quiem must.

title: ENGINEERS AGREE ON RAIL CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The nation's railroads reached a, contract settlement today with the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, including agreement on the crucial and vexing issue of work rules.

title: W.H.O. Bars East Germany
description: GENEVA, May 13East Ger many was denied admission to the World Health Organization today for the second consecu tive year by the United Nations specialized agency's member states. The vote to defer its ap plication was 62 to 34, with 19 abstentions.

title: WESTMORE WILCOX, RETIRED BANKER, 76
description: Westmore Willcox, a retired banker and financial consult ant, who led American eco nomic missions to other coun tries during and after World War II, died Wednesday at his home, 45 Sutton Place South, after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: 6% Drop in Profits Reported by A.&P.
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company showed a 6 per cent decline in its annual earn ings, on a 1.6 per cent dip in sales. This reflected the sharp drop in fourthquarter earnings and sales, the only quarterly de cline of fiscal 1970, according to results announced yesterday.

title: School Strike Documentary
description: We shudder to think how a foreigner might appraise American urban life, let alone our school systems, while watching "Ira, You'll Get Into Trouble."This is a feature-length documentary scanning the sound, fury and utter bedlam of the New York teachers' strike in 1968, pinpointing the Ocean Hill-Brownsville eruptions. Made by young Stephen Sbarge, the film opened yesterday at the Film Forum. It will play for two week-ends, Thursday through Sunday nights.Using a fast-flying, candid-camera format, Mr. Sbarge catches angry faces and angrier comments from many splintered factions involved. He clearly favors a faction of student union activists who dominate the movie.But the general din, the babbling and the violence, while recorded on film, add up only to a confusing cacophony comparable to the Tower of Babel shutdown. What price Little Red Schoolhouse?

title: IOWA BRASS QUINTET PLAYS 3 NEW WORKS
description: The Iowa Brass Quintet, with a little bit of electronic help, were the performers for the third event in the Second An nual May Festival at the New School of the Composers Thea ter/Choreographers Theater.

title: Obote Is Still a Problem for Uganda's New President
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 2 When Milton Obote was presi dent of Uganda, he erected a heavy bronze portrait medal lion of himself as large as poker table over the entrance of Parliament.

title: A Republican Insurgency
description: A political party is a conglomerate of many views, cohered by traditional loyalties and fundamental unifying agreements among otherwise disparate groups. While constant compromise on detailed programs is required in any party, the survival of that party in power depends on its relevance and effectiveness in dealing with the funda mental problems of society. Today in the United States those fundamental issues minimally include the war, the economy, the environment, the cities and the civil liberties of our people. On present course, the Nixon Adminis tration appears headed for the shoals on all these issues. Ironically, there is nothing particularly Republican about President Nixon's approach to today's critical national problems.

title: Agreement on Stand on Mideast Is Indicated by Common Market
description: PARIS, May 13The six Western European Common Market countries, in their first effort to align foreign policies, indicated tonight that they had agreed on proposals for a solu tion of the Middle East prob lem.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: It Requires a World Agency To Define the Sizes of Pigs
description: GENEVA, May 13The Inter national Organization for Stand ardization has the answer for anyone who cannot tell one young pig from another: a set of scales.

title: PARIS PEACE TALKS INTO FOURTH YEAR
description: PARIS, May 13The Viet nam peace conference began its fourth year today with each side blaming the other for the failure to stop the killing.

title: TEMPERAMENTS'SEEN ON DANCE PROGRAM
description: The classic and the expres sionistic are rarely so happily joined in ballet as in George Balanchine's Four Tempera ments. It is a piece that per mits a range of individual idio syncratic interpretations within a strong but elastic and formal framework.

title: 3 Negroes Nominated as Army Generals
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 The Army named three Negro colonels for promotion to the rank of brigadier general today. The nominations were among SO promotions to onestar rank that have been approved by President Nixon and now go to the Senate for confirmation.

title: Kahane and Colombo Join Forces to Fight Reported U.S. Harassment
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., a reputed underworld figure who founded the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, and Rabbi Meir Kahane, militant leader of the Jewish Defense League, joined forces yesterday to fight what they called harassment by the Federal Government.

title: Woman Will Be Next President Of American Baptist Convention
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 The next president of the 1.5 million member American Bap tist Convention will be a woman.

title: $2.25 Wage Bill Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, proposed to day that the minimum wage be raised from $1.60 to $2.25 an hour. Mr. Williams, Democrat of New Jersey, said he would introduce a bill to raise the minimum to $2.25 within a year after enactment for many work ers and within two years for the remainder.

title: Felsenstein Takes Opera Expertise to Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., May 13East Berlin is a world apart from east Long Island, but Walter Felsenstein, an opera impresario who is used to having a foot in two worlds, easily made the tran sition this week when he brought the expertise of the Komische Oper to the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York.

title: MAINE SUGAR FREED IN BANKRUPTCY SUIT
description: Judge Edward T. Gignoux of the United States District Court of Maine has dismissed all bankruptcy proceedings against Maine Sugar Industries, Inc., Fred H. Vahlsing Jr., president of Maine Sugar, announced yes terday.

title: Godman's 300 Marks Triumph in Bowling
description: DETROIT, May 13 (UPI) Jim Godman handed the pre viously unbeaten Don John son two consecutive match game defeats last night to win the American Bowling Congress masters tourna ment. The victory was worth $5,560. Johnson won $3,950.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar  This extraordinary country whose combined NegroMalay ancestry makes its in habitants the only genuine AfroAsians of the third world, has special fea tures no other land can claim.

title: State Senate Votes to End Railroad FullCrew Law
description: ALBANY, May 13  After a lively debate, the Senate vot ed 29 to 23 today to repeal the socalled fullcrew law under which railroads are required to employ a fireman or helper, in addition to an engineer, on die sel engines they operate in this state.

title: BOEING HEAD SEES HALFBILLION RISE IN OUTLAY FOR SST
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The board chairman of the Boeing Company, William M. Allen, said today that revival of the supersonic transport program would require at least half billion dollars more in Govern ment financing that was needed before the project was canceled.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As an attorney, I was disturbed by a letter (May 5) from a group of Temple University faculty members charging that the impending trial of Angela Davis was a continuation of her persecution for her political ac tivities and associations and that the charges against her were necessarily baseless.

title: Toting Up DollarsandCents Cost of Sex Discrimination
description: Business and industry were warned yesterday of the cost of continued sex discrimina tion at the opening sessions of a twoday national con ference on equal pay and pro motion for women. And wo men were told that they were not applying enough pressure.

title: MARKET OFF A BIT AS VOLUME RISES
description: Aggressive trading in con sumeroriented healthcare is sues caused sharp fluctuations in these stocks yesterday as the general market took a slight dip.

title: Duryea Sees Democratic Chiefs To Work Out City Tax Package
description: ALBANY, May 13Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea met with Democratic legislative lead ers here today and told them he would like to work with the City Council on May or Lindsay's proposed $9.1bil lion budget.

title: Riflemen in AboutFace At C.C.N.Y. Sports Fete
description: About a dozen members of the rifle team walked out of the awards ceremonies when the president of City College, Dr. Robert E. Marshak, was introduced last night at the school's annual AllSports Nite dinner at Finley Student Center.

title: An Opening to Gateway
description: President Nixon's endorsement of the proposed Gate way National Recreation Area enhances the prospect that the national park system will be brought at last to urban America, where most of the country's popula tion is to be found. Differences over detail are not unimportant, but they are far less consequential than the support of top Federal, state and city officials for the overall plan.

title: Slow Pace Toward Equality
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission has accu rately identified economic rather than narrowly racial differences as the most serious obstacle to integration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The budget crises faced by state and local governments persist. In some areas, important services have been cut back and civil servants dismissed. New revenues are eagerly sought after.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)  Sears Roebuck &,Co. has recalled its Evening Shad ow dinnerware because of hazardous lead contamination, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Miss Dickerson Becomes Bride Of Bank Aide
description: Miss Madeleine Stiles Dickerson and Simon Conran Hamilton Watson were mar ried here yesterday after noon in St. James's Episco pal Church by the Rev. Ralph R. Warren. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: The Lockheed Loan
description: The Administration has asked Congress to authorize a $250million loan guarantee to save the Lockheed Air craft Corporation and its L1011 (Tristar) airbus program. The bill that was sent to Congress yesterday does not mention Lockheed directly but only proposes loans for major business enterprises in danger of failing. Secretary of the Treasury Connally stated, however, in a separate letter to Congress that substantially all of the $250 million would go to Lockheed.

title: Six Quit Egyptian Cabinet In a Major Political Shift
description: CAIRO, May 13Egypt un derwent a sweeping political change tonight, with resigna tions by half a dozen members of the Cabinet, including the Minister, of War, Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Fawzi, and the Minister of Interior, Sharawy Gomaa.

title: Market Place:
description: Now that The Washington Post Company is about to march to market with a bun dle of 1,300,000 of its shares, we all have an opportunity to see how rising costs have led another major institution to seek public money to fi nance growth.

title: CABBIE SURRENDERS IN SHOOTING OF FOUR
description: A cab driver who allegedly wounded three policemen and another man with a shotgun Wednesday in downtown Brooklyn surrendered volun tarily yesterday at the Brook lyn District Attorney's office.

title: Two American Professors Reach Peking From Hanoi
description: TOKYO, May 13 (AP)Two American university professors arrived in Peking by train to day after a visit to North Viet nam, a Peking broadcast said.

title: Rail Traffic Is Off
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 Freight traffic on United Stales railroads in the week ended May 8 was below the corres ponding week last year. The Association of American Rail roads reported freight traffic in the week totaled an estimated 15.2 billion tonmiles.

title: CAR SALES UP 24% IN MAY HO PERIOD
description: DETROIT, May 13Newcar sales in the first 10 days of May climbed to 217,619 United States models, up 24 per cent from 176,203 units in the year earlierperiod.

title: Bunker Encouraged by Move
