description: Mrs. Nancy Hershkovitz who had pleaded guilty to falsifying a passport application, failed to appear in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday for sentencing and was declared a fugitive from justice. She is a member of the Jewish Defense League.

title: Reputed Crime Figure Arrested In L.I. Home on Heroin Charge
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 14Paul Sciacca, the reputed former head of one of the five Mafia families in the New York metropolitan area, was arrested today on charges of conspiring to sell and selling heroin.

title: Mohammed Sadek
description: New War Minister and military commander in chief... was promoted Thursday from lieutenant general to full general... has been chief of staff since September, 1969 a 48yearold career officer with mild disposition but firm military demeanor regarded as an efficient soldier with little political ambition, but could help President Anwar elSadat solidify his political position by unifying armed forces behind him... first saw combat with British against Germans in the Western Desert in World War IL.. Fought the Israelis in 1948, 1956 and 1967... after 1956 conflict, commanded Egyptian forces in the Sinai for a year, then studied military intelligence in Moscow... later served two years as military attach in Bonn... after 1.967 conflict, he was named a major general and chief of military intelligence... three years later became lieutenant general and chief of staff served occasionally as a trouble shooter in interArab disputes for President Nasser and was Arab League's Assistant Secretary General for Military Affairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Listening to President Nixon at his most recent press conference in the White House, one can not help but feel that our Government is very much troubled by the issue of how to relate to the Chinese Communist Government without hurting the position of the Chinese Nationalist Government in the United Nations.

title: Comment From Algiers
description: PARIS, May 14  Mr. Tab commenting in Algiers on t?? the acquittal of the 13 membe of the Black Panther party ?? New York said, I am ove joyed that the brothers are fre I always said that the case wa an attempted railroad and the defendants rights were beinflagrantly violated. I knew justice was to be done the verdict would be not guilty, so am not surprised.

title: VIKOA HOLDS PROFIT IN PERIOD UNLIKELY
description: Vikoa, Inc., which lost $8million last year, will probably not show a profit in the second quarter of 1971, Theodore Baum, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting here.

title: Connecticut Banks Merging
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 14 (UPI)The City Trust Company of Bridgeport and the Waterbury National Bank will consolidate to form the City National Bank of Connecticut, it was announced yesterday. City Trust and Waterbury, National issued a joint statement announcing that the Controller of the Currency had approved the consolidation, effective May 12.

title: DAYAN SEES NO GAIN FROM CRISIS IN CAIRO
description: TEL AVIV, May 14Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned Israelis tonight against expecting any positive change in ArabIsraeli relations as a result of the present power struggle in Egypt.

title: MOHAWK PILOTS GET RAISES IN NEW PACT
description: Mohawk ?? jet pilots will receive pay increases averaging 11.8 per cent a year over a 37month period under a contract settlement between Mohawk and the Air Line Pilots Association announced yesterday.

title: F.T.C. Aide Backs Correcting of Ads
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 14The Federal Trade Commission's proposed penalty of corrective advertising could well kill off certain products, a commission official told some of the nation's leading advertising agency executives here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mahmoud Riad
description: Foreign Minister of Egypt since March, 1964... longtime friend of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser... one of the group of young officers who seized power in the revolution of 1952... of medium height, solidly built, an immaculate dresser... born Jan. 8, 1917, in Cairo, educated at the Egyptian military academy and the general staff college... served in the 1948 war with Israel and entered diplomacy as a military aide in the 1949 armistice negotiations with Israel on the island of Rhodes after the revolution of 1952 became director of Palestine Department of the Foreign Ministry... named Ambassador to Syria in 1955, foreign affairs adviser to President Nasser in 1958 and representative to the United Nations in 1962... delivered his nation's annual policy speech at the start of each United Nations General Assembly session... lives on Zamalek, an island in the Nile in Cairo, with wife Sawsan, and three sons.

title: Socialists Offices Fired On
description: HOUSTON, May 14 (Reuters)  The headquarters, of the Houston Socialist Workers party was raked by gunfire early today. Twentytwo bullets were fired through the windows of the deserted building. Damage was described as slight. The party is running candidates for mayor and other city offices in forthcoming elections.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Here is a strange story, especially if it is true. A man into into a Florida jaiala fronton and booed too loudly according to the owner, who wouldn't let him in next time. The man appealed to the Florida State Racing Commission, which told him he had 'every legal right to attend any sporting event licensed by the state and that he could even boo if he desired. Thus armed, he went back to the fronton, and got thrown out again. In the ensuing publicity, the fan has written, he lost his job as a salesman for a popular soft drink: he states that the fronton is one of that soda's biggest customers.

title: An Englishman's New York
description: LONDONI saw New York for the first time ten years ago. It was so immeasurably rich in the diversity of its humankind that I cut my sleeping time to a minimum. I walked, I rode in subways, buses and cabs, marvelling at it all, making sorties into the ethnic reaches of Yorkville, Harlem, the West Side and the Lower East Side like an inspired maniac. I plunged into the swirling pools of 42nd Street and Coney Island, remembering Warner Brothers and the Ashcan School.

title: RIESSEN AND ASHE SCORE IN SINGLES
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 14 (AP) Marty Riessen and Arthur Ashe eliminated the Australian stars, Rod Laver and Roy Emerson, respectively, in the men's singles quarterfinals of the $50,000 Aryamehr tennis tournament today.

title: I.O.S. ACCOUNTANTS DECLINE REELECTION
description: Arthur Andersen & Co., certified public accountants, will not stand for reelection as auditors for Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., it was disclosed in Geneva yesterday.

title: Court Blocks Publishers In Fight on Postal Rises
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Federal Court of Appeals here denied today an appeal by magazine and newspaper publishers and other major mailers who are attempting to block postage rate increases scheduled to go into effect Sunday.

title: Luau BOYSENDRA SINGS POULENC WORK
description: To sing a complete program of Poulenc, as Lucile BoySendra, mezzosoprano, did Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, calls for a special kind of artistry; sheer vocalism is not enough.

title: Brand,Pianist,Plays A Beethoven Sonata And Several Etudes
description: If everything Nathan Brand played in his Alice Tully Hall piano recital on Thursday night had been as good as the first movement of his opening sonata, Beethoven's No. 24 in sharp (Op. 78), his would have been an unadulterated triumph.

title: PEROT COMPLETES F. I. DUPONT DEAL
description: The takeover and refinancing of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co. by H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire, and a group of his associates was completed yesterday after months of negotiations.

title: Jury May Get Seale Case on Wednesday
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14If Judge Harold M. Mulvey can maintain what he described today es a rather tight schedule of summation and charges, the Jurors in the SealeHuggins murder trial will get the case next Wednesday afternoon.

title: Guggenheim Acquires 250 Works of Modern Art
description: The outofcourt settlement of two law suits has brought the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum nearly 250 works of art owned by the late Hilla Rebay, a painter, collector and director of the museum during its formative years.

title: KORCHNOI ADVANCES IN CHESS TOURNEY
description: The Soviet Grand Master, Viktor Kerchnoi, defeated a countryman, Yefim Geller, in Moscow on Thursday in the first game of their challengers quarterfinal for the world chess championship. Geller exceeded the time limit on the 36th move and Korchnoi was declared the victor.

title: Fight Over Mansfield Plan Viewed as One Battle in a Wider War
description: WASHINGTON, May 14With some new ammunition from the Russians and some massive help from old Democrats, President Nixon appeared today to be subduing the Senate rebels who want to cut the American Army in Europe by half this year. In fact, the President flew to Florida this afternoon believing the battle of the moment wonfor the moment.

title: North Korea Spy Boat Sunk
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 14 South Korean jet planes and ships sank a North Korean spy craft early today, the military announced. All the crewmen, believed to number 15 or so, were believed drowned.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Matthew A. Crenson (OpEd April 20) states that in some ways city air is probably cleaner today than was thirty, forty or fifty years ago, implying that concern over pollution may be overdrawn.

title: Settlements in Detroit
description: DETROIT, May 14  Detroit's newspaper publishers and unions have agreed on new contracts without a strike.

title: Dr. Carlisle Storm Boyd, A Retired Pediatrician
description: Dr. Carlisle Storm Boyd, retired pediatrician and internist, died yesterday in Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 90 years old and made his home at the Presbyterian Residence, Syosset, L. I.

title: $1M1LLION HANDLE FORECAST ON RACE
description: Can they take a hundreddollar check? an outofbreath gambler asked a policeman yesterday at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Antiques: Tapestries
description: Don't raise your hopes for getting a windfall on tapestries you inherited just because a set of Gobelins went for $190,000 at the Norton Simon sale last Saturday at ParkeBernet.

title: CHARGES DROPPED FOR JOHN J, KENNY
description: NEWARK, May 14The Government today dropped extortion conspiracy charges against John J. Kenny, the former Hudson County Democratic chairman, as he agreed to be a prosecution witness against l 1 other officials accused of extorting bribes.

title: U.S. URGES BUSING IN AUSTIN SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Nixon Administration recommended today extensive ing as part of a plan to desegregate public schools in Austin, Tex.

title: DeLury Files Suit As Inquiry by City Seeks Photos of 19
description: The City Department of Investigation is investigating some city sanitationmen, it was learned yesterday.

title: Administration Is Asked to Give Heart Research Equal Status With Planned Cancer Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The American Heart Association has formally asked the Nixon Administration to give heart research preferred status akin to that proposed for cancer. Included in the request is a plea for an extra $50million for heart programs during the next fiscal year.

title: Mine Kills 5 G.I.'s
description: SAIGON, May 15 (Reuters)Five American soldiers were killed when their personnel carrier hit a land mine 20 miles from Danang in Quangnam Province yesterday, the United States command reported today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 15 (Reuters)  Jordan today accused Palestinian commandos of blowing up a section of the rail line linking Amman with Damascus last night.

title: Choreoconcerts Dance Troupe Concludes Spring Season Here
description: The group concert, like democratic form of government, is not perfect. Yet both have an operative viability to commend them.

title: That Queen Of Secrecy
description: KEATS called it that Queen of Secrecy, the violet. Others say it is shy and retiring. Yet in InKl wood Hill Park, the New York Botanical Garden, Fort Tryon Park and many other parks in the city, this delicate herb flowers so exuberantly that no passerby not completely immersed in workaday worries can miss seeing its rich, violetblue blooms.

title: The Ultimate Crime
description: Exploitation and mistreatment of children are odious practices in poor and underdeveloped countries; in an affluent society they are inexcusable. Yet America today is guilty of crimes against children committed not as occasional aberrations but, often, as publicly condoned practice. The guilt is compounded by the fact that the abuse exists alongside much overindulgence.

title: For Young Readers; The Praying Mantis; Insect Cannibal. By Lilo Hess. Photographs. 48 pp. Charles Scribner's Sons. $4,95. (Ages 7 to 11)
description: The life history and carnivorous habits of this grisly and irresistible insect, together with tips on its care as a pet: how to feed it hamburger

title: Massenet'sCendrillon Is Revived
description: Massenet's Cendrillon has one claim to fame. A Chicago production of the opera in the early part of this century cast two notable and competitive sopranos, Maggie Teyte and Mary Garden, in the roles of Cendrillon (Cinderella) and Prince Charming. That would have been a performance to see.

title: Books: F.T.C.
description: In this age of the embattled consumer the story of the Federal Trade Commission is especially pertinent and controversial. As the author points out, Consumer protection was not one of the agency's original jobs. In recent years the complaint has been that the F.T.C. has not been as active or effective as it should be in its role as watchdog of fair play in the American market place.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The clash of the dollar and the West German mark in world money markets produced some tense moments for many corporate financial officers. For others, however, there were just quiet smiles of satisfaction.

title: Atlantic Beach Strives to Preserve Its 40YearOld Proprieties
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., May 15The streets are quiet now. The traffic is light and the few stores are doing a leisurely business. There are a few Spanishstyle houses with Moorish domes that are a reminder of days past. And there are also new ranch houses and splitlevels.

title: Ch. De Go Hubert, a West Highland White, Judged Best at Springfield K.C.
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 15The form ran true on the race track infield of the Eastern States Exposition Grounds today as the finalist with the top credentials was named best in a record entry of 1,479 dogs at the 44th fixture of the Springfield Kennel Club.

title: Bayard Cutting Arboretum Is Victim of a Wave of Vandalism
description: OAKDALE, L. I., May 15Broken fences, splintered park benches, smashed swans eggs, chipped tiles and trodden plantings bear testimony to the growing vandalization of the nationally known Bayard Cutting Arboretum here.

title: St. Joseph's Wins Crown In Middle Atlantic Baseball
Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Robert Montgomery's interview is strangely illogical. In it, he says, You see, last spring [Brustein] turned down [Subject to Fits] for the Yale Rep after he saw it in workshop. For him, it plain didn't make sense... He felt the same way about Stavrogin's Creatures which he asked me to do as a spinoff from Dostoevski's The Possessed.

title: Michigan Wins in Tennis
description: EVANSTON, Ill., May 15 (UPI) Michigan won five final events and compiled 123 points today to win their fourth consecutive Big Ten tennis title. The Wolverines Joel Ross, who was unseeded when the tournament began, won the No. 1 singles competition, defeating Bill Meyers of Northwestern in the final, 76, 46, 60.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: EVIDENCE that the economy is continuing its recoverybut certainly not at a booming ratewas contained in various statistics flowing out of Washington recently. The data that confirmed that assessment were the slight rise in April unemployment and the latest reports on personal income and industrial production which depicted an economy that was still rising, though hardly at a hectic pace.

title: QUEENS POTHOLES KINGSIZED ONES
description: Queens is pothole country. It has more streets laid out than the other boroughs in the city. And those streets, many of them in marginal condition, usually manage to produce a bumper crop of potholes each year, to the detriment of automobile tires, axles and driver equanimity.

title: Mary McCarthy again her own heroinefrozen foods a new villain
description: First it was Trotskyite periodicals, and psychoanalysis, and cocktail parties; next, progressive education and McCarthyism; then diaphragms, casseroles, Venetian blinds and enlightened pediatrics; now it is conservation, the Generation Gap and Vietnam: Mary McCarthy's tireless notation of the American Scene continues. Her new novel, Birds of America, provokes a peculiar double effect: here, we exclaim, is something we can point to in the year 2000 and find, embalmed in it, the very air of 1970; and yet this light and bright topicality of Miss McCarthy's, to judge by the fate of her earlier novels, has, like other radiant things, a very short halflife, and, fictionally speaking, turns rapidly to lead, its occasion once past.

title: Move to Cut U. S. Force Worries NATO
description: BAGNOLI, Italy, May 15Senior United States military and Government figures expressed extreme concern today over the effect on the allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of any Senate move strength in Europe.

title: The Toughest Cop In America Campaigns for Mayor of Philadelphia
Ohio Newspapers Sold
description: WELLSTON, Ohio, May 15 (AP)B. B. Mills, president of Southeastern Ohio Newspapers, Inc., has announced the sale of his controlling interest in the company to Wedell D. Harbert of Hyanis, Mass. The company operates The Sentinel, a daily serving Wellston and Jackson, and The Democrat Inquirer in McArthur, a weekly. Mr. Harbert is business manager of the Cape Cod Standard Times in Hyannis.

title: Mary L. Lang Plans Nuptials
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., May 15 The engagement of Miss Mary Lucille Lang to Rex Lynford Lardner Jr. has been announced by Mrs. Benjamin R. Lang of Burlington and Dennis, Mass., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rex Lardner of Great Neck, LT., and a grandnephew of the late Ring Lardner, the humorist.

title: What Garden Centers Can Do
description: TREES shrubs, flowers, house plants  all lend beauty to our daily lives whether we live in the city, suburb or country. Who has not been pleased to see small window boxes brimming with colorful flowers outside city apartment? Those few precious blossoms mean as much to their owner as the large country estate means to the wealthy executive.

title: Japanese Visit Pittsburgh To See Pollution Facilities
description: PITTSBURGH, May 15 (UPI) A Japanese official has said that air conditions in this steelproducing city are much better than in Tokyo.

title: Weight Lifter Sets Record
description: BUDAPEST, May 15 (AP)Janos Mathen of Hungary set a world weightlifting record today in the lightweight class when he pressed 324 pounds.

title: Some Nassau Boaters Give Police Gray Hairs
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., May 15 While thousands of Long Island boat owners prepare enthusiastically for the start of the yachting season, the marine bureau of the Nassau County Police Department awaits it with some trepidation.

title: Historic Church on Hudson Long Empty, Being Rebuilt
description: COLD SPRING, N. Y., May 14The first Roman Catholic Church built in the Hudson Valley north of Manhattan is being restored by a nondenominational group after sitting empty for 60 years.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: In some parts of this business, I get the feeling that there is something like a Creative Recession going on.

title: European Discus Mark Set
description: MALMO, Sweden,. May 15 (AP)  A Swedish discus thrower, Ricky Bruch, set European record today with throw of 224 feet 1 inches, three inches shorter than Jay SiIvester's world record.

title: CONGRESS STUDIES CAMPAIGN DEBTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Congress is investigating the possibility that big corporations are illegally subsidizing political candidates by settling long overdue campaign bills at less than full value.

title: Vatican Cites New Kind of Rights
description: ROME, May 15  A document that the Vatican is sending to Roman Catholic bishops conferences throughout the world says that technological progress and population growth are giving rise to a new kind of human rights.

title: AntiHeroine
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Battle Protesters In Berkeley and Arrest 41
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 15The police fought a series of skirmishes this afternoon with demonstrators commemorating the second anniversary of the destruction of People's Park here.

title: Agnew Says Fulbright Lies About Remarks on Patriotism
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)  Vice President Agnew said today that Senator J. W. Fulbright lies in his teeth in saying Mr. Agnew had questioned the patriotism of dovish Senators.

title: Lawyer Is Fiance of Lillian Isseks
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., May 15The engagement of Miss Lillian Sue Isseks to Charles A. Judelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Judelson, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Judge and Mrs. Abraham Isseks. Both families live here.

title: A salvation and a battlefield
description: Unlike fine wines but like so many other American institutions, baseball has failed to improve with age. Push has come to shove. The major league baseball hierarchy (team owners and a Commissioner appointed by the owners) has consistently neglected to improve the lot of its principals, the players, until coerced. A player's union, guaranteed minimum salaries, proper grievance procedures and integrated spring training facilities were all achieved in the face of concerted efforts by the hierarchy to stand pat.

title: L.I. Youth Orchestra to Play Europe
description: MINEOLA, L. I., May 15One evening in 1962, a young clarinet student looked up during one of his !lessons and complained to his teacher about having no place to perform classical music. The student asked his instructor, Why don't you start an orchestra?

title: How to Get Kicked Out of Prague;VIENNA.
Pending City Pact With Con Ed Scored by Abrams as Wasteful
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged yesterday that a pending city agreement with the Consolidated Edison Company would barter away a potential $20million annual saving on electricity costs for the city government in exchange for a pitiful annual payment of $500,000.

title: For Some Landlords, a Life Style That's Far From the Tenants World
description: Wealthy landlords, as you might expect, rarely have landlords.

title: Mrs. Sheldon Has Son
description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 15 A son was born April 30 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sheldon in Stamford Hospital. Mrs. Sheldon is the former Barbara Polokoff of Paterson, N. J. The child, whose father is vice president of the Sheldon Precision Company of Prospect, has been named Jeffrey Brian.

title: Plover was angry and didn't know it
description: Plover plays radio in San Francisco. M.C. for a dialin talk show, he's quick and glib with opinions, but heavy, brooding and shy about his feelings. Your littlebetterthanaveragemalechauvinistpig, he is hip enough to drink Dos Equis beer, and tender enough with any woman who is not his wife. Most of his 14 years of marriage have been spent hulking over the TV at night with his bottle of Dos Equis in a San Francisco suburb, but Plover can't allow himself to imagine that Thalia wasn't having a good time. He hulks at the center of Don Carpenter's fourth book, somewhat disoriented and befuddled and angry for having been kicked out of the house, at last, by that somewhat drab female. In the midst of his own subdued melodrama he doesn't know how he could be.

title: Money Machine
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The staff of the Federal Reserve Board has strongly criticized a new mathematical model of the economy that... tended to support the Administration's optimistic forecast for the economy this year. The model was developed by Arthur B. Laffer, young economist working for George P. Schultz, director of the Office of Management and the Budget.

title: Encouraging Exports
description: Finally, we are taking exports seriously.

title: LETTERS
description: To The Financial Editor: An article (May 9) entitled Computer Scare Talk by Mel Mandell underplays the problems that many companies face in the protection of vital information.

title: Eric Kronen Weds Miss Lynn Bryan
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., May 15 Miss Lynn Bryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Bryan, was married here this afternoon to Eric S. Kronen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leif C. Kronen of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Miss Dreyer Wed To Carl Doerge Jr.
description: Miss Meredith A. Dreyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Francis Dreyer of Baltimore, was married here yesterday afternoon to Carl H. Doerge Jr., second vice president of Smith Barney, the investment banking firm. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Doerge of Shaker Heights, Ohio. His father is vice president of the brokerage firm of Hayden Miller in Cleveland.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE NIXON ADMINISTRATION sent to Congress bill that would authorize a $250million loan guarantee save Lockheed Aircraft and its financially pinched Tristar jumbo jet program. The bill did not mention Lockheed directly. Earlier General Electric had urged the Administration not to grant the loan guarantee unless Lockheed used Americanmade engines in the Tristar.

title: A Dim View of Con Ed
description: Can men who had sucessful careers in Government use that experience in running a major utility?

title: Wanted: SpaceAge Steam Engine
description: Since the California State Assembly decided to investigate steam power as an alternative to the internal combustion engine automobile back in 1968, many steamers have been built and tested, but none is any closer to production today than three years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With regard to your May 6 news story on the wonlost record of international wars, I am curious to know when offtrack betting will start?E. PHEN JOHNSTONToronto, May 7, 1971

title: James A. Rubin, Eileen McCarty Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. McCarty of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Marie McCarty, to James Anthony Rubin, son of Mrs. Robert H. Rubin, also of New York, and the late Mr. Rubin. The couple plan a Nov. 6 wedding.

title: Spain Advances in Cup
description: LONDON, May 15 (AP)Yugoslavia, Spain, France and Hungary advanced today to the semifinals of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition while the Soviet Union took a 21 lead over Belgium and West Germany went ahead of Austria, 21.

title: From Roz To Bela Lugosi
description: Dear Stanley: You picked a perfect time to take your cure. The season has come to a wobbly, witless halt, what with Rosalind Russell playing a middleaged CIA agent somehow loose over Albania like an outofcontrol U2. The movie is called Mrs. PollifaxSpy and it opened here after Miss Russell herself made one of those graciousmajestic personal appearances on the David Frost Show, to talk about her career, but mostly to plug the picture, which, she was happy to point out, is clean. I guess it Is. It's also a wistful reminder of the good old nineteenfifties, when the entire world was ours to highfly over as we saw fit.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THEM that has gitseven in recessions. For example, there's Joseph Hardy. Work looks for him. He's just barely back from London, where be staged Robert Marasco's Child's Play (after winning a Tony for his staging of the Broadway production), and already he's busy with preparations for a new edition of You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown, this time on Broadway, opening at the Golden on Friday. Now the word is that he'll soon begin thinking of his latest assignment. That Championship Season, by Jason Miller, which should be in the focal arena an the fall,

title: James Wright knows something about the pure clear word
Reader's Report
description: The potlatch at the end of the road is the Washington State Apple Blossom Festival, toward which races a hot earful of fugitives. Cleveland Timentawa, an A.W.O.L. Indian G.I. heading homeward. Colin Kelly Barnover, a killer inclined toward multiple murders. Echo Tolson, a preteener whose father was one of Colin's victims. Its violent chase notwithstanding, the intent of the novel is introspection rather than suspense.

title: Diane Gray Married
description: Miss Diane Gray, a dancer and teacher with the Martha Graham Dance Company, and James W. Viera, technical director in this country of L'Oreal of Paris Products, a cosmetics firm, were married here yesterday morning in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building. The bride, who was graduated from the JuilHard School of Music, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon D. Gray of Painesville, Ohio. Her parents own and operate a school of dance there. Mr. Viera is the son of Mrs. Joseph A. Viera of Miami, Fla.,

title: Albany Assemblymen Are Considering a Measure to Restore Civil Rights to Convicts
description: ALBANY, May 15Charles J. Starkins is civilly dead.

title: Patriots Sign Three
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)The New England Patriots announced today the signing of a linebacker, Ed Philpott; guard, Torn Beer, and a receiver, Bill Rademacher. The Patriots also said they had sold 45,000. season tickets for Schaefer Stadium in Foxboro.

title: Stamps
description: GUERNSEY, the Channel Islands Bailiwick, ?? June 2. will postally recall that Thomas De La Rua is a Guernseyman. On that date it will release fourstamp series honoring the man and the securityprinting firm that bears his nameand commemorating four historic stamp issues with which the firm was involved.

title: G.O.P. Governors Set Date
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Republican Governors Association announced this week that its next meeting would be held Nov. 1719 at French Lick, Ind.

title: Reader's Report
description: Little does Bob Davis know, when he takes a temporary job on The New York Record, that he'll be around long enough to acquire an inside view of its workings, from the sportsdepartment copy desk to the publisher's sanctum, including even the sacred precincts of the ladies room. (Quite a story there!) His sabbatical from The Fort Wayne Item lengthens into a tour that covers a couple of changings of the guard at the paper of record. (Now what could that paper be? It once owned a triangular building featuring an electric sign flashing frontpage bulletins.)

title: HARRY E. ROCKEFELLER
description: Harry E. Rockefeller formerly of Bronxville, N. Y., who retired in 1966 as general manager of the electricwelding division of Union Carbide Corporation, died Thursday at Delray Beach, Fla. His age was 70.

title: Liquori Finds Out Today If Time Waits for Some
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15Marty Liquori will learn tomorrow whether time waits for some men.

title: St. Augustine's Picks Coach
description: Saint Augustine's College in Raleigh, N.C., has appointed Harvey D. Heartley of Raleigh, as athletic director and basketball coach. Heartley has been North Carolina's State Coordinator of Youth Affairs.

title: The World
description: BRUSSELS  We survived. So said the Abbe Sieyes when asked how he had made out in the French revolutionary reign of terror. And so might international money men reply if asked the outcomeso farof the latest currency crisis.

title: Irish 1,000 Guineas Is Taken by Fauoletta
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, May 15. ReutersAn English filly, Favoletta, owned by Robert Moller, won the $37,864 Irish 1,000 Guineas, run over one mile, today.

title: John We Chaffee, Barbara Hunter Plan Marriage
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., May 15  Miss Barbara Walrath Hunter, a greatgranddaughter of President William Howard Taft, plans to be married in July to John William Chaffee, formerly a fellow student at Swarthmore College.

title: Child to the Zientses
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15 A daughter was born April 21 to Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Zients at the Methodist Hospital here. Mrs. Zients is the former Miss Eileen Bernstein of Syracuse. Her husband is a TVradio commentator for WHAS here. His father is president of Gimbels New York. The child has been named Rachel Susan.

title: A Peaceful Place With Memories
description: JALAPA, MexicoThe contrast is striking: Mount Orizaba, with its silvery cap of snow 18,851 feet high, dominating the horizon 40 miles to the southwest; tropical Jalapa, embowered in gardenias, oleander, crepe myrtle and trumpet vine, and, nearby, the Mexican War battlefield of Cerro Gordo, where American soldiers are supposed to have played ball using Gen. Santa Ana's wooden leg as a bat.

title: Brooklyn Boys Build Jet That Works
description: A group of students in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn have built their own airplane  a scaleddown version of the McDonnell Douglas F4 Phantom II jet that is used for reconnaissance and combat in Vietnam.

title: Miss Carolyn R. Nesbitt Wed To Stuart Levin of Le Pavillon
description: MENDHAM, N. J., May 15 Miss Carolyn Ralston Nesbitt was married here this afternoon to Stuart Levin, president and part owner of Le Pavillion, a New York restaurant. The Rev. Robert Phillips performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Dewey Palmer, Physicist, Dies; A Founder of Consumers Union
description: ORADELL, N. J., May 15Dewey H. Palmer, a physicist and medical engineer who was a founder of the Consumers Union, died last night of cancer at his home, 527 Mackay Avenue. His age was 72.

title: Mary Dexter Stephenson Is Fiancee of Peter David Goldberg
description: Miss Mary Dexter Stephenson and Peter David Goldberg will be married June 12 in Southampton, L.I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Only a mind conditioned by weekly body counts could produce a Middle East peace proposal as grotesque as the one by Ernest van den Haag (letter April 18)a calculation so incredible it would make an Egyptian mathematics textbook wince.

title: Use of Black English to Help Children Fit In at School Is Debated Here
description: Linguistics experts, teachers and college students yesterday discussed the issues surrounding the use of black English, and they agreed they don't be solvin the problem.

title: NORWAY DEBATES COMMON MARKET
description: OSLO, Norway, May 12 Trygve Bratteli, the Laborite Premier of Norway, is facing growing doubts within the country over the prospect of Norwegian membership in the European Economic Commuity or Common Market.

title: Et Al.
description: Clonky survey of sexual practice in America from the Puritans to Oh! Calcutta! Totally predictable, without thought to redeem it.

title: The World
description: BRUSSELSThe Brussels negotiations on enlargement of the European Economic Community take place in an otherwise empty 14story office building called the Charlemagne. It is a strange process in a strange setting.

title: Gov. Carter Heads Board
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 15 (AP)Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia was elected today as chairman of the Southern Regional Education Board, which announced a $2million grant for five mostlyblack universities In the South.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor The proposed use of $250million of public funds in aid of the shareholders of the Lockheed Corporation, if accomplished, will surely be a benchmark in grandscale welfare aid for those who have undertaken otherwise unprofitable risks of the market place.

title: Pettersson Captures Pole For Madrid Formula 2 Race
description: MADRID, May 15 (UPI)Ronnie Pettersson of Sweden posted the fastest time today in practice for Formula Two grand prix of Madrid auto race scheduled tomorrow.

title: Et Al.
description: The author and family follow the modernday equivalents of the old trails West. Well written, saturated in history, an appealing travel book.

title: Minorities Conduct a Solidarity Fete at College
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 15  The politics and art of two cultures mingled at a festival at the Farmingdale Agricultural and Technical College the other day, and when it was over the black and Puerto Rican student organizers said that they had succeeded in presenting to the administration and the rest of the student body an image of solidarity among minority groups.

title: Taboo on AntiSemitism Seen Waning
description: Norman Podhoretz, the social and literary critic, said yesterday that for the first time in a generation Jews in the United States were confronted with open antiSemitism because of a sharp weakening of a longstanding taboo against it.

title: Chicago and Nevi York: Contrasts
description: CHICAGO, May 15For 16 years, Richard J. Daley has run this city, and the marks of his tenure are everywhere: the big concrete expressways that speed commuter and commercial traffic in and out; O'Hare Airport, the world's busiest; city streets that are well swept and brilliantly lighted; the downtown building boom that is raising glistening commercial skyscrapers over the Loop's rackety el tracks; the luxury glass and steel highrise apartments marching along the lakefront.

title: William Joseph O'Neill Marries Miss Lorraine Everleigh LaVoy
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 15Miss Lorraine Everleigh LaVoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth R. LaVoy Jr. of Montclair, was married here today to William Joseph O'Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Neill of ZImont, L. I., at the Union Congregational Church.

title: Purdue Golfers Triumph
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15 (UPI)Purdue captured the 52d Big Ten golf championship today by nine shots over Michigan State. Minnesota's Dave Haberle, shooting his third par 72, took indivdual honors with a 293.

title: Koor: Giant of Israeli Industry
description: A company with annual sales of $300million may be considered small by American standards.

title: Parade Beginning at 2 To Mark Norway Day
description: Norway Day will be celebrated in Bay Ridge at 2 P.M. today with a parade in which 20 bands, 60 marching units and 25 floats are expected to take part.

title: Massachusetts House Kills 2 Bills Shielding Newsmen
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)The Massachusetts House has killed two bills designed to protect the confidential sources of newsmen.

title: POET LOSES POSTS IN SLOVAK PARTY
description: PRAGUE, May 15The Slovak Communist party concluded its threeday congress in Bratislava today by dropping Ladislav Novomeski, a poet, from his Slovak party offices and calling for tighter state control of culture.

title: CHICANOS OPPOSE NEW TEXAS BISHOP
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 15The Most Rev. John Joseph Fitzpatrick, recently appointed by Pope Paul VI as Bishop of the Brownsville Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, may meet a very cool reception when he arrives to assume his new duties May 26.

title: 2 Passers to Be Feted
description: John Brodie and George Blanda, quarterbacks, and the former head coach of the Cleveland Browns, Blanton Collier, will be among the award recipients at the fourth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Professional Football Writers of America May 24 at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Reader's Report
description: Arfur, a little girl dressed as a little boy, escapes through funhouse looking glass to popfantasy world, where she spends five years shooting pinball. If there are worse ways of spending five years, I just don't want to hear about them. I want an ending, says Arfur, as she plays a few final sets with the Pinball Phantom. A beginning too, and for good measurea middle.

title: Unstable Cambodia
description: Cambodia's first cabinet crisis since the Prince Sihanouk era has ended with a reshuffle of portfolios and no significant change in the power structure, but an underlying instability continues.

title: Radioactive Ore Waste Stirs Fears
description: DENVER, May 14Radioactive leftovers from uranium ore processing mills are emerging as a major health concern in three areas of western Colorado, raising questions of possible misuse of the radioactive wastes in the construction of buildings in seven other states.

title: Laurie J. La Fontaine Bride of Lawyer
description: SILER CITY, N. C., May 15 Miss Laurie Jean La Fontaine was married here this afternoon in St. Julia's Roman Catholic Church to Carl Burckly Schellenberg. The Rev. William Pitt performed the ecumenical ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Eliason, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Stamps
description: CANADA on June 1 will postally commemorate the inaugural of more powerful transmitters for Radio Canada International, and its 1971 census, an event conducted every 10 years. A 15cent stamp bearing the message Speaking to the World in English and French will commemorate Radio Canada. A 6c stamp will take note of the census.

title: Irish Wolfhound Gets First Top Honor
Jordan, Stressing the Jerusalem Issue, Assumes a Tougher Position Toward Any Mideast Accord
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 13At a time of intense diplomacy elsewhere over the Suez Canal, the royal Government of Jordan, more secure in power than at any time since the 1967 ArabIsraeli war, has assumed more of a hardline position in the Middle East peacemaking efforts.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Last July, Harold Warshay was trying to convince big investment institutions to buy color television stocks. The institutions were hardly enthusiastic because of the lackluster results being shown by companies in the field, but Mr. Warshay, who is in charge of institutional sales for Gruntal & Co., thought a turnaround was near. The color TV group, he argued, could appreciate 30 to 50 per cent over the next six to nine months.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWThe question that is fascinating about the trial of the nine Soviet Jews now taking place in Leningrad is not so much whether they will be found guilty; under Soviet law, that is a foregone conclusion. They will all undoubtedly be convicted of participating in a bumbling plan to hijack a plane, sending abroad documents critical of Soviet policy toward Jews, and stealing a duplicating machine to aid in the dissemination of their protests  some of the charges brought against them.

title: The World
description: DACCA, East PakistanOur vultures are the happiest creatures in Pakistan, a weary villager said last week, speaking of the series of disasters that have struck the country's eastern region.

title: But We've Lost the Faith
description: ATONE of voice is passing from our literature because it is passing from our lives. Listen ing to Archibald MacLeish's Scratch, an adaptation of the Stephen Vincent Benet short story, The Devil and Daniel Webster, we were aware that it was not only failing as a play but as an act of faith. It was written out of a confidence we do not at the moment feel, attributing to all of us as Americans virtues we are no longer certain we possess. In a sense, as we watched, we saw through two things: we saw through the play's clumsy dramaturgy, the literally fading cadences of the play's political and rhetorical style; and we saw through ourselves. How sentimental we had been, until very, very recently, about the forever incorruptible goodness of the nation!

title: For Young Readers; Metamorphosis; The Magic Change. By Alvin and Virginia Silverstein. Photographs. 74 pp. Atheneum. $5.50. (Ages 9 to 13)
description: A thoughtful presentation of this peculiar kind of growth process which has enabled seven varied species to survivebutterflies, bees, dragonflies, frogs, salamanders, starfish and eels. Beginning naturalists should find plenty to interest them in these factfilled chapters.

title: Britain Attracts More U.S. Academics
description: LONDON, May 15For a variety of reasons, ranging from side effects of the Vietnam war to the economic crunch in the United States, American university teachers are coming to Britain in greater numbers than ever.

title: A Victim Describes Blast in Queens
description: Mrs. Mabel Featherstone saw the gas explosion and the debris flying at her from across the  street. I tried to turn, she said, but I. didn't turn fast enough.

title: Disputed Gettysburg Tower Going Up
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 15Contractors began borings here this week for piers and footings for a new 300foot skyblue steel observation tower for tourists.

title: National Notes
description: It was a strange alliance: an ItalianAmerican with a reputation for underworld activities, and a rabbi who leads a group of militant Jews. But they professed a common cause: to fight what they called Federal Government harassment of their organizations.

title: Memoirs of a Bourgeois Hell's Angel In Bermuda
description: NO, you are not Barney Oldfield, nor were meant to be, but when you go to Bermuda for a few days you decide the thing to do is to try a whirl on a motorassisted bicycle. (The expression, so elegant in its pedantry, is not the least among the inducements.) After all, motorassisted bicycles are the rage of the island. The travel agent in New York has told you that there are now 15,000 of them in use there, more than 5,000 of which are for rent to tourists, of whom about 250,000 a year rent them during their Bermuda visits. All very cheap and simple, too. Rental $5 for one day, $9 for two days, $12 for three; no license required. In fact, no requirements of any kind except that you be 16 or older and capable of riding an unassisted bicycle. You still remember that time you explored Bermuda on an unassisted one 20 years ago, how you were puffing when you got to the top of the steep hills. And that was 20 years ago. No question, motor assistance is in order this time.

title: U.S. Aids 5 African Nations
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 15 (Agence FrancePresse)The United States Agency for International Development will lend $6million to develop cattle breeding in five Frenchspeaking West African nations under an agreement signed here with the Meat and Livestock Economic Community of the Ivory Coast, Niger, Upper ?? Dahomey and ??

title: For Young Readers
description: The chipmunk can climb trees and swim, has poor eyesight, eats dogwood flowers, nuts, seeds, puffballs, June bugs, earthworms, bird's eggs and young birds when available. The female admits the smaller male to her burrow only for mating. Such facts are mingled with the author's extensive and loving observations on the residents of his garden and terrace. Delightful reading for any age.

title: MODEL CITIES JOBS LOSE CANDIDATES
description: Nine candidates for positions on slumbased Model Cities committees have been ruled off the ballot by the city's special board supervising next Friday's elections.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: LETTERS
description: To The Financial Editor: Having been a student of social and business conditions in South Africa for many years and having made two trips there within recent years, may I comment on the article by George M. Houser (Point of View, April 18).

title: For Young Readers
description: Considering their adaptability, intelligence and venerable (300millionyear) history, it seems almost worthwhile to keep a few roaches around just for observation. If not, one alternative to calling the exterminator is to keep a live centipede in the pantry. Informative and lighthearted.

title: Our Driver Could Not Resist Picking Up Goats
description: CUZCO, PeruThe day was bright and cold. Inca warrior arrayed in red and gold blew conch shells to herald the crowning of their king. The scene, a curious mixture of Indian and Spanish elements, was part of the Inti Raymi ceremony, an annual festival, which has not changed much over the centuries here in the ancient capital of the Incas.

title: Et Al.
description: An old pro's unbuttoned tour of Israel. Green spent a summer poking about in the ruins, listening to Bible history lectures, visiting kibbutzim. His account is impressionistic, goodhumored and sharply observant.

title: Et Al.
description: An academic study of the balance between order and disorder in art and life by the California esthetician: inanimate being tends toward en tropy; animate life toward order; art wobbles on in between; orderliness is not order; etc. Donnish.

title: MISS M'EVOY, 18, JUMPING VICTOR
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 15Michele McEvoy, who has to stretch to reach 5 feet and weighs barely 100 pounds, all but locked up the amateurowner jumper championship today at the Children's Services horse show.

title: LEPRECHAUN GETS A FIRST AND THIRD
description: RYE, N. Y., May 15Spencer J. Leach Jr.'s and Peter T. Cooper's Leprechaun held a 31point lead over James F. Fulton's Verve today after the first two races in the annual spring regatta of the Etchells22 Class on Long Island Sound off the American Yacht Club.

title: Sandra Gail Levin Affianced to William Theodore
description: ATLANTA, May 15Miss Sandra Gail Levin will be married here June 14 to William Harold Theodore.

title: A QUIET MRS. HICKS BAFFLES CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Her. quiet, almost shy demeanor has prompted many a baffled colleague in Congress to wonder: Is this the real Louise Day Hicks, the terror of Boston politics?

title: Art
description: ABOUT 15 years ago happenedsomething in no way freakishthat helps explain how something ridiculous could have happened a couple of weeks ago in the form of an announcement from one Billy Apple; a member of New York's artistic community. Mr. Apple announced an EarthWorksConceptual event called Roof Dirt connected with the cleaning of the secondfloor rear roof at 161 West 2?d Street, which is Mr. Apple's address.

title: Brooklyn Unit Cited for Data on Blacks
description: A community group that has spent the last five years determining the historic contribution of the black community in Brooklyn was honored in Washington last week for identifying and preserving buildings of the early 19th century free black community.

title: T. J. Hamilton Jr. Weds Carol Heym
description: ORANGEBURG, N. Y., May 15Thomas J. Hamilton Jr., formerly of Greenvale, L. I., and Miss Carol Heym of Philadelphia were married here last Saturday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Troup Mathews, Mr. Hamilton's uncle. Town Justice Robert Feenick of Orangeburg officiated.

title: WHITE EDGES BLACK FOR DURHAM MAYOR
description: DURHAM, N. C., May 15 (UPI)James Hawkins, a white real estate dealer, won the nonpartisan Durham mayoral election over Asa T. Spaulding, a black insurance executive, by an unofficial margin of 1,541 votes today.

title: Thais Cite Own Moves Toward Peking
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 15 Thailand has responded to the prospect of better relations between China, her major potential foe, and the United States, her principal ally, by saying that she has been working to improve her relations with China for as long as three years and has received word that China is favorable to such improvement.

title: 7 Colonels Accused of Plot Are Ousted in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 15 (AP)The army forced seven colonels to retire last night. Sources said that the seven were implicated in a conspiracy against the sixweekold Government of President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse.

title: Maximizing the mini
description: And whatever became of the minidress? Well, obviously you can't keep a good mini down. Happily for the legwatchers, there are plenty of smart women who know that, when the thermometer hits summer, there's nothing cooler than a short, short skirt baring lots of leg. (This summer, those legs will probably be wrapped up in maxisandals.) Long live the mini!

title: 53 Negroes Given Grants In Journalism by A.N.P.A.
description: Grants totaling $22,825 have been given to 53 Negro students in 32 accredited journalism departments, the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation announced yesterday.

title: Club Rugby
description: Manhattan Club 12, Neath Athletic 3. Manhattan B Club 3, S. Francis A Club 0 Washington A Club 21, Now York Club 3.

title: Red Cross Head Renamed
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 15 (UPIPresident Nixon appointed today E. Roland Harriman to a new threeyear term as chairman of the American Red Cross, a position he has held since 1950.

title: Gardens
description: SNUGGLED high on Cape Cod bluff looking out across Vineyard Sound to Martha's Vineyard is a magnificent preRevolutionary house. Nestled around it are black pines, sassafras, junipers and two marvelous old apple trees. A huge pair of boxwood are by the front door, another pair of Japanese hollies trim the terrace door and in a corner is a cluster of fine oldfashioned New England lilacs. Down in the woods, where a sandy path leads to the beach, the dogtooth violets are just coming into bloom and fresh green fronds if ferns are everywhere.

title: South Bend and Elkhart Join Amtrak Network
description: WASHINGTON May 15 (AP)  Amtrak will begin serving South Bend and Elkhart, Ind., next Tuesday under a limited plan, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation notified Representative John Brademas yesterday.

title: Inquiry to Be Reopened In West Virginia Crash
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)The National Transportation Safety Board has ordered further inquiry into the causes of the plane crash in Huntington, W. Va., last Nov. 14 that killed 75 persons, including most of the Ma???? University football team.

title: Reader's Report
description: Hooper Dunlap, a native Californian, goes out to Waikiki in the 1950's to become a surfing bum and succeeds handsomely. With his buddy Jonas Vandermeer, another Californian, Hooper shuttles between an exotic rooming house and the sea's edgeeach man taking out time enough from his pastime to father a child. Jonas's playmate is an indefatigable beach follower named Goldie. Hooper's choice is a Polynesian dancer named Nona. Both girls eventually make happy marriages with other people, the boys being too narcissistic to take up housekeeping.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 70 YACHTS BEGIN WINGED FOOT RACE American Eagle Out to Win Trophy 3d Year in Row
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., May 15The New York Athletic Club'S 62d annual distance race for the Winged Foot Trophy, the traditional overnight opener of the cruising yacht season on Long Island Sound, began tonight.

title: S. B. A. Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON  What is good for the corner garage and the neighborhood delicatessen is good for America  or so the people at the Small Business Administration fervently assert.

title: Music
description: TO CREATE a Romantic hero, take a man, endow him with intellect, drive, talent and smoldering passions, and subject him to fires of suffering. It is not important whether the hero wins or loses, only that he feels deeply and that he wears his suffering like a crepe headband sunk into his flesh.

title: For Young Readers
description: Another wellrounded description of a familiar species. It includes the story of how scientists doggedly banded 375,000 of these baffling birds, nearest kin to the hummingbird, before discovering, in 1943, their winter habitat: the upper Amazon basin.

title: SENATORS REPORT OUTSIDE EARNINGS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, says he earned $44,331 from speeches delivered across the nation last year, more than his $42,500 Senate salary.

title: A study of mystery and detective fictionmassive and limited
description: For over forty years, since they and the century were in their twenties, the historian Jacques Barzun and his friend Wendell Hertig Taylor have been reading crime literature and comparing notes on it. Their lifelong hobby has now issued in a descriptive list of several thousand books, both fiction and fact. It includes valuable sections on studies and histories of the crime novel, true crime, the literature of Sherlock Holmes, and ghost stories and the supernatural. But the greater part of their massive volume is devoted to the most complete bibliography known to me of mystery and detective fiction since Poe.

title: Top Subcontractor Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) William C. Herrmann, president of the Optic Electronic Corporation of Dallas has been named the winner of the Small Business Administration's subcontractor of the year award. Mr. Herrmann was selected Thursday from among 200 small subcontractors. He will be honored in ceremonies here Tuesday.

title: A Short Course in Pubmanship
description: STREATLEY, Berkshire, England The curious names of British pubs originated in days when most people were largely illiterate and innkeepers painted symbols on signsThree Crowns, Red Cow, Leg of Mutton and Cauliflowerto tell the traveler where he was. Even today, if you ask or directions hereabouts, you'll likely be advised to turn right at The Seven Stars, keep straight on past The Man in the Moon, and stop opposite The Rising Sun.

title: Wendy Goldstein Plans Bridal
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., May 15Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Goldstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Goldstein, to Donald E. Weckstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Weckstein of New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 2.Miss Goldstein, an assistant producer at Grey Advertising in New York, is an alumna of the School of Speech and Dramatic Arts of Syracuse University. Her father is president of Elk Realty, Inc., New York. Her grandfather, Joseph I. Lubin, is a founding partner of Eisner & Lubin, certified public accountants and treasurer of the United Jewish Appeal and the Joint Distribution Committee.

title: Meredith Hill To Be a Bride
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., May 15  Miss Meredith Jane Hill and Joseph Henry Kwaitkowski will be married June 6 at the Anabel Taylor Chapel at Cornell University.

title: Marion Bruckner To Marry Aug. 29
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 15 Miss Marion Duke Bruckner and Raymond Stanley Baxter 3d, members of the May 31 graduating class at Bucknell University, will be married here Aug. 29.

title: Preakness Day: A Family Affair With Frisbees, Soul and Kazoos
description: BALTIMORE, May 15Under a hail of Frisbees, thousands of fans camped in the infield on Preakness Day today, breaking out buckets of fried chicken, beer and whiskey while youngsters blanket hopped on the 800,000 square feet of grass surrounded by the Pimlico Race Course running track.

title: Son to the Wassersteins
description: A son was born April 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Wasserstein in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. The child, whose father is a lawyer, has been named Jeffrey Neal.

title: Imai Scores a 68 and 205 For 3Shot Lead at Tokyo
description: TOKYO, May 15 (UPI) Masayuki Imai of Japan shot a fourunderpar 68 today and took a threestroke lead with a total of 205 in the $27,000 JaIpan Airlines international golf tournament.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: When contemplating a foreign invesment, a valid polittical analysis must be based on the bedrock assumption that there is no such entity as a safe country.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONSenator Mike Mansfield, an accommodating Irishman from Montana, can be as stubborn as he is gentle, and that probably explains as much as anything why the Administration suddenly found itself confronted last week with a political crisis on the long quiescent NATO front.

title: Homo Improvement
description: KNOWLEDGE of the techniques involved in cutting and drilling holes in glass can be useful in many ways: for cutting pieces to fit when replacing panes in windows and doors, for replacing glass tops on furniture, for cutting curved pieces when working on hobby or craft projects, for drilling holes in mirrors to simplify mounting  and for such projects as drilling holes in bottles (to make them into lamps).

title: 201 DECEIT TAKES FEATURE AT BIG A
Newcombe, Ashe Bow in Iran; Riessen, Alexander Gain Final
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15 (AP) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., defeated John Newcombe of Australia, 63, 76, today in a semifinal of the $50,000 Aryamehr tennis tournament.

title: Homeowners Face Share of Erosion Control Cost
description: ALBANY, May 15  A bill that would create hurricane protection and flood and erosion control districts in Suffolk County is being held in committee pending the formulation of an amendment that would assure that property owners benefiting from jetties and other measures bear the brunt of the local share of costs.

title: Television
description: PFC. CARMINE MACEDONIO, 21, a postman's son from Williston Park, Long Island, died when his tank hit a mine in Vietnam. Wednesday evening at 8:30 on Channel 13, Part. of the Family, an NET documentary, visits Private Macedonio's parents and eight brothers and sisters, who talk about his life  and his death. The program also includes visits with the families of two students killed (luring antiwar demonstrations at Kent State University and Jackson State University. Here are excerpts from the comments of Carmine Macedonio's parents and his younger brother Angelo.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONLastweekend, when the latest international monetary flareup was nearing its climax, John B. Connally Jr., Arthur M. Burns, Paul W. McCracken, George Shultz and Richard M. Nixon, as far as is known, got some sleep.

title: Members of House Tour Gateway Site Along With Lindsay
description: The Congressional chairman who is a key to establishing the Gateway National Recreation area that would frame the entrance to New York Harbor strolled with Mayor Lindsay yesterday across the Rockaway dunes.

title: For Young Readers
description: The moose calf spends most of its first year beside its mother. The narrative, filled with concrete details, is built around excellent photographs. For once text and pictures really work together. When it says a moose foraging in midwinter, getting snow on its nose, there frowning on the opposite page is Old Snow in the Face kneedeep in a drift.

title: Bisconti Defeats Chapman, 4 and 3, in Final of Richardson Memorial Golf
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 15Peter Bisconti Jr., who came from Westchester County three years ago to win the Travis Memorial tournament at Garden City, completed another successful golfing trip to Long Island today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: James Reston maintained (column May 2) that the objective of Mayday was to shut down Government bureaucracy, paralyzing (at least temporarily) the war effort. His bittersweet humor about Washington's Hydra bureaucracy was undoubtedly true.

title: Art
description: THE art scene in San Francisco (meaning the entire Bay Area) has rarely, if ever, been characterized by a sense of esthetic abundance. There is certainly no shortage of artists here, and the museums are impressive in their number, if not always in their quality. Indeed, the Bay Area now boasts two new museum structuresat Berkeley and at Oaklandwhich are among the handsomest and most original anywhere in the world. But the gallery scene is meager, and this, I think, is a reflection of something significant in the art life of the placenot only the absence of a lively market for new art, but the absence of a certain energy and curiosity, a certain indispensable complexity and lan, of which the dynamics of the art market are more a symptom than a cause. Such energy and complexity no doubt exist, but they remain isolated and embattled, almost a private moral code suspicious of social connection, and thus without the power to effect a vital, ongoing cultural en terprise

title: A dead man alive in his speeches, a live man dead in his speeches
description: All praises are now given to the name and memory of Malcolm X. In his person he represented the apotheosis of blackness; but, except for the last 11 months of his political career, he articulated the aims and ideals of the Nation of Islam as the number one spokesman for the Honorable Elijah Muhammud. This is important to remember because as the most important black political figure of the sixties, Malcolm X brought the thought of Elijah Muhammud to a larger audience and thereby increased its influence. That fact is not recognized or acknowledged today, but it is very evident in The End of White World Supremacy, collection of four previously unpublished speeches given during 1962 and 1963, Malcolm's last year in the Nation. Here we find the concepts that, three years after his death, would be gathered under the rubric black power and forwarded as a secular in the necessity to know black history; black separation; the need for black unity; black control of the political, economic and social institutions of the black community.

title: Proposal Would Use Fresh Air Fund Camps as a Part of School Program
description: All 118,090 fifth graders in the RonxIwill spend a week in the country as part of their regular school curriculum if plan being organized by group of 28 educators, politicians, school administrators, environmentalists and camp officials is successful.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: BEDMINSTER, N.J.Environmentalists and ecologists are helping John E. Schork succeed in a dirty business.

title: Browning's Vayu Triumphs In Long Island Sound Race
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 15Donald Browning's Vayu whipped a fleet of six Resolute Class sloops today as the Cow Bay Area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition opened its 1971 season on Manhasset Bay.

title: Gen. Legare Tarrant, 66; Led Air Defense Unit Here
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 15Brig. Gen. Legare K. Tarrant died today at his home. He was 66 years old.

title: Kansas City Editor Rises
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 15 (AP)William W. Baker, editor of The Kansas City Star since Jan. 1, 1967, has been named executive vice president. He will continue as editor. the newspaper announced today.

title: ST. JOHN'S VICTOR IN COLLEGE TRACK
Saigon Reports New Push Into Parrot's Beak Region
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sunday, May 16The South Vietnamese military command announced today that a multibattalion force had launched a new operation in the Parrot's Beak region of eastern Cambodia.

title: David Panzer Weds Amy Beth Hamburger
description: HARRISON, N. Y., May 15 The marriage of Miss Amy Beth Hamburger to David Murray Panzer took place here today at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Panzer. Dr. Paul Steingerg, dean of the Hebrew Union College of New York and Jerusalem performed the ceremony.

title: Center on Energy Utilization Is Established at U. of P.
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15The University of Pennsylvania has established the National Center for Energy Management and Power.

title: Drumtop Captures $45,650 Garden State Grass Race in Track Record Time
Haber, Handball's Bad Boy, Off Form
description: The difference between last year's invitation fourwall handball tournament at the New York Athletic Club and this year's can be described in two words: Paul Haber.

title: Road Back Starts on May 30 For Mountain Valley Stables
description: The long road back will start for Mountain Valley Stables on May 30.

title: Et Al.
description: Another layer in the thickening popular gloss on Masters & Johnson's clinic. Sensibly and crisply told, this is the story of Sam and Louise, who have The Problem: he's too fast, she's too slow. The authors, also husband and wife, have written extensively on marital subjects; this latest effort is done with more depth and taste than the recent, similar The Couple.

title: A Bit Longer on Top, Please
description: Long Hair"that was what the Indians called Gen. George Custer, among other things. In fact, many military men at that time sported long hair and beards. By World War I, hirsuteness was out and the crew cut was in. Now the pendulum is swinging back again. Last week, the Army relaxedever so slightlyits regulation on hair. The soldier can now wear his.hair a bit longer in back, providing it doesn't extend below the shirt collar. He can grow sideburns providing they don't extend beyond the opening of the ear. Tidy mustaches are okay. Beards, however, are still out, as are shorthair wigs for those soldiers who want to kep their hair long while off duty, but disguise it while on duty. As for General Custerwell, it's clear that he would have trouble passing muster.

title: Avinga had no prospects but he did have a soul
description: The forces of civilization are as irresistible as they are destructive. Americans in particular should know that this is true, for they have the clear example of their own experience as missionaries, relatively recent at that, in the New World wilderness. In spite of the extent to which that experience has been romanticized, they should know that human suffering and cultural disintegration are the natural byproducts of enforced liberation and enlightenment.

title: The Happy Ending (Maybe) of The Selling of the Pentagon
Music
description: THE New York Philharmonic's season has just ended, and a most interesting ?? it was. It seemed to follow a trend noticed in other orchestras and even soloists around the country. Of course there were the Beethoven concerts, which were de rigueur in 1970, the bicentennial of the composer's birth. But otherwise there was a heartening exploration of repertory. While the Philharmonic managed to avoid the phenomenon of the socalled romantic revival, it nevertheless found plenty of other material, some of importance, that had not been heard in this city for many years. One thinks of such disparate items as the Szymanowski Mass and Haydn's Lord Nelson Mass, or the wonderful excerpts from Berlioz's Beatrice at Benedict, or the Wehern Passacaglia, or the early Tchaikovsky symphonies.

title: Riverboat Freight Business Thriving
description: CINCINNATIThe City of St. Louis, pushing 12 barges and making 8 knots down the Ohio River, was somewhere between Huntington, W. Va., and Ashland, Ky., when Roy Grote asked Billy Harper what time it was.

title: Et Al.
description: A lawyer on the law for laymen. Mr. Bishop, professor of corporation, military and international law at Yale, has here collected some of his law journal articles, magazine pieces, book reviews, etc. He can be devastating on the liberal martyr complex of a Jessica Mitford, and work his way nicely through the weaknesses to the ultimate value of a Vance Packard on privacy. Although he is no conservative, Mr. Bishop finds most of his targets on the left. His stated motive is to meet the flood of cant, fustian and emotional nonsense which pollutes the intellectual atmosphere. All hail the ecology of the word!

title: Shaw's John Bull, A Study of Ireland, Revived in London
description: LONDON, May 15The neglect of John Bull's Other Island while the Shavian barrel has been scraped for all kinds of oddities and trifles is one of the mysteries of the British Shaw revival. The play is an obvious masterpiece: and it clearly emerges as such in Alan Strachan's exhilarating Mermaid Theater production.

title: John Gregory Dallin Is Fiance Of Susan Borden Necarsulmer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Necarsulmer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Borden Necarsulmer, to John Gregory Dallin, son of Mrs. Dorothy H. Dallin of Bellport, L. I.

title: NEW GRAINS HELP CHINESE FARMERS
description: HONG KONG, May 15  Improved varieties of grain are contributing substantially to China's grow more food campaign but officials at collective farms say that they have never heard of the development of miracle rice and wheat in the outside world. They say they rely on new strains developed in their own areas for higher yields.

title: 2 Landmark Houses Moved to New Sites
description: Two old brick houses that have been designated landmarks were gingerly loaded onto flatbed trucks yesterday and moved out of downtown urbanrenewal site to a new location.

title: Chile Sends Trade Team to East Europe
description: SANTIAGO, Chile May 15Foreign Minister Clodomiro Almeyda led a Chilean economic mission that left today on a trip to seven Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union.

title: Up Against the WallIn Bookcases
description: The university crisis has provided raw material for a literary industry. Once the domain of presidents (their prose leaden, their spirits oily, their thought weak) or of specialists in education (for whom the obvious was not nearly obvious enough), the university's problems are now every man's theme. What melancholy expert on humanity's future has not enriched us with his sorrowful reflections on higher education? Which professor in his middling years has not sought the elixir of youth by proclaiming the renewal of the university? Youthful contributors to the discussion succeed one another at generational intervals of a semester. The spring brings its round of confrontations, the fall their literary re enactment. Conferences, symposia, committee and commission reports follow without number or end. Is anything new being said; can anything new be said? Perhaps not, but with tirelessor reckless  determination, new authors set their books on our overcrowded shelves.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The fact that some Federal agencies consider maternity leave an employe right (article Maternity Leave, May 2) is not surprising. Whenever the Government wanted to get things done its own way to promote its own interests, it simply imposed another employe right.

title: CANONER0 II WINS PREAKNESS, EASTERN FLEET NEXT;
Nancy H. Sargent Is Married To Robert L. Caporale, Lawyer
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., May 15Miss Nancy Hunnewell Sargent was married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church to Robert Leo Caporale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Caporale of Jamaica Plain and Scituate. The Rev. Samuel Shoemaker Johnston, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Detroit, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. William H. Clark, rector of St. Andrew's.

title: Cincinnati Merchants Await Annual Visit of Terrible Williamsons, a Clan of Wandering GypArtists
description: CINCINNATI, May 12The terrible Williamsons are due back any day now, as regular as springtime, and some merchants here can hardly wait. Every year, just before Memorial Day, the Williamsons return to town, peeling off hundreddollar bills to pay for their Cadillacs and their stocks and their funerals.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIt has been widely stated, in Congress and elsewhere, that the socalled Mayday demonstrators in Washington, by their disruptive tactics, damaged the peace movement and alienated many of its supporters. But two weeks after the mass arrests in the streets of the nation's capital, seems more likely that the real damage was done by the forces of law and order to their own supposed cause.

title: Singapore Names Publisher Accused of Espionage Links
description: SINGAPORE, May 15The Government today accused Aw Kow, publisher of Inc Eastern Sun, an Englishlanguage daily newspaper here, of receiving $1.2 million United States dollars from a Communist intelligence service based an Hong Kong.

title: Movies
description: EVERYBODY knows that Elia Kazan's wife, Barbara Loden, has made a huge splash with her first directorial effort, Wanda. But not everybody knows that another member of the Kazan household has gotten into the movie act. Chris Kazan, the veteran director's 32yearold son, recently had the pleasure of seeing his first screenplay, Home Free, put before the camera. In fact, it has already been completed and is scheduled for release in August. Young Kazan coproduced the film with Nick Proferes, on a budget of $130,000, and for his director he had the phenomenally good luck of getting a real prothe one and only Elia Kazan.

title: The World
description: HONG KONG  Chinese Communist leaders in Peking, from Premier Chou Enlai on down, arc on record as saying a regular flow of visitors from the United States and other countries will be admitted into Communist China from now on. Last week there were more signs that at least a trickle had begun.

title: BANK OF AMERICA BIG COAST TARGET
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15A visitor asked a friend the other day how to find the Bank of America headquarters. That's easy, came the reply. Just follow the smoke,

title: Unconscious Sidelined From Belmont Stakes
description: Arthur A. Seeligson Jr.'s Unconscious, who finished fifth in the Kentucky Derby after leaving the post as the favorite, has been sidelined from the Belmont Stakes, the third of the Triple Crown races.

title: Harriet Glickman Plans June Bridal
description: The engagement of Miss Harriet R. Glickman to Richard L. Mayer has been announced by her brother, Melvyn Glickman of Worcester, Mass. The wedding will be next month.

title: HUB ROLE IS URGED FOR PATERSON, N.J.
description: The Regional Plan Association has proposed that Paterson, a dingy industrial city of 150,000 about 13 miles west of Manhattan, be transformed into a mayor metropolitan center for four northern New Jersey counties.

title: French Toehold
description: DETROITA large French international oil company, aided by 200 specially hired women established a beach head in Michigan a month ago in what could ultimately be an invasion of the United States petroleum market.

title: Botanical Garden Council To Sponsor Bus Trip There
description: The Women's Council of the New York Botanical Garden will sponsor a bus trip on June 8 to the garden in Bronx Park.

title: 59,220 Travelers Killed inU.S.in'70, Decrease of 1,251
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) A total of 59,220 persons were killed in the various forms of travel in the United States last year  a rate of about 162 a day.

title: Learning to Live With Monetary Flexibility
description: LONDONStability has long been an assumption life in the international monetary world, a fundamental value. Only gradually, in recent years, has there emerged a group of critics worried about stability becoming immobility.

title: Photography
description: ANY HOME darkroom enthusiast can quickly and easily process color prints with a new kit recently introduced by the FR Corporation, 951 Brook Avenue, Bronx, N. Y. 10451. Using the Rapid Access Color Print Process, the kit includes all the chemicals needed, 25 sheets of printing paper, a set of 3x3inch color printing filters, a thermometer, complete instructions and the new FR OneShot Drum Processor. The Chemicals (all liquid) permit prints to be evaluated in only 4 minutes and they are also compatible with Agfacolor and Unicolor papers.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Herbert R. Lottman, in his otherwise carefully researched and wellwritten article on Frankfurt (Travel section, April 11), refers to some quaint old trolley cars he saw in the city.
