He must have had extraordinarily bad luck. When I was last in Frankfurt about two years ago, I saw only extremely modern and fast trams, running smoothly and quietly on welded track, not polluting the air at all. For comfort, no bus ride could compare with what they offered. What's so old fashioned about transportation of this quality? I only wish we had anything comparable in the United States.

title: Supreme Court Decision Prompts Meeting Here of 100 Lawyers Battling Execution of Their Clients
description: Lawyers representing prisoners in death rows around the country met here yesterday to seek ways to keep their clients from execution.

title: ATLANTA SUBURB SPLIT OVER BOND
description: SANDY SPRINGS, Ga., May 13  The cancellation of speech by Julian Bond at a high school here has sparked miss debate in this usually quiet, affluent, allwhite suburb of Atlanta.

title: LESS CRIME NOTED BY TAXI INDUSTRY; ??b Robberies and Assaults Down Sharply in Last Year
description: The taxi industry reports that robberies and assaults drivers continued to drop sharply in the last year and attributes the decline to both stronger police protection and new driversecurity measures.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS CHINA LENDS $207MILLION
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 15  The Pakistani Government said today that China's latest interestfree loan to be used in shoring a precarious economy here will amount to about $207million.

title: CARPENTERS OFFER CARNEGIE CONCERT
description: The Carpentersthe brotherandsister team of Richard, 25, years old, and Karen, 21who came out of nowhere with their bland but rhythmic treatment of a neglected Burt BacharachHal David song, Close to You, brought more of the same to Carnegie Hall on Friday evening for two performances along with their own sound system.

title: BURGER DECLINES TO BAR MAIL RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15In eight words, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger quashed today any remaining possibility that postal rate increases scheduled for tomorrow could be prevented from going into effect.

title: New Navy League Head
description: SAN DIEGO, May 15 (AP)A Boston businessman, Thomas E. Morris, has been elected national president: of the 44,000memOcr Navy League to succeed James Hannan of Birmingham, Mich. He was chosen during the league's 69th convention, which ended yesterday with the participation of to the Navy's mllitary and civilian chiefs.

title: Ernest Truex
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Jurors for U.S. Courts Are Sought to Ease Congestion
description: Efforts are under way to ease congestion in the nation's Federal courts by reducing the number of jurors in civil cases from the traditional 12 to only 6.

title: Movies
description: ON February 24, 1971, 6yearold western that cost $80,000 to make in 1965 and starred nobody very important had its American premiere, practically unnoticed, in Dallas.

title: It May Not Be a Pest or Disease After All
description: IS it a bug? Or, is it a disease?So pondered two mystified suburban gardeners one midsummer clay last year. What had killed two forsythias but not the third? And, now what, at the same time of the year. was killing one lilac bush but not the other?

title: Murcer's Decisions Pay Off With Higher Batting Average and Longer Hair
description: Bobby Murcer made two decisions last winter: he would let his batting average get higher and his hair grow longer.

title: To Valhalla, to Visit Mr. Ibsen
description: HENRIK IBSEN rose from his armchair near the fireplace. Come in. Join me in a bit of smorgasbord and a glass of akvavit, he said ??ordially.

title: SEX DISCRIMINATION IN U.S. JOBS CURBED
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)The Civil Service Commission has ruled that men only and women only requirements must be removed from almost all Federal jobs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is a growing concern that President Nixon's policies are determined, not by the welfare of his American fellow citizens, but by his desire to be reelected in 1972.

title: Jeanine Sofiak Plans Nuptials
description: GARY, Ind., May 15Miss Jeanine Kay Sofiak and John Llewellyn Brendler plan to be married here on July 10.

title: Et Al.
description: From England comes this collection of six critical essays on the leading figures of what is loosely called The New LeftChe Guevara, JeanPaul Sartre, Herbert Marcuse, Frantz Fanon, R. D. Laing and the American black power advocates. The perspective is ivorytower academic; the contributors are professors from both sides of the Atlantic; they share a willingness to use violence to liberate the oppressed; there is also a common rejection of conventional Marxism. A worthy attempt to place in perspective the leading proponents of radicalism in our day.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWas that just the ghost of the SST in Congress last week, or a genuine Phoenix rising, from the ashes of last March? The Senate will have an official answer on Wednesday, but with the old major industrial boosters of the supersonic transport now evidently disenchanted, the SST revival looked highly unlikely.

title: Bianchi, 2 Other Squires Are Fined in Assault Case
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15 (AP) The Virginia Squires coach and two of his players were found guilty of assault and battery and fined here yesterday in connection with a fight during an American Basketball Association game Dec. 23.

title: Penn's Landing Site Is Planned as a Tourist Center
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15Whether or not this city hosts a world's fair for the nation's bicentennial in 1976, the historic downtown section of the Delaware River where William Penn landed in the 17th century will be remodeled to lure tourists.

title: An Austere Style Marks the Dances Of Farber Troupe
description: As a puremovement choreagrapher, Viola Farber offers a special aristocratic austerity. Although the timespace concerns of the Merce Cunningham style may have once served her as a point of departure, her present interests seem focused particularly upon a deliberately confined vocabulary.

title: Man Chased by Store Aide Killed by Police in Queens
description: A man being pursued by al store detective was shot and killed yesterday by a city patrolman when he turned on his jursuers with a sixinch gravity knife in Flushing, Queens.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Ballads, in company with bridges and barges, have undergone some changes since the early eighteenhundreds, but the latter, at least, remain as vital and busy a link between ports, fields and factories as they were in the last century.

title: Mrs. Court Keeps Title
description: LONDON, May 15 (AP)Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia overcame an upset stomach today and defeated Francoise Durr of France, 60, 63, to retain the women's title in the BioStrath hard court tennis championships at the Hurlingham Club.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Apparently the Winter Garden is considered one of Broadway's most soughtafter musical houses. What I'd like to know is  Why?

title: School Dropouts Learn Job Skills at Ft. Totten
description: Thirtythree young men, dropouts from school who have never been able to find a real job, hope to learn work skills and further their educations in a new residential training program at Fort Totten in Bayside, Queens.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE LEANS TO MUSKIE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The first detailed poll of the New Hampshire electorate this year shows Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine with a commanding lead over seven potential rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972.

title: My Three Guides: From the Irascible To the Romantic
description: THE new dehumanized tape tours may be the In thing now, but my wife, Lee, and I would not exchange them for some very human encounters with the irascible Mr. Winkler in Paris, the hospitable Albert in Copenhagen and the dashing Ramon in Barcelona during stopovers on our recent 40day cruise to Europe.

title: An Upturn in Business Giving?; Recession Hits Arts Less Than Other Charities
description: Next Wednesday, Carnegie Hall will be filled with the sound of music and glum countenances. For unless American Airlines, the sponsor of the American Youth Performs concert, can find another company to share the $175,000 a year it costs to run the musical apprenticeship program, another cultural victim will be chalked up to the recent business slump.

title: Rebecca Van Buren Engaged to Soldier
description: Miss Rebecca Van Buren, a student at the Moore College of Art in Philadelphia, and Pfc. Jeffery B. Baer, who is serving with the Army at Fort McNair in Washington, plan to be married June 26. The ceremony will take place in Grace Presbyterian Church in Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: A WORD of praise for a delightful musical, 70, Girls, 70.

title: U.S. and French Horse Owners Are Engaged in Germ Warfare'
description: PARIS, May 15Two French trotters, weakened by a 46day confinement in quarantine at Kennedy International Airport, returned home this week carrying the germ of a major international quarrel.

title: Sir Tyrone Guthrie Dies at 70; Director and Scholar of Stage
description: DUBLIN, May 15Sir Tyrone Guthrie, the director, author and producer, died today at his home in Newbliss, County Monaghan. He was 70 years old.

title: The Perennial Avantgarde
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Whitney Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dwight Whitney of New York and Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarissa Whitney, to George Richard Biehl, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Raymond Biehl of Longport, N.J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This spectacular, mountainous Hudson area should never embrace a major jetport [editorial May 1]. Its beauty and natural resources should remain an asset to New York State forever.

title: FAST FELLOW, 45, TAKES COAST MILE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 15 (UPI)Fast Fellow, again demonstrating his liking for Hollywood Park, raced to his third straight stakes victory today with a strong stretch move to capture the fourth running of the $55,350 Caballero Stakes for 3yearold colts and geldings.

title: Boys'
description: The Salvation Army broke ground last week for a $950,000 building that will house offices, a boys club and daycare facilities at Riverdale Avenue and Watkins Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: 2 Die in Crash on L. I.
description: ST PATCHOGUE, L.I., May two men were killed and three injured here early today in a twocar crash on Sunrise Highway. The dead were Joseph Burla, 66 years old, the driver of one car, who lived at 23 Kendall Avenue, North Tarrytown, N.Y., and his passenger, John Taylor, 68, of 45 Clinton Street, North Tarrytown.

title: FUND NOW ACCEPTED BY BLACK CATHOLICS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The National Office of Black Catholics, which said last November that it would not take one cent of $150,000 the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops had designated for its use has now announced that it has accepted the money.

title: Miss Elita Lanaras Will Marry in June
description: Miss Elita Lanaras, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Lanaras of Athens, plans to be married there next month to Antony V. Georgiadis of London. He is the son of Lady Crawford and the late Vassos Georgiadis of Kampala, Uganda who owned coffee and sisal plantations and a tobacco company. His stepfather, Sir Frederick Crawford of Salisbury, Rhodesia, was Governor of Kenya and Uganda from 1957 to 1961.

title: Travel Industry Courts Affluent Negroes
description: The cover of a new United Air Lines brochure tantalizes travelers with the same sort of enticing tropical scene that has lured mainlanders to Hawaii for generations: Under a sunny sky, a young couple in flowered shirts smile against a lush backdrop of flowers and cool green ferns bent slightly by a soft wind.

title: MOST IN POLL BACK WASHINGTON POLICE
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) A public opinion polling group says a heavy majority of people it interviewed disapproved of recent antiwar demonstrations in Washington and felt mass arrests of protesters were justified.

title: ExPlaywright Explains That Ex
description: TALKING or writing about theater depends on who you are and where you're located. If you're Neil Simon or the producer oi. Hair, everything is ?? if you're an investor in ?? or Applause, theater is music in the bank; if you're a writer standing in the wings with a script in your pocket that no one has time to read, it's a conspiracy against genius; if you're a playwright who has turned to something else like crime or chamber music and look in on the stage years later, you are inclined to ask: Is that what the fuss is (was) all about?

title: U.S. Journal
description: Thirtytwo essays, all of which appeared in The New Yorker. Calvin Trillin calls them the result of three years of reporting about Americanot the Great Events & Mighty People, but middlesized or small events and people who are, with a few exceptions, only locally famous. Like a plate of 32 tiny cookies that won a prize at the county fair, you can gobble them up in few hours without surfeit.

title: Chet Huntley, in Montana, Likes Not Living by Clock
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., May 14Last Aug. 1, at age 58, Chester Robert Huntley, who in 35 years in radio and television had achieved considerable fame and not inconsiderable affluence, came back here, 40 miles east of his native Cardwell, to become the board chairman and promoter of Big Sky of Montana, Inc.

title: New Nursery in Brooklyn
description: The Kane Street Jewish Nursery, serving the Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens communities, will open in September on a halfsession basis at the Baith Israel Synagogue at 236 Kane Street in Brooklyn. Information may be obtained from Arthur Lichtman, chairman of the nursery committee, at 5969575 or Isaac Druker, the secretary, at 8750872.

title: Miss Comstock Married to Banker
description: ESSEX, Conn., May 15Miss Constance Comstock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Harwood Comstock, was married here this morning to Kenneth A. Southworth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Southworth Jr. of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Ernest S. Harris Jr. performed the 1 ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: Donald Duncan, 78; Promoter of YoYo And Parking Meter
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP) Donald Franklin Duncan, a selfeducated businessman who made the Yoyo a milliondollarl seller and established the parkI ing meter in cities, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: Czech Official Says Communism is Best Able to Combat Pollution
description: OSTRAVA, Czechoslovakia, May 14More than 100 experts on environmental problems who had spent a week in Prague studying answers to pollution have received a pithy one here:

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Accountants get Interested in the strangest thingslike tax problems facing people who die in Luxembourg and want to be cremated.

title: ETHEL CASEY SINGS WORKS BY WEBERN
description: The majority of New York premieres on Ethel Casey's Program of Premieres in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night were by Anton Webern. Although Webern left only a small corpus of published music at his death in 1945, scholars have recently unearthed numerous early works. The 18 new songs offered by Miss Casey were written between 1899 and 1909.

title: Sandra Steele Becomes Bride
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., May 15  In the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here this afternoon, Miss Sandra Carnegie Steele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Carnegie Steele, became the bride of Stuart Wentworth Pratt, son of Mrs. E. Stuart Pratt and L. Mortimer Pratt, both of Boston.

title: The Tablet, Catholic Weekly, Reflects Change
description: Brooklyn's population has changed and so has the official Roman Catholic weekly newspaper in the borough, The Tablet.

title: GoAhead on Rail Links To 2 Airports Announced
description: Governor Rockefeller of New York and Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey announced jointly yesterday that the Port of New York Authority would finance and construct direct, highspeed rail links from midtown Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport and from Newark to Newark Airport.

title: ISRAEL SAYS TROOPS KILLED 2 GUERRILLAS
description: TEL AVIV, Israel. May 15 (AP)Israeli troops killed two Arab guerrillas in separate clashes on the occupied west bank of Jordan and the Gaza Strip, the Israeli command said today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: OTB Operation Attracts Governor of Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland said today New York's offtrack betting system definitely is appealing.

title: 2 New Play Areas For Central Park Announced by City
description: Plans for the construction of two new playgrounds in Central Park have been announced by August Heckscher, the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Ad ministrator.

title: Rutgers Professor Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) Dr. Richard P. McCormack, a Rutgers University history professor, has been named by President Nixon as a member of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission. He succeeds Catherine Drinker Bowen, who resigned last December.

title: Is New Orleans Jazz Dying?
description: WOODY ALLEN gets up at 6 A.M. in New Orleans and prowls the fresh morning streets"absorbing jazz history, he says. And when the city's musicians begin to stir, Woody has his clarinet with him, ready to sit in whereever he can, He is an anonymous part of the audience that stands in the rear of dingy Preservation Hall, listening to a band that includes the clarinetist who is his idol, 69yearold Albert Burbank. He talks of jamming with Burbank but he hesitates.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The rush to get at the golden goose will kill it!

title: For Young Readers; A Cycle Of Seasons; The Little Brown Bat. By Lucille Wood Trost. Photographs. 47 pp. Scott. $4.25. (Ages 7 to,11)
description: The truth about bats makes the old Dracula legendry seem wanting in imagination. The familiar device of describing a species in terms of single specimen's history is given extra dimensions with a section devoted to a careful study of a cave full of hibernating bats in midwinter.

title: the traveler's world
description: THERE are extant, alive and Pune??oning in America today, according to Government officials, at least 60 socalled consumerism organizations dedicated to the proposition that that old Latin slogan caveat emptor should be reversed from let the buyer beware to let the manufacturer, dealer and seller beware of the aggressively alert buyer. To date no one consumerism group has staked out as its preserve the great American tourist, but the loss has not been felt too keenly because the great American tourist has demonstrated that he can take pretty good care of himself.

title: Mr. Thrasher
description: He is a dandy, a showoff and a superb performer. His common name is Brown Thrasher, but he is also known as fox thrush, ground thrush, French mockingbird and half a dozen other flattering names. He is not a thrush at all, but a member of the same family as the mockingbird and the catbird, the Mimidae, or the Mimics. He is one of the most engaging singers we have.

title: ItalianAmerican Rights League Builds Strength in Several Major Cities
description: The New Yorkbased ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League is gaining strength as a national organization, involving itself in grass roots community projects and attracting new members in several major cities.

title: The Light Before the Sun
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Killed as Floor Collapses At Village Hall in France
description: BAYEUX, France, May 15 (Reuters)  Thriteen persons died and five were seriously injured tonight when the floor collapsed at a wedding reception in the village of Sallen near this Normany town.

title: Leslie Gilman Wed to T. S. Babcock
description: SPRING LAKE, Mich., May 15Miss Leslie Elizabeth Gilman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin E. Gilman, was married here this morning to Theodore Stoddard Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Nash Babcock of Old Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. John W. Shackleton, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Cards Sign Top Draft Pick
description: ST. LOUIS, May 15 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals signed today their firstround draft choice, Norm Thompson of the University of Utah, a defensive back.

title: Mail:
description: To the Editor: One of your ardent subscribers, Dr. F. Willson Daily, who is also a yachting enthusiast, noticed with much interest the article you had on April 30 entitled 253 Years of Red Sails in the Sunset. He forwarded this article to me since I was the Commodore of our Savannah Yacht Club at the time we celebrated our 100th anniversary two years ago. Our club was organized on June 14, 1869.

title: Architecture
description: IRONY, I have been told by wise editors, is bad journalistic technique. But ironies abound in life and architecture, and I cannot resist adding these notes to the preservation items of the last few weeks.

title: 8 ATHLETESCHOLARS TO BE CITED MAY 27
description: Eight outstanding metropolitan high school athletescholars will receive awards May 27 at a dinner to be given by the New York Chapter of the National Football Foundation at the Essex House. Five hundred are expected to attend, according to the chapter's president, Jack Prendergast.

title: Queens Planning Board 4 Says City Seeks to Destroy Corona
description: Community Planning Board 4 in Queens, representing the Elmhurst and Corona sections,, has accused the city in a formal report of being determined to destroy those areas of proud homeowners.

title: Glenda Farrell 19041971
description: THIS morning, under a still soft mound of earth overlooking the stately Hudson at West Point, there rests the body of Glenda Farrell, American actress. She is the only member of her profession whose grave is situated in the cemetery of the United States Military Academy. The reason: she was the wife of Colonel Henry Ross, Class of 26, and specifically chose the site during the last of her gallant days. Her grave is marked by the cross symbolizing her devout Catholicism. When, in time to come, her husband joins her there, the cross will be matched by a graven Star of David. There is something very

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Art
description: IN Teorema  a fine, strange Italian movie by Pier Pasolini  there is a scene in which a young man, a painter, undergoes a moment of spiritual crisis and/or mental breakdown (this the sort of stylish ambiguity at which some European filmmakers excel). Beatificlooking in his sunlightflooded studio, he is experimenting with a small canvas, pouring blue paint onto it from above, but for some reason he is not pleased with the result. Perhaps it is too successful? (The blue paint is gorgeous in Technicolor.). He seems driven by a need to defile somehow the purity of his art; it's as if his own talent suddenly disgusted him. Finally, he urinates on the painting. It seemed to me, watching the movie, that was supposed at this point to feel revulsion and a kind of awe, but I couldn't help it, I laughed  to my regret., since I had been really caught up in Teorema and want ed to like everything in it.

title: Music
description: THE Juilliard Opera Center's last premiere, given in late March, was Harold Farberman's The Losers. It was about today's youth, specifically a gang like Hell's AngeIs. The company's next premiere due this Thursday and Saturday, is about the youth of another and more innocent era, the characters in Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn. The opera is by Hall Overton, a 51yearold composer on the Juilliard faculty. He collaborated on the libretto with Judah Stampfer.

title: Bridge Slam gadgets: Use sparingly, handle with care
description: CONVENTIONS that ask for information about aces, such as Blackwood and Gerber, are deceptively simple. In practice there are many pitfalls for the unwary.

title: New Zealander Sets Mark In N.A.I.A. Steeplechase
description: SAN DIEGO, May 15 (AP)Jeff Matthews, a 22yearold sophomore from Auchland, New Zealand, captured the 3,000meter steeplechase last night in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics district track meet.

title: JOBLESS ENGINEER TO PLAN CAR POOLS
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., May 15A plan to alleviate some of Long Island's traffic problems, get people to work faster and more cheaplyand make himself some moneyis being advanced by an outofwork electrical engineer here.

title: MULTIYEAR PACT GIVEN TO FRAZIER
description: Walt Frazier, squelching rumors that had him jumping to the American Basketball Association, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the New York Knicks of the National Basketball Association.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While the United States commitment to Taiwan is ambiguous, it certainly implies protection against conquest by force. But 22 years after mainland China came under the effective control of the Communist Government, this country has no obligation to defend the increasingly absurd claim of the Chiang Kaishek regime that it is the sole government of China.

title: JAZZ WORKS GIVEN BY BILL EVANS TRIO
description: The Friday noontime sessions at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street, which have usually focused on big bands (such as the Julius SchwartzJerry Rail Orchestra, which will play next week) or small groups involving musicians who are not normally heard together (such as the combination of Bobby Jones, tenor saxophonist in Charles Mingus's group, and trumpeter Kenny Durham, who will appear in two weeks), veered yesterday from this norm to present one of the top contemporary jazz groups, the Bill Evans Trio.

title: Norwegians of Bay Ridge, a Proud and TightKnit Community
description: Along the esplanade overlooking the Narrows, blueeyed children play tag, pull wagons and ride tricycles their handknitted, intricately patterned sweaters and pompon hats dotting the shoreline like so many gay afghans.

title: New Office Building in Harlem, First in Years, Opening Friday
description: The first new office building in Harlem in at least two decades  an $8milllion, sixstory structure  will open its doors Friday under the joint ownership of a white suburban realestate company and a local black and Puerto Rican development group.

title: Son for the Paynes
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 15A son was born on April 24 to Mr. and Mrs. Joe E. Payne Jr. in the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Payne is the former Elizabeth Ritchie. The child has been named Jeffrey Ritchie. His father is a landscape architect.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Even if, as it turns out, it has nothing much to do with the book, Donald E. Westlake's GAVE AT THE OFFICE (Simon & Schuster, $5.95) is a very funny title, just as the contents provide a very funny book. It is narrated by a real schnook, a loser type. Guys drink his liquor, but he never gets the girls, he falls overboard, and nobody misses him; things go wrong, and he is the patsy. Yet there is something endearing about him, for he is essentially pure.

title: New York
description: A stranger in the great state of New York might believe that one of its tourist attractions is something called the Cave of the Winds.

title: The New Hebrides Headhunters Have Changed Their Ways, It's Nice to Know
description: VILA, Efate Island, New Hebrides There are still a few places in this welltramped world where a person can travel in the style to which his forebears were accustomed and New Hebrides is one of them. I am not talking about the style of the grand tour because that is probably gone forever; I am talking about traveling to places a vast number of other people have not already visited, and meeting people who are as interested in you as a stranger to their world as you are in them.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONAs Europeans never tire of pointing out, the chief underlying cause of the recent international monetary turmoil was the longcontinued deficit in the United States balance of payments.

title: Civilian Is Killed in Belfast In Attack on British Soldiers
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. May 15A civilian was killed and three Miler personstwo of them soldierswounded here tonight in an exchange of gunfire.

title: DATA ON COLLEGES TO GUIDE STUDENTS
description: High school students seeking colleges best suited to their aims and desires will he aided in the fall by a new service offered by the College Entrance Examination Board.

title: CANADIENS SEEK TO SQUARE SERIES
description: MONTREAL, May 15Hockey here is different than it is in other cities. There is the pride of a record 15 Stanley Cup championships.

title: 2 New Yorkers Die in Crash
description: LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. May 15 (AP)  Two New York City men died today when the car in which they were riding hit a bridge abutment here, the police reported. They identified the victims as Edwin Garcia, 19 years old, of 4537 40th Street, Long Island City, Queens, and Robert Ropp, 21 of 1270 First Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Gardens
description: ASTHE magnificent display of bulbs fades out, gardeners will want to fill these areas with color that lasts until the first hard frost in autumn. Annuals are the answer.

title: AUGUST KLIPSTEIN JR., CHEMICALS OFFICER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 August Klipstein Jr., a retired chemicals executive, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 6 Deer Lane.

title: Preakness Winner Pays $12.80 Here; $1.1Million Is Bet
description: Betting more than they had on the Kentucky Derby, New York's offtrack horseplayers once again enjoyed a bigger payoff on Canonero II yesterday than handicappers who bet the colt at the track in the Preakness.

title: Only 305 Birds Survive San Francisco Oil Spill
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (UPI)Despite one of the most intensive wildlife rescue efforts, in history, only 305 of the thousands of birds pulled out of the San Francisco Bay oil spill Jan. 18 have survived.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The ancient dilemmas of American politics are back in the headlines again: How to give the President the powers necessary to defend the nation in a time of nuclear weapons and international ballistic missiles, and still maintain the control of Congress. How to keep him strong enough to govern the nation without allowing him to impose his will on the people and their representatives in the Congress.

title: Ubleis of Austria Easily Wins World Harness Driving Series
STATE SPURS CITY ON CHILDREN'S AID
description: The State Board of Social Welfare has called on New York City to expand help to children, particularly in their own homes, charging that 'too many children go into foster care and then remain in care too long.

title: Television
description: MOST composers fight shy of the TV box. For them it is a monster that devours talent only to spew it out flattened into its own faceless image. But Benjamin Britten thrives on pitting his technical prowess against conditions that a lesser man might find constricting. He is also too sharply aware of the artist's duty to communicate to spurn the most powerful agent of communication our century offers. Reassured by successful BBCTV productions of his Peter Grimes and Billy Budd, Britten accepted a commission to write an specifically for TV.

title: MANDRILL ROCKS IN LATIN TEMPO
description: Rock with Latin influences has grown in vogue recently. But it takes more than a set of congas to make a Latin band, a lesson not all those trying this music have learned. Mandrill, a hefty Latin rock band from BedfordStuyvesant, has.

title: Baptists Urge U.S. to Pull Out Of Indochina by End of the Year
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 15The American Baptist Convention today called upon President Nixon and Congress to withdraw all United States military personnel from Indochina, except those in diplomatic service, 'hopefully by Dec. 31, 1971. The vote was 1,451 in favor of the resolution and 199 against.

title: College Rugby
description: Princeton 23, Harvard 11. Yale 17, Harvard 0. Yale 6, Princeton 5.

title: CHANGE IS URGED IN N.Y.U. STUDIES
description: A highlevel New York University commission has recommended that students be allowed to complete work on their bachelor's degrees in as ??, as three years or as many as six.

title: The Nation
description: There was a red Dodge Dart parked on the Harlem River Drive overlooking the Harlem River, just across from a police precinct station house shortly after 9 P.M., Jan. 17, 1969. There was a black woman at the wheel, Joan Bird, aged 20, and there were two black men in the car. Two motorcycle policemen approached; a shootout followed, the two black men escaped and Miss Bird was taken to a precinct station house for questioning. Her mother was roused from bed and brought to the station house.

title: Weaver, With a 208, Leader at Houston
Tropical Grenada Is Torn by Rising Political and Social Conflict
description: ST. GEORGE'S, GrenadaMost tourists who cavort along this island's Grand Anse beaches and gasp at the beauty of the jungle in its mountainous interior never learn that this 21by12mile island is in the grip of serious social and political conflicts.

title: Stamps
description: AMERICAN hospitals and their services to the people will be commemorated postally this year. Tomorrow, at a luncheon on the Esplanade of Rockefeller University, adjacent to New York Hospital, E. T. Klassen, a governor of the United States Postal Service, will unveil the design of a stamp that will be imprinted on a postal card honoring men and women of the selfless profession, as they were described by Postmaster General Winton M. Blount.

title: Magazine Names Editor
description: ATLANTA, May 15 (UPI)Bruce Galpnin, awardwinningi author, and a former bureau manager for The Washington ??ost, has been named managing editor of Atlanta Magazine.

title: Young Star Heads U.S. Archers For First Competition in Russia
description: ERIE, Pa., May 15 (AP) John Williams is a high school senior and straightshooting archer. His goal: the 1972 Olympics, to be held in Munich, Germany, will included archery for the first time. Williams won't go so far as to say he might be a gold medal winner, but...

title: Queens Students Check On Cost of TV Repairs
description: How can a person tell an honest television repairman from a dishonest one? Was the amount paid for parts and labor a fair price? Did a television set need all the repairs the serviceman said it needed?

title: Estimate Board Majority Assails Mayor on Toll Plan
description: Mayor Lindsay was accused yesterday of trying to condition the city for a transitfare increase by misleading the people into believing that tolls on the East River bridges will be the key to saving the 30cent fare.

title: Samuel Koo WedsMiss Chung, Cellist
description: In the Park Avenue Christian Church yesterday afternoon Miss MyungWha Chung, a cellist, was married to Samuel Koo, a worldnews editor at Associated Press headquarters here. The Rev. Dr. William J. Jarman performed the ceremony.

title: GIRL DIES, 6 INJURED IN BROOKLYN CRASH
description: A 7year old girl was killed last night and six other persons critically injured when the car an which they were riding rammed into a divider on the near the Meeker Avenue exit in Brooklyn.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I read with astonishment Paul Avila Mayer's attack on the production of his adaptation of Strindberg's Dance of Death. Particularly offensive to me was his scurrilous attack on the actors, Viveca. Lindfors and Rip Torn. I don't know why he avoided mentioning my name, since I was the director.

title: Canonero Il's Triumph Dispels Doubts of Experts About His Capabilities
description: BALTIMORE, May 15An explosion of Latin joy erupted when Canonero II sped past the finish line today, first in the Preakness, and Gustavo Avila stood in the irons to wave to the crowd.

title: Dance
description: LAST Sunday two dance companies finished their season, leaving New York to the comparative peace and quiet of merely having two companies at Lincoln Center. The companies that have departed are Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company and Alvin Ailey's American Dance Theater. Artistically, both of them had very good seasons, but the attendances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for Feld were most disappointing.

title: Reader's Report
description: This novel by Jose Cabanis is vintage realism that holds up exceedingly well. The years 1937 through 1950 seem joyless only in retrospect to Gilbert Samalagnou, who has spent them in hot pursuit of sex. Age 18 finds Gilbert, a student in Toulouse (Cabanis's native city), being initiated by Juliette, an older man's mistress. As the years roll by, he becomes involved with Gaby (his best friend's wife), with Ingrid (a phlegmatic governess), with Noelle (whose father cultivates incest). Happiness eludes himand when he is asked, toward the end of the novel, whom he loves and who loves him, he says no one.

title: Redwood Runaround
description: Three years after Congress passed the law establishing a Redwood National Park, the park still does not exist. The obstructionist attitude of the Reagan administration in California and the avarice of the lumber companies are primarily responsible for this impasse. But Congress, which failed to anticipate these difficulties, and the National Park Service, which has been slow to assert the public interest, must share the responsibility.

title: Movies
description: THE notices were mainly terrific. They called Taking Off a wonder, found the director (Milos Forman) an ace at probing American homes. The performers were funny, gentle, sweet, the family relationships lovingly cemented, the tone deeply touching, the total filmic experience that of a near miracledomestic Comedy that doesn't do dirt on life. Rain at last, right? Take me to the Plaza Theater?

title: Art of Kicking Is Theme of Book
description: Football fans over 40 years of age may remember the coffincorner kick. This was the punt that rolled out of bounds inside the opponent's 5yard line and left him with a real problem. It was a great, dramatic play in football when practiced by someone like Eric Tipton of Duke before World War II. We seldom see the coffin corner kick any more, especially in pro football. Although coaches like Dick Nolan of the San Francisco 49ers and Hank Stram of the Kansas City Chiefs insist that kicking is onethird of every game, many different weapons of the kick have been all but forgotten.

title: Fate of 2,800 Homes Unresolved As Hearings on Gateway Reopen
description: WASHINGTON, May 15As a Senate subcommittee prepares to resume hearings here Monday on the proposed Gateway National Recreation Area, the fate of nearly 2,800 privately owned houses on the Rockaway Peninsula at Breezy Point remains unresolved.

title: BARKER, ROSS REACH WESTCHESTER FINAL
description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 15SteVe Ross and Bob Barker will play for the Westchester tennis title tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Armonk Tennis Club. The tournament is the first of the Eastern outdoor season.

title: Band Born on L.I. Hits the Big Time
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., May 15Five years ago, Phil Galdston, who was then 15, and Richie Bronsky, who was 16, started a rock band in Richie's basement with three of their friends here.

title: Dartmouth Crew Wins 3d Packard Cup in Row
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 15Dartmouth's heavyweight crew built a gradual lead after 500 meters and moved on steadily to defeat Syracuse and Massachussetts Institute of Technology today in the Packard Cup regatta on the Connecticut River.

title: Deauville: The Grande Dame Can Still Cancan
description: DEAUVILLE, FranceThe Dolly Sisters, the Empress Eugenie and the Folies legendary Mistinguett may long since have vanished from this elegant playground, but their places have been taken by a glittering retinue of titled Europeans, millionaires, government officials, movie stars, wouldbe movie stars anddespite Mayor Michel d'Ornano's observation that we are looking for the elite, not the massestens of thousands of ordinary Frenchmen and other tourists who want to get in on the action, be it at the casino, the race tracks, the polo field, the nightclubs or the boardwalk and beach.

title: Soviet Gets Plan to End Water Shortage
description: MOSCOW, May 15A leading Soviet expert on water resources called this week for a longrange program of conservation and for vast water diversion projects to assure future generations of an adequate supply.

title: For Young Readers; Sea Turtle Swims the Ocean; By William M. Stephens and Peggy Stephens. Illustrated by Ren Martin. 48 pp. Holiday House. $3.95. (Ages 6 to 10)
description: A smoothflowing text traces the life cycle of the green sea turtle, which roams the Caribbean from Florida to South America yet returns at spawning time to the beach where it hatched from the egg. Natural enemies include everything from sand crabs to man, whose voracity, probably equaled only by that of the mantis, may yet render this gentle reptile extinct.

title: Catherine Wriston to Be Wed To Richard Quintal in Summer
description: Miss Catherine Bigelow Wriston and Richard Martin Quintal have made plans to be married this summer.

title: Great on the gridiron, in the movies and in life
description: James Toback reveals as much about himself in this book as he does about his subject, Jim Brown. In fact, the book reads like an autobiographicalbiographical sensitivity encounter between Toback and Brown and, as the title suggests, Toback makes no bones about his underlying motivations for wanting to interview Brown. It is not merely because Brown is a great athlete and a great man, but because he is also a black man around whom exists an aura of mammoth sexuality.

title: Aura ofWhitman s Brooklyn Lives On
description: Beyond a name given to square off the public path, there are no physical reminders of Walt Whitman in the Brooklyn Heights he loved so much.

title: Elizabeth Birmingham Betrothed
description: SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., May 15Miss Elizabeth Gaillard Birmingham and Loyal Eldredge Leavenworth will be married June 19 in Norwalk.

title: Miss Decker Sets Wedding
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 15  Miss Katherine Louise Decker and Carlton Farquhar Andrus, who are with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in Washington, plan to be married there on July 31.

title: Binoculars? Blois Non! At Calcutta in Paris
description: PARIS, May 15 (UPI)Patrons crowding to see the American stage revue Oh, Calcutta! were told by the police today to check their binoculars at the door.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: $25,000 PACE WON BY RUM CUSTOMER
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 15Rum Customer, seeking to become the second pacer in history to earn $1million, won the $25,000 Lyss Hanover Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The 6yearold bay horse turned in the fastest clocking of the New York harness season, 2:00% for the mile.

title: WISSEL IS PRESENT AT RAMS'
description: Fordham held its annual Block F Dinner last night in what was to have been largely a gala evening of thanks to the Rams 197071 basketball team and its coach. But the coach was not present.

title: NOFAULT SYSTEM GAINS IN CONGRESS Bay State Insurance Plan Discussed in Both Houses
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Favorable reports from Massachusetts on its experiment in nofault automobile insurance have impressed Congressional committees without materially affecting the uncertain outlook for a Federal nofault law.

title: Lindsay Names 7 to Board Of Brooklyn Public Library
description: Mayor Lindsay has appointed four new members and reappointed three others to the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: Letters War Crime Trials (Continued)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Howlett Married
description: WINNETKA, Ill., May 15Miss Ruth Landry Howlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Porter Howlett, was married at her home here this afternoon to Christopher Morton Knowles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stinchfield Knowles. Both families reside here. The Rev. Lawrence Schwarz of the Winnetka Congregational Church performed the ceremony.

title: DAYCARE CENTER IS DELAYED ON L.I.
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 The financing by Nassau County of an integrated daycare center for underprivileged children in this affluent community is being delayed by prolonged court litigation.

title: Dartmouth Crew Wins 3d Packard Cup in Row
description: BOSTON, May 15Northeastern University's heavyweight crew won the Joe Burk Cup today by defeating the University of Pennsylvania on the Charles River in Cambridge, Mass. The Huskies rowed the 2,000meter course in 6 minutes 20.4 seconds, the Quakers in 6:24.3

title: Et Al.
description: A short account of the author's experience with open heart surgery in a New York hospital last year  originally published in The New Yorker. Absolutely a minimum of hard informationa pure New Yorker approach  shot through with little emotional gasps and details. The operation itself is frightening because much goes wrongnobody seems to know why. Miss MacKenzie's stay in Intensive Care is a nightmare  she develops mysterious complications. Gradually she gets better  enough to go home but not to be completely free of symptoms. For all its mannerisms, the memoir is affecting.

title: 2 Shows Canceled Last Year By Campus Unrest Come Back
description: After a year's absence, two hardy Long Island fixtures return to the dog show circuit next weekend. The Ladies Kennel Association of America holds its 65th allbreed event at Hofstra University in Hempstead Saturday, with an entry of 1,730. The Long Island Kennel Club's 69th show

title: About Motor Sports
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15Next to Gasoline Alley in Indianapolis Motor Speedway there is a cafeteria with two entrances. One is open to the public and the other is protected by a guard and a sign that says: Men Only. Inside, the division is maintained by a low wooden partition. Over the paging system of Gasoline Alley a voice intoned, Carl Haas, your mother would like to meet you at the rear gate. A woman member of a television crew started to enter Gasoline Alley and was ejected, politely but firmly.

title: U.S. Labor Aide Voices Hopes Of Averting Strike on Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The probability of a nationwide rail strike apparently receded slightly today after a series of meetings involving the signalmen's union, railroad operators and the Government.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTONShould there be an independent national cancer authority as proposed in a bill sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts? Should there be an independent cancer cure program within the National Institutes of Health as proposed last week by President Nixon?

title: Memoirs Of an Aesthete 19391969
description: Books that are constantly stolen from libraries should be republished in a special paperback series. Harold Acton's first volume of memoirs (19041939) is maddeningly scarce, it's been swiped from many public shelves, and a friend of mine even admitted the temptation to rip it off from I Tatti. This vastly enjoyable chronicle details Mr. Acton's Italian upbringing and his years as the mentor of his generation at Oxford, where he shouted his poems through a megaphone, celebrated Eliot and the Sitwells long before their popularity, edited new poets, defied pessimists and Philistines, and gave advice to fledgling collectors: Your etchings are the messes of a miserable masturbator.

title: U.N. OFFERS PLAN TO SOLVE DEFICIT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15A new financial plan for the debtburdened United Nations is being submitted to governments this week by Secretary General Thant and Edyard Hambro, President of the General Assembly.

title: Legislators Here Oppose Plan for 2 City Highways
description: ALBANY, May 15Brooklyn and Manhattan legislators, both Republicans and Democrats, are threatening to work for the defeat of Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue unless proposals for two road projects in the city are either drastically modified or deleted from a pending Rockefeller highway bill.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Education
description: Many of the young people who are applying to the nation's law schools in record numbers see the law as a tool to help the underprivileged and oppressed. At the same time, a growing faction in the legal profession is expressing doubts about the capacity of the law schools to respond to a demand for that kind of legal education.

title: Eastern Gets Mail Route
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board had given Eastern Airlines authority to carry mail, without subsidy, between Miami and Freeport, Grand Bahama Island.

title: Recordings
description: BELLINI'S first two operas were so successful when they were produced in Naples that his third, Ii Pirata, was given its premiere at La Scala in Milan, in 1827. The composer was not yet 26, and for one of that age it is a fine achievement. Thought to be the longest of his operas, it is not consistently absorbing, but it obviously merits the occasional revivals it has had in recent years, as well as the current threedisk recording on the Angel label.

title: Drama on a 5,280Foot Stage
description: Dom Rossi thinks Jim Ryun will beat Marty Liguori in their Dream Mile today at Franklin Field. Rossi is so confident of his choice that he made the following wagers with Pete Doelger, a friend:

title: Foreign Notes
description: Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the heart transplant pioneer, has been complaining in recent weeks about lack of cooperation from fellow doctors in Capetown who, he charged, have been sending patients home to die rather than letting them undergo transplants. In one tearful speech he even suggested that he might be forced to leave Capetown's Groote Schuur hospital, where he performed the world's first such surgery, unless matters changed. Said Dr. Barnard, Doctors at Groote Schuur do not share my view that heart transplantation is a medically acceptable form of treatment.

title: Television
description: EVERYONE knows that, except for the occasional prestige special, serious drama is pointedly ignored in the wonderland of television. Everyone also knows that the more experimental playwrights and directors have virtually been barred from the home screen.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Twins Send Down Barber
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 15 (AP)The Minnesota Twins exchanged righthanded pitchers with Portland today, calling up Pete Hamm from the Pacific Coast League farm club and sending down Steve Barber.

title: Medicine
description: When New York State passed a liberalized abortion law last summer, a new business was bornthe commercial abortion referral agency. Its function: To help a woman find a doctor or a hospital to perform an abortion.

title: Senator Mansfield's Folly
description: Senator Mansfield could not have chosen a more inopportune time to revive his effort to cut American forces in Europe in half by the end of the year. His amendment will surely be rejected next Wednesday unless the Senate has lost all sense of responsibility; but its mere introduction could harm nearly every ongoing negotiating effort by the United States and its allies.

title: STEW'S FLUTE HEARD WITH A BACKUP BAND
description: Jeremy Steig has been playing in relative obscurity long enough now, so that recognition is not only possible but necessary.

title: Shades of McCarthy
description: To the Editor:

title: LOSEN CAPTURES STAR CUSS SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 15 Frederick C. Losen of the Huntington Bay fleet sailed Hotspur to a 1minute 23second victory on a 7.3mile triangle on Long Island Sound today in the fourth race of the Western L.I.S. Star Class annual EyeOpener regatta.

title: Kirkland College Will Get Anonymous $2Million Gift
description: CLINTON, N.Y., May 15 A $2million gift from an anonymous donor has been pledged to Kirkland College, liberal arts college for women, Samuel F. Babbitt, the college president announced today.

title: Gift of $3Million Is Pledged for L.I. Health Institute
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 15A $3million gift has been pledged by Saul P. and Julius Steinberg toward the construction of Long Island's first Institute for Community Health at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center here.

title: Miss Morse Illinois Bride
description: WJNNETKA, Ill., May 15  Miss Margaret Levis Morse was married here this afternoon to Lawrence Howe Delafield. The bride is descended from the Duc de Levis, and the bridegroom from Gen. William Howe, adversaries in the French and Indian War.

title: L. C. Anderson Becomes Fiance Of Miss Taylor
description: RENO, May 15  The engagement of Miss Karen Elizabeth Taylor to Lawrence Clarke Anderson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Gidney, stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of State Senator and Mrs. Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, N. Y.

title: Cosmopolitan black and provincial blacktwo political styles
description: Until recently Negro political leadership was recruited largely from the middle and upper classes. Whether within or outside the South the process of mediating blackwhite political relationships as been a bourgeois affair. This is not, after all, surprising. The black bourgeoisie possessed not only the skills and experiences required of political leadership, but were more acculturated to white American institutions, political and others. This did not mean, however, that talented individuals of the Negro lower classes never achieved political leadership. They did, but they were exceptions, usually of lower middleclass or skilled, working class occupations like artisan and shopkeeper.

title: Plea Is Pressed for Park in Sunnyside
description: On one of those brightly colored maps, the Sunnyside, Woodside and Maspeth areas of Queens look as if they ought to be collectively called Green Acres.

title: HIGHER PRICES SEEN BECAUSE OF DROUGHT
description: Fresh vegetables, bread and cereals and even meat may eventually cost the housewife more because of the drought in the South and Southwest ?? Farmers are already feeling the pinch.

title: The World
description: CAIROWhen Egypt was left temporarily adrift last September by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, United States experts tried to look into the future to determine who could rule the country after 18 years of his strong and mesmeric leadership.

title: THRONGS IN CAIRO CHEER PRESIDENT AND BERATE FOES
description: CAIRO, May 15Their emotions aroused by President Anwar elSadat's dramatic narration last night of a conspiracy to overthrow him, tens of thousands of Egyptians demonstrated today in the streets of Cairo.

title: Puerto Rico Names a Coach
description: MEMPHIS, May 15 (AP)Gene Bartow, Memphis State basketball coach, was named today to coach the Puerto Rican team in the PanAmerican Games in August.

title: ServanSchreiber: What Shall We Do?
description: PARISToward what priorities do we intend to direct the genius of our savants and our technicians?

title: Helen Morrison, Teacher, Fiancee
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 15  Mr. and Mrs. Maxey Neal Morrison have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Dana Morrison, to William M. Moore, son of Mrs. Leslie Moore of St. Johnsbury, Vt., and the late Mr. Moore.

title: TWO CREWS TIED IN MATCH RACING
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 The State Maritime College, represented by Graham M. Hall, its sailing instructor, and the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, with James D. McNitt as skipper, each won two races on Long Island Sound today and will sail against each other tomorrow in the final round of the club's second annual interclub matchracing regatta for the Greenwich Cup.

title: Lytton Strachey
description: To the Editor:

title: Stamps
description: HISTORIC Preservation will be the theme of a block of four United States commemorative stamps to be issued Oct. 29 at San Diego, Calif. The release coincides with the annual conference of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a national, private organization chartered by Congress to direct historic preservations.

title: They're Calm but Die Younger
description: Single people, long thought to be the victims of all sorts of psychological stresses, may be less afflicted by the pressures of every day living than their married counterparts.

title: Sadowsky Stands Astride 2 Factions
description: Queens sent Edward L. Sadowsky to the City Council in 1961 as one of the original liberal Democratic reformers. But the City Council has sent Mr. Sadowsky back to Queens as one of its inner circle of leaders, one who is trusted by and works closely with the regular Democratic establishment.

title: A Coach Is Up Against the Wall
description: Thomas G. Kudzma teaches mathematics at the Lowell Technological Institute, Lowell, Mass., and coaches the crew there on a voluntary basis. He also designs posters that publicize regattas and recall the days a century ago when rowing was an eminent spectator sport.

title: The Schizophrenic Azores
description: VILA DO PORTO, Santa Maria Island, the Azores  Some time ago, two Swedish cruise ships, two French warships and one American Navy vessel arrived almost simultaneously at nearby Sao Miguel Island. With a sign in the harbor proclaiming in four languages Welcome to Ponta Delgada and thousands of wellheeled sightseers scrambling ashore, the local shopkeepers, fearing trouble, peremptorily shut down.

title: 3 Rebels Killed, Ceylon Says
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 15. (Reuters)Security forces have captured an insurgent camp at Anuradhapura in North Central Province yesterday, killing three rebels and capturing six, an Army spokesman said today.

title: Goose Goslin, Outfielder, Dead; Elected to Hall of Fame in 1968
description: BRIDGETON, N.J., May 15 (AP)Goose Goslin, who was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame in 1968 died at Bridgeton Hospital today. He was 70 years old. The former hardhitting American League outfielder had undergone surgery for removal of his larynx last July.

title: Tours and Plant Sales
description: THE 18th annual House and Garden tour for the benefit of the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine of New York University Medical Center will be held Thursday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Outstanding homes in Ridgefield, Conn., Waccabuc, N. Y., and the Beinecke Gardens in Greenwich, Conn., will be visited. Box luncheon ($3) will be served by advance reservation at the Waccabuc Country Club. Tickets are $10. For further information in the New York area contact: Mrs. Edna Blankfort, OR 93200, ext. 2006; in Westchester County, Mrs. Price H. Topping, 914 TE 41897.

title: Wilson Says U.S. Undercut 67 Move With Kosygin to Set Up Vietnam Talks
description: LONDON, May 15  Harold Wilson, the former Labor party Prime Minister, says that he and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union came close to arranging Vietnam peace talks in February, 1967, but were sabotaged by the White House.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 15I see by the papers that you're raising the price of stamps again.

title: Civilian Gets Top U.S. Post In Central Area of Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15 (AP)  The United States command annonuced today that a civilian, John Paul Vann, was taking over as the senior American representative in South Vietnam's Central Highlands and central coastal provinces. It is the first time since the major troop buildup in 1965 that this post has been given to a civilian.

title: Miss McCarthy Explains
description: [JeanFrancois Revel, author of the recent Neither Marx nor Jesus (a great success in France, to be published here in the fall) conducted this interview with Miss McCarthy in her apartment near the Gare Montparnasse. In seven years, M. Revel said, I had been in Mrs. West's flat [Miss McCarthy is married to James West] only at night, for parties and dinners. It looked strange to me in the daylightsmaller, quiet and proincial. He used a tape recorder, which, he said, gave a professional, technotronic side to our conversation. M. Revel also pointed out that although he has taken part in many interviews this was the first in which he was the interviewer.]

title: Mrs. Katharine Bahnson Wed In South to John de Braganca
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., May 15  Mrs. Katharine King Bahnson, widow of Agnew Hunter Bahnson Jr., was married here at noon today to John M. de Braganca, a greatgrandson of King Miguel, who ruled Portugal from 1828 to 1834. The Rev. James C. Hughes performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Reynolda Presbyterian Church.

title: B.C. Lions Sign U.S. Player
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, May 15 (AP)  The British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League signed Brooks Thomas, former Mississippi State guard today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, May 15 (Reuters)India accused Pakistani today of deliberately forcing two million Pakistanis to flee to India and said the solution) could lead to a threat to peace in south Asia. The Indian Government, in a note, called for an end to what it termed a campaign of terror by the Pakistani Army against refugees.

title: Miss Kate Butler Righter. Bride In Buffalo of Donald J. Zammit
description: BUFFALO, May 15  Miss Kale Butler Righter, daughter of James H. Righter, publisher of The Buffalo Evening News, and Mrs. Righter, was married here today to Donald Joseph Zammit, who served as a sergeant with the First Air Cavalry in Vietnam. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Domenic Zammit of New York.

title: For Young Readers; Thor; Last of the Sperm Whales. By Robert M. McClung. Illustrated by Bob Hines. 64 pp. William Morrow. $3.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: The decimation and gradual extinction of the oceans onceawesome whale herds by modern whalers is the emerging theme of this case history of a 68foot bull sperm whale. The tale begins with the creature's birth off the Hawaiian Islands in 1930 and ends with a narrow escape from a Japanese whaling crew in the North Pacific in 1970. A skillful dramatization of ecological facts.

title: Coach of Sacred Heart High Captures A.A.U. Decathlon
description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 15 Richie Robinson, track coach at Sacred Heart High School in Yonkers, won a twoday Amateur Athletic Union Olympic Development decathlon today with 6,449 points.

title: Diana Le Lievre to Wed Saturday
description: Miss Diana Louise Le Lievre and Richard H. Cordes plan to be married outofdoors at Mackinac Island, Mich., next Saturday.

title: Officials in Washington Believe Sadat Is Riding Out the Crisis
description: WASHINGTON. May 15American official and diplomatic sources said today that they tended to believe that President Anwar elSadat was successfully riding out the political crisis in Egypt.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass.Men and boys armed with clip nets were congregated below the Mill Pond Dam on the Marston Mills River, happily capturing spawning alewives that were surging upstream from Prince Bay, but I was after the pinkfleshed brown and rainbow trout in nearby Hamblin Pond.

title: Arizona Backs Vote at 18; 10 More States Needed
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 15 (AP)The Arizona Senate approved 24 to 3 yesterday a House resolution ratifying proposed United States Constitutional amendment to give 18yearolds the right to vote in state as well as Federal elections.

title: Maternity Center Unit Elects New President
description: The election of Mrs. S. S. Marshall 3d as president of the Maternity Center Association was announced yesterday. She succeeds Mrs. Donald S. Woofer, who served for three years.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: AS a playwright, I can appreciate the problems Patricia Bosworth faced in writing her article on me; I can appreciate the effort to fabricate a coherence from an essentially disjointed interview; I can understand the inclination to strengthen a statement by omitting its qualifications; I know the temptation to bow to an audience rather than yield to the reality of the subject.

title: Kathleen Therese Amend Is Bride
description: Miss Kathleen Therese Amend was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard Kenneth Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Collins of Yonkers. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More by the Rev. Gerard C. Reedy, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Slurs to Be Cut From Welfare Residency Bill
description: ALBANY, May 15The preamble to a bill requiring a oneyear residency for persons applying for welfare in the state is being rewritten to delete wording found objectionable by black and Puerto Rican legislators.

title: Market Pause Due?; Down Trend Followed By Rally Is Favored
description: Many a money manager and Wall Street analyst, were he given the chance to write the stock market's script over the next couple of months, would borrow from the Rip Van Winkle plot.

title: POPULATION DROP A WORRY IN LISBON
description: LISBON. May 15The Portuguese are fearful that a population decrease could jeopardize this developing country's plans for economic expansion.

title: Teacher's Clothing Set Afire by 3 Girls In School in Bronx
description: A 24yearold teacher in Public School 73 in the Bronx was hospitalized with seconddegree burns Friday after three students set her clothing on fire, the police reported yesterday.

title: JACKSON HEIGHTS PRODS PLANNERS
description: The city's plan to give parkstarved Jackson Heights a minipool and playground sounded fine, but it turned out to be rather noxious notion to some residents.

title: No No Billy Wins by Head
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (AP)No No Billy, ridden by Robert Breen, got up in the final stride to defeat the favored Great Mystery by a head in the $20,000 Co. Matt Winn Handicap at Arlington Park today.

title: Mail:
description: To the Editor: When a person comes from the Old World to live in the New he expects from preconceptions to find a land of extremes in many aspects of life.

title: Civic Groups Hear Mayor and Say Pressure Is Needed to Induce City to Act
description: More than 1,500 representatives of civic and community organizations in the five boroughs were called together by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to discuss neighborhood improvemeat, and many of them insisted that pressure had to be applied to get results.

title: Pop
description: ANYONE who may have been startled to find that Follies could elicit such extreme expressions of divergent viewpoints as have appeared in these pages in recent weeks, is not likely to discover an explanation for either extreme in the original cast recording of the musical on the Capitol label.

title: G.I. Heroin Addiction Epidemic in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 15The use of heroin by American troops in Vietnam has reached epidemic proportions.

title: The Annual Meeting Of the Corporation
description: SHAWNEE, Okla., May 14 The annual meeting of the National Refractory & Brake. Company took place here today in an atmosphere that longtime observers of corporate meetings said was more hostile than any they could remember. Fisticuffs were narrowly avoided at several points when shareholders stormed the dais to charge that the giant petrochemical firm was behind the times in its awareness of social issues.

title: Martin Andrews Weds Miss Elizabeth Scott
description: Miss Elizabeth Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Scott of London, was married there yesterday to Martin Andrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Erskine Andrews of New York. The Rev. Richard Incledon, Roman Catholic chaplain at Cambridge University, performed the ceremony in Ealing Abbey at noon.

title: Letters:
description: To THE Editor:

title: CAMPUS POLICIES FOUGHT IN COURT
description: Two Queens College seniors, both members of the conservative Young Americans for Free dom, have chosen lawsuits instead of demonstrations to change campus policies.

title: For Young Readers; The Mother Beaver; By Edith Thacher Hurd. Illustrated by Clement Hurd. 32 pp. Little, Brown. $3.95. (Ages 6 to 8)
description: The reproductive cycle in a beaver colony is described in a graceful narrative. The language, while easy enough for beginners, manages both to convey feeling and to avoid the wooden quality that is such a hazard with a simple vocabulary.

title: Whips Crack 9 Homers In a Game, bat Lose
description: There's no way mathematically three can equal nine, but the Winnipeg Whips of the International League have proof it does in baseball.

title: Revson Sets Indianapolis Mark With 178.696 M.P.H. in Trial
Busy Sail Season Ahead for Long Island Sound
description: With the MidSound chempionship season of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound ready to hit the waves next Saturday and Sunday and the first of the Long Island Multihull Association regattas set for next weekend, plus the Y.R.A. distance racing schedule already under way through Oct. 17, weekend sailors may find the Sound as crowded as Times Square at rush hour this summer.

title: Kennedy Passes Muskie in Poll As 1972 Choice of Democrats
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has moved ahead of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine as the choice of registered Democrats for the Presidential nomination in 1972, according to the latest Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

title: RUINS WIDEN PICTURE OF PERSIAN EMPIRE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15The archeological picture of the early beginnings of the ancient Persian Empire, which at its height ruled most of the Middle East and parts of India, has been considerably broadened by the discovery at a small town on the coastal plain of the Persian Gulf.

title: Lissa Waite Bride Of Robert Weller
description: NEW HAVEN, May 15Miss Lissa Waite, daughter of William Gilman Waite, the Henry L. and Lucy G. Moses Professor of Music at Yale University, and Mrs. Waite, was married here today to Robert Weller, a member of the class of 72 at the Yale Law School. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Weller of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: Gallagher, Defensive End At Yale, Signed by Vikings
description: Jim Gallagher, Yale's allEast and allIvy defensive end for the last two seasons, has signed with the Minnesota Vikings of the National Football League. Gallagher, a threeyear letterman, was a 14thround draft choice by the Vikings, who will try him as a linebacker.

title: A time of pain and anger, gentleness and decency in Mississippi
description: Social problems are essentially boring. If they contain elements of sex and violence, they have a chance of being popular for a while; but even with those things going for them, Great Issues soon become stale. Our flagging interest in yesterday's causes can only be revived, if at all, by some horrible new development, preferably involving bloodshed. The war in Vietnam had become a public bore until the invasion of Laos, which wakened us back into fiery protest for about 10 days. Martin Luther King, in his reasoned, steady campaign to uplift the conditions of his people (and therefore of all of us) had become a hohum figure, a passe personage, until he was slain and thus elevated into the sure popularity of martyrdom.

title: Penn Trackmen Take First Heptagonal Title in 30 Years, With Princeton
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15Thwarted in last year's controversial meet, Pennsylvania won its first outdoor Heptagonal team title in 30 years today.

title: NORTHERN LASSIE TAKES TWO TITLES
description: THREE BRIDGES, N. J., May 15Dr. H. B. Steinbach's Northern Lassie captured two championships  one on hackoff  and finished as the reserve titleholder in another division today at the Hunt Cap Farm's horse show.

title: To a Texan's taste
description: There are certain dishes that haunt the minddeliciously. And one of them is roast kid. Several years ago, we dined at the ranch of the Dudley Doughertys in Beeville, Tex. The Dougherty kitchen, was presided over by Rosa de in Garza, who turned talented Mexican hand to preparing roasted baby goat with a wellseasoned northoftheborder sauce flavored with tomatoes and cumin seeds.

title: CANNES SINGS PRAISE FOR HEART MURMUR
description: CANNES, France, May 15Louis Malle's 11th film, Heart Murmur, a chronicle of adolescence with accidental incest between a mother and her 15yearold son, was cheered and warmly applauded by capacity audience at the Cannes Film Festival. The film is the first of the four French entries.

title: Home Furnishings Industry Goes Big Time
description: New corporate giants, well financed, aggressive and largely formed by acquisitions, are thrusting their way up through the traditionally conservative surface of the American home furnishings industry.

title: Coins
description: THIS is Senior Citizens Month and the special exhibition at the American Numismatic Society Museum, assembled to honor this city's residents, is a most impressive one. All the items on displaymonies, medals, tokens and artwere carefully selected and arranged for the exhibit by the society's curators with the interests of New York's seniors in mind.

title: USE OF WATER CUT IN SOUTH FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, May 15Water rationing began in parts of South Florida this week when saltwater from the Atlantic Ocean threatened to contaminate the underground water supply.

title: Tanzania, in good of Leftist Urgency, Seizes Property and Attempts to Rally People
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 9After a long period of relative political somnolence, leftwing forces seem to be increasingly in command of this East African nation of 13 million.

title: Blue Cross Increase Sought
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)Bluel Cross of Massachusetts is seeking rate increases of about 33 per cent far nanaroup subscribers, which could raise a monthly charge for a family by $9.02.

title: Black Students at Former White School in Detroit Learn Racial Pride Along With 3R's
description: DETROIT, May 15The Hampton School sits in the center of Detroit's old Silk Stocking district on the city's west side, surrounded by streets lined with elms and threestory homes. The motivated children of the welltodo middleclass made the school one of the city's best. and men like George Romney still reminisce fondly about the schooling their children received there.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MORONI, Comoro ArchipelagoWith the exception of the Portuguese empire, which lingers on like some political dodo bird, there are few imperial relics left in this revolutionary age and it is questionable whether any, even British Gibraltar or French Djibouti, have real value.

title: WAXWORKS PLANS AROUSE SINGAPORE
description: SINGAPORE, May 10  It took General Tomoyuki Yamashita and his imperia?? Japanese forces 70 days to march down the Malay peninsula to Singapore, where on Feb. 15, 1942, he accepted the surrender of Gen. A. E. Percival, commander of the defending British forces.

title: RIZZO CONFIDENT OF EASY VICTORY
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15Representative William J. Green, produced a wave of endorsements from nationally prominent liberals this week in his campaign to upset former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo in the Democratic Mayoralty primary next Tuesday.

title: Jenkins Homers and Notches 7th Victory as. Cubs Overcome Padres, 6 to 4
Patricia Bobermin Bride
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 15Miss Patricia Elizabeth Bobermin and Alexander Charles Sutherland 2d were married today in the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy here. The Rev. James D. Ford, the Protestant chaplain, performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mts. Robert Bobermin of East Greenbush. Mr. Bobermin is manager of the New York State Records Center in Albany. The bridegroom is the son of Col. E. V. V. Sutherland, U.S.A., who is chairman of the English department at the Military Academy. In July the bridegroom plans to join Nazareth College as admissions officer and as an instructor in English.

title: U.S. Aide Terms Greece Loyal Ally of Atlantic Pact
description: LONDON, May 15 (AP)The Greek militarybacked regime] has been a loyal ally of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Martin J. Hillenbrand, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, said today.

title: Activist Who's Trying to Slow Down
description: The chairman of next Thursday's benefit concert at Lincoln Center for Jazzmobile has threatened to retire, and, if Mrs. Harold C. Haizlip carries out her threat, the city will lose the involvement of one of its most dynamic young activists.

title: Women Stars to Play Big Roles In National Golf Day Tourneys
description: National Golf Day, the sport's own philanthropic project, is wholeheartedly endorsed by the United States Golf Association. The annual event, which begins tomorrow and lasts four weeks, will have something new this year.

title: Antismoking Hour Set By Philadelphia Suburb
description: MEDIA, Pa., May 15 (AP) This Philadelphia suburb of 5,800 residents has set aside an hour a day for an antismoking drive.

title: Boston Writers Protest TV Ball Pen Invasion
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)The Boston baseball writers said they would protest to the president, Joe Cronin, because of a television invasion of the Baltimore bull pen during today's game with the Red Sox.

title: JETS GRANTHAM SIGNS 12TH PACT
description: The New York Jets signed pair of University of MississipI pi products, Larry Grantham and Vernon Studdard, for 1971, the head coach and general manager, Weeb Ewbank, announced yesterday.

title: Nancy Willa Pasachoff Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Pasachoff of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Willa Pasachoff, to Marc Leslie Kutner, son of Mrs. Samuel J. Nachwalter of Riverdale, the Bronx and Lake Peekskill, N. Y., and the late Edwin Kutner of Brooklyn.

title: BRAZILIANS SET UP INFORMATION UNIT
description: Foreign Minister Mario Gibson Barboza of Brazil said here yesterday that his Government had set up a committee with the task of clarifying information, whether it is positive or negative to combat a systematic campaign of distortion about his country in the foreign press.

title: SPARKMAN BOAT WINS CONNECTICUT RACE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 Only the Soling Class was ready today for the first championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association season for Connecticut area fleets, based eastofRye, off Riverside Yacht Club.

title: LETTERS
description: To The Financial Editor: I was disappointed that the serious pollution problem that Wrigley and other gum manufacturers have created was not mentioned in Seth S. King's article about Wrigley (May 9).

title: ELMER J. HOARE, 68 ESTATE SPECIALIST
description: Elmer J. Hoare, a senior partner in the law firm of Turk, Marsh, Kelly & Hoare, 666 Fifth Avenue, died Friday at his home, 201 East 79th Street at the age of 68.

title: Cassette Tours: Electronic Era In Sightseeing
