description: AS their car enters Glacier National Park at West Glacier, Mont., Mrs. Peter Caldwell pushes the on button and the air is suddenly filled with a fanfare reminiscent of the opening of a Walt Disney wildlife film. Presently a narrator introduces himself and invites his audience to join him in a tour of the park. Mr. Caldwell is driving; his wife is beside him in the front seat; Billy, 13 years old, and Betty, 11, are in the back.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: I wish to address my remarks to statement made by David Elkind in his remarkably fair article on Wilhelm Reich. A small matter in light of Reich's turbulent life, however in all fairness to A. S. Neill, Summerhill is not a school for adolescents run along Reichian lines.

title: Atlanta Beats Rochester In Soccer League Test, 10
description: ROCHESTER, May 15 (AP)Atlanta took a 20 lead in the first half and went on to scare a 31 victory over Rochester tonight in a North American Soccer League contest.

title: The Last Word: That Khrushchev Book
description: There is a persistent rumor of plans by TimeLife and Little, Brown to bring out a second volume of Khrushchev's reminiscences. The temptation must be great, for the first volume has been resounding commercial success, perhaps the biggest international publishing deal in history, and it is variously but reliably reported that there still remain up to 150,000 words of unused material. Yet if the publishers are hesitating, they have good reasons. Now that the smoke has cleared from the initial blitz of publicrelations hoopla and speculation, scholars have begun to demonstrate that the book is questionable from beginning to end.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his San Clemente press conference (news story May 2) President Nixon emphasized a favorite economic theme of the Administration; namely, that the current prolonged spell of high unemployment is an inevitable consequence of the shift from a war economy to a peace economy. We have not had full employment, he said, except in wartime. This is a dangerous error of economic theory and history, a Marxist criticism of American society which is surprising to hear from a President.

title: L.I. Surgery Clinic Opened To Treat Disorders of Hand
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 15A handsurgery clinic has opened at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center here.

title: ACES LEAD FRENCH IN BRIDGE FINALS
Bill Would Not Allow Discharge of Addicts
description: WASHINGTON, May 15Representative John M. Monagan, Democrat of Connecticut, has introduced legislation in the House that would require the military to certify that servicemen being discharged from active duty are free from drug addiction.

title: For Young Readers; Dolphins; By Martha and Robert Moffett. Photographs. 85 pp. Franklin Watts. $3.75. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: A charming subject covered from head to tail in straightforward, simple prose. Along with the account of scientific investigation into the dolphin's intelligence and responsiveness, enough interesting speculation is thrown in to give readers something to think about on their own.

title: Thank God les Thursday! Coming Soon? The FourDay Week; BOSTON.
description: CROSS the country, some 20,000 blueand whitecollar workers are demonstrating that the fourday week is no longer a figment of a union organizer's imagination. They are members of the ThankGodR'sThursday Club: they get every Friday off in addition to Saturdays and Sundays.

title: TRIBUTE PAID HERE TO ARMED FORCES
description: With their flags flapping in a steady breeze and their brass buttons glinting in the bright sun, 10,000 of the nation's military men and women marched clown Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in the 22d Armed Forces Day Parade.

title: Genetic Counseling Centers Established in New England
description: BOSTON, May 15 (AP)Three genetic counseling and treatment centers are being opened in New England, the National Genetics Foundation has announced.

title: Manhattan country house
description: Strollers along Manhattan's Upper East Side are often amazedand charmedto find two clapboard houses with verandas and tiny front yards sandwiched between their brownstone neighbors. The two frame houses are landmarks that have stood virtually unchanged since before the Civil War. Tom Morrow, partner in the fabric firm Hannett Morrow Fischer, bought the smaller one (opposite page) eight years ago. Except for walling in doorways to get more wall space, he left the parlor floor very much as it was 1859. Downstairs, Morrow removed paneling installed in the 1900's to expose the brick walls, the fireplace and ceiling beams. He also modernized the kitchen. The back stoop was given a skylighted roof and turned into a conservatory. The house retains its country delights, despite the city sprawling around it.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  A group of national civil rights leaders, jolted by a series of reverses in their long fight for open communities, met in New York last week in an effort to find a way to pick up the pieces. They decided to start a grass roots campaign in behalf of their cause a sure sign that they have found the situation to be bleak.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As Willie Mays and Henry Aaron creep closer to the once unapproachable home run record of Babe Ruth, interest quickens and speculation mpunts with the realization that these twin terrors have finally broughtthe unattainable within reach. The Ruthian total of 714 homers no longer lies beyond the distant horizon.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Prof. David Elkind's article has managed to elevate Wilhelm Reich to the level of nearrespectability his followers sorely need. Although the author's dispassionate critique may find some good in this tragic man's psychiatric studies, it is an error of the first magnitude to assume the same about his scientific efforts. The best yardstick with which to judge Reich in this area is to question how far his ideas would have gotten had he not been a famous, and admittedly brilliant, student of Freud's.

title: When New York Made It
description: Exactly a century ago, four men were born who made things diff erent in Americasuch things as our fiction and painting and music and poetry. They were Stephen Crane, Theodore Dreiser, John Sloan and James Weldon Johnson. In 1871 Crane was born in New Jersey, Methodist minister's son; Dreiser in Indiana, a German. Catholic immigrant's son; Sloan in Pennsylvania, a failed salesman's son, and Johnson in Florida, a black headwaiter's son. They became, in a sense, the first New Yorkers.

title: ExPriest Gets College Post
description: UNION, N. J., May 15Dr, Laurance A. Dorr, a former Jesuit priest and associate dean of the School of Education at Central Michigan University, has been named vice president for academic affairs at Newark State College here, effective July 1. In 1967 Dr. Darr left the priesthood and the Jesuit order, of which he had been a member for 22 years. He married in 1968 and he and his Joyce, have a daughter, Maria.

title: Mrs. Mowbray Rewed
description: BRANFORD, Conn., May 15 Mrs. Cynthia Burt Mowbray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Burt of New York and Hailey, Idaho, was married here today to Bruce E.rnest Beebe, son of Mr. and mrs. Ernest C. Beebe of Bronxville, N. Y., and Golden Beach, Fla. The ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. James F. Martin, The bridegroom is associate editor with Business International in New York. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce,

title: Nixon Wins Wide Backing On Troop Total in Europe
description: KEY BISCAYNE. Fla., May 15The White House today won the endorsement of 24 former high ranking public servants  including former President Lyndon B. Johnsonof a Presidential statement asserting that the unilateral withdrawal of American troops from Europe would constitute an error of historic dimensions.

title: Medicine
description: Opponents of the proliferation of nuclear power plants being built to meet the country's growing energy needs are making the most of the testimony of a scientist who argues that such projects are babykillers.

title: For Young Readers; Talking With The Animals; By Daniel Cohen. Photographs. 134 pp. Dodd, Mead. $3.95. (Ages 11 to 15)
description: A survey of man's recurrent dreams of talking with the other creatures, starting with hoaxes and legends and ending with scientific experiments. Touched briefly but clearly are communications among apes, whales, birds and bees as well as man's attempts to break through to the apes and dolphins. Answers some questions, stimulates even more.

title: DR. ABDUL ABBASS, EXIRAQI OFFICIAL
description: CARBONDALE, Ill., May 15 Dr. Abdul Majid Abbass, former Iraqi official who since 1962 had been a professor of government at Southern Illinois University, died today at his home. He was 59 years old.

title: Dance: Nothing Wasted
description: It would be ridiculous to call any ballet  particularly a ballet barely past its second birthday  the world's greatest; ridiculous and meaningless. But I have no doubt that, at least at present, my favorite ballet, and the one that gives the most continuing pleasure, is Jerome Robbins's Dances at a Gathering.

title: Young Peoples Symphony Presents Two Soloists
description: An anonymous bomb threat at intermission bliefly clouded the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra concert in Philharmonic Hall Saturday afternoon. Alter a thorough search of the evacuated Auditorium, the program continued without incident.

title: State Maritime Wins
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 16 The New York State Mari time College at Fort Schuyler won the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's second annual interclub matchracing regatta for the Greenwich Cup today.

title: Nguyen Cao Ky: On the Sinking Boat
description: SAIGON, South VietnamSouth Vietnam is like a sinking boat, with deceptively good coat of paint outside, and a helmsman who is unfaithful, disloyal, and dishonest. A whirl of wind and the boat will sink to the bottom.

title: Castle's Soogie Moogie Takes Overnight Race on L.I. Sound
Miss Erica Kessler Is Bride Here
description: Miss Erica Margo Kessler was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Lodish. Rabbi Cyrus Arfa performed the ceremony at the Post Chapel at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

title: Candidates and Their 71 Budgets
description: Four Democratic Senators are actively raising Presidential campaign funds in New York City, according to party sources. Those candidates, their 1971 campaign budgets, and some of their key New York financial representatives are:

title: Kennedy Sets Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced today that he would hold hearings May 2527 to hear testimony of representatives of five Presidential and other national commissions that have studied civil disorders, campus unrest and obscenity. The hearings will concern Federal implementation of the commissions recommendations.

title: Bridge: Aces Seem Certain to Keep Title in World Play in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 16The Aces headed confidently for victory over France in the world championship final here today. They began the day with a lead of 44 international match points, most of which was acquired in a burst of three deals in the first session last night.

title: 4 Democratic Contenders Raise Curtainin Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, May 16Four of the leading contenders for the Presidential nomination were paraded last night before Wisconsin Democrats.

title: HOTA IS WINNER OF U.S. SOCCER CUP
description: LOS ANGELES, May 16 Efforts that lasted for 49 years finally paid off for New York Hota today as the team captured the United States soccer championship for the first time.

title: 3 More Cars. Qualify for Indianapolis 500 Race, Increasing Number to
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16 Three more cars qualified today for the Indianapolis 500 race, bringing to 26 the number that have earned starting positions in the 55th running of the annual event on May 29.

title: Chief of the Mounties William Leonard Higgitt
description: OTTAWA, May 16When William Leonard Higgitt was appointed Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police 18 months ago, very few Canadians outside the civil police force he had served for 32 years knew the name.

title: Navajo Leader Exhorts Indians To End Dependence on Others
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 16  Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Indian Nation, said at a conference here that American Indians were being encouraged to leave the reservations and join the mainstream of American life, but that your scientists and colleges tell us that the mainstream is polluted.

title: Boost for Peacekeeping
description: Interest in the twoChina recommendations of the President's Commission on the United Nations has tended to obscure other important proposals in its recent report. Among these is the suggestion that the United States undertake bold new initiatives to revitalize the peacekeeping and peacemaking capabilities of the U.N.

title: Republic in Soviet Regains A District From Neighbor
description: MOSCOW, May 16In an unusual shortcutting of constitutional procedure, the Soviet Union's Republic of Kazakhstan announced this week that it had reassumed control of a rich irrigated cotton district it ceded to the neighboring Uzbek Republic eight years ago.

title: Firebomb Near Synagogue
description: A Molotov cocktail was dropped on the sidewalk opposite a Flatbush synagogue yesterday afternoon, but it apparently burned out without injuring anyone the police said. The bottle was found across the street from the Jewish Center of Hyde Park, 779 East 49th Street, near Avenue D. A synagogue official told the police passing motorist had seen three youths drop the bottle on the sidewalk and flee.

title: Chess: Spassky Defeat of Larsen Wins Poll on Top Matches
Miss Kellog Rides Sienna To Show Title at C. W. Post
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 16 Sienna, a 5yearold brown mare owned by Mill Pond Farms and ridden by Fernanda Kellogg of New York, won the green working hunter title and finished as reserve champion to Mrs. Carol Ann Ostrov's Dancing Along in the amateurowner hunter division today at the first Sigma Delta Pi, horse show at C. W. Post College.

title: Board Asks Defeat of a Bill Retaining 4 Specialized Schools Entrance Tests
Missiles Fired at Gunship
description: SAIGON, May 16 (Reuters)North Vietnamese gunners fired two surfacetoair missiles at an American AC130 gunship as it flew over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos today, the United States command reported.

title: Columbus, Ind., Grows Used to Its Fine Architecture
description: COLUMBUS, Ind, May 16 On your left, ladies and gentlemen, the striking green sign of Early Holiday Inn Period. And on your right, the fabled orange roof sometimes known as Classic Howard Johnson.

title: Chinese Powdered Milk Arrives in East Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May, 16  The Government reported that a Chinese transport plane carrying powdered milk from Peking arrived in Dacca, East Pakistan, today. to help victims of the recent strife there.

title: SAIGON CUTS OFF CAMBODIAN NEWS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16South Vietnamese military authorities have moved to stop the flow of what they contend is inaccurate press information about operations in Cambodia.

title: G.I.'s Find It All in Saigon's Scag Alley
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam May 16  Wartime overcrowding created the twisting, narrow lane and the mean, cramped cinderblock houses that line it, but it is scag, or heroin, that gave it its G.I. nameScag Alleyand that attracts the bored and unhappy American servicemen from nearby Tansonnhut Air Base.

title: Battle for Fox Control Nearing an End
description: The battle for control of Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation comes to a head tomorrow morning when stockholders will decide whether to return the present management to office or install a new team proposed by a group of insurgents.

title: SEALY GOLF WON BY MISS PALMER
CHILEANS DONATE ONE DAY OF WORK
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 16President Salvador Allende Gossens hammered a few nails today at a houseraising in the Che Guevara encampment as he led Chile in a national day of voluntary labor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Le Duan Leaves China
description: HONG KONG, May 16 (Reuters)  The North Vietnamese Communist chief, Le Duan, has left China for Hanoi after a long tour which took him to the Soviet Union and China, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

title: Leningrad Trial Hears Plea for
description: MOSCOW, May 16  Mark Y. Dymshits, a leader of the 12man group convicted last year of planning to flee abroad by, hijacking a small Soviet plane, was reported today to have testified that the nine Leningrad Jews now on trial had nothing to do with that abortive hijacking plan.

title: Libel Suit Threatened In Israel Over Lansky
description: TEL AVIV, May 16  A newspaper item indicating that the reputed underworld figure from the United States, Meyer Lansky, has an interest in Israel's leading hotel chain resulted this weekend in a threat of a $285,000 libel suit.

title: CHARLES DANIEL, 92, OWNED ART GALLERY
description: Charles Daniel, a former New York art dealer, who helped many artists start their careers with exhibitions in his gallery, died Friday at a nursing home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived at 172 Myrtle Boulevard, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: S. A. Goodman, Financial Aide, Marries Suzanne L. Grossman
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., May 16 Miss Suzanne Lynn Grossman and Stephen Arnold Goodman were married here at noon today.

title: YOUNG BREAKS MARK IN U.S. 5,000 METERS
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., May 16 (UPI)George Young, a threetime competitor in the Olympics, set an American record in the 5,000meter run last night with a mark of 13 minutes 32.2 seconds in the meet dedicating a new Tartan track at Bakersfield College Stadium.

title: BANKS CONSIDER PRIMERATE RISE
description: The sharp, upward swing in openmarket interest rates in the last few weeks has produced new pressure for an increase in the prime lending rate at the nation's major banks. Conversations over the weekend with officials at some of the largest banks indicated that an increase from the 5 per cent level established only three ago is already under consideration at some institutions.

title: Graham Victor in Playoff Over Ozaki in Tokyo Golf
description: TOKYO, May 16 (UPI)Australia's David Graham sank a twofoot birdie putt on the third suddendeath playoff hole today to defeat Japan's Masashi Ozaki in the first Japan Airlines International golf tournament.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 16Early in 1965 Harold Wilson, then Prime Minister, was worried that President Johnson might give way to the hawks and escalate the war in Vietnam. So. Mr. Wilson says in his memoirs. He therefore telephoned the President and suggested he fly over to Washington for a cautionary talk.

title: SADAT IS MOVING TO CONSOLIDATE HIS RULE IN EGYPT
description: CAIRO, May 16  President Anwar elSadat moved briskly today to insure internal order in Egypt following last week's leadership shakeup, and pledged to build a new state in which every individual will feel free and secure.

title: Armenian Chorus, 85 Strong, Gives Robust Recital
description: The Armenian Cultural Association Chorus, which sang at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon is a big group, 85 strong, and it let loose with wave after wave of thundering resonance during its concert.

title: He'll Remodel That Fur CoatOr Help You Do
description: No fur pelt, coat or stole, however lowly, scruffy or shabby, needs feel ashamed to show its hair in Mr. A's salon, even though Mrs. Henry Ford 2d buys there occasionally.

title: Italian Driver Is Killed in Race Won by VaccarellaHezemans
description: PALERMO, Sicily. May 16 (AP)An Italian driver was killed and three others wrecked their cars today in the first lap of the Targa Florio race, won by Nino Vaccarella of Italy and Toine Hezemans of The Netherlands in an Alfa Romeo.

title: Last Roundup
description: As recently as the beginning of this century, two million wild mustangs roamed the far western United States. They were the bane of cattlemen and sheepmen because they occupied valuable grazing lands. But these small, tough, wild horses make inimitable saddlehorses for those who can tame them, and they have become an imperishable part of the romantic legend of the Old West.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigarette Ads Found Doubled in 14 Magazines
DANCE SERIES MOVES INTO A FINAL PHASE
description: The American Dance Marathon, which began at the ANTA Theater in January and continued at the City Center in April, has entered its third and final phase for this season, specializing now in the work of choreographers who desire performances in nontheatrical spaces. The series, under the sponsorship of the New York. City Center, opened Saturday evening at the Emanuel Midtown Young Men's Hebrew Association with the Grand Union and will conclude the evening. of May 28 at an as yet undisclosed site.

title: NIXON AIDE TERMS SST FIGURE HASTY
description: WASHINGTON, May 16Clark MacGregor, President Nixon's chief lobbyist in Congress, said today that the Boeing Company was revising very sharply downward its earlier estimates that a new supersonic transport program would cost up to $1billion more than the old one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is unfortunate that in the furor over the Administration's depreciation reform proposal so much attention has been focused on strictly shortrun economic circumstance. Your April 29 editorial criticizes that program on the grounds that (1) it is not likely to solve the unemployment problem or stimulate capital spending as well as other means, and (2) that other social priorities should take precedence.

title: ISRAELIS EXPECT A SNAG ON PEACE
description: JERUSALEM, May 16  Premier Golda Meir and her Cabinet concluded today that the current power struggle in Egypt would delay  but not defeat  the diplomatic moves under way to reopen the Suez Canal and to arrange a partial settlement between Egypt and Israel.

title: The Black Prince
description: ITHACA, N. Y.Crystallized embodiment of greatness, excitement, fascination, flamboyance, floating like a butterfly, stinging like a beethe syncopation of the tassels on his shoes, the synergetic staccato jabs he threwThe Black Prince, the outlaw who eluded America with the cunning of Br'er Rabbit, the first free black champion ever to confront white America, Muhammad Ali, a.k.a. The Greatest. The only living man that I can truly identify with, that all he is I feel part of.

title: Karl Farkas, Entertainer; Seen Here in Merry Widow
description: VIENNA, May 16 (UPI)Karl Farkas, one of Austria's leading variety artists, died in hospital here today. He was 77 years old.

title: SYLVESTER JARVIS
description: Sylvester Jarvis, a thirdgrade detective in the New York police department, died Friday night at his home at 114 Patmore Avenue, Yonkers, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 38.

title: DENTAL PROGRAM FOR PUPILS SET UP
Fittipaldi Wins in Lotus
description: MADRID, May 16 (UPI) Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, driving a Lotus 69, won the Formula Two Grand Prix of Madrid race today covering 60 laps of the 2.13mile Jarama circuit in 1 hour 29 minutes 42.9 seconds.

title: Pakistani Refugees Competition Angers Indian Poor
description: PETRAPOLE, India, May 16The continuing heavy influx of Bengali refugees fleeing from the Pakistani Army in East Pakistan is placing a severe strain not only on India's economy but on her social fabric as well, as the presence of the refugees forces prices up and wage rates down.

title: Etna Lava Perils 2 Towns
description: CATANIA, Sicily, May 16 (AP)Villagers in two Mount Etna towns, Fornazzo and Sant Alfio, prayed in their churches but stood their ground tonight as flaming lava from the volcano advanced toward their homes. The lava stream, 300 feet wide and 12 feet high, moved forward slowly a few miles away.

title: Governor's Lament Is Termed Truer Than Mayor's in Annual BluesSinging
description: ALBANY, May 16Faithful to the annual scenario, Governor Rockefeller is crying poor mouth in the current tales of fiscal woe competition between the Rockefeller and Lindsay administrations.

title: RAIL STRIKE CALLED TODAY ACROSS U. S. AS TALKS FAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Monday, May 17The Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen will go on strike nationwide at 6:01 A.M. today, Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson announced at 1:45 A.M.

title: Pentagon Unsure of Total on Drug Use in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 16The Department of Defense has been concerned for several years about the use of illicit drugs, especially heroin, by American servicemen stationed in Vietnam, a department spokesman said today.

title: DONALD F. DUNCAN OF YOYO FORTUNE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 16 (AP) Donald Franklin Duncan, a selfeducated businessman who made the YoYo a milliondollar seller and established the parking meter in cities, died yesterday. He was 78 years old.

title: Metros Tie Cosmos On Late Goal at 22; Stritzl Thrown Out
description: TORONTO, May 16  Walter Muir headed in a corner kick with 30 seconds to play today to give the Toronto Metros a 22 tie with the New York Cosmos in a North American Soccer League game before 6,751 fans at Varsity Stadium.

title: Sweden, Resigned to What Is, To Issue Hairnets to Soldiers
description: STOCKHOLM, May 16Fix hairnets!

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Brandeis U. Alumni Reject Angela Davis as President
description: WALTHAM, Mass., May 16 (AP)  Brandeis University alumni voted overwhelmingly today to reject the candidacy of the black militant Angela Davis and reelected Morton L. Ginsberg, a New York lawyer, as president of the Brandeis Alumni Association.

title: Roundup: Montanez Is Phils Savior
description: About the only bright spot of the season for the Philadelphia Phillies, who are in last place in the National League Eastern Division, has been the play of Guillermo (Willie) Montanez, a rookie center fielder.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 43, To Tie Stanley Cup Final
BERNARD RACKOW; LED HOME FOR AGED
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., May 16 Bernard Rackow, executive director of the Daughters of Israel Pleasant Valley Home in West Orange, died of an apparent heart attack today at his home, 17 Winfield Drive. He was 54 years old.

title: Holzman and Wife Hurt in Car CrashBoth Hospitalized
description: Red Holzman, the general manager and coach of the New York Knickerbockers, and his wife, Selma, were involved in an automobile accident yesterday morning that caused both to be hospitalized.

title: Ceylon Says Area in South Has Been Cleared of Rebels
description: COLOMBO Ceylon, May 16The district of Galle in southern Ceylon has been cleared of insurgent activity, the Government announced today.

title: McGovern Asks $31Billion in Reform
description: NEW HAVEN, May 16Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, urged today that $31billion in current spendingmost of it from the defense budgetbe diverted in effort to eliminate poverty, pollution and racism by the end of this decade.

title: Spartan Weather Marks Greek Independence Day
description: The Greeks usually have word for it. Yesterday the word was vrochi (rain) and thousands of GreekAmericans hoped that it would end in time for the 31st annual Independence Day parade on Fifth Avenue.

title: JOSIAH PITTS WOOLFOLK
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 16 (AP)Josiah Pitts Woolfolk, who published hundreds of short stories and a dozen or more novels under the name Jack Woodford, died early Sunday at Eastern State Hospital.

title: Jewish Committee Gets $1Million For New Unit
description: A $1million gift was presented to the American Jewish Committee yesterday by Dr. Morton K. Blaustein of Baltimore for the establishment of an institute devoted to the advancement of human rights.

title: CITY BUDGET CUTS OUTLINED BY TROY
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., newly elected Democratic party leader of Queens, said yesterday that he had told Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. that he could see $500million being cut from Mayor Lindsay's proposed $9.1billion budget.

title: ROSS TOPS BARKER IN FINAL, 64, 63
description: ARMONK, N.Y., May 16 Steve Ross of Brooklyn, the ninthranked player in the East, won the Westchester men's tennis championship today by defeating Bob Barker of Port Washington, L.I., 64. 63, in the final at the Armonk Tennis Club Barker ranks 15th.

title: Hospital Marks Its 200th Year
description: The New York Hospital, the oldest hospital in the city, celebrated its 200th anniversary yesterday with a service at Trinity Church, the place where it all started.

title: BERKELEY PAPER MAY LOSE FUNDS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 16The role of Berkeley's student newspaper in yesterday's disturbances around People's Park was the center of controversy today.

title: Tremor Shakes Sarajevo
description: BELGRADE, May 16 (Reuters)A medium earth tremor shook the central Yugoslav town of Sarajevo early today, the national press agency reported. The tremor shattered windows in a railway building but caused no more extensive damage, the agency said.

title: Greek Liner Runs Aground And Is Refloated Off Britain
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Monday, May 17 (AP)The Greek liner Ellinis had steering trouble early today and ran aground outbound from Southampton harbor, but tugs refloated it on a rising tide two hours later.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM G, FOERCH
description: RIVER EDGE, N.J., May 16William G. Foerch, commander of the New York District of the American Legion in 196768, died yesterday in Pascack Valley Hospital, Westwood. He was 76 years old and had lived at 260 Adams Avenue.

title: First of North Sea Oil To Reach Norway Soon
description: OSLO, Norway, May 13A 45,000ton Greekowned tanker, flying the Liberian flag, will signal Norway's debut as a commercial oil producer when she arrives early next month at the southwestern port of Stavanger.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: SAN DIEGO, May 16 (UPI)Nine meet records were broken during the finals of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics District 3 competition last night.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach continued its awardwinning streak Friday night at the 1970 Andy Awards festivities. the Advertising Club of New York at the New York Hilton. But at this third major award ceremony of the season, the D.D.B. haul was almost embarrassing In the 17 categories not one agency except Doyle Dane got more than one first prizeand D.D.B. pulled in a fantastic 11.

title: Browning's Vayu Victor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 16  There were more members of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club race committee than contestants as rain and gusty winds today kept most of the Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound sailors in port.

title: With Health and Environment Trends, Adults Swing to Bicycles
description: WASHINGTON, May 16Bikes don't pollute, bankrupt or kill you, and they keep you in shape. This is the passionately held view of Arthur Phillips, a 54yearold professor at the University of Miami, who sold his car two years ago.

title: SAXOPHONISTS PAY TRIBUTE TO HODGES
description: Seven jazz saxophonists yesterday paid tribute with their horns to one of the most renowned of their colleagues, the late Johnny Hodges. The musicians, who performed in Saxophones for Johnny, the 11th annual concert of the Duke Ellington Society held at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, were Harold Ashby, Paul Gonsalves, Jerome Richardson, Zoot Sims, Buddy Tate, Norris Turney and Earle Warren.

title: Law Dean Named Citizens Union Head
description: The Citizens Union announced yesterday that Robert B. McKay, dean of the New York University Law School, has been elected as its chairman, the sixth in its 74year history.

title: West Highland Is Named Best In Field of 1,454 at Willimantic
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 16Ch. De Go Hubert, the West Highland white terrier owned by Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N. J., and handled by Cliff Hallmark, and best in show at Springfield yesterday under a brilliant sun, proved he could work just as well in the rain when he gaited a best in show today in a field of 1,454 dogs at the Windham County Kennel Club show at Recreation Park.

title: McNamara Visiting Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 16 (Reuters)  Robert S. McNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, arrived here today from New York to discuss with Nigerian leaders possible areas of further financial assistance by the World Bank. Mr. McNamara is on a nineday tour of Nigeria and Ghana.

title: Trade Volume at Canton Fair Reported to Reach New High
description: CANTON, China, May 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  Business transactions during the monthlong Canton tradefair reached a new high level, an official said today.

title: CRITIC LAUDS HOOVER FOR LIFE OF SERVICE
description: COOKEVILLE, Tenn., May 16 (UPI)Representative William R. Anderson, a critic of J. Edgar Hoover's role in the Berrigan case, praised the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today for his lifetime of distinguished public service.

title: Patterson Formula Victor
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., May 16Jim Patterson of Roslyn Heights, L. I., won tile Formula event in the North Atlantic Road Racing Championship at Bridgehampton Race Circuit this weekend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE KORN
description: George Korn, who ran his own roofing business on Manhattan's West Side until his retirement last year, died yesterday in Royal Hospital, the Bronx, following a short illness. He was 90 years old and lived at 960 East 22nd Street, Brooklyn.

title: Troubles Persist in Prison at Auburn
Prague Shunning Politics This Spring
description: PRAGUE, May 16  Spring has come again to Prague, but it is not the Prague spring of 1968.

title: Lester Johnson, Vice President Of Celanese Corporation, Dead
description: BRIARCLIFF, N. Y., May 16 Lester B. Johnson, a former treasurer of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and an executive vice president for financial and legal operations of the Celanese Corporation of America, died after a heart attack at his home here today. He was 53 years old.

title: MRS. SARA CORALNIK
description: Mrs. Sara Gorodetski Coralnik, formerly an organic chemist and a librarian for the American Jewish Congress, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 200 West 108th Street.

title: Mounties Attacked Over Surveillance
description: OTTAWA, May 16For the first time in nearly a hundred years Canadians have begun to speak harshly of the tactics and the motives of the venerable Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: PRETENTIOUS WINS FARMINGTON TITLE
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 16  Bernie Traurig piloted Pretentious to the secondyear green working hunter championship in effortless fashion today at the rainsplattered closing session of the Children's Services horse show.

title: Frances J. Kdrolenko Is Married
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 15Miss Frances Jane Korolenko, who received a Ph.D. in genetics in 1969 from Brown University, and Stephen Vale Shabica, a graduate that year of the university, were married this afternoon.

title: DONNIE ALLISON WINS NASCAR RACE
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., May 16 (UPI)  Donnie Allison beat his brother, Bobby, and Buddy Baker in a lastlap sprint today to win the Winston 500 stock car race.

title: U. S. Will Prod Soviet on TroopCut Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States was very anxious to begin negotiations with the Soviet Union over mutual troop reductions in Europe.

title: Brownsville's Smoke Signals
description: Splintered timbers rise on Sterling Place, charred black against an azure sky. They jut awkwardly from the upper floors of a totally gutted building. The roof is gone. The ravaged interior stands exposed to the sun. Elsewhere on Sterling and on Saratoga, for block after block, the thin brick shells of abandoned tenements teeter on the brink of collapse.

title: ACADEMY EXPELS 3 FOR MARIJUANA USE
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 16 (UPI)The Naval Academy announced today the expulsion of three more midshipmen in connection with an investigation into the use of marijuana.

title: New York Wins in Lacrosse
description: The New York Lacrosse Club routed the Philadelphia Lacrosse team, 115, in a league game at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday. Tom Guaranto and Terry Horner scored two goals apiece for New York, and Jay Rauth tallied twice for Philadelphia. New York's record is now seven victories and three losses.

title: AMEX HAILS TESTING OF DIVIDEND SERVICE
description: The American Stock Exchange announced over the weekend that its new, automated Dividend Settlement Service had successfully completed its pilot operation and would be expanded to serve all clearing members, effective June 1.

title: J. D. Ginsberg, Dale M. Yellen Wed in Jersey
description: DEAL, N. J., May 16Miss Dale Margaret Yellen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Yellen, was married here today to Jerome David Ginsberg, son of Mrs. Charles Ginsberg of Succasunna and the late Mr. Ginsberg. Rabbi Irving Perlman performed the ceremony at the Yellen home.

title: CHINA PRODUCING JET OF OWN DESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 China is producing for the first time a jet fighter of its own design, according to senior American analysts.

title: Tanzania Shows Slight Pickup in Economy
description: DAR ES SALAAM, TanzaniaThe economy of Tanzania has begun to rally slightly after suffering the worst drain of assets since independence.

title: LINDSAY BACKS BILL FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: Mayor Lindsay has told four City Councilmen he supports their legislation seeking to protect homosexuals against discrimination in areas such as employment and access to public accommodations.

title: WESLEY L. PENDERGRAFT
description: HILL AIR FORCE BASE, Utah, May 16 (AP)Brig. Gen. Wesley L. Pendergraft died of an apparent heart attack yesterday morning. He was 46 years old.

title: The Peking Factory
description: PEKINGCenturiesold traditional crafts and modern propagandistic art are produced side by side in the arts and crafts factory in Peking. The emphasis for export on the traditional, while the propaganda is more for local consumption. Peking has long been noted and respected for making the highest quality art goods in China and when Chinese crafts are purchased anywhere in the world, the fact that an article was made in Peking serves assure the quality and raise the price. The Peking factory is the only one in China that carries on all the traditional crafts. It produces lacquerware of all kinds, cloisonn, carvings in jade, quartz, soapstone and other stones, ivory carvings, inlaid screens and chests and intricately painted furniture.

title: Klemenko of Soviet Takes European Gymnastics Title
description: MADRID, May 16 (UPI) Victor Klemenko of the Soviet Union upset his teammate and the defending champion, Mikhail Voronin, to win the European gymnastics title by a narrow margin yesterday.

title: The Mills Package
description: Like most major pieces of legislation, the welfare bill worked out in the House Ways and Means Committee under the leadership of Representative Mills of Arkansas is a compromise. It costs more than conservatives would prefer and is less generous than liberals would like but, on balance, it deserves support as a substantial improvement over the existing system.

title: Defective Smell Is Linked to Hepatitis
description: Two scientists have reported that a defective sense of smell leads to the loss of appetite that accompanies acute viral hepatitis, a serious infection of the liver.

title: DeL ury Warns Against Limiting Pensions for Sanitationmen
description: The president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association warned yesterday that his men would refuse overtime work if the Legislature passed a proposed bill limiting their pension rights.

title: The Kilns Near Canton
description: CANTONThe traditional shapes and designs that over the centuries made Shekwan porcelain objects highly prized art have been discarded at the famous 800yearold Shekwan kilns at Foshan, in southeast China, 20 miles outside Canton. Instead, the porcelain workers of Shekwan serve the cause of Communist China's revolution by making utilitarian dishes for peasant households and garishly colored statuettes of heroic figures that have emerged in Maoist propaganda in recent years. A product just designed at one Shekwan porcelain factory but not yet in production is a statuette 12 inches high showing three handsome, muscular American workers, two blacks and a white man, standing together with clenched fists and gazing defiantly ahead. One has a foot planted on a crate that reads U S A upside down on one side, and one holds high a plaque that says on strike.

title: ULHMANN DEFEATS LARSEN IN CHESS
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, May 16 (AP)East Germany's Wolgans Ullmann defeated Denmark's Grandmaster Bent Larsen in 46 moves in their second match for the World Chess Championship quarterfinals here today.

title: Doctors Ignored on HotCold Dosing
description: An anthropologist has found that the hotcold theory of disease held by many persons of Puerto Rican origin can result in a failure to follow doctor's orders if the orders run counter to the theory.

title: A Few G. I. Addicts Aided in U. S.
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., May 13 Jim is a 20yearold private from Fairbanks, Alaska. Dennis is a 20yearold giant of a soldier at 6 feet 4 inches, a private from the streets of Philadelphia.

title: Cardinal Agagianian Is Dead; Scholarly Mission Leader, 75
description: ROME., May 16 (Reuters)Gregory Cardinal Agagianian, one of the most scholarly and respected members, of the Sacred College of Cardinals, died at his Rome residence tonight. He was 75 years old.

title: West Germany Advances
description: AUGSBURG, Germany, May 16 (Reuters)West Germany, which reached the challenge round last year, gained the Davis Cup European Zone Group by semifinals today, winning in singles to complete a 41 victory over Austria. Christian Kuhnke routed Peter Pokorny, 63, 61, 64.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LUBECK, West GermanyHeinrich Mann was born here in 1871 in a patrician house that until these last weeks carried a slab in memory of Thomas but ignored the older brother, Heinrich, who between 1910 and 1930 was nearly as much read and discussed as Thomas, whose fame, however, has proved more lasting. In a celebrated dispute during World War I, Heinrich corn mitted himself to democracy and radical opposition to imperial Germany while Thomas wrote two books in praise of German power and against the very notion of democracy. Thomas Mann later became a democratic opinion leader of the Weimar Republic and paid tribute to his brother's earlier insights. Heinrich Mann's most famous novel, Der Untertan, was written in 1913 but could not be published as a book before the German defeat in 1918. The magazine that ran it in installments in 1916 had to stop publication, by order of the cersor.

title: Rivals Fear Canonero II's Guns
description: BALTIMORE, May 16 Canonero II will spend a few days in the barns at Pimlico before being vanned to New York to compete in the Belmont Stakes on June 5. Juan Arias, the trainer of the Venezuelanowned, Kentuckybred colt, was undecided this morning as to exactly when he would ship out.

title: Dr. Bard's Dream
description: Only on occasion is the average New Yorker aware that his city goes back in time as well as up in space. He cannot see the history for the buildings. But such an occasion is the bicentennial of the New York Hospital, whose buildings comprise that vast compound on the East River of which the hospital itself is the principal component.

title: Lebanese Say Cairo's Meddling May End
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 16The reorganized Egyptian Government of President Anwar elSadat may, in the opinion of informed Lebanese, end an era of interference by Cairo in the internal affairs of other Arab countries.

title: New Orders Easing For Steel Products
description: PITTSBURGH, May 16New orders for steel were lagging last week. At one large mill, orders had dropped to 50 per cent of capacity. That compared with 90 per cent of capacity in April and about 130 per cent of capacity at the peak of the order boom.

title: Scott Simon Weds Sarina Dale Beges
description: Miss Sarina Dale Beges was married yesterday afternoon to Scott Jared Simon, pianistcomposer with the rock group, Sha Na Na.

title: Zeitlin Plays Sonatas In Recorder Recital
description: Nineteenth century romantic composers understandably had little use for the baroque recorder's sweet, fragile pipings, and only in our time has the instrument once again become popular, especially with amateurs.

title: FILMS BY LENNONS SHOWN AT CANNES
description: CANNES, France, May 16Mr. and Mrs. John Lennon underwent their baptism of fire as directors last night when their short films Apotheosis and The Fly were presented here at a late evening showing in the Filmmakers Fortnight Festival running concurrently with the main festival.

title: Paper in Singapore Ceases Publication; Red Link Charged
description: SINGAPORE, May 16The Eastern Sun, an Englishlanguage daily published here, ceased publication today in the wake of a Government campaign against its proprietor that culminated in an official statement charging a Communist operation to influence the newspaper.

title: Stamina Is Surprise Element as Liquori Improvises on Coach's Victory Plan
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16Marty Liguori's strategy against Jim Ryun, which resulted in another victory today in their Dream Mile at Franklin Field, was not a surprise.

title: OUTLOOK DARKENS FOR BOND MARKET Many Expect Lower Prices With Offerings Heavy
description: The mood in the bond market darkened late last week, and almost everyone seemed to think interest rates would continue heading higher.

title: Borge Livens Butler Music Festival
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 16Since music festivals are now a dime a dozen and often so alive in form and content as to be almost indistinguishable from one another, it is a treat to find one so unconventional as the Romantic Music Festival that opened here last night at Clowes Memorial Hall on the Butler University campus.

title: A NEW FEE SCALE SET FOR DAY CARE
description: A new, stateset fee scale for all families receiving publicaided day care for children is being put into effect here by the city Department of Social Services.

title: South African A.A.U. Plans Track Meet Open to All
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 16 (UPI)The South African Amateur Athletic Union plans to invite the world's top athletes of all races to an open international meet in Early 1972, its president, Matt Mare, said today.

title: 1972 Candidates Off and Collecting
description: Senator George S. McGovern flew into New York from Los Angeles a week ago and stopped at a couple of homes in Scarsdale. Sixteen hours later, the South Dakota Democrat left with more than $10,000 for his Presidential campaign.

title: Kent State Briefs Asked
description: RAVENA, Ohio, May 16 (UPI)  Judge Edwin Jones of Portage County Common Pleas Court gave state and defense lawyers yesterday two weeks to file briefs on defense motions asking dismissal of five indictments stemming from the Kent State University disturbances a year ago. The five were among 23 indictments returned by a special state grand jury which investigated the campus violence that culminated in the fatal shooting of four students by National Guard troops.

title: SHIFT OBSERVED IN BLOCK TRADING
description: A fundamental change appears to be occurring in the market for large blocks of stock due to the advent of freely negotiated sales commissions in Wall Street.

title: Green Takes Houston. Golf by Beating January on First Extra Hole
Canonero ll's Victory Seen By 5 Million in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, May 16 (AP)Canonero Il's victory in yesterday's Preakness was seen by half of Venezuela's population, and most viewers feel the colt will win the Belmont Stakes.

title: Model Cities Funds Get New Use, Cutting City Antipoverty Load
description: The Federal. Government is paying the total costs of a number of antipoverty programs here that were originally designed to be financed in part by the city.

title: First Arab Named As Deputy Minister By Cabinet in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, May 16  The Government today appointed the first Arab Deputy Minister in Israel's 23year history.

title: TV: Free Time on Modern Dance
description: The television screen is a television screen. That's obvious enough, but evidently it is so obvious that it tends to be ignored. And this is particularly true in the transference to the TV screen of traditional theater productions  drama, dance and opera.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16Jim Ryun walked out onto Franklin Field a few minutes before 3 P.M. and seemed sniff at the damp, chill air. Tall, imperially slim, he has an easy looseness about his body, but he holds his head odd angles, cocked it seems, perhaps for flight, and this gives him a staglike quality. His features are sharp, his jawline strong and clear, his hair parted and trimmed neatly into what was once called an Ivy League cut. Twitches around his eyes, and the wide, forced fixedness of his smile showed he was not calm.

title: Beyond the Examiners
description: In recommending the abolition of the New York City school system's Board of Examiners, the Commission on Human Rights has joined an impressive array authorities who for years have called for such action.

title: SCIME PIANO RECITAL DISPLAYS MATURITY
description: Seven years ago this week, Roger Scim included Beethoven's Sonata in G, Op. 10, No. 2, and Debussy's Pour le Piano on his New York debut program, and he played them again at his second Town Hall recital, late Saturday afternoon.

title: Pope Paul Warns Rich Not to Forget The Equality of Men
description: ROME, May 16Pope Paul VI warned the rich and powerful of the world today never to forget, out of indifference, egoism or arrogance, that all men are fundamentally equal and that they are brothers.

title: Mrs. Adamovich Triumphs
description: Mrs. Tanya Adamovich of the New York Fencers Club won a foil competition from 24 other women yesterday at the Fencers Club. Mrs. Adamovich compiled a 41 wonlost record in the event.

title: Mother of Accused Riga Woman Is Honored in Synagogue Here
description: For almost an hour yesterday afternoon, 1,500 persons filled a synagogue on the Upper East Side and paid tribute to a Jewish woman from the Soviet Union whose daughter is about to go on trial there.

title: Denver Five Signs Robisch
description: DENVER, May 16 (AP)The Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association have signed Dave Robisch of Kansas.

title: Miss Karen L. Cooperman a Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Karen Lynn Cooperman to Robert Lloyd Pritsker took place at the Regency Hotel yesterday. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony.

title: ART JACKSON
description: ST. CATHERINES, Ontario, May 16 (Canadian Press)Art Jackson, a retired National Hockey League player, died of a heart attack while playing golf over the weekend. His age was 55.

title: Extra Buses Will Provide Alternative Way to City
description: Car pools and buses were expected to be the major alternatives today for 150,000 rail commuters in the metropolitan area, as the national railroad strike shut down all commuter lines except the Long Island Railroad and the Port Authority Trans Hudson lines from New Jersey.

title: Liquori Beats Ryun by Foot in 3:54.6 Mile
Economic Crosscurrents Beset Latins
description: LIMAA high United States Treasury official pleads that he represents a country with severe economic woes and a diminishing role in world affairs before a meeting of international bankers at a time when the dollar is under pressure in important money markets.

title: GILLIGAN'S ISLAND BEATS 1,882 RIVALS
description: LAMPETER, Pa., May 16Ch. Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, a 2yearold German shepherd owned and bred by Daniel P. Dwier of Kresson, N. J., defeated 1,882 rivals today to win best in show at the 26th annual Lancaster Kennel Club event.

title: Ellen Kay Feinstein, Teacher, Wed
description: Miss Ellen Kay Feinstein was married at noon yesterday to Henry Kimeldorf, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kimeldorf of Queens Village, Queens. Rabbi Josiah Darby performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Feinstein, parents of the bride, in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Students Revive Good Old 1950's
description: A year after student antiwar protests closed dozens of, colleges and universities across the country, thousands of the same youths are caught up in a new pursuit nostalgia for the good old days. For these people, the good old days mean the nineteenfifties.

title: Advertising:
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 16The outgoing chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies voiced the concern of many agency men as the organization ended its threeday meeting here yesterday at the Greenbrier. He asked for more guidance from the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Discount Is Pushed For Export Loans
description: WASHINGTON, May 16 A serious move will begin in the House of Representatives this week to force the Federal Reserve System to start a special discount facility for exportrelated bank loans.

title: TRADE WEEK FINDS A NEW U.S. FOCUS
description: A kind of retooling of American trade objectives to fit an increasingly complex global economy will be the focus of annual World Trade Week observances opening here today.

title: Miss Ephros Jane Gittleman Married
description: The marriage of Miss Ephros Jane Gittleman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Isaac F. Gittleman of Brooklyn, to Seymour Manello took place here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi David Haymovitz performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. David Manello of Oak Park, Mich., and the late Mr. Manelio.

title: India Takes 21 Cup Lead
description: TOKYO, May 16 (UPI)India won a marathon fiveset doubles match from Japan today to take a 21 lead in their Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final.

title: UNFINISHED WORK DELAYING ALBANY
description: State Assembly sources said yesterday that Speaker Perry B. Duryea expected the legislative session to be extended beyond the tar et closing date of next Saturday because of unfinished business.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Film 'Ivan Denisovich' Best at Long Distance
description: Although the newspaper ads have been announcing Alexander Solzhenitsyn's "One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich," what opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse is a movie by Casper Wrede, of which Solzhenitsyn's novel is the source and not the finished product. Actually the confusion, which would make perfect sense to any publicist, is to a degree supported by the film, for it is not merely a close adaptation; it has, much of the time, the look and, indeed, the feel of a careful, tasteful, rather sumptuous illustrated edition.Ivan Denisovich (Tom Courtenay) is a political prisoner, a poor peasant who, while in the Russian army during World War II, escaped from a Nazi P.O.W. camp and for his pains was sentenced by the Stalinist government 10 years as a spy. He is now in his last two years, a seasoned prisoner in an especially harsh Siberian labor camp, where the film, like the book, follows him from before dawn until after dark through the depressions and successes of one unexceptional midwinter day.But I doubt whether anything really gets into the movies as "unexceptional." And though the movie protests the modesty of its intentions (through the services of a fairly obtrusive voice-over narration) and honorably avoids all of the easier rhetorical excesses, it nevertheless strains toward a certain expansiveness, a range that it is one of the chief glories of Solzhenitsyn's novel never openly to assume.For where the novel sees through the eyes of its Ivan Denisovich, whose rough, crafty, decent pragmatism saves it from most pretensions, the movie chooses mostly to look at himand though Tom Courtenay is an actor who knows how to preserve his privacy in front of a camera, the result is that what had been "point of view" in the book becomes in the movie something less meaningful and more grandsomething like "image of man."I think this is why, despite some really estimable performances (besides Courtenay, I especially liked Espen Skjonberg as the tough and admirable work-gang boss Tiurin), the film tends to be happier the further it gets from its peopleor, while it is with them, the more it can understand them as exemplars of the human condition and the less as individuals."One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich" is thus a movie that looks uncommonly good in long distance, as in the emergence of the prison camp, rather as a bright galaxy in a dark void, that begins the film; or in the stunning shots of the prisoners and the guards trudging across the flat snow-covered landscape from prison camp to work site in the morning and back again at night.Such sequences, however, with their excellent cinematography (by Sven Nykvist, a veteran of recent Bergman films) and their intelligent exploitation of realistic locations (in Norway, near the Arctic Circle), carry the aura of an almost official view of high quality, as if this were how an important movie made from an important novel ought to look.At its best, for example, in depicting the brick-laying that makes up the actual work day of Ivan Denisovich, or at its worst, in the stiff-upper-lip gentility of the dialogue in Ronald Harwood's screenplay, the movie means to expose a universality in its comprehension of individual experience. But at its best, and even at its worst, both the excellence and the ineptitude seem to derive from virtues and vices that are largely academic.

title: Radio City Rockettes Given New Director
description: Emilia Sherman has been named director of the Radio City Music Hall's Rockettes. She will succeed Russell E. Markert, director of the precision dancing troupe since the opening of the theater in December, 1932. He will retire on May 31.

title: Riessen Turns Back Alexander in 4 Sets For $10,000 in Iran
description: TEHRAN, Iran, May 16 (AP) Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ind., defeated John Alexander of Australia, 67, 6.1, 63. 76, today to win the Aryamehr Cup, which was personally awarded by the Shah.

title: RUSSELL GREENLEE
description: INDEPENDENCE, Kan., May 16 (AP)Russell Greenlee, a retired Associated Press staff member from the Minneapolis bureau, died last night of heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Rita Halle Kleeman, 85, Dead; Wrote Life of Young Roosevelt
description: Mrs. Rita Halle Kleeman, an author who had been active in promoting international goodwill, particularly in this hemisphere, died Saturday at her home, 14 Sutton Place South. She would have been 86 years old next Sunday.

title: Discipline of Saving
description: United States Savings Bonds are tailormade for people who find it difficult to save money. That is especially true for those who vow they will take a little out of each paycheck and save it, but never do. United States Savings Bonds are easy to buy, and they are indestructible.

title: Books of The Times.
description: I was trying to plow right through Home Life in order to get my review in on time, but it was impossible. Every few pages, had to stop and admire the bookor simply sit back and feel it. My God, but my fellow creatures are fascinating! I found myself thinking. How touching, how absurd, how real they are! All at once I was delighted to be sharing their destiny. Not that Home Life is a happy bookfar from it. But it doesn't matter, because its people are so dimensional. It's so reassuring  positively exhilarating  to find that we haven't yet been flattened out by life, our features abraded away by the sheer rush of phenomena.

title: Mariner 9 Delayed
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 17 (UPI)The space agency delayed the flight of the Mariner 9 toward Mars until Sunday at the earliest because of extra steps taken to avoid a repeat of the failure of Mariner 8.

title: Beneficial Corp. FirstQuarter Earnings at a Peak
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mayor Lindsay's contention that commuters earn 29 per cent of the city's wages and thus should pay 29 per cent of the city's taxes has merit. It is flawed only in this respect. Outofstate commuters already are being taxed, and taxed handsomely, by New York State, to cross the line to work.

title: Yanks Beat Orioles, 63, for Stottlemyre's 4th Victory;
Ullmann Beats Larsen
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, May 16 (AP)East Germany's Wolgang Ullimann defeated Denmark's Grandmaster Bent Larsen in 46 moves in their second match of the World Chess elimination quarterfinals here today,

title: Earth Tremor in Ecuador
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, May 17 (AP)A strong earth tremor was felt here early today. There were no reports of casualties or damage.

title: CostAccounting by Post Office Held Arbitrary by Bulk Mailers
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Attorneys representing users of second, third and fourth class mails charged today that the costaccounting techniques the Post Office Department used in assessing higher postal rates that went into effect yesterday were arbitrary and judgmental, and not based on accepted statistical methods.

title: B52's Stage Raids
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, May 17 (AP)Only light ground action was reported in South Vietnam today. United States B52 bombers again made raids in Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam.

title: SEDGMAN IS VICTOR IN BRITISH TENNIS
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 17 (AP)Frank Sedgman of Australia, making a tennis comeback at the age of 43, defeated 21yearold Jean Paul Meyer of France today in the first round of the British hard court championships. The score was 64. 6.4, 6.3.

title: HERBERT RUMMEL OF TRAVELERS AID
description: Herbert H. Rummel, general director of the Travelers Aid Society of New York and a social welfare executive for many years, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital of leukemia. He was 62 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES $216BILLION RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The House Ways and Means Committee, reversing a position it took last week, voted 13 to 12 today to add an increase of $2.6billion in Social Security benefits to the omnibus welfare bill. The vote last week was 13 to 12 against the increase.

title: 7.2% Are Jobless in Jersey
description: TRENTON, May 17 (UPI)Linemployment in New Jersey remained essentially unchanged last month from March, remaining at 7.2 per cent of the work force, or 222,400 people. A slight decline of 3,300 in the number of jobless, compared with the March total, slightly less than officials had expected. the State Department of Labor and Industry reported today.

title: Union Seminary Is Reconsidering Its Purpose
description: The Union Theological Seminary handed out 157 diplomas and inaugurated a new president yesterday with ceremonies indicating that the 135yearold pinnacle of liberal Protestantism is in process of radically rethinking its purpose.

title: SCHOOLAIDE PLAN CALLED A SUCCESS
description: An independent study of the city's paraprofessional program in public schools has found overwhelming evidence of its success.

title: Catholic and Episcopal Clergy Meet on Unification
description: YONKERS, May 17Clergymen of the Roman Catholic and Episcopal Dioceses of New York held a joint study day today to discuss the possibility of eventual union of the two churches.

title: Books of The Times
description: When I recently discovered Jasper Ridley's mammoth new biography of Lord Palmerston, the 19thcentury English statesman, I ran off to a corner with like a dog with his prize bone. Nineteenthcentury English history happens to be particularly weak part of my, historical backgrounda vacuum filled with freefloating Corn Laws, Reform Bills, Opium Wars, and balances of powerand here was the story of the figure after whom part of 19thcentury English history was named; a colossus who strode European history from the time of Napoleon to that of Bismarck and who vied at the tables of diplomacy with the likes of Talleyrand and Metternich; a subject who perhaps more than any other 19thcentury Englishman could provide me with a handle to his times. And though much had already been written on Palmerston, Jasper Ridley, an English lawyer who gave up his practice in order to write, claimed in the Foreword to Lord Palmerston to have covered a wider ground than any previous biography. Here, thought, was the key.

title: Joe Jones, Drummer, And Quintet Fill In At Jazz Interactions
description: Jazz interactions which is once again presenting Sunday jazz concerts after a lapse of almost two years, ran into one of the problems of promoters of onenight stands last weekend.

title: LAWRENCE ROBERTS, A POLLUTION EXPERT
description: Lawrence M. Roberts, retired senior vice president and director emeritus of ResearchCottrell, Inc. of Bound Brook, N. J., air pollution control and water and waste treatment equipment, died Friday in Wickenburg, Ariz., at the age of 73. He lived there and in Bound Brook.

title: Romney Hails Prefab in Yonkers
description: YONKERS, May 17George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, strode up and down 10 flights of stairs, picked his way through tangles of electrical cables and dodged a swinging 10ton concrete wall today to inspect a prefabricated highrise luxury apartment house here.

title: MRS. WANG CHIYUAN
description: Mrs. Wang Chiyuan, wife of a leading Chinese painter and calligrapher, died Sunday at her home, 399 East 72d Street. She was 73 years old. Mr. Wang operates the School of Chinese Brushwork at the home address.

title: Clinton Takes Track Crown In Bronx 5th Year in Row
description: DeWitt Clinton captured the track team title in the Bronx division of the Public Schools Athletic League for the fifth straight year yesterday at Randalls Island.

title: BAR UNIT OPPOSES ETHICS BILL HERE
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York called yesterday for local conflictofinterest legislation to cover most of the city's elected, appointed and Civil Service employes.

title: Villemare of Rangers To Drive at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 17  Gilles Villemure, better known as the New York Rangers backup goaltender, will make his local debut as a harness racing driver tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway. The FrenchCanadian, who brought home 15 winners last season, will substitute for Lucien Fontaine in the ninth race, and drive Wairau Lord.

title: McDonnell Douglas Settles Tax Case With Government
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to pay the Federal Government about $21.5million in settlement of claims for the years ended June 30, 1965, and 1966 and for the six months ended Dec. 31, 1966. The company also dismissed its suit against the Government in United States Tax Court for the year ended June 30, 1965.

title: Floodlight Kits Recalled
description: CLEVELAND, May 17 (UPI)The General Electric Company's lamp division announced today that it was recalling G.E. outdoor floodlight and holder kits sold during and after August, 1970, owing to a possible flaw in the electrical wiring of the lamp holder that could cause severe shock. A company spokesman said an investigation turned up about 40 units that may have been affected.

title: Using Model Cities
description: Faced with an acute shortage of operating funds, the Lindsay administration is considering a shift of some Federal Model Cities money into the maintenance of routine municipal services in the slums.

title: U.S. OPENS CAMPAIGN TO SAVE ELECTRICITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Federal Government, predicting an electric power crisis in some areas this summer, announced today a nationwide campaign to conserve electricity.

title: Catholic Teachers Here Vote to Keep Their Union
description: The lay teachers in the 300 schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York have voted 1,198 to 850 to have the Federation of Catholic Teachers continue to represent them as bargaining agent.

title: RETAILERS STUDY INNERCITY DECAY
description: The specter of downtown deterioration hovered yesterday over a shoppingcenter convention dedicated to examining the bright prospects for new suburban sites.

title: WILLIAM H. SCHWARTZ
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.J., May 17 William H. Schwartz, an industrial market analyst in Newark, died yesterday at his home. He was 55 years old and lived here at 116 Laurel Drive.

title: 1,100 Furloughed by Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, May 17 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Press Company announced today that it had furloughed 1,100 noneditorial employes as a result of strike by 400 printers. The company said the action was not a lockout. It said 700 editorial, business and maintenance personnel would remain on the job. The company prints The Press and The PostGazette.

title: Indonesia Seeks Renewal Of Relations With China
The Guerrillas in Jordan: Defeated and Quarreling
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 13Only nine months ago the Palestinian guerrillas, apparently secure in their Jordanian stronghold, were widely regarded as a powerful element in the affairs of the Middle East.

title: Turkish Leftists Kidnap Israeli Consul General
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 17 (AP)  Four leftist terrorists kidnapped the Israeli Consul General, Efraim Elrom, today. Mr. Elrom, who was an interrogator of Adolf Eichmann, the executed Nazi war criminal, and is 58 years old, battled his abductors.

title: RAIL STRIKE SENDS FUTURES PRICES UP
description: Soybean and grain futures prices rose yesterday in early, trading on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of speculation over the effects of the rail road strike.

title: GEORGE G. MOORE
description: George Gordon Moore, a lawyer, publicutility officer and sportsman, died Sunday in Los Angeles, where he had lived in retirement since 1933. He was 94 years old.

title: EXCHANGE'S BOARD CLEARS PEROT PLAN
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had unanimously approved constitutional amendments that would limit indemnification of a group associated with H. Ross Perot in the recapitalization of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc.

title: GOVERNMENT GETS AID IN JERSEY CASE
description: TRENTON, May 17Another defendant in the Federal extortionconspiracy trial of leading Hudson County and Jersey City officials became a major witness for the Government today and was granted immunity from prosecution as a jury was chosen for Thursday's opening of the Government's case.

title: Native Royalty Wins Roseben, Pays $10.80 as Favorite
description: Here's the horse, Ivan H. Parke, trainer of Harbor View's Native Royalty, told Johnny Rotz just before yesterday's 29th running of the Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct You've ridden him before. Use your own judgment.

title: Economists Divided On Use of Monetary And Fiscal Stimuli
description: Several leading economists were sharply divided yesterday over whether more monetary and fiscal stimulus is needed to prod the economy.

title: Market Place:
description: The more you heard the more you wonder just how one goes about finding suitable investment counsel.

title: Common Market Imposes Levies
description: BRUSSELS, May 17  The Common Market Commission has imposed a system of levies and rebates on food products traded between Germany and the Netherlands and the four other Common Market countries.

title: Egypt Is Purging Leftist Group
description: CAIRO, May 17A Communistoriented group in the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political organization, has become the focus of a sweeping shakeup, reliable sources reported today.

title: SINGAPOREEXPELLING 3 FOREIGN NEWSMEN
description: SINGAPORE, May 17The Government today ordered the expulsion of three journalists on 48 hours notice.

title: Gold and Jewels Fresh From the Land of Milk and Honey
description: Israel's flourishing jewelry industry is the focus of an exhibition at Cartier. Ten Israeli artists, including Yaacov Agam, whose sculptures are being shown at the Denise Rend gallery here, have contributed 200 pieces in gold and precious stones to the collection. Israel, explained Gideon Flanter, one of the contributing artists, is rich in inspiration  there is the texture of the land and its architecture, whether it goes back to the Romans or as it is now.

title: Governor Denies Trying to Link Parochial Aid to City Revenues
description: ALBANY, May 17Governor Rockefeller denied today that he had linked the proposal for increased aid to nonpublic schools with the campaign for restoration of revenue sharing for localities.

title: QUARTER NET OFF 57% AT ANACONDA
description: The Anaconda Company, which announced last week that it would appoint a senior New York banker as its new chief executive officer, reported yesterday that earnings, in the first quarter plummeted 57 per cent, compared with those of the 1970 period.

title: TAIWANESE GUILTY IN FOILED MURDER
description: A 33yearold Taiwanese was convicted of attempted murder yesterday in State Supreme Court here for his part in plot to kill the Deputy Premier of Nationalist China.

title: Darryl Zanuck, Fox Chairman, Declines to Run for Reelection
description: Darryl F. Zanuck, the 68yearold chairman of the board of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, announced yesterday that he had decided against being a candidate for reelection.

title: Presbyterians Elect First Woman as Moderator
description: ROCHESTER, May 17  Mrs. Lois H. Sair of Waukesha, Wis., was elected moderator of the United Prebyterian Church here tonight on the fourth ballot.

title: Parolee's Rights to Counsel at Revocation Hearing Is Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that a parolee had a constitutional right to legal representation at a hearing weighing the revocation of his parole.

title: Everglades Fires Doused
description: MIAMI, May 17 (UPI)Five days of intermittent rain have succeeded in dousing stubborn Everglades fires, but the National Weather Service refused to mark an end to South Florida's recordbreaking, eightmonth drought.

title: City Center Treats Wall St. to Some Modern Dance
description: An attractive blonde reincarnation of Isadora Duncan, in pink tunic and bare legs, loped gracefully around a sapling on the Chase Manhattan Plaza at lunchtime yesterday to the tune of Beethoven's Ninth.

title: Bill Bans Hunting by Air
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Despite Administration objections, the House passed, 307 to 8, and sent the Senate today legislation that would make hunting from airplanes a Federal crime. The bill would provide a fine of up to $5,000, a year in prison or both for anyone convicted of shooting or firing at any bird, fish or other animal to kill, capture or harass it.

title: LESBIANISM CHARGED IN JUVENILE CENTERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)Two teenaged girls from New York City gave Senate subcommittee investigating juvenile delinquency today a detailed picture of alleged lesbianism, beatings and apathy in the city's centers for delinquent girls.

title: Bill in Legislature Seeks 5 Judgeships for Queens
description: ALBANY, May 17  Queens Democratic and Republican leaders have asked the Legislature to create five Supreme Court judgeships and have agreed on bipartisan endorsements for two Republicans and three Democrats, including Borough President Sidney Leviss and possibly District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

title: U.S. Poseidon Submarine Joins Base in Scotland
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 17 (Reuters)The United States Navy has strengthened its Polaris submarine force at the Holy Loch base in Scotland with a submarine carrying the bigger multiple warhead Poseidon missile.

title: Canadiens Out to Close Show Tonight With Brother Act
description: They're brothers, but their most similar characteristic the ability to score goals.

title: NIXON AIDE BACKS IMPOUNDED FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) A top Administration budget official said today that more than half of the $12.2billion in appropriations currently impounded was in construction funds that would be paid out in the next fiscal year as contracts are completed.

title: Nixon Back From Florida
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) President Nixon returned here tonight after a fourday working vacation spent at the Florida White House on Key Biscayne. The Presidential party arrived at the White House at 6:34 P.M.

title: Bank of Commonwealth
description: DETROIT, May 17The financially troubled Bank of the Commonwealth has reduced its borrowings from the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago to a daily average of $20million to $30million from $260million to $270million a few months ago, John A. Hooper, chairman and chief executive said at the bank's annual meeting here today.

title: Brooklyn Parents Protest a Busing Plan
description: Parents boycotted Public School 179 in the Parkville section of Brooklyn yesterday in a dispute with the Community School Board of District 20 over plans to bus pupils to junior high school next autumn.

title: NIXON BIDS CONGRESS ACT TO HALT RAILROAD STRIKE; ENTIRE SYSTEM AFFECTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 President Nixon asked Congress today to act quickly to halt a strike by railroad signalmen that had shut down virtually all the nation's railroads.

title: Treasury Adopts Rules On Pollution WriteOffs
description: WASHINGTON, May 17, (UPI)The Treasury Department adopted today regulations authorizing businesses to take a fast income tax writeoff of the cost of pollution control facilities.

title: The Theater: Godspell
description: Innocence reigned like thunder at the Cherry Lane Theater, where last night a new musical called Godspell opened. It is a musical based upon the Gospel according to St. Matthew, and deals with the life and teaching of Jesus Christ. Conceived and directed by JohnMichael Tebelak, and with music and new lyrics by Stephen Schwartz (most of the lyrics are based on the Bible), in an. earlier version it was originally produced at La Mama.

title: Irresponsibility on the Rails...
description: The nationwide railroad paralysis caused by an utterly unwarranted strike involving just over 2 per cent all rail workers points up the need for legislative remedies far more fundamental than President Nixon's call for a special backtowork law designed to keep the trains running until July 1.

title: F.B.I. Said to Urge Use Of Boy Scouts as Informers
