description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17A document said to be among those stolen from the Federal Bureau of Investigation indicates that the agency encourages local police departments to recruit Boy Scouts as informers.

title: Montgomery, Ala., Elects An Independent as Mayor
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 17 An independent candidate upset the Democratic nominee for Mayor in today's election here.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The tide was falling, slack water was near. Rich colors played above the western horizon as the sun set, purple, orange, red and yellow. But I had no fish.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The character of the present public debate on developing the SST is pro. foundly disappointing. Such a development is now technically possible, and an American supersonic plane is sure to fly eventually.

title: Basic Financial Changes in U.S. Are Urged
description: Top Government officials called yesterday for basic changes in the nation's financial structure.

title: Locally Raised Money Reopens 14 Urban Task Force Offices
description: Fourteen of the city's 40 Urban Action Task Force offices have reopened since Mayor Lindsay on April 19 ordered all the offices closed because of the fiscal crisis.

title: High Court Backs Hit and Run Laws
Executive Changes
description: M. Todd Cooke has been named president of the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, the city's largest mutual savings bank and the third largest of its kind in the country. He succeeds R. Stewart Rauch, who will become the bank's chairman. The changes will become effective June 15.

title: Brooklyn Bus Strike Ends
description: The 35 buses of the Pioneer Bus Corporation, linking Brroklyn's Mill Basin area to subways, schools and shopping centers, resumed operation yesterday, after a 77day strike. Drivers and mechanics, represented by Division 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union, approved a new contract last Thursday night. The carrier plans to restore service also to racetracks and to Shea Stadium as soon as possible.

title: ... and a NoWin War on Inflation
description: A principal impetus toward the kind of wage irresponsibility reflected in the strike of rail signalmen has been the skyrocketing trend of pay scales in construction.

title: Preservation of a Shahn Excites His Jersey Town
description: ROOSEVELT, N. J., May 17The residents of this Depressionborn, New Dealsired town, snuggled in a woodland on the edge of the Assunpink Wildlife Sanctuary in central New Jersey, have been struck by a windfall that has brought on an embarrassment of cultural riches.

title: Army's Drive on Heroin Hurt by Asian Attitudes and, Perhaps, by Official Involvement
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17The newly intensified American campaign to stop the flow of heroin to United States servicemen here is hampered by Asian attitudes and, it is believed, official involvement.

title: Notes on People
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau yesterday became the first Canadian Prime Minister to make an official visit to the Soviet Union.

title: Advertising:
description: Consumerism and how to cope with it were the themes that ran through the opening session of the new Council of Better Business Bureaus, which presented 12 speakers in the first day of its fiveday meeting in Miami, Fla.

title: Nolan, Heinsohn Given New 49er, Celtic Pacts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP)The San Francisco 49ers, who had to waited 25 years tO win their, first division title, presented Coach Dick Nolan today with a new fiveyear contract. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Pakistan Thanks China
description: RAWALPINDI, India, May 17 Pakistan today expressed her deep appreciation to China for the supply of two tons of powdered milk sent as relief assistance to East Pakistan. The milk was sent from Peking on a special flight Saturday and was received in Dacca, the East Pakistani capital, yesterday.

title: Stock Prices Sink In Biggest Setback Of Last 11 Months
description: The stock market suffered its sharpest decline in 11 months yesterday amid predictions that major banks soon might raise their prime lending rates to corporations. The nationwide strike of railroad signalmenand fears that it might slow the economic recoveryalso contributed to the market drop.

title: ITALIAN DELEGATION EN ROUTE TO CHINA
description: ROME, May 17A 74member economic delegation left for China today, led by a member of the Government and including representatives of major Italian industries.

title: VINCENT P. LA ROSA OF FOOD CONCERN, 44
description: Vincent P. La Rosa, executive vice president and a director of V. La Rosa & Sons, Inc., Westbury, L.I., macaroni and Italian specialties, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 44 years old.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson and the other former Federal officeholders and military figures assembled by President Nixon to lobby for continued full American troop strength in Europe are the very men responsible for the assumption by successive administrations of worldwide military commitments that our economy can no longer sustain.

title: 40 POLICEMEN FACE KNAPP UNIT QUERIES
description: The Knapp Commission investigating allegations of corruption in the New York Police Department has begun recalling a group of about 40 policemen who have been contesting in the courts the right of the commission to question them.

title: Text of Nixon's Message
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 17 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's message to Congress on the railroad strike:

title: New York City's Budget Gap
description: While there remains considerable disagreement on the exact size of New York City's projected budget gapMayor Lindsay advances one figure, Governor Rockefeller anothertwo major issues of justice and of equity have emerged on which there can be no disagreement.

title: CONNALLY IS FIRM ON DOLLAR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Secretary of the Treasury John 13. Connally Jr. told a Senate committee today that there would be a complete change in the international situation of the dollar if the United States continued to hold down inflation relative to other countries.

title: SEARS'S EARNINGS AND DIVIDEND UP
description: ALHAMBRA, Calif., May 17 Maybe it was the dividend increase. Maybe it was because firstquarter earnings were up 11.1 per cent. Or maybe, as Gordon M. Metcalf, chairman, suggested, it was the basic timidness of most stockholders.

title: Bedford Shim Erupts After Policeman Kills Knifer
description: A series of disorders flared in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday following the fatal shooting of a black man by a white patrolman. Several persons were injured.

title: Foe Reported Advancing
description: VIENTIANE, May 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  North Vietnamese troops were today reported advancing in force toward Houei Kong, the Government's one remaining stronghold on the Boloven Plateau, 20 miles southeast of Paksong.

title: Hodgson Says Construction Pay Curbs Are Working
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that it would be impossible, until 1973 at the earliest, to keep annual wage increases in the nation's construction industry as low as 6 per cent.

title: Bonn Cites Credit Policy
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 17 (AP)The West German Government's decision to float the mark is primarily measure of credit policy and is not aimed at revaluing the mark upward, the Bundesbank said today.

title: 25 Million More Youths Will Be Able to Vote in 72
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Census Bureau says there will be more than 25 million young people potentially eligible to vote for President for the first time in the 1972 election.

title: TV STATION SALE SET BY PULITZER
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company of St. Louis announced yesterday it had agreed to sell the assets of television station KVOATV of Tucson, Ariz., to a company controlled by Donald W. Reynolds of Fort Smith, Ark. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: The Velazquez
description: It is virtually impossible to think of the Metropolitan Museum's new Velazquez without thinking of its price tag. This is a shame because the association deforms great work of art. As a physical object the painting becomes a piece of rare merchandise; and as a target ethical questions as to the uses that should be made money in a confused society, it becomes an innocent victim. As a work of art the painting has nothing to do with any such values.

title: U.S. Force Cut by 4,600; 262,500 Left in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 (AP)The United States command announced today that American troop strength in South Vietnam was reduced by 4,600 men last week to 262,500, the lowest total in more than five years.

title: MRS. JOSEPH L. JONES
description: PELHAM, N.Y., May 17 (UPI) Mrs. Helen Sullivan Jones, wife of Joseph L. Jones, retired vice president of United Press International, died today at her home. She was 71 years old.

title: $4Million Offer Reported for Canonero II
description: Pedro Baptista, the earthy, emotional pipe manufacturer from Caracas whose Canonero II has become an instant wonder horse, disclosed yesterday that he had received a $4million offer for his big bay colt, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness.

title: Brustein Stays at Yale
description: Robert Brustein has been reappointed dean of the Yale School of Drama, it was announced by Kingman Brewster Jr., the university's president. Mr. Brustein was appointed dean in 1966 for a fiveyear term, ending June 30. His reapointment is for a threeyear term.

title: N.C.A.A. and A.A.U. Chiefs Optimistic on Ending Dispute
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 17 (AP)The presidents of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic nion said today they were optimistic on resolving the long feud between the two groups over the administration and control of amateur athletics.

title: Rain Falls on Timber Fire
description: ELY, Minn., May 17 (AP)Showers fell today on fire that has ravaged some 15,000 acres of timber in the Superior National Forest of northern Minnesota, but a spokesman for the United States Forest Service at Ely said it would take a good downpour to bring the ?ames under control.

title: Geller and Korchnoi Draw
description: MOSCOW, May 17 (Reuters)Grandmasters Yefim Geller and Viktor Korchnoi, both of the Soviet Union, drew their third game in the world chess eliminations on the 35th move here today, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported.

title: Laughing in Israel
description: TEL AVIVAcross the short span of our national history, we have become accustomed to being somewhat isolated within the Family of Nations.

title: North Vietnamese Capture Key Laos T own Near Trail
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 17The Laotian command announced today that the North Vietnamese had taken the last important Government position on the Boloven Plateau, the strategic high ground in the southern panhandle.

title: Hope for Wild Birds Seen In Artificial Insemination
description: Cornell University ornithologists announced yesterday what they said was the first successful rearing of a wild bird of prey hatched from an artificially inseminated egg. The bird was a redtailed hawk.

title: Seoul Police Seize 31 G.I.'s Protesting the Vietnam War
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 17 South Korean riot police arTested 31 American soldiers who were demonstrating peacefully against the Vietnam war on a downtown street this evening.

title: Tight Power Supply Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  Electricpower capacity to meet peak air conditioning loads this summer will be in tight supply in most of the Eastern half of the nation, the Office of Emergency Preparedness said today.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)Tommy Heinsohn, handed the job of rebuilding the Boston Celtics after.Bill Russell's un expected retirement in 1969, was given a third oneyear contract today as coach of the National Basketball. Association club.

title: Sadat Will Command The Police Force, Too
description: CAIRO, May 17  President Anwar elSadat has agreed to a request by police and security officers that he be their commander in chief, it was reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The gyrations of the world currency crisis of the last few days have been formidable. We may expect further crises in the future, unless something is done about it.

title: Con Ed Says Public's Aid Is Needed to Attain Goals
description: The president of the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday the company needed strong public support if it was to realize its goal of becoming one of the most modern and clean electric systems in the United States by 1975.

title: Bridge: The Aces Defeat French Team To Keep World Championship
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 17The Aces held off a brave challenge by their French opponents to retain the world championship title in convincing style here this afternoon. They began the fourth and final session of the play of the Bermuda Bowl competition with a lead of 45 international match points, which at one time was whittled down to 29. But that was the highwater mark for French hopes, and a final surge by the reigning champions brought them victory by 62 points, 243181.

title: Assembly G.O.P. Leaders Table Welfare Reform Bill
description: ALBANY, May 17  A bill that would have created the office of Welfare Inspector General, with the power to investigate frauds in the welfare system, ran into unexpected opposition today and was tabled by the Republican leadership in the Assembly.

title: Completion of Loan to I.O.S. Is Expected by June
description: Investors Overseas Services, the giant offshore mutual fund, expects to complete the details of a $10million international loan before the annual meeting to be held next month in Toronto, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: JEWISH AGENCY GETS ORDER AGAINST J.D.L.
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday permanently barred the Jewish Defense League from invading or disrupting the executive offices of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies here.

title: Kennedy Race Is Doubted
description: NEWARK, May 17 (UPI) Lawrence O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, said tonight he did not expect Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to become a Presidential candidate, despite increasing reports of nationwide support for such a bid.

title: High Court Asked to Rule On an Acquisition by I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to reverse a lower court ruling that the 1969 acquisition of the Grinnell Corporation by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was legal.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana has, done us all a service. His proposal to force a 50 per cent reduction in American forces in Europe has made it clear how difficult it is in this country to change a policy that has achieved institutional status, no matter how little sense the policy may have come to make.

title: Rogers Terms a Canal Pact a First Step
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. May 17Secretary of State William P. Rogers emphasized here today that the United States would regard any IsraeliEgyptian agreement on the opening of the Suez Canal as a first step toward full implementation of the Security Council resolution that calls for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Arab territories conquered in 1967.

title: Murphy Names 4 Police Deputies
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday a number of changes in the top civilian posts within the Police Department.

title: Senate SST Hopes Fade; Ozone Peril Called Grave
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Senate backers of the supersonic transport acknowledged today that the chances for a revival of the SST were dwindling rapidly under the weight of its projected costs.

title: Administration Considers Plan to Keep U.S. Paying Dues to the International Labor Organization
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The Nixon Administration, according to Government and labor officials here, Is considering a compromise plan to keep the United States a duespaying member of the International Labor Organization.

title: Soviet Ministry Raking In the Rubles
description: MOSCOW, May 17The Ministry of Railroad Construction has apparently hit upon a gold mine.

title: Roundup: 3 Indians Hurt Chasing PopFly Homer
U.S. OFFICIAL URGES TRADE RECIPROCITY
description: Peter G. Peterson, Presidential adviser on international economic affairs, said yesterday that true reciprocity was needed to keep the United States competitive in a world of new economic superpowers such as Japan and the European Economic Communty.

title: AIRLINE INSTALLING NEW WEAPON FINDER
description: Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it was introducing new advanced magnetometer at its major airport terminals to detect potential hijackers carrying weapons.

title: Capitol Police Expanded
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) A House subcommittee stirred by the recent Capitol bombing, voted unanimously today to increase the 665man Capitol police force by more than 30 per cent. Six police dogs to help detect explosives Were also authorized.

title: Jeers Greet Report to Commons on the Market Talks in Brussels
description: LONDON, May 17Hostile questions and jeers greeted report to he House of Commons today on the breakthrough in Britain's negotiations to enter the Common Market.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Bronx In Coed's Heroin Death
description: Two men pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to having given heroin to Antoinette Dishman, a 17yearold Barnard student found dead on Jan. 30, 1970.

title: Auto Manufacturers and Food Shippers Immediately Affected by the Rail Walkout
description: Besides rail commuters in the few major cities that still have them, the strike by the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen yesterday immediately affected the auto industry, the post offices and shippers of perishable foodstuffs.

title: A Rival for Ann Landers and Dear AbbyBut It's in the Family
description: CHICAGOA minute fraction of the country's newspaperwomen are syndicated columnists, and never before in the recollection of syndicate executives has a single family produced three at once.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 17This court will come to order. This is the case of the people vs. D. Boone. The Attorney General will state the charge.

title: 3 NEWSMEN TO GET COLUMBIA AWARDS
description: The Alumni Association the Columbia University Graduatc School of Journalism announced yesterday that its 1971 journalism awards would go to Hodding Carter, publisher of The Delta DemocratTimes of Greenville, Miss.; Clayton Knowles, a political reporter for The New York Times, and Les Trautman, managing editor of The Staten Island Advance.

title: Letters May Arrive Marked Postage Due
description: WASHINGTON, May 17A spokesman for the Post Office Department said, today that letters mailed after Saturday midnight that did not contain sufficient postage to meet the new rates that became effective yesterday would probably be sent on to their destinations, instead of being returned to senders, with additional postage due upon receipt.

title: Alternative Transit Routes Available to Commuters
description: The national rail strike has shut down the Penn Central, ErieLackawanna and Jersey Central Railroads and the Staten Island Rapid Transit lines. The Port Authority Trans Hudson lines continue to operate normally, but Long Island Railroad service terminates at the Woodside and Elmhurst stations in Queens, where riders may switch to subways.

title: Jordan Frees 435 Guerrillas
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May (AP) King Hussein's Government has released 435 Palestinian guerrillas from Jordan's prisons during the last four days, Government spokesman reported today. All were set free under a newly declared amnesty in return for the guerrillas evacuation of Amman last month, the spokesman said.

title: New Marine Midland Unit
description: LONDON, May 17 (Reuters) The Marine Midland BankNew York said today, subject to final approval by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, it had formed a new Londonbased merchant bank, the International Marine Banking Company, Ltd. It will have an initial capital made up of the sterling equivalent of $25million preferential shares and an additional 10year subordinated loan capital of $15million, Marine Midland said.

title: MUM DEFEATS O'BRIEN AT FORUM
description: Donato Paduano, the former welterweight champion of Canada, seems to operate on the theory of better late than never. That's how the Montreal fighter scored his unanimous 10round decision over courageous, but weakhitting, Bobby O'Brien of Bayside, Queens, last night in the Felt Forum.

title: District Leaders Oppose Delay in Leadership Vote
description: Strong opposition from a majority of the Democratic district leaders in Manhattan and from Vincent F. Albano Jr., the Republican county leader, appeared yesterday to have killed a bill in Albany to put off leadership elections for a year.

title: Harness Owners Want 2 Per Cent of Offtrack Bets Earmarked for Purses
description: Describing itself as desperate to be heard, the Standardbred Owners Association urged yesterday that 2 per cent of all offtrack wagering be earmarked for harnessracing purses.

title: Al Tananbaum, 61, Dies
description: Alfred A. Tananbaum, one of three brothers who built Yonkers Raceway into leading harness track, died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 61 years old. Details on page 42.

title: HARVARD REJECTS PROPOSALS FOR G.M.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 17  The Harvard Corporation, the university's main governing board, refused today to support four stockholders proposals designed to change the policies of General Motors.

title: UNIFORMITY ASKED ON CIGARETTE TAX
description: The men concerned with trying to collect tobacco taxes in several Northeastern states endorsed again yesterday an old solution to the problem of cigarette smuggling: The imposition, one way or another, of a nationally uniform tax.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: TOKYO, May 17 (AP)India defeated Japan, 32, in the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis final today, with Permit Lail scoring the deciding singles victory.

title: TV: Tonight, It Pays to Dial Around
description: In a recent article, a favorite colleague (who won't be aimed here, but the piece was written for The Times of London, and that's a devilishly clever hint) gazed upon American television and found it almost disastrously wanting. Except for the commercials, an occassional talk show and Sesame Street, TV fare was generally dismissed as a blight on both the mind and the body politic.

title: Pakistan, in a Shift, Asks U.N. for Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 17Pakistan asked the United Nations today for food and coastal steamers to distribute relief supplies in East Pakistan.

title: Brecht's Literary Legacy In East Germans'Custody
description: BERLIN, May 17The East German Government has placed Bertolt Brecht's literary legacy in national custody following the death on May 6 of his widow, Helene Weigel.

title: U.S. Officials Hopeful
description: WASHINGTON, May 17United States officials said today that there was now a possibility of some forward movement on mutual EastWest troop reductions in Central Europe.

title: American Express Official In Athens Freed From Jail
description: ATHENS, May 17Demetrios Papaefstratiou, the general manager of American Express in Greece, was released from jail today after being held for two months by the Government.

title: Soviet Asks Up to 10 Years in Jews'
description: MOSCOW. May 17A Soviet prosecutor asked for prison terms of up to 10 years for the nine Jewish defendants in the second Leningrad trial linked to a plane hijacking plot last year.

title: SOVIET GOLD SOLD IN LONDON MARKET
description: PARIS, May 17The Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europe have been selling gold in London to meet foreign exchange needs, according to a report by a Belgian bank.

title: Villagers Imperiled by Lava To Bear Holy Relics Up Etna
description: SANT ALFIO, Sicily, May 17 (Reuters)  Villagers obtained permission from their Bishop tonight to carry the relics of their saints to the edge of a river of lava that threatens to engulf their homes.

title: Mrs. Chisholm. Mrs. Abzug Introduce Child Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) Legislation providing $5billion in Federal funds for childcare services in the 1973 fiscal year and $10billion by 1975 was introduced in the House today.

title: For Sale: Angry Horses That Hate People
description: MILES CITY, Mont., May 16  For 20 years the buyers have come to the Custer County Fairgrounds in May to stand in the dusty arena under the twostory judges stand and decide the fate of horses.

title: HIGH COURT FREES FILM HELD OBSCENE
description: A Swedish film, Language of Love, seized by Customs officials as obscene in October, 1969, will be released to theaters here as a result of a United States Supreme Court order handed down yesterday. According to a representative of Unicorn Enterprises, Inc., the importers, the feature is to have its local premiere at the Agee I Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 47th Street, and in two other theaters on May 26.

title: Dr. Eric H. Faigle, 70, Dies; Former Dean at Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., May 17Dr. Eric H. Faigle, a professor of geography at Syracuse University who became dean of the College of Liberal Arts and was vice president for student services from 1960 until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday at his home. He was 70 years old.

title: Commuters Here Switch To Buses and Subways
description: Some 145,000 metropolitan area commuters scrambled for alternative means of getting to and from work yesterday as signalmen on local railroads joined in the national rail strike.

title: FRANK M. DOWNEY
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., May 17Frank M. Downey of 58 Wilder Street, a retired vice president of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday in Elizabeth General Hospital. His age was 82.

title: Inquiry Into Panther Raid Grand Jury Ordered by Chicago Judge
description: CHICAGO, May 17The chief judge of the Criminal Courts Division ordered his own investigation today into the activities of a special grand jury that has reportedly voted to indict the Cook County State's Attorney, Edward V. Hanrahan.

title: Thrift Units'
description: The inflow of new deposits into savings and loan associations soared to a high of $1.9billion during April, the United States Savings and Loan League estimated yesterday. The increase compared with gain of $239million in the corresponding month last year. According to the League, April normally sees a very small growth in deposits at associations or a net loss.

title: Jewish Unit for Blind Dedicates $7Million Building on 65th St.
description: The 57yearold Jewish Guild for the Blind, a nonsectarian agency, formally dedicated its new 12story building at 15 West 65th Street yesterdaya building to house a compresive range of programs for the blind and visually handicapped.

title: The Cost of the SST
description: Two disclosures last week made dramatically clear the probable cost of reviving the project to build an American supersonic transport. In Seattle, the chairman of the Boeing Company said a new startup would involve an additional expenditure of a very large amountan expenditure on the top side of about $1 billion, on the low side of at least half a billion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John J. Kapstein (letter May 7) may be a fine trader, but he is no politician, or he would have known that the Soviet Union long ago abandoned its 1948 support of Israel.

title: U. S. TELLS SOVIET IT FAVORS PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, May 17Ambassador Jacob D. Beam told Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today that the United States believed it had the same views as the Soviet Union on the desirability of starting talks on reducing troops and armaments in Central Europe.

title: U.S. Ground Role Ending In Vietnam, Resor Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) The Army Secretary, Stanley R. Resor, said today that by fall the United States would be in a position to have no significant effect on ground combat activity in Vietnam.

title: NEW RULES ARE SET ON C.O.D. SECURITIES
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday adoption by their boards of governors of new rules designed to reduce the 16 to 25 per cent rejection by banks of socalled c.o.d. securities deliveries from member brokerage firms.

title: Mylai lnquiry Hears Colonel Was Told About His Rights
description: FORT MEADE, Md., May 17 (AP)The Army's No. 2 civilian lawyer testified today that Col. Oran K. Henderson was informed of his rights on each of the five occasions lie appeared before a special Pentagon inquiry into an alleged coverup of the Mylai massacre.

title: Police Lieutenant Charged in Jersey In Nine Burglaries
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 17 A police lieutenant was arrested today on charges of having looted nine stores in the last six months.

title: Tough Chief Signalman Charles James Chamberlain
description: WASHINGTON, May 17If there is one thing that everybody involved in the current railroad dispute agrees on, it is that Charles James Chamberlain is a tough negotiator.

title: Dr. Raymond Travis Dies; Jersey Educator Was 49
description: WEST CALDWELL, N.J., May 17Dr. Raymond M. Travis, superintendent of the West Essex Regional School District since 1964, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 49 years old and lived at 9 Deer Trail Road.

title: Advertising:
description: Advertisers and ad agencies throughout the country, alarmed as most citizens are about the everincreasing problem of drug abuse, are trying to fight it with the weapon they know bestadvertising.

title: SINGAPOREEXPELLING 3 FOREIGN NEWSMEN
description: SINGAPORE, May 17The Government today ordered the expulsion of three journalists on 48 hours notice.

title: Sato Vows Not to Revalue Yen;
description: TOKYO, May 17Prime Minister Eisaku Sato pledged again today not to revalue the yen upward, while the Finance Ministry took some emergency measures to stem the incoming flow of dollars.

title: New Bazelon Concerto Led by Composer at Y
description: Max Pollikoff's Gallery of Music in Our Time concerts at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A are dedicated to the proposition that contemporary music is not dead. And Sunday night's program demonstrated just how lively and various it can be.

title: Farband Chorus Presents Tribute to Vladimir Heifetz
description: The Farband Culture Chorus, Joseph Milo conductor, gave a Vladimir Heifetz Memorial Concert at Town Hall late Sunday afternoon.

title: BACKER WILL SEEK SURROGATE'S POST
description: With the field of candidates still growing, Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer announced yesterday he was running for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate in New York County.

title: Music: Prague Spring
description: PRAGUE, May 17  The summer festival season has already started all over Europe, and Prague's Spring has been going on for a week. This is a monthlong festival that in some respects parallels all the others. Internationally famous musicians come in and out, playing much the same repertory they play in New York, Vienna, Munich or Bergen. But one thing makes the Prague Spring unique, and that is its opera series.

title: Minneapolis Museum Opens Today
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 17After a weekend of parties, previews, inaugural ceremonies and other festivities including a Sunday afternoon pop circus for childrenthe Walker Art Center will open its new $5.5million building to the general public tomorrow, I suspect it is going to be one of those buildings that will change a lot of minds about what we can and should expect from the architects who design our new museums. For here, amazingly enough, is a new museum building that gives cheerful priority to the works of art it is house.

title: Study Finds No Evidence That Breast Cancer Is Linked to Pill
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17Preliminary evidence presented here today showed no relationship between a woman's use of oral contraceptives and her risk of developing breast cancer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am writing you in reference to your editorial of May 3, Sabotaging Medical Care, which refers to the LavernePisani Bill, of which I am major sponsor.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At the age of 18 Don Schollander had achieved these things: He had won four gold medals in the 1964 Olympic Games; he had set 37 American and 22 world swimming records; he had been voted the world's best athlete, amateur or professional, and he had entered the freshman class Yale. All items were to have profound effects on his life, the last one most of all.

title: Local Setback for the Tories
description: Britain's Conservative party returned to power in 1970 promising to curb soaring inflation and strikes. Instead, prices have continued to rise at an annual rate of 9 per cent, strikes are at an alltime peak this year and unemployment rocketed last month to its highest April figure since 1940.

title: TROY'S PLAN SEEN AS UNREALISTIC
description: Three City Council leaders yesterday described as unrealistic an assertion by Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., Queens Democrat, that $500million could be cut out of the city's proposed $9.1billion budget.

title: House Votes $150Million For Lunches in Schools
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The House approved today a $150million increase in the program to provide free or reduced price meals to needy children.

title: List Off Sharply In Amex Trading
Keg Explodes, Killing Man
description: GARDEN CITY, May 17 (UPI) The grounds superintendent of the Cherry Valley Country Club here was killed late this morning when a beer keg exploded as he was attempting to tap it. Nassau County Police spokesman said that William L. Orlosky, 31 years old, of 8 Fore Court, Brentwood, apparently died instantly of severe head injuries. The police said Mr. Orlosky was pumping gas into the keg when the pressure apparently caused it to explode The blast sent parts of the keg 150 feet into the air.

title: Stockholm Reprieves Elms; Issue Is Put Off Until Fall
description: STOCKHOLM, May 17 (Reuters)A cluster of condemned elm trees, which for five days had been an issue between militant conservationists and the city authorities, was given a reprieve todayat least temporarily.

title: Blount Is Shocked By O'Brien Charge Of Postal Politics
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Postmaster General Winton M. Blount said today that he was shocked, to say the least, by charges that the United States Postal Corporation, which will go into operation July 1, was bogged down in partisan politics, service cutbacks and financial ineptness.

title: WHITE JURY TO TRY A NEGRO SHERIFF
description: OPELIKA, Ala., May 17An allwhite jury of five women and seven men was picked today to try Alabama's first civil rights case against an elected Negro official.

title: Quake Hits Turks'
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 17 (Reuters)  Earthquake shock waves today destroyed 975 houses and severely damaged 2,700 others in southwestern Turkey.

title: Circus Caravan Through Lincoln Tunnel Causes Elephantine Traffic Jam
description: A lumbering caravan of 19 elephants, a zebra, a llama and a pony marched last night from South Kearny, N. J., to Madison Square Garden through the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: S.B.I.C.'S REQUEST REFUSED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today an application for exemptions from most aspects of the Investment Company Act by smallbusiness investment companies.

title: Bill Blass's Collection for the Fall: It's Helping Seventh Avenue Save Face
description: Hats with veils are back, and don't scoff. Bill Blass shows them with his fall collection, and Blass is a man to be reckoned with these days. He's a designer whose time has come. Nothing he touches turns to dross, not even gold brocade for evening. He just shapes it into culottes, adds a fisher fur hemband and a jersey bodice, but that's running ahead of our story.

title: Agnew Says Hanoi Stalls On P.O.W.'s to Gain in Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 Vice President Agnew said today that the United Slates and South Vietnam mere making final arrangements to repatriate 570 sick and wounded North Vietnamese who are prisoners of war.

title: Liquori Coy on A.A.U. Plans, Next Race With Ryun
description: Still savoring the sweetness from the most satisfying victory of his track and field career, Marty Liquori remained uncommitted yesterday on when and where lie would meet Jim Ryun again in their dream series of mile races.

title: 32 Pakistani Miners Killed
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 17Thirtytwo miners were killed yesterday in an explosion in a coal mine at Sinjabi, 30 miles northeast of Quetta, in the northwest area of West Pakistan.

title: ARTHUR R. LILLICRAPP
description: EASTON, Pa., May 17Arthur R. Lillicrapp, a retired vice president of the Dixie Cup Company, now part of American Can Company, died yesterday in Phillipsburg, N. J. He was 83 years old and lived here.

title: Amendments Offered in Senate To Block Mansfield Troop Cut
ASSEMBLY RETAINS MARIJUANA LAWS
description: ALBANY, May 18The State Assembly today rejected a proposal to make the marijuana laws more lenient, apparently killing for this year a campaign that had the support of Governor Rockefeller and the state's district attorneys.

title: DURYEA IS EASING BUDGET DEMANDS
description: ALBANY, May 18Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea today retreated from his demand that the New York City Council prune the proposed city budget and tax package before the Legislature considers giving the city authority to levy the taxes.

title: SWITCH IS SMOOTH IN EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN May 18  Two weeks after he took over East Germany's ruling Communist party, Erich Honecker has begun without advance fanfare to establish his own style of leadership.

title: Alabama Deputy Questioned on Kicking Charge
description: OPELIKA, Ala., May 18Testimony ended today in the trial of Sheriff Lucius D. Amerson, accused of the misdemeanor violation of a prisoner's civil rights.

title: MRS. FRASER WILKINS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Mrs. Anne Bryan Wilkins, wife of Ambassador Fraser Wilkins, Inspector General of the Foreign Service, died of a stroke Sunday in Providence, R. I.

title: Cosmos 420 Orbited
description: MOSCOW, May 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the 420th in its series of unmanned Cosmos satellites and indicated it was traveling close to the orbit of the Salyut satellite, with which the manned Soyuz 10 spacecraft once docked last month.

title: Excerpts From the Chief Justice's Speech on the Need for Civility
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Following are excerpts front a speech by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger at the opening session of the American Law Institute:

title: WagePrice Control Law
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (Reuters)President Nixon signed today a bill extending his discretionary authority to estatelish mandatory wage and price controls until May 1, 1972. However, the White House sail the President had on plans to use the authority.

title: AllStar Coaches Named
description: Bill Russell, the former coach and star center of the Boston Celtics, and Larry Brown, the Denver Rockets playmaker, were named yesterday as coaches for the National Basketball AssociationAmerican Basketball May allstar game on May 28 in Houston. Russell will direct the N.B.A. squad, Brown the A.B.A. team.

title: Roundup: Lonborg Return Brings Ovation, Victory
description: It was almost like 1967 all over again for Jim Lonborg at Boston's Fenway Park last night.

title: Soviet Leaders Urge Revision Of Wholesale Pricing System
description: MOSCOW, May 18  The Soviet leadership threw its support today behind a new system of wholesale prices intended to spur lagging technical progress in this country's Governmentrun economy.

title: Kahane and a Black Leader Pledge Unity
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane bead of the Jewish Defense League ceremonially broke bread yesterday with Dr. Thomas Matthew head of a black selfhelp group in the latter group's Harlem factory yesterday and the two men pledged a brotherhood relationship between their organizations.

title: Girl. 12. Slain in the Bronx; Boy, 12, Is Seized as Killer
description: A 12yearold girl was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon after she and two girl friends had an argument with three boys who were cleaning windshields of cars at the Third Avenue exit of the Cross Bronx Expressway, the police reported.

title: Youth, 19 Charged in Death Of 3 by Auto in the Bronx
description: A 19yearold deaf youth was charged yesterday in the death of the wife of a Bronx patrolman and his two infants killed when they were struck by an auto while walking on a Bronx sidewalk.

title: Dollar Tribulations
description: Is the basic cause of the chronic deficits in the United State balance of payments an overvalued dollar and undervalued foreign currencies? And is the solution of this nation's international financial problems a realignment of currencies? A sharp conflict exists within the Nixon Administration over what the balance of payments policy is and should be. That conflict became clear this week with the testimony of Secretary of the Treas ury John B. Connally Jr. before the subcommittee on international trade of the Senate Finance Committee.

title: Blazers and Chubbies Galore
description: Seventh Avenue was in a state of animation yesterday as fall showings continued. Chester Weinberg sought to revive the couture. Victor Joris made the world safe for long coats for still another season. Stan Herman stuck plastic tetrahedronshaped pins over everything.

title: PRESIDENT HAILS BILL ON WELFARE
description: WASHINGTON, May 18President Nixon praised the House Ways and Means Committee today for approving an omnibus welfare reform bill that includes a $2.6billion Social Security increase that the Administration had opposed.

title: Civil Service Union Sets Statewide Strike June 16
description: ALBANY, May 18  The board of directors of the Civil Service Employes Association called today for a statewide strike of their 150,000 members, beginning at midnight June 16, unless the jobs of 8,250 state employes slated to be cut because of budget cuts are restored.

title: EUROPEAN EXTENDS APOLOGY TO U.S. AIDE
description: STRASBOURG, France, May 18 (AP)The Swiss president of the Council of Europe's Assembly apologized today to a United States official for the disclosure of the American's reported defense of Greece's military regime before a council committee.

title: Good Fortune Finally Falls to Revson: Place on McLaren Team
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 18This. could be Peter Revson's year. Now that he has won nationwide attention as the polesitter in the Indianapolis 500, Revson may at long last be able to get rid of the erroneous peg that has plagued him for so many years  that he is the heir to the Revlon cosmetic fortune. Peter, a 32yearold bachelor who has business interests of his own, facetiously describes himself as the poor relation"; he is not the son of Charles Revon, but a nephew.

title: Where Did Civilization Arise?
description: SHEFFIELD, EnglandA major revolution is taking place in our understanding of man's early past. It transforms the whole picture which we have of the prehistory of the Old World, leading us to look on the barbarians of Europe with a new respect.

title: When Johnny Came Marching Home Again
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y.The war in Vietnam ended last week for Mrs. Ethel Rausch and her family. It was over at 6:25 A.M. last Wednesday, when United States Marine Pfc. John Rausch, 19, came home.

title: Gov. Licht's Mother Dies
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., May 18 (AP)Mrs. Rose Licht, mother of Gov. Frank Licht, died last night in Miriam Hospital. She was 74 years old. Besides the Governor, she leaves two other sons, Harry and Julius, and eight grandchildren.

title: China Transformed by Elimination of Four Olds'
description: HONG KONG, May 18One of the early objectives of the Cultural Revolution in China, which began in 1966 and goes on today, was to wipe out the four oldsold things, old ideas, old customs and old habits.

title: 3 Youths Acquitted in Deathi Of Negro in New Bedford
description: FALL RIVER, Mass, May 18 (AP)A Superior Sourt jury scquitted three white youths today of the murder last summer of a Negro teenager during racial disturbance in New Bedford.

title: Finns Attack Paper Industry on Pollution
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 18 The Finnish pulp and paper, industry, a powerful competitor and big dollarearner on world export markets, is coming under increased attack on the question of water pollution.

title: Rossetti Attracts Reform Support On Party Election
description: Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, Democratic county leader in Manhattan, drew unexpected Reform support yesterday for his proposal to delay local leadership elections for a year.

title: U.S. Charges Store Used Illegal Forms In Collecting Bills
description: A major furniture and appliance store in Harlem was indicted yesterday on charges of using a fradulent collection device to dupe customers.

title: United Presbyterian Church Calls Inquiry Into Lay Group
description: ROCHESTER, May 18 (AP)The United Presbyterian Church ordered a preliminary inquiry today on whether a large laymen's group was in defiance of it.

title: Police Tighten Control of Narcotics Unit
description: In an effort to improve the quality of narcotics arrests and reduce opportunities for corruption, the Police Department has clamped tighter controls on its narcotic policemen while at the same time encouraging them to go after higherlevel dealers.

title: The Forgotten Neighbors
description: OTTAWA, May 18Very few men manage to get political power without being corrupted or to give it up without being wounded and depressed, but Lester B. Pearson, former Prime Minister of Canada, is one of them.

title: Bank of America Issue Withdrawn as a Failure
description: The Bank of America finally admitted yesterday that its $100million issue of 61  per cent capital noteswhich were first offered through its nearly 1,000 branches in California in early April  has been a flop. The bank said that the issue would be withdrawn on Friday, with $30million of the bonds still unsold.

title: Lockheed Loan Debated;
description: WASHINGTON, May 18.A top Nixon Administration official said today that the single most effective step Congress could take now to help the ailing aerospace industry would be to approve the Administration's plan to guarantee $250million worth of loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Thomas Nevin, Character In Hemingway War Novel
description: MEXICO CITY, May 18 (UPI)  A British ambulance driver, a comrade of Ernest Hemingway in World War I, died here yesterday of emphysema.

title: 74 Oriental Jewish Protesters Arrested in Jerusalem Clash
description: JERUSALEM,. May 18 (AP) Young Oriental Jews, protesting what they termed ethnic discrimination, fought street battles for six hours today with the police. Ten policeman and Several demonstrators were injured in Israel's worst rioting in years.

title: Defeat Seen for Mansfield Troop Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The White House was described as confident today that it could defeat a proposal by the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, for a 50 per cent reduction in American troops in Europe, but as less certain that it could beat back a possible lastminute Senate compromise.

title: Beck Tax Debt Affirmed
description: SEATTLE, May 1 (AP)The U8nited States Tax Court has ruled that Dave Beck, former Teamsters Union president owes more than $1million in underpaid taxes and penalties. The ruling was received here today by the Internal Revenue Service. An eightday trial of the civil suite was held in February 1969.

title: 16 Mafia Suspects Put On Tiny Italian Isle
description: LINOSA, Italy, May 18 (UPI)Sixteen reputed Mafia chiefs were deported today to this tiny island in the Mediterranean, where the police hope to keep them in isolation until gang violence on Sicily ends.

title: Analysts Get Forecasts
description: The domestic petroleum industy faces a shortage of refining capacity and will need to import almost half its petroleum products by 1980, according to Charles E. Spahr, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio).

title: Houston Seeks 72 Parleys
description: HOUSTON May 18 (AP)Mayor Louie Welch said today that Houston's civic leaders would offer $350,000 in money and services to each of the major political parties to hold their 1972 national conventions at the Astrohall. This is less than half the amount each party requested but Mr. Welch said it was subject to increase.

title: CINERAMA WILL SELL 20% STOCK INTEREST
description: William R. Forman, chairman of Cinerama, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement by Cinerama to sell 3 million shares of the company's stock to Newport Industries, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of National Bulk Carriers, Inc., at $3.125 a share and to grant a fiveyear option to the purpurchaser to acquire an additional 1 million shares at the same price. The 3 million shares amount to more than 20 per cent of the total of 13.5 million Cinerama shares outstanding.

title: TV: Part of the Family Examines Three Deaths
description: There is no easy approach to Part of the Family. ReVolving around the deaths of three young persons caught in the crossfire of our nation's politicial and social crises, it is reallysomewhat like Edward Albee's fine All Over"about life, about the lives of the surviving family and friends. It is often deeply moving. It is occasionally, however, objectionably indulgent.

title: From Cork: A Green Machine
description: Mike Keogh is one Irish track athlete who took an unexpected detour between County Cork and Villanova University.

title: Education Board Hears Public On Curbing Violence in Schools
description: Students and parents asked the Board of Education last night to do something about violence in the schools, and were told that this is a national problem and that you should talk to your principal.

title: Turkey Announces Arrest of Student in Kidnapping of Israeli Consul
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 18 (AP)The Turkish authorities announced today the arrest of a student in the abduction of Ephraim Elrom, the Israeli Consul General.

title: Budget Cuts Sow Despair At a State Mental Hospital
description: WINGDALE, N. Y.  The traditional springtime party for employes with 25 years service will not be held this year at the Harlem Valley State Hospital.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One facet of your editorial policy seems to be completely inconsistent and wholly contradictory. You state that the modern conscience deems capital punishment revolting and barbaric. You further add that the hangman, the electric chair and the gas chamber have no place in a civilized society. Both premises are valid. It is noble and humane to have compassion for a criminal. Society may not have the right in today's culture to take the life of another, no matter what heinous crime may have been perpetrated.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINE SEES PROFIT IN 71
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 18 American Airlines will be in the black this year, even though it operated at a net loss of $25.6million in the four months ended April 30, George A. Spater, president, said today. In calendar 1970, the airline operated at a net loss of $26.4million.

title: Bombing Witness Offered Immunity
description: SEATTLE May 18Leslie Bacon, who has been in custody for three weeks as a material witness in an Investigation of the bombing of the United States Capitol, was offered a limited immunity by the Government tonight so that she might be required to answer questions put to her by a grand jury.

title: Theater: The Homecoming Revived
description: When Harold Pinter's The Tfomecoming was first introdtited on Broadway in 1967 there was a recalcitrance in some quarters to approach the play on its own terms. The Homecoming simply cannot be pigeonholed, even in terms of Pinter's other work  although clearly it bears his imprints: the feeling of lurking menace, the startling wit, the violent shifts in temper that in their absurdity seem more true to life than what usually passes for real life on the stage.

title: U.S. Jets Attack in North
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, May 19 (Reuters)Four United States supersonic jets attacked antiaircraft gun sites in North Vietnam in the last 48 hours, the United States military command reported today.

title: U.S. PUSHES EASING OF EXPORT CURBS
description: GENEVA, May 18  The Nixon Administration's campaign for a lowering of foreign barriers to United States exports in order to bolster the dollar is being carried to an international audience of financial and business leaders.

title: LA GUARDIA FRIENDS SEEK TO SAVE WNYC
description: Directors of the La Guardia Memorial. Association, consisting of close governmental associates and friends of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday not to sacrifice the city's radio and television facilities, WNYCAM, FM and TV, in the current budget crisis.

title: Dartmouth Faculty Asks Fully Coeducational College
description: HANOVER, N. H., May 18The Dartmouth College undergraduate faculty has voted overwhelmingly to ask the Dartmouth board of trustees to review in June a recent decision to consider establishing an associated school for women here rather than admitting women directly to the college.

title: Packard Visits Athens On Mediterranean Tour
description: ATHENS. May 18Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard arrived today on fournation Mediterranean mission to assess ways to bolster United States defense capability in the area.

title: Use of Old Laws Planned To Fight Ocean Pollution
description: WASHINGTON May 18 (AP) The Corps of Engineers and the Coast Guard will use a pair of 19thcentury laws in new drive to control ocean polluters according to Representative Henry S. Reuss chairman of the House Subcommittee on Conservation and Natural Resources.

title: OTB Takes Three Options on Future
description: Legal offtrack betting will continue here next Monday even if outofstate races have to be used, a spokesman for the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation said yesterday.

title: Italy Acts to Halt Fouling of Coast
description: ROME, May 18Italian authorities acted today to halt further pollution of the country's west coast and to alert the public against what they described as grave and continuing deterioration of the environment.

title: THOMAS P. CLEERE
description: Thomas P. Cleere, picture editor for many years of The New York JournalAmerican, died Monday in Goddard Hospital, Stoughton, Mass. He was 58 years old and was living in Randolph, Mass.

title: Disaster Areas Declared
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) President Nixon declared today three counties in Tennessee struck by tornadoes on May 7 as major disaster areas The White House listed no specific amount of Government funds allocated to Carroll, Gibson and Benton Counties, pending further survey of aid needed.

title: Buffalo Students Discuss Drug Problems
description: BUFFALO  The game is on Mary, a 20yearold student at the University of Buffalo.

title: TV Program for Common Cause Documents Opposition to War
description: Common Cause, the citizens lobby of which John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, is chairman, is screening a special television program, The People Speak Out on the War, to respond to the views of President Nixon on the war in Indochina.

title: Less Daylight Time Voted
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee approved today an amendment to the Uniform Time Act by which daylight saving time would extend from Memorial Day to Sept. 30. Daylight saving time now extends from the last Sunday in April to the last Sunday in October.

title: F.B.I. Candidacy Rejected
description: MILWAUKEE, May 18 (AP) Jervis Leonard, a former Assistant Attorney General, said today that was no substance to reports he was a candidate to succced 1 Edgar Hoover as the director of the Federal Borean of Investigation.

title: Advertising:
description: By using minority media, an advertiser not only reaches his Minority group prospect better but also puts money Into the hands of small minority businesses, Livingston L. Wingate, executive director of the New York Urban League said yesterday.

title: PROSECUTOR OUT IN BERGEN COUNTY
description: TRENTON, May 18Gov. William T. Cahill today ordered Robert Diits superseded , as prosecutor of Bergen County and announced that Mr. Diits was being investigated for his official conduct in office.

title: Max Lowenthal, Lawyer, Dies; Book on F.B.I. Stirred a Storm
description: Max Lowenthal, a lawyer who served as counsel to Congressional committees in the 1930's and 1940's and who wrote a sharp critique of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1950, died yesterday in his home at 444 Central Park West of a heart ailment. He was 83 years old.

title: Another Curb Upset
description: ORANGETOWN, N. Y., May 18A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that local laws limiting the places where abortions may be performed are unconstitutional because they conflict with state law, which sets no such regulation.

title: CZECH TENNIS ACE PLANS TO DEFECT
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 18 (UPI):Milan Holecek, the 27yearold Czechoslovak tennis star, said today he did not intend to return home and would seek United States oit izenship.

title: Gadgetry Mars Serious Music In Song Recital
description: The first rule for a talented musician in giving recital is a simple one: Pick good music and trust it.

title: The Mansfield Amendment: Yes
description: WASHINGTONSenator Mansfield's proposal has been treated as an aberration by a normally balanced and solid politician. But with hindsight, it is Mr. Mansfield who is likely to appear the statesman and his opponents irresponsible. For there is an excellent case to be made for a substantial reduction in American forces in Europe.

title: Harbor Welcome Is Given Tube for Queens Subway
description: A tube large enough to drive four trains through it was towed into New York Bay yesterday to a hero's welcome.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As spokesmen for the labor and employer group of New York's building and construction industry, we wish to point out where you erred in the May 7 editorial, Stretching Construction Dollars.

title: Commuter Lines Striving For Runs This Morning
description: The metropolitan area's railroads were striving early this morning to resume full service following the end last night of the signalmen's strike, which had curtailed service for 145,000 rail commuters here.

title: GROUP HERE SUES ON SURVEILLANCE
description: A suit to bar the city's Police Department from the surveillance of political dissenters in violation of their constituional rights of free speech association and privacy was filed yesterday in Federal Court here.

title: Agnew Finds Nixon Foes Unremitting
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 18Vice President Agnew said here today that President Nixon had been confronted every step of the way by an opposition that views his defeat and the defeat of his policies as its prime order of national business, second to none.Mississippi for a Republican party function in a year and half. He is well regarded in Mississippi, particularly among the new urban middle class upon which the Republicans are trying to build a party in this onceagricultural state.

title: 8 BRITISH SOLDIERS WANDER INTO CHINA
description: HONG KONG Wednesday, May 19 (Reuters)Eight British soldiers inadvertently drove across the Chinese frontier yesterday, were held for several hours and released early today, a Government spokesman said.

title: Pollution Laws Called A Threat to Industries
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)  The United States Chamber of Commerce warned today that antipollution laws could kill entire industries and that the Government should be ready to pay for the economic consequences.

title: DALTON HEAD GAINS SUPPORT IN VOTING
description: Donald Barr the embattled headmaster of the Dalton School had won a large measure of support early this morning withe election of a new president and new member of the board of trustees.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon has stated repeatedly that his Administration was not responsible for starting the Vietnam war. This is correct. ButWhose Administration is responsible for the 68 battle deaths the week of May 6, 1971?

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The biggest threat to subSaharan Africa is that when the present generation of leaders fades away there will be a struggle for power among younger politicians who have neither the experience of national administration taught by latterday colonialism nor the prestige of the successful revolution against colonialism which produced today's independent black nations. At that point there is grave danger that tribalism's centrifugal forces may dissolve many new nationstates into chaotic fractions.

title: Fox Battle Ends With Results Undisclosed
description: WILMINGTON, Del., May 18  After two months of constant vituperation, frenzied solicitation of proxies and widely publicized legal challenges, management and an insurgent group of stockholders of the 20th CenturyFox Film Corporation ostensibly brought their battle to a quiet close at the annual meeting here today.

title: Findings on CarTheft Ring Go to Bronx Grand Jury
description: Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said yesterday that for the last four months his office had been investigating a large cartheft ring that operated with the possible aid of corrupt. policemen.

title: Hong Kong Dishes Recalled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 18 (UPI)The Federal Government reported today the recall of a line of enameled metal dishes made in Hong Kong because they were found to have dangerous levels of poisonous cadmium. A spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration said that the Akron Company of Los Angeles was voluntarily recalling the dishes.

title: Howard Hall, Former Head Of Amana Company, Dies
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 18Howard Hall, former president and chairman of the Amana Refrigeration Company, producer of home and industrial refrigeration equipment, died on Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: U. S. Expects SoviettoTest Large New Missiles Soon
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Administration officials have disclosed that the Soviet Union is pressing ahead so rapidly with its new missile program that test firings are expected within the next few months.

title: CLEMENCY ASKED FOR LENINGRAD 9
description: MOSCOW, May 18The lawyers for the nine Soviet Jews on trial for antiSoviet activity asked the Leningrad court today to take account of the defendants backgrounds and hand down lighter sentences than those demanded by the prosecutor yesterday.

title: 6 ARE ARRAIGNED IN 1970 JAIL RIOTS
description: Six men were arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens on a series of charges growing out of the riots in the Queens House of Detention in Long Island City last October.

title: Concern in France: If Britain Joins Six, Will All Speak English?
description: PARIS, May 18When President Pompidou and Prime Minister Heath hold seven hours of intimate conversation on Thursday and Friday, they will have to use interpreters because neither knows enough of the other's language to speak for himself.

title: OneThird of Blacks Found in 15 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Nearly half the nation's black population Is now concentrated in 50 cities, and third of the toal is in 15 cities, according to a Cenusu Bureau compilation made public today.

title: NIXON ANSWERS BLACK PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18President Nixon issued a 112page response today to 60 demands made by the black members of the House of Representatives, rejecting some of their major proposals but saying he agreed with several others.

title: Destroyer Spills Oil Here
description: A leak of undetermined origin In the Massey, a Navy destroyer docked in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and used for Navy Reserve training, caused 200 gallons of fuel oil to spill into the East River yesterday afternoon. Firemen, using a 200footlong flotation collar and hoses, confined the oil to between Piers C and D. The 4,000gallon tank from which the oil came was drained to prevent further leakage.

title: Feminist Accuses Press
description: WASHINGTON May 18 (Reuters)Germaine Greer, the feminist and author of the book The Female Eunuch, accused the American press today of failing to report adequately on social issues of particular interest to women. She spoke at a luncheon of the National Press Club, which only this year agreed to admit women members.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bausch & Lomb, Inc., announced yesterday in Rochester, the election of Daniel G. Shuman as chairman and Jack D. Harby as president of the optical goods and scientific instruments company. William W. McQuilkin, who has been president since 1959 and chairman since 1969, was elected chairman of the executive committee; succeeding Carl S. Hallauer, who will continue as a director of the company. Both Mr. Schuman and Mr. Harby have ben executive vice presidents since 1967.

title: CITY SCHOOL OFFICE ASSAILED BY BEANIE
description: The Board of Education was asked yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame to withdraw a completely unnecessary proposed lease for a district school board office that would cost the city $413,294 over five years.

title: Museum Opens Pacific Exhibit
description: The sounds of warm Pacific waves rolling up a Samoan beach swirled through the newest exhibition hall at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday.

title: 2 Church Groups Disavow Unreliable Film Ratings
description: Protestant and Roman Catholic motion picture agencies have withdrawn their support of the movie industry's voluntary filmrating system.

title: Mitchell Says Crime Fight Is Pressed
description: ATLANTA, May 18Attorney General John N. Mitchell said here today that at least 1,600 figures in organized crime were indicted or convicted by the Federal Government last year.

title: A Correction
description: DETROIT, May 18Directors of Bank of the Commonwealth have declared a dividend of $1.45  a share on the bank's 304,465 outstanding preferred shares payable June 1 to stockholders of record May 21. A report in The New York Times on Tuesday that the directors had omitted the current dividend on preferred shares was incorrect.

title: COURT BARS ACTION ON SEGREGATION IN JERSEY SCHOOLS
description: TRENTON, May 18A special threejudge Federal Court refused today to nullify existing public school district lines in New Jersey to force racial integration.

title: Bridge: Aces Better Than Blue Team? 72 Olympiad May Give Clue
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 18 The victory of the Aces in the 1971 world champion ship, which ended here yesterday, answered one question but left another unanswered. It is now clear that the professional sextet of Jim Jacoby, Bob Wolff, Mike Lawrence, Bob. Goldman, Bill Eisenberg and Bob Hammen is the best team now active in the game. They won both the qualifying stage and the final against France in convincing style.

title: Burger Assails Unruly Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called upon the legal profession today to develop stronger disciplinary procedures to deal with illmannered lawyers who employ more adrenalin than judgment in court.

title: Tighter Controls for a Slimming Belt
description: From now on, the Federal Trade Commission has decreed, this phrase is to be included in the advertising for and packaging of ToneOMatic belts, one brand of weighted belt sold as a waist slenderizer and muscle strengthener. The belt is made of leatherette and is divided into compartments that are filled with lead granules. It is priced at $20.

title: Robert Mayer of Newsday Wins Mike Berger Award
description: Robert Mayer, a columnist for Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, has won the 1971 Mike Berger Award for a series of features on New York, Elie Abel, the dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, announced yesterday.

title: LOU MAXON, BUILT MAJOR AD AGENCY
description: DETROIT, May 18 (AP) Lou Russell Maxon, retired advertising agency executive and philanthropist, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old. Mr. Maxon began Maxon, Inc., which grew into one of the nation's top advertising agencies, when he was 27. The agency was disbanded shortly after his retirement eight years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Pusillanimous is the word to characterize the conduct of the Korean police action by President Harry S. Truman. Wretched characterizes the conduct of the Vietnam conflict by Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon.

title: MRS. JOHN L. HANDY
description: STOWE, Vt., May 18Mrs. Virginia Seiberling Handy, wife of John L. Handy, who retired recently as president of Handy Associates, management consultants, died yesterday. She was 71 years old and lived here on Mountain Road.

title: The Mansfield Proposal
description: It is a bizarre context in which the Senate will vote today on Majority Leader Mansfield's amendment to slash American forces in Europe in half by the end of 1971. In Moscow, Premier Kosygin has just reiterated the Soviet Union's willingness to do everything possible reach agreement on mutual force reductions in Central Europe by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: The Mansfield Amendment: No
description: The sudden reappearance of the Mansfield Resolution in its present form constitutes one of the vagaries of American politics which from time to time confound our allies and shock those responsible for the conduct of foreign policy in this country.

title: Life Returning to Routine for Egyptians
description: CAIRO. May 17The excitement of conspiracy and political upheaval that has gripped Egypt for the last several days was dying down rapidly today, with people revertng to the more mundane aspects of daily life.

title: Cambodian Aide Denies Damage to Angkor Wat
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 18 (AP)The head of a national committee charged with protection of the ancient Khmer ruins at Angkor has denied that Angkor Wat was damaged by a Government artillery barrage, the official Cambodian news agency said today.

title: 9th New York Film Fete Trims Fare, Citing Record Loss in 70
description: The New York Film Festival, scheduled for Oct. 1 to Oct. 15 at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater, will present perhaps 12 fewer films this year than it did last year. It has reappointed Richard Roud as director.

title: BedfordStuyvesant Relatively Calm After Outbursil
description: A relative calm came to the trashlittered streets of the BedfordStnyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday, following a series of disorders there on Monday.

title: LONG COOLINGOFF
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday. May 19The nation's railroad workers began returning to their jobs early this morning after Congress passed and the President signed a bill ordering an immediate end to a strike by signalmen.

title: MADRIGAL CHORUS OF C.W.POST HEARD
description: With Casual grace and an air of genuine pleasure In what they were doing, the Madrigal Singers of C. W. Post College strode, singing, on to the Tully Hall stage Monday night to open the concert they shared with the college's Chamber Singers.

title: CAR MAKERS SCORED ON RECALL NOTICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) The Transportation Department contends that recall notices sent by automobile manufacturers to owners of defective cars and trucks often fail to spell out all the possible dangers involved.

title: Business Unit for Arts Plans to Widen Its Role
description: When the Business ComMateo for the Arts was formed about four years ago by more than 100 chief executives of major American corporations, it assumed it would be selfliquidating as goon as its mission of educating corporations to support the arts was accomplished. But at the fourth annual meeting of the committee at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday it became clear that the committee was preparing to brOaden its role and.stay in business indefini??ly.

title: Power Politics
description: Governor Rockefeller's bill to regulate the siting power plantswhich has been killed in committee but could be revivedwould in effect place the admittedly urgent demand for power far above all environmental considerations. Final decisions on location of plants would rest with the Public Service Commission. Whatever disapproval the Department of Environmental Conservation might register concerning a proposed power site, the P.S.C. would be free to give priorityas it almost surely wouldto the need for power.

title: The Berrigan Indictment
description: The recently revised indictment against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five other persons suggests that the Justice Department prepared this potentially important criminal case in an extraordinarily careless and irresponsible manner.

title: CANCER STUDIES BACK SCREENING
description: LOS ANGELES, May 18Several studies described here today indicate that relatively simple screening programs can detect breast cancer at an earlier, more curable stage, producing a much better chance of surviving the disease, the most common cancer that can be fatal to women.

title: NEWSMEDIA REVIEW BEGINS PUBLICATION
description: The publication of the first issue of [more], a critical review of the national and local news media by wellknown professional writers, was announced here yesterday by Richard Pollak, editor of the new journal, and William Woodward 3d, its publisher.

title: Batavia Revenue Drops
description: ALBANY, May 18 (AP) New York State announced today that it collected $1,221,184 in parimutuel revenue from the 51day spring meeting at Batavia Downs, almost $115,000 less than last year.

title: Braves Defeat Mets, 86; Garr, Aaron, Hit Homers
TV RECEIVER PRICES RAISED 24% BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would increase prices selectively by 2 per cent to 4 per cent on its 1971 line of television receivers. This followed similar actions by competitors.

title: IRWIN A. WEINER
description: Irwin A. Weiner, a business agent of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday in Coney Island Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived at 3000 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: MOSCOW PLEDGES EFFORT ON TROOPS IF WEST RESPONDS
description: MOSCOW, May 18Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin said today that the Soviet Union would do everything possible to reach agreement on reducing forces in Europe if the Western powers display real readiness to take practical steps in this direction.

title: Post for Student Rejected By Berkeley City Council
description: BERKELEY, Calif, May 18The Berkeley City Council rejected last night a bid to appoint a University of California graduate student, Richard Brown, to a vacancy on the Council.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is the irony of our times that the Metropolitan Museum spent $5.5 million on a single painting by Velasquez when so many people are jobless and hungry in the city's slums. Was this purchase in the public interest? [Editorial May 18.]

title: Raymond Evans, Manager At First National City Bank
description: CALDWELL, N. J., May 18 Raymond M. Evans, manager of the personalfinance division of the First National City Bank at its New York headquarters, died of a stroke yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 61 years old and lived at 6 Highview Road. Caldwell.

title: Fogg Bids Agnes Mongan Au Revoir
description: Agnes Mongan, a brilliantly rational woman who relishes her sobriquet, La folle du Fogg, was the recipient of festive tributes Monday night upon the occasion of her retirement as director of Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum. The faculty dressed up, the invited students combed their hair, and guests came from as far away as Los Angeles to celebrate Miss Mongan's 42yearlong association with the museum. The farewell was made perfect because it is temporary. Miss Mongan will return to the Fogg after a year's leave of absence to resume duties as curator and lecturer.

title: Rewarding Irresponsibility
description: By once again making interim pay increases part of an emergency backtowork law, Congress seems determined to create incentives for more irresponsible union tieups of the nation's railroads. That unpleasant prospect clouds the relief the country feels now that the trains are running again. Both Senate and House have repeated for striking railroad signalmen the same mistake Congress made last December when it hooked an order for higher pay to a law mandating an elevenweek truce in a strike by four other rail unions.

title: Conservative Gets U.S. Post
description: Kieran O'Doherty, a founder and vice chairman of the Conservative party in New York state, was appointed by the Nixon Administration as a $30,000ayear consultant in the Department of Commerce. Mr. O'Doherty, a 44yearold lawyer and unsuccessful candidate for Lieutenant Governor in 1964, will work on a study of the franchising industry.

title: 800 Pay Homage to Fireman Who Lost His Life in Jamaica Explosion
description: Walter J. Bozenko, the 680th fireman to die in the line of duty during the 106year history of the New York City Fire Department, was buried yesterday afternoon at Long Island National Cemetery, at Pinelawn in Suffolk County.

title: Role of Rochester Scouts as Informers Is Belittled
description: Are Boy scouts being used as informers by the Federal Bureau of Investigation?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The April 11 letter by Frank Maria supporting Senator Fulbright's remark on Israel demonstrates that when people have to make a choice between antiSemitism and antiCommunism they choose antiSemitism.

title: City Schools Ask $678 Million to Build
ARMY MYLAI INQUIRY SCORED BY DEFENSE
description: FORT MEADE, Md., May 18 (UPI)A lawyer charged today that Lieut. Gen. William R. Peers consistently violated the constitutional rights of the soldiers he questioned about the 1968 Mylai slayings.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: Welfare Measure Passed In Assembly After Tabling
description: ALBANY, May 18The Assembly today approved by vote of 88 to 59 a measure sponsored by Governor Rockefeller to create the office of Welfare Inspector General with broad powers to investigate state and local welfare operations.
