The measure, which had been tabled yesterday, now goes to the Senate.

title: Increase Is Recorded for First Quarter
description: The J. C. Penney Company had a 13.7 per cent gain in net income on a 9.9 rise in sales in the first quarter ended May 1, William M. Batten, chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday. Penney's is the country's second largest departmentstore and catalogue chain after Sears, Roebuck & Co.

title: Pleiku Center for Addicts Source of Dispute
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 12  They're always threatening to close the place down, said Specialist 4 Robert Canberra, a 20yearold Army medical corpsman who once used heroin and who now runs Highland House where addicts in the 52d Combat Aviation Battalion at Camp Holloway can come to try to get off drugs.

title: Protests in Capital Cost $5.5Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The disruptions and other antiwar demonstrations here from April 24 to May 5 cost the Federal GoVernment and the District of Columbia more than $5.5million Federal and city officials said today.

title: Rep. Ford Discusses
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)  The House minority leader, Gerald R. Ford, suggested today that the Government might have to take action to push up some interest rates to slow the flow of dollars out of the country.

title: Mobil Oil Assesses Ecology Impact
description: SARASOTA, Fla., May 18 (AP)William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, told stockholders today that concern about ecology is the main barrier to expanded oil exploration, especially in promising offshore areas.

title: Company Issues Warning,
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation warned yesterday that the Government would lose more than $250million in reduced tax income if Congress rejected the bill to authorize loan guarantees in that amount, and Lockheed was thereby forced into bankruptcy.

title: F.P.C. Nominee Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nomination of Dr. Pinkney C. Walker dean of the University of Missouri School of Business Administration, to the Federal Power Commission. The nomination was opposed by Senator Lee Metcalf Democrat of Montana who said Dr. Walker was too closely associated with the power industry.

title: E.E.C. Aide Assails Rumors From Bonn
description: PARIS, May 18An official of the European Economic Community has suggested that the monetary crisis has been aggravated by West German officials who talk too much and while not mentioning him specifically has pointed the finger at Bonn's Economics and Finance Minister, Karl Schiller.

title: ENEMY OVERRUNS A 2D TOWN IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE. Laos, May 18Government forces suffered a new blow in the southern panhandle of Laos today as North Vietnamese troops, attacking behind a heavy rocket barrage, overran the town of Dong Hene.

title: Walkout Forces Layoffs Of Thousands Over U.S.
description: The nation's economy was hit hard by the rail strike yesterday before Congress voted to halt the strike, as thousands of workers were laid off in the ??, coal and food industries.

title: Panel Bids Public Join Pollution Fight
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 The Presidential Citizens Advisory Committee on Environmental Quality called today for a broad range of public involvement in the fight against pollution of the environment.

title: HOUSING STARTS SHOW SLIM DROP
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) The pace of homebuilding declined slightly in April, but it continued to run well ahead of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 46 Texas Counties Decisively Approve Legal Mixed Drinks
description: DALLAS May 18 (AP) Thirsty Texans who have not been able to buy a mixed drink at a public Dar since 1919 voted overwhelmingly today for legal mixed drinks in the 46 counties where the referendum was held.

title: MRS. CHARLES LANGMUIR
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 18 Mrs. Edith Ruggles Langmuir, widow of Charles H. Langmuir, a retired vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, died today in the Merwick nursing home of Princeton Hospital. She was 93 years old.

title: Councilmen Dispute Welfare Budget
description: The Lindsay administration's welfare budget, its jobcutback claims and its projected taxyield figures were attacked yesterday by City Counalmen.

title: An Optimistic Religious Leader Lois Harkrider Stair
description: ROCHESTER, May 18The first woman to becothe moderator, or spiritual leader, of the threemillionmember United Presbyterian Church, maintaind that religion is far from dead.

title: Albatross and Local Time Win Division Trials for Messenger
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 18 Albatross ($2.60) and Local Time ($6.20) captured their respective divisions in tonight's onemile trials for Saturday night's Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Brooklyn Unveils Plans for a Museum
description: Mrs. John V. Lindsay officially unveiled architectural plans for the new Brooklyn Children's Museum yesterday, while many on hand for the ceremony speculated as to when and whether it would actually be built.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although I am wholeheartedly in sympathy with the purport of your editorial of May 6 concerning this Government's repudiation of its obligation to pay its dues to the International Labor Organization, I think by omission you do an injustice to Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn.

title: ExAddicts Ask Early Drug Education
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Four rehabilitated drug addicts told a Presidential commission today that compulsory elementary school instruction on the dangers of drug abuseincluding prekindergarten indoctrinationwould be the greatest preventive to future addiction. One member of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse then said, This is one of the most important points made in hearings before this panel to date. The member, Dr. John A. Howard, president of Rockford College, congratulated the four men and other members nodded assent.

title: U.S. CONCEDES TAP IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 18 (UPI)Attorney General John N. Mitchell in an affidavit submitted in United States District Court here concedes that the Government used electronic survillance in gathering evidence against Sister Elizabeth McAlister one of eight antiwar activists indicted in an alleged kidnapping and bombing plot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Jews in the Soviet Union are threatened not only with continued attempts at the extinction of their cultural and religious heritage, but also with frightening efforts at physical intimidation, even annihilation.

title: LAWYERS SUM UP IN THE SEALE CASE
description: NEW HAVEN, May 18In six hours of argument  using shouts, sarcasm and sometimes insultsthe three lawyers in the SealeHuggins murder than today summed up for the jury their different versions of the kidnapping and killing of Alex Rackley in May, 1969.

title: Denver Runoff Likely
description: DENVER, May 18 (AP)Mayor William H. McNichols of Denver and a fellow Democrat, Dale Tooley appeared headed for a runoff election June 15 according to unofficial returns in the nonpartisan city election today.

title: U.S. CRIME AGENCY IS DECENTRALIZED
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Jerris Leonard, the new head of the Administration's program to improve state and local crimefighting, announced today a revamping of his agency that will make it more decentralized.

title: Court Voids State's Limitation On Medicaid in Abortion Cases
description: The State Supreme Court annulled yesterday a state directive that barred Medicaid payments for abortions to all but medically indicated cases.

title: Inquiry on Auto Industry Urged in Antismog Delay
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Representative Phillip Burton of California, purporting the discovery of new evidence in a hitherto secret Government document, called today for reopening the Government's investigation of an alleged criminal conspiracy by the automobile industry to keep antismog devices off automobiles.

title: Advertising:
description: The first formal and official announcement of the industrywide program of advertising selfregulation was made yesterday at the first international meeting of the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Miami.

title: Led by Mayor, Spring Bicycle Season in Park Opens
description: The lazy vistas and fairytale emerald light of Central Park have been luring the city's masses for more than century. But in case anybody hadn't gotten the word about New York's rhapsody in green, Mayor Lindsay and pack of cycling social figures were on hand last night to sing its praises.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Patent President Nixon accepted the resignation of George A. Gorecki, retiring as examinerinchief of the Board of Appeals of the Patent Office.

title: Israeli Cabinet Meets
description: TEL AVIV, May 18 Premier Golda Meir convened her Cabinet today in an extraordinary ,meeting in Jerusalem to discuss the abduction of Mr. Elrom.

title: Carnegie Groups to Back G.M. at Annual Meeting
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York and the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching announced yesterday their support for the recommendations of the Genral Motors Corporation management at the company's annual meeting this Friday.

title: Computer Makers Show Programed for Optimism
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 18The spring joint computer conference opened here today in an aura of cautious optimism about an upturn in the industry's immediate prospects.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Misunderstandings of the intent and functioning of the Appalachian Regional Development Program have resulted in incorrect appraisals of its success in the five years it has been in operation.

title: Nixon Moving to Meet Latin Pleas for More Arms Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 18President Nixon has exercised his option to exceed the ceiling of $75million a year set by Congress in 1967 on United States arms aid to Latin, America exclusive of training. He has also recommended to Congress that the ceiling next year be raised to $150million.

title: Villagers With Holy Relics Pray Before Etna's Lava
description: CATANIA, Sicily, May 18  The farmers and winegrowers of Sant Alfio, a village on the eastern slope of Mount Etna, carried relics of their patron saints some two miles up the mountainside and prayed that lava slowly streaming down from a lateral crater would spare their homes.

title: RIZZO WINS RACE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 18Former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo crushed Representative William J. Green to day in Philadelphia's Democratic mayoral primary. State Representative Hardy Williams placed a distant third.

title: Accounting Board Seeks Breakdowns
description: The Accounting Principles Board, the senior rulemaking body of the accounting profession, plans next year to require that diversified companies publish a breakdown of their sales and earnings by major product lines.

title: Books of The Times
description: All I could talk about was babies and recipes! This is the headline of a recent advertisement on the plight of the woman who is intellectually out of it. While no one would call Mary McCarthy intellectually out of it, the line comes to mind in connection with her new novel, Birds of America. Forsaking the group and the groves, Miss McCarthy has elected to take us into the kitchen and nursery of her imagination. In many ways, it's a fascinating experience. (Can you imagine Jana Child writing a political novel?) We find out how she feels about frozen foods, injected turkeys, bean pots, mixes oh, all sorts of things. And we meet Peter, the baby. He's 19 old, but a baby nevertheless, and only a mother could love him. As the book opens, Peter and his mother, Rosamund, are taking refresher course in Americana. They're revisiting Rocky Port, Maine, where they had spent a happy summer celebrating her second divorce four years ago. But alas, Rocky Port has been invaded and occupied by that archvillain of American imperialism, the tourist. The Great Horned Owl has died of a broken heart, the cormorants are gone, and Peter and Rosamund can't find their favorite waterfall, which has undoubtedly been bulldozed under for a superhighway.

title: CEYLONESE REBELS FIND THEIR VOICE
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 14  In the second month of the Ceylonese student rebellion, a selfstyled spokesman for the rebels has emerged here. His code name is Tilak. which means jewel in Sinhalese, and he is busy looking up Western journalists here while the Ceylonese authorities are trying to hunt him down.

title: Humphrey to Address Class
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 18 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota and former Vice President in the Johnson Administration, will deliver the commencement address June 6 at the University of Bridgeport.

title: Sparkman Hails T.V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, saluted the Tennessee Valley Authority today on its 38th anniversary. By promoting the economic progress of the T. V. A. area, he said, T. V. A. has helped promote the progress of the nation.

title: Navy Lets $101 Million Job In Sonar Project to G.E.
description: SYRACUSE, May 18 (AP)The General Electric Company has received a $101million contract from the Navy to produce sonar systems for 30 Spruance class destroyers, it was announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: Frank Mankiewicz, the Washington columnist who was press secretary to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Is expected to join George S. McGovern's presidential campaign this week.

title: Oil Platform Burns
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 18 (AP)  An oil production platform housing 16 wells off the Louisiana coast burst into flames today, but the fire was out within hours after the wells were shut down. The Coast Guard said there were no injuries.

title: Fanny May Wins Status Of Government Securities
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Internal Revenue Service has ruled that both debt obligations and stock of the Federal Nationl Mortgage Association can be treated as Government securities for purposes of purchase by savings and loan association and mutual savings banks.

title: House Votes to Consider Nixon's Manpower Plan
description: WASHINGTON May 18The Nixon Administration won a preliminary skirmish today in its fight to keep alive a key part of the President's proposal for revenue sharing with the states and localities.

title: Randall to Replace Nash
description: Tony Randall will replace Ogden Nash, who is ill, narrator in the Carnival Promenade to be presented at a Philharmonic Promenades Concert at Philharmonic Hall on June 2, 3 and 5. Mr. Randall will read the poet's verses for Carnival of Marriage, a potpourri for narrator, piano and orchestra arranged from the works of several composers by Andre Kostelanetz, the Promenades conductor.

title: Market Place: A Poker Game In Smoking Car
description: Put this in your locomotive and smoke it: There can be little doubt that shareholders and creditors of the Penn Central Company are playing an elaborate game of poker over the few remaining assets of this holding company.

title: VISTA Merger Survives a Test in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 18President Nixon's plan to merge the Peace Corps, VISTA and four smaller volunteer antipoverty programs into a new agency survived its first important test in Congress today.

title: Convict Who Fled Attica Held Here
description: The convict who confounded prison officials by slipping past the supposedly escapeproof gates of the Attica Correctional Facility was captured yesterday morning in Greenwich Village. He was so surprised he couldn't say anything, said John J. McCarthy, the head of the Correction Department bureau that coordinated the more than monthlong manhunt for the fugitive, Joseph Sullivan. Mr. McCarthy said Sullivan was apprehended as he walked down 11th Street toward University, Place. He was dressed in a sports jacket and was carrying an unloaded sawedoff.22caliber rifle and ammunition in a valise. He never had a chance to get it, said Mr. McCarthy. The fugitive also had $44 and a subway token.

title: Conflicting Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, May 18A Senate finance subcommittee taking a longterm look into the nation's trade problems, heard directly conflicting testimony today on the issue of the seriousness of import competition for United States industry.

title: $52MILLION RISE ASKED FOR CONED
description: ALBANY, May 18An examiner for the Public Service Commission recommended today, that Consolidated Edison be given a temporary increase in its electricity rates of $52,192,000 a year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Long before the first ball was tossed in a spring training encampment last February, the one indisputable fact Acknowledged by most selfanointed experts was the identity of the World Series contestants for the following October. Once again it would be the Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds. So superior did each appear to be that there was no way of preventing a repeat confrontation.

title: Detergent Curb in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 18Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis today signed legislation that prohibits the sale or use of highphosphorous detergents in Maine after June 1, 1972. The law specifies highphosphorous detergents as any presoak soap enzyme or other cleaning agents containing more than 8.7 per cent phosphorous by weight.

title: Surcharge Study Issued
description: Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that the abolition of fixed sales commissions for stock transactions would destroy the central securities markets as they are known today.

title: JURY IN LOUISIANA FREES STATE AIDE
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 19 Louisiana's Attorney General, Jack P. F. Gremillion, and two other defendants were found not guilty today on 15 counts charging conspiracy, mail fraud and fraud in the sale of securi ties and the sale of unregistered securities of the Louisiana Loan and Thrift Corporation.

title: A.T.&T. Plans Offering Of $1.4Billion in Stocks
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday plans to raise nearly $1.4billion in new capital through the sale of preferred stock. If successful, the offer ing would be the largest single stock sale in history.

title: PARLEY SET TODAY ON CITY'S BUDGET
description: The summit meeting to find the money to fill New York City's budget gap will begin this afternoon in Albany.

title: Russians Launch a Spacecraft On 6Month Trip Toward Mars
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, May 20 The Soviet Union announced early today that it had launched an instrumented spacecraft to ward the planet Mars. It is scheduled to reach its destina tion in November after a voy age of about 290 million miles.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 19 (UPI) The Maine House rejected to day, 89 to 53, a proposed re form of the state's 19th cen tury abortion law.

title: MRS. J. HOWARD WOOD
description: CHICAGO, May 19 (UPI) Mrs. J. Howard Wood, wife of the chairman of the executive committee of The Tribune Com pany, died yesterday in Sanibel, Fla. She was 72 years old. The Tribune Company is the parent organization of The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News, the Ontario Paper Com pany and other corporations.

title: LOUIS GREBENAK
description: Louis Grebenak, an artist and teacher, died of cancer in Fort Hamilton Veterans Hospital on Monday. He was 58 years old and lived at 16 Montgomery Place in Brooklyn.

title: 8FootTall Woman Dies
description: HOUSTON, May 19 (Reuters) Delores Pullard Johnson, who at 8 feet 2 inches was listed as the world's tallest woman, died in a hospital here yester day. She was 24 years old and had been employed by a travel ing carnival.

title: C.B.S. Signs Cosby for 1972
description: Bill Cosby, whose current show on the National Broad casting Company network was canceled, has signed with the Columbia Broadcasting System to do an hourlong weekly se ries of comedy and variety in the fall of 1972. Robert. D. Wood, C.B.S. network presi dent, said the television pro gram would originate in New York.

title: Johnson Ceremony on TV
description: All three major networks plan live television coverage of the dedication ceremonies Saturday of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library in Austin, Tex., spokesmen for the networks said yesterday. The coverage is to begin at 12:30 P.M. and con tinue for 3 to 45 minutes, ac cording to The Associated Press.

title: LENINGRAD COURT WEIGHING VERDICT
description: MOSCOW, May 19The judge and two laymen sitting as cojudges in the Leningrad trial of nine Jews retired today to arrive at a judgment in the case. The defendants are ac cused of a hijacking plot, the illegal possession of a duplicat ing machine and the dissemi nation of printed material of an allegedly antiSoviet nature.

title: West Side Road Finished
description: Drivers using the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel during the rush hours will have direct north bound access to the West Side Highway for the first time to day with the opening of a new traffic connection by the Tribor ough Bridge and Hunnel Au thority. Drivers can reach the access by riding under West Street through the underpass.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Living in Washington is wonderful, on account of the interesting neighbors you have.

title: Papp Altering Central Park Theater
description: The Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where more than a million people have seen free Shakespearean pro ductions over the last dec ade, is being altered from its fanlike design to a horseshoe form.

title: JAMES J. HEALEY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 19 James Joseph Healey, who re tired as president of the former Healey Buick Company, a dealer, died yesterday at St. Joseph Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 1064 Newfield Avenue.

title: Rights Group Fills Post
description: ATLANTA, May 19 (UPI) Stoney Cooks was named exec utive director of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence today. Mr. Cooks, 28 years old, said he would conduct an extensive black voter registra tion program. He joined the organization as a field orga nizer six years ago.

title: Phils Hand Mets 4th Loss in Row, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 19  The New York Mets got their first look tonight at Philadel phia's new $45million Veterans Stadium, but they found the na tives unusually hostile.

title: Miss Bacon Is Sent to Jail After Balking at Questions
description: SEATTLE, May 19Leslie Bacon was sent to jail tonight when she refused to answer questions before a Federal grand jury investigating the bombing of the United States Capitol. Miss Bacon, a 19yearold anti war activist, was sentenced for contempt in Federal Dis trict Court after having re jected the judge's grant of immunity from prosecution earlier today.

title: Enemy Base Sought
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 19 (AP)Seven hundred South Vietnamese troops were re ported combing an area along the Laotian border today, searching for a major North Vietnamese base and command headquarters.

title: Brooklyn Democratic Fete

title: A Mother's Plea
description: On April 26, 1971, my dream was fulfilled: I arrived home, home to Israel, to live, to work, to suffer and to enjoy life with my people. It was a great day for .me. But my victory is a bitter one. For my 23yearold daughter, Ruth, remained in Russia, in prison.

Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival; Paul Sills, producer of Story Theater, and The Phoenix Theater have been honored for outstanding achievements. Other citations have gone to John Guare, author of The House of Blue Leaves, Claire Bloom of Hedda Gabler and Anthony Quayle and Keith Baxter of Sleuth.

title: GENERAL DEMOTED OVER MYLAI CASE
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  The Army disciplined two gen erals today for failing to con duct an adequate investigation into the slayings of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai in 1968.

description: The head of Badische Anilin und SodaFabrik, A.G., of West Germany said yesterday that his company had agreed with the Dow Chemical Company to concentrate their joint fiber operations at the Dow Badische Company in Williamsburg, Va.

description: WASHINGTON, May 19, (Reuters)President Nixon pre dicted today that within the next few years the United States would be on friendly terms with all countries of the world, including China.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation announced yesterday in Chicago that John J. Nevin has been elected president and chief operating offi cer. Mr. Nevin, 44 years old, who was elected a director, had been vice president, marketing at the Ford Motor Compa ny since 1969. He served as a member of the automotive company's corporate operating pol icy and product commit tees. From 1966 to 1969, he was general manager of the AutoliteFord Parts Division. Mr. Nevin has held a number of positions in financial, product planning, marketing and general manage ment during his 17 years at Ford.

Ronald Reagan of California as his successor, the Gallup Poll reported today. Vice President Agnew would be the second choice and Governor Rockefeller of New York would be third.

title: Screen: 'Guess What We Learned . . .':Avildsen's Work Boils Stereotype Enemies Two Suburban Families Fight Sex Education
description: When John G. Avildsen's "Joe" opened last year, some critics detected a certain ambiguity in the quality of its contempt for its hardhat hero. In "Guess What We Learned in School Today?," an earlier Avildsen that opened yesterday at the Loew's Cine, there is no such ambiguity, merely stupid hatred, but there are ineptitudes and unrewarding obscurities enough to sink the movie.Deep inside "Guess What We Learned in School Today?" is a burlesque horror story about two suburban husbands, Roger Manley and Lance Battle, who fight to maintain their families' purity and the American Way of Life against the evil incursions of pot, Communism and the carnal knowledge to be unleashed should be education be taught in the local schools by one Dr. Lily Whitehorn.As you will have noticed, the film makes rather a thing of its personal names, and since Manley learns to his own distaste that he is homosexual and Battle has for the last 10 years been impotent, the irony sits heavy on each identification. Lily Whitehorn, a lanky spinster speaking truth, betrays herself only by an occasional Freudian slip ("wildly" for "widely") into the kind of movie "Guess What We Learned in School Today?" should have been content to remain.The movie it keeps trying to be, however, is an amalgam of social satire and sane sex propaganda and it succeeds with neither. It attacks mostly easy enemies (uptight cops, super patriots, militarism, brand names, etc.) and it defends nothing at all except good appetites and therapeutic pornography.This is where I feel a certain doubleness of intention in "Guess What We Learned in School Today?" For where it ambitiously produces everything it despises (Lance and Roger have elaborate on-screen fantasies and a whole slew of playable character quirks), it scarcely presents what it admires and time and again it comes to look like a series of blackout skits from the more inhibited edges of an exploitation movie.Because I happen to like some exploitation movies and to deplore the pious simplicities of this film, I can salvage from it only the memory of a few good women who might have been put to better use: Rosella Olson (Mrs. Manley) for her fine body, Jane MacLeod (Mrs. Battle) for her plump and pretty face, and Yvonne McCall (Dr. Whitehorn), whose fantastic freckles and big wide grin constitute the only real point of attraction in "Guess What We Learned in School Today?"

description: Tax regulations governing medical deductions have been scalped neatly by three dif ferent taxpayers. As a happy result, many ailing taxpayers now may be able to claim an additional medical deduction or two on their Federal in come tax.

description: BONN, May 19The federal Cabinet drafted legislation to day that promises to cause a proliferation of that German specialty, the double family name.

description: WASHINGTON, May 19  Representative James J. Dela ney, a Queens Democrat star tied luncheon guests in the Rayburn House Office Building today when he swung a fist at Representative Bertram Podell, a Brooklyn Democrat. He ap parently missed.

title: F. W. WOOLWORTH SEES SALES RISE
description: CLEVELAND, May 19 (AP)  The F. W. Woolworth Com pany expects a sales increase of about 10 per cent this year, Lester A. Burcham, chairman and chief executive officer, told shareholders at their annual meeting here today.

title: Dirtymouth' Traces Bruce on Screen
description: At the time of his death in 1966, Lenny Bruce was prohibited from giving public performances in New York. Earlier he'd been deported from England, canceled in Australia (after he told a rude story about the Crucifixion), and busted on various charges (usually for obscenity, several times for narcotics) in Philadelphia, Miami and San Francisco, among other places. Following his death, however, life, as it has a way of doing when it's too late, suddenly looked up for the man who had died a pauper.A filmed record of one of his last appearances ("Lenny Bruce") was released in 1967. The next year, the New York Supreme Court reversed a criminal court's ruling and found his nightclub act to have had redeeming social valuewhich might have amused Lenny, who thought redeeming social value a rather silly criterion to be judged by.At least two legitimate plays on his life have been in the works; Albert Goldman is writing what a friend of mine is sure will be the definitive biography, and one feature film has actually been made. The movie is called "Dirtymouth" and it opened yesterday at the Penthouse and R. K. O. 59th Street Twin Cinemas."Dirtymouth" is a very bad movie that can't quite make up its mind whether Bruce, played by Bernie Travis, who vaguely resembles the star, was a young Tom Edison, ahead of his time, or the sort of mad doctor who must be punished for tampering with the secrets of the universe. Quite early in the film, a worried nightclub patron, who has been listening to one of Bruce's milder monologues, says with the awe of someone who has just seen an atom smashed: "There's no telling where a thing like this could lead!" Later on, one of the star's admirers states flatly: "Lenny Bruce is the past, the present and the future!"The truth of the matter is that Bruce was a very good, if not great, comedian, who was sidetracked, and who was very much a product of his time, the uptight 1950's. One of the ironies "Dirtymouth" seems bent on not recognizing is the fact that, five years after his death, the words that Lenny was prosecuted for using are now to be heard in any number of neighborhood movie houses. The revolution that Lenny spearheaded has come and almost gone. Society hasn't collapsed into a gibbering mess, but then it hasn't been completely liberated either."Dirtymouth," which covers Bruce's career from the late 1950's until his death of an apparent overdose of narcotics, talks quite a lot about the comedian's brilliance while demonstratingin its choice of material and in the performancethat he wouldn't have made a decent second banana to Pal Joey. Herbert S. Altman, the writer-director-producer, has, in addition to hiring more bad actors than I can remember seeing in one film in 20 years, tried to make his simple little screenplay look a good deal more complex than it is.In what can only be called misguided attempts at pure cinema, Altman, several times, tries to find the movie equivalents to Bruce's narrative style. He dramatizes Bruce's story about how Jesus was arrested in Miami (because He carried no identification), and he presents us with montages showing us the judges and the district attorneys, who prosecuted Bruce on various occasions, in grotesque, musical comedy make-up. It doesn't really work. I suppose that legal reasons may be responsible for the brush-off the film gives to the star's drug problems, as well as to other areas of his private life."Dirtymouth" has so little on its mind, so little to offer, that while I was watching it yesterday morning at the Penthouse, I wondered if, perhaps, it wasn't watching me. Bad movies prompt paranoid fantasies.

description: ALBANY, May 19A special Senate committee that investi gated the operations of the New York City Board of Edu cation following reports of a $40million deficit earlier this year proposed six bills today aimed at preventing future fis cal crises.

description: WASHINGTON, May 19  A Federal grand jury has indicted the producers of a videotape version of the play Oh! Cal cutta! on a charge of trans mitting an obscene, lewd, lascivious and filthy videotape Production over closedcircuit telivision.

title: Queens Woman Is Accused In Slaying of TeenAged Son
description: A, 50yearold Queens woman was charged with murder yes terday after she had allegedly stabbed her 18yearold son and hit him on the head with a sledgehammer while he slept, the police said.

title: James Saville Yates, 68, ExAd Man, Art Director
description: James Saville Yates, a re tired advertising and publishing art director, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on Division Street in Sag Harbor, L.I. Death was ascribed to a heart ailment and emphysema.

title: One Working Mother Versus the I.R.S.
description: For about 35 minutes in the United States Tax Court at Federal Plaza yesterday morning, J. Barclay Collins, one of the lawyers repre senting Elizabeth Barrett, stood before Judge Arnold Raum and explained in con siderable detail why he thought his client would be deprived of her Constitutional rights if the Internal Revenue Service refused to let her de duct $2,860 for child care ex penses on her 1965 Federal income tax return.

title: Collegians to Tour Pacific
description: KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP) Eight college football players will visit American servicemen in Pacificarea hospitals and Vietnam this summer, the Na tional Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation announced today. Among the players are Johnny Musso, Alabama halfback; Ly dell Mitchell, Penn State half back; Stan Maudlin, Texas line backer, and Rocky Long, New Mexico quarterback.

title: Chess:Portisch No. 1 Substitute For SixMan Eliminations
description: When Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, finished in a tie for seventh place in last year's interzonal tournament at Palma, Majorca, neither could have been precisely overjoyed. The players who finished in the first six places in that tournament qualified for the series of matches now under way to determine the next challenger to the pres ent world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: POLICEMAN ADMITS PERJURY IN INQUIRY
description: Carmello J. Zumatto, a sus pended New York policeman, pleaded guilty yesterday to ly ing to a Bronx grand jury that is investigating payoffs to the police by numbersgame rack eteers.

title: Newark Rights Aide Resigns
description: NEWARK, May 19Eugene T. Johnson, chairman of the NeWark Human Rights Com mission; submitted his resigna tion to Mayor Kenneth A. Gib son, today, saying a new ap pointment to the American Hospital Association and other medical groups would occupy much of his time. Mr. Johnson had been commission chairman since 1969.

title: MOST RAILROADS BACK TO NORMAL
description: Much of the nation's freight and passenger rail service was reported back to normal yester day, but the aftereffects of the twoday strike could still be felt in the scattered delays and snarled freight  delivery sched ules that marked the first day back to work for the striking railroad signalmen.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Most anyone can run a mile. It seems at first absurd that anyone should devote so much of his time and thought to running it very fast. It looks to be more pain than pleasure, yet without the mystique of the marathon. The money is not too good and the sprinters get the pro football contracts. The girls who hang around tennis players are usually richer and prettier. And yet, year after year, new milers appear, disappear, flash, break down, are replaced. The mile is the premier event at most track meets and every so often a race is run that confirms the suspicion that the mile is probably as nearly perfect as a sporting event can be.

title: 421 st Cosmos Launched
description: MOSCOW, May 19 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today the 421st earth satellite in its Cosmos space research series, Tass, the official press agency, reported. The satellite was orbiting every 92 minutes between 176 and 306 miles from the earth at an angle of 71 degrees. Equipment on board was working well, Tass said.

title: Driver of Cab Slain
description: A 26yearold man was shot and fatally wounded yesterday in a gypsy cab he had bor rowed, the police reported. Luis Martinis of 230 Blake Ave nue, Brooklyn, was found lying in the front seat of the cab at Sterling Place between Troy and Schnectady Avenues. The police speculated that robbery was the motive.

title: Learning to Be H. L. Hunt's Daughter
description: DALLAS (UPI)The life style in the house of H. L. Hunt, the billionaire, was one of learning by doing.

title: COTTON TRADING SUSPENDED HERE
description: For the first time since Oc tober, 1946, the New York Cot ton Exchange suspended all trading in cotton futures yes terday because of a backlog of paper work caused by heavy trading.

title: Bridge: Well ThoughtOut Defense Proves Key in Exhibition

title: Shaheen Decides to Refuse Answers in Copeland Case

title: HERMAN ZUTKOFF
description: Herman Zutkoff, who estab lished the Manhattan account ing concern of H. Zutkoff & Co., died yesterday in Monte fiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 73 years old and lived at 2500 Johnson Avenue, River dale the Bronx.

description: LONDON, May 19Prime Minister Heath said before leav ing for Paris today that Britain was at a rare, probably unique moment in her history.

title: Theater: Pericles, Prince of Tyre
description: The Classic Stage Company is in process of becoming a New York institution. It is a small theater, clearly run on a shoestring of dedication and hope, that offers New York, week in, week out, a classic repertory of plays.

title: DECISION ON RENTAL IS PUT OFF BY BOARD
description: The Board of Education post poned action last night on a recommendation that it request the city to rent space for the superintendent and local board of Community School District 23, which takes in the Browns ville section of Brooklyn.

description: The indictment of a Har lem man on homicide charges in connection with the shoot ing of an offduty narcotics detective on May 5 was an nounced yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B, Roberts.

description: HONG KONG, May 19 An editorial that will be published in principal Peking publications tomorrow portrays the United States Government as an ad ministration beset by troubles at home and abroad.

description: Book publishers, who toast themselves as the last 19th century rugged individuals, are finding that survival in the 20th century calls fr a degree of to getherness.

description: SEAFORD, L.I., May 19 A 19yearold Seaford High School senior who had been cited for his championship per formance on the varsity wrest ling team over the last three years has been stripped of his honors because of his arrest on marijuana charges eight months ago.

title: Amex List Registers First Gain in Five Sessions
description: The American Stock Ex change posted its first gain in five sessions yesterday as the list made a small advance in slow trading.

title: Chinese Presence in Pakistan Is More Noticeable
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 19  The Chinese presence in Pakistan has become increas ingly noticeable as new aid from Peking is announced, newspapers praise Chinese poli cies and columns of blueuni formed Chinese officials march through airport waiting rooms.

title: MachineGun Fire Hits 2 Policemen
description: Two patrolmen, assigned to a patrol car guarding the resi dence of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, were raked by fire from an auto matic weaponapparently a machine gunlast night when they tried to stop a car for a traffic violation on Riverside Drive. They were critically wounded.

title: City of Brotherly Love
description: It is hard to say which is more depressing about the victory of Frank Rizzo: his reputation as the toughest cop in America or the cynical silence on issues that marked his winning of the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Philadelphia. Whether voters regarded his repu tation as qualification enough for the high office or were attracted by the remarkable ignorance the candi date displayed on a wide range of subjects, Philadelphia's political prospects are disquieting. Either the Democrats are headed for a historic split in November or the city is headed for trouble after November.

title: BILL WOULD IMPERIL ROLLS TRISTAR ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (Reuters)Senator Robert Taft Jr., Republican of Ohio, today introduced legislation that would doom participation by RollsRoyce 1971, Ltd., in the Lockheed Tristar project.

description: To the Editor:

title: Attacking Rent Control
description: A package of antitenant bills, now alive, now dead in the ebb and flow of legislative sentiment in Albany, seems alive again. This is unfortunate because the package seriously undermines New York City's recently revised rentcontrol law even before it has had a chance to be tested. The few good features of the package are over shadowed by the encouragement its vacancydecontrol provisions would give landlords to harass tenants into vacating their apartments.

title: PRESBYTERIAN GROUP IS UPSET BY INQUIRY
description: ROCHESTER, May 19 An official of the Presbyterian Lay Committee said today that he was surprised, puzzled and shocked when the church's General Assembly ordered an inquiry into the activities of the theologically conservative group.

title: CLARENCE P. BAXTER
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., May 19Clarence P. Baxter, a re tired textile designer and man ufacturer with headquarters in New York, died yesterday in Framingham Union Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: MILLS URGES TRIAL OF TEXTILES CURBS
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., May 19 (AP)Voluntary restraints on Japanese textile exports to the United States deserve a fair trial, but it may well be that in the end, the Congress will have to approve statutory con trols, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat fraorn Ar kansas, said today.

title: Ley Bruce: Legal Woes
description: Lenny Bruce probably would have laughedand then cursed.

title: BUSINESS GAINS SEEN BY PURCHASING AIDES
description: Purchasing executives expect 1971 to be a better year for business than 1970, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Police Blotter, a Relic, Replaced in Test Project
description: The traditional police blot ter  the large green ledger in which an officer records citizen complaints, precinct rollcalls and other station business in longhand  has been eliminated in a pilot program to modernize procedures.

title: 9 Injured in Blast Here Inside a Sewage Tunnel
description: Nine men were injured yes terday when a fragment of dy namite was set off inadvertently in a sewage tunnel under con struction on the Upper West Side.

title: Lowell Joins Democratic Race For Nomination for Surrogate
description: Stanley H. Lowell, a former Deputy Mayor and chairman of the City Commission on Hu man Rights, announced yester day that he was running for the Democratic nomination for sur rogate, committed to a pro gram of reform.

title: Hungarian Upsets Pilic
description: HAMBURG, Germany, May 19 (UPI)Unheralded Peter Szoeke of Hungary scored an upset at the German international tennis championships today by elimi nating thirdseeded Nicola Pilic of Yugoslavia in a 50game marathon.

title: Richey, Smith Advance
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 19 (Reuters)Cliff Richey and Stan Smith, America's No. 1 and 2 players, advanced to the third round of the $13,000 Belgian open tennis championships to day.

title: U.S. and Soviet Aides in Accord on Fishing Dispute
description: ABOARD THE COAST, GUARD CUTTER DUANE AT SEA, May 39 (UPI)  United States Government officials, concluding that Soviet harass ment of American lobster boats had not been authorized by Russian officials, expressed optimism today that their meet ing at sea with the Soviet fish ing fleet commander had solved the fishing dispute between the two nations.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES HIGH SCHOOL CURB
description: ALBANY, May 19New York City Democrats split into emotionally charged camps to day as the Assembly passed a bill designed to limit the Board of Education's power to alter the city's four specialized high schools.

title: Joseph Goldstein, 56, Dies; Passaic Redevelopment Aide
description: PASSAIC, N. J., May 19 Joseph M. Goldstein, a lawyer and chairman of the Passaic Redevelopment and Urban Re newal Agency, died yesterday at Passaic General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 56 years old and lived here at 60 Crescent Avenue.

title: Man In the News
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 19 By sweeping aside his Dem ocratic opponents for Mayor in convincing fashion in the primary yesterday, Frank Lazarro Rizzo became the favorite in the November election. If elected, he will be Philadelphia's first Mayor of Italian extraction. But the 240pound for mer police com missioner, who earned a national reputation as the toughest cop in America, may have a battle on his hands. W. Thacher Longstreth, his Republican opponent, expects to force him to debate all the fundamental urban issues that Mr. Rizzo refused to debate in the primary cam paign, when his strategy was to sit back and let his op ponents divide the liberal vote.

title: Roundup: Boyer Is on Home Run Binge
description: All that was missing for Clete Boyer in Atlanta last night was Morganna, the exotic dancer, who gained fame last season by planting kisses on baseball players, Clete included.

title: KOSYGIN, TREK IN SURPRISE MOVE, SIGN AMITY PACT
description: MOSCOW, May 19  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin signed an agree ment today calling for regular highlevel contacts to improve friendship, goodneighborli ness and mutual confidence.

title: Police in Brazil Question TimeLife Correspondent
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 19 A staff correspondent for the TimeLife Publishing Company was questioned here yesterday for one hour by the Brazilian federal police apparently inter ested in his professional activ ities and his views on United States aid to Brazil. He was not detained.

title: Panel in Senate Approves Nixon Judicial Nominations
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Com mittee approved yesterday Pres ident Nixon's nominations of three judges for the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which covers New York, Conecticut and Vermont.

title: RED SOX TRIUMPH OVER YANKEES,72; SIEBERT WINS NO, 7
description: BOSTON, May 19The Bos ton Red Sox, enjoying the rari fied air of the top spot in the American League's Eastern Di vision, maintained their 2 game lead over the Baltimore Orioles tonight by bombing two New York Yankee relief pitch ers in the late innings to fash ion a 72 victory before 21,077 fans at Fenway Park.

title: New Cancer Treatment View Scored
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19 Surgeons attending a meeting here on breast cancer took sharp issue today with the con tention of some colleagues that the standard treatment for the disease is more drastic than necessary.

title: Mayors Reelect Whelan
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 19 (AP)Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City, who goes, on trial tomorrow on Federal ex tortionconspiracy charges, won reelection today as a vice pres ident of the New Jersey Con ference of Mayors at the or ganization's annual meeting. A spokesman said that the organi zation did not want to prejudge Mr. Whelan by blocking his re election.

title: Methodist Unit Asks Peace
description: POULTNEY, Vt., May 19 (AP) A resolution to end the war in Southeast Asia was approved today by the Women's Society of Christian service at the open ing session of the Troy Confer ence of the United Methodist Church.

title: 3 U.S. Walker Cup Stars Ponder Pro Careers
description: A United States team of 10 amateur golfers left last night for Scotland to defend the Walker Cup and three of them declared they were con sidering careers as profes sionals.

title: Texas Cuts Output Of Oil on Indication Of Lower Demand
description: AUSTIN, Texas, May ,19  The state of Texas trimmed its oil production again today, as a number of major companies indicated lessened demand for domestic crude oil.

title: 4 ProtoFolk Dances By Miss Hay Spark American Marathon
description: Group interaction, purpose ful tranquility and a logical mind are the tools that Debo rah Hay uses to fashion her disarmingly gracious dances, which make much sense out of little movements. For the Amer scan Dance Marathon she has prepared a series of four short works which are protofolk dances developed from simple accretion; adding a sway to an ordinary step then a change of direction or an alteration in the basic 4/4 rhythm. The program was performed in selected lo cales Tuesday, among them Time/Life Plaza and Lincoln Center.

title: Black G.I.'s Rally in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 19 About 150 Negro servicemen staged a rally at United States Eighth Army Headquarters here today in observance of the birthday of Malcolm X, a black leader assassinated in New York in 1966. The Negroes, from Army and Air Force units de manded an end to racial dis crimination in the military. They broke several windows and tables and pushed over ovens at a mess hall, when they were refused lunch there because they were visitors.

title: EVERY week, more than 26,000 Jobs are advertised In The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.ADVT.
Columbia Music Unit Faces Extinction
description: The Group for Contem porary Music at Columbia University, one of the coun try's most prestigious avant garde ensembles, is facing extinction, at least as a universitysponsored organi zation. The orisis, which has split the music faculty and rubbed academic tempers raw, resulted from the Co lumbia faculty's decision to deny tenure to Charles Wuorinen, the Pulitzer Prize winning composer and pianist who was one of the group's founders.

title: SENATE REJECTS BID TO REVIVE SST BY VOTE OF 5837
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The supersonic transport's come back collapsed late tonight in the Senate. The rollcall vote to kill an $85million House appro priation for further SST devel opment was 58 to 37, the widest margin against the project.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Lhasa Apso in its homeland, Tibet, is known as Abso Seng Kye, the Bark Lion Sentinel Dog. Patricia and Tom Chenoweth breed the little dog at Saratoga Calif., and for many years his bark was heard only on the Coast. But now Chen Apsos have been sounding off in the Midwest and East. Last Novem ber, Ch. Chen Korum  Ti was best in show at Boardwalk, in Atlantic City, in a field of 3,004.

title: JERSEY DISTRICTS DECLARED ILLEGAL
description: NEWARK, May 19New Jer sey's legislative redistricting plan for this year's State Sen ate and Assembly elections was declared unconstitutional here today by Superior Court Judge Samuel Allcorn Jr. on the ground that it failed to ful fill the United States Supreme Court's oneman, onevote edict.

title: Bonanno's Trial Postponed Because of Poor Health
description: Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonan no, reputed to be a longtime Mafia figure, won an indefinite postponement yesterday of his scheduled trial on charges of obstructing justice.

title: Chou Meets U.S Scientists
description: TOKYO, May 19 (AP)Pre mier Chou Enlai of China met today in Peking with two visit ing American scientists, the Chinese press agency said in a broadcast monitored here. The Americans are Dr. Arthur W. Galston, a plant physiologist from Yale University, and Dr. Ethan R. Signer, a microbiolo gist from the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology.

title: North Bergen Reform Slate Begins Its Administration
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., May 19 (UPI)The Spirit of 71 re form slate, which unseated Mayor Angelo J. Sarubbi and other incumbents in elections on May 11, has taken office and named the new Mayor's brother its Township Clerk.

title: NEW CAIRO CABINET CONVENED BY SADAT
description: CAIRO, May 19  President Anwar elSadat convened his new Cabinet today, five days after it was organized amid a grave political challenge to the Egyptian leader.

title: BURNS SUPPORTS NIXON RATE VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, sup ported today the Nixon Admin istration view that raising in terest rates was not the right way to improve the interna tional position of the dollar.

title: Harpsichordists In a Lively Bill
description: Harpsichordists, like their delicately strung instruments, tend to be temperamental in dividuals, touchy and hard to keep in tune with the rather gross modern world. But there is a fairly important literature for two claviers available to them, so oc casionally a pair of players such as Gerald Ranck and Robert Smith discover a com patibility that allows them to explore it in public.

title: Loss of Trade Vigor Held Vexing the Administration
description: One of the major problems confronting President Nixon and his top aides is the search for a solution to the loss by the United States of its competi tive edge in world markets.

title: Bedford Tribunal to Investigate Slaying of Black
description: Community groups in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn called yesterday for their black elected officials to act as judges for a tribunal next Tuesday that would inves tigate the killing of a black resident by a white policeman.

title: Plan for VISTA Merger Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 President Nixon's plan to merge the Peace Corps, Volunteers in Service to America and other volunteer antipoverty programs into a new agency called Action cleared a Senate subcommittee today on a partyline vote of 4 to 3.

title: Merchant Heads Unit at Blair As a Retail Merger Specialist
description: A wellknown New York merchant who headed three leading New Yorkbased chains has become a merger special ist and Investment banker.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SHOW AN UPTURN
description: The bond market turned around yesterday, and prices advanced for the first time in more than a week, dispelling some of the gloom that had hung over the credit markets for the last several days.

title: Longshoremen Will Negotiate For Nationwide Work Contract
description: Thomas W. Gleason, presi dent of the International Long shoremen's Association, said yesterday that the union would push for a national contract in its coming wage negotiations, with emphasis on royalty com pensation for new automation techniques that are expanding in the industry.

title: Souvanna Welcomes U.S.China Thaw
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 19 Premier Souvanna Phouma today praised China's historic ally nonaggressive attitude to ward Laos and expressed the hope that an improvement in ChineseAmerican relations would lead to restraints on What he termed North Viet nam's expansionism.

title: Two Tiger Cubs Thrive While Living Dog's Life
description: Two newborn Bengal tiger cubs adopted by golden re triever after they were re jected by their mother, a circus performer, were re ported to be doing well yes day.

title: Betraying the Helpless.
description: The mentally ill, the brain injured and the mentally retarded are among the most vulnerable and helpless members of society. Often passive and depressed, they have little or no competence to deal with ordinary prob lems of lifenor do they constitute a pressure bloc of voters. Precisely because of their poignant situation, their treatment is a test of how humane any society really is.

title: Valenti Charges, Clergy Seeks Film Censorship
description: Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America yesterday called the action by Protestant and Roman Catholic motion picture agen cies withdrawing their support from the film industry's rating system a subtle attempt to destroy publio confidence in the ratings and thus destroy them. He said the move was a pos sibly unconscious attempt on the part of the two religious agencies to bring ?? Gov ernment censorship.

title: Hope to Get Honorary Degree
description: OLEAN, N. Y., May 19 (AP) Bob Hope, the comedian, will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree from St. Bonaven ture University at commence ment exercises May 30. The university said Mr. Hope would receive the degree in recogni tion of his stature as a great American entertainer and hu manitarian. The Roman Cath olic university also will award an honorary doctor of humane letters degree to Mr. Hope's wife to recognize her work for Catholic charities in the Los Angeles area.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today May 20, 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Intergovernmental Working Group on the Declaration on the Human Environment 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NATO Says Troop Talks Can Precede Berlin Pact
description: BRUSSELS, May 19United States officials said here today that the Atlantic alliance would not insist on a satisfactory settlement of Berlin's future as a condition for talks with the Soviet Union on mutual and balanced reductions of forces in Central Europe.

title: CASSUTO CONDUCTS STUDENT ORCHESTRA
description: Alvaro Cassuto, a Portuguese conductor who made his debut here in 1968 as assistant con ductor of the Little Orchestra Society, was the podium guest of the orchestra of the Man hattan School of Music for a concert given in Borden Audi torium on Tuesday night.

title: U.S. SAID TO DISTORT NATIONAL PRIORITIES
description: Mayor Lindsay accused Washington yesterday of dis torting national priorities and applying a double standard for Federal assistance programs. The Government, he said, is in different to the devastated slums of the nation.

title: Advertising:
description: Pan American World Air ways, which in the past has spent more on advertising and said less about it than any other major airline, is becoming a blabbermouth.

title: Nader Says G.M. Violates Safety Law on Vega Flaws
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 Ralph Nader accused the Gen eral Motors Corporation today of violating the Federal auto safety law by failing to notify 23,300 Chevrolet Vega owners of safetyrelated defects in their cars.

title: Merger News
description: The Collins Radio Company, which broke off merger nego tiations on Tuesday with. TRW, Inc., has a new suitor the North American Rockwell Cor poration. North American Rock well announced yesterday that it had begun preliminary dis cussions to purchase a signifi cant interest in Collins and was seeking an affili ation of the two concerns. Their spokesmen de clined to give any further details. They stressed that the talks were still in the initial stages and that any agreement would be subject to the approval of bath boards and Collins stock holders.

title: Notes on People
description: Her Majesty regrets, Queen Elizabeth II said in a message read before Parlia ment yesterday, that she must ask for an increase in the current royal budget of $1.14million a year.

title: U.S. and Britain Said to Agree On Aid Program for Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 The United States and Britain are reported to have agreed to head an international effort to shore up the precarious finan cial position of Pakistan.

title: ASTRONOMY DATA TO AID AIR STUDY
description: For years astronomers la mented that atmospheric dust and gasses obstructed their view of the stars. They have dreamed of putting their tele scopes on the moon or in earth orbit to get above such impedi ments.

title: ACQUITTAL IS WON BY NEGRO SHERIFF
description: OPELIKA, Ala., May 19 Lucius D. Amerson, whose elec tion as sheriff at Tuskegee in 1966 encouraged other Negroes to run for office in Alabama, was acquitted today, along with his chief deputy, Richard Coleman Jr., of a Federal charge of mistreating a prison er.

title: Last Laotian Stronghold on Plateau Is Said to Fall
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 19 (Agence France  Presse)The town of Houei Kong, the last stronghold of Government forces on the Boloven Plateau, reportedly fell to enemy forces today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The world's greatest deliberative body has been locked in historic debate en an issue worthy of its vocal cords, to wit, the Mansfield amendment. This would force a 50 per cent reduction in the American military presence in Europe, and here are some of the subtle terms in which the Senators discussed this difficult matter:

title: PETER VANSTEEDEN 3D
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 19 Peter VanSteeden 3d, a New York advertising man, died to day bf cancer at his home. He was 41 years old and lived at 5 Oak Shade Avenue.

title: Ogden Nash, Master of Light Verse, Dies
description: Ogden Nash, whose droll verse with its unconventional rhymes made him the country's bestknown producer of humor ous poetry, died yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Bal timore. His age was 68.

title: ExportLoan Legislation Opposed by the Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The Federal Reserve Board opposed today a proposal in Congress to give banks the automatic right to discount exportrelated loans with the Reserve. The board also op posed a provision in the same legislation that would exempt export  related bank loans from the present program of controls over bank lending abroad.

title: Ashau Battle Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19 (UPI)Thousands of South Vietnamese troops moving in the Ashau Valley reportedly fought a sixhour battle today with large enemy forces en trenched there.

title: But the Private Classes Are $1,000 a Day
description: Working for the Cordon Bleu isn't ?? souffls and foie gras. For Richard Grausman, 32, the first representative of the worldfamous Paris cooking school in America, the job has involved several unlikely tasks. He has experi mented with margarine for puff paste. He has improvised large, lightweight mirrors out of the shiny synthetic ma terial called Mylar. And he has found himself involved, as the Cordon Bleu's United States representative, in the school's pending action against a cook ing magazine.

title: Making It Mutual
description: The Senate's wise defeat of the Mansfield amendment now makes it possible to move toward EastWest nego tiations for mutual balanced force reductions rather than a unilateral, mandatory, 50 per cent slash in American troops alone by the end of the year.

title: Easing Is Seen in Import Stand of Apparel Makers
description: DALLAS, May 19Some signs developed here today that the oncesolid front of apparel manufacturers de manding quota legislation to protect the domestic indus try against imports from low wage countries is no longer a universallyaccepted atti tude.

title: A Blaze in Port Chester Delays Commuters on the Penn Central
description: Thousands of commuters on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central were delayed get ting home last night when a fire in a building near the tracks in Port Chester, N. Y., caused rail service to be shut down for an hour between Rye and New Haven.

title: State Official Offers Proposal to Reduce FosterCare Cost
description: More than $27million a year could be saved, a state official said yesterday, by helping chil dren to stay at home instead of being placed in foster care and by shortening the stay of those who are in foster homes.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislative Retrogression
description: This has not only been a harsh and bitter retrench ment session of the State Legislature, in which the poor and disadvantaged were particularly harmed, but it has also been an unusually retrogressive session. has, so far, been a session in which many of those elected to represent the people have tended rather to represent themselves or special interests, and to seek partisan advantage rather than promote the public wel fare.

title: BLACK LUNG PLAN HELD INADEQUATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 Critics of the Administration's handling of a compensation program for the victims of coal miner's black lung disease charged today that costcon scious officials had been rob bing disabled workers and their widows and children of benefits Congress intended them to have.

title: Army to Give Industrial Projects Top Priority in Pollution Battle
description: An official of the Army Corps of Engineers said yes terday that new industrial projects would be given first priority in enforcement pro ceedings against polluters.

title: SENATE BARS A REDUCTION IN AMERICAN NATO FORCE; MANSFIELD DEFEATED,6136
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 The Senate, in a major foreign policy victory for the Nixon Administration, rejected today all proposals for a reduction in the American forces stationed in Western Europe.

title: WAGENAAR DEAD; COMPOSER WAS 76
description: Bernard Wagenaar, whose symphonies and string quartets won, him recognition in this country, died Tuesday in York Harbor Hospital near Kenne bunkport, Me. He was 76 years old and lived at 450 Riverside Drive and at Edgartown, Mass.

title: DONALD A. WELLS, OFFICER OF B.B.D.O.
description: Donald A. Wells, executive vice president and general man ager of Batten, Barton, Durstine & OSborn, Inc., international, advertising agency, died last night in New York Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 249 East 48th Street.

title: CEREMONIES HELD FOR MALCOLM X
description: About 200 peopleinclud ing a few who were not yet born when the man they came to honor was assassinated  stood quietly on a sunny ceme tery slope yesterday to honor Malcolm X, who was also known as El Hajj Malik EI Shabazz.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, May 19No simple box score can record gains and losses that were registered today in the Senate's rejection of a move to reduce by Waif the American forces in Europe this year, or even the next three years.

title: Tommy Thomson, Coached Track Teams at Annapolis
description: OCEANSIDE, Calif., May 19 (UPI)Earl J. (Tommy) Thom son, head track coach at the United States Naval Academy for 36 years and an Olympic gold medalist for Canada in 1920, died of cancer today. He was 76 years old.

title: The Talk of Telluride
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.Bestrid ing his narrow world, border ed on three sides by alpine mountains that plunge to the edge of town, the marshal, Everett Morrow, waits, hand ?? casually on the pro truding butt of his revolver. He watches all newcomers cautiously as they peep about this gently decaying town of 521 per sons. His white police car has a No. 1 license plate and a bumper sticker that reads: If you don't like cops, the next time you're in trouble call a hippie.'

title: JohnsManville to Move Office From Here to a Denver Suburb
description: The JohnsManville Corpora tion announced yesterday that it would move its corporate headquarters from here to a suburb of Denver by the end ?? next year.

title: Numbered Account Rallies to Win $33,450 Fashion at Aqueduct by 3 Lengths
description: Numbered Account looks like money in the bank for Ogden Phipps, the breeder and owner of the daughter of Buckpasser.

title: 2 HELD IN CAPITAL ON TIE TO PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 A United States magistrate found probable cause today to hold Rennie Davis and John R. Froines ?? grand jury action in connection with the recent antiwar demonstrations here.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: MARKET EDGES UP IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday in a cautious creep andcrawl session amid low volume. The turnover of 11.74 million shares was the slowest of 1971, except for the 10.01 million shares on the first trad ing day.

title: Books of The Times
description: GAUGUIN'S PARADISE LOST. By Wayne Anderson. With the Assistance of Barbara Klein. 371 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $12.50.

title: Blind Athletes to Compete In Bronx Sports Weekend
description: The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind will meet athletes from the Mary land School for the Blind in an all sports weekend tomor row and Saturday.

title: NIXON DEFENDED ON RIGHTS RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 The Nixon Administration, a day after responding to demands for more aid to minorities, strongly defended its civil rights record today.

title: U.S. Limits Saigon Air Force Potential
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19  The United States, while turning the South Viet namese Air Force into one of the largest in the world, is at the same time sharply limiting its tactical and strategic capa bilities on the assumption that the war will continue to wind down.

title: DR. AARON PETERS JR.
description: Dr. Aaron T. Peters Jr., a physician in Brooklyn for 22 years, died Tuesday in St. John's Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived at 566 Greene Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Use of Safety Lenses Prescribed by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration, despite oppo sition from specialists who prescribe eyeglasses, has or dered that all glasses and sunglasses made after Dec. 31 be equipped with safety lenses unless a specialist pre scribes otherwise.

title: Anaconda Outlines Chile Claims
description: ANACONDA, Mont., May 19  Shareholders of the Ana conda Company were told to day at the annual meeting here that Congress might eventually be asked to vote a large por tion of the billions of dollars that could be lost by Amer ican corporations in Chile. A record number of shareholders, about 850, attended.

title: Senate RollCall Vote Deleting SST Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate ap proved today an amdendment by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, to de lete funds to develop the super sonic transport:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CARMEL, N. Y.Trout were rising in the first big pool (the one with the large boulder on the righthand side as one faces upcurrent) downstream from the point where the West Branch of the Croton River goes under Route 6.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Montreal Turnout
description: MONTREAL, May 19More than 3,000 hockey buffs waited through the night at Montreal International Air port at Dorval for the trium phant homecoming of Les Canadiens, now more than ever the indigenous sports symbol of Quebec.

title: SHAFER DISCOUNTS MARIJUANA VETO
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 President Nixon's promise to ignore a proposal that marijuana be, legalized will not inhibit the National Commis sion on Marijuana and Drug Abuse from making such a recommendation if the facts support that course, Raymond P. Shafer, chairman of the com mission, said today.

title: Death in Golden Bangla Desh
description: KARACHI, PakistanPoet Rabin dranath Tagore wrote many years ago: I love you my golden Bangla Desh  O Mother, during spring the fragrance of your mango groves mad dens my heart with delight  This spring there is only the stench of death in the mango groves of East Pakistan/ Bangla Desh as many hearts are mad dened by massacre.

title: Primates Gather at Zoo for Benefit of Inmates
description: The Central Park Zoo was the chilly setting last night for what may be the only zoological extravaganza in its historya blacktie din ner dance, no less, with cocktails in the presence of lions, tigers and chimpan zees, dinner in a tented jungle and dancing around the Sea Lion Pond.

title: Citrus Export Plan Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)Highly placed officials in the Nixon Administration said today that the United States believes the European Economic Community has pre pared a proposal aimed at re solving the United States Com mon Market tensions over citrus exports.

title: WILLIAM REED DIES; BIG 10 HEAD SINCE '61
description: PARK RIDGE, III., May 20 (AP)William R. Reed, com missioner of the Big Ten ath letic conference, died early to day in a suburban Chicago hos pital. His age was 55.

title: Census Finds Inflation Erased Gain in Family Income in 1970
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 The purchasing power of the typical American family did not increase last year, for the first time in nine years, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: End of the SST
description: By the authoritative margin of 58 to 37, the Senate has now definitely resolved the question whether Gov ernment funds should be used to build a supersonic transport. In refusing to finance two prototypes, the Senate avoided an implicit commitment to spend billions later to underwrite the cost of production.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Proud winners of varsity letters in college once re garded such recognition of athletic excellence as ranking almost on a par with the sheepskin that turned them loose on the cold, cruel world. At least that's the way it was when I went to school. Getting a degree was a cinch. Getting a varsity letter was fraught with difficulty.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Buckley to Address Big G.O.P. Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Senator James L. Buckley, elected as a Conservative and now listed as Conservative Republican, will be one of the main speakers at the New York Republican State Committee's fundraising dinner in New York City next month.

title: Petrifying the High Schools?
description: The State Assembly has passed a bill which would prohibit the Board of Education from making virtually any changes in the procedures by which students are admitted to New York City's four specialized high schools.

title: State Income Tax Upheld By a Pennsylvania Court
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 20 (AP)  The Commonwealth Court upheld today the con stitutionality of the state in come tax.

title: Egypt's Vulnerable Strong Man
description: President Anwar elSadat's tough talk on a Middle East peace settlement only thinly conceals the desperate need of Egypt's new strong man for an early breakthrough in stalled negotiations. Having gone out on a limb in his bid to make peace with Israel and having suppressed Communistoriented hardliners within the shattered coalition that succeeded the late President Nasser, Mr. Sadat has to show some success soon in his effort to regain lost Egyptian territory through diplomatic means or lose the popular support that enabled him to triumph over his enemies.

title: Credit Markets: Recovery Continuing
description: The recovery in the credit markets that got. started Wednesday continued yester day.

title: JAMES B. LYTTLE
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., May 20  James B. Lyttle, a profes sional engineer and vice presi dent of Corbetta Construction Company of New York, died today of a heart ailment at his home, 150 Boulevard. His age was 58.

title: Bonn Is Pleased by Defeat Of Mansfield Plan in Senate
description: BONN, May 20 (Reuters) The West German Government today expressed satisfaction at the United States Senate's re jection of Senator Mike Mans field's proposal to halve the American 310,000man force serving in Europe by the end of this year.

title: World Snowfall Mark Set
description: PARADISE LODGE, Wash., May 20 (UPI)  Snowfall at Mount Rainier National Park reached a new world record, with 84.3 feet recorded so far this season. The weather sta tion here recorded a threeinch snowfall earlier this week, bringing the season total to 1,014.5 inches. The old world record at an official weather station was 1,000.3 inches, set here in 195556. More snow is expected at the park next month.

title: WOITACH DISPLAYS POWER AS PIANIST
description: Richard Woitach, who played at the New York Cultural Cen ter Wednesday night, is a power pianist, but he also has plenty of control.

title: Phase of Capitol Bombing Inquiry Ends
description: SEATTLE, May 20  With Leslie Bacon now in the city jail for contempt of a Federal Court, the initial public phase in the investigation of the March 1 bombing of the na tional Capitol has ended incon clusively.

title: SOVIET CAUTIOUS
description: MOSCOW, May 20The So vietAmerican move on arms limitation announced today was viewed by observers here as having strengthened the posi tion of those Soviet leaders who have been pressing for weapons  control agreements and improved relations with the United States.

title: Data on Income
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Following is a table of median family income in constant dollars over the last decade, showing the percentage change over each previous year, based on a Census Bu reau report issued today:

title: Jamee Tucker Becomes Bride
description: Miss Jamee Tina Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Tucker of Chicago and Nippersink, Wis., was married at noon yesterday to Peter Stephen Gregory. Rabbi Paul Silvershear, performed the ceremony at the home here of the bridegroom's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. George S. Gregory of New York and Paris. A luncheon followed at the 21 Club.

title: Flaming Steak: A Quick Dish
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (Reuters)Mr. Hunter said a standby, lowerfee mortgage banker program is being con sidered to combat the uncertain ty in the mortgaterate market.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
William Thedford, Official Of Movie Theater Chain
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 William H. Thedford, vice pres ident of National General The atres, Inc., died yesterday at CedarsMount Sinai Hospital after a short illness.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS C5A AND SAFEGUARD
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) The House Armed Services Committee authorized today $357.2million for the Penta gon's controversial C5A trans port project and $1billion for President Nixon's Safeguard antiballistic missile system.

title: StockDelivery Failures Showed a Rise for April
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday that the volume of fails in April had risen from $1.74billion to $1.8billion, while the volume of fails 30 days old or older had risen from $52.7million to $74.4million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Annette Joelson, Writer, Dies; Began Career in South Africa
description: Annette Joelson, a South Af rican biographer and novelist, died in London last Friday. She was 68 years old, and had lived in London since her mar riage in 1942 to Maurice Ja cobs, a merchant banker.

title: Muskie Unit Forms on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP) Formation of a California citizens committee to promote Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, for Presi dent was announced today by Secretary of State Edmund Brown Jr.

title: CHILE TO INVESTIGATE COPPER OPERATIONS
