description: ROME, May 21An inquiry has been opened into what is described as an international narcotics ring involving notori ous figures of the Sicilian Mafia linked with racketeers in the United States.

title: Service for Ogden Nash Held in Baltimore Chapel
description: BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP) A memorial service was held today for Ogden Nash in the chapel of the Church of the Redeemer, where he was mar ried in 1931. The poethumorist died Wednesday.

title: OTBUnion Accord at Yonkers Clears Way for Off track Action
description: An agreement that guar antees racetrack workers full job security cleared the way yesterday for off track betting to stay on gait next Monday night when harness racing shifts from Roosevelt Raceway to Yonkers Raceway.

title: Out of Long History of EnglishFrench Discord, Accord on Steps to Partnership
description: PARIS, May 21It is said that when the French are friendly they are very friend ly and that when they are unfriendly they are French.

title: GARY WHITE, TEXAN, SINGS RARE PROGRAM
description: Gary White sings as if he has to blast each word through his mustache, which is of con siderable proportions.

title: News Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21The plaint of some Navajo and the Hopi Indians that their south western reservations are being desecrated and despoiled by a bevy of 20th century power plants confronts the Federal Government and the nation at large with a surprising tangle of issues. The Indians, supported by some major conservation or ganizations, asked the United States District Court in Washington last week in effect to halt the big gest power project in the na tion's historya projected com plex of six coalfired plants in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Nevada (two of them are al ready operating) that would produce three times as much power as the Tennessee Valley project.

title: Happy Birthday, U.S.L.T.A.
description: The United States Lawn Ten nis Association will observe its 90th anniversay today.

title: Court. Study May. Stall Bombing Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 2l The Justice Department's effort to obtain grand jury testimony from Leslie Bacon about the bombing of the United States Capitol could be stalled for many months while the Su preme Court considers a chal lenge to a new law concerning compulsory testimony.

title: Russian Seamen Discover Portland, Ore., Is Friendly
description: PORTLAND, Ore.Old Joe, a myna bird at the Portland Zoo; failed its first Russian lesson the other day.

title: POMPIDOUHEATH ACCORDS PAVE THE WAY FOR BRITAIN TO ENTER COMMON MARKET
description: PARIS, May 21  President Pompidou and Prime Minister Heath announced today that they had reached agreements that would pave the way for British entry into the Euro pean Economic Community.

title: Yet Another NixonJohnson Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 When President Nixon arrives in Austin tomorrow for the ded ication of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library, it will be his seventh encounter with Mr. Johnson since Inauguration Day, and another stage in his effort to maintain at least an outwardly warm relationship with his predecessor.

title: Fellow Patrolmen React Bitterly, Complain to Mayor and Murphy
description: Policemen at the West 135th Street station reacted to the killing of two of their number last night with bitterness, hos tility and anger.

title: White G.I. Gets License To Wed Georgia Black
description: JONESBORO, Ga., May 21 (UPI)A white Army lieuten ant and his black fiance ob tained a marriage license to day after the Federal Gov ernment filed suit to strike down Georgia's law barring racially mixed marriages.

title: Man in the News
description: The man who has become the cause of the breach be tween the Cuban revolution and Western intellectuals who supported it is one of the hestknown and most controversial poets of Fidel Castro's generation. In his work, Heberto Padilla has shown a hardeyed, cool style that has kept him in trou ble with the Cu ban leadership since 1968. His arrest in March and his humiliation and re. lease last month after a con fession of wrongdoing aroused outcries in Europe and the United States among those Mr. Castro calls bour geois liberals. The state ment by 60 prominent intel lectuals in Paris yesterday exacerbated matters.

title: Hall Overton Attempts Opera About Huck Finn
description: Huckleberry Finn hated the refined ways of the Widow Douglas and Miss Watson, who gave him a home, and he would scarcely seem to fit into the sophisticated milieu of opera. The composer Hall Overton and his coli brettist, Judah Stampfer, have made a valiant attempt to put the famous Mark Twain character onto the lyric stage without depriving him of his rebellious, Ameri canasapplepie, hayseed charm.

title: Antiques: Glass Paperweights of U.S.
description: American glass paper weights have not been get ting the attention they de serve from serious collectors.

title: Jersey Soldier Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 21. (AP)  The Defense Department an nounced today, that Specialist Stephen J. Hadley, of the Army and from Chatham, N. J., had been killed in action in South east Asia.

title: Astronaut Takes Leave
description: HOUSTON, May 21 (Reuters)  A scientistastronaut, Dr. Donald Lee Holmquest, has left the space program for a year to take up teaching and medical research at Baylor School of Medicine here, the space agency announced today. There are 47 astronauts on the active list now.

title: and for Riverside Park?
description: The proposal to turn Brooklyn's scenic Shore Parkway into a noisy commercial highway seems to have been abandoned by Governor Rockefeller in his haste to get a transportation bond issue passed by the Legislature. if so, the city has cause to be relievedbut not so relieved that it should settle for the equally illconceived plan for rebuilding Manhattan's West Side Highway.

title: U.S. INSURANCE PLAN WILL BENEFIT SLUMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Government announced plans today for a new crime insurance program that will permit merchants and residents in the slums to protect their property at the same premium rate as that paid by storeown ers and citizens in the affluent suburbs.

title: 2 POLICEMEN SLAIN BY SHOTS IN BACK; 2 MEN ARE SOUGHT
description: Two city policemen were shot from behind and killed last night in a housing development on the northern edge of Harlem.

title: Polish Trawler Harasses U.S. Craft in New Incident
description: BOSTON, May 21 (UPI)A Polish fishing trawler ran through the gear of an Ameri can lobster boat today, the third such incident by foreign vessels in the two days follow ing a conference between Uni ted States and Soviet officials, the Coast Guard reported.

title: DELAYS REPORTED IN MIXED SCHOOLS
description: Witnesses and committee members expressed dissatisfac tion with voluntary school de segregation in the North at hearing held here yesterday by six members of the General Education Subcommittee of the House Education and Labor Committee.

title: 2 Britons, Near Top, Abandon Climb on Unscaled Everest Face
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 21 (AP)  An attempt to climb the unconquered southwest face of Mount Everest was aban doned less than 2,000 feet from the summit today with two British climbers too exhausted to continue.

title: Cut in TV Smoking Found
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) The American Cancer Society reported today that cigarette smoking by performers in tele vision programs has dropped 50 per cent in the last three years. Volunteers monitored 183 programs and found smoking was cut in half in the spring of 1971 compared with a similar survey in 1968.

title: Women in job CorpsProblems and Benefits
description: JERSEY CITYThe setting is reminiscent of a college campus: Gray, lookalike buildings. Green grass. Groups of giggling and gos siping girls scurrying to class.

title: Fraud Charge Dropped
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 21 (AP)A fraud and conspiracy indictment against Joseph Kav anaugh in the Louisiana Loan and Thrift Corporation case was dismissed today by Fed eral District Judge Alvin B. Rubin at the Government's re quest.

title: Amex Prices Decline in Dull Trading
description: Prices moved lower in dull trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Running Out on the I.L.O.
description: The plan the Administration is reported considering to end this country's unconscionable withholding of dues from the International Labor Organization would substitute another irresponsible form of international pressure for the one in which the United States is now engaged.

title: Taft Moves Toward an Attempt To Dominate the G.O.P. in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Senator Robert Taft Jr. is mov ing toward an attempt to domi nate the Ohio Republican party a move of some importance in Presidential politics.

title: King, Denver Oil Man, Hit By Liens Filed by I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service has filed tax liens against the property of John M. King, the Denver oil man, in an effort to recover about $5million in taxes it contends Mr. King owes the Federal Government, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: LAIRD URGES SAIGON TO ACT ON NARCOTICS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Reu ters)Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird today said the South Vietnamese Government must be more realistic in facing up to the problem of how to stop narcotics from reaching American servicemen.

title: 3 Services Will Rate Views Toward Race
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)Future fitness reports on Army, Navy and Air Force officers will include ratings on racial attitudes and com mitment to equal treatment for minorities.

title: Faster I.B.M. Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation an nounced yesterday a faster version of its System/360 Model 20 computer. The com puter will have a main memory cycle time of 3.6 microseconds.

title: Market Place. When Auditors Won't Cooperate
description: The nation's accountants don't like to discuss it, but from time to time a corpora tion changes auditors because the auditor won't sign a let ter in the annual report that overlooks a controversial in terpretation of a reporting rule.

title: U.S. Acts to Prevent Bias In Housing Advertisements
description: WASHINGTON, May 21In an effort to reduce housing dis crimination, the Government moved today to prevent the use of racial and religious des ignations in newspaper ad vertisements.

title: Albatross Heads Field of Eight in Messenger stakes at Westbury Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 21 Eight sophomore pacers, who earned their berths by finishing no lower than fourth in elim ination trials last Tuesday, were entered today in the $114,977.50 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway tomor row night.

title: Presbyterians Hear Plea for Jailed Soviet Jews
description: ROCHESTER, May 21  Mrs. Rivka Aleksandrovich, the mother of a 23yearold nurse now in a Soviet jail and who is scheduled to go on trial next Monday on charges of antiSo viet agitation and propaganda, was given a standing ovation here today by nearly 800 Pres byterian leaders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3Day Birthday to Start For Brooklyn Bridge
description: Three days of public festiv ities and free entertainment in celebration of the 88th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge will begin here at 11 A.M. Today and continue through Monday afternoon.

title: Bridge: Precision Team, Starting Tour Of World, Wins in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, May 21 The Precision International Team scored a comfortable victory here on the first leg of its world tour last night after overcoming some early problems. The final score in a 40deal match against Hong Kong was 151 to 69 interna tional match points.

title: Indians Top Yanks, 87, on Hodge's Hit
description: CLEVELAND, May 21Har old (Gomer) Hodge, Cleveland's rookie pinchhitter who de livered successfully on his first four trips to the plate in the major leagues, did his thing again in the ninth inning to night to give the Indians an 87 victory over the Yankees in a wild and wooley game at Mu nicipal Stadium.

title: G.M. Critics' Proposals Voted Down at Meeting
description: DETROIT, May 21The Gen eral Motors Corporation at its annual meeting today easily de feated proposals by its critics designed to break manage ment's hold on the board of directors and to end its opera tions in South Africa.

title: Suspect Killed in Queens In Subway Booth Holdup
description: A wouldbe robber was shot fatally when he attempted to hold up a subway change booth in Queens last night, the police reported.

title: POST'S STONITSCH MAY QUIT TRACK
description: TEANECK, N. J., May 21 Ron Stonitsch said today that he knew how Jim Ryun must have felt when cries of quit ter followed Ryun into his muchpublicized retirement.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 A lightweight armored seat, for which a patent will be granted June 1, is already in general use by helicopter pilots in Vietnam. The bullet proof bucket seat, made of ceramic mate rials, protects a craft's pilot from his knees to his neck. The Norton Company, Worcester, Mass., manufac turer of the seat, will re ceive Patent 3,581,620 as assignee of Eldon W. Hauck and Samuel H. Coes, engi neers on its staff.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Dismisses a Lawsuit Over Use of Birth Curb Pill
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI)A $1.5million suit against the manufacturer of a birth control pill has been dismissed by a jury of six women and five men. The suit charged that the G. D. Searle Company, manu facturers of Enovid, was re sponsible for the death of one woman and serious injury to another.

title: F.C.C. Chides WWRL Over Cleric'sBlessings
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 The Federal Communications Commission has admonished the Sonderling Broadcasting Corporation, which operates radio station WWRL in New York City, for having al lowed a minister to use the station's facilities to allegedly solicit money in return for tips on the numbers game.

title: ALBERT H. ACKEN
description: ORANGE, N. J., May 21 (AP) Albert H. Acken, executive vice president of the New Jersey State Chamber of Com merce, died today at Orange Hospital after a long illness.

title: 30 U.S. SOLDIERS KILLED IN ATTACKS ON VIETNAM BASES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 22Thirty Ameri can soldiers were killed and 50 wounded in three devastating rocket and mortar attacks in the northern war zone of South Vietnam, the United States com mand announced today.

title: Injunction Is Issued
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 21 (AP) District Judge Herman Jones is sued a temporary restraining order late today forbidding mili tant interruptions of the dedi cation ceremonies.

title: Bias Laid to Transit Body and T. W .U.
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People charged yesterday that the Transit Authority, 75 per cent of whose employes are black or Puerto Rican, had con pired with the Transport Work ers Union to bar members of minority groups from certain highpaying jobs.

title: Three Financial Writers Win $1,000 Loeb Awards
description: STORRS, Conn., May 21 Joseph Livingston of The Phila delphia Bulletin and Philip Greer of The Washington Post have won $1,000 prizes in the annual Loeb award contest for financial journalism, it was an nounced here today. Chris Wel les of Institutional Investor won the $1,000 prize for the magazine category.

title: Protests, U.S. Quintet Fail to Deter Soviet
description: CINCINNATI, May 21 (AP) The Soviet Union Olympic basketball team won its sixth game against American College; allstar teams tonight, 9785, and there were two protest in cidents before the contes.

title: La Salle Wins Track Title; Groneveldt High Jumps 66
description: La Salle Academy scored 90 points to take the Christian Brothers schools track and field title yesterday at St. John's University, Queens.

title: The City Ballet Gives Who Cares And Dim Lustre
description: A nostalgic nosegay perfumed the New York State Theater Wednesday evening as the New York City Ballet offered several glances into the recent and slightly remote past.

title: Art: New Talent in Printmarking Show
description: New Talent in Printmak ing, 1971, is this year's ver sion of an annual exhibition at Associated American Ar tists, 663 Fifth Avenue at 52nd Street, that has racked up a solid roster of alumni. This year it is made up of five small one  man shows, all good.

title: Rail TonMileage Off 2.9%
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended May 15 totaled an estimated 15.1 billion tonmiles, 2.9 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. The Associa tion of American Railroads also reported that car loadings in the latest week totaled 532,212 cars, a decrease of 36,881, or 6.5 per cent below the com parable week last year, and 36,917 trailers or containers, down 0.6 per Cent from 1970.

title: Two Share Travis Medal
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21Pete Biscounti and Jim Bostwick, winners of the Wal ter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament in 1968 and 1969, respectively, shot par 73 today over the tricky Garden City Golf Club course to tie for the medal in the 60th annual Tra vis invitation tournament.

title: Long Island Is Not to Be Scoffed At
description: When I was a kid growing up in Queens, relatives from Brooklyn and the East Side used to visit on Sundays and sit in our small back yard on folding chairs and talk about how nice it was to be out on Long Island. They were wrong, of course, but the mistake persists; there are still people who live in Manhattan, and you men tion places that are really in New York City like Bellaire or Laurelton, and they say that's Long Island. Well, don't try to tell that to anyone who really lives on Long Island.

title: At 91, a Historian Relates the Story Of Her Own Life
description: In the cool dark of a re cent morning, Margarete Bie ber, age 91, rose a half hour earlier than usual. It was 6:30 and there were prepara tions to complete before her assistants would come to work at 10 and her visitors would arrive later in the day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: State Court Upholds Mayor In Eliminating 475 City Jobs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Myles J. Lane ruled yesterday that Mayor Lindsay acted within the scope of his execu tive authority in eliminating 475 city jobs.

title: World Health Unit Sets Cancer Study
description: GENEVA, May 21  The World Health Organization is sponsoring one of the most ex tensive cancer research projects yet undertaken to determine whether a virus is responsible for a littleknown form of can cer in Africa.

title: THANT SAYS TENSION MOUNTS ON CYPRUS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21Secretary General Thant warned the Security Council today that mounting tensions between the Greek and Turkish communities in cyprus could burst into a Mediterra nean war unless they were resolved.

title: PUBLISHERS SUED ON WIRE SHARING
description: The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust complaint yes terday against The New York Times and the company pub lishing The Chicago Daily News and The Chicago SunTimes to stop them from sharing a single wire and sales agent for their supplemental news services.

title: Award for Mrs. Lasker
description: Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, phil anthropist in medical affairs, has been named rrecipient of the American Cancer Society's 1971 Alfred P. Sloan Jr. Me morial Award. The award hon ors national leaders for achieve mens in cancer, control, a fiel?? Mrs: Lasker has supported gen erously.

title: Witness in Jersey Describes Kickback
description: NEWARK, May 21A prose cution witness in. The Hudoni CountyJersey City extortion conspiracy trial testified in Federal Court today that Bernard J. MUrphy, the Jersey City purchasing agent, had de manded a $3million kickback on a proposed $42million elec tric construction contract.

title: Israelis Expect U.S. Pressure for Easing Terms
description: JERUSALEM, May 21Israel's leaders are bracing themselves for new pressure from the Uni ted States to soften their terms for a settlement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: 60 Western Intellectuals Berate Castro
description: PARIS, May 21Sixty Euro pean and American intellec tuals, among them JeanPaul Sartre, Alberto Moravia and Susan Sontag, have written to Premier Fidel Casto to express their disillusionment with him over Cuba's treatment of the poet Heberto Padilla.

title: 35 Indians Evicted From Naval Station; Sioux Treaty Cited
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 21 (UPI) A force of Federal marshals and Hennepin County sheriff's officers evicted today about 35 Indians who were occupying building at the Twin Cities Naval Air Station.

title: Prices Show Drop On Heavy Trading In Silver Futures
description: Silver future prices dropped sharply again yesterday in heavy trading on the Com modity Exchange (Comex) here. A total of 5,172 trades were transacted.

title: Walter G. Dunnington, 79, Dies; Lawyer on Corporate Boards
description: Walter Grey Dunnington, counsel and former senior, part ner of the law firm of Dunning ton, Bartholow & Miller, 161 East 42d Street, died Thursday in a nursing home in South ampton, L. I. He was 79 years old and lived at 960 Fifth Ave nue and in Southampton.

title: NIXON STATES AIM IS 1971 ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 President Nixon said today that the United States and the Sov iet Union had committed them selves to seek to reach an agreement on arms limitation that would be implemented some time this year.

title: BankBacked Bill Loses In Assembly for 3d Time
description: ALBANY, May 21Like old soldiers, old bills never die. Sometimes they don't even fade away.

title: Market for New Issues Displays A Listless Pattern for the Week
description: The newissue market, which has been strong in recent weeks, turned in a lackluster performance this week in com paratively quiet trading.

title: F.T.C. CITES BIG DROP IN MERGERS FOR 1970
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Corporate mergers declined sharply last year, the Federal Trade Commission said today, with only four concerns worth $100million or more being ac quired.

title: New Drive Into Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (Reuters)  American helicopters have airlifted near ly 2,000 South Vietnamese troops into eastern Cambodia for a drive against two North Vietnamese divisions, military sources here reported today.

title: F.P.C. Settles on Rate Rise For Southern Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Federal Power Commis sion announced today the ac ceptance of a settlement pro viding for wholesale naturalgas rate increases totaling $30.3 million annually by the South ern Natural Gas Company, Bir mingham, Ala.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, May 21A little after 7 this evening, in a room hung with tapestries of Biblical scenes, President Pompidou spoke of an important moment in the history of Britain, France and Western Europe. The am bassadors, officials and journal ists listening could not doubt that they were present at such a moment. Barring what now must be the unexpected, they were witness ing the birth of a new Europe, a community of 300 million peo ple. For them, and for great na tions elsewhere, nothing will ever be quite the same.

title: House Inquiry Scored as a Red Smear
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 A leader of the antiwar coalition that organized the April 24 demonstration here charged to day that the House Internal Security Committee was en gaging in a red smear to di vert public attention from an tiwar activities.

title: Stanford Man Reported New Economic Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Ezra Solomon, an economics professor at Stanford Univer sity, will succeed Hendrik S. Houthakker as a member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, it was reliably reported today.

title: MARKET EASES IN CAUTIOUS DAY
description: Commercial Solvents, a re cent market favorite, tumbled yesterday as stock prices gen erally edged downward in cau tious trading.

title: A. SIDNEY NORTON, 73, BANKERS TRUST AIDE
description: A. Sidney Norton, a retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday at St. Simons Island, Georgia. He was 73 years old.

title: San Francisco Seeks Delay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 (AP)The San Francisco Board of Education voted last night to appeal a decision by Federal District Judge Stanley Weigel ordering it to submit a plan to desegregate the district's ele mentary schools in the fall. At the same time, the board told its advisory committee to draw up another plan that would call for desegregation of all San Francisco schools by June, 1972.

title: Curb Is Sought on Mylai Statements
description: FORT MEADE, Md., May 21 (UPI)  Col. Oran K. Hender son's lawyers sought today to prohibit the Defense Depart ment from making any more public statements about the My lai case on the ground that such statements were prejudicing the colonel's defense.

title: Dance: Three Works by Sanasardo
description: Paul Sanasardo, whose company's miniseason ends at the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight, is an elusive choreographer. His company is obviously beautifully trained and dedicated. It is a smoothly honed instrument, efficient, if a shade imper sonal. I suppose smoothness is the fundamental quality of both Mr. Sanasardo's com pany and his choreography. It is a smoothness that all too often slips away in the memory, pleasantly enough yet unremarkably.

title: CORDERO SCORES AQUEDUCT TRIPLE
description: Angel Cordero won the fea ture event on the card at Aque duct yesterday, aboard Elmen dorf's Specious. Engaging Jean Cruguet in a stretch duel aboard Joy Henshel's Valesse, Cordero guided his mount to a 1  length success in the 1 1/16 mile turf event for older fillies and mares.

title: DR. JACQUES VORIS
description: DARIEN, Conn., May 21 Dr. Jacques V. B. Voris, a gen eral practitioner here, died yes terday, apparently of a heart attack, in Norwalk Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 258 West Norwalk Road.

title: Frank Marcus Play Due
description: The Formation Dancers, a new play by Frank Marcus, is scheduled for Broadway pro duction during the 197273 sea son by the producing firm of Morton Gottlieb, Helen Bonfils and Michael White. The play is about sophisticated New York ers, particularly a married man in his 40's and his problems with present day morality.

title: EDWARD BUDD JR., OF RAILCAR FIRM
description: Edward G. Budd Jr., who re tired as chairman of the Budd Company of Philadelphia in 1967, died Thursday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. His age was 69.

title: Russian Negotiators Make Chinese Tour
description: MOSCOW, May 21The So viet Union announced today that the members of its nego tiating team at the 19month old border talks in Peking had completed a tour of three Chinese cities as guests of the Chinese Government.

title: Price Index Climbs 0.3%, Largest Rise in 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, May 21,  The Consumer Price Index re corded in April its largest rise in three months, chiefly be cause unfavorable weather in Florida and California caused large increases in the price of fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: RESOR QUITS POST AS HEAD OF ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Stanley R. Resor, Secretary of the Army in both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, re signed today after the longest period of service, and one of the most difficult, In that post.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Votes on Draft Bill Amendments Scheduled Over Next 2 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Senate agreed today to a series of votes over the next two weeks on key amendments to a bill to extend the military draft, which under existing law, would expire June 30.

title: El Cordobes Bullfight Set For Telecast at Garden
description: A live closedcircuit color telecast of a bullfight from Spain, starring El Crdobes, will be shown at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, June 13, at 4 P.M.

title: Allin C. Seward 3d Dies at 62; Helped Set Up U.N. Missions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21  Allin Carey Seward Jr., who played a key adminis trative role in organizing the world organization's many overseas missions before re tiring in 1969, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital in Connec ticut. He was 62 years old.

title: Seale Jury Out 3d Day
description: NEW HAVEN, May 21The jury in the murder trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins ended its third day of deliberations today without re turning a verdict.

title: Muskie Bids Other Lands Delay Any Flights by SST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21  Those nations still developing supersonic trans ports should not fly them until the international community has assessed what effect they may have upon the environ ment, Senator Edmund S. Mus kie said here today.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) President Nixon has been told by two aides, back from a mission to Europe and Africa, that efforts to prevent drug use among United States military forces in Europe appear not to be altogether effective.

title: Reston 3d Times Writer Given a Visa by Peking
description: James Reston, a vice presi dent and columnist of The New York Times, has received a visa to enter China.

title: The Slurbs Are Ahead of the Cities
description: It is time for the cities to get mean and nasty. If the citydweller's naked eye hasn't told him yet, the current flow of census material and political rhetoric are making it patently clear: The noncities are engaged in a major conflict with the cities, and the cities are losing.

title: John H. Boylan Weds Christine Broomfield
description: Miss Christine Broomfield, a former secretary at the United States Embassy in London, was married yester day to John H. Boylan, an as sociate producer with the American Broadcasting Com pany's Evening News.

title: Last Chance for Wetlands
description: Tidal wetlands are a critically important zone in nature's defense system. Marshes and estuaries reduce erosion and damage during storms and floods, provide habitat for birds and wildlife, are essential for shellfish, and reduce pollution by converting organic pollutants into useful nutriments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HEARTS SET BACK COSMO ELEVEN, 42
description: Donald Ford, a slim, dark haired Scotsman who confesses that he likes cricket rather than soccer, displayed his soccer skills at Yankee Stadium last night by scoring three goals and pacing Hearts of Scotland to a 42 victory over the New York Cosmos.

title: School's Concert and Art Show Canceled Here by Pupil Protest
description: A daylong demonstration by black students forced the can cellation yesterday of the High School of Music and Art's semi annual concert and art exhi bition, which was scheduled for last night and tonight.

title: Knudson Paces Fort Worth Golf on 136
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 21 (AP)George Knudson of To ronto, using a newstyle, flying saucer putter, rallied for a 69 today and took the lead after the second round of the $125, 000 Colonial national invitation golf tournament.

title: Security in Austin Is Expanded For Johnson Ceremony Today
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 21The number of guards to be on hand for the dedication of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Li brary tomorrow was apparently doubled today after antiwar groups said they would, storm police lines if necessary to make their views known.

title: CALM URGED AT KENT AFTER ARREST OF 63
description: KENT, Ohio, May 21 (UPI) After three nights of disturb ances, the president of Kent State University today pleaded with students to remember the tragic results of last year, when four students were killed by Ohio National Guardsmen during antiwar demonstrations.

title: 4 Austrian Artists Recall Vienna Era
description: The Vienna of the turn of the century smelled of death. In the history of Austria it was a period of stifling deca dence, provincial hypocrisies and bankrupt moralities. It was the time when the Aus troHungarian Empire was degenerating into eventual collapse. And yet, in the midst of the falsity and cor ruption of Vienna, the same Schoenberg was breaking with traditions in music, Freud was experimenting with psychoanalysis and the visual arts were enjoying a veritable renaissance in the works of Egon Schiele, Gustav Klimt and Oskar Kokoschka.

title: Communique, Excerpts From Statement
description: PARIS, May 21Following is the text of the English ver sion of the joint communiqu issued here today following talks between President Pom pidou and Prime Minister Heath, as well as excerpts from statements by Mr. Pom pidou and Mr. Heath:

title: Lye Thrown at Bus Dispatcher, Mistaken for a City Policeman
description: Two men who mistook a Transit Authority bus dispatch er for a policeman threw lye into his face as he stood on a street corner in the Bronx yes terday.

title: Battrick Upsets Fillol and Gains Final in British Tennis
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 21 (UPI)Gerald Battrick scored what he called the best win of my career today when he beat Jaime Fillol of Chile, 75, 16, 63, 16, 63, to gain the final of the $36,000 British hardcourts tennis champion ship.

title: The Talk of Canton
description: CANTON, China, May 20 In 1949, a few months before the Communists seized Can ton, two Americans clam bered out of rickshas at the entrance to a hotel on Shameen Island, the old foreign quarter.

title: TOUGH TRADE LINE URGED BY SHULTZ
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) George P. Shultz, director of the Office of Management and Budget, agreed with Senators today that the United States must take a much tougher line in working out problems with its international trading part ners.

title: ALLENDE PLEDGES TO SHUN VIOLENCE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 President Salvador Allende Gossens said today that Chile's goal was a socialist revolution without death, chaos or hun ger.

title: JAZZ BAND ASSISTS NARCOTICS CENTERS
description: Add one more to the length ening list of big jazz bands that have been turning up at the Friday noontime sessions at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street. Yesterday's entry bore a cumbersome name  the Julius SchwartzJerry Kail Anti Drug Orchestrabut it swung through a set of crisp arrange ments with a bright, blithe at tack.

title: CARL C. FREYER
description: Carl C. Freyer, long an execu tive in the floorcoverings in dustry, died at his home on Thursday after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 54 Adams Street, Garden City, L. I.

title: Henry A. Sahm Dies at 71; A Former L.I. Supervisor
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., May 21Henry A. Sahm, a former councilman and supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, L. I., died yesterday in Boyn ton Beach. He was 71 years old and lived here.

title: SHLOMO DROR DEAD; ARTIST IN ISRAEL, 82
description: Shlomo Dror, an artist, farm er and former mayor of Avi chail, Israel, died there May 14 at the age of 82.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY BIDS POLICE OBEY LAW
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 21Undaunted by his failure to convict a Negro sheriff, Lu cius D. Amerson of Tuskegee, on a charge of mistreating a prisoner, United States Attor ney Ira DeMent says that he intends to push forward with a crusade for police profes sionalism.

title: EXEMPTIONS VOTED IN UNDECLARED WAR
description: SALEM, Ore., May 21The Oregon, Senate passed today a bill to exempt Oregon service men from serving in wars that have not been declared by Congress.

title: Mets Down Braves To End Slump, 62
description: There wasn't much the New York. Mets could do about Henry Aaron at Shea Stadium last night, but they handled the rest of the Atlanta Braves well enough to score a 62 vic tery and snap their longest los ing streak of the season at five games.

title: Bengali Refugees in Squalor in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 21 India's 1,350mile border with East Pakistan is beginning to resemble a continuous and severely depressing gypsy camp.

title: Carrier Returns to War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP)The United States air craft carrier Midway has re turned to the Indochina war after more than five years off the line for extensive modern ization, the Navy said today. The 25yearold carrier has been on station in the Tonkin Gulf since Tuesday, and her planes have been attacking the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos.

title: Scientists Intensify Research on Marijuana's Effects
description: A panel or scientists, re porting a growing concern among physicians about the unknown longterm hazards of smoking marijuana, met for the last two days to ex change information on basic research into the drug.

title: Gimeno Defeats Kuhnke
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 21 (AP)Andres Gimeno of Spain gained the quarter finals of the German inter national open tournament today with a 61, 86, 64 victory over Christian Kuhnke of West Ger many.

title: Awards Are Given To Ethnic Writers Of Children's Books
description: Winners of the third annual contest for previously unpub lished manuscripts were an nounced yesterday by the coun cil on Interracial Books for Children at a reception held at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.

title: PENN STATE DOWNS ARMY TRACK SQUAD
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 22 penn State's outdoor track team, led by Scott Chatham and Greg Fredericks, defeated Army, 8470, today.

title: EXAGENT OF F.B.I. TO HEAD L.I. STUDY
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., May 22 former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who specialized in espionage and conspiracy investigations is the new head of the department of police science of the State University's Agricultural and Technical College here.

title: Hamden Drops Franchise
description: Ted Capozzi, general man ager of the Hamden, Conn., team, the Northern Division champion, returned the fran chise to the Eastern Basketball Association yesterday because of failure to get New Haven Coliseum as a site for its games.

title: COMMUTERS'
description: ALBANY, May 22Both city and state officials agreed today that negotiations over the city's $896million tax package were in a cold stalemate.

title: Et Al.
description: An updating of the 1964 his tory of American labor, which went from the earliest days of the Republic to the sixties. The author now adds chapters on public employe unions, black workers and trends of the last decade. The Times called the earlier edition brilliant and original. Mr. Brooks continues to deserve the praise.

title: An Appraisal
description: AUSTIN, Tex,It is possible, after leaving the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library, to feel slight ly overJohnsoned. Only history will know for sure. But in the random way that democracy scatters art and monuments among its leaders, Mr. Johnson has a winner. This is the first unabashed bid for immortal ity using that curi ous new hybrid, the Presidential library  museum, and it has pro duced a substan tial work of architecture. The age of Lincoln and Jefferson memorials is over. It will be Presidential libraries from now on.

title: In Anguilla It's the Spirit of '71
description: Once upon a time there was a West Indian island called An guilla that liked being a British colony. Then, in 1967, London gave Anguilla its independenceas part of a new island nation dominated by neighboring St. Kitts. Anguillan felt rejected; they rebelled, and demanded a return to the status quo. This confused the deep thinkers in London, so they sent troopspara troops!to put down the revolution in reverse. And they sent politicians to argue and Scotland Yard police to keep order. But the Anguillans would not give up, and now Great Britain has capitulated and agreed to grant them their dependence (that is, once London has figured out the legal technicalities involved). And the Anguillan, presumably, will live happily forever after.

title: Liquori Is Easy Victor in El Paso Mile Despite Slow Time of 4:10.9
description: EL PASO, Tex. (AP)Marty Liquori of Villanova, battling swirling dust and strong winds, won the mile today with ease at the El Paso invitation track and field meet in the slow time of 4 minutes 10.9 seconds.

title: Nassau Coliseum Envisioned as Home of Big League Teams
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.The Nassau Coli seum, shaped like a loaf of bread and rising above a 500acre wasteland in Mitchel Field, will soon be the home of Long Island's first majorleague teams.

title: Miss Packard Wed to Officer
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 22Miss Cynthia Ann Packard, daughter of Vance Packard, the author, and Mrs. Packard of New Canaan and Chappaquiddick, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Harvey Wallace Richmond, U. S. A., son of Prof. and Mrs. Arthur A. Richmond 3d of Annap olis, Md.

title: Poly Prep Wins State Title
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., May 22 Al Fineberg, the meet's only double winner, led Poly Prep of Brooklyn to its first state private schools invitation track victory today. Poly Prep had 67 points, one more than Stony Brook Prep. The New York Military Academy was third with 37. Fineberg captured the shotput at 54 feet 4 inches and the discus throw at 1261.

title: Cuellar and Orioles Check Red Sox, 52
description: BALTIMORE, May 22Mike Cuellar pitched a fourhitter and Brooks Robinson and Don Buford hit home runs for the Baltimore Orioles today as the Orioles downed the Boston Red Sox, 52, snapping Boston's fivegame winning streak.

title: Photography
description: Q UITE a controversial set of pictures you got here, said Ge raldo Rivera, puta tive cultural ombudsman for ABC's Eyewitness News, smiling into the spotlights, though whether he was re ferring to the photographs (which, however one might describe them, are hardly controversial), their subjects the Hell's Angelsor his own reaction to the Angels, remained unclear.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Pause and take stock! This was the advice of Ely Callaway, president of Burlington Industries, Inc., the world's largest textile manufacturer, in respect to knitted fabrics. Textile men, he said, are so intent on getting into the knit boom that they are guilty of lapses of good judgment in their efforts to increase capacity.

title: Swept off his feet while keeping his head
description: In an age when the airwaves have crosspollinated haute cul ture and hoi polloi till you can't tell them apart, when American culture is no long er a contradiction in terms, it takes strange new combina tions of skills to comprehend it all. Takes, for example, the standup critic: an intellectual entertainer who may sometimes be profound, but is never pe dantic; whose ideas are light, mobile and quickly deployed; who requires, for his work, not a cloistered institution complete with library and lecture hall, but only an occasion and an audience. Such a man is Al bert Goldman.

title: Chicago School Goes to the Head of the Class
description: CHICAGOIt could never have happened in Cambridge, Mass., where not only the Charles River but also strong feelings divide the Harvard Business School from the Keynesian economists of Harvard and Massachusetts institute of Technology who dominated government and business thinking during the nineteensixties.

title: Jarvis and 2 Other Rookies Agree to Bills' Contracts
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., May 22 (AP)The Buffalo Bills signed three rookie draft choices to day, including Bruce Jarvis, a center from the University of Washington.

title: Garr of Braves Is Hoping to Earn Respect and a Higher Salary
description: When Ralph Garr was 17 years old, he thought of a plan for his posthigh school days.

title: Dr. Robert M. Harris Dies; Internist in Miami Was 74
description: MIAMI, May 22 (UPI) Dr. Robert Miller Harris, a physi cian who attended Sir Winston Churchill, died here yesterday at the age of 74.

title: Nixon Hails Johnson Library at Dedication
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 22The $18.6million Lyndon Baines Johnson Library complex was dedicated today in a nationally televised ceremony that drew 3,000 guests, including former and present aspirants for the Presidency.

title: Dennis King, Stage Star, Dead; Noted for Vagabond King Role
description: Dennis King, who was popu lar with several generations of theatergoers, particularly as star in musical shows, died of a heart ailment Friday night in University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 404 East 55th Street.

title: Death of Woman, 93, In West Side Home Laid to ExConvict
description: A 36yearold former convict was charged with homicide last night in the murder of a 93 yearold woman in a luxury apartment on the Upper West Side Thursday morning.

title: Mark Steinman Weds Dina Albright
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., May 22 Miss Blandina Van Etten Albright, a member of a family famous in American journalism for five genera tions was married here this afternoon to Mark Steinman, who was a fellow student at Goddard College. Circuit Court Judge Franklin Billings of Montpelier preformed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Albright of Chi cago and Woodstock. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Steinman of Rochester.

title: Classy Breeze Is Victor
description: MIAMI, Fla., May 22 (AP) A crowd of 10,338 made Classy Breeze the 75 favorite and First Bloom the 85 second choice in the Cypress Stakes at Calder Race Course today, and that's the way they officially finished.

title: Kennedy Library to Be Scaled Down
description: When the Kennedy family announced on Dec. 13, 1964, the selection of I. M. Pei, the New York architect, as designer for the John F. Kennedy Me morial Library at Harvard Uni versity, every indication was that the libraryresearch com plex would be completed by 1970, if not sooner.

title: Columbia Oarsmen to Compete In Henley Regatta in England
description: Columbia's lightweight var sity crew will go to England's Henley Royal regatta June 30 July 3 and row for The Thames Cup, the university has an nounced. The trip is a com mendation for this crew which began the season as a loser and ended up a winner.

title: Sect in Israeli Village Disputes Pagan Label
description: TEL AVIV, May 22 (Reu ters)The 500 villagers of Ghagar in the Israelioccupied Golan Heights, who are be lieved to be descended from the preIsraelite Canaanites, have called on Israel's Edu cation Ministry to delete reference to them as pagans.

title: Suzanne Fiske Shaffer Married to Bayard Kellam
description: CANAAN, N. Y., May 22 Miss Suzanne Fiske Shaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fiske Shaffer of Brooklyn, was married here this afternoon to Bayard Kel lam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Kellam of East Chatham. The Rev. Norman R. Farnum Jr. performed the ceremony in the Canaan Con gregational Church.

title: A Woman Is Nominated To P.S.C. for First Time
description: ALBANY, May 22Gover nor Rockefeller has sent to the Senate for confirmation the nomination of Mrs. Car mel Carrington Marr of Brooklyn to be a commis sioner of the State Public Service Commission.

title: Books: Pierre du pont
description: PIERRE S. DU PONT ANE THE MAKING OF THE MOD ERN CORPORATION. By Al fred D. Chandler Jr. and Ste phen Salsbury. Harper & Row. 722 pages. $17.50.

title: The Little Priest Who Stands UP To Brazil's Generals
description: RECIFE, Brazil. I THOUGHT I could no longer remain silent without losing the respect of the young, said the animated Brazilian priest, who stood no taller than an altar boy. Dom Helder, as he is commonly known, was recalling a speech that he made at the Palais des Sports in Paris on May 26 last year before several members of the French Roman Catheolic hierarchy and a standing roomonly crowd.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Is it possible we have heard a Presi dent talk again about a war to end wars? Surely, since Wilson, it is very late to believe such things.

title: C. M. Amory Jr. Weds Muffie Bancroft
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 22  Miss Margaret Woodward Stewart Bancroft, daughter of the Duchess d' Uss, the Standard Oil heir ess, was married this after noon to C. Minot Amory Jr. in St. John's or Lattingtown Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, performed the ceremony.

title: OSCAR R. FLYNN JR., FINANCE PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Oscar Rogers Flynn Jr., professor emeritus of finance at Columbia University, died yesterday in his apartment on Morningside Heights. His age was 73.

title: Solving the Payments Riddle
description: The dollar crisis has produced a burst of Administra tion statements designed to prove that neglect, whether benign or malignant, does not represent the official United States balanceofpayments policy.

title: Relatives Seek Aid
description: GENEVA, May 22A dele gation of 173 wives and rela tives of United States service men missing or held prisoner in Indochina arrived here today for a visit timed to coincide with the start Monday of a Red Cross conference that will con sider revising the 1949 Geneva Conventions protecting military and civilian war victims.

title: Ceylon's Elephants Are Back on the Job, a Sign of Normality as the Leftist Rebellion Fades
description: KANDY, Ceylon, May 13 We are going back to work, Simon, the elephant tender said. We are not afraid any more.

title: Miss Royster Becomes Bride Of Eric Holch
description: In Holy Trinity Episcopal Church here yesterday after noon, Miss Elspeth Merck Royster, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Royster of New York and Henderson, N.C., was married to Eric Sanford Holch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Holch of Greenwich, Conn., and Nan tucket, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clarke Oler.

title: Mural Enlivens Queens Playground
description: Playgrounds often seem to have little to do with playing. Deserts of asphalt and eye sores of chainlink fences, they can be gray and forbid ding, more like prisons than fun spots. They discourage rather than invite cama raderie and amusement.

title: Chess
description: THE tenth number of that useful Yugoslav publication, the Chess Informant has appeared in the United States and is, incredibly, even larger than the last. This one contains 841 games from a wide variety of national and international events, all played in the last six months of 1970, as well as other material: crosstables, middlegame and endgame positions, and news from FIDE (the International Chess Federation) of which it is the official organ.

title: Gardens
description: WETLANDS, while interesting to look at, are not usually too easily traversed. But in Sam uel T. Senior Memorial Park in Easton, Conn., the visitor can get to the heart of the wetlands without getting his feet wet.

title: SOVIET MOON ROVER GETS A LIMITED ROLE
description: MOSCOW, May 22 (UPI) Soviet scientists retired the Lunokhod moon vehicle to re duced activity today after six months of successful operation on the lunar surface, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Helene Weigel 19001971
description: SHE had the face not of an actress but of a woman, a woman who had lived with the soil, a peasant woman browned by wind and sunlight, with high cheekbones halfSpanish, half Oriental. She was small, al most tiny, but on stage seemed a giant; lean as an animal who has had to hunt for food and who has been hunted as prey. Her eyes, alert and crinkly with crow's feet, carried the sadness and pain of the world, and her mouth cried out  and also was able to laugh.

title: Black Educators Are Critical On Support for Negro Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Black educators renewed today their criticism of the Nixon Administration, philanthropic groups and private donors for what they described as failure to support black colleges and universities.

title: BATTRICK SCORES UPSET IN TENNIS
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, May 22 (Reuters)Unseeded Gerald Battrick won his first major tennis title today when he Upset Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia in the final $36,000 British hardcourt (clay) cham pionships.

title: CRANIS ADVANCES TO TENNIS FINAL
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 22 Firstseeded Paul Cranis of New York and Don Brosseau, a trans planted Californian, reached the final of the Eastern men's hard court tennis championship at the Woodbury Country Club today.

title: U. of New Haven Nine Wins N.A.I.A. District 32 Crown
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn., May 22 (AP)The University of New Haven lost a morning baseball game today but returned in the afternoon to take its third con secutive National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Dis trict 32 title.

title: Harlem Model Cities Aides Fail In Plan to Get Expense Accounts
description: An effort by the leaders of the HarlemEast Harlem Model Cities organization to vote themselves $126,300 a year in expense money$1,000 a month for the chairmanhas been re jected as unwarranted and wasteful.

title: Gun Attacks on Police Up Sharply Here
description: Gun attacks on city police men have risen sharply this year, with an average of three policemen shot every two weeks thus far. Last year's shootings averaged less than one a week.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Shame and Anger

title: L.I. Osteopath Appointed
description: Dr. Gerald Teplitz of Wood mere,. L. I., has been elected to a oneyear term as president of the New York Citl Society of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons. Dr. Teplitz will suc ceed Dr. Alexander D. Pheter son, who will become a mem.

title: SHUVEE, $3.40, WINS TOP FLIGHT SECOND YEAR IN ROW
description: Shuvee, Mrs. Whitney Stone's formidable mare who has beat en colts, won the $53,900 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, making it two years in a row that she has taken the 1mile test for older fil lies and mares. Her margin over the runnerup, Cathy Honey, was threequarters of a length.

title: Meditations on Norman Mailer, by Norman Mailer, against the day a Norman Mailest comes along
description: Sexual Politics, described by its author, Kate Millett as a hybrid (of literary and cultural criticism), was an ugly. monster. It presented an incontestable truth, that society is unjust to women, by means of an argument that did injustice to both sexes and almost every pertinent fact.

title: The World
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  In the years when the Vietnamese Com munists had the use of the Cambodian seaport of Sihanouk vine and ample sanctuaries along the Cambodian side of the bor der with South Vietnam, the ef fects of the Indochina war on the populated regions of the Laotian panhandle were limited.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE premise of this column's two part view of consumerism is that the great American tourist needs no apostle of consumerism; he can do it himself  it being to avoid and correct abuses perpetrated upon him wittingly or unwittingly. All it requires is that, first, the traveler purchase his travel as carefully and suspiciously as he buys anything else at a comparable cost, and, secondly, if and when a car rier, hotel, travel agent or some other supplier does him wrong, he lets them know about it promptly and properly.

title: Lady Reading, the First Woman In House of Lords, Is Dead at 77
description: LONDON, May 22Stella, Dowager Marchioness of Read ing, the founder and inspiration of Britain's Women's Voluntary Service for Civil Defense and for years a close friend of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, died today at her home here. She was 77 years old.

title: Police Will Use Videotape to Gather Evidence in Cases of Drunken Driving
description: In a move designed to raise the conviction rate for drunken driving, the city's Police De partment is planning to video tape suspected offenders fol lowing their arrests, starting this fall.

title: FireBombings in Pittsfield
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass, May 22 (UPI)Two buildings were fire bombed early tolay but firemen kept damage to a minimum. Molotov cocktails were thrown into the Riverside Cafe and a building across Columbus Street from the cafe, the police said. Witnesses said a carload of per sons had thrown the firebombs from the car.

title: U.S. Visitor to Hanoi Hopeful on Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, May 22A representative of the American Friends Service Committee just back from Hanoi said today that he believed the North Viet namese were ready to negoti ate the release of American prisoners of war sooner than had previously been assumed.

title: New Guinea Cargo Cult Plans Human Sacrifice to Find Wealth
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 22 The leader of a cargo cult in Australian New Guinea has caused serious official concern by threatening to die by cruci fixion and to sacrifice a boy, July 7, according to reports from the island.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 22.  Unseen apparently by office boys, reception ists, secretaries, building guards, in shdrt, by the whale apparatus meant to shelter us from humanity, he had slipped into the office and had his sample cases open on the floor in a flash. The latest machine  he began.

title: JOSEPH S. STERN, 80, LED U.S. SHOE CORP.
description: CINCINNATI, May 22 (AP) Joseph S. Stern, retired board chairman and former president of the United States Shoe Cor poration of this city, died today at his home. He was 80 years old.

title: This is the way the world will end
description: An interested reader of contempo rary American fiction will know Wal ker Percys first two books, The Moviegoer and The Last Gentle man. In the first book, the funny, despairing voice of Percy, reminis cent of Machado de Assis, was re vealed in some amplitude. If you liked that book, Percys genial abil ity to direct the eye to the grace that sometimes accompanies doom, pointlessness and insanity, was ir resistible and even encouraging.

title: Trouble Becomes Routine on Colorado Tunnel Project
description: SILVER PLUME, Colo., May 20Ten miles west of here stand the big granite mountains that mark the Continental Divide and the site of one of the nation's most ambitious and troubled highway projects.

title: DR. JOHN N. HAYES
description: SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., May 22Dr. John N. Hayes, who for 35 years was medical director of Gabriel's Sanitarium, treat ing tuberculosis patients, died yesterday at the Uehlein Nurs ing Center. He was 79 years old.

title: EDUCATOR URGES PRAISE OF TRADES
description: A leading vocational coun selor advises parents to tell their children that there is prestige and a good life in be ing an expert plumber or car penter.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sisters Attend Miss Metzger At Her Bridal
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 22Miss Merrill Craig Metzger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Andrews Metzger of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Green Hill, R. I., was mar ried here this afternoon to Eric Watt Wiechmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jer done Wiechmann of West port and New York.

title: Leslie Fiedler Reintroduces Himself
description: A list of the great critics and his torians of American literature in this century would have to include Leslie Fiedler, by far the least academic, the most voluble, diverse, uneven, divisive, rambunctious andto use his own word, heavy with irony, pride and regretcontroversial. At 54, professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo (on leave this year to teach at the University of Vincennes in France), Fiedler has written five books of criticism and hundreds of essays, articles, reviews, stories and poemsplus two novels and an autobiographical apologia pro vita sua, Being Busted. He has taught literature all over America and Europe and written for maga zines that range from Partisan Re view to Playboy to Ramparts. Dur ing the past two decades he has been a New York Jewish intellectual hol ing out in Missoula, Mont., a latter day prophet of the switch from whisky culture to drug culture, a celebrant of the young new mutants, an apostle of pop, and an embattled Buffalo civil libertarian caught in the cause clbre of a 1967 pot bust (still on appeal in the courts).

title: Mao Is Seen as Benefit Even to Visitor
description: HANGCHOW, China, May 22 From the moment a foreign er crosses into China, the per sonality of Mao Tsetung per vades almost every walking hour.

title: Moses, the Park Builder, Opposes Gateway Recreation Project
description: Robert Moses, who has spent most of his career directing and developing public works projects, opposes President Nixon's proposed Gateway Na tional Recreation Area flanking the entrance to New York harbor.

title: Pleas of Two Objectors
description: Following are portions of statements filed by two young men, one in Massachusetts and one in California, seeking deferment as conscientious objectors on moral and ethical grounds. They indicate the difficulties faced by draft boards now in deciding who should go into the military and who should not. The test is sincerity and depth of conviction.

title: BROOKLYN TRACT GETS PLAN FOR USE
description: After 10 years of indecision and bickering, the Manhattan Beach community of Brooklyn has finally developed a prelim inary plan for the development of 15 acres of federally owned Land for facilities for elderly residents, retarded children and an expanded Kingsborough Community College.city on the condition that the land be used for education, recreation or health facilities.

title: Texas Women Roll 1,235 For 2d in W.I.B.C. Doubles
description: ATLANTA, May 22 (UPI) Mrs. Helen Jones and Mrs. Roberta Billings of Waco, Tex., surged into second place in open division doubles with 1,235 on the nexttolast day in the Women's International Bowling Congress tournament today.

title: SHIELDS'S AILEEN WINS IN REGATTA
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 22 Two collisions on Long Is land Sound today marred the first Yacht Racing Association championship regatta of the season, conducted for a fleet of 76 by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Pennsylvanian Chosen Miss U.S.A.
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 22 (AP)Michele McDonald of Pennsylvania was crowned the most beautiful girl in America tonight at the 20th annual Miss U.S.A. beauty pageant.

title: The key was symmetry
description: The aim of this thoughtful and illuminating study is clear ly set forth in the preface: it is not  A survey of the music of the classical period, but a description of its lan guage. That language is stud ied, not in its runofthemill use, but in its creation, devel opment, and triumphant exploi tation by the three great fig ures of the age. For Rosen free ly admits to holding the old fashioned position that it is in terms of their achievements that the musical vernacular can best be defined.

title: Horse Show News
description: The United States Eques trian Team is in Fountaine bleau, France, today await ing the start of the first show on its 1971 European tour.

title: HIGHRISE FIRES POSE NEW PERILS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 If the increasing numbers of Americans who live and work in highrise buildings remember anything from their schoolday fire drills, they will probably do everything wrong when a fire breaks out. And firemen themselves are not sure how to fight highrise fires.

title: Et Al.
description: A nutritionist with a natural foods bias marshalls evidence that the American diet is be coming bizarre. Mrs. Hunter claims there is an unholy alli ance between scientists on fat (bad pun intended) retainers and the food trade associations that retain them to convince you that almost anything put into food nowadays is good for you. (One such scientist recommends Cokes and corn chips for teenagers' snacks, for instance.) She claims that sta ples, such as meat and milk have lost food value as mass production, agro  industrial methods push for lower costs and higher profits. Some beef cattle are forcefed like Stras bourg geese; feed includes tal low, grease, wood, feathers and a carcinogenic hormone that produces marbled, watery meat. It's a compliment to Mrs. Hunt er to say this is an unappetizing book.

title: NEWAGENCY PLAN DROPS VISTA AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, May 22An internal staffing report indicates that only Peace Corps officials or outsidersand no present, officials of VISTA or other pro gramsare being considered for the principal jobs in Action, the Administration's proposed consolidation of voluntary ac tion agencies.

title: Annual Meeting Season, 1971, Is HoHum Time
description: The corporate annual meeting season peaked out last week with Friday's marathon session of the stockholders of the General Motors Corporation.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: 50,526 ARE ADDED TO STATE CENSUS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Census Bureau has found 50,526 more New York State residents.

title: Movies
description: ZERO MOSTEL, a Harlem tailor in Jan Kadar's The Angel Levine, will be a Canadian junk dealer in the Czech director's second Eng lishlanguage film, The Lies My Father Told Me. Based on an original screen play by Ted Allan, the comedydrama will get under way for producer Harry Gulkin in Montreal next September.

title: Dropped Throw Extends New York Losing Streak
description: CLEVELAND, May 22Steve Dunning, Cleveland's impressive young righthander, extended the Yankees losing streak to five games today with a strong pitching performance and some luck as the Indians won, 21.

title: The Return Of Charles Lindbergh
description: THE clean  shaven, pleasant countenanced man in a khaki shirt open at the throat and slightly rumpled khaki trousers was sitting on a bench in the sweet Hawai ian air and talking with measured seriousness to a small group of con servationists and three reporters. A horseshoe of silverygray hair fringed his head, and a clutch of errant strands was neatly combed over the top of his scalp to cover part of his baldness. His face was lightly tanned and little creased, save for some crow'sfeet at the outer corners of his blue eyes. Speaking in a flat, al most Midwestern voice, he was saying, Up to this time, we have for gener ations concentrated on the use of natural resources; and now, rather suddenly in terms of years, we are confronted with the need of con serving our natural resources.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Churchwomen Who Are Too Busy for Sewing Circles
description: Mrs. Donald Davis of Clin ton, N. J., had her cats try out a new brand of kitty litter to help her church women's group raise funds to send an Indian girl to school.

title: Sarajevo Dooms 19thCentury Locust Trees to Widen Approach to Bridge
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, May 8Four graceful locust trees, 80 years old and nearly as high now as the minaret on the 400yearold All Pasha Mosque they shade, are destined to be the next casualties of Sarajevo's battle with the fu ture.

title: DRIVERS'
description: A drivers' school designed to explore the maneuvering capa bilities of Porsche sports cars will be conducted all day next Saturday at Mitchel Field, L.I. The program is not a racing school, but a course in proper control of the Porsche near its adhesive limit and in emergency situations.

title: MAKING BABIES' PLAY GROUPS WORK
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Married Minister Is Ordained Priest, A First in Portugal
description: LISBON, May 22For the first time in this conservative Roman Catholic country, a married Protestant minister, who has three children, has been ordained a Catholic priest.

title: Richard Lee Jr. Marries Patricia Eliscu
description: BETHESDA, Md., May 22 Miss Patricia Lynn Eliscu, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson J. Eliscu of San Mateo, Calif., and New York, was married here today to Richard J. Lee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee of Cheshire, Conn. The Rev. Richard N. Eick, a Congregational min ister, performed the cere mony at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Martin.

title: The Nation
description: Capitol Hill has become the nation's busiest railroad termi nal. If rail management isn't in Congress seeking money to bail out a bankrupt carrier or under write a coordinated passenger network, the legislators can ex pect to find the nonstop labor woes of the railroads demand ing emergency attention.

title: 2 Star Texas Linemen Are Signed by the Jets
description: Bill Zapalac, a defensive end, and Scott Palmer, a de fensive tackle, were signed yesterday by the New York Jets of the National Football League. Both are from the University of Texas.

title: SOVIETU.S. PARLEY ON SPACE CANCELED
description: HOUSTON, May 22 (Reuters) Technical talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on space cooperation have been indefinitely post poned because Russian special ists are too busy, the space agency has disclosed.

title: New York
description: Many a New Yorker found a letter postmarked Weldon, N. C., in his mailbox last week; it started out with a flourish of candor:

title: Home Improvement
description: BUILDING the decorative wall cabinet shown here is an interesting and reasonably simple woodworking project that can provide the homeowner or apartment dweller with storage space for a variety of miscellaneous items that always seem to be hard to find a place forglass ware, bricabrac, coasters, scarves, sweaters, gloves, hobby supplies, cameras, photo albums and similar small articles that frequently get misplaced or lost inside deep drawers and closets.

title: Education
description: Next to aerospace, no in dustry in America has sunk so rapidly from boom to bust in the past few years as higher education, and the distraught leaders of acade mia have had all too little difficulty tracing the causes of Its declinethe general recession, more intense and varied demands on public funds and private philanthro py, and widespread unhappi ness over campus radicalism.

title: Consultants Turn a Cost Corner
description: After a year of concentrat ing on costcutting jobs for their customers, and doing some of the same for them selves, many of the nation's consulting concerns are re turning to a more traditional mix of choresand taking home fatter pay checks in the bargain.

title: Therese E. Dattola Prospective Bride
description: Mrs. McCarthy Dattola of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Therese Eugenie Dattola to James Arthur Ulmer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ulmer Jr. of Andrews, Tex.

title: About the pain of breaking away from a lover and from an old sense of self
description: The Will to Change is an extraor dinary book of poems and some thing else as well. It has the urgency of a prisoner's journal: patient, la conic, eloquent, as if determined thoughts were set down in stolen moments. It takes risksas Adrienne Rich has been doing in her recent collections, Leaflets (1969) and Necessities of Life (1966)in the name of living through a time/ that needs to be lived through us. There are, of course, polished poems in this book, the kind which will eventually detach themselves into anthologies.

title: Malaga: Beaches, Bulls and Pablo, Too
description: MALAGA, SpainThis bustling Mediterranean portthe Ma laca of the first century B.C. ists who pass through here mainly as the gateway to the sea and sun of Spain's Costa del Sol. All year long, va cationers arrive here by land, sea and air and immediately buzz off for Tor remolinos, Fuengirola, Marbella or any one of dozens of other resorts that line this coast 65 miles northeast of Gibral tar and facing North Africa. Those who tarry here even for a day or two, how ever, discover that Malaga has some resort tricks of its own and is well worth the stopover.

title: Queens Woman Has Treated and Healed Thousands of Crippled Birds
description: It all started about 20 years ago with a oneeyed, whitebreasted nuthatch, who, logically, was named Hatch.

title: World ORT Union Awarded Prize by Swiss Foundation
description: The International Foundation Humanum, sponsored by the Swiss Government, has award ed a cash prize to the World ORT Union, a prominent Jewish international organization, ac cording to word received here.

title: Gilhooley Expected to Head Public Service Buses
description: John J. Gilhooley, a former member of the New York City Transit Authority, is expected to assume tomorrow the post of president and chief executive officer of the Public Service Co ordinated Transport Company, New Jersey's largest bus con cern.

title: Drought, the Worst in 30 Years, Parches Northern Mexico Area
description: MEXICO CITY, May 22The worst drought in 30 years is affecting a vast area of north ern Mexico, causing wide spread damage to the cattle industry and farming and bring ing increased suffering to the inhabitants of the poverty stricken desert region.

title: INTEGRATED BANK DRAWS INVESTORS
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 22 More than $500,000 has been invested in the last five months by hundreds of people here many of them domestics and unskilled laborersin a bank that will be primarily controlled by blacks.

title: CityProgramRefurbishesWilliamsburgTenements
description: Freshly rehabilitated apart ments with green, yellow and beige fronts are replacing for merly rundown tenement units in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Smith's Gazelle
description: This latest by Lionel David son, who can be a hypnotic storyteller (Making Good Again, The Menorah Men'), is a disappointingly tedious ramble through the Israeli des ert in pursuit of the nearly extinct species of the title. A herd of rare gazelle, thought to have been phased out a generation earlier, flourishes in a desert ravine, tended by a mad Bedouin named Hamud. The herdsman feels the beasts have been sent to him as a divine sign; in their service he makes a corner of the desert bloom with alfalfa, radishes, onions and grapes. Two little boys find their way onto the ravine, one an Arab and one a Jew; they submerge their differences in helping Hamud care for his rare herd, until the Six Day War dissipates everything. Yes, here are two men of good will, and a glimpse of Mother Nature abetting a miracle of survivalbut any parabolic significance they may have is lost amid the author's

title: Big Ten Meeting This Week To Seek Reed's Successor
description: IOWA CITY, May 22 (AP) Big Ten athletic leaders will assemble here Monday for a regular spring business meet ing spurred into an emergency session by the death of the conference commissioner, Wil liam R. Reed, last Thursday.

title: Announcements
description: Engagements

title: Mrs. Alford Is Wed To R. D. Coursen
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Mrs. Carolyn Yeaw Alford of Washington and Chatham, Mass., an educational spe cialist with the Bureau of Higher Education in the De partment of Health, Educa tion and Welfare, was married here this afternoon to R. Dennison Coursen, president of Coursen & Co., a consulting firm here. The Rev. Richard Eick performed the ceremony in the Westmoreland Con gregational Church.

title: LETTERS
description: Expected controversy over a proposal to establish a Latin American Regional Fi nance Corporation [New York Times, May 9] reflects a con. tinuing constraint to speed ing up economic advance in most developing countries,. namely, the irresolute coming to terms with the critical im portance of the private enter prise sector.

title: IrishContraceptiveBan Defied by 43 Women
description: DUBLIN, May 22 (AP)  Fortythree women returned to Dublin by train from Bel fast, Northern Ireland, to night, wearing birthcontrol devices. They were defying the 1935 Irish Republic law that bans the importation and sale of them. Contracep tives are legal in Ulster.

title: Miss Kennedy Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Maureen Rose Ken nedy and Thomas Henry Vanderspurt plan to be mar ried here in September.

title: WEST SIDE PUPILS GET BIGGER ROLE
description: We're throwing facts our selves now. Grace Silva proud ly declared during a rap session here reviewing the op eration of Project Y.E.A. in the junior high schools of School District 3, on the Upper West Side.

title: Joe Adonis Is Jailed in Milan While Court Decides on Exile
description: MILAN, Italy, May 22 (AP) Joe Adonis, once the reputed gambling boss of the East Coast, was jailed here today on a preventive custody war rant.

title: Anne Waggoner Married to Student
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 22  Miss Anne Katherine Waggoner and Michael Francis Paulsen were married here this afternoon in the Immaculate Conception Ro man Catholic Church by the Rev. William J. Dowd.

title: INDIA SEEKS HALT IN REFUGEE FLOW
description: NEW DELHI, May 22India has mounted a broad diplomatic and publicity campaign to try to mobilize world pressure on Pakistan to halt the refugee flow from East Pakistan.

title: Miss Elizabeth Hethea Griffis Bride
description: Miss Elizabeth Hethea Griffis was married here yesterday afternoon to Jere miah Milbank 3d, heir to one of the nation's oldest and least publicized fortunes and son of the chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: About Motor Sports
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 Few forms of televised sports have been bombarded as much as auto racing. Racing fans wonder why their sport cannot be covered as well as pro football and other events. The man who stops most of the critics' shots is also the man who knows most of theanswers. To begin with, says Chuck Howard of ABC Sports, in a mo tor race things happen in manyplaces at the same time. Moreover, the action is con tinuous, with no such logical time breaks as there are in football, baseball and boxing.

title: Miss Judith Goldsborough Wed on Coast
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., May 22Miss Judith Drake Golds borough and John Rogers Dunlop were married here to day in an outdoor ceremony on Mount Tamalpais by the Rev. Edward Beggs, an Epis copal priest.

title: Movies; Lionel Stander: Who's Afraid of John Wayne?
description: YOU'RE a 63yearold actor with a double chin, gray hair, a beer belly and a droopy left eyelid. Astonishingly, after two decades of being blacklisted by Hollywood, you've ?? handed the, mealy role of a Mafia chieftain in MGM's comedy, The, Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight. So naturally you do what you're told: you mind your manners, pick up your paycheck, and don't rock the boat. Maybe you even eat a little humble pie, or better still, keep your mouth shut altogether. Maybe, but not if your name is Lionel Stander.

title: 20 HELD IN TUMULT NEAR KENT STATE U.
description: KENT, Ohio, May 22 (AP) Twenty persons, including six Kent State University students, were arrested early today after the fourth straight night of dis turbances at Kent.

title: United Fund Donors Aid 425 Units Here
description: The United Fund of Great er New York is the largest local network of community services in the world. It offers every person who either lives or works in New York the chance to contribute at one time at his place of busi ness, to 425 local health and welfare agencies and the Red Cross. The fund never con ducts housetohouse or neighborhood campaigns. It does, however, seek contri butions from business, trade unions, civil service and em ploye groups.

title: 2 Slain Patrolmen Joined Department on Same Day
description: The two patrolmen who were killed Friday night in Harlem were family men who joined the police force the same Au gust day nearly five years ago after graduating together from the Police Academy.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: RUSSIANSHEAR U.S. BACKS ARMS TALKS
