description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 25Two different ways of looking at an elephant illus trated at an international bank ers' meeting here today some of the basic conflicts between the United States and Europe over the role of the dollar in the monetary system.

title: Policeman Is Slain in Capital; Daughter of Coast Aide Held
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)  The daughter of the City Manager of San Jose, Calif., was charged with first degree murder today, shortly after a policeman was killed and a suspect wounded in a suburban bank robbery.

title: Sterling Beats Rodriguez In 10Round Bout in London
description: LONDON, May 25 (UPI) Bunny Sterling withstood Luis Rodriguez's best head punches to record a 10round decision over the former world welter weight champion tonight.

title: Walker Cup Golf Begins Today in Scotland
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 25A glance at the rec ord books would indicate no contest. Over the 50 years of Walker Cup history, the British golf team has only one victory in. 23 meetings with the United States.

title: Patterson Faces Daniels In Cleveland Bout Tonight
description: CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) Floyd Patterson will fight Ter ry Daniels in the feature heavy weight bout at the Cleveland Arena tomorrow night.

title: Leaders Agree to increase State Aid To Parochial Schools by $33Million
description: ALBANY, May 25Aides of Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leadership have agreed on a formula for extend ing $33million in additional state aid to nonpublic schools, including an extra $5million for innercity needs.

title: Confessions of a Cuban Poet
description: The Cuban poet Heberto Padilla was arrested in Cuba in March and released last month after confessing to wrong doing and wrong thinking. (His treat ment prompted sixty European and American intellectuals to write to Pre mier Fidel Castro to express shame and anger.) The text of Mr. Padilla's con fession was distributed in New York by the Cuhan Mission to the United Nations with the explanation that the poet had admitted to counterrevolu tionary activities and asked for an op portunity to expose and discuss his conduct publicly. This article is ex cerpted from the confession:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: EVERY week, more then 26.000 Jobs ere advertised In The New York Times. Sec the Employment Columns today, Advt.

title: WILLIAM L. GAYA
description: CHATHAM, N.J., May 25 ?? L. Gaya, vice president the Bates Manufacturing company of West Orange, ??anufacturers of adding ma ?? and other office equip ent, died yesterday in Over ?? Hospital, Summit. He was ?? years old and lived here at ?? Runnymede Road.

title: Amtrak Cancels Its Service Between Detroit and Toledo
description: LANSING, Mich., May 25 (UPI) Gov. William G. Milliken said today he had been notified that the proposed DetroittoToledo passenger train originally ap proved by Amtrak had been canceled.

title: Pennsy's Trustees Explain Bank Deal
description: George F. Baker, a trustee of the Penn Central Transpor tation Company, said here yes terday that the trustees wouldn't have thought of giving up the common stock of the Pennsylvania Company, if the banks that are taking the stock hadn't agreed to lend the railroad up to $150million.

title: Benguet Meeting Reset
description: The annual meting of Ben guet Consolidated, Inc., in Ma nila was adjourned yesterday until June 8 for lack of a quor um, a company spokesman said in Washington.

title: Deere & Co. Quarter Net Gains
description: Net income of Deere & Co. rose in the quarter and six month period ended April 30, the company announced yes terday.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Several bullish influences sent grains and soybean futures prices up yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SAIGON ACCEPTS HANOI P.O.W. PLAN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 26The South Vietnamese Government an nounced today that it was ready to accept North Vietnamese conditions for the release of 570 disabled war prisoners from South Vietnamese prison camps.

title: Sack at White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House at 7:26 o'clock tonight.

title: CHRIS CONNOR SINGS STYLIZED PROGRAM
description: Earlier this month, Blossom Dearie retrieved Trude Heller's, Avenue of the Americas at Ninth Street, from 11 years of rock, returning the room to the intimate supperclub aura it had in its prerock days. But al though Miss Dearie's stay was all too brief (she may be back in July), the new policy con tinues, represented now by Chris Connor, who will be there through Sunday.

title: Toyota Granted License To Make Wankel Engine
description: NECKARSULM, West Ger many, May 25 (AP)The Toy ota Motor Company today became the fifth Japanese auto mobile producer to he granted a license to manufacture the rotarypiston Wankel engine, developed in Germany.

title: Jersey Court Acts
description: TRENTON, May 25A state appeals court has overturned a lower court's decision that had ordered a Montclair couple to return their 2yearold adopted daughter to the child's natural parents.

title: ALBANY DRAFTING CITY FISCAL PLAN
description: ALBANY, May 25Governor Rockefeller and Republican leg islative leaders are considering a New York City fiscal package that would consist of about $320million in taxing authority for the city and $150million in new Federal aid, legislative sources reported today.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO DOUBT PENTAGON'S VIEW ON MISSILE THREAT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Senate Republican sources re ported today that the Central Intelligence Agency concluded that at least twothirds of the large new silo holes recently detected in the Soviet Union were intended for the relatively small SS11 intercontinental missile and not for a large new weapon as the Defense Depart ment has suggested.

title: Bridge: Precision Bidding Explained In Forthcoming Goren Book
description: The increasing number of players who have been im pressed in recent years by the virtues of a system based on a strong oneclub bid will welcome the publication next week of Charles Goren's book The Precision System of Contract Bridge Bidding. The publisher is Doubleday and the price is $5.95.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Assail Udall on Power Project
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov., May 25 Legal representatives of South western Indians told a Con gressional committee today that the Secretary of the In terior and the Bureau of Indiana Affairs had violated their offi cial responsibilities in approv ing Indian collaboration in a big regional electric power development.

title: Transit Needs Stressed Here at Convention
description: Aerospace technologists were told yesterday that they must come out of the clouds and understand political con siderations, city finances, la bor problems and human relations before they can help the nation's cities solve their transportation needs.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received yesterday $21.8million in additions to two existing Navy contracts for nuclear ship reactor com ponents.

title: Stanley Tananbaum to Head Track
description: YONKERS, May 25Stan ley Tananbaum of Harrison, N. Y., was named today to succeed his late brother, Mar tin, as president of Yonkers Raceway. The track's board of directors also announced the election of Sidney Roth of Manhattan as vice presi dent and Murray Nadler of Lido Beach, L. I., as secre tary.

title: JAPAN'S TRADE ROLE IN U.S. DOWNGRADED
description: Charges that Japan is taking over American markets, espe cially in textiles, were called sheer myth yesterday by No buhiko Ushiha, Japanese Am bassador to the United States.

title: Roundup: Rookie Is Reds' New Stopper
description: Add Ross Grimsley's name to those of Gary Nolan, Wayne Simpson and Don Gullett among outstanding rookie pitchers the Cincin nati Reds' Farm system has produced in recent seasons.

title: Police Report No Suspect In Slayings of Patrolmen
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that people are being questioned who have direct or indirect re lation to the crime in the staying of two policemen last Friday.

title: Western Union Radio Link
description: The Western Union Tele graph Company said yesterday it is building a 30mile micro wave radio link between Mid dletown, Va., and Romney, W. Va., as a connection for a major computer complex near ing completion in Virginia with the existing Western Union transcontinental transmission network.

title: Adjournment in Albany May Come Next Week
description: ALBANY, May 25 The Legislature today appeared to be lurching rather than rush ing toward adjournment and, as a result, legislative leaders raised the possibility that the session could extend into next week.

title: Legislature Retains Admission Tests for City's Four Specialized High Schools
description: ALBANY, May 25Without debate, the Senate and the As sembly gave final legislative ap proval today to a bill designed to limit the New York City Board of Education's power to alter the city's four specialized high schools.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
1 of 5 Men Said to Favor Violence to Effect Change
description: One out of every five Ameri can men questioned in a na tionwide survey said he be lieved some degree of iolence was necessary to produce need ed social change in this coun try.

title: Danger in the Sea
description: There was little public reaction several weeks ago the Food and Drug Administration warning against eat ing swordfish. Apparently many people cannot or do not wish to believe that the relatively high mercury content of swordfish makes it a health hazard.

title: Ballet: Two Premieres Presented by the Stuttgart
description: If the Stuttgart Ballet were the Bolshoi Ballet, Its new program last night at the Metropolitan Opera House would have unabashedly been called Highlights, Cautious ly and more suitably, most of it went under the heading of Divertissements.

title: Stocks on Amex Continue to Decline
description: Prices moved lower on the American Stock Exchange yesterday for the third consec utive session in steppedup trading.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaUnited States policy in Africa faces the pos sibility of serious embarrassment be fore the year ends when, as is ex pected, Britain ceases to participate in the United Nations boycott of Rho desia. This autumn the Heath Govern ment in London must decide whether to renew its role in the U.N. blockade and the answer is forecast as negative.

title: xon Sends Condolences To the Family of Dodd
description: OLD LYME, Conn., May 25 (UPI)Messages of condolence, cluding one from President xon, were received today by e family of former Senator ??omas J. Dodd.

title: Merger of VISTA Is Backed by the House
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 President Nixon's plan to merge the Peace Corps, VISTA and other voluntary action agencies was approved today by the House and a key Senate com mittee.

title: Generals Rescued
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 26 (AP) Enemy soldiers shot down a helicopter carrying two allied generals yesterday, but the of Ificers were rescued uninjured.

title: House Unit Cites Rise in G.I. Drug Use
description: WASHINGTON, May 25A Congressional study mission re ported today that heroin addic tion had become so great a problem among American serv icemen in Southeast Asia that its only effective solution was the withdrawal of all troops from the area.

title: Addis Ababa Halts Buseds
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 25 (Reuters)Public buses the main target for rioting students over the last six days were withdrawn from service today, leaving the capital with out public transport. About 120,000 passengers were strand ed in the city.

title: U.S. Monetary Reserves Decline
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The United States suffered a relatively small $35million loss of international mone tary reserves in April, all of it in gold, the treasury re ported today.

title: Friend of Laird Expected To Be Named Army Chief
description: WSHINGTON, May 25 (AP) President Nixon is expected to nominate Robert F. Froehlke, an Assistant Secretary of Defense and a boyhood friend of Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, as Secretary of he Army, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Earthquake Experts Urge Worldwide Effort to Help Curb Damage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 Earthquake experts from 28 nations met here this week and drew up a series of recommen dations that they hope will save lives, minimize property dam age and bring immediate relief to earthquake victims.

title: City Charges Some Sanitationmen Charge for Collecting Trash
description: New York City charged in State Supreme Court yesterday that some sanitation workers had been regularly taking fees for collecting trash from com mercial establishments in Man hattan in violation of Sanitation Department regulations.

title: Potential Called Vast for Gains in Medicine
description: A practicing surgeon told a group of aerospace engineers yesterday that there was a great potential for new tech nology in medicine, but that there was an even greater potential for its failure in solving problems of health care.

title: Two Returning Americans Cite Big Change in Chinese Science
description: Chinese science has been radically altered in the last few years, according to two Ameri can professors who returned from China yesterday.

title: Lions Say They'll Move
description: DETROIT, May 25 (UPI) The Detroit Lions reaffirmed today their decision to move to Pontiac amid reports that a proposed 80,000seat domed stadium in Pontiac would cost $50million instead of $38 million.

title: Scientists' Group Sues A. E. C. For Data on NewType Reactor
description: A national organization of scientists, tin an effort to stir public debate, filed suit yester day aimed at forcing the Atomic Energy Commission to disclose information on the po tential environment impact of a new type of nuclear reactor that is under development.

title: Man In the News
description: Gustav Husak, whose ac cession to the leadership of Czechoslovakia's Communist party marked the end of the country's springtime of re form, is defended by some Czechoslovaks as the greatest Schweik of alla hopeful ref erence to the good soldier who befuddled another set of overlords by his own brand of com pliance. No one is prepared to sug gest that Mr. Hu sak sees himself in the role, but there were some phrases in the speech he made yesterday as the party's First Secretary that did recall Schweik, the hero of the Jaroslav Hasek novel whose innocent gratitude for his mistreatment ultimately undermined the officialdom of the AustroHungarian em pire.

title: Democrats Charge RentControl Deal
description: ALBANY, May 25Republi can legislators have combined an upstate rentcontrol exten sion bill with another bill end ing rent controls in New York City in what Democrats charged today was an effort to break up a coalition threatening to block decontrol in the city.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANCIENT HISTORY. A Paraphrase. By Joseph McElroy. 307 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Home Mortgage Rates Up
description: Interest rates on home mort gages jumped almost half percentage point in the biweek ly auction of the Federal Na tional Mortgage Association, the company announced yes terday.

title: YEAR'S RESIDENCY FOR RELIEF WINS ALBANY PASSAGE
description: ALBANY, May 25After al most four hours of heated ar gument, the Senate late today passed 32 to 21 and sent to Governor Rockefeller the bill he sponsored to establish a one year residency requirement be fore a person could be eligible for welfare assistance.

title: ALLENDE OPPOSES NIXON OVER ARMS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 25 President Salvador Allende Gos sens said today that the Chilean Government does not view with satisfaction the proposal by President Nixon to increase the level of arms sales to Latin America.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Five manufacturers of sports cars and production sedans have posted more than $200,000 in awards for drivers in 11 classes of com petition in the 1971 national championships of the Sports Car Club of America. Prizes will be based on finishes in first, second and third places; the exact total therefore will not be determined un til the end of the season. The man ufacturers' as sistance programs also in clude free components in certain cases or parts and equipment at discounted prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking Beirut Students Act
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25 (Reuters)Hundreds of strik ing students took over two more buildings today in their occupation of the American University of Beirut. They have been striking since May 13 against a 10 per cent increase in tuition fees for the 197172 academic year.

title: China Resumes Rebuilding Regional Party Machinery
description: HONG KONG, May 25  The reconstruction of the Chinese Communist party's regional ma chinery has resumed after al break of about a month. It seems likely to be completed by July 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Joseph B. Milgram (letter May 7) requests that the proponents of U.S. withdrawal from Indochina ask them selves what North Vietnam is doing in those sovereign nations and why they do not withdraw. It is implied that only their withdrawal should signal our own.

title: Husak Lauds '68 Invasion As Prague Congress Opens
description: PRAGUE, May 25  Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak Communist party leader, opened the longdelayed 14th Con gress of his party today with praise for the invasion of his country by Warsaw Pact na tions in August, 1968.

title: William Schweitzer, Marksman, Director of KimberlyClark, 70
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., May 25William P. Schweitzer, a director of the KimberlyClark Corporation and one of the world's leading marksmen, died yesterday in Monmouth Medical Center here after a long illness. He was 70 years old and had homes at Colts Neck and at Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Virginia Assembly to Meet On Redistricting June 3
description: RICHMOND, May 25 (AP) Gov. Linwood Holton today called the General Assembly to resume its recessed session June 3 to repair the state's legislative reapportionment leg islation.

title: Cincinnati Bank Expects WriteOff of Loan Loss
description: William N. Liggett, president of the First National Bank of Cincinnati, said in a letter to shareholders that the bank ex pects a charge against operat ing income in the first half of about $7.7million.

title: Conferees Vote $2Billion Public Works Project
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Ignoring threats of a Presi dential veto, House and Senate conferees agreed today on a Democraticsponsored bill that would authorize a $2billion public works program to help combat unemployment.

title: 2 Charged With Separate Attempts to Kill Patrolmen
description: A clergyman and a towtruck operator were arrested yester day on separate charges of at tempting to murder policemen in Brooklyn.

title: Mets Subdue Phils in 12th Inning, 54
description: The New York Mets, wh?? seem to be working overtime this year on their flair fo?? drama, went 12 innings at She Stadium last night to defeat th?? Philadelphia Phillies, 54.

title: ROBERT C. MILLAR
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 25 (AP)Robert C. Millar, re tired president and general manager of the Florida Publish ing Company, died at his home near here yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Woman's Bid to Renounce Citizenship Is Denied
description: A 48yearold woman has tried unsuccessfully to lose her United. State citizenship so that she might gain a European es tate amounting to millions of dollars.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN THE SEALE CASE; PUBLICITY CITED
description: NEW HAVEN, May 25The judge in the murderkidnapping case of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins dismissed all charges against them today, saying that massive publicity about their aborted trial had made it too difficult to try them again.

title: Theater: Ride a Black Horse Opens at St. Marks
description: The black middleclass lib eral on talking terms with his white neighbors and col leagues is not exactly a new villain for black nationalism, but he is the one black playwrights seem to be tak ing more and more interest in nowadays. The final play of the present season by the Negro Ensemble Company, is a case in point. It is John Scott's Ride a Black Horse, which opened last night at the St. Marks Playhouse.

title: City Utilities Aide Denounces Power Rationing
description: New York City's chief utilities planner yesterday denounced an interim state report that has proposed, among other moves, that major industrial, office and store buildings in New York City be cut off from elec tricity for entire days to avoid repeated blackouts of wider areas.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Internatonal Busi ness Machines Corpora tion has elected Patricia Roberts Harris, a Wash ington lawyer, to the hoard of directors. Mrs. Wirris, who is a partner in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Kampelman, recently was also made a direc tor of the Scott Paper Company. Mrs. Harris was formerly a member of the faculty of the Howard University Law School and served as United States Ambassa dor to Luxembourg dur ing former President Johnson's Administra tion. After beginning her legal career with the United States Department Justice in the criminal division, she joined Howard's law faculty in 1961. She became Ambassador in 1965.

title: TIGERS TRIUMPH OVER YANKS, 74, FOR 7TH IN ROW
description: DETROIT, May 25  Lindy McDaniel, the former stalwart of the Yankee bull pen, again had all the effectiveness of batting practice pitcher as the Tigers rallied for 74 victory over New York tonight in the opener of a threegame series at Tiger Stadium.

title: Ken Tatum to Have Surgery
description: BOSTON, May 25 (AP)Ken Tatum of the Boston Red Sox, who suffered a fractured cheek bone when struck by a line drive in batting practice at Baltimore on Sunday, will un dergo surgery tomorrow.

title: Results of Retailers Are Mixed;
description: Results were mixed in retail financial reports for the April quarter released yesterday, with Gimbel Brothers, Inc., re porting a 43.7 per cent decline in its net income from the year before.

title: Arts Council Parley Studying Role of Government
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The theme of the annual con ference of the Associated Councils of the Arts this year is Washington and the Arts, and the Federal Gov ernment is playing a dom inant role in the three days of deliberations.

title: REALTORS FACING ACTION ON RIGHTS
description: The city's Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that it had failed in its eight month campaign to persuade the Real Estate Board of New York and the realestate indus try in general to change its standard policy of deliberate and malicious discrimination against minority groups.

title: Brown, Mayor's Man in Albany, Serves Legislators in Serving City
description: ALBANY  When Assem blyman Alexander Chananau, a Bronx organization Demo crat, has a problem in his FordhamTremont district in volving the city bureaucracy, he usually turns to Richard A. Brown, a short, friendly dynamo who represents Mayor Lindsay in Albany.

title: Vote on Draftees' War Duty
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate rejected, 52 to 21, today an amendment by Senator Gay lord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, to a bill extending the draft law, to bar sending draftees to Vietnam unless they volunteer:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent editorial Phantom Pen sions in Industry properly warns that only a minority of plan participants can expect benefits. In all likelihood the massive layoffs caused by defense cutbacks and the recession are causing pension credit losses far beyond the expectations of plan designers.

title: No Deal Involved
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 26State Department of ficials said that there was no deal involved in the release. They said, they hoped, but had no reason to believe, that Hanoi would proceed to release Amer ican prisoners.

title: SUSPECT IN MURDER ARRESTED IN TURKEY
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 25 (AP)  Justice Minister Ismail Arar announced today the ar rest of a 24yearold economics student and said that he was a prime suspect in the kidnapping and murder of the Israeli Con sul General, Efraim Elrom.

title: PODGORNY NAILED ON VISIT TO CAIRO
description: CAIRO, May 25President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the So viet Union was received with smiles, a warm embrace and kisses today by President Anwar elSadat as he arrived for cru cial talks on the state of Soviet Egyptian relations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STORES' AID ASKED ON CONSUMERISM
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. May 25 A major split in industry re action to the consumer move ment has developed in the last year, Ralph Nader asserted at a convention of discount retail ers here today.

title: Justice for Jerusalem
description: Last March, talking to the multitude in St. Peter's Square, Pope Paul spoke of the recognition of the extraordi nary requirements of the Holy Places in Israel and of a pluralism of his toric and religious rights converging in Jerusalem. He did not, as alleged, call for its internationalization.

title: From Dakto to Detroit: Death of a Troubled Hero
description: DETROIT, May 25A few tenants living in the E. J. Jefferies Homes, a dreary public housing project in Corktown, an old Detroit neighborhood, can still re member Dwight Johnson as a little boy who lived in one of the rustbrown buildings with his mother and baby brother. They think it strange, after all that has happened to Dwight, to remember him as a gentle boy who hated to fight.

title: A Correction
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Through an error in transmis sion, an article on a Govern ment jobs program for unem ployed aerospace and defense industry professionals in yes terday's New York Times in correctly listed the maximum relocation allowance as $11,200. The correct figure is $1,200.

title: Pentagon Refuses to Give Lockheed Data to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)A Pentagon official re fused today to give Congress any details of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's financial condition either before or after the House and Senate act on an Administration request to grant the concern a $250mil lion loan guarantee.

title: Convicted Jews Said to Testify in Riga
description: MOSCOW, May 25Wit nesses at the trial in Riga of four Zionist Jews were re ported today to have testified that the defendants had re printed and distributed Israeli pamphlets and publications judged by the Soviet authorities to be subversive.

title: Rare Antelope Damaging Soviet Grain
description: MOSCOW, May 25  A rare animal species, the Saiga ante lope, has been so well pre served by Soviet game laws that its growing herds have been invading wheat lands, causing wide damage.

title: Crowds in Alabama Give Nixon Warm Welcome
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 25 President Nixon toured the heart of George Wallace coun try today, calling for unity and cooperation between the races and receiving, in the process, a warm welcome that may well rekindle his hopes of capturing heavier Southern support in 1972.

title: MARION L. ANDERSEN
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., May 25 Mrs. Marion Lineaweaver Andersen of Tower Hill, a poet, died yesterday in Martha's Vine yard Hospital after a short ill ness. She was 59 years old, the wife of Earle O. Andersen.

title: The Silent Palestinians
description: Secretary of State Rogers's effort to promote a disen gagement along the Suez Canal as a first step toward a Middle East settlement has tended to divert attention from other key issues in the ArabIsraeli dispute. One of these concerns the future of twoandahalfmillion restive Palestinians. The Palestinian cause has also been eclipsed lately by the defeat and dispersal of Palestinian guerrilla forces in Jordan and because of deep divisions within the Palestinian leadership.

title: Steel Industry Cites Profit Plunge in a Report to U.S.
description: The American steel industry has told Vice President Agnew and the Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy that recent sharp declines in steel earnings had already had an adverse effect on the credit rating of at least one major steel com pany.

title: VOTE LAW POLICY STIFFENED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 The Justice Department has re versed itself and decided hence forth to block the enactment of all new election laws in the South unless the states can prove that the statutes do not foster racial discrimination.

title: Miner Hot Line Begun
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Bureau of Mines an nounced today a hot line tele phone on which coal miners can report violations of health and safety regulations at any hour. The bureau said the miner would call collect, his complaint would be recorded, and a bu reau official would act on the information the next working day.

title: Utilities in East and Midwest Step Up NuclearFuel Orders
description: Utilities in the East and Mid dle West stepped up their or dering of nuclear fuel yester day.

title: STERLING E. GRAHAM OF CLEVELAND PAPER
description: CLEVELAND, May 25 CAP) Sterling E. Graham, a retired president of the Forest City Publishing Company and for mer publisher of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, died last night in his Shaker Heights home. He was 79 years old.

title: Kennedy Center Gets France's Gift of Art
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)France formally pre sented two tapestries by Henri Matisse and two sculp tures by Henry Laurens yes terday to the Jahn F. Ken nedy Center for the Per forming Arts.

title: CLEANWATER ACT HELD INSUFFICIENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Congress was told by the Con troller General today that Fed eral enforcement procedures against water polluters were generally slow and cumber some.

title: E. CHESTER GERSTEN OF BANKERS TRUST
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., May 25 E. Chester Gersten, vice chair man of the board of the Bank ers Trust Company of New York, died here yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, after a short illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 205 Midland Avenue.

title: Riessen and Froehling Advance To 2d Round of French Tennis
description: PARIS, May 25 (UPI)  Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., Iraced through his firstround match in the $95,000 French open tennis tournament today, routing Sergio Palmieri of Italy, 75, 61, 61.

title: Disaster Plan for Power
description: A sharp warning that New York City cannot hope to survive without drastic economies in the use of elec tricity marks the study just completed by William K. Jones of the State Public Service Commission. It is by far the gloomiest of all the dismal analyses of the city's power crisis with which New Yorkers have been deluged since the catastrophic blackout of November 1965.

title: 5,000 Policemen From Many Cities Attend Rites Here
description: More than 5,000 policemen, including groups from 45 cities around the country, gathered here yesterday for the funeral of Patrolman Waverly M. Jones, who was shot in the back while on duty Friday,

title: Nixon Reorganization Plan Defended
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Senate Government Operations Committee opened hearings to day on President Nixon's gov ernment reorganization plan. The mood was one of genial skepticism.

title: Stafford to Attend Exhibit
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (Reu ters)Col. Thomas P. Stafford of the Air Force, the Gemini and Apollo astronaut, will he the official representative or the United States at Belgrade's Cosmos International Exhibi tional Space Exhibition, it was announced today. Colonel Staf ford will participate at the America Day activities at the fair on July 4

title: BELGIAN BIDS BLOC ADMIT BRITAIN SOON
description: BRUSSELS, May 25Premier Gaston Eyskens of Belgium asked today for quick admis sion of Britain into the Com mon Market lest British public opinion exert too much adverse pressure on Parliament.

title: GRENADE EXPLOSIONS SPUR KOREA INQUIRY
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 25 (Reuters)The United States Army offered a $1,000 reward today for information on the disappearance of 68 grenades at a unit near here.

title: Tolan's Heel Operated On
description: CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP) Bobby. Tolan, Cincinnati Reds outfielder, was reported in good condition today following sur gery to correct a reinjured Achilles tendon. Dr. George Ballou, team physician, said Tolan would remain in a long cast for four weeks. Tolan suf fered the original injury Jan. 7 playing basketball and rein jured the heel jogging earlier this month.

title: Soviet SST, in Its First Flight to the West, Arrives in Paris for Air Show
description: PARIS, May 25The Soviet supersonic airliner, the TU144, dipped its delta wings over Le Bourget Airport today and landed gracefully on its maiden flight to the West.

title: Stage: Buechner's Woyzeck Surf aces
description: In the past two months I have been fortunate enough to see two productions of Woyzeck, but I have still not seen Woyzeck, at least not the Woyzeck one imag ines.

title: Advertising:
description: It'll be two magazines for the price of one, said Ray Forenza with the kind of enthusiasm one expects from a space salesman.

title: PAUL ANKA MARKS 15 YEARS ON STAGE
description: Fifteen years is not very long in a show business ca reer (where was George Jes se! 15 years ago? Vietnam or Korea?) But when you are 29 and you have been in show business for 15 years, it must seem like a long time.

title: Lieutenant Governor Kentucky Victor
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25 Lieut. Gov, Wendell Ford won an apparently easy victory to night over a former Governor, Bert T. Combs, in the Demo cratic gubernatorial primary.

title: Pleased by Backing on U.N. Seat, Peking Offers Diplomatic Ties, but Malaysia Is Moving Cautiously
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 25Communist China has responded to Malaysia's sup port for its seating in the United Nations by urging Mal aysia to open diplomatic rela tions.

title: BELLE OPPOSES OFFTRACK BETTING FOR PRO FOOTBALL
description: Pete Rozelle, the commission er of the National Football League, came out against off track betting for pro football yesterday. He came out strong ly.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS BUDGET RUMORS
description: Mayor Lindsay, charging that he was being shut out of the Albany discussions that will de termine the size of next year's city budget, called reporters into his office yesterday to com ment on an Albany rumor that he had heard from another re porter.

title: HarvardM.I.T. Arms Experts Pleased by Nixon's Move on Talks
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26 The Charles River Gang a disarming band of Harvard and M.I.T. professors who run an armscontrol operation that stretches right into the White Househave found themselves pleasantly disarmed by Presi dent Nixon.

title: STEEL PRICE RISES ARE SET IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, May 26 (UPI) The Steel Company of Canada, the nation's leading steel pro ducer, announced today price increases that could increase the cost of cars and appliances.

title: China Expert Sees Chance to End War
description: WASHINGTON, May 26An academic specialist in Chinese affairs told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that recent changes in China's foreign policy offered the United States an opportunity for a genuine, face6saving res olution of the Indochina war.

title: MEANY DENOUNCES ECONOMIC POLICY
description: George Meany, president of the A. F. L.C. I. O., warned the Nixon Administration yes terday against any move to interfere with the collective bargaining process in critical negotiations that lie ahead.

title: Reserve Official Favors Paying Bills Through Savings Accounts
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 26A governor of the Federal Reserve Board has swung his weight behind a pro posal that would enable Ameri cans to use their savings ac counts for automatic payment of household bills.

title: Arrest in Turkey Denied
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 26 (Reuters)  The martiallaw command denied today that a suspect in the kidnapping and murder of Efraim Elrom, the Israeli Consul General, had been arrested, as announced yester day by Justice Minister Ismail Arar.

title: Kenneth Royall of Truman Cabinet Dies
description: DURHAM, N.C., May 26 (AP) Kenneth C. Royall, the last United States Secretary of War and the first Secretary of the Army, died Tuesday night in a hospital here, where he had been for five weeks. He was 76 years old.

title: Father and Son Win $1Million in Jersey
description: MAYS LANDING, N. J., May 26 (AP)Alfred E. Moon and his son, David C., both of Mercerville, won $1million today in the New Jersey lot tery.

title: STOCKS END MIXED AS TRADING EASES
description: The stock market ended al most where it started yesterday as advances outnumbered de clines by a slight margin, but leading market averages fin ished with small Tosses.

title: Corruption and 'The Cop':Boisset Work Opens at Cinema Rendezvous
description: Despite a certain exploitable political notoriety (alleged suppression and then censorship by the French Government, which would seem to scare too easily), Yves Boisset's "The Cop," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous, is in fact a routine revenge melodrama notable mostly for the predictability of its episodes and the frequency with which those episodes fail to follow one another in meaningful or even logical sequence.Cops are of course involved, and one does tend to exceed one's office by killing deserving thugs for personal vendetta but the idea is completely traditional, and it used to be treated with more passion, intelligence and courage in American movies 20 years ago.Boisset's cop begins his plunge when a young colleague is killed by a gunman, one of a pair who have just assassinated an underworld chieftain, a real rat, who may have a finger in the police department. The Cop, Inspector Favenin, has been absolutely straight, but he goes quietly obsessional in hunting and eliminating the killer of his pal. In this he is a parallel of the other gunman, Dan (John Garko), also seeking revengefor his best friend, for his best friend's sister, and ultimately for the victim of Favenin.In the moral system of "The Cop" there are good crooks and bad crooks, but cops are neither good nor bad but only, for one reason or another, subject to corruption. Favenin is corrupted by his feelings; Dan, however, is ennobled by histhough both men pursue analogous courses of action to comparable goals and between them they leave the world a better, if considerably emptier place, by the end.Because its cops are such sealed creatures, working in dark suits in dark places and enclosed rooms (Dan, on the other hand, has a place in the country and lots of horses) they have the potential for a kind of interest that the film never wholly realizes but that it does recognize by observing them in a program of tense profile close-ups that look like serious style and that must go back, for antecedents, at least to Hitchcock's "Blackmail" (1929).With little going for him, with scarcely a clue for a characterization, Michel Bouquet does wonders in sustaining and intensifying his Inspector Favenin. Bouquet ("The Bride Wore Black," "La Femme Infidele") is surely one of the ornaments of the current French cinema, and although the movie doesn't really allow for a great performance, so long as he is on screen, "The Cop" seems almost good.

title: Opposition to Appointment Of Watson as Judge Rises
description: WASHINGTON. May 26  Opposition appeared to be building today to the possible Presidential appointment of Al bert S. Watson, former Repub lican Representative from South Carolina, to the Court of Mil itary Appeals.

title: Pentagon Says the Soviet May Have 2 New ICBM's
description: WASHINGTON, May 26De fense Department officials said today that the 60 new missile silos detected in the Soviet Union recently might be in tended for two new types of intercontinental missiles rather than one, as suggested earlier.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: For many years I have pondered the rationale for antitrust legislation. The recent Penn Central crisis and the current Lockheed disaster a satisfying basis for more vigorous antitrust activity: No single private enterprise should be so large that its justifiable demise endangers the na tion's economy.

title: ' When Eight Bells, Toll,' Melodrama by MacLean:Anthony Hopkins Stars in Adventure Tale
description: Yesterday I learned something: there is a certain kind of movie that is best seen from the middle, which is the way that fate (and the opening of several other films on the same day) dictated that I see "When Eight Bells Toll," the newest and possibly the silliest action melodrama yet written by Alistair MacLean, the author of "The Guns of Navarone" and "Where Eagles Dare."The film, which opened at the Penthouse and a number of other theaters around town, is a handsome, technically elaborate movie variation on a plot that you may have first encountered at the age of 8 in one of the early adventures of Tom Swift or the Hardy Boys  the one about ships carrying gold bullion disappearing at sea without a trace."When Eight Bells Toll" has to do with a secret cove on the coast of Scotland, a band of cutthroats who really do cut throats, an adventuress with a foreign accent, and a British Admiralty sleuth who spends a good deal of his time in a wetsuit scaling anchor chains, sheer cliff faces, the villains and the adventuress.By entering such a film in the middle, one is immediately relieved of a number of burdens. The plot makes no sense whatsoever, and thus it is impossible to identify with anyone in particular. Like the frontier wife who, according to Abraham Lincoln, came out of her cabin one day to find her husband in mortal combat with a bear, we carry impartiality to its outer limits. We urge: "Go it, man. Go it, bear." The action of the filmincluding helicopter crashes, pursuits at sea, underwater explorations of sunken shipsbecomes so unattached to emotional need, so pure, so abstract, that it can be enjoyed in the manner of a wild but well-turned syllogism.Unfortunately, I made the mistake of staying over to see the film from the beginning. When it is watched in some sort of rational sequence, the movie collapses in a heap of failed attempts to be both plausible and stylishthe first being beyond Mr. MacLean's interest, and the second being beyond the talents of Etienne Perier, a director whose every shot and cut is predictable.The cast includes Anthony Hopkins, as the frogman who has the distinctive good looks of an Argosy illustration, and Nathalie Delon, whose performance, as the adventuress, evokes all the mystery and enchantment of Bella Darvi's performance as the physicist in Samuel Fuller's "Hell and High Water."

title: Personal Finance
description: The widespread and ever increasing coverage of work ers by group life insurance has caused a problem that many middleaged persons should worry about. A gap in financial planning occurs when a person retires at age 65 and finds that his group life coverage either ends, drops sharply, or must be converted at high premiums to straight life.

title: YANKS' 2RUN 8TH HALTS TIGERS, 21, FOR SIOILEMYRE
description: DETROIT, May 26  Mel Stottlemyre and Roy White, two of the Yankees' most valu able and dependable perform ers, combined their talents to night to produce a 21 victory over the Tigers, ending De troit's sevengame winning streak at Tiger Stadium.

title: Stronger Fight on Job Bias
description: A formidable array of antidiscrimination laws, court orders and plansboth Governmentenforced and volun taryhas brought only modest progress toward eradicat ing employment bias in the once lilywhite construction trades. That progress may be speeded considerably by the decision of Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel requiring a New York metal lathers' union to give com pensatory pay to blacks shut out of jobs by its discrimi natory practices.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: In Bleak Glasgow, Unemployment Is Reaching Its Highest Level Since Depression
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 18At the unemployment of fice on Muirhouse Street, the men sit on benches in silence. They light cigarettes and stare at the posters on the wall that say: Careers in the fire service... Join the Royal Navy.

title: WOMAN IN DRUG CASE GETS 20 YEARS TO LIFE
description: Mrs. Dollree Mapp, the de fendant in a criminal case that resulted in a 1961 landmark decision of the United States Supreme Court barring the ad mission of evidence seized without a warrant, was sen tenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Paul Balsam to 20 years to life for the illegal possession of heroin.

title: The Price of Clean Water
description: The alarming state of American watersdramatized every few weeks by some new crisis in the way of poisonous fish or a dying lakedemands stronger legis lation than any the country has yet had. Of the three water pollution control bills now before Congress, the Administration's would authorize $6 billion for treat ment facilities over a threeyear period; Senator Muskie of Maine calls for $12.5 billion in Federal funds over five years; and Representative Dingell of Michigan proposes a fiveyear program at $5 billion a year. The Dingell bill would reimburse the states for funds already advanced, freeing them to take on fresh obligations, as well finance the major share of projects still needed to bring all navigable waterways up to present quality standards.

title: Patterson Decisively Outpoints Daniels in Cleveland 10Rounder
description: CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP) Floyd Patterson, former heavy weight champion, gained a unanimous decision tonight over Terry Daniels of Dallas in a 10round bout at the Cleve land arena.

title: COSMOS DEFEATED BY ITALIANS 63
description: Lanerossi Vicenza, a First Division soccer team from Italy, had difficulty getting under way for a tour of eight United States cities, but in the first stop at Yankee Stadium last night it had only minor problems in de feating the New York Cosmos, 53, before 4,100 fans, the larg est crowd to watch the two monthold Cosmos.

title: 2 PANEL CHAIRMEN WARN OF VIOLENCE
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 The nation faces the pos sibilities of racial war and of becoming a lawlessly repres sive police state, the chairmen of two Presidential study com missions testified today at a Senate subcommittee hearing.There are arsenals, being built up by the extreme right and extreme left, said Milton S. Eisenhower, who was chairman of President John son's Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence. If trouble breaks out, Mr. Eisen hower warned, it could be devastating.

title: Nationalist China Cites Trade Advantages
description: Nationalist China's Minister for Economic Affairs, Yunsuan Sun, asserted yesterday that his country offers larger, more cer tain business for America than does Communist China.

title: ABORTION AGENCY IS GRANTED STAY
description: The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division granted a stay yesterday of a lower court's order that would have closed the Abortion Information Agency, Inc.

title: ALCOA SUED BY U.S. ON SUPPLIER PACTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI)  The Justice Depart ment filed a civil antitrust suit today accusing the Aluminum Company of America, the na tion's largest producer of alum inum, of illegal reciprocal agree ments.

title: HAVANA SAYS POET ASSAILS DEFENDERS
description: MIAMI, May 26 (AP)The Havana radio said today that Heberto Padilla, the awardwin ning Cuban poet who was jailed and then confessed to antirevo lutionary crimes, has attacked 60 foreign intellectuals who came to his defense, calling them cynical enemies of so cialism.

title: 20 Women Teachers Accuse City U. of Sex Prejudice in Jobs
description: Sex discrimination was charged to the Board of Higher Education yesterday by 20 women teachers who were brought to a City Hall news conference by Councilman Carol Greitzer.

title: Italy's Exiled Mafiosi Suspects Are Unwanted Guests on Islands
description: ROME, May 26Wanted small Italian island without directdialing telephones and with landlords willing to let rooms to suspected Mafiosi on a yearround basis.

title: Serkin Cancels Series
description: Rudolf Serkin has canceled the four recitals of Beethoven piano sonatas scheduled for Carnegie Hall next season. The pianist played four Beethoven programs there during the sea son just ended and was expect ed to complete the cycle of 32 sonatas in a 197172 series. He was forced by illness to cancel a recent recital tour, but has resumed playing and will ful fill all his engagements for next year except the Beethoven series.

title: SADAT INDICATES A SOVIET ACCORD
description: CAIRO, May 26Both Egypt and the Soviet Union empha sized the positive today as talks began between President Anwar elSadat and President Nikolai V. Podgorny.

title: United Presbyterians End Assembly on 10th Day
description: ROCHESTER, May 26  The United Presbyterian Church end ed its general assembly here this afternoon after making signifi cant decisions in the areas of the women's liberation move ment, civil rights and Protestant unity.

title: UTILITY ASSAYS PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The Southern Company ex pects earnings this year in the range of $1.78 to. $1.83 a share, Alvin W. Vogtle Jr., president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting at Macon, Ga. He based his esti mate on the possibility of no further rate increases being ap proved this year. The com pany's 1970 share earnings reached $1.94 on fewer shares outstanding.

title: LOCKHEED DEFICIT WIDENED IN YEAR
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corpo ration yesterday reported 1970 loss of $86,282,000. This compared with a $32,642,000 loss in 1969.

title: Elderly Plan Capital Rally
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) More than 2,000 elderly Americans will rally here June 10 to 12 to attract national at tention to the problems of the retired generation, the National Council of Senior Citizens an nounced today.

title: APPEAL MADE ON AID TO U.N. CYPRUS FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 26The United States and Britain warned the Security Council today that they must have greater cooperation from other members if they are to continue their heavy contribu tions to finance the peacekeep ing force in Cyprus.

title: Coast Slayings Recall Mass Murders of Past
description: The slaying of 12 itinerant farm workers in Yuba City, Calif., yesterday recalled sev eral mass killings of the past.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One may strive for better environ mental quality, and one may even maintain that swordfish is a somewhat overrated sea food (compared, for example, to fresh cod fillets dredged in butter), and yet wander if sword fish lovers aren't getting a raw deal from the Food and Drug Administra tion's mercury warning.

title: In Law Firm Here
description: Kenneth Claiborne Royall went from Secretary of War to Secretary of the Army under the restructuring in the Tru man Administration that com bined all branches of the armed forces in a single Department of Defense.

title: PLANNERS APPROVE S.I. DEVELOPMENT
description: Plans for a cluster housing development involving the con struction of 440 condominium apartments around a large com mon green in the Grasmere section of Staten Island were approved by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

title: REAL ESTATE TAX COULD RISE IN CITY UNDER G.O.P. PLAN
description: ALBANY, May 26Governor Rockefeller and Republican leg islative leaders have agreed to back legislation that would per mit New York City to evade the constitutional limit on real estate, taxation and increase city real estate taxes by about $130million, legislative sources reported today.

title: Tell International Foram How Overseas Dollar Market Operates
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 26  An international bankers' forum was told today that dangerous practices ex ist in the market of borrowing and lending overseas dollars.

title: Draft Resister Is Sentenced to 6 Months
description: A 23yearold honors gradu ate of Columbia College, Ful bright scholar and doctoral can didate at Rockefeller Univer sity was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison and 18 months of supervised civilian employment for his refusal to enter the Army.

title: Wayne Returns
description: "Big Jake"? One guess. Big John Wayne, that's who, and the new picture would amount to familiar, Wayne-Western trivia except for the climax, a murderous pip. It happens lengthily and just in time.Directed by George Sherman, the sequence is played to the hilt, as Big John, flanked by his son, Patrick, Chris Mitchum (Big Bob's boy) and Bruce Cabot (as an Indian) close in on the kidnappers of Wayne's movie grandson (his 8-year-old child, John Ethan Wayne). The shadowy stealth, a church tower, a killer Collie, a flashing machete and the spitting guns add up to a horrifying humdinger. Another Wayne son, Michael, is the producer.The rest of the picture, the long prelude, simply jogs along fairly tediously on the rescue trail, with the star being his laconic self, plus conventional spurts of violence, likewise the saddle humor. Maureen O'Hara peers in briefly at the outset of a man's-man exercise, with good teamwork, too, by Richard Boone and Bobby Vinton. It's a long wait. Our advice is to stick it out.

title: A BalingWire Budget
description: Suburban and upstate Republicans, in charge of the state's governmental machinery in Albany, are putting together what must be described as a balingwire budget for New York City. If the carefully leaked reports from the master strategists prove accurate, the package will contain some of the new taxing authority requested by the citybut this authority will not extend to taxing commuters.

title: S.E.C. Disciplines Brier For Violating Capital Rules
description: WASHINGTON, MAY 26 (UPI)The Securities and Ex change Commission today dis ciplined Daniel S. Brier & Co., a New York brokerage firm, and ordered hearings on charges that two other brok erage houses had sold unregis tered stock.

title: News of Dogs
description: So important are dogs to Al and Patricia Korn that they built their kennel be fore their house.

title: Misty Noon, $13.40, Wins at Belmont
description: Misty Noon came along in the stretch under the guidance of Heliodoro Gustines to win the $20,000 feature event at Belmont Park yesterday. Her bert Allen's campaigner scored by two lengths over Knight of the Road, with Hydronaut next in the slim field.

title: News Merger
description: At a special meeting held yesterday in Chicago, stock holders of the Aurora Corpora tion of Illinois, which has head quarters in New York, approved an agreement under which Au rora would acquire the preci sioncastings division of the Allied Products Corporation of Chicago. The acquisition in volves 11,067,267 shares of Aurora common stock and about $3,5million worth of first mortgage income bonds that will become due June 1, 1985.

title: 17NATION PARLEY FOCUSES ON CITIES
description: INDIANAPOLI, May 26  Authorities from 17 countries, meeting under auspices of the Nixon Administration and the North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation, sought today to find some common solutions to the deterioration and agony of the cities.

title: PARK'S MAJORITY CUT IN KOREAN ELECTION
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thurs day, May 27President Chung Hee Park's Democratic Repub lican party retained a reduced but safe majority in the Na tional Assembly today as a result of Tuesday's general elec tion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a reader of The Times for more than, 45 years, I have witnessed the once splendid objectivity of its edi torials degenerate to the point where their sense of fairness is open to ques tion. Insofar as their attacks on Presi dent Nixon are concerned, at times they even seem to lack reason.

title: Kranepool, Foli Scuffle In Dugout During Game
description: A brief fight broke out in the New York Mets' dugout last night, between Ed Krane pool and Tim Foli, but it was quickly quelled and dis tracted few of the 22,409 persons in Shea Stadium.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The campus of Manhattan Community College lies in crowded corridors scattered among four office buildings in a midtown neighborhood of whores, hustlers and drug dealers. The twoyear college has had, and apparently still has, a serious narcotics problem that has touched the athletic department as surely as any other. Students have chosen drugs over intercollegiate competition, dropped off teams rather than quit drugs, and, in several cases in several sports, competed while stoned. While few coaches anywhere are willing to discuss this aspect of the problem, the situation at Manhattan C. C. is not considered unique.

title: ExOfficiai of Illinois Indicted On Bribe and Tax Charges
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 26 (UPI)James White, who served as purchasing agent for the late Illinois Secretary of State, Paul Powell, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on 19 counts of interstate bribery, in come tax evasion and filing false tax return.

title: Burton Stops Harris in 4th
description: Willie Burton of New York, scored a fourthround technical knockout over EEmperor Char ley Harris last night in the heavyweight fight at Sunnyside Garden, Queens. Referee Johnny Lobianco stopped the bout at 2 minutes 44 seconds. Harris had been knocked down in the third and fourth rounds and had a cut over his left eye. Burton has 16 victories and a draw in 18 pro fights.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, May 26In the newmodel Conservative par ty of Prime Minister Heath a party of individual en terprise and competition, stripped of the old privileged imagePeter Walker is a perfect symbol.

title: Fox Management Is Seen Victor in Control Battle
description: The manageinent of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation has apparently defeated an insurgent bid take control of the giant motion picture company. However, the dissidents seemingly be lieve that the vote is close enough for them to pursue their legal challenges against certain of the management proxies and intend to con tinue the hardfought battle in the courts.

title: Jaywalking With a TwoTime Loser
description: ITHACA, N. Y.On my sixteenth birthday while visiting Los Angeles, I crossed Wilshire Boulevard against the light. I was arrested. The judge let me off with a lecture, on account of my age, and because I had come from New York where people don't know that laws are to be obeyed.

title: TIMES MIRROR CITES SLIGHT PROFIT DROP
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26 (AP) The Times Mirror Company will continue to reduce costs and increase productivity dur ing 1971, Franklin D. Murphy, chairman, told stockholders to day at the annual meeting.

title: 1970 Incident Recalled
description: Last November, an incident involving a Lithuanian sailor sent shock waves through the United States Coast Guard and the Nixon Administration.

title: Fischer Beats Taimanov Again; Now Leads in Chess Match 40
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, May 26Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles defeated his Soviet opponent, Mark Taimanov, for the fourth game in a row in their quarterfinals knockout chess match.

title: ECONOMIC GAUGE UP FOR 6TH MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy rose in April for the sixth consecutive month, the Commerce Department re ported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Pullout of Equipment a Problem, Too
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26As the American role in the war declines, officers are discovering that disposing of the installations and supplies in Vietnam is more complicated than it was to build them or bring them in.

title: ASHE DROPS A SET BUT TOPS RUSSIAN
description: PARIS, May 26 (UPI)Ar thur Ashe survived a shaky start against an unknown Rus sian in the $95,000 French open tennis championships today.

title: ABRAMS CAUTIONS ON LAXITY BY G.I.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 27 (AP)Gen. Creighton W. Abrams said to day that a herculean effort was needed to keep United States troops as alert as they need to be during the Ameri can disengagement from the Vietnam war.

title: Chess: Even the Pros Have Off Day, European Tournament Shows
description: A cartoon that appeared in a chess magazine some time ago shows two men, one rather boorishlooking, and the other looking annoyed. The caption (it is, of course, the boorishlooking one who is speaking) runs: I seen in the papers you played in a chess meet. Is that a game something like checkers?

title: BRITAIN MAY ADMIT 10,000 ASIANS IN YEAR
description: LONDON, May 26 (Reuters) Britain will double the quota for immigrants of Asian origin from her former East African colonies, it was announced to day.

title: Plan for Big Utah Power Plant Debated
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 26 Plans for the biggest coalfired power plant in the world were exhaustively debated today by utility executives and conserva tionists at a Congressional hearing.

title: PRICES EDGE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose slightly yester day after declining for three consecutive sessions. However, declines again outpaced ad vances, with 449 down and 406 up. A total of 266 issues were unchanged.

title: Charade in Prague
description: Since both Gustav Husak and Leonid I. Brezhnev are intelligent men, neither can take very seriously the cur rent charade at the fourteenth Congress of the Czecho slovak Communist party in Prague. References to the international assistance the Soviet Union gave Czecho slovakia in 1968 are unlikely to convince anyone aware of the facts that what happened was anything but a brutal invasionone that robbed a small country its sovereignty. At most, Messrs. Husak and Brezhnev are engaged in the retrospective rewriting of history, apparently hopeful that future generations may be deceived even if their contemporaries are not.

title: DEBATE EMBROILS PANEL ON SCHOOLS
description: A controversy has developed over the Board of Education's pioneering project to measure the effectiveness of schools and their teachers.

title: STATE COURT DELAYS CUT IN PHONE RATES
description: ALBANY, May 26The Court of Appeals today delayed a re duction in rates for customers of the New York Telephone Com pany ordered by the Public Service Commission in Septem ber, 1970, pending the outcome of an appeal by the company.

title: Gimbel's Profit Drop Put To CreditSystem Upset
description: Delinquent charge and credit accounts amounting to over $6 million remained uncollected for at least a year at Gimbel Broth ers' flagship store here as a re sult of computer problems and poor supervision, stockholders were told here yesterday at the annual meeting.

title: Boeing and Italians Join to Build STOL Airliner
description: The Boeing Company, whose supersonic transport project was recently shelved by Con gress, lias taken initial aim at a different market of the future that of short takeoff and landing (STOL) airliners.

title: Walter Goodspeed, Headed Container Manufacturer
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., May 26Walter S. Goodspeed, re tired president of the Packag ing Corporation of America, died yesterday at his home here after a lang illness. He was 68 years old and also had a home in Grand Rapids, Mich.

title: JAPAN AUTO MAKERS TO RAISE U.S. PRICES
description: TOKYO, May 26 (Reuters) Leading Japanese car manu facturers are planning to raise their export prices in the United States. They said their purpose was to slow down a sharp increase in American im ports of Japanese cars.

title: Round One in Britain
description: The opening round of Prime Minister Heath's drive build parliamentary and public backing for Britain's en try in the European Economic Community has served mostly to sharpen the uncertainties about the outcome. For one thing there has obviously been more erosion than anticipated in support for entry among Mr. Heath's Conservative colleagues in the House of Commons.

title: Colombo's RealEstate License Is Ordered Restored by Court
description: State Supreme Court in Man hattan ordered the Secretary of State of New York yesterday to restore a realestate salesman's license to Joseph A. Colombo Sr.

title: COURT BROADENS PAROLEE RIGHTS
description: ALBANY, May 26The State Court of Appeals ruled today that the right of a parolee to be represented by an attorney in a parole revocation hearing was retroactive and that a new hearing should be held if the parolee could show that he had been denied due process.

title: Why Is It Man's World and Woman's Place?
description: The reason for the divi sion of the world into man's place and a woman's place is not anatomical, psychologi cal or temperamental differ ences but a vast and cen turiesold superstructure of myths.

title: Market Place:
description: The Singer Company's an nual report displays some thing for everyone: pretty girls, pizazz, imagination and candorespecially candor.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Military Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP)  Following is the 42 to31 rollcall vote by which the Senate defeated today an amendment to add $1,7bil lion in military pay increases to the draft extension bill:

title: Times Colleagues Salute Knowles and Grutzner
description: Clayton Knowles and Charles Grutzner, who are retiring this week after several decades as reporters for The New York Times, were honored by their colleagues last night at a party at The Lambs, 128 West 44th Street.

title: DeMartinos Lose Appeal In Effort to Keep Lenore
description: ALBANY, May 26 (AP)Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino were turned down by the State Court of Appeals today in an other attempt to keep Baby Lenore, the child they are seeking to adopt.

title: 1,000 at West Hartford Rites For ExSenator Thomas Dodd
description: STONINGTON, Conn., May 26 Former Democratic Senator Thomas J. Dodd was buried here today on a grassy slope in the eastern Connecticut country of rolling farmland and stone fences where he was born.

title: Laird Assures Brandt on Berlin Goals
description: BONN, May 26  Defense Secretary Melvin P. Laird has reassured West Germany that it need not fear any loss of United States interest in a Ber lin settlement in favor of deals with the Russians on troop reductions and strategicarms cuts.

title: Electricity Law Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) Atomic Energy Commissioner James T. Ramey urged Congress today to pass legislation to as sure the production of electric power to meet the nation's needs with a minimum impact on the environment. He testi fied before a House Commerce subcommittee.

title: JUNE I RISE PLANNED IN BAGPAPER PRICES
description: The Continental Can Com pany said yesterday it would increase prices on grocery bag, sack and merchandise bag pa per, effective June 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dovish Senators and Representatives many of whom seem to think they can soar to the Presidency on their whitewinged reputationsoften assert that the North Vietnamese would glad ly return American prisoners of war if only we would remove our troops im mediately and declare our interest in Vietnam summarily ended.

title: The Talk of Four Corners
description: FARMINGTON, N, M., May 26Driving west from Farm ington you top a rise called Harper's Hill and there they are: four giant smokestacks sending a stream of brown ishgray chemicals into the clear Western air. To be ex act, the stacks emit 350 tons of My ash a day, enough to make the plume visible from an Apollo spacecraft. The smoke would be a normal sight in Los Angeles or New York, but here, in the rugged northwest corner of New Mexico, it seemed as if a child had taken a dirty hand and smeared it across the freshly washed sky.

title: Joffrey Ballet Finds London Critics Cool, Audience Receptive
description: LONDON, May 26  The City Center Joffrey Ballet, in its first London season, is attract ing large audiences but has had only a lukewarm response from the critics.

title: U.S Coast Guard Seizes 4 Cuban Fishing Vessels
description: MIAMI, May 26 (AP)The Coast Guard seized four Cuban fishing boats today and took their eight crewmen into cus tody on charges of violating the United States' 12mile fishing zone.

title: U.S. Pressure Reported Behind Saigon's Decision to Accept Hanoi P.O.W. Plan
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 26.The United States ap plied firm pressure on the Sai gon Government to persuade it to meet all of Hanoi's condi tions for the release of 570 dis abled North Vietnamese prison ers, informed sources said to night.

title: HARASSMENT SEEN IN AUBURN STUDY
description: ALBANY, May 26A special legislative committee that stud ied allegations of brutality at the Auburn Correctional Facil ity concluded today that there was little doubt such activity existed, though it was de scribed as mental harassment rather than physical abuse.

title: Job Safety Targets Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) George C. Guenther, Assist ant Secretary of Labor, said to day that the Labor Department would first concentrate on five of the nation's most hazardous industries in a drive to improve job health and safety under a new federal law. Mr. Guenther said the five industries were longshoring, roofing and sheet metal, meat and meat products, miscellaneous transportation equipment  mostly mobile home manufacturersand lum ber and wood products.

title: Judge Maresa Is Fifth Democrat In Contest for Surrogate's Post
description: A fifth candidate for the Democratic nomination for Sur rogate in New York County joined the field yesterday with the announcement of Civil Court Judge Orest V. Maresa that he was going to run for the post.

title: CITY U. POSTPONES AN INAUGURATION
description: The inauguration of Dr. Theodore Powell as president of Kingsborough Community Col lege, which was scheduled for today, has been postponed by the Board of Higher Education following complaints brought against the president last week by some Kingsborough depart ment chairmen.

title: Miss Carol B. Moon Married Here to Patrick Denis Cardon
description: Miss Carol Browning Moon and Patrick Denis Cardon, who are studying for docto rates at New York Univer sity's Institute of Fine Arts, were married here yesterday. The ceremony in the Brick Presbyterian Church was per formed by the Rev. Dr. Wil liam H. Hudnut Jr. A recep tion at the Colony Club fol lowed.

title: Surprise Key Element of Cannes Film Fete
description: CANNES, France, May 26 Surprise has been the leit motif of the 1971 Cannes fes tival, which is celebrating its 25th birthday.

title: Roundup: 3 Catchers Deliver the Goods
description: Ellie Hendricks, Bob Mont gomery and Jerry McNertney, hardly known for their hit ting prowess, got their chances at the limelight last night. The catchers for the Baltimore Orioles, the Boston Red Sox and St. Louis Cardi nals, won games for their re spective teams.

title: ' Cat O'Nine Tails'
description: Only blindly abject devotees of the whodunit should discover catnip in "The Cat O'Nine Tails," which whipped into local theaters yesterday from Italy, complete with English dialogue, color and James Franciscus and Karl Malden to make this "Cat" hop sporadically. Any simple souls who expect large dollops of probability and authentic excitement are cautioned that they're in short supply in the concoction of slayings and sleuthing that is dished up here.It isn't ungallant to note that the title refers to the number of clues Mr. Franciscus, as an over-inquisitive reporter, and Mr. Malden, as an unlikely blind crossword puzzle expert, have to solve the four murders committed by someone in the posh Terzi Research Institute. It all stems from the fact that Professor Terzi and his associates are about to come up with a wonder heredity drug and shed new light on the criminal factor in chromosomes.Unfortunately, Dario and Salvatore Argento, the producer and director-writer, who previously were represented here by another sample of the genre, "The Bird With the Crystal Plumage," have drawn mere surface portrayals from a scurrying cast, who only occasionally generate some tension. They're just workman-like, much like Mr. Malden, who simply quips at one point:"I like solving puzzles." You'd have to be dedicated to puzzles to love this "Cat."

title: ' Gunfighter'
description: About a third of the way into it, I began to wonder what kind of acting style might be appropriate for "Support Your Local Gunfighter," a Burt Kennedy parody Western with a plot too numerous to mention, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. Just before the end a jackass appeared in a celebration scene, and I think he showed the appropriate kind of acting style, but he was on screen for so short a time, and his only contribution really was not to say anything, that I hesitate to rely on so slight an indication.Everyone else, however, shoutsall the timeexcept for James Garner (the lead, but not the gunfighter), who snarls. I believe that all this desperate vivacity is supposed to conjure up an aura of bright and comfortable good feeling. But for me it is the agony of the spirit, the decline of the West, the sullen beating of the heart of darkness.

title: Eddie Neloy Dies at 50
description: Eddie Neloy, trainer for the Phipps family's vast thoroughbred racing empire, died yesterday of a heart at tack at Belmont Park. He was 50 years old. Neloy's greatest horse was Buck passer, the 1966 horse of the year, who won 25 of 31 races and earned $1,462,000. Obituary on Page 42.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Klein Bars Intimidation
description: DES MOINES, Iowa (UPI) Herbert G. Klein, Communica tions Director for the Executive Branch, said today that the Nixon Administration would take no part in attempts to in timidate the broadcast indus try.

title: Lancers, Scots Play to Tie
description: ROCHESTER, May 26 (AP) The Rochester Lancers and the touring Hearts of Edin burgh, Scotland, played to a scoreless tie tonight. It was the Scots' second tie on the tour and left their wonlost record, at five victories, two ties and one defeat.

title: Herder and Herder Books Undergo a Vast Change
description: Herder and Herder, long noted for prestigious, high quality books on Roman Catholic theology and philos ophy, is riding the wave Ger mans call Die Sexwelle.

title: N.H.L. Transactions
description: Detroit Red WingsTraded Mike Robitaille, a defenseman, and Don Luce, center, to Buffalo Sabres for Joe Daley, goalie.

title: Microfilm Group Elects
description: John R. Robertson, manager of field sales of the business systems market division of the Eastman Kodak Company, has been elected president of the National Microfilm Association. Milton Mandel, president of the Microfilming Corporation of America, has been elected vice president and treasurer of the association.

title: Bridge:Late Rally Helps Tourists To Beat Strong Thai Team
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 26  The Precision interna tional touring team posted a thrilling lastboard victory over a powerful Thai group here last night. The home team led virtually all the way, and with three deals re maining in a 40board match had a lead of 19 international match points.

title: Fairchild Seeking KLIF
description: Fairchild Industries, producer of aerospace equipment, an nounced yesterday an agree ment in principle to purchase radio station KLIF of Dallas for $10.5million in cash from the McLendon Corporation, a fain ilyowned company with exten sive interests in theaters, real estate and oil as well as radio and television. The purchase is subject to approval by the Fed eral Communications Commis sion.

title: News Analysis
description: Sohn Lindsay doesn't have a partyhe's a man without a party, Governor Rockefeller told a group of suburban Dem ocratic legislators last Friday.

title: General Foods Corp. Sets Mark In Earnings for the Fiscal Year
description: The General Foods Corpora tion announced yesterday rec ord earnings for the fiscal year ended April 3.

title: How to Make Congress Work
description: CHICAGOOnce again Congress has dashed itself against the hard rock of reform. Senate reformers hurtled against the cloture rule and may once again alter it in some small and use less way. The effort in the House was more fascinating because it was a rare campaign against the seniority rule. No formal rule ever required seniority or guided its use, yet neither chamber of Congress has ever seri ously challenged seniority as the sole method for distributing power in com mittees. There has probably been a sentimental majority against seniority ever since it became a rigid practice early in this century,, but that majority vanishes at every moment of com mitment.

title: Executive Changes
description: Tootsie Roll Industries, Inc., announced yes terday the election of Charles S. Larmon as presi dent, Before joining the Chicagobased company in 1969 as executive vice president and chief opera ting officer, he was an executive with Alberto Culver and General Foods International.

title: Credit Markets: Yields Decline on Utility Issues
description: The credit markets yesterday made an effort to bring interest rates back down a bit, and the attempt met with some success.

title: WITNESS IS HELD IN POLICE SLAYING
description: An 18yearold student from Brooklyn who allegedly saw the gunmen who shot two police men in Harlem Friday night was held in $50,000 hail yester day as a material witness.

title: LOIS K. WILLIAMS, ARTIST, 71, IS DEAD
description: MENDHAM, N. J., May 26 Lois K. Williams, an artist and former vice president of the Needlework Guild of New York, died today at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 71 years old.

title: Nixon Urges Wider Support for the Arts
description: WASHINGTON, May 26In furtherance of his wish that the growing partnership be tween Government and the arts continue to be devel oped to the benefit of both, President Nixon today sent a memorandum to the heads of executive departments and agencies asking them to look into new ways in which their agencies can more vig orously assist the arts and artists can be of additional help to the agencies and their programs.

title: Thousands of Policemen Gather Again for Funeral of 2d Patrolman
description: DEER PARK, L. I., May 26 Policemen massed in si lence here today for the fu neral of Patrolman Joseph A. Piagentini of the New York City Police Department, who was slain last Friday night. They came from 80 depart ments in about a dozen states, nearly 5,000 men in all, gathering much as they had yesterday In the Bronx to honor the white police man's murdered black part ner, Patrolman Waverly M.
