description: PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP  The Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League to day relieved Vic Stasiuk of his head coaching duties.

title: DOW OFF BY 0.63 AS VOLUME LAGS
description: The stock market continued to act yesterday like a driver who has slowed down for the caution light and is wondering what direction to take.

title: SHARP EXPANSION IN MONEY IS NOTED
description: Monetary expansion acceler ated markedly during the last two weeks, banking data pub lished yesterday showed.

title: Credit Markets: Bond Prices Climb
description: The bond markets, which have been feeling better since prices stabilized Tuesday, con tinued to regain their health yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MIAMI, May 27, (AP)A tele phone caller attempted today to extort $200,000 from Na tional Airlines, using an alarm clock planted in a locker in Miami International Airport.

title: Japan Firm on Yen
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 27Japan today formally served notice to the world banking community that she does not intend to revalue up ward or float the yen but that she will support activities to try to make the world's mone tary system more supple.

title: Cruguet Scores Fourth Victory of Day With Bold Inquiry
description: Bold Inquiry, Craig Cullinan's cligible for the Belmont Stakes, showed fine closing ability to take the feature event yester day at Belmont Park. With Jean Cruguct, his rider, going to his fourth victory of the program, Bold Inquiry beat the Calumet Farm's Gleaming by 1 lengths.

title: U.S. Trade Balance Off Sharply in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The United States trade balance de teriorated sharply in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Gaku Troupe Offers A Variety of Dances In Riverside Series
description: The Gaku Dance Theater, which is not anywhere as Japa nese as it sounds, and the Sophie Maslow Dance Company presented the first in a series of new dance concerts Wednesday night at Riverside Church. The twoweek engagement, with changing programs, will run through June 6.

title: Faisal Uses Own Chef At White House Lunch
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)King Faisal brought along his own chef, butler and taster to prepare and serve his lunch at the White House today.

title: Few Women Found in Top U.S. Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The proportion of women in policy making jobs, in the Federal Gov ernment has scarcely increased over the last three years, ac cording to a study made by the Democratic National Commit tee.

title: Austrians and Chinese Agree To Establish Diplomatic Ties
description: HONG KONG, May 27Aus tria and China have agreed to establish diplomatic relations, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

title: WILLIAM LEWIS
description: William McKinley Lewis, a former vice president of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died yesterday, after a short illness, in Dunedin, Fla., where he re sided. He was 74 years old and had lived in Morris Township, New Jersey.

title: Nixon Flying to West Point To Review Cadet Corps
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) President Nixon will fly to the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. Saturday to review the corps of cadets and deliver an ad dress at the parade ground.

title: RAIL CARLOADINGS REPORTED LOWER
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended May 22, which was affected by a twoday nationwide strike, was down 15 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago. Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week was considerably above the same period a year ago, mainly because of labor problems in the industry last year.

title: Sneak Punch on Rents
description: In cavalier disregard of every principle of home rule, Governor Rockefeller and the Republican leadership in the State Legislature have rammed through a package bill that punches a huge hole in the already chaotic pattern of rent control in this city.

title: The Seale Jurors: One Tells of Fear During Deliberations, Another Only of Screeching Among Females
description: One or the jurors in the aborted murder trial of Bobby G. Seale, and Mrs. Ericka Hug gins, Black Panther leaders, told yesterday of fear so great that three jurors were trembling and shaking, sure they would be killed if they voted for con viction. Another said there was no fear  merely a lot of screeching between females.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The more I think about him, said Dick Nolan, the more convinced I am that John Brodie could be a late bloomer like Charlie Conerly, getting better each year and improving with age. And like Charlie, he can still be a star quarterback when he's 40. Let's see. That gives him at least five more seasonsand maybe more, Look at George Blanda. He's 43.

title: Alcindor to Wed, Then Play for Stars
description: HOUSTON, May 27 (UPI) The presence of Lew Al cindor makes the National Basketball Association a solid favorite over the Amer ican Basketball Association in their playerpromoted all star game in the Astrodome tomorrow night.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices Of Computer Parts
description: The International Business' Machines Corporation's ru mored more aggressive mar keting pose became highly visible yesterday as the com pany announced a new pricing schedule designed to prevent the erosion of some of its mar kets for peripheral equipment.

title: Books of The Times
description: JUNGLE LOVERS. By Paul Theroux. 307 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: Purse minder Wins Peter Pan by 9 Lengths and Is Aimed for Belmont Stakes
description: Purse Finder of the Briar dale Farm scored an upset vic tory in the $25,000 Peter Pan Purse at Belmont Park yester day, and earned a chance to start in the Belmont Stakes week from today.

title: Miss Stoddart Becomes Bride
description: Miss Nancy Stoddart was married yesterday afternoon to Peter C. R. Huang at St. James' Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ralph Warren.

title: V.F.W. Chief Says Withdrawal Should Match Prisoner Release
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) The head of a war veterans group said yesterday that Unit ed States troop withdrawals from Vietnam should be done at a rate matching the release of United States prisoners of war.

title: Marks Levine Dies Here at 80; Manager for Noted Musicians
description: Marks Levine, a founder and former president of the Na tional Concerts and Artists Corporation, who managed many leading musicians, died yester day in Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 101 West 55th Street.

title: ...and Low Games
description: To deal with a type of hunter who has even less claim to sympathy than the brave tourists on safari, the House of Representatives has just passed a seemingly unargu able bill. The measure would make it a crime, anywhere in the country, for a private citizen to shoot or fire any animal from an airplaneunless armed with a state permit to go after particular predators known to be damaging his property.

title: Mrs. Polikoff Married Here
description: Mrs. Jean Loeb Polikoff was married here yesterday evening to Raymond S. Troubh at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Loeb.

title: 12,252 See Metros Lose
description: TORONTO, May 28 (Canadian Press)  The touring Lanerossi Vicenza team from Italy built a 30 halftime lead tonight then held on for a 32 victory over the Toronto Metros Of the North American Soccer League before 12,252 fans.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL, SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profile, of today's newsmakers in a loose leaf edition. Write: The New York Times. Library Services. Box FP480, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.  ADVT.

title: N.B.A. AllStars, Without Alcindor, Defeat A.B.A., 125120, at Astrodome
description: HOUSTON, May 28 (UPI) Walt Frazier scored 26 points and Oscar Robertson made two free throws in the final seconds to lead a National Basketball Association allstar team, play ing without Lew Alcindor, to a 125120 victory over the Amer ican Basketball Association in the first game between the two rival professional leagues to night.

title: G.E. Adds 3 Appliances
description: The General Electric Com pany has introduced three com pact appliances: a trash com pactor that is expected to be competitive with other brands that range from $229 to $239, a portable microwave oven at $400 to $450 and a 60pound portable electric dry er that will retail for $129.95.

title: Ohio Paper Purchased
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, May 28 (AP) The Hamilton Journal News, an afternoon daily news paper with a circulation of about 30,000, was purchased today by Harte Hanks News papers, Inc., of San Antonio, Tex., which operates 15 papers in Texas. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: King Resources Comments On Lawsuit Filed by I.O.S.
description: DENVER, May 28 (Reuters)  The King Resources Com pany said today that the suit tiled by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., against King Re sources seemed to have been timed to blur the main issue, which was an $8million promissory note I.O.S. owed King Resources that was due Monday.

title: Judo Expert Receives A Belt Where It Hurts
description: LONDON, May 28 (UPI) Keith Remfry's reward for helping Britain in last week's European judo champion ships was to lose his job.

title: Fischer Takes 50 Lead In World Title Chess Match
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, May 28Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the United States chess champion, beat Mark Tai manov of the Soviet Union to day in the fifth game of the world chess championship quar terfinals.

title: FOE SAID TO FAIL AGAIN AT SNOUL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, May 28 (AP)A new battle for the eastern Cambo dian town of Snoul was fought yesterday, and allied forces said they had won it.

title: NoFault Insurance: No
description: No fault Is a catch phrase which everybody uses but no one under standi. Newspapers, radio, television stations are heard extolling its vir tues; public print never has an analysis of what is wrong with nofault insur ance plans.

title: Poughkeepsie Will Dismiss Teachers in a Budget Crisis
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 28 (UPI)  The Board of Ed ucation here has announced it would dismiss 103 professional staff members in the city's school system because of a lack of funds.

description: Th' Dimmycratic party ain't ore speakin' terms with itsilf.Mr. Doo ley (Finley Peter Dunne), 1900.

title: Many Quit Island as Reputed Mafiosi Begin Exile
description: FILICUDI, Italy, May 28 (AP) The inhabitants began aban doning this tiny island today in protest against the presence of 18 reputed Mafia leaders who were exiled here Wednesday.

title: Caracas Investigates Firing
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 28 (Reuters) Venezuela's De fense Ministry is investigating an incident yesterday in which a Venezuelan Air Force B25 bomber fired on two American helicopters on loan to the Co lombian Government, Foreign Minister Aristides Calvani Silva said today. No one was hurt in the incident near the Colom bian border.

title: Columbia Journalism School Awards Three Fellowships
description: Pulitzer Traveling Fellowships stipends of $3,000 for travels anywhere in the worldwere awarded by the Columbia Uni versity Graduate School of Journalism yesterday to three members of the current gradu ating class.

title: Swiss Bank's Statement
description: GENEVA, May 28  The Swiss National Bank expressed today the firm hope that every effort would be made at the international level to re establish and maintain stable currency exchange rates.

title: FedMart Completes Talks To Get $12.5Million Loan
description: SAN DIEGO, May 28 (Reu ters)The FedMart Corpora tion said today it had completed negotiations with the Bank of America and four Texas banks for a fiveyear term loan of $12.5million.

title: The Indy 500
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J.There are those who would silence the racing cars and mothball the circuits and even halt the Indy 500. They would endjust like that  the sound and fury of racers chewing up pavement. But are they right? Must auto racing die?

title: Coast Slaying Toll Reaches 21; Sales Receipts Led to Suspect
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., May 28 Sutter County sheriff's deputies uncovered a 21st body today as they continued to probe the soft earth of peach orchards along the Feather River just outside this Sacramento Valley farming center.

title: Top Pentagon Aides Instructed To Stay Silent on Mylai Cases
description: FORT MEADE, Md., May 28 (AP)The Pentagon's top of ficers were told by a military judge today to stop making statements about action taken against Army officers impli cated in the alleged coverup of the killings at Mylai.

title: U.S REEVALUATES CAR BUMPER RULE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 The Administration's automo bile safety chief testified today that the new Federal safety standard for protective bump ers on passenger cars might be strengthened.

title: L.I.U. Honors Lomax
description: Stan Lomax, sports broad caster for radio station WOR AM for the last 30 years, was presented last night with Long Island University's Zeckendorf Award, for his efforts in pro moting college sports, at the school's 19th annual Varsity Club sports award dinner.

title: Connally Tells Bankers U.S. Will Defend Dollar
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 28Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr. voiced today the United States Gov ernment's determination to de fend the dollar and said that other industrialized nations must respond by assuming greater world responsibilities.

title: Negotiating Formula Seen in Berlin Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The Soviet Union and the three Western powers appear to be close to agreement on a nego tiating method in their talks on Berlin that would permit them to set aside for the time being their disagreements on the legal status of the divided city.

title: STELLA FROST OUT OF YONKERS PACE
description: YONKERS, May 28  Stella Frost was stricken by a virus this morning and definitely is out of tomorrow night's $10,000 A1 onemile pace at Yonkers, Raceway and most likely will not start in the $100,000 Mar tin Tananbaum International at 1 miles next Friday night.

title: Braves Put Boyer On the Waiver List
description: ATLANTA, May 28 (UPI) Clete Boyer was told by the Atlanta Braves today they would give him his un conditional release if no other National League team picked him up for the $20, 000 waiver price within the next five clays.

title: New Bedford Police Cleared
description: BOSTON, May 28 (AP)An investigating committee of the Massachusetts Police Associa tion today exonerated the New Bedford Police Department of charges of overreaction during disorders last summer. An earli er report by Attorney General Robert H. Quinn had cited po lice overreaction and harass merit of minority groups by unidentified policemen.

title: West German Train Crash Fatal to 45 Laid to Error
description: WUPPERTAL, Germany, May 28 (AP)  Authorities today blamed human error for West Germany's worst railroad acci dent.

title: ITALY'S 25TH YEAR AS REPUBLIC MARKED
description: ROME, May 28President Giuseppe Saragat today opened celebrations commemorating the 25th anniversary of the Italian Republic with a warn ing that the nation's liberty may be threatened at any moment.

title: SYRIANSOVIET PACT NOW EXPECTED ALSO
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28 Syria is expected to follow Egypt in signing a treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union, informed Arab sources said here today.

title: They Love to Dance, and If They Don't, Well ... Mother Is Boss
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 28Autumn leaves are over here; come on, autumn leaves, a woman cried urgently.

title: Government to Give the City A Part of Miller Field on S.I.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The General Services Adminis tration announced an agree ment today to turn over 85 acres of Miller Field, a deac tivated Army airfield on Staten Island, to New York City for school and recreational pur poses.

title: Seale Is Released On $25,000 Bond; Leaves for Coast
description: NEW HAVEN, May 28 (AP) Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party, was freed yesterday on $25,000 bond after 21 months in prison.

title: U.A.R. Pacta Landmark, The Soviet Public Is Told
description: MOSCOW, May 28  The Soviet people were told today that the 15year friendship treaty signed yesterday with Egypt marked a historic land mark in Soviet history.

title: Lawyer Tells of Own Illicit Aid to Aliens
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., May 28A Boston lawyer admitted today that he had induced at least 250 Portuguese immi grants to remain in the country illegally while he worked out a plan designed to force the United States to keep them.

title: Rohr Corporation
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif., May 28The Rohr Corporation re ported today a drop of 61.3 per cent in net earnings per share in the nine months ended April 30.

title: NoFault Insurance: Yes
description: NEWTON, Mass.Automobile insur ance rates go up and up, seemingly without end; the courts are jammed with automobileclaims cases that tarry for years; the injured receive as benefits less than half the money paid in as premiums.

title: DROP CONTINUES FOR EGG FUTURES
description: With the output of eggs ex ceeding demand, there has been much selling of shell egg fu tures lately on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Yester day, prices of the two most active contracts dropped 60 points each (hundredths of a cent a pound) with June shell egg futures falling to a new seasonal low for the seventh straight day.

title: Index of HelpWanted Ads Leveled Off Last Month
description: The helpwanted index, a sensitive economic indicator that measures the volume of classified advertising in 52 major newspapers, leveled off during April, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: City Borrowing Approved
description: ALBANY, May 28 (UPI)  Governor Rockefeller signed legislation today permitting New York City to borrow $310million to balance this year's budget.

title: Jean Vilar, French Actor and Director, Is Dead
description: PARIS, May 28  Jean Vilar, the actor and director who dominated theater in France for a generation, died this morning in his hometown of Sete, in southern France, of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Gulf Waters Eating Away a Louisiana Resort Beach
description: GRAND ISLE, La.The Gull of Mexico has been cat ing away Louisiana's coastal wetlands at the rate of 16 square miles a year for sev eral years, the year of En gineers estimates.

title: Defunct Bridal Salon Besieged in Queens
description: A Queens bridal salon whose owner has gone out of business was mobbed yesterday by bridestobe and their relatives, who com plained that the gowns they had paid for were locked in the store.

title: Pearl River Budget Voted
description: PEARL RIVER, N. Y., May 28  Voters of the Pearl River School District approved a $7, 109,000 school budget yester day by a vote of 1,351 to 876. A $7,400,000 budget had been defeated May 5 by 178 votes. A specialized service budget of $304,000 also was approved yesterday by a vote of 1,238 to 966. This provided for inter scholastic and intramural ath letic contests, driver education, adulteducation courses and expanded community services.

title: Opposition Paper in Singapore Is Closed on Government Order
description: SINGAPORE, May 28  The Singapore Herald ceased publi cation today following a Gov ernment order at noon revoking the newspaper's printing license.

title: Quebec Will Close Village Where CaveIn Killed 31
description: QUEBEC, May 28 (UPI) The northern Quebec village of St. Jean de Vianney and parts of neighboring Shipshaw, where 31 persons were killed when the earth caved in May 4, will be closed permanently by the provincial government.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN SLOW TRADING
description: A flurry of activity in the computer group provided one of the stock market's features yesterday as trading remained slow on the eve of the Memorial Day weekend. The turnover of 11.76 million shares was the third lowest for this year.

title: NATO Moves to Build Up Forces in Mediterranean
description: BRUSSELS, May 28  The North Atlantic alliance moved today toward a more effective defense of its Mediterranean flank.

title: Bank Seeks a Delay
description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 29 (AP)David Rockefel ler, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said today he had asked Prime Minister Lee to defer final decision on the newspaper until a hank official could look into the situation more closely.

title: Film: Artistic Vampires
description: Want to see a fascinating vampire movie? Then catch the Belgian-made, English-language "Daughters of Darkness," which arrived yesterday. Subtle, stately, stunningly colored and exquisitely directed by Belgium's young Harry Kumel, the coscenarist, this is far and away the most artistic vampire shocker since the Franco-Italian "Blood and Roses" 10 years ago. The censorson this side of the water anyway  almost crippled that one by yanking out the homosexuality.The new picture is stronger and better-rounded, with the same double theme intact. Like a poisonous flower, it wafts through the main premises, a huge, coastal hotel off-season, housing a honeymoon couple, two strange women guests and a quaking porter. That is the set-up, and we guarantee that the picture, gliding silkenly into horror, will glue you to your seat.John Karlen, Daniele Ouimet and Andrea Rau do well, but it is the honey-voiced evil conveyed by Delphine Seyrig, from "Last Year at Marienbad," that dominates the footage. If she ever checks into a Hilton Hotel, with the brilliant Mr. Kumel again piloting, that should be quite a picture, too.

title: Passage of Betting Bill Expected in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, May 28  The Connecticut General Assembly is expected to approve legisla tion next week permitting a state lottery, parimutuel bet ting on horse racing and off track betting in the state.

title: Roar of Motorcycles Draws 20,811 Fans to Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 28 Middle America showed up in force, taking its station wagons, Fords and Plym ouths into this affluent vil lage tonight, spending more than $120,000 to see and hear a night of motorcycle racing called the Yamaha Gold Cup.

title: Commercial Fun...
description: One would think that the great surge of interest in the environment would have discouraged completely that ghoulish species of business literature which pro motes safaris for the pursuit of rare game. Unfortunately, one would be wrong; that species of literature is far less endangered than the animals whose destruction invites.

title: I.M.F. Credit to Honduras
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund announced to day a $15million standby credit to Honduras.

title: J. J. KENNY DENIES RECEIVING DEAL
description: NEWARK, May 28John J. Kenny, the former Hudson County Freeholder, county Dem ocratic chairman and a power in the state Democratic party, insisted today that when the trial of nine of his former asso ciates here is over, all he will have left is his freedom.

title: 422 Died Here in '71 From Drug Causes, About Same as 1970
description: Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, re ported yesterday that there had been 422 deaths from acute reactions to heroin and other drugrelated causes this year, approximately the same as the total a year ago.

title: 5 of Week's 9 New Offerings Rise in Price as One Declines
description: The newissues market post ed a good advance this week as the number of companies going public increased.

title: INCO IS WORKING ON COLOR STEELS
description: Research scientists at the In ternational Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., are close to de veloping stainless steels that can be produced commercially in almost any desired color, not just the mirrorlike, silver finish of existing stainless grades.

title: Plane Crash Laid to Fire
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) Fire and explosion in flight caused the crash of a twin engine executive plane in which all five persons aboard were killed near Piketon, Ohio, Dec. 17, 1969, the National Trans portation Safety Board said to day. The Cessna 40. piloted by David E. Weidner, 42 years old, Mount Carmel, Ohio, was en route from Cincinnati to Park ersburg, W. Va.

title: Fordham Professor Named As Dean of the Law School
description: Prof. Joseph M. McLaughlin, a specialist in procedural law and a faculty member of Ford ham University for 10 years, has been appointed dean of the Fordham Law School, the Rev. Michael P. Walsh, president of the university, announced last night.

title: MRS. A. B. WILLIAMS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass, May 26 Frederica Howell Williams, reporter for The Newark (N.J.) Evening News during the nine teen twenties, died at her home here yesterday after a short ill ness. She was 74 years old and the widow or Albert B. Wil liams, an engineer.

title: Murder in Mississippi
description: Tuesday was Commencement. Day for Joetha Collier, the day she got her high school diploma and looked forward to going off to college next fall. When Joetha collier was in grade school, she had not dreamed that the daughter of an impoverished black family living on a dirt road outside Drew, Miss., could get to college. But Mississippi has moved perceptibly toward the goal of equal educational opportunity in the last decade, and college was now only a few months off for Joetha.

title: CALE J. SCHNEIDER, INVENTOR, 79, DIES
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, May 28Ca J. Schneider, who invented a, multipronged cake breaker to slice the softest cake, and cur rently in use as a comb for AfroAmerican coiffures, died today in his Toledo home. He was 79 years old.

title: LINDSAY ATTACKS STATE ON BUDGET
description: In his most biting language so far about Albany's handling of the city's fiscal problems, Mayor Lindsay accused the state yesterday of acting with a combination of arrogance and contempt,

title: Demands by Hijacker
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sat urday, May 29 (AP)The hi jacker, carrying a shotgun and reportedly wrapped in a large quantity of explosives, or dered that the Nassau airport be fully illuminated and that he be brought the money and a woman.

title: DR. ARTHUR DAVIDOFF
description: Dr. Arthur Davidoff, associ ate professor of dentistry at New York University College of Dentistry, died Wednesday of a heart attack in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 100 Bleecker Street.

description: The chairman of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee threatened yesterday to stall financial aid for the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation indefinitely, unless the Admin istration discloses details of the corporation's current financial position.

title: Bridge: Play in Goldman Open Pairs Is Feature of Regionals Today
description: The Goldman Open Pair Championship, the oldest event in contract bridge, is the feature of today's play when the Eastern Regionals continues at the New York Hilton. Two qualifying ses sions today will he followed by semifinal and final stages tomorrow.

title: Muskie Warns Party of Fund Peril
description: Senator Edmund S. Muskie told 50 leading New York Dem ocrats yesterday that his Presi dential campaign would cost at least $10million before next summer's national conven tion, and he warned that the party was in danger of ex hausting itself financially be fore the 1972 campaign.

title: A Message of Necessity
description: The device which Governor Rockefeller and other Gov ernors before him have used to gain passage of bills they favor in the closing hours of the legislative session called a message of necessity. When the Governor sends a message of necessity to the State Legislature, ho curtails the normal waiting time during which indi vidual legislators can study a bill. By this shabby method the legislative leaders are enabled to railroad measures immediately into law.

title: PRICES RECEIVED BY FARMERS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) Prices received by farmers for raw products rose 2 per cent in May, the first increase since February, and averaged 3 per cent more than a year before, the Agriculture Depart ment announced today.

title: Travelers Leave for ThreeDay Holiday
description: The first Congressionally en acted threeday Memorial Day weekend began last night the way nonCongressionally en acted threeday Memorial Day weekends used to beginwith clogged roads, busy terminals, fully booked resorts and a ??itssummeratlast mood.

title: RITES FOR SLAIN GIRL SET AT DREW SCHOOL
description: DREW, Miss., May 28 (AP) The school board granted per mission today to hold funeral services in the Drew High School auditorium Sunday for a slain black girl.

title: A Beauty Contest With a Difference: Saigon's First, and Girls Didn't Weep
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 28  No one showed their legs, but one girl sprinkled gold sequins on her eyelids while another wore long black lace gloves. At least five contestants had such jutting silhouettes it was believed they wore padded brassieres. Nearly all 30 con testants wore at least one pair of false eyelashes, and everyone seemed to smell of hair spray.

title: Podgorny Leaves Cairo
description: CAIRO, May 28President Podgorny left Cairo for Mos cow this afternoon ending threeday unofficial visit that laid the basis for tighter So vietEgyptian relations under the treaty of friendship and co operation.

title: ARMS TALK ROLE SLATED FOR NATO AND WARSAW PACT
description: VIENNA, May 28The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union have decided to turn over nego tiations on the limitation of nuclear arms in Central Europe to the entire membership of the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization and the Warsaw Pact.

title: 3 Crashes Involving Four School Buses Injure a Total of 96
description: A total or 96 persons were injured yesterday in accidents involving school buses in three different sections of the coun try.

title: 1,000 Police Attend Funeral of Slain Capital Officer
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Po licemen from seven states, in cluding 250 from New York City, were among 1,000 officers who massed today at the fu neral of a patrolman slain Tuesday in a gun battle with bank robbers,

title: Fire Stalls Rail Service
description: Service on the Harlem and New Haven Divisions of the Penn Central was interrupted for about 25 minutes yesterday beginning at 6:34 P.M. as a re sult of a brush fire near the tracks at 241st Street and the Wakefield Station in the Bronx. Electric power was cut off to permit firemen to fight the blaze.

title: SUCCESSOR TO LAZAR IS PICKED IN QUEENS
description: The City Council is expected to elect Eugene Mastropieri, a 33yearold lawyer, as a Queens Councilman at Large next Fri day to replace Michael J. Lazar, the new taxi commissioner, who resigned his councilmanic post yesterday.

title: Nixon News Conference
description: WASHINGTON. May 28 (AP) President Nixon's news con* ference next Tuesday will begin at 8:30 P.M. Eastern daylight time the White House said today. The radio and television broadcast will he from the East Room of the executive mansion.

title: Woman Trapped in Subway Died of Smoke Inhalation
description: Smoke inhalation caused the death of a woman trapped in a subway train under the East River Wednesday evening, the Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: KEPPEL LEAVES BOARD OF CITY U.
description: Francis Keppel has resigned as a member of the Board of Higher Education, the govern ing body of the City Univer sity, to avoid a conflict of in terest with his outside business activities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: R. S. Reynolds Jr., chairman of Reynolds Metals Company, has been named to serve as president of the aluminum com pany. The appointment was taken to fill the vacancy which will occur June 1, when Jos. H. McConnell, who became 65 years old this month, retires as president. He will remain a di rector and serve as a consult ant to the company.

title: ByElection Victory by Labor Is Viewed as a Rebuff to Heath
description: LONDON, May 28  Last June, with consumer prices ris ing at an annual rate or 5.6 per cent, Edward Heath capi talized on voter discontent to oust the Labor Government and lead his Conservative party to power. Part of his winning campaign oratory was a prom ise of action to reduce prices at a stroke.

title: Class 44: Animation of an Open Classroom Generates Curiosity
description: First came the chimes, then the voice, calmly but cryptically promising great truths. Mystical experiences don't happen often in public schools, otherwise Class 44 might fairly have expected something in that line.

title: Expulsions Announced
description: LISBON, May 28The Por tuguese Foreign Minister, Dr. Rui Patricio, announced here today that members of the White Fathers still in Mozam bique had been ordered to leave immediately.

title: COMPULSION LAID TO SCHOOLS HERE
description: Some students and parents have complained to the New York Civil Liberties Union that public school children were re quired earlier this month to write letters to elected officials protesting the city budget cuts.

title: Laos Post Reported Overrun
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 28 (UPI)Enemy troops reported ly overran a Government blocking position today on the west ern part of the Boloven Plateau in southernmost Laos.

title: Crane Eggs to Be Incubated
description: FORT SMITH, Northwest Ter iritories, May 28 (Canadian Press)  Canadian and United Stales biologists collected 11 eggs today from nests of the are whooping crane in Wood Buffalo National Park for arti ficial incubation. They will be flown by jet to the Patuxent research center in Laurel, Md., on Saturday.

title: Trevino Leads by Stroke At Memphis With 132
description: MEMPHIS, May 28 (AP) Lee Trevino recorded his sec ond straight 66 today and moved into the secondround lead in the $175,000 Danny Thomas Memphis Golf Classic.

title: KODES, MRS. COURT ADVANCE IN PARIS
description: PARIS, May 28 (AP)The defending champions, Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, and Mrs. Margaret Court of Aus tralia, won secondround sin gles matches today in the French open tennis tournament.

title: Antiques: Chinese Ware
description: When it came up for auction last Saturday, the Chinese porcelain plate orig inally owned by De Witt Clinton served as a good re minder of the variety of wares the Chinese sold, to Americans early in the 19th century.

title: Market Place: Stormy Weather For Hemisphere
description: It all started with a 67 room hotel, marina and golf course on the south side of New Providence Island in the Bahamas  14 miles from Nassau and the gambling casinos on the north side.

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS HE DID NO WRONG
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 28 (UPI)  Robert Dilts, who was ousted by Gov. William T. Ca hill last week as Bergen Coun ty Prosecutor, said through his attorney today that neither he nor any member of his staff were guilty of wrongdoing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art: Impromptu Egyptian Exhibition
description: Suppose you have a large gallery scheduled for remod eling but vacant until fall, a few dollars left in the budget, not many, for buy ing some new lights and re painting some old cases, and one of the finest Egyptian collections in the world, mostly in storagewhat do you do?

title: Threat to Chile's Freedom
description: President Allende assures foreign visitors that his leftist Government will preserve freedom and democracy in Chile; but there are grounds for doubting that free institutions can survive the economic straitjackets being fashioned by the Allende coalition. One of these institu tions Is Chile's free press.

title: Witnesses and Autopsy Report Rebut Police Version Of Negro's Slaying During Chattanooga Disorders
description: CHATTANOOGA, May 28 An unarmed black man shot to death here during recent civil disorders was almost help lessly intoxicated and was fired upon by the police with out provocation, according to witnesses to the shooting.

title: Dance: Robbins's Genius
description: What is one to say about Goldberg Variations after one has said thank you? Jerome Robbins's new ballet, seen for the first time in its final version at the New York State Theater on Thursday night, is a work of such am plitude and grandeur that it can make you fall in love with the human body all over again. What a piece of work is man! And with what ballets does Mr. Robbins cele brate that workmanship!

title: Patent ChiefWill Visit Soviet in Licensing Bid
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  The United States is ready to make its first effort to help American business men profit from their techno logical knowhow in the So viet Union.

title: PHILHARMONIC GIVES SHOSTAKOVICH MUSIC
description: The New York Philharmon ic's Invitation to the Dance Promenade concerts being giv en this weekend have Anna Aragno and Edward Villella as principal guest artists in a lit tle series of dances devised by Mr. Villella for the occasion.

title: MITSUBISHI RUNS A TIGHT MEETING
description: TOKYO, May 28A shout ing, fistswinging confrontation between antiwar protesters and rightists turned the semi annual general shareholder meeting of giant Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., into pandemonium today.

title: 148 YACHTS START IN 200MILE RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 28 The Long Island Sound sail ing season's first crusingyacht race into open water began to night when a fleet of 148, rated under the International. Offshore Rule, set sail from off Larchmont Breakwater on the Storm Trysail Club's 26th an nual Block Island race.

title: Aide Says Chile Will Seek Ties to Soviet Trade Bloc
description: MOSCOW, May 28  The, Foreign Minister of Chile, here for talks with Soviet leaders, disclosed today that his Gov ernment intended to develop contacts with the economic al liance of the Soviet bloc.

title: '74 Service Due for Both Soviet SST and Concorde
description: PARIS, May 28  The report ed lead of the Soviet Union in the race to market a supersonic jetliner all but vanished today.

title: Boiler Failure Halts Cruise Of Maine Maritime Vessel
description: CASTINE, Me., May 28The Maine Maritime Academy train ing ship, State of Maine, has had to turn back From the mid Atlantic to her home port here because of the failure of one of her two boilers, officials said today.

title: Lyrical Abstraction Show at Whitney
description: Like baroque or abstract expressionism or almost any general art tag, lyrical ab straction is one of those vague terms that can at once embrace sweeping similarities as well as differences in styles and personalities. Noth ing could sustain this obser vation more than the current lyrical abstraction exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art. A donation to the museum by Larry Al drich, the wellknown Sev enth Avenue dress manufac turer and art collector, the paintings on display are by 33 young American artists, and they run a gamut of artistic persuasions.

title: Smithsonian Can't Find Keys to Centennial Safe
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)The combination and keys to a centennial safe ara lost, apparently among the Smithsonian Institution's 62 million items, and if they are not found by 1976, Con gress will he looking for a safecracker.

title: Residents Leave Pakse
description: PAKSE, Laos, May 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  With the enemy threat apparently in creasing, every flight from this town near the Thai border to Vientiane is fully booked for the next 12 days. Many of those who cannot get a seat on one of the daily flights leave by road through Thailand.

title: Notes on People
description: Now that President Nixon has reportedly dropped plans to nominate Albert W. Wat son to the United States Court of Military Appeals. The former South Carolina Representative is said in Washington to be under con sideration to fill an expected vacancy on the Interstate Commerce Commission. Don ald L. Jackson is expected to leave the commission this summer to work with the Or ganization of American States.

title: Unions Protest Expected Layoffs by City
description: Unions representing various groups of city employes pro tested yesterday against cur rent or anticipated layoffs and warned of possible job actions.

title: T.W.A. IS CONTINUING EMPLOYMENT CUTS
description: While Trans World Airlines is waiting for an upturn in its business, it is continuing cut backs in employment.

title: A Second Soviet Craft Headed For Mars
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, May 29 The Soviet Union announced early today that it had launched a second instrument ed spacecraft toward Mars.

title: Navajos to Demand New CoalMine Guarantees
description: PAGE, Ariz., May 28  The Navajo Indians' chief disclosed today that the tribe would de mand new guarantees from industry against environmental damage from a controversial reservation coalmining project in northern Arizona.

title: NATIONS HELD WARY ON CODE FOR REBELS
description: GENEVA, May 28Govern ments are approaching with diffidence proposals by the Red Cross for expanding to internal conflicts the protection that the Geneva conventions provide to the victims of wars between na tions.

title: Donohue Favored to Win Indy 500 Today
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 The 55th running of the Indianapolis 500 tomorrow will bring together the fastest 33car field ever assembled for the event, with six or eight particularly strong en tries certain to make it one of the most competitive races in recent years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Diener & Dorskind Agency Files For Reorganization in Court
description: Diener & Dorskind, Inc., an advertising agency handling a large volume of classified ad vertising yesterday filed a pe tition in United States District Court here for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Fed eral Bankruptcy Act.

title: HUGE AID TO CITIES OPPOSED BY AGNEW
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28  Vice President Agnew spoke out sharply today against the idea of the Federal Govern ment's moving hastily and with massive expenditure of funds to help the cities as soon as the din of crisis and the rhet oric of disaster begin to be heard.

title: BOBBY JONES TAKES LEAD IN JAZZ COMBO
description: Bobby Jones, a tenor saxo phonist whose jazz talents have been simmering for more than 20 years, seems to be finally bringing them to a boil. Mr. Jones appeared yesterday after noon at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street, as coleader with Kenny Dorham of a quin tet that provided crisp, swing ing backing for the relaxed power of his playing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: Boston Stops Blue, 43
description: Dick Williams returned to Boston last night for the first time since lie was dismissed as the Red Sox manager in 1969 and brought Vida Blue, the major league's hottest pitcher, along for protection. It wasn't enough.

title: Bank of Japan Governor Decries Trade Imbalance
description: TOKYO, May 28Japan's top banker expressed concern today over an embarrassingly large growth in exports, com bined with continued delays on the liberalizing of import curbs. Tadashi Sasaki, Gover nor of the Bank of Japan, told the Japan Press Club that ex ports in the first quarter had risen 30 per cent above those for the 1970 period, while the country's promised import liberalization showed little progress.

title: Women Win Admittance To 500 Garage Area
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 Mechanics at the Speedway garages are used to all kinds of outsiders staring and ask ing questions in the final hours before the Indianapolis 500 race. But one gender of outsider they are not used to is female.

title: U.S. Aides See Pact as a Soviet Move to Bolster Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Administration specialists on the Middle East believe that the 15year treaty signed yesterday between the Soviet Union and Egypt represents a major effort by the Russians to consolidate their interests and investments in the Arab world.

title: Receiver Appointed
description: SINGAPORE, May 28 (Reu ters)The Herald's crisis be gan last week when Mr. Lee disclosed at a news conference that the paper was heavily in debt, charged it with consist ently taking the Government nn and intimated it was in volved in what he called black operations.

title: Xenon Bulbs Find New Use
description: The DuroTest Corporation has announced that it has adapted its xenon highinten sity light bulbs for use in theater film projectors, tele visionstudio lighting and thea ter spotlights. The xenon bulbs were originally developed for illuminating the Apollo space craft on the launching pad.

title: OTB Pool for the Belmont Backed by Track Officials
description: Howard J. Samuels did well both at the bargaining table and the parimutuel windows yesterday during a daylong se ries of deliberations at Belmont Park.

title: Benefit Softball Marathon Begins at Oceanside High
description: The 72hour marathon soft ball game for the benefit of the Ken Kunken Medical Fund be gan at 6 o'clock last night at Oceanside (L. I.) High School. There are still a few openings at $1 a man or $10 a team an hour. The game will end at 6 P.M. Monday.

title: Florida National Banks File 3,213,103Share Offering
description: Florida National Banks of Florida, Inc., said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the public offering of 3,213,103 common shares for sale through an underwriting group led by duPont, Glore Forgan, Inc., and Salomon Brothers.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fall at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 Yields on United States Treas ury bills fell in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities, announced today in advance of the Monday holiday.

title: Angels Rout Kline in 3d, Beat Yanks, 96
description: Home proved no haven for the New York Yankees last night as they continued to ex perience the type of frustration that marked their lamentable trip by losing to the California Angels, 96.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 Machines that automatically read such papers as public utility bills and payrolls for American industry are elabo rate and rather expensive. To make character recognition eco nomical for users with a limited volume of docu ments, David H. Shepard has invented a time sharing system with a central station serving a whole city. Mr. Shepard will receive Pat ent 3,582,884 for the appa ratus next week. It is assigned to the Cognitronics Corpora tion, New York, of which he is president.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For eight increasingly uncomfortable hours, the groom, the horse and the veterinary technician circled one another warily in a deadly serious dance. The horse had just won a show event and the technician met him at the ring to test his urine for drugs, a new procedure. The groom, under orders to prevent the test, jerked and jiggled the harness so the horse would not relax long enough to relieve himself. The groom, his arms aching, dared not stop tugging; the technician could not leave his stakeout for an instant and the horse seemed in pain.

title: Gangsters in a British Style: Grissom Gang' Opens at 2 Theaters Here Story Takes Place in Missouri of 1930's
description: "Its morals," wrote Leonard Mosley in London's Daily Express 23 years ago, "are about on a level with those of a scavenger dog. Its aim is lascivious. Its dialogue is cheap and suggestive. Many of its scenes are revolting."Mr. Mosley was writing about a British attempt to make an American gangster film out of James Halley Chase's "No Orchids for Miss Blandish." I never did see that film, which caused something of a scandal in England but was generally ignored by critics when it opened three years later. However, I've no doubt that the same sort of knee-high dudgeon will greet Robert Aldrich's film version of the Chase novel, which opened yesterday at the DeMille and Juliet I Theaters under the title of "The Grissom Gang."You don't really have to think very much about "The Grissom Gang" to call it offensive, immoral and perhaps even lascivious, although to me, that word, when it is applied to an aim, is more of a promise than a threat. "The Grissom Gang," like so many Aldrich films, especially "What Ever Happened to Baby Jane" and "The Dirty Dozen," carries lurid melodrama and violence to outrageous limits, for what often seems like the purely perverse hell of it.There is, however, lurking around the edges of the film, if not actually on the screen, the suspicion that Aldrich is such an uncompromising (maybe even revolutionary) moralist that he can only make his points in terms of action so grotesque that it challenges easy, safe compassion, sympathy and credibility.As I say, this is only a suspicion, but it's enough to make an ultimately unsuccessful film like "The Grissom Gang" a lot more interesting than nicer, more obviously high-minded movies.I've not read Chase's novel, but the film that Aldrich and Leon Griffiths, his screenwriter, have made from it looks like a Big Little Book version of "Sanctuary." The pictures are vivid and blunt and the prose could hardly confuse a slow-reading 8-year-old, for whom the film is definitely not intended.The setting is rural Missouri in the early 1930's, before the repeal of Prohibition, and the story has to do with the kidnapping of a rich, frizzy-haired Kansas City girl (Kim Darby) by a gang of small-time hoods led by a homicidal old lady with a definite mustache (Irene Dailey) and her simpleminded son (Scott Wilson). He's the sort of young man who still counts the number of cookies he eats, as if the total number of cookies eaten in a lifetime were among the accounts kept in heaven, complains to Mom when the girl he wants to rape pushes him away, and giggles a lot when he shoots a friend in the face.If that doesn't put you off, then the manner in which Aldrich dramatizes his redemption theme certainly will: his Temple Drake, after going through a purgatory of humiliation and fear, discovers the meaning of love in the devotion of her idiot Popeye.One of these days, Aldrich is going to make a movie that is as great as it is full of sensation. Everything in "The Grissom Gang" is carried to an excess that draws attention to itself, and helps to deny what I hesitate to call its serious intentions.The period detail is quite marvelous and overdone, like the Rudy Vallee record on the soundtrack, the use of fly swatters, the costumes (including Miss Darby's white satin, Jean Harlow evening dress), the shots of gang members sitting around the poker table in shirtsleeves and gun holsters. Everybody sweats constantly, and nobody dies off-screen, always on-screen, in what the newspapers of the day used to describe as a hail of bullets.What's worse, Aldrich lets his performers, especially Miss Dailey and Wilson, behave as if they were in "The Beverley Hillbillies." They mug without shame, although I did like Miss Darby, an actress whom I haven't always admired in the past, as the sullen, quite pathetic victim, and Connie Stevens, as a beautiful and dim-witted moll any hood would be lucky to call his own.It may be, of course, that Aldrich's strengths are his excesses, which have a kind of disembodied energy in them, but in "The Grissom Gang" these excesses seem to contain a certain contempt, not just for the sensibilities of his audience (which I don't care about), but for his characters, whom, I think, he wants to take seriously. It's a very mixed up movie but one that is worth thinking about.

title: Symington Seeks Secret Session on U.S. Laos Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 Senator Stuart Symington said tonight that he would ask for a secret session of the Senate to review the American in volvement in the war in Laos.

title: Film Society Begins Children's Series Today at Tully Hall
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting the first of its new series of "Movies for Kids" programs today at Alice Tully Hall. All seats are reserved, and tickets are priced at $2 each, obtainable by mail or at the hall at Broadway and 65th Street. The films have been selected generally for youngsters upwards of 6 years old. The holiday-weekend batch of pictures is as follows:"Hugo and Josephine," today at 11 A.M., is a treat for everybody, a small, gentle masterpiece from Sweden, Exquisitely photographed in color, it shows two children in their private kingdom of nature and their relationship with a wise giant of a guardian."Vacation in the Clouds," today at 3 P.M., is only middling. This Czechoslovak import about three farm youngsters and a helicopter is scenic but a bit contrived and precious. The kids themselves should spot this soon enough. The color is only fair."My Side of the Mountain," tomorrow at 3 P.M., is first-rate viewing for the youngsters, as a spunky boy proves he can live alone in the Canadian wilderness. The tone is gentle but sturdy, the color and the settings are lovely and young Teddy Eccles is an appealing hero."The Big Store," Monday at 11 A.M., is not tip-top Marx Brothers, but this 1941 romp does let the four clowns run wild frequently and hilariously. The chaos should suffice.Eight short subjects totaling 90 minutes and including adventure and animated selections, comprise the program scheduled for Monday afternoon at 3 P.M.

title: Gary Teachers Vote Strike
description: GARY, Ind., May 28 (UPI) Gary school teachers voted today to strike next week in protest of new school board policies. The teachers were ob jecting to the board's decision to suspend seniority status in order to move teachers from school to school to achieve racial balance.

title: Kabi Laretei, a Pianist, Dares Play Hammerklavier Sonata
description: There have been famous pianists who refused through out their careers to play the Hammerklavier Sonata in public, but kbi Laretei is not one of that prudent group, The young, Estonianborn, woman not only took on the goliath of Beethoven sonatas in her Alice Tully Hall recital on Thursday night but prelud ed her program with it.

title: 2 New Soviet Satellites
description: MOSCOW, May 28 (UPI)  The Soviet Union launched to day its second unmanned Cos mos earth satellite in two days, the official press agency, Tass, said. No details were given on the mission of the satellites, Cosmos 423 and Cosmos 424. Tass said the equipment aboard both was functioning normally.

title: Trees Are Uprooted for Pavilion
description: With its roots wrapped neatly in burlap and rope, a pin oak tree was hauled from behind the Metropolitan Mu seum of Art and transplanted nearby yesterday as work men continued to clear the site of the museum's Lehman Pavilion, to be built this summer.

title: Pullman Predicts a Gain
description: Samuel B. Casey Jr., presi dent of Pullman, Inc., told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday that the company's secondquarter earn ings should be somewhat better tha a year ago. He said May freightcar orders were brisk.

title: Court Upholds Nun In Berrigan Inquiry
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 28 The Government suffered an other setback today in its con spiracy case against the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and others.

title: Catholic Order Meeting on Mozambique Pullout
description: ROME, May 28Leaders of the White Fathers, a Roman Catholic order engaged in Af rican missions, met here today to discuss the consequences of their decision to pull out of Portugal's East African terri tory of Mozambique.

title: BMW Lifts Auto Prices  To Reflect Rise in Mark
description: The Hoffman Motors Corpora tion, the United States distrib utor of BMW cars, said yester day that it was informing its dealers of a price increase of 3 per cent to reflect the recent rise in value of the German mark in relation to the dollar.

title: UConn Pitcher Leader
description: STORRS, Conn., May 28 (AP) A University of Connecticut left  hander, Brian Ilerosian, leads the nation's major colic pitchers with an earned run average of 0.63, according, to statistics released today. The sophomore has pitched 72 in nings and given up five earned runs.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: LAS PALMAS, Spain, May 28 (UPI)  Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark last night in the eighth game of their quarterfinal match, gaining an other chance at survival.

title: WITNESS IN SLAYINGS IS SEEKING RELEASE
description: Clarence Lee, the 18yearold Brooklyn student being held in Civil Jail in $50,000 bail as a material witness in the slaying of two patrolmen last Friday night, sought a writ of habeas corpus yesterday to obtain his release.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 600 Stage Wildcat Strike At 20 Jersey Bell Offices
description: JERSEY CITY, May 28 (AP)  Approximately 600 repair men and installers staged a wildcat strike at 20 New Jersey Bell Telephone Company facil ities here and in Union City today after 300 of the men were refused admittance be cause they wore antiBell T shirts.

title: Legislators Dissatisfied With Stewart Field Plan
description: ALBANY, May 28A group of state legislators who rep resent districts in and around Stewart Airport said today that the Governor's plan for development of the field into a commercial jetport still was not acceptable to them.

title: Mariner 9 Ready
description: The launching of a second Soviet spaceship toward Mars has applied added pressure on the American launching team preparing Mariner 9 for lift off at 6:21 P.M. today.

title: U.S. Gold Imports Up in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (Reu ters)  United States gold im ports totalled $20,722,637 in April, up slightly from March imports of $19,983,954, the Commerce Department report ed tonight.

title: Albany's War on Welfare
description: In the declaration of legislative intent which forms the preamble to the new residency requirement for wel fare eligibility, the State Legislature in Albany in effect blames the poor for everything from inadequate housing to air pollution. The logic seems to be that the poor must therefore be denied welfare benefits until they have lived in New York State at least a year. This law is not only meanspirited; it applies to such a small proportion welfare recipients as to be almost meaningless.

title: MRS. CHARLES PARR
description: CHESTER, Conn., May 28 Mrs. Ruth Butler Parr, a poet and shortstory writer, died yesterday in her home at Strait Road. Her age was 86. She was the wife of former Connecticut State Senator Charles McKew Parr.

title: Regents Recommend Increase In Aid for Nonpublic Schools
description: ALBANY, May 28The State Board of Regents today urged additional state financial aid for nonpublic schools.

title: REA AND KOUVOLO OF PITT TRIUMPH IN I.C.4A TRACK
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 28  Pittsburgh as an I.C. 4A track and field champion?

title: JAMES D. KENNEDY, EXKING KULLEN AIDE
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., May 28James D. Kennedy, who be came active in supermarket expansion early in the century on Long Island, died yesterday at his home at 87 Garden City Avenue. He was 78 years old.

title: LOSS CONTINUES FOR J. P. STEVENS
description: J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., the nation's second largest publicly owned textile producer, contin ued to show a deficit in the second fiscal quarter, thereby increasing the loss for the six months ended May 1, according to its report issued yesterday. Burlington Industries is the largest producer.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Busing To Integrate Schools in Pontiac
description: DETROIT, May 28  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld to day an order to force Pontiac, Mich., into massive busing to desegregate schools, although there was no formal segrega tion policy in Pontiac as there is in some parts of the South.

title: New Balanchine Ballet Shifts Bow to Jane 17
description: The premiere of PAMTGG, George Balanchine's new work for the New York City Ballet, will take place on June 17 instead of next Thursday.

title: $5 Exacta Pays $7,048
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 28 (AP)Long shots ran 1, 2 in the fourth race today at Holly wood Park, combining for $7,048.50for$5 exacta pay off, second highest in Califor nia history. King Rogers won and paid $37.60. Mint Agent, 641, was second.

title: Kadota Scores Knockout
description: TOKYO, May 28 (AP)The Orient lightweight champion, Shinichi Kadota of Japan, knocked out the South Korean challenger, Yung Chul Chuo, in the fifth round today to retain his title. Radota weighed 134 pounds and Yung 134.

title: JOB SAFETY RULES TAKE EFFECT TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 New standards regulating the joh safety of an estimated 57 million United States workers will take effect tomorrow with their publication in The Federal Register.

title: Late Rally Spurs Amex List as Volume Declines
description: A late rally pushed up prices on the American Stock Ex change yesterday, the index gaining 0.08 to close at 25.71. However, volume fell to 3, 205,710 shares from 3,449,590 shares on Thursday.

title: Rohr Announces Talks on Buying Greyhound Unit
description: Merger News

title: They Became Senate's First Female Pages and Discovered Women's Lib
description: WASHINGTONMy ideas on women's liberation have changed a good deal since this experience, said 16 yearold Ellen McConnell, who is one of three female Senate pages sworn in recently after months of Congres sional fretting. Before all this delay, I guess I wasn't too sympathetic because I hadn't found any discrimi nation in my life. But now I understand why women get so angry.

title: ROBERT MIDDLETON DOMINATES CONCERT
description: Robert Middleton had the lion's share of a Vassar College faculty concert in Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night with good reason.

title: Ransom in Food Is Set For Consul in Argentina
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, May 28 (AP)A demand for a ransom of $62,500 in food to poor families in Rosario in exchange for the release of the kidnapped honorary Brit ish Consul, Stanley Sylves ter, will be met by the meat packiffil plant of which Syl vester was director, plant sources said today.

title: RIGHT TO REFUSE MEDICINE UPHELD
description: The United Slates Court of Appeals, in a 2to1 decision, has upheld as constitution al the right of a patient to re fuse medical treatment because of religious beliefs.

title: CHIPS RAFFERTY, ACTOR, 62, DEAD
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 28 Chips Rafferty, Australia's bestknown film actor, died in a street here of a heart attack last night. He was 62 years old.

title: GOVERNOR ASSAILS CITY RENT OUTCRY AS A CRUEL HOAX
description: Governor Rockefeller charged yesterday that city officials and others were engaging in what appears to be an or ganized campaign of cruel misrepresentations of his measure to end rent control of apartments here as they be come vacant.

title: Florida Aide Opposes Extradition of DeMartinos
description: MIAMI, May 28  Deputy Attorney General Herbert T. Schwartz of Florida said today that he would recommend against any extradition moves by New York courts in the case of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino.

title: ' Escape From the Planet of the Apes' Proves Entertaining
description: Nobody is going to believe it, but I must say anyway that Don Taylor's "Escape From the Planet of the Apes," which opened yesterday at the Astor, the Juliet 2 and the 34th Street theaters, is one of the better new movies in town, and better in a genrescience-fictionthat at the crucial middle level where the history of movies is made, if not written, has recently been not so much bad as invisible."Escape From the Planet of the Apes" takes place more or less in the present, 2,000 years before the end of the world by nuclear explosion set off during a battle between human beings and their masters, gorillas ("Beneath the Planet of the Apes" 1970).Three scientists, pacifist chimpanzees, escape the general destruction by traveling back through time in the very space ship with which Colonel Taylor had made his surprising journey forward not so long before ("Planet of the Apes" 1968).They thus bring with them not only the knowledge of mankind's doom, but also its very seed, for Zira, the female chimpanzee, is pregnant with the child whose name will eventually appear in the sacred histories as the first in rise up against the tyranny of people and assert the supremacy of the apes.As movie premises go, I think this is quite beautifulthough I am sure that in one variation or another it has been used beforeand its development in "Escape From the Planet of the Apes" does it considerable justice.Allowing for certain probable impossibilities (the film is much stronger in fiction than in scienceno drawback so far as I'm concerned) there is enough thought to support the kind of dramatic inevitability this particular form needs and allows.As in most monster movies, the subject finally is human guiltbut here rendered richly ambivalent, because the monsters are scarcely monstrous and the guilt is a function of unassailable strategic intelligence.It follows that the heavy, Dr. Otto Hasslein (Eric Braeden), should be the United State's President's science adviser. Though sinister, he, like the other human beings in the film, maintains a degree of credibility unusual in the movies, or in life.As the chimpanzee Corneliusagreeable, short-tempered, a bit too proud of his mind  Roddy McDowall seems to have evolved a performance designed as a tribute to the late Edward Everett Horton. Kim Hunter plays his wife, Zira, rather in the manner of your maiden aunt from Peoria, and like McDowall's, her characterization is hugely successful.Don Taylor's direction seems composed in equal parts of efficiency and tact, and with this material alone he earns his place among the just for every easy irony he avoids. There are certain remarkable moments (for example, the first shot of the chimpanzees' hotel room, especially prepared for their welcome to Los Angeles), but more often there is a sense of decent professionalism un-attracted to spectacular devices.By conservative estimate, the President of the United States turns out to be a weighty idiot in 90 per cent of all science fiction filmsand he seems to be in almost 90 per cent of all science fiction films.But in "Escape From the Planet of the Apes," William Windom's President is allowed to be urbane, wise, articulate and astute. And though I'm sure I'll never see his like again, I'll remember him as not the least of this film's graces.

title: British Aluminum Debut Faces World Glut
description: INVERGORDON, Scotland, May 25Britain's debut as a primary aluminum producer is being crimped by worldwide overcapacity in the metal.

title: BLACK CAUCUS PLANS FUNDRAISING DINNER
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 The congressional Black Cau cus will sponsor a $100aplate fundraising dinner June IS to raise money to hire a staff. The caucus is made up of Ihe 13 black members of the House of Representatives, all Demo crats.

title: SOUTHWIND TAKES JUNIOR JUMPOFF
description: DEVON, Pa., May 28James Hulick's Southwind moved into the lead for the junior jumper championship by winning the first class in a jumpoff today as the Devon Horse Show opened an eightday run. There will he no competition on Sun day.

title: A Crime Family's 65Year Journey Into Legitimacy
description: You can trust members of your own family first, relatives second, Sicilians third, Italians fourth, and forget about the rest of them. Giuseppe Lupollo

title: Czech Intellectuals Expect Tighter Curbs
description: LONDON, May 28When Gustav Husak, the leader of the Czechoslovak Communist party, addressed the party congress Tuesday, he did not make a statement on the arts. The intellectual commu nity in Prague let out a sigh of relief.

title: A Volunteer Army?
description: With the Selective Service extension bill now the pending business on the Senate floor, the handful of antiwar liberals who have opposed draft repeal are being challenged in open debate. Forced to reconcile their opposition to the Indochina war with their support of the system which is its prime source of unwilling manpower, the prodraft doves have developed an extensive ar ray of objections to repeal; a common theme has been the beneficial impact of draft eligibility as a stimulus to antiwar protest. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the bestknown opponent of ending the draft, articulated this con cern in a recent speech: It is unwise to insulate from the horrors of war middle and upper class Americans who might lead the pretest against sense less foreign adventures. I frankly would question, for example, whether the current pressure for deescalation of the Indochina war would be as great if young men from every social background were not threatened with service in that war.

title: La Guardia Jet Is Hijacked And Flown to the Bahamas
description: A man who said he had a large quantity of explosives strapped around his waist took control of an Eastern Airlines 727 jet in midair last night and, after landing and allowing the passengers to debark at La Guardia Airport, hijacked it to Nassau in the B??amas.

title: Angela Lansbury Joining With Brother in Sister
description: Thirtysix years ago in Lon don, Angela Lansbury played Little Red Riding Hood in a family Yuletide pantomime and her brother Edgar appeared as the Big Bad Wolf.

title: MRS. JOHN R. DAVIES
description: ALEXANDRIA. Va., May 28 Mrs. Ruby Hardy Davies, widow of Justice John R. Davies of the Municipal Court in New York, died today here at the age of 90.

title: Humble Gets Big Contract
description: The Defense Supply Agency announced yesterday that it had awarded $212.5million in contracts for 2.1 billion gallons of jet fuel. The Humble Oil Division of the Standard Oil Com pany (New Jersey) received a $25.3million contract, the largest single award.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The World
description: TEL AVIVNumerically, they were insignificantan extremist group of perhaps 50 youths who sprang from the anonymous squalor of Jerusalem's slums to clash with the Israeli police in the capital's Zion Square. Yet last week the group's name the Black Panthers  was on everyone's lips and Israel was un dergoing an extraordinary bout of soulsearching.

title: Congress and Foreign Policy
description: This Memorial Day weekend is a particularly appro priate time to consider the national mechanism which decides when young Americans shall be sent abroad fightand perhaps to diefor their country. That mech anism has been dominated by the President in recent decades but a new mood of greater foreign policy as sertiveness is now evident in Congress.

title: Sundancer D. takes Tornado Cup Pace at Yonkers, With Trader Hardin Next
description: YONKERS, May 29As Sun dancer D. $7,20 was pacing to a 2length victory over Trader Nardin in tonight's $10,000 Tornado Cup test for Class A1 standardbreds at Yonkers Raceway, some harness racing buffs must have wondered how a healthy Stella Frost might have fared in the onemile event.

title: Woodside to Get A New Memorial For War Victims
description: The community of Wood side, Queens, will receive a new war memorial and pub lic park tomorrow as part of its 48th observance of Memorial Day.

title: Car Accident Victim Found With Bullets in His Head
description: A 39year old Staten Island man was in fair condition yes terday after doctors discovered that in addition to injuries he had received Friday night in an automobile accident at South and Wall Streets he had been shot five or six times in the head.

title: Brooklyn Prep to Close After 64 Years
description: What does Joseph A. Cali fano Jr., the former special assistant to President Lyn don B. Johnson, have In com mon with John Dockery, the Jets' cornerback?

title: Suspicious Fire Damages Church in New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 29A 159yearold church here was heavily damaged to day by a blaze that a Fire De partment official termed sus picious.

title: Fishbach Tennis Case Gets a Hearing
description: Eastern tennis officials are buzzing over the disqualifica tion of 17yearold Mike Fish bach in the semifinals of the Eastern men's hardcourt cham pionship last Saturday. His case comes before the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's rules committee a week from tomorrow.

title: Television
description: THE hot topic is suddenly drug addiction. It's not new, just hot. Ad dicts in the city, in su burbia, in middle America, in Vietnamcome the headlines and the analyses, and it's time for instant crisis and breastbeating. Of course the problem has been gestating in the public arena for years but perhaps it is best to let bygones of official adminis trative blindness be bygones. Perhaps.

title: FOOTBALL LOOP SET FOR ITS 10TH YEAR
description: The Atlantic Coast Football League will open its 10th sea son on Aug. 27.

title: U.N. Group Wants PapuaNew Guinea Independent by '80
description: SYDNEY, Australia, May 29 A United Nations survey mis sion has recommended inde pendence by 1980 for Papua and New Guinea, a strategic and largely primitive island area administered by Australia.

title: House Tour: Perfect Chance to Poke Around Stranger's Home
description: A matronly visitor from the suburbs strolled into an East Side apartment the other day, took one look at the brightly decorated, patternsagainstprints living room and whispered to a friend: You'd think they'd get a nervous breakdown living here!

title: WITNESSES OPPOSE ALEUTIAN HBLAST
description: ANCHORAGE, May 29The Atomic Energy Commission concluded today three days of environmental impact hearings in which almost every witness not employed by it testified in opposition to a projected under ground nuclear test.

title: The U.S.S.R. Gains in Egypt
description: The new fifteenyear SovietEgyptian treaty of friend ship and cooperation goes far enough toward cementing the ties between the two states to raise questions whether Egypt may be on the way to becoming another Soviet satellite. Certainly any thought that the U.S.S.R. might soon be dislodged from its Middle Eastern foothold is ended for the time being.

title: Klecatsky Wins Two Races and Shares Title in Third
description: While some judges worried about moving violations and others fretted about parking violations, Dr. Harry Klecatsky took time out from his duties at New Rochelle Hospital yes terday and prescribed highest individual honors for himself at the 103d annual Memorial Day rowing regatta.

title: Miss Elizabeth G. Jacobs Married
description: SHREVEPORT, La., May 29Miss Elizabeth Grey Ja cobs and George Frazier 4th were married here this af ternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Byron Ja cobs, grandparents of the bride. The Rev. James C. Buckner of St. Paul's Epis copal Church performed the ceremony.

title: Souvenir Card for NAPEX '71
description: NAPEX '71, the National Philatelic Exhibition held in Washington the weekend of May 2123, was provided with a Bureau of Engraving and Printing souvenir card (illustrated) that was devoted to Washing ton scenes based on the vignettes from three 1950 stamps that commemorated the capital's sesquicentennial anniversary.

title: Stamps
description: ON May 17, E. T. Klas sens, a governor of the United States Postal Service, unveiled at New York Hospital the design of a 6c commemorative stamp that is to be imprinted on forthcoming postal card. The date of release and site of is suance are to be announced.

title: A marble statue at Harvard, but no biography till now
description: To generations of American lawyers, Joseph Story has been an unavoid able but shadowy figure (shadowy in part because overshadowed by his con temporary, Chief Justice John Mar shall). Story is the author of Martin v. Hunter's Lessee, as fundamental to our constitutional structure as Mar bury v. Madison but no triumph of style or concision. Marshall had an interest in some of the land that was in issue in the Martin case, dis qualified himself and couldn't seize it by the throat and dispose of it in one of those opinions that evoke the image of the king of the jungle exe cuting his prey.

title: DAHL OF COLUMBIA A 2SPORT CAPTAIN
description: Dwayne Dahl and Larry Las off have been elected cocap tains of the 197172 Columbia University track team.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: REAGAN IS BESET WITH PROBLEMS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 29  While conservative Re publicans speak of him fondly at the national level as an alternative to the renomina tion of President Nixon, Gov. Ronald Reagan's troubles con tinue to mount at home.
