description: To the Editor:

title: Janet Margreta Kendall Is Fiancee
description: HOLDEN, Mass., May 29  Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Wilcox have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wilcox's daughter, Miss Janet Mar greta Kendall, to Tristram Coffin Gaillard. He is the son of Mrs. Merrill K. Lind say of New York and North Branford, Conn., and the late Theodore L. Gaillard.

title: Wanted: Bright, Motivated M.B.A.'s
description: Sonic 1971 graduates don't know that the job market has been tight.

title: The Outer City: U.S. In Suburban Turmoil
description: This is the first of five articles based on a twoweek trip by five correspondents of The New York Times through metropolitan areas, exploring the growth, com plexities and attitudes of suburban America.

title: Outwit The Plant Pests
description: BY USING effective nontoxic meth ods and materials, gardeners can outwit plant pests. It will take some imagination and ingenuity. One approach, companionate plant ing, encourages you to become a keen observer of plant relationships, since certain plants bestow protection upon others. If you put garlic around the base of your favorite rosebushes, you may find that the roses develop hearty resistance against blackspot, mildew and aphids. Add clumps of parsley around the same rosebushes, and rose beetles may not come into the vicinity.

title: Bearnarth's Diet: Fine Yarns
description: Larry Bearnarth, a New York Met from the bad old days, is a Milwaukee Brewer now although it would take a microscopic study of daily box scores to prove it.

title: Rockets Kill 12 at Danang
description: SAIGON, Sunday, May 30 (Reuters)  Twelve civilians were killed and 11 were wounded when North Viet namese rockets struck five houses in the northern city of Danang this morning, the South Vietnamese command reported.

title: What the Little Fellow Says to the Teamsters Is What Counts
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. IT was as if Jimmy Hoffa never had gone away. The only deci sion anybody cared about at the quarterly meeting of the Teamsters executive board this month was his. That was how it always had been through 10 years in which little Mis ter Big maintained a steely grip on the steering wheel of the giant truck union, the country's biggest and strongest labor organization. And that was how it was now, as the caretakers Hoffa left in charge when he went off to Federal prison four years ago met at the plush Diplomat Hotel and Country Club here to draw up a slate of officers for elec tion at the Teamsters' convention in Miami Beach July 5

title: Why Make St. Matthew Dance? For the Fun of It
description: EARLY In a fidgety, color  splattered, jubi lant and most enjoy able new rock musical, Godspell, at the Cherry Lane, a quotation from Buck minster Fuller pops up that May have a great deal to do with the unleashedif as yet not altogether formeden ergies that are bit by bit re making the contemporary theater.

title: EAST AFRICA BLOC FUNCTIONS AGAIN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 20 A deadlock that has threatened the continued existence of the East African Community since Uganda's military coup d'tat last January appears to have been broken.

title: Koreans Say Opposition Gains Will Help Democratic System
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 29 Hopes for development of democracy based on checks and balances are rising in South Korea as a result of this week's general elections.

title: Miss Straley Fiancee Of Michael G. Kirsch
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 29  Mr. and Mrs. J. Bryan Straley of Westbury and Spencer, W. Va., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Lou Straley, to Michael Ger ald Kirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer A. Kirsch of Glen Cove.

title: Major Tennis Event Slated
description: TOWSON, Md. (AP)Bigtime tennis will return to the Balti more area with a threeday tournament Jan. 7 through 9 at Towson State College.

title: Patriots Sign 2 Players
description: BOSTON, May 29 (AP)  The New England Patriots signed today a receiver, Charlie Fra zier, and a guard, Angelo Loukas.

title: Athletics Beat Red Sox, 12 to 8;
description: BOSTON, May 29  Light hitting Dick Green cracked pair of home runs, the second pulling Oakland from behind in the sixth inning, and the A's outslugged the Boston Red Sox, 128, today four in the fifth, took a 75 lead in the sixth when Oakland erupted for four runs to go ahead, 97.

title: New Recreation Board Sworn In in Brooklyn
description: The city's first Recreation Center Advisory Board, com posed of community residents, was sworn into office last week by City Recreation Com missioner Joseph W. Halper at the St. John's Park Recrea tion Center on Prospect Place in Brooklyn.

title: Tokyo Finds Life Without Cars Is Heaven
description: TOKYO, May 29  Ten months after Tokyo inaugu rated a series of pedestrian paradises, shopkeepers in the affected areas have mixed feelings, but the pedestrians themselves remain ecstatic.

title: A Gentle, Rumpled French Biologist Says There's More to Life Than Pure Chance
description: VILLE d'AVRAY, France Like Albert Einstein, Jean Rostand cannot accept that Man is only the product of a roll of the dice in a uni versal game of chance.

title: The Rotten Corps
description: In 1957 a small group of McKinsey employes decided to initiate an infor mal Christmas gettogether. Dubbing themselves the rotten corps, they met for libations at a local bar.

description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Mary Shea to John W. Mulcahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Mulcahy of Yonkers, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Shea.

title: CENSUS COMPARES 195070 FAMILIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The average American family is a little older, a little smaller and has considerably more in come and education than it did 20 years ago, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Missouri Five Gets Aide
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., May 29 (AP)  Don Kelley, a former Ohio State athlete who coached fresh man basketball at Iowa State last season, was named an as sistant coach of the staff at the University of Missouri today.

title: N.B.A.A.B.A. CONTEST DISAPPOINTS CHARITY
description: HOUSTON, May 29 (UPI) The first N.B.A.A.B.A. AllStar game was a disappointment at the gate and to the charity for which it was aimed. But post game reviews today indicated that the 21 stars and their pen sion funds fared very well.

title: The Peace Movement Is Using The Wrong Strategy
description: IN the spring of 1971 light really did appear at the end of the bloody tunnel in Vietnam.

title: Science
description: OxygenO2is a colorless gas whose presence on the surface of the earth sustains human life. The addition of a single atom of oxygen cre ates ozone, a faintly bluish gas whose presence in the stratosphere protects all forms of life from the lethal ultra violet rays of the sun. There has been new concern of late that this ozone barrier might be seriously eroded by a new technological development the supersonic transport.

title: Miss Tererizio Becomes Bride
description: TENAFLY, N.J., May 29 Miss Nancy Ann Terenzio, daughter of Peter B. Terenzio, executive vice president and director of Roosevelt Hospital in New York, and Mrs. Ter enzio, was married here this morning to George Britton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Britton of Washington.

title: Meadowland in West Virginia Being Made Into a Race Track
description: About Motor Sports

title: 1782 Handbill Sold for $275; Focused on Brooklyn Lottery
description: A stained and somewhat creased 18thcentury handbill that may have been one of Brooklyn's earliest news papers was auctioned last week for $275, a prize to an anonymous collector bidding in a sale of Americana at the ParkeBernet Galleries.

title: Utah Five Edges Soviet
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 29 (AP)A team of Utah allstars scored a 9491 basketball vic tory over a touring team from the Soviet Union tonight. The defeat was the first suffered by the Russians after eight straight victories in America. It also was the last game in the tour.

title: A maxicalorie masterpiece
description: Once in awhile certain dishes in wellknown restaurants gain an eminence all their own. This is true of the incredibly rich chocolate cake of New York's Coach House restaurant. It took a good deal of persuasion to get the recipe, and caloriecounters may not thank us for our efforts. Note well, however, it takes a skilled hand and several hoursto make this seductive masterpiece.

title: Elizabeth Nelson Wed to A. J. Coppola Jr.
description: HARRISON, N.J., May 29 Miss Elizabeth Suzan Nel son and Alfred J. Coppola Jr. were married here this after noon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great by the Rev. Leonard D. DiFalco. A reception was held at the White Plains Hotel, where the bride is ex ecutive secretary to the owner and general manager.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Perhaps it would have happened any way, but baseball's expansion from the 16team format it had a dozen years ago to the 24team setup it has today might have been delayed interminably if it had not been for the hot foot touched off by Branch Rickey, a stubborn old man with a heretical idea. The Mahatma was smarter than all other baseball men, even Walter O'Malley of the Dodgers, and any threat he posed to the establishment had to be treated with grave apprehension.

title: Reds Gets Foster of Giants For Duffy and Farm Hurler
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 (AP)The San Francisco Giants traded a rookie outfielder, George Foster, to the Cincinnati Reds today. They got an infield er, Frank Duffy, and a minor league pitcher, Vern Geishert, in return.

title: Samuels Calls AntiOTB Statements by Heads of Pro Sports Unrealistic
description: Pete Rozelle, Bowie Kuhn and Clarence Campbell are living in a fantasy world, Howard J. Samuels suggested here yester day.

title: Chess
description: THE new cycle of Candidates' matches is now under way, and from it will emerge not only new challenger to world cham pion Boris Spassky, but doubtless also some new evidence to decide the ques tion whether this kind of competition is the best way to select that challenger. It is not generally realized that this question has two parts: first, it must be decided whether match play is the fairest way to decide who most deserves a crack at the championship, and sec ondly, whether match play produces the best chessthe kind of games that contribute most to chess as a source of enjoyment.

title: Miss Jacobatros to Wed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Jacobatros, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Jacobatros, to Peter S. Kalikow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Kalikow of New York. A June 17 wed ding is planned, Miss Jacoba tros's father was president of the Standard Steel Sales Company. The future bride groom is president of the Momo Corporation, machin ists in Carona, Queens. His father is founder and chair man of H. J. Kalikow Com pany, builders and develop ers, and chairman of the Kal ikow Construction Company, both in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Namath: A MostWaned Fella
description: In a survey of National Foot ball League coaches, Joe Namath of the New York Jets emerged as the most coveted quarterback in pro football.

title: Miss Dunham Becomes Bride Of H.A. Blachly
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., May 29 Mss Elizabeth Anne Dunham and Hugh Alexander Blachly, singers with a mutual in terest in Renaissance music, were married here this noon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Chapel in the Woods, where a huge stone served as the altar and the wedding party sat on wooden benches sur rounded by hemlocks and dogwoods. The Rev. Arthur Hargate performed the cere mony.

title: Orioles Win, 118, From Twins
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 29Brooks Robinson slammed four hits, driving in five runs today, and the Baltimore Ori oles defeated the Minnesota Twins, 118.

title: In Soo Hwang, Yale Coach, Heads National Judo Unit
description: In Soo Hwang, Yale's coach of judo, has been elected presi dent of the National Intercol legiate Judo Association.

title: White House Book Prices Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)The White House His torical Association has an nounced that the price of the three books it publishes for sale to White House visitors, and others will be increased by 25 per cent in book effec tive Tuesday.

title: RIG RED TRIUMPHS OVER ARMY, 1716
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 29 Bob Shaw's third goal with 2 minutes 7 seconds remaining gave Cornell a 1716 victory over previously undefeated Army in a semifinal match of the First National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship tournament at Michie Stadium today.

title: For Young Readers
description: The children in E. L. Konigsburg's Altogether, One at a Time may be short in stature, but they are long on mental acuity. As spies in the adult camp, they understand its inhabitants almost too well. Every one was more ready than Mother was, remarks the narrator of In viting Jason. She put on a bright dress and makeup, but I knew what was going on underneath both. However, this very knowingness can sometimes work against its pos sessors, the affluent but not affable heirs of modernity; they are vulner able to certain shocks and ironies that might pass right over the heads of the more naive. One of the best of these stories, The Night of the Leonids, for example, fea tures a stargazing expedition with a chic grandmother who is light years away from littleoldladyhood. In it the 10yearold narrator discovers disconcertingly that acting like grownup has its price as well as its privileges.

title: Art
description: LET'S hope I'm wrong and that repeated visits will show that the Amer ican Museum of Nat ural History's new Hall of the Peoples of the Pacific is not Vie disaster that it seems on first acquaintance. Right now I feel that it has set the tech nique of artanthropological installation back 50 years.

title: National Peace Corps Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) President Nixon proclaimed today the week of May 30 to June 5 as National Peace Corps Week, marking the 10th anni versary of an agency that has sent more than 45,000 volun teers to nearly 70 developing nations,

title: ALWORTH, HAYES YEARN FOR SPURS
description: Tom Landry, coach of the Dallas Cowboys, has said that Lance Alworth and Bob Hayes could give the Dallas Cowboys the No. 1 passreceiving com bination in the National Foot ball League. But he added that the Cowboys will have to give, too, in the neighborhood of $125,000.

title: Foley Will Be Enshrined In Holy Cross Hall of Fame
description: Jack (The Shot) Foley, the most prolific scorer in Holy Cross and New England college basketball history, has been elected to the Holy Crosa Var sity Club Hall of Fame.

title: FRESH AIR DONORS ARE ON INCREASE
description: Every year since 1912 one man has sent three $10 bills to the Fresh Air Fund to help slum children spend two weeks in the country during the sum mer. This year his envelope arrived with $25.

title: Traffic to Cape Cod Blocked As Tenants Protest Evictions
description: BOURNE, Mass., May 29 Chanting Housing now, more than 300 marchers caused a traffic jam today on the Saga more Bridge spanning the Cape Cod Canal. They promised to return July 4 if state and local officials failed to aid lowin come families who are being evicted from their homes to make room for tourists.

title: The World
description: LONDONAsk a waitress or the man in the pub about the Common Market, and chances are you will get a negative an swer: Oh, I hope we don't do that, sir. I was in Italy last sum mer, and I ate the peaches, and I didn't like the whole thing. Then what are you going to do about New Zealand? They must keep us out.

title: Recordings
description: RAHSAAN, Rahsaan, they say repeatedly, as they file slowly into the college gym nasium. Rahsaan refers to Rahsaan Roland Kirk who used to be plain old Roland Kirk, jazzman extraordinaire, before he became Super black. Starting with the Newport Jazz Festival (in that infamous summer of 1969), he broke through to the great young white au dience while achieving major prominence with the new black audience. At Newport, he had them dancing in the aisles; but this was a new audience here at Colby Col lege for a recent concert by Kirk, and most of them had never heard him before.

title: Nixon to Name Judge
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) President Nixon, has an nounced that he plans to nom inate Roy L. Stephenson of Des Moines to be United States Appeals Court Judge for the eighth circuit, which includes Arkansas, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North and South Dakota.

title: INDIANA VICTOR IN BIG TEN TRACK
description: IOWA CITY, May 29 (AP) Indiana's Hoosiers, amassing 19 points in the 220yard dash, re tained their team title while six individual meet records were set and one tied in the 71st Big Ten outdoor track and field championships today.

title: COL. ALFRED BYRNE OF NATIONAL GUARD
description: Col. Alfred S. Byrne, who re tired last January as chief of staff of the 42d Infantry Divi sion, New York National Guard, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 645 East 14th Street. He was 55 years old.

title: Gardens
description: THE easytogrow herba ceous peonies make a marvelous splash in May when they are laden with big, beautiful blooms. And the plants, with strong, handsome and inter estingly divided leaves, re main decorative throughout the growing season.

title: Movies
description: DIRECTOR Abraham Po lonsky, who finally broke through Holly wood's blacklist two years ago with the highly regarded Tell Them Willie Boy Is Here, is making up for lost time in a big way. His latest feature, Romance of a Horsethief, will soon be released by Allied Artists. It stars Yul Brynner, Eli Wallach, Jane Birkin and Lainie Kazan. And now he is busy planning three more projects, the first of which will be Mario and the Ma gician, based on Thomas Mann's 1930 novella about a magician who exerts an evil influence on the inhabi tants of an Italian village and is finally killed by one of his debased victims.

title: How the 2d BestInformed Man in the White House Briefs the 2d WorstInformed Group in Washington
description: WASHINGTON.

title: Traditionalist Vigil At Vatican Protests Vernacular Mass
description: ROME, May 29  Several hundred Roman Catholic tradi tionalists from various Euro pean countries gathered today in St. Peter's Square for an all night vigil to pray for the church's return to the Latin form of the mass.

title: BenGurion Tells U.S. Jewish Youth To Study in Israel
description: American Jewish youth can achieve a thorough Hebrew education beyond the Bar Mitz vah age13only by living in Israel, according to David Ben Gurion.

title: STUDENTS' RIGHTS GIVEN IN SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 29 The Suffolk County Human Rights Commission has drawn up a comprehensive student rights directive outlining the responsibilities and rights of students in the county's public schools.

title: Military School to Close
description: ALTON, Ill., May 29 (UPI) Western Military Academy will close permanently next week after 92 years of operation, Col. Ralph B. Jackson, the superin tendent, said today.

title: Stephen Foster, You'd Never Recognize De Camptown Races
description: SHLAND, Va.De Camptown race track five miles long, Oh! doodah day goes the song, and although the course here is much smaller, that shortcoming is more than made up for by the boisterous clamor, the color and the high jinks of some 20,000 spec tators swarming over a sweet, green Virginia hillside. The 18th annual run ning of Ashland's Camptown,Racesin 1952 the town revived the tradition cel ebrated in Stephen Foster's songtook place a couple of Saturdays ago on a livestock farm outside of town and was observed by a mile of people spraw ling, squatting, lying and curled togeth er on blankets, drinking beer and grain alcohol Purple Jesuses, singing in har mony, devouring several tons of South ern fried chicken, the couples caressing, the children chasing, the oldsters tip pling, and everybody, at 25minute in tervals, jumping up to cheer the horses in the succession of seven races.

title: Hijacker Is Held on Air Piracy Charge
description: A former New York police man, seized in the Bahamas as he stepped off an Eastern Air lines 727 jet he had hijacked Friday night with a weaponless but terrifying bluff, was re turned to the city on air piracy charges yesterday.

title: SCHOOLS FIND AID IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 29  This city's 275 public schools will apparently open on sched ule Tuesday after the holiday under an emergency borrowing plan worked out with 11 major local banks.

title: Crash at Start: 20 Injured
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 29A missing flagpole was the reason for the accident at the start of the 500mile race today, ac cording to the driver of the pace car, a local Dodge dealer.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: In the year 1936. a 20year old named Morris Katz enrolls at the University of Minne sota. Object: matrimony with a rich, ugly, Jewish girl. This simple intention proliferates an uninterrupted Chain of rich jokes, ugly jokes, Jewish jokes, marriage jokes and poor jokes. Mr. Shulman has been manu facturing gag humor since be fore Portnoy knew he had a complaint, and his fans will know what to expect.

title: Television
description: THE bachelor apartment Tony Randall shares with his costar Jack Klugman on The Odd Couple, ABC's increasingly suc cessful TV translation from the original Neilsimon, veers from Downbeat Slobby the lifestyle of Klugman's character Oscar, a rumpled whatthehell sports writerto Uptight Sleek, reflecting the compulsions of Randall's Felix, an over wrought photographer with an insati able need to fluff up pillows and empty ashtrays.

title: JOHNSON SCHOOL GETS SLOW START
description: AUSTIN, Tex.They want elegancenice, neat, closed systems, John A. Gronouski, the former. Postmaster General and Ambassador to Poland, was saying of political science schol ars the other day. But this is a messy world we live in. We've got to turn out kids who are not afraid to tackle prob lems.

title: REVELLI CONDUCTS MICHIGAN U. BAND
description: A significant era in American band music came to an end in Carnegie Hall on Friday night when William D. Revelli led the University of Michigan Sym phony Band in his last concert with it prior to his retirement from the University after an illustrious 36year career there.

title: Coins
description: THE independent Repub lic of Haiti has com memorated its discovery by Columbus (Dec. 6, 1492) by issuing a pure silver coin with the denomination of five gourdes. The 1970 dated specimen, measuring 30 mil limeters in diameter and weighing 23.52 grams, is be ing minted in frosted proof condition as a speciality for collectors.

title: Education
description: Across the nation there are increasing efforts to re view and perhaps change the ways in which teachers are trained, accredited and appointed. In New York City these efforts have focused on a challenge to the Board of Examiners, which for 73 years has passed on the qualifications of all teachers and most administratorsa total of 60,000 at present In the huge system.

title: Duffy, Fox and John Triumph in Y.R.A. Regatta
Cyrus connects the dots of his past
description: Like his two earlier novels  A Smuggler's Bible, which appeared in 1966, and, Hind's Kidnap: A Pastoral on Familiar Airs, published in 1969Joseph McElroy's Ancient History: A Paraphase is a strange, labyrinthine creation. Described by the narrator (named Cyrus, after the founder of the Persian Empire) as my writing, my confession ... my Memorial Span, my parallel lives, the work, which runs unbroken for over three hundred pages, undivided into chapters or clearly distinguish able parts, represents that middle aged man's determined effort to fol low out the thread of his past with out losing his place in the present, to create a charged field in which experiences of past and present be come equivalent.

title: NEW FIGHTING REPORTED AT GETTYSBURGH & ANTIETAM  A DISPATCH FROM THE FIELD.
Recordings
description: THIS IS A RECORDING: Lily Tomlin (Polydor). The second side of This Is a Recording, which actually is a recording of a performance by Lily Tomlin at the Ice House in Pasadena, California, opens with what is presumably a bit of ad lib wit addressed by Miss Tomlin to some un fortunate member of her au dience, to wit:

title: ARCHITECTS HONOR SCHOOL IN ILLINOIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)  The American Institute of Architects announced today the selection of the Crow Island School, Winnetka, Ill., to re ceive its 25year award.

title: New York
description: The Mayor of New York, John V. Lindsay, was invited to In dianapolis last week to share his wisdom and experience with sev eral hundred dignitaries from around the world at the Interna tional Conference of Cities. He was not, however, invited to Al bany to share anything with Gov ernor Rockefeller and the hand ful of men who were deciding his city's future. Last week, among other things, they opted to end rent control and reduce welfare payments in his cityand they are still secretly debating how much money New York will have to spend in the coming year.

title: 16 Yachts Round Block Island in Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 29 One of the slower Storm Trysail Club Block Island races was in progress today as only 16 cruis ing yachts of the 148 that began the 200mile passage last eve ning off the Larchmont (N. Y.) Yacht Club were reported round the island by 6 P.M.

title: Early Days of Golf in Catskills Recalled by Longo
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., May 29When I first came to the Catskills in 1932, said Tony Longo, the old pro, most of the guests didn't know a putting iron from a Remington rifle. Golf? They thought people were nuts to walk five miles just to hit a little white ball.

title: Kvalheim Takes TwoMile Run In 8:30.2 at Coast Track Meet
description: MODESTO, Calif., May 29 (UPI)Arne Kvalhelm of Nor way and Rod Milburn of South ern University were the indi vidual stars today at the Califfornia relays.

title: Gallup Poll Asserts 81% in U.S. Use Automobiles to Get to Work
description: American workers spend an average of 16 minutes each way going to and from work, and 81 per cent of them do their traveling by automobile, the Gallup Poll asserts.

title: Miss Wilber of U.S. Leads Moscow Archery Tourney
description: MOSCOW, May 29 (AP) Doreen Wilber of the United States moved into first place today in the women's overall standing of the Moscow inter national archers tournament.

title: ANDREW SCHARPS
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 29 Andrew Scharps, a senior vice president in charge of invest ment portfolios for the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany, died of a heart ailment today in White Plains Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 32 Heathcote Road.

title: REPORT ASKS CITY TO SUPPLY HEROIN FOR CONTROL PLAN
description: A city program to provide heroin to drug addicts under going rehabilitation has been proposed to Mayor Lindsay by his Narcotics Control Council after strong disagreement with in the council over the con troversial idea.

title: ClubThrowing Golfer Wins Pollution Award
description: A clubthrowing golfer was given a pollution award this week and warned not to further a danger to fish and lake vegetation.

title: Son for Mrs. Engels
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs, Robert D. Engel of Riv erdale, the Bronx, on May 19 in the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. Mrs. Engel is the former Miss Barbara Ruth Flink, daughter of Mrs. Paul David Flink of Asbury Park, N, J., and the late Mr. Flink. The child, whose father is an art director with Young & Rubicam, Inc., advertising agency here, is named Mat thew David.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  In a littlenoticed moment in the British House of Commons last Monday, Prime Minister Heath, reporting on his talks in Paris with President Pom pidou, said the two men had agreed on the need to nego tiate suitable arrangements for four small European coun tries as part of the package deal that would admit Brit ain into the European Com mon Market.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: During the last few years I have engaged in sometimes lively correspondence with readers who are opposed to hunting.

title: Crisis in the Church
description: A decade after Pope John XXIII summoned the bishops of the Catholic Church to Rome for Vatican Council II, the shock waves of change still shake this ancient insti tution. Aggiornamentothe Church's sweeping away cobwebbed practiceshas proved no easy task. From simplifying the liturgy and reexamining old customs, the Church has moved on to reargue fundamental issues, tome of which have not been seriously debated since the postReformation Council of Trent in 1563.

title: Seton Hall Nine Tops Sf. Joseph's, 41, to Win N. C. A. A. District Title
description: PRINCETON, N. J., May 29 Seton Hall scored three un earned runs in the fourth inning and another unearned run in the fifth to defeat St. Joseph's, 41, today and win the Nation al Collegiate Athletic Associa tion District Two baseball playoffs.

title: David Thorne Fiance of Rose Geer
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 29Miss Rose O'Neil Geer and David Hoadley Thorne plan to be married in late June.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Powerboat Choices Rule Waves
description: World championship ocean powerboat racers and unlimited hydroplane experts seem to work all year as well as be tween races concocting new designs, subtle changes in bal ance and more ways to increase power. But when the last spray of a regatta disappears, the familiar faces and the familiar boats remain on top.

title: Twyla Tharp Company Dances At Sunrise in Fort Tryon Park
description: For the statistically minded, the hardcore modern dance au dience in New York numbered about 70 souls as of 5:32 A.M. Friday. The location was Fort Tryon Park at sunrise and the occasion was Twyla Tharp and Company's first performance of the day that marked the sea son's close of the enterprising American Dance Marathon sponsored by the New York City Center.

title: JETS SIGN RIGGINS, NO. 1 DRAFT CHOICE
description: The New York Jets an nounced yesterday the signing of their No. 1 draft choice, the Kansas running back, John Riggins. The 237pounder was the first running back selected in last January's National Football League.

title: British Shrimping Dwindles, Puzzling Fishermen and Biologists
description: LYTHAM, England, May 23 The shrimps are barely run ning on Britain's northwest coast.

title: Child for the Fisches
description: A daughter was born on May 17 to Mr. and Mrs. Jo seph Fisch in the LyingIn Hospital. The child, whose father is chief counsel of the New York State Commission of Investigation, has been named Beth Rachel.

title: Al Unser Triumphs In Indianapolis 500; 250,000 Watch Race
description: Al Unser of Albuquerque, N. M., won the Indianapolis 500, America's richest auto race, yesterday for the sec ond straight year.

title: Freeport May Act on BlockBusting
description: FREEPORT, L. I., May 29 The Village of Freeport is con sidering adopting local ordi nances that would provide strict penalties against real estate men who engage in blockbusting.

title: Kathleen McMurray Is a Fiancee
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 29  Dr. Joseph P. Mc Murray, president of the Col lege of New Rochelle, and Mrs. McMurray have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen McMurray, to Jeffrey P. Nelson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Nelson of Elmira.

title: Nicklaus Practices at Merion And Says He Can Play Course
description: A few days ago Jack Nick laus paid his first visit to Merion in more than a decade and had Pennsylvania golf fans buzzing again.

title: Giants Down Expos With 6Run 6th, 83
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 Bobby Bonds's threerun home run and a tworun clout by Willie McCovey sparked a six run, sixthinning rally today as the San Francisco Giants scored an 83 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: PAKISTANIS' TIES WITH U.S. SOURING
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 29  The troubles that have shaken Pakistan recently are being compounded by a general souring of lifegiving economic and diplomatic relations with the United States.

title: Law
description: NEW HAVENFor six months Bobby G. Seale had been on trial for his life, Now, last Tuesday, the day after the jury had an nounced it was hung and the judge had declared a mistrial, the chairman of the Black Pan ther party was back in court. He was waiting to hear what Judge Harold M. Mulvey had to say about the next step in the Alex Beckley murder case.

title: Dr. D. H. Brown Weds Anne Kalff
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., May 29 Miss Anne Wilmpje Kalff and Dr. David H. Brown were married at noon today in the Unitarian Church of Plain field by the Rev. Raymond Baughan.

title: CHIEFS TOP TORNADO IN LEAGUE SOCCER, 41
description: ATLANTA, May 29 (AP)  Nick Papadakis tallied two un assisted goals tonight to lead the Atlanta Chiefs to a 41 tri umph over the Dallas Tornado in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Jazz Musicians to Aid Disturbed Children in Nassau
description: ROOSEVELT, L.I., May 29 Arvell Shaw, the huge, jovial man who was the bassist with Louis Armstrong's AllStars for almost 20 years, is putting his music to work a week from tomorrow for a cause that led him to leave Mr. Armstrong's group six years ago and settle in this Nassau community.

title: 3 WHO QUIT KLAN TELL OF DISSENT
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 29 Bitter dissension is wracking the eastern Pennsylvania klav ern of the United Klans of America.

title: WARHEAD FOR ABM TERMED OBSOLETE
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Atomic Energy Commission is spending $190million to test fire an antimissile warhead that it contends is vital for national defense but that some scien tists allege is obsolete.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON Memorial Day is supposed to be a time of remembrance for the Americans who died in our nine major wars. They are a growing and tragic company. With 45,145 bat tie deaths in Indochinamore than in any other American war except the Civil War and the two World Wars Americans killed in action since the beginning of the Republic now total 573,060.

title: The New Movies
description: DIRTYMOUTH, a movie about the late comedian Lenny Bruce written and directed by Herbert S. Altman, is a very bad movie that can't quite make up its mind whether Bruce, played by Bernie Travis, was a young Tom Edison, ahead of his time, or the sort of mad doctor who must be pun ished for tampering with the secrets of the uni verse, says Vincent Can by. Dirtymouth talks quite a lot about the come dian's brilliance while dem onstratingin its choice of material and in the per formancethat he wouldn't have made a decent second Pal Joey.

title: YANKS DOWN ANGELS, 61
description: For the first time in nearly three weeks, the New York Yankees succeeded yesterday in scoring as many as three runs in a single inning. Then, to prove it was no fluke, they did it again four innings later and coasted to a 61 victory over the California Angels.

title: Blackmer Heads Company To Promote Auto Racing
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 David L. Blackmer of Indianap olis, who has long been asso ciated with promotional aspects of auto racing, was appointed this week to the presidency of Motorsports PR/Marketing, a newly formed company that serves as a marketing consult ant in the field of auto racing.

title: RESCORING SLATED ON '71 MERIT TESTS
description: CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) The answer sheets of all high school students who took the 1971 National Merit Scholar ship Qualifying Test will be re scored because of technical difficulties, Science Research Associates reported this week.

title: GIBBS AMONG FOUR SIGNING WITH NETS
description: With Dick Gibbs of the Uni versity of Texas at El Paso heading the group, four more college draft selections have been signed by the New York Nets.

title: Ulster Customs Unit Blasted
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, May 29 (AP)A British customs station was blown up today at Killea on the border with Ireland three miles from Londonderry. The office was closed at the time.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONHe has been around all the time, of course, campaigning occasionally for candidates he admires (usually rank outsiders), writing an oc casional piece for some journal or other, or surfacing as a teacher of poetry at the University of Maryland.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Chicago Plan to Put Minorities In Building Jobs Seems Doomed
description: CHICAGO, May 29The Chi cago Plan for Equal Opportu nity, which was started a year and half ago with the goal of bringing 4,000 Negroes and Spanishspeaking Americans in to skilled construction jobs in the Chicago area, is on the brink of failure.

title: Murtaugh in Good Condition, To Rejoin Pirates June 6
description: PITTSBURGH, May 29 (UPI) Danny Murtaugh, the man ager of the Pittsburgh Pirates who has been hospitalized since May 20, was give a clean bill of health today. He will rejoin the club June 6.

title: Miss Christine Aukstikalnis Engaged to Peter Trimingham
description: AUBURN, Mass., May 29 Miss Christine Aukstikalnis, a stewardess with Northeast Airlines, plans to be married here Aug. 15 to Peter Darrell Trimingham, passenger ser vice manager with Northeast in Bermuda, where his father is vice president and director of Trimingham Brothers, Ltd., the Hamilton department store.

title: U. of Texas Gets Grant
description: The University of Texas has received a threeyear, $1.6 million grant from the National Science Foundation for its sci ence development program. The grant, made public last week by Dr. Peter T. Flawn, interim vice president for academic af fairs, will be used to continue the fouryearold, interdiscipli nary program that has brought numerous scholars to the uni versity and has brought many departments together to work on large projects.

title: Davis to Coach Lafayette
description: EASTON, Pa., May 29 (UPI) Thomas R. Davis, 32 years old, an assistant coach at American University for two years, was named head basketball coach today at Lafayette. He succeeds Hal Wisseli, who earlier this month became head coach at Fordham.

title: Betsy K. Lynch Plans Nuptials
description: NEW HAVEN, May 29 Miss Betsy Kenna Lynch, whose father, the late Theo dore Francis Lynch, was board chairman of the Marlin Firearms Company in North Haven, plans to be married to Ernest David Strom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Strom of Meriden.

title: Miss Rinehart Is Engaged to Wed
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 29  Miss Christine Leftin Rinehart of Montgomery and Robert Wilmot Polatty of Atlanta plan to be married here Aug. 28.

title: Anne Reed Bride Of Paul D. Guthrie
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 29In the Helen Hills Hills Chapel on the campus of Smith College here today, Miss Anne Elizabeth Reed, a graduate student in educa tion at Smith, was married to Paul Donald Guthrie, who is studying for a doctorate in astronomy at the University of Massachusetts. The cere mony, written by the couple, was performed by the Rev. Jeffrey Campbell of the Uni tarianUniversalist Church of Amherst.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. Companies in Bolivia Uneasy
description: LA PAZ, BoliviaThe rad ical left is pushing Bolivia's nationalistic Government to ward virtual elimination of all United States private in vestment in this country, which is rich in resources and poor in capital.

title: Jo Hornblower Marries Alix Tower
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., May 29 Miss Alexandra Cheston Tower, who received a B.A. degree in English from Stan ford University in March, was married here this afternoon to Jonathan Marshall Horn blower, a veteran of service with the Army in Vietnam.

title: VIOLONOR VICTOR BY NOSE ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 29 (UPI)  Frenchbred Violonor, driving on the outside, got up to score by a nose today for his first United States stakes victory in the $54,850 Argonaut Stakes for 3yearolds at Holly wood Park.

title: what's New in Theater?
description: THE HOMECOMING, a re vival of Harold Pinter's play, got three favorable and three mixed reviews. One critic turned it down. Speaking in praise of it, Mel Gussow said: It opened with an excellent cast, so in tune with the play that it almost makes one forget the memorable Royal Shakespeare produc tion. On the surface, The Homecoming might be con sidered a domestic comedy, but it is like no other have seen. The dialogue is often contradictory  and very funny. This is a re markable work in an ad mirable production. Much of the credit must go to the director, Jerry Adler, who, like his actors, has proper respect for Pinter's humor, atmosphere, lan guage, pauses and reso nances. For Walter Kerr, see Page 9.

title: Cyanamid Broadens Base
description: The American Cyanamid Company can be expected to make sulphuric acid or syn thetic fertilizer for a long time to come, but the role of staple chemicals in the company's product mix is bound to decline further.

title: PRESIDENT URGES CADETS TO UPHOLD MILITARY'S HONOR
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 29 President Nixon urged the 3,700 cadets at the United States Military Academy today to preserve a high sense of honor in their profession de spite mounting assaults on mili tary traditions from within the ranks and without.

title: Kerr on The Basic Training of Hummel
description: ALTHOUGH one's first supposition is that The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel is going to be another outburst against the Vietnam war, and though David Rabe's play at the Public does waste a con siderable amount of time go ing through the familiar mo tions of barking commands at clogtrotting trainees, the evening is actually something else. It is a play about the selfassertion of an agreeable cipher:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONEleven years ago it was the missile gap, and before that there was the bomb er gap. Two years ago there was the firststrike threat of large Soviet SS9 missiles. And now there is the big hole threat.

title: Jim Turnesa to Have His Day Next Month
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 29 (AP)Jim Turnesa, 58yearold former Proles slonai Golfers' Association champion and one of seven famous golfing brothers, will he honored June 11 at the Briar Hall Country Club.

title: the traveler's world
description: NIAGARA IAGARA FALLS, N.Y.  Of the hundreds of young men and wo men who were graduated here yesterday by Niagara University, 50 received bachelor of science degrees awarded for completing their work in the University's Institute of Transpor tation, Travel and Tourism. They con stituted the second class to be graduat ed by the institute and when they marched out of the ceremonies, 48 of the 50 had jobs in private industry and as R.O.T.C. transportation officers in the Army. Many had two job offers to choose between.

title: Nancy A. Harrington Is Betrothed
description: DENVER, May 29Mr. and Mrs. Martin Harrington have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Nancy Anne Harrington, to Charles S. Rutter, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexandre Rutter of Cedarhurst, L. I. A Sept. 11 wedding is planned.

title: U.S. AGAIN DELAYS MINE UNION TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Justice Department has agreed to postpone until Sept. 13 ac tion on its suit seeking to void the reelection in 1969 of W. A. Boyle as president of the Unit ed Mine Workers.

title: Gallup Poll Reports a Plurality Favors Entry of Peking in U.N.
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 The Gallup Poll reported today that for the first time since it began taking surveys on the is sue, more Americans favored admission of Communist China to the United Nations than op posed it.

title: Criminals At Large
description: There have been a few rum bles about this column's at titude toward style in mystery fiction. The idea seems to be that it is unfair to attack writ ers for clumsy prose or inept plotting in what is, after all, primarily escape reading. It is true that nobody expects Tol stoy or Melville in a book about cops or spies. But does that mean the amenities of the English language should be dis carded? That characterization should be ignored? That plots should be thrown together like the letters in a sackful of Scrab ble tiles? A writer (any writer) has minimum obligations. If they are not met, the public should be warned.

title: PACE COLLEGE CITES THREE TOP ATHLETES
description: Peter Rezzonico of Union iCty, N. J., Brian Finnerty of Short Hills. N. J., and Robert Fenster of Forest Hills, Queens, hay won Pace College's top athletic awards.

title: Whitewash
description: To the Editor: In his review of Harold Weis berg's FrameUp, John Kap lan quotes the author on tangential subject . . . the treat ment of Weisberg's previous book (Whitewash) in The Washington Post:

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONThose who advo care a negotiated settlement of the war in Indochina instead of a unilat eral American withdrawal from a continuing war fought with American support for Saigon, are bound by the logic of their views to oppose the reelection of President Thieu next October. His fourno policy (no coalition, no neutralism, no Commu nist party and no land concessions to the Communists) precludes any hope of negotiation.

title: Jobless Aerospace Aides To Get Political Training
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)The Government has announced that it will recruit 400 unemployed aerospace scientists and engineers from 10 communities to be re trained for jobs as adminis trators in state, county and city government.

title: Coast Slaying Toll Rises to 23; Suspect Plans a Not Guilty Plea
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., May 29 (UPI)Deputies recovered the 22d and 23d bodies today in the Yuba City murders.

title: Reader's Report
description: There have been manytoo many novels in which the pro tagonist tries to find himself: here is one in which he tries to lose himself.

title: Mailbox: N.Y. U.'s Official View
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: Shades of The Cradle Will Rock, Winterset and other morality plays of the 1930's! Almost 40 years after the N.R.A., Davis Grubb recaptures a dash of the idealistic fervor of working class literature.

title: Minorities for Annapolis
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The White House has re ported that the 1970 board of visitors to the Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., has recom mended a greater effort to re cruit midshipmen from among racial minorities.

title: McMillan: Let Ashe Play
description: PARIS, May 29 (Reuters)  South Africa will eventually have to pocket its pride and let the black American tennis play er, Arthur Ashe, into the coun try, Frew McMillan of South Africa said today.

title: Department of Agriculture Denies Beef Contamination
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (Reuters)The Department of Argiculture, has denied that beef containing residues of a cancer  inducing hormone is reaching American consumers.

title: Frances Williams Is Wed to Student
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 29 Miss Frances Ann Williams, who was graduated last Sun day from Windham College in Putney, Vt., was married this noon to William E. Holm berg, who will receive his bachelor's degree this sum mer from the University of Denver. The Rev. Charles Harrah performed the cere mony at the Brookville Re formed Church.

title: Law
description: Conspiracy. The word con jures up images of treachery, dark basements, secret pass words, plots of violence.

title: 5 FROM ST. JOHN'S ON ALLSTAR TEAM
description: Although St. John's compiled a 2451 overall wonlosttied record, it did not win the Metropolitan Conference base ball title this year. However, the Redinen did place five men on the league's 14man allstar team named by the coaches.

title: Fined for Carving Names
description: GALLUP, N. M., May 29 (AP) A Federal magistrate, Peter McDevitt, assessed 30day jail sentences this week to two Mas sachusetts student teachers at nearby Ramah High School after the two women pleaded guilty to having carved their names on Inscription Rock at El Morro National Monument. He suspended the jail sentences on payment of $100 fines each. The women were identified as Martha Trusz, 21 years old, and Judith Scribner, 20.

title: These dresses are for wearing
description: One of the hardest things to find lately has been a wearable dress. (Gypsies and American Indians have had an easy time of it, we admit, but it's been tough other women.) Well, things may be looking up. We've discovered some delightfully ungimmicky summer dresses in carefree fabrics that are easy to wear and strictly contemporary. If your taste runs to shirtdresses or cheerfully patterned knits, you're set for summer. Just add sandals and a bracelet or two.

title: U.S. Acts to Bar the Import of Treasures Plundered From Mayan and Other Sites
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The United States is moving to bar the importation of archeological and architectural treasures particularly those of the Mayan civilization  now being stolen in increasing quantities from Mexico, Central and South America and the Caribbean Islands.

title: Yale Nine Selects Negro As Captain for First Time
description: Earl Thomas, an outfielder from Los Angeles, has been elected captain of the 1972 Yale baseball team. Thomas, a junior, is the first black to cap tain the Eli baseball squad. He succeeds the second baseman, Joe Massey, whose teamlead ing .345 batting average helped Yale to a 1417, wonlost rec ord this season.

title: Queensboro Kennel Club Adds An Outdoor Show
description: News of Dogs

title: New Campus Planned For Nassau College
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 29Each weekday more than 15,040 students crowd into the old wooden barracks at Mitchel Field where during past wars Air Force men ate and slept. The students park their cars on the asphalt run ways where pilots once taxied their airplanes.

title: Renaissance Man'71 Style
description: Lord Shaftesbury has winged it back to England, but he'll be back in October. And anybody who didn't see him this time will have another chance then.

title: WORLD SKI GROUP TOUGHENS RULES
description: OPATIJA, Yugoslavia, May 29  The Federation Interna tionale de Ski (F.I.S.) toughened its rules on eligibility and com mercialism at its 28th Congress, which ended today, but it stopped well short of the de mands by Avery Brundage, the 83yearold president of the In ternational Olympic Committee.

title: Say Shore Sail Put Off
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., May 29 High southerly winds up to 40 knots resulted in the postpone ment of today's scheduled opening of the Memorial Day weekend invitation regatta of the Bay Shore Yacht Club. There will be a double sail to morrow.

title: Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, 82, Of Federal District Court, Dies

title: Photography
description: THE Polaroid Corpora tion has introduced a new line of Color Pack Cameras which use a unique flash system that automatically regulates the amount of light put out ac cording to the distance the subject is from the camera when the picture is taken. Designed to operate within a range of from 3 to 10 feet, these new model cameras (labeled the 400 series) take a special flashgun that has a series of movable louvers or shutters in front of the flash cube. As the camera is fo cused, these shutters are automatically opened or closed so that part of the light emitted when the cube is fired will be cut off. Thus, at close distances the louvers are almost fully closed (less light is needed), while at greater distances the louvers are almost all the way open (more light is needed). This opening and closing is com pletely controlled by the dis tance the camera is focused on, so bright subjects or nearby walls and windows will have no effect on the exposure.

He thought his programs should give a pike to a significant contemporary work, Hans Werner Henze's El Cimarron, and he has scheduled it for performance on July 16. Based on the story of an escaped slave during an 1898 Cuban revolution, it will be given in English. The language is said to be less than refined, and Sweeley wonders whether it will offend the gentle matrons of Westchester County who are among his steady customers.

title: Film Festival Alive and Well?

Among the questions fielded by Mar tin Segal, the small, ener getic investment banker who is also the president of the Lincoln Center Film Society, was ome from a reporter who wanted to know if this year's festival would continue to show what he described, in effect, as depressing, down beat, esoteric movies.

title: For Young Readers
description: When President de Gaulle with acerbity called the Jewish people dominateur he meant domineering. But the word also means dominant, something quite different. And were this people not so, it's a safe guess they wouldn't be around any more. The Holocaust, which catalyzed the formation of the State of Israel, was whatever Hell is; but the activity of eliminating Jews, systematically or otherwise, had been around a long time. Golda Meir, who was born in Kiev and grew up in Pinsk, still sees before her the Cossacks' horses rearing above children in flight. She remembers planks frantically nailed over doors and windowspathetic safety measures against a pogrom or Jewkilling expedition. She sees her father's anguish as he announces that for a set of chairs beautifully wrought he was a firstrate carpenterhe received nothing, being a Jew. And, most of all, she hears the question, Why? Why? She and millions of Jews since time was have asked.

description: For the first time since 1951, the United States, citing lack of funds, is making no official plans to participate in Brazil's upcoming sao Paulo Bienal, the international art exhibition sec ond only in prestige to the Venice Biennale.

title: Bridge: Jersey City Pair Sets Pace In Eastern Regionals Here
description: Matthew and Zachary Granovetter of Jersey City led a field of 580 pairs into the final session of the Gold man Open Pairs in the East ern Regionals being played at the New York Hilton Ho tel yesterday.

title: Miss Shendell Is Bride Here

The ecumenical ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Kline and the Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien, head master of the Fordham Pre paratory School and a Roman Catholic priest.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 (AP) Al Unser increased his lead to 1,200 points over A. J. Foyt Jr. in the United States Auto Club Championship trial stand ing by winning the 500mile race yesterday at the Indiana polis Motor Speedway.

title: After the Prague Congress
description: The display of servility to the Soviet Union at last week's Czechoslovak Communist Party Congress illus trates the abasement of the present leadership in Prague. The dominant theme was one of gratitude to Leonid I. Brezhnev for putting the nation in chains again.

title: Nuns' Prayer Movement Attracts Laity
description: Growing numbers of Roman Catholic and nonCatholic lay men, seeking respite from the pace of daily living, are parti cipating in a prayer movement started for nuns.

title: 69 on Hijacked Plane Reported Still in Cuba
description: MIAMI, May 30 (AP)A Pan American Airways jet liner hijacked to Cuba yester day with 69 persons aboard was still in Havana tonight.

title: MEROLA IS DEFIANT ON COMMUTER TAX
description: The City Council's finance hairman warned yesterday that the City Council was not likely to increase the income tax on city residents unless it was al lowed to raise the tax on com muters.

title: Indonesia Reviews Concessions And Tax Breaks for Foreigners
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 23 The Indonesian Government has begun to reassess its pol icies toward foreign investors after four years of luring them into the country with enticing agreements, tax breaks, and lucrative concessions. The time has come, say some Govern ment officials and economic ad visers, for Indonesia to get better deal.

title: 3 U.S. Stars 71 Choices In British Amateur Golf
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, May 30 (AP)Steve Melnyk, Tim Simons and Lanny Wadkins, American Walker Cup players, were grouped as 71 favorites for the British Amateur cham pionship starting over Carnous tie's 130yearold links tomor row.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, May 30One of the most original thinkers in Britain is a so ciologist named Michael Young. So ciologist is really too dusty a word: Dr. Young is a provoker of new social ideas and organizations. He started the consumer movement in Britain. His idea for education by television has flowered in the Open University. His book, The Rise of the Meritocracy, showed in Utopian satire how those who rise to power on merit may be as intolerant and stifling as the old aristocracy.

title: DE BEERS WIDENS ANGOLA GENT HOED
description: LISBON, May 30De Beers of South Africa has consoli dated its hold over diamond rights in Portugal's wealthy west African territory of An gola with the recent expiration of the contract of the Angola Diamond Company.

title: DENNIS J. CAREY SR.
description: Dennis J. Carey Sr., who with his wife, the late Margaret Col lins Carey, founded the Peerless Oil Company (later the Petro chemicals Company), died yes terday in New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 195 Adams Street, Brooklyn.

title: House Member Says Nixon In '68 Vowed a Fast Peace
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  Representative Donald W. Riegle Jr., Republican of Michi gan said today that he was told by Richard M. Nixon in the Presidential campaign of 1968 that if the Republicans won we will end this war in six months.

title: The Critics Have Lost Their Cool
description: ROXBURY, Conn. Any assertion that our war in Indochina is based on killing civilians is, I believe, com pletely and demonstrably untrue, If this charge of attempted genocide had been accurate, surely the populations of both North and South Vietnam would have been decimated by now. Instead, there has been an actual esti mated increase of about 2,000,000 people in South Vietnam since 1965, and of estimated hundreds of thou sands in North Vietnam.

title: Ky Confirms Plan to Seek South Vietnam Presidency
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 (Reuters)Vice Presi dent Nguyen Cao Ky confirmed at an impromptu news confer ence today that he was a can didate for President in the Oct. 3 election but told newsmen to wait a few clays for further details about his plans.

title: Suspect Described
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., May 30 (AP)Juan Vallejo Corona was a familiar figure in the can tinas and skid row bars of Marysville and Yuba City, a muscular, businesslike man scouting for farm workers.

title: COSMOS, LANCERS FINISH IN A 22 TIE
description: ROCHESTER, May 30The New York Cosmos remained Division of the North American Soccer League today as they played a 22 tie with the secondplace Rochester Lancers before 5,343 fans at Aquanis in first place in the Northern Stadium.

title: Indy Racers Busy Picking Up Pieces
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 30  Outside one of the garages of Gasoline Alley at Indianapolis Motor Speedway today, was slate signboard with the chalked notice; Big SaleUsed Race Cars and Parts Very Cheap. Later in the afternoon a me chanic corrected used to abused.

title: Screen: 'The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus'
description: If you recall last year's Off Broadway "Chicago 70," which was put on by the Toronto Workshop Company at the Martinique Theater here, you're hereby apprised that the 16mm. color film version on view at the Film Forum through next weekend is essentially the same improvisational dramatization. It includes excerpts of the 1969-70 trial of the "Chicago 8" with infusions of "Alice in Wonderland," juvenile classroom recitations and pseudo-radio broadcasts. The film version, labeled "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," is decidedly true to its title as "circus," "conspiracy" and justifiable polemics, but it is rarely moving as movie drama.Basically, a moviegoer is affected by what he sees and even if the truth, like the politics of our time, is both tragic and comic, it has to be strongly visualized as well as declared on screen. There is a great speaking of minds from the actual record in "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus" but, unfortunately, there is not a great deal to stir the hearts or the eyes of the uninitiate.As noted, the polemics as well as the confusion of a baffled Judge Julius J. Hoffman facing the taunts and life-style (and the psychedelic dress) of the disparate likes of Abbie Hoffman, Bobby Seale, Allen Ginsberg (reciting some of his explicitly sexual poems) and Country Joe McDonald singing his anti-Vietnam rock, are forceful and to the point.One is also Impressed that maintaining law and order before defendants and attorneys who are trying to stress that the court is not their idea of law and order any more than is Mayor Richard J. Daly's rule of Chicago strikes effective notes for both the Establishment and a younger generation divorced from it.Kerry Feltham, the director, who has employed practically the same cast that George Luscombe used in the play, has drawn forthright declamations from all of them, both black and white. And, it must be noted that, while it is sometimes confusing, different actors are sometimes switched to play the same role, such as Judge Hoffman's, and do prove their versatility.The cast, to name a few such as Mel Dixon, Jim Lawrence, Peter Faulkner, Neil Walsh and Diane Grant and not to slight the others, are Yippie, hippie and serious enough to project authentic dedication to their art and dialogue. But like the documentary "Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family," seen here last month and also dealing with the trial, "The Great Chicago Conspiracy Circus," which was photographed on sets with a mirror background, is generally as static as a photographed play.What the Toronto Workshop Company has to say is obviously ingenious theater even if it is political and perhaps partisan. But it is, sadly enough, good rhetoric that does not add up to an exciting or innovative film.

title: Larsen and Ulhmann Adjourn
description: CANARY ISLANDS, May 30 (AP)Grandmasters Bent Lar sen of Denmark, and Wolfgang Ulhmann of East Germany ad journed on the 43d move to night in the ninth game of their quarterfinal elimination match to determine a challenger for the world chess champion. The game will be resumed tomor row. Larsen leads with 4 points to 3 for Ullmann.

description: ADENAU, Germany, May 30 (AP) Porsche clinched the world manufactdrers' title for the third straight year today, by sweeping the first three places in the 600mile sports car race on the 14.2mile Nuerburgring circuit.

title: MRS. COURT UPSET IN FRENCH TENNIS
description: PARIS, May 30 (AP)Mrs. Gail Chanfreau of France ruined Mrs. Margaret Court's bid for a second consecutive tennis Australian, slam when she upset the Australian, 63. 64 today in the third round of the French open championships.

description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) An international match be tween the Washington Darts of the North American Soccer League and Lanerossi Vincenza of Italy was postponed today because of rain. It was resched uled for tomorrow afternoon.

title: Kumar Goshal, Journalist, Dies; Writer on Africa and Asia, 71
description: SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., May 30Kumar Goshal, author, journalist and lecturer on Asian and African affairs, died here yesterday at his home, 35 Split Rock Road. He was 71 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A year ago, during a rally on the Berkeley campus protesting the invasion of Cambodia, a student looked up to see Cal athletes in their varsity letter jackets rise and begin moving toward the exits. Well, I guess it's time for practice, he said. What's wrong with these guys? Doesn't anything affect them? But the athletes, many them bearded and beaded, were deeply affected: In fact, they were leaving for their own rally to discuss what action they, as a group, could take against the administra tion's war program.

title: The Student as Hardhat
description: In January 1966 I left college, frus trated with education (or the lack of it) and went out into the world became a construction worker in Man hattan and met a unique brand of peopleproud, hardworking and dedi cated to the proposition that their children would not sweat as they had. They were tough, yet understanding; brutal, yet sensitive. We worked hard together and slowly our mutual re spect grew. After a stint in the U.S. Army, I returned to college.

title: Norton Simon, Jennifer Jones Marry on Yacht

Most of the crowd left voluntarily, but the police said that they had forcibly evicted 200 persons after an injunction yesterday ordered the area vacated.

One remembers the father in his highcollared cloak and elaborate headpiece, along with the beast  elegantly shaggy in green fur mittens and mask; but scarcely any movement leaves a trace on the memory.Richard Kuch's piece was given its premiere perform ance Saturday evening at the theater of Riverside Church in the current joint series presented by the Sophie Mas low and Gaku dance compa nies.

The company began cautious testing of the generator, which went out of service last July 21, on Saturday in the hope it might begin producing eiectricity later this week.

title: Hung Jury
description: Judge Harold M. Mulvey faced a dilemma of extraordi nary legal and human complexity when the jury delib erating the murderkidnapping charges against Black Panther Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins failed to reach a verdict, The high emotions whipped up by the case in New Haven clearly made a retrial a difficult and distasteful prospect. Selection of the jury had taken more than four months; without a change in venue and per haps some lapse in time, to assemble a new one may well have seemed a superhuman task.

title: Paris: Screen Seizes on Inbreeding
description: PARISWhat is "in" in French films? The answer is: inbreeding, especially that very essence of inbreeding: incest. It occurs in at least three recent French productions: "Bof," "Les Maris de l'An Deux" and "Le Souffle au Coeur." The last two have been leaders at the box office for weeks, while the first was rewarded with a "Succs D'Estime," a phrase that might be freely translated as: financial failure.Arts AbroadLouis Mail's "Le Souffle au Coeur"a French expression designating a slight heart condition that adolescents sometimes experience passinglydescribes the sentimental education of a teenager in a middle-class provincial milieu in the fifties, when France was still embroiled in her Indochina war. Adults whom only the magic word "career" can extract from their apathy, homosexual Jesuit educators, equivocal boy-scout friendships, youngsters playing practical jokes or losing their virginity in brothelsin short Mr. Mall has conjured up a dinosaur one had thought long since extinct: The Grande Bourgeoisie.The result is that the nature of the subject has contaminated the work: the film is well made, polite, unimaginative, studded with society jokes, dry as an insect and quite boring. Perhaps, it was to jolt the spectator out of his tedium that Mr. Mall introduced incest. It is committed by the mother, a "foreigner" with Bohemian inclinations, and her yet unspoiled son. The scene is brief, and it is immediately erasedfrom incest to palimpsestby a scene of "normal" love-making and a hearty family laugh; still, it ought to have alarmed the French censors, and their intervention ought to have made the movie into a scandal, that is, into a success.Unfortunately, they saw nothing wrong. Indeed, "Le Souffle au Coeur" was selected to represent France at the Cannes Festival. And so the indispensable uproar would never have occurred, had it not been for the help of that dowdiest of institutions, French television.Michel Pollac invited Mr. Mall, Alberto Moravia and Professor Grass to discuss incest on his weekly literary television program, "Post-Scriptum," one of the few lively shows currently on the TV screen. Mr. Pollac's great discovery had been that while books are always dull, writers can be hilariously funny, when assembled in herds. In fact, he had at last come upon a satisfactory substitute for the wrestling matches on which television networks throughout the world have been relying for years. The show's deficiencies were themselves a reflection of today's cultural scene: It was numerically dominated by representatives of the New Left, who tend to be as stereotyped in their reactions as Mr. Mall's bourgeoisie. Whenever an independent opinion was voiced, its utterer was hooted down and showered with sarcasms.Something less foreseeable happened: the management of French television, in the name of morality and of the good French public, took a series of measures that eventually amounted to suppressing "Post-Scriptum" (thereby indirectly but efficiently launching "Le Souffle au Coeur"mention of which was forbidden on the airon the road to popular success). This ill-inspired, dangerous decisionthe act of censorship is always more harmful than that which is censoredis in line with the inexorable evolution of French television, once the most creative in the world, toward conformism, an evolution inherent in the systematic, deliberate shift of all responsibilities and powers from creators to civil servants."Les Maris de L'An Deux" ("The Spouses of Year Two of the French Revolution"), another official entry of France at Cannes, did not need the odor of scandal to become a hit.It had Jean-Paul Belmondo. "Les Maris" is a tongue-in-cheek, cloak-and-dagger movie, aimed at family audiences, a genre at which the French are curiously adept and of which "Fanfan La Tulipe," starring the late Grard Philippe, is the classic. Fights, escapes, pursuits against a background of amiable Terrorthe episodes flit by so quickly and so weightlessly that the incestuous love of a brother and a sister passes almost unnoticed. But then, we see them no more closely together than riding on the same horse, and there are so many surprising events to take in, not the least of which is the reconstruction, for budgetary reasons, of 18th-century Nantes in 1970 Rumania.It is difficult to imagine a amusing, tender and amoral film than "Bof," an exclamation meaning somthing like: "So What?," used to express one's smiling indifference to everything from lateness at an appointment to the collapse of values in the Western world.The film illustrates this new paganism. It begins, deceptively enough, at a portrayal of working-class life. A young man become a delivery boy, lugging crate upon crate up steep backstairs. He marries a salesgirl, his mother dies, his father, jobless comes to live with him . . . We begin to realize that the film's maker, Claude Faraldo, has something else in mind than social realism when the father asks his son to let him sleep with his wife, "only from time to time, of course." This poses no problem. In fact, nothing does.As every student of surrealism knows, fantasy is effective only when embedded in a context of credibility. Mr. Faraldo intelligently lends both verisimilitude and humor to his anarchist's daydream by putting it in sharply observed proletarian existence and by deriving the most preposterous mischief from the exquisitely drawn affection between father and son. "I live off you, I sleep with your wife, I've killed your mother.""Bof" went almost unnoticed: the censors had neglected to object. If this trend toward increasing liberalism on the part of the Censorship Commission (appointed by the Ministry of Culture) continues, it will soon become necessary to convince the public that talent is the worst of all obscenities.

title: Bronx Detective Elated Over Winning White House Fellowship
description: Detective Sgt. Terence D. McCann pointed his ruler at the chart on the wall of the Benedict Avenue station. It showed the number of rob beries committed in the 41st Precinct of the Bronx.

title: Padres' Kirby Tops Mets, 42;
description: SAN DIEGO, May 30Ivan Murrell of the San Diego Pa dres, who has been experiment ing with a hollowedout Japa nese bat, switched back to his madeinAmerica model today and hit a tworun home run that defeated the New York Mets, 42.

title: TURKS ENCIRCLED AFTER SEIZING GIRL
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Monday, May 31Two youths, believed to be members of a guerrilla group that kidnapped and killed the Israeli Consul General, seized the 19yearold daughter of a Turkish Army major yes terday and held her hostage in her home.

title: ANDREW STEWART, ACCOUNTANT, DIES
description: DUMONT, N. J., May 30 Andrew Stewart, a retired part ner in the international public accounting firm of Haskins & Sells, died yesterday of an ap parent heart attack at his home, 32 East Quackenbush Road. He was 83 years old.

title: Fortin's Thunderbird, a Cal40, Triumphs in Block Island Race
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 30 Roger T. Fortin's Thunderbird, a modified Cal40 sloop out of American Yacht Club of Rye, N. Y., was declared the overall winner on corrected time today in the 26th annual Block Island race of the Storm Trysail Club.

title: The Outer City: There Is 14 To Firm Stereotype
description: This is the second of five articles based on a twoweek trip by five correspondents of The New York Times through metropolitan areas, exploring the growth, com plexities and attitudes of suburban America.

title: CITY RENT CHIEF TO HELP TENANTS BAR HARASSMENT
description: Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, said yes terday that he was forming citywide tenants' group to act against any landlord harass ment after the new vacancy de control law went into effect July 1.

description: News Analysis

title: A.A.U. Denies Curbing Athletes
description: Top American track and field athletes will be under no pressure to compete in the PanAmerican Games or in ternational events sponsored by the Amateur Athletic Union this summer, Robert Giegengack said yesterday.

title: African Christian Sects Grow Rapidly
description: Every Sunday morning bathers and picnickers at the Bar Beach on Victoria Island off Lagos, Nigeria, find they must wend their way through numerous clusters of white robed figures facing out to sea.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

title: Audie Murphy, War HeroActor, Missing With 4 on Plane Flight
description: ATLANTA, May 30 (AP)An airplane carrying Audie Mur phy, the movie actor who was the most decorated American soldier of World War II, and four other men has been missing since Friday on a flight from Atlanta to Martinsville, Va., the Federal Aviation Ad ministration said today.

title: City Health Level Found Far From Satisfactory
description: The health of all classes of people here is much worse than it should be, given the advanced state of the medical arts, the richness of the city's medical establishment in men, institutions and pro grams, and the wealth of the city as a whole.

title: Hardin Gets Relieved Of His Belongings
description: What you see, said Jim Hardin, the newest Yankee, pointing to a virtually empty locker, is what I got.

title: 400 FINED $5 EACH IN ANTIWAR MARCH
description: LEXINGTON, Mass., May 30 (UPI)About 100 Vietnam vet erans and more than 300 sym pathetic townsfolk were fined $5 each today for having violated curfew regulations during a peace demonstration and campout on historic Lex ington Green.

title: NIXON SETS PARLEY WITH POLICE CHIEFS
description: THURMONT, Md., May 30 (UPI)The White House said today that President Nixon would meet with representa tives of the nation's police chiefs and sheriffs this week to discuss the Federal role in preventing attacks on police men.

description: A compromise solution ap proved by the community school board of District 20 in Brooklyn has not only brought to an end a boycott of Public School 179, but also has won the board the ap plause of the boycotting par ents' commitee.
