description: PHILADELPHIA, May 30 Miss Mary Cross Lueders, a mezzosoprano with the New York City Opera, was mar ried here this afternoon to Frank Andrew Corsaro, a New York stage and opera director.

title: John Reilly, Board Chairman Of Todd Shipyards, Dies at 82
description: John D. Reilly, chairman of the board of Todd Shipyard Corporation, who directed its vast shipbuilding, repair and conversion program in World War II, died yesterday at the Valley Nursing Home, West wood, N. J. He was 82 years old and lived at 69 Abbey Place. Yonkers.

title: Mays Tops Record For Runs Scored, Surpassing Musial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (UPI)  Willie Mays's tworun homer in the seventh inning powered the San Francisco Giants to a 54 victory over the Montreal Expos today in the first game of a doubleheader and made Mays the National League's runscoring champion with 1,950. He had been tied with Stan Musial of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: DENMARK PRESSES INFLATION BATTLE
description: COPENHAGEN, May 23 Denmark, chronically plagued by one of the worst inflation records in Europe, is trying to trim sonic fat off the welfare state to contain Government spending.

title: Music: Festival at Bath
description: BATH, England, May 30 Sir Michael Tippett, the di rector of the Bath Festival, is one of Britain's most re spected composers, but con temporary music is not much in evidence during the 10 day festival, and that is how the audience wants it, The Bath Festival got under way on Friday night with a Mo zart program, and the over whelming percentage of the music that will be heard con sists of wellloved master pieces. But there also are a few unusual program ideas, one of which could be ad mired last night, That was when Opera Rara held forth at the Guildhall.

title: TV Networks Move to Upgrade MuchCriticized Children's Fare
description: Commercial and public tele vision networks are preparing ambitious new plans for their children's programs, which have been under frontal attack by civic and parental groups as never before.

title: Funeral for Slain Girl Is Held in Mississippi
description: DREW, Miss., May 30 (UPI)  Seven hundred persons, in cluding the white officials of Drew, jammed into an audi torium today for the funeral of Jo Etha Collier, an 18year old black girl who was killed by shots from a passing car last Tuesday.

title: Repair of Brooklyn Church Spire Is Goal of FundRaising Events
description: The 150foot coppersheeted steeple atop St. Paul's Roman Cathelic Church, a landmark in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn since 1836, will be the focus of a series of events in the next two weeks to raise funds for its renovation.

title: Bronx Patrolman Is Robbed Of $1,300 Cash on Street
description: Three men, one armed with a knife, held up an offduty patrolman, Joseph Perez, in the Bronx early yesterday morning and robbed him of $1,300 in cash and his service revolver, the police said.

title: OFFICER ACCUSES A NARCOTICS UNIT
description: A New York police sergeant yesterday accused the police unit responsible for arresting major heroin dealers with fail ing to move against a large drug operation in East Harlem after being given specific telligence about its activities.

title: RAYMOND S. BAXTER Sr.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., May 30 Raymond S. Baxter Sr., re tired president of the Aguirre Corporation, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 228 Mill Spring Road.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Springwick Park Wins
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 30 Springwicl< Park, a thorough bred chestnut gelding, owned and ridden by David Edwards of Marleton, scored 16 points on two blues and two second place finishes to win the ama teurowner hunter champion ship today at the Short Hills Farm horse show.

title: Area Schoolboy Stars Top U.S. Quintet in Exhibition
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 30 The New YorkNew Jersey AllStars, led by Mel Utley of Far Rockaway High School, beat the United States AllStar Quintet, 80.79, in overtime to day at Kutsher's Country Club.

title: Lowell Ames Norris, Writer of Many Crime Stories, Dies
description: NORTH PEMBROKE, Mass., May 30 (AP)Lowell Ames Norris, who wrote or edited some 3,000 crime stories in a 40year career with Macfadden Publications in New York, died at his home here Friday.

title: Lord Goddard Is Dead at 94; A Former Lord Chief Justice
description: LONDON, May 30  Lord Goddard, Lord Chief Justice of England from 1946 to 1958, died at his home here last night. He was 94 years old.

title: CHINA'S ICBM TEST SAD TO E CLOSER
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  China, whose longrange mis sile program has lagged behind American predictions, appears on the verge of two important breakthroughs, in the view of some analysts here.

title: Lefkowitz Submits an Objection To Proposed Con Ed Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, May 30Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to day opposed a recommendation made to the Public Service Commission that Consolidated Edison be given a temporary increase in its electricity rates of $52,192,000 a year.

title: CHOW CHOW BEST IN JERSEY SHOW
description: METUCHEN, N. J., May 30 In weather better suited for perhaps water spaniels, Ch. Eastward Liontamer of Elster, a chow chow in superb coat, was named best in show at the Plainfield Kennel Club's fixture early this evening.

title: The Message From Four Corners
description: Since the Southwest and California are booming eco nomically, their need for electric energy is rising sharply. Since the region has run out of acceptable sites for hydroelectric dams, it is imperative to find alternative sources of energy.

title: MITCHELL DETAILS VOTING LAW PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Attorney General John N. Mitchell has given the details of a plan for enforcing the section of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that is designed to block discriminatory elec tion law changes in the South.

title: J. P. Norelli Marries Deborah Korenblatt
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 30Miss Deborah Jane Korenblatt was married here this afternoon to Joseph P. Norelli at the Colony Beach Club.

title: A HouseBuilt From 2 SilosThat Would Be Unusual Anywhere
description: WATER MILL, L. I.Even out here where summer homes are frequently as bi zarre as a converted wind mill or lighthouse, where the architecturally unconven tional is quite conventional, people are startled by the vacation house that Paul Mil vy built from two silos.

title: Argentina Plans to Widen Door to Foreign Investors
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 30 The Argentine military Govern ment, in a bold and calculated gamble, is about to reverse its shrill policy of economic na fonalism and open the door wider to foreign investors.

title: RANGEL PROTESTS PLAN FOR ADDICTS
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel denounced yesterday the recommendation of the Mayor's Narcotics Control Council that the city provide heroin to ad dicts in a rehabilitation experi ment, saying the proposal was a cruel hoax and a vicious conspiracy.

title: WARREN W. FRAIM
description: Warren W. Fraim, retired merchandising manager of Mc Call's Pattern Company and a director and past president of the Flatbush Church League of the Young Men's Christian As sociation, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack while taking a friend to Kennedy In ternational Airport. He was 67 years old and lived at 1836 New York Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Helen Jacqueline Robin Is Married
description: At Temple Israel here yes terday, Miss Helen Jac queline Robin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Robin of Washington and Madrid, became the bride of Jeffrey Marshall Clyman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Clyman of New York and Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the cere mony.

title: MAYOR E. D. BERGIN OF WATERBURY, 59
description: WATERBURY, Conn., May 30Mayor Edward D. Bergin, who was serving his fourth, nonconsecutive terms as the chief executive of this indus trial city, died today, apparent ly of a, heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Young Computer Industry Finds Adult Woes
description: The computer industry is still reeling through the first reces sion of its young, but action packed and growthfilled, life.

title: For Her Dinner Guests, Never a Dj Vu Feeling
description: COVENTRY, Conn.  Mrs. Bruce Stave says she likes cooking so much that she spends six hours a day at it, frequently experimenting and innovating, so that she serves her family at least three to four new dishes every week. And she never serves a guest the same dish twice.

title: Chess: Swiss Tournament Systern Has Its Good Points and Bad
description: Most chess tournaments in this country are run on the Swiss system, designed to enable many players to take part in a single event held over a short period of time.

title: Airport Parking Attendants Accept New 3Year Contract
description: A strike threatened for to morrow by parking lot attend ants at Kennedy International Airport was avoided yesterday when 125 members of Local 917 of the teamsters union accepted a new threeyear contract with Kinney National Service Inc.

title: Kent State Composer Threads Tragedy Into Opera
description: Halim ElDabh, a com poserinresidence at Kent State University, was walk ing toward a noon class on that nowfamous campus one day a little more than a year ago. Suddenly, from a park ing lot about 200 feet away he heard shots. He saw stu dents running. One rushed past him screaming, Every body's falling dead.

title: THE RUSSIAN CHURCH MEETS TO HOLD VOTE
description: MOSCOW, May 30A Spe cial Council of the Russian Or thodox Church today pledged the church's loyalty to the So vict regime as it began a four day meeting to elect a new Patriarch for the church's fol lowers, estimated at 40 million.

title: Books of The Times
description: HERE COMES EVERYBODY, By William C. Schutz, 295 pages, Harper and Row. $6.95.

title: Aeolus Y.R.A. Victor
description: RYE, N. Y., May 30Robert Shattuck; whose Etchells22 sloop was being repaired after a collision last weekend, took the helm of Dr. Paul Gooding's Aeolus today and won the class race at the fourth regatta of the Yacht Racing Association cham pionalip season on Long Island Sound.

title: Big Perfecta in Vermont Pays a Bettor $43,887
description: POWNAL, Vt., May 30 (AP) An unidentified bettor won a record total of $43,887 with a $2 wager on the Big Per fecta today at Green Moun tain Park.

title: The Court and Single Human Souls
description: PITTSBURGHWhen a man is draft ed to fight in a war he believes is wrong, there are two damaging results. The first is that the state repeals the right of individual conscience in a crit ical moral matter, the life and death of other men. The second is that by usurping the place of conscience, the state forfeits its best safeguard against its own propensity to err.

title: Help in the Twilight Years
description: There is a darker side to the medical advances that have brought increased longevity to so many Americans. In this city, for example, there are tens of thousands of older citizens whose twilight years are bleak because of poverty, physical disability, lack of mobility and similar factors. The demand for more adequate provision for the needs of the aged rises steadily as their numbers and difficulties growespecially in this period of inflation.

title: Telegraphers Call a Strike At Western Union Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The United Telegraph Work ers will go out on strike at mid night tomorrow, a union leader said today after talks with the Western Union Company broke down.

title: Ferrari Finishes 9th
description: Porsches also finished sixth, seventh, eight and 10th, with a Ferrari ninth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Races Listed Today in East
description: Two bigmoney races at Belmont and Garden State, one with a wideopen field and the other with a heavy favorite, will spice today's racing program for those in the metropolitan area who decide to pass up the beaches and parades.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Stewart, Retired Editor Of Christian Herald, 62, Dead
description: LIGHTHOUSE POINT, Fla., May 30Ford Stewart, who re tired three years ago as editor and publisher of The Christian Herald, died here today of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Swedes Take Athens Rally
description: ATHENS, May 30 (AP)Ove Andersson and Arne Hertz of Sweden won the 19th Interna tional Acropolis motor rally today after four days of rally ing and racing throughout Greece. They won in an Alpine Renault A110.

title: Allisons Finish 1, 2
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 30 (AP)Bobby Allison outgunned his brother, Donnie Allison, in a battle of Mercurys today to win the $200,000 world 600 race at a track record 140.442 miles an hour. The former mark of 135.832 m.p.h. was set by Jim Paschal, in a Plymouth, in 1967.

title: Shultz Quietly Builds Up Power in Domestic Field
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 George P. Shultz is an illusion ist.

title: Reform. Democrats' Clubhouse In Brooklyn Damaged by Bomb
description: A bomb explosion early yes terday morning damaged the storefront of the Independent Neighborhood Democrats, a nine  month  old party reform club working in South Brook lyn.

title: NonEvents Unmark WashedOut Holiday
description: Without a gleam of sun shine to brighten it, yester day was a day made up of great many things that did not happen.

title: ISRAELI SUCCESSES LINKED TO A CADRE
description: TEL AVIV, May 27Israel's military preeminence in the Middle East rests largely upon about 45,000 professionals officers, noncommissioned of ficers and enlisted menin the army, navy and air force.

title: Brogan Joins Club's Board
description: Thomas J. Brogan, former chairman of the New Jersey Racing Commission, has been elected to the board of directors of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club.

title: Personal Finance
description: Late tomorrow afternoon the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will tell the world how much a share its new convertible preferred stock will be worth and howmuch it will pay in dividends and what will be the conver sion price into common shares. If the offering to its more than 3million shareholders is suc cessful  and there is little doubt it will bethe world's largest corporate enterprise can expect to raise some $1,375,000,000 to help satisfy its neverending appetite for dollars.

title: RUSSIANS LEARN OF SST PROBLEMS
description: MOSCOW, May 30  Now that the supersonic airliner TU144 has been exposed to Western inspection at the Paris Air Show, the controlled Soviet press is slowly coming to grips with problems of supersonic flight long passed over in si lence.

title: Russia's Mr. Aviation
description: Man in the News

title: Souphanouvong Visits Hanoi
description: TOKYO, May 30 (AP)Prince Souphanouvong of Laos, leader of the Communist. Pathet Lao, paid an unpublicized visit to North Vietnam last week with a delegation of Laotian offi cials, including military leaders, the Hanoi Radio reported today.

title: Memorial Day
description: Banks, stock exchanges, public and parochial schools, post offices and most depart ment and retail stores and library branches are closed. There is no regular refuse collection, and Sunday park ing rules are in effect.

title: TREVINO IS VICTOR BY 4 SHOTS ON 268
description: MEMPHIS, May 30 (AP) Lee Trevino shot a final 67 for a 72hole total of 268 and an easy fourstroke vic tory in the $175,000 Danny Thomas Memphis golf tourna ment today.

title: AARON J. EZICKSON
description: Aaron J. Ezickson, of 1072 East 14th Street, Brooklyn, retired editor of the Wide World Photos department of The Associated Press, died yes terday of a coronary occlusion. He was 75 years old.

title: Resort Plan Sparks Montana Controversy
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.Big Sky could be the greatest thing that ever happened to Montana, said the wife of the general storekeeper in the loamdeep Gallatin Valley. Or, she added, it could be something else.

title: In Cologne, Popular Library on Jews
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, May 24In the early postwar years the Cologne bookdealer Karl Keller was besieged by scores of students from the nearby university who demand ed books about and by Ger man Jews.
